entry.meaning: alpha, the first letter of the Greek alphabet. As a numeral, ά = 1, α = 1000. As a prefix, it appears to have at least two and perhaps three distinct senses: ἀ- (before a vowel, ἀν-) negative, as in ἄ-γνωστος, ἄ-δικος. ἀ-, ἁ- copulative, indicating community and fellowship, as in ἁ-πλοῦς, ἀ-κολουθέω, ἀ-δελφός. An intensive force (LS, s. α), as in ἀ-τενίζω is sometimes assumed (but v. Boisacq, s.v.).
in NT, Abaddon, the angel of the Abyss: Re 9:11.†
without weight; metaph. (MM, VGT, s.v.) not burdensome: II Co 11:9.†
used in the phrase Ἀ. ὁ παήρ, Abba, Father (v. Swete on Mk, I.c.): Mk 14:36, Ro 8:15, Ga 4:6.†
Abilene, a district in the Anti-Lebanon: Lk 3:1.†
Abia, Abijah. Son of Rehoboam (III Ki 14:1): Mt 1:7. A priest of the line of Eleazar (I Ch 24:3, 10): Lk 1:5. †
Abiathar (I Ki 21:1): Mk 2:26.†
Abiud, Abihud: Mt 1:13.†
Abraham (Ge 17:5 al.): Mt 1:1, 2 al.

in cl., boundless, bottomless (e.g. ἄ. πέλαγος, ἄ. πλοῦτος Æsch.). [In LXX (for תְּהוֹם, Ge 1:2, al.; exc. Is 44:27, Jb 41:22 for צוּלָה, מְצוּלָה, Jb 36:16 for רַחַב) and] NT, as subst. (MM, VGT, s.v.), ἡ ἄ. (sc. χώρα), the abyss; of the sea (Ge 1:2); of the underworld, as the abode of the dead: Ro 10:7 (a paraphrase of De 30:13 LXX); as the abode of demons, Lk 8:31, Re 9:1, 2, 11, 11:7, 17:8, 20:1, 3 (Cremer, 2). †
to do good, show kindness: 1 Ti 6:18 (Cremer, 8).†
to do good; univ.: I Pe 2:15, 20, 3:6, 17, III Jo 11; for another's benefit: Mk 3:4 (T, ἀγαθὸν ποιῆσαι), Lk 6:9; acc. pers., Lk 6:33, 35 (Cremer, 8). †
well-doing: I Pe 4:19.†
doing well, acting rightly (Plut.): I Pe 2:14 (Cremer, 8; MM, VGT, s.v.).†

in general, good, in physical and in moral sense, used of persons, things, acts, conditions, etc., applied to that which is regarded as "perfect in its kind, so as to produce pleasure and satisfaction, . . . that which, in itself good, is also at once for the good and the advantage of him who comes in contact with it" (Cremer, 3): γῆ, Lk 8:8; δένδρον, Mt 7:18; καρδία, Lk 8:15; δόσις, Ja 1:17; μέρις, Lk 10:42; ἔργον (freq. in Pl.), Phl 1:6; ἐλπίς, II Th 2:16; θησαυρός, Mt 12:35; μνεία, I Th 3:6 (cf. II Mac 7:20); as subst., τὸ ἀ, that which is morally good, beneficial, acceptable to God, Ro 12:2; ἐργάζεσθαι τὸ ἀ, Ro 2:10, Eph 4:28; πράσσειν, Ro 9:11, II Co 5:10; διώκειν, I Th 5:15; μιμεῖσθαι, III Jo 11; κολλᾶσθαι τῷ ἀ, Ro 12:9; ερωτᾶν περὶ τοῦ ἀ., Mt 19:17; διάκονος εἰς τὸ ἀ., Ro 13:4; τὸ ἀ. σου, thy favour, benefit, Phm 14; pl., τὰ ἀ., of goods, possessions, Lk 12:18; of spiritual benefits, Ro 10:15, He 9:11, 10:1. ἀ is opp. to πονηρός, Mt 5:45, 20:5; κακός, Ro 7:19; φαῦλος, Ro 9:11, II Co 5:10 (cf. MM, VGT, s.v.).
to do good: Ac 14:17.†
goodness (representing "the kindlier, as δικαιοσύνη, the sterner element in the ideal character," AE, Eph., 5:9; on its relation to χρηστότης, v. Tr., Syn., §lxiii): Ro 15:14, Ga 5:22, II Th 1:11.†
exultation, exuberant joy: Lk 1:44, Ac 2:46, He 1:9, Ju 24; χαρὰ καὶ ἀ., Lk 1:14 (Cremer, 592).†

to exult, rejoice greatly: seq. ἐπί, c. dat., Lk 1:47; c. dat. mod., I Pe 1:8, Re 19:7. Mid., with same sense: Mt 5:12, Lk 10:21, Ac 2:26, 16:34, I Pe 4:13; seq. ἵνα, Jo 8:56; ἐν, Jo 5:35 (1 aor. pass. perh. as mid.; but v. Mozley, Psalter, 5), I Pe 1:6 (Cremer, 590).†
unmarried: I Co 7:8, 32; fem. (= cl. ἄνανδρος), ib. 11, 34.†
to be indignant: Mt 21:15, 26:8, Mk 10:14, 14:4; seq. περί, Mt 20:24, Mk 10:41; seq. ὅτι, Lk 13:14 (v. MM, VGT, s.v.).†
indignation: II Co 7:11 (v. MM, VGT, s.v.).†

to love, to feel and exhibit esteem and goodwill to a person, to prize and delight in a thing. Of human affection, to men: τ. πλησίον, Mt 5:43; τ. ἐχθρούς, ib. 44; to Christ, Jo 8:42; to God, Mt 22:37; c. acc. rei, Lk 11:43, Jo 12:43, Eph 5:25, II Tim 4:8, 10, He 1:9, I Pe 2:17, 3:10, II Pe 2:15, I Jo 2:15, Re 12:11. Of divine love; God's love: to men, Ro 8:37; to Christ, Jo 3:35; Christ's love: to men, Mk 10:21; to God, Jo 14:31; c. cogn. acc., Jo 17:26, Eph 2:4.

love, goodwill, esteem. Outside of bibl. and eccl. books, there is no clear instance (with Deiss., LAE, 18:4, 70:2, cf. the same writer in Constr. Quar., ii, 4; and with MM, VGT, s.v., cf. Dr. Moulton in Exp. Times, xxvi, 3, 139). In NT, like ἀγαπάω, -ῶ, Of men's love: to one another, Jo 13:35; to God, I Jo 2:5. Of divine love; God's love: to men, Ro 5:8; to Christ, Jo 17:26; Christ's love to men: Ro 8:35. In pl., love feasts: Ju 12 (DB, iii, 157).

beloved (v. M, Pr., 221); by God: of Christ, Mt 3:17; of men, Ro 1:7; by Christians, of one another: I Co 4:14; freq. as form of address, ib. 10:14; opp. to ἐχθρός, Ro 11:28 (v. AR, Eph., 229; Cremer, 17; MM, VGT, s.v.).
to impress into public service, employ a courier; hence, to compel to perform a service (prob. common in the vernac.; cf. Deiss., BS, 86f., MM, Exp., iv; VGT, s.v.): Mt 5:41, 27:32, Mk 15:21.†
a vessel (v. MM, VGT, s.v.): Mt 25:4.†
a message: I Jo 1:5, 3:11 (Cremer, 18; MM, VGT, s.v.).†
to announce, report: Jo 4:51 (WHR omit), 20:18 (MM, VGT, s.v.).†

a messenger, one sent: Mt 11:10, Ja 22:25. As in LXX, in the special sense of angel, a spiritual, heavenly being, attendant upon God and employed as his messenger to men, to make known his purposes, as Lk 1:11, or to execute them, as Mt 4:6. The ἄ. in Re 1:20-2:1, al., is variously understood as a messenger or delegate, a bishop or ruler, a guardian angel, the prevailing spirit of each church, i.e. the Church itself. (Cf. Swete, Ap)., in l.; DB, iv, 991; Thayer, s.v.; Cremer, 18; MM, VGT, s.v.)
a vessel: Mt 13:48.†
come! used as adv. and addressed, like φέρε, to one or more persons: Ja 4:13, 5:1.†
without genealogy, i.e. without recorded pedigree (cf. Ne 7:64): He 7:3 (Cremer, 152; MM, VGT, s.v.).†
unborn (Plat.); of no family, ignoble, base (opp. to ἀγαθός, Soph., Fr., 105): opp. to εὐγενής, I Co 1:28 (for exx. from π., v. MM, VGT, s.v.). †

to make holy, consecrate, sanctify; [in LXX chiefly for קדשׁ pi., hi. ;] to dedicate, separate, set apart for God; of things: Mt 23:17,19, II Ti 2:21; of persons: Christ, Jo 10:36, 17:19. to purify, make conformable in character to such dedication: forensically, to free from guilt, I Co 6:11, Eph 5:26, He 2:11, 10:10, 14, 29, 13:12; internally, by actual sanctification of life, Jo 17:17, 19, Ac 20:32, 26:18, Ro 15:16, I Co 1:2, 7:14, I Th 5:23, Re 22:11; of a nonbeliever influenced by marriage with a Christian, I Co 7:14. In the intermediate sense of ceremonial or levitical purification: of things, II Ti 2:21; of persons, He 9:13. to treat as holy: Mt 6:9, Lk 11:2, I Pe 3:16 (Cremer, 53, 602; MM, VGT, s.v.). †

as an active verbal noun in -μός, it signifies properly the process τὸ ἁγιάζειν, rather than the resultant state, ἁγιωσύνη, hence, consecration; sanctification: so strictly in Ro 6:19,22 (but v. Meyer), I Co 1:30, I Th 4:3,7, II Th 2:13, He 12:14, I Pe 1:2. Elsewhere it perhaps (Ellic.; but v. Milligan, Th., 48) inclines to the resultant state: I Th 4:4, I Ti 2:15 (Cremer, 55, 602). †

primarily, dedicated to the gods, sacred (Hdt.; rare in Att., never in Hom., Hes. and Trag., who use ἁγνός), hence, holy, characteristic of God, separated to God, worthy of veneration. Its highest application is to God himself, in his purity, majesty, and glory: Lk 1:49, Jo 17:11, Re 4:8. Hence of things and places which have a claim to reverence as sacred to God, e.g. the Temple: Mt 24:15, He 9:1; of persons employed by him, as angels: I Th 3:13; prophets, Lk 1:70; apostles, Eph 3:5. Applied to persons as separated to God's service: of Christ, Mk 1:24, Jo 6:69, Ac 4:30; of Christians, Ac 9:13, Ro 1:7, He 6:10, Re 5:8. In the moral sense of sharing God's purity: Mk 6:20, Jo 17:11, Ac 3:14, Re 3:7. Of pure, clean sacrifices and offerings: I Co 7:14, Eph 1:4.
sanctity, holiness, regarded, properly, as an abstract quality (v. next word, and cf. Lft. Notes, 49; MM, VGT, s.v.): II Co 1:12, He 12:10.†
holiness, the state in man resulting from ἁγιασμός, q.v.: Ro 1:4, II Co 7:1, I Th 3:13 (Cremer, 52; MM, VGT, s.v.).†
the bent arm: Lk 2:28 (cf. ἐναγκαλίζομαι).†
a fish-hook: Mt 17:27.†
an anchor: Ac 27:29, 30 40 ; fig. (MM, VGT, s.v.), He 6:19.†
uncarded, undressed, i.e. new (MM, VGT, s.v.): Mt 92:6, Mk 2:21.†
purity: I Ti 4:12, 5:2 (Cremer, 58. For exx. of ceremonial use in π., v. MM, Exp., iv).†
to purify, cleanse from defilement; ceremonially: Jo 11:55, Ac 21:24, 26 24:18; morally: Ja 4:8, I Pe 1:22, I Jo 3:3. †
purification: in ceremonial sense, Ac 21:26 (LXX).†

to be ignorant, not to know: absol., Ι Ti 1:13, He 5:2; c. acc., Ac 13:27 17:23, Ro 10:3, II Co 2:11; ἐν οἷς, II Pe 2:12; seq. ὅτι, Ro 2:4 6:3 7:1, I Co 14:38; οὐ θέλω ὑμᾶς ἀγνοεῖν, a Pauline phrase: c. acc., Ro 11:25; seq. ὑπέρ, II Co 1:8; περί, I Co 12:1, I Th 4:13. ὅτι, Ro 1:13, I Co 10:1 (for similar usage in π., V. MM, VGT, s.v.). Pass.: I Co 14:38, II Co 6:9, Ga 1:22. not to understand: c. acc., Mk 9:32, Lk 9:45. †
a sin of ignorance (so in π.; v. MM, VGT, s.v.): He 9:7.†
ignorance : Ac 3:17 17:30, Eph 4:18 (with sense of wilful blindness; cf. MM, VGT, s.v.), I Pe 1:14.†

free from ceremonial defilement , in a condition prepared for worship (for exx. of pagan usage, V. MM, VGT, s.v.). holy, sacred, venerable (II Mac, l.c.). As in OT (cl.), pure, chaste, undefiled, guiltless; of persons: II Co 7:11 11:12, I Ti 5:22, Tit 2:5, I Jo 3:3; of things: Phl 4:8, Ja 3:17, I Pe 3:2. †
purity, chastity (cf. ἁγιότης): II Co 6:6 11:3.†
purely, with pure motives: Phl 1:17.†
ignorance (opp. to γνῶσις): I Co 15:34, I Pe 2:15 (v. Hort in l.; MM, VGT, s.v.).†
unknown: Ac 17:23 (cf. MM, VGT, s.v.).†

an assembly (Hom., Xen., al.). a place of assembly, a public place or forum, a market-place (Hom., Thuc, al.; LXX): Mt 11:16 20:2 23:7, Mk 6:56 (cf . MM, VGT, s.v., ἀγυιά) 7:4 (Bl., §46, 7) 12:38, Lk 7:32 (Bl., l.c.) 11:43 20:46, Ac 16:19 17:7 (Cremer, 59; MM, VGT, s.v.). †

to frequent the ἀγορά (Hdt., al.). to buy in the market, purchase (Xen., al.; LXX; in π. very common in deeds of sale, v. MM, VGT, s.v.): absol., Mt 21:12, Mk 11:15; c. acc. rei, Mt 13:44, 46, al.; seq. παρά, c. gen. pers., Re 3:18 (LXX, Polyb.); ἐκ, Mt 27:7; c. gen. pret., Mk 6:37, al.; metaph., I Co 6:20 7:23, II Pe 2:1, Re 5:9 14:3, 4.

frequenting the ἀγορά , a lounger in the ἀγορά (Xen., al.): Ac 17:5. In late writers (Strab., al.), proper to the ἀγορά : ἀγοραῖοι (sc. ἥμεραι) ἀγονται (cf. Lat. conventus agere), court-days are kept, Ac 19:38 (for exx. of both usages, v. MM, VGT, s.v.). †
the chase, a hunting or catching: Lk 5:4. that which is taken, a catch: of fish, Lk 5:9. †
to live in the fields: Lk 2:8.†
to catch or take by hunting or fishing; metaph., Mk 12:13.†
of the wild olive (Anth.). As subst., the wild olive: Ro 11:17, 24 (CGT, in 1.; MM, VGT, s.v.). †
living in fields, wild: μέλι. Mt 3:4, Mk 1:6. savage, fierce: Ju 13. (Cf. usage in π. of a malignant wound; MM, VGT, s.v.) †

a field: Mt 6:28, al. the country: Mk 15:21, al.; pl., country places, farms: Mk 5:14 6:36 56, Lk 8:34 9:12. = χωρίον a piece of ground: Mk 10:29, Ac 4:27, al. (On the occurrence of this word as compared with χώρα, χωρίον v. MM, VGT, s.v.)
to be sleepless, wakeful (Theogn., Xen., al.); metaph. (LXX) = cl. ἐγρήγορα, to be watchful, vigilant: Mk 13:33, Lk 21:36, Eph 6:18, He 13:17.†
sleeplessness, watching: II Co 6:5 11:27. (Plat., Hdt.; for exx. in π., v. MM, VGT, s.v.) †

to lead, bring, carry: c. ace, seq. ἐπί, εἰς, ἕως, πρός and simple dat.; metaph., to lead, guide, impel: Jo 10:16 Ro 2:4, He 2:10, II Ti 3:6, al. to spend or keep a day: Lk 24:21, Ac 19:38 Intrans., to go: subjunc., ἄγωμεν, Mt 2:46, al. (Cramer, 61; MM, VGT, s.v.).
a carrying away. a leading, guiding; metaph., training; hence, from the expression ἀ. τοῦ βίου, absol., conduct, way of life: II Ti 3:10 (Cremer, 61; MM, VGT, s.v.). †

a gathering, esp. for games. a place of assembly. a contest, struggle, trial; metaph. (MM, VGT, s.v.), of the Christian life as a contest and struggle: Phl 1:30, I Th 2:2, I Ti 6:12, II Ti 4:7 He 12:1; solicitude, anxiety: Col 2:1. †
a contest, wrestling (Eur., Xen.). Of the mind, great fear, agony, anguish (Dem., Arist.): Lk 22:44 (cf . Field, Notes, 77 f. ; Abbott, Essays, 101 f. ; MM, VGT, s.v.). †
to contend for a prize: I Co 9:25, to fight, struggle, strive: Jo 18:36; metaph. (MM, VGT, s.v.). Col 1:29 4:12, I Ti 4:10 6:12, II Ti 4:7; c. inf. (Field, Notes, 66), Lk 13:24 (Cremer, 609) †
Adam: Lk 3:38, Ro 5:14, I Co 15:22,45, I Ti 2:13,14 Ju 14. Christ ὁ ἔσχατος Ἀ., I Co 15:45.†
without expense, free of charge: I Co 9:18.†
Addei: Lk 3:28.†
a sister: Mt 19:29, al.; metaph. (MM, VGT, s.v.), of a member of the Christian community: Ro 16:1, I Co 7:15 Ja 21:15, al.

in cl., a brother, born of the same parent or parents. [In LXX (Hort, Ja., 102f.), for אָח ;] lit. of a brother (Ge 4:2, al.). Of a neighbour (Le 19:17). Of a member of the same nation (Ex 2:14, De 15:3). In NT in each of these senses (1. Mt 1:2, al.; 2. Mt 7:3; 3. Ro 9:3) and also, of a fellow-Christian: I Co 1:1, Ac 9:30. This usage finds illustration in π., where ἀ. is used of members of a pagan religious community (M, Th., I, 1:4; MM, VGT, s.v.). The ἀδελφοὶ τ. Κυρίου (Mt 12:46-49 13:55 28:10, Mk 3:31-34, Lk 8:19-21, Jo 2:12 7:3, 5 10 20:17, Ac 1:14, I Co 9:5) may have been sons of Joseph and Mary (Mayor, Ja., Intr. viff.; DB, i, 320ff.) or of Joseph by a former marriage (Lft., Gal., 252ff.; DCG, i, 232ff.), but the view of Jerome, which makes ἀ. equivalent to ἀνεψιός, is inconsistent with Greek usage. (Cremer, 66.)
abstract, brotherhood, brotherly affection (LXX). Concrete, the brotherhood, the Christian community: I Pe 2:17 5:9 (MM, VGT, s.v.). †
unseen, unobserved, not manifest (Ps, l.c.): Lk 11:44. uncertain, indistinct: I Co 14:8. †
uncertainty: I Ti 6:17.†
adv. uncertainly: of direction, I Co 9:26.†
to be troubled, distressed (MM, l.c.): Mt 26:37, Mk 14:33, Phl 2:26.†

in Hom., Hades (Pluto), the god of the underworld. the abode of Hades, the underivorld; in NT, the abode of departed spirits, Hades: ἐν τ. ᾅ., Lk 16:23; εἰς ᾅ., Ac 2:27,31; πύλαι ᾅδου, Mt 16:18; κλεῖς τοῦ ᾅ., Re 1:18; metaph., ἕως ᾅ., Mt 11:23, Lk 10:15; personified, Re 6:8 20:13,14 (Cremer, 67, 610; MM, VGT, s.v.). †
not to be parted, mixed, undistinguishable (cf. Pr, l.c., and v. Lft., Ignat. Eph., §3). without uncertainty (Hort, in l., but v. MM, VGT, s.v.): Ja 3:17. †
unremitting, incessant: Ro 9:2, II Ti 1:3. (For exx., v. MM, VGT, s.v.) †
unremittingly, incessantly: Ro 1:9, I Th 1:3 2:13 5:17.†

intrans., to be ἄδικος, do wrong, act wickedly or criminally: Ac 25:11, I Co 6:8, II Co 7:12, Col 3:25, Re 22:11; to do hurt, Re 9:19. Trans. to do some wrong: ὃ ἠδίκησεν, Col 3:25; to wrong some one, Mt 20:13, Ac 7:26, 27 25:10, II Co 7:2, Ga 4:12, Phm 18, II Pe 2:13; pass., Ac 7:24, II Co 7:12; mid., I Co 6:7 (suffer . . . to be wronged; WM, §38, 3; but v. Bl., §54, 5; and cf. ἀποστερέω); to injure, hurt: Lk 10:19 Re 2:11 6:6 7:2, 3 9:4,10 11:5. †
a wrong, injury, misdeed (MM, VGT, s.v.): Ac 18:14 24:20, Re 18:5.†

injustice: Lk 18:6, Ro 9:14. unrighteousness, iniquity: Jo 7:18, Ac 8:23, Ro 1:18, 29 2:8 6:13, II Ti 2:19, I Jo 1:9 5:17; opp. to ἀλήθεια, I Co 13:6, II Th 2:12; to δικαιοσύνη ], Ro 3:5; ἀπάτη τῆς ἀ., II Th 2:10; μισθὸς ἀδικίας, Ac 1:18, II Pe 2:13,15; ἐγράται τῆς ἀ., Lk 13:27; μαμωνᾶς τῆς ἀ., Lk 16:9; κόσμος τῆς ἀ., Ja 3:6; οἰκονόμος τῆς ἀ., Lk 16:8. = ἀδίκημα, an unrighteous act: ironically, a favour, II Co 12:13; pl., He 8:12 (Cremer, 261; MM, VGT, s.v.). †
unjust: Ro 3:5, He 6:10. unrighteous, wicked: Lk 16:11 18:11, Ac 24:15, I Co 6:1,9 I Pe 3:18; opp. to δίκαιος, Mt 5:45; to εὐσεβής, II Pe 2:9; to πιστός, Lk 16:10 (Cremer, 200). †
unjustly, undeservedly: I Pe 2:19.†
Admin.: Lk 3:33.†

of things (prop. of metals: LXX, ll. c.), not standing the test, rejected: γῆ, He 6:8. Of persons, rejected after testing, reprobate: Ro 1:28, I Co 9:27, II Co 13:5-7, II Ti 3:8, Tit 1:16 (Cremer, 212). †
guileless (Pind., Thuc). Of liquids (Æsch., Eur., and late prose writers), genuine, pure (in π. and in MGr. of wine, also of corn: MM, VGT, s.v.; Milligan, NTD, 77): of milk, metaph., I Pe 2:2. †
of Adramyttium, a seaport of Mysia: Ac 27:2.†
the Adriatic sea, in later Greek usage extended to take in all the waters between Greece and Italy: Ac 27:27.†
thickness, vigour. abundance, bounty: II Co 8:20. †
Abbott-Smith omits this number to be unable (cl., Philo; π., v. MM, VGT, s.v.). In LXX and NT (Kennedy, Sources, 124; Hatch, Essays, 4; Field, Notes, 46 f.), to be impossible: Mt 17:20, Lk 1:37. †
of persons, unable, powerless: Ac 14:8; fig. Ro 15:1 (MM, VGT, s.v.). Of things, impossible: Mt 19:26, Mk 10:27, Lk 18:27, Ro 8:3, He 6:4,18 10:4 11:6. †
to sing, intrans., c. dat. (MM, VGT, s.v.), of praise to God: Eph 5:19, Col 3:16 ; trans., c. cogn. acc.: ᾠδὴν, Re 5:9 14:3 15:3. †
ever; of continuous time, unceasingly, perpetually: Ac 7:51, 2 Co 4:11 6:10, Tit 1:12, He 3:10. Of successive occurrences, on every occasion (MM, VGT, s.v.): I Pe 3:15, II Pe 1:12. †
an eagle: Re 4:7 8:13 (Rec. ἀγγέλου) 12:14. Where carrion is referred to, ἀ. is probably a vulture (cf. Jb 39:30, Pr 30:17): Mt 24:28, Lk 17:37 (MM, VGT, s.v.).†

unleavened: ἡ ἑορτὴ τῶν ἄ. (הַג הַמָצָּה), the paschal feast (also called τὰ ἄ., Mk 14:1), Lk 22:1; ἡμέρα τῶν ἄ., Mt 26:17, Mk 14:12, Lk 22:7; ἡμέραι, Ac 12:3 20:6. Fig., of Christians, free from corruption: I Co 5:7; exhorted to keep festival, ἐν ἀζύμοις (sc. ἄρτοις, λάγανοις, or, indefinitely, "unleavened elements"), ib. 8 (Cremer, 724).†
Azotus, a Philistine city: Ac 8:40.†
of things or persons, unpleasantness, odiousness (Hipp., Dem., al.); dislike (Plat.), disagreement (MM, VGT, s.v.): Lk 23:12 D. †

in Hom., Hes., the lower air which surrounds the earth, as opp. to the purer αἰθήρ of the higher regions; generally, air (MM, VGT, s.v.): Ac 22:23, I Th 4:17, Re 9:2 16:17; of the air as the realm of demons, Eph 2:2; ἀ. δέρειν, of striving to no purpose, I Co 9:26; εἰς ἀ. λαλεῖν, of speaking without effect, not being understood, I Co 14:9.†
immortality: I Co 15:53,54 I Ti 6:16 (cf. Cremer, 285 f.).†
of persons, lawless (III Mac, l.c.); of things, lawless, unlawful: Ac 10:28, I Pe 4:3.†

in cl. slighting or denyiyig the gods (Plat.; cf. MM, VGT, s.v.); godless, ungodly (Pind.); abandoned by the gods (Soph.) In the NT (cf. Lft. on Ign. ad Trail, §3), of the heathen, without God, not knowing God (Cremer, 281): Eph 2:12. †
lawless, esp. of those who violate the law of nature and conscience (cf. MM, VGT, s.v.): II Pe 2:7 3:17.†

to set aside, disregard (in Gramm., to reject as spurious): διαθήκην , Ga 3:16; ἐντολήν , Mk 7:9; νόμον . He 10:28; πίστιν , I Ti 5:12. to nullify, make void: Lk 7:30 (v. Field, Notes, 59), I Co 1:19, Ga 2:21. to reject: Mk 6:26 (Field, op. cit., 30), Lk 1O:16, Jo 12:48, I Th 48, Ju 8 (for exx. in π., v. MM, VGT, s.v.). †
a disannulling, setting aside: He 7:18 9:26 (for similar usage in π., v. Deiss., BS, 228 f.; MM, VGT, s.v.).†
Athenian: Ac 17:21,22.†
to contend in games, wrestle, combat: II Ti 2:5.†
a contest, combat, esp. of athletes; fig., a struggle: He 10:32 (for exx., v. MM, VGT, s.v.).†
to gather, assemble: Lk 24:33.†
to be disheartened: Col 3:21.†
unpunished (MM, VGT, s.v.). innocent: Mt 27:4 (WH, R, mg., δίκαιον) 27:24.
of a goat: He 11:37 (MM, VGT, s.v.).†
the sea-shore, beach (cf. Field, Notes, 146; DCG, i, 175 f.; MM, VGT, s.v.): Mt 13:2,48 Jo 21:4, Ac 21:5 27:39,40.†
Egypt: Mt 2:13-15,19, Ac 2:10 7:9-39, He 3:16 11:26,27; γῆ Αἴ., Ac 7:40 13:17, He 8:9, Ju 5 (cf. Ex 5:12, al.); ἡ Αἴ., Ac 7:11; fig., of Jerusalem as hostile to God, Re 11:8.†
everlasting (freq. in Inscr.; MM, VGT, s.v.): Ro 1:20, Ju 6.†
a sense of shame, modesty: I Ti 2:9 (for exx., v. MM, VGT, s.v.).†
Ethiopian: Ac 8:27.†

blood. In the ordinary sense: Mk 5:25, Lk 8:43,44 22:44, Jo 19:34, Ac 15:20,29 21:25, Re 8:7,8 11:6 16:3,4,6 19:13. In special senses: of generation, origin, kinship (cl.): Jo 1:13 (v. MM, VGT, s.v.); as in OT (AR on Eph, l.c.), in the phrase σάρξ καὶ αἷ. (αἷ. κ. σ.), to indicate human nature as opp. to God and created spirits: Mt 16:17, I Co 15:50, Ga 1:16, Eph 6:12, He 2:14; of things in colour resembling blood: Ac 2:19,20, Re 6:12 14:18-20. of bloodshed, a bloody death (cl.): Mt 23:30,35 27:4,6,8,24,25, Lk 11:50,51 13:1, Ac 1:19 5:28 18:6 20:26 22:20, He 12:4, Re 6:10 17:6 18:24 19:2 ; αἷ. ἐκχέειν (Deiss., LAE, 428; MM, VGT, s.v., αἷ.), Ro 3:15, Re 16:6; of sacrificial blood, as an expiation: He 9:7,12,13,18-22,25 10:4 11:28 13:11; of the blood of Christ, Mt 26:28, Mk 14:24, Lk 22:20, Jo 6:53,54,56, Ac 20:28, Ro 3:25 5:9, I Co 10:16 11:25,27, Eph 1:7 2:13, Col 1:20, He 9:12,14 10:19,29 12:24 13:20, I Pe 1:2,19, I Jo 1:7 (cf. 5:6,8), Re 1:5 5:9 7:14 12:11. (Cremer, 69 f., 612 f.) †
shedding of blood (Eccl.; Cremer, 71): He 9:22.†
to lose blood, suffer from a flow of blood (Hipp.): Mt 9:20.†
Æneas: Ac 9:33,34.†
praise (Eccl.): θυσία αἰνέσεως (Le 7:12, זֶבַח תּוֹדָה), He 13:15.†
to praise: c. acc, τ. θεόν, Lk 2:13,20 19:37 24:53, Ac 2:47 3:8,9, Ro 15:11; c. dat., τ. Θεῷ (Je 20:13, al. for הִלֵּל לְ; v. Field, Notes, 245), Re 19:5.†
a dark saying, riddle: I Co 13:12 (cf. Nu, l.c.).†
poët, and Ion., = μῦθος, a tale (Horn., al.). = Att. ἔπαινος, praise (Horn., al.): Mt 21:16 (LXX), Lk 18:43. In π., a decree (MM, VGT, s.v.). †
Aenon: Jo 3:23.†

capture. choosing, choice (v. MM, VGT, s.v.). that which is chosen, hence, opinion; esp. a peculiar opinion, heresy: I Co 11:19, Ga 5:20, II Pe 2:1 R, txt. In late writers (MM, VGT), of a set of persons professing particular principles or opinions, a school, sect, party, faction: Ac 5:17 15:5 24:5,14 26:5 28:22, I Co, Ga, II Pe, l.c., R, mg. (Cremer, 614). †
to choose: Mt 12:18 (LXX, ἀντιλήμψομαι).†
capable of choosing (Plat.). causing division, heretical, factious (Cremer, 614): as subst., Tit 3:10. †
to take; Mid., -ομαι (M, Pr., 158 f.; MM, VGT, s.v.), to choose: Phl 1:22, II Th 2:13, He 11:25. (Cf. ἀν-, ἀφ-, δι-, ἐξ-, καθ-, περι-, προ-αιρέω.) †

to raise, take up, lift or draw up: Jo 8:59 11:41, Ac 27:17, al. to bear, carry: Mt 4:6 16:24, al. to bear or take away, carry off, remove: Mt 21:21, Jo 19:31, I Co 5:12 6:15 (v. Lft., Notes, 216), al.; of the taking away sin by Christ, Jo 1:29, I Jo 3:5. (Cf. ἀπ’, ἐξ-, ἐπ-, μετ-, συν-, ὑπερ-αίρω). For exx. from π., v. MM, VGT, s.v.)
to perceive: c.acc. rei (Bl., §36, 5; MM, VGT, s.v.), Lk 9:45 (Cremer, 619 f.).†
perception (MM, VGT, s.v.): Phl 1:9.†
sense, organ of perception: He 5:14 (MM, VGT, s.v.).†
greedy of base gains: I Ti 3:3,8 Abbot-Smith omits I Ti 3:3, Tit 1:7.†
from eagerness for base gain: I Pe 5:2 (here only).†
abusive language, abuse (Lft., ICC, in l.; MM, VGT, s.v.): Col 3:8.†
base, shameful: I Co 11:6 14:35, Eph 5:12, Tit 1:11 (MM, VGT, s.v.).†
baseness: Eph 5:4.†
shame (MM, VGT, s.v.): subjectively, Lk 14:19, II Co 4:2; objectively, Phl 3:19, He 12:2; as something to be ashamed of, Re 3:18; pl. (Bl., §32, 6), shameful deeds, Ju 13.†

to disfigure (Hom.). to dishonour (Pr 29:15). to make ashamed (Si 13:7). Pass., to be put to shame, be ashamed: II Co 10:8; Phl 1:20, I Pe 4:16, I Jo 2:28; c. inf. (M, Pr., 205), Lk 16:3 (cf. ἐπ- (-ομαι), κατ- αἰσχύνω). †

to ask, request: absol., Mt 7:7, Ja 1:6; c. acc. pers., Mt 5:42, Lk 6:30; c. acc. rei, seq. ἀπό, Mt 20:20, I Jo 5:15; id. seq. παρά, Ac 3:2, Ja 1:5; c. dupl. acc. Mt 7:9, Mk 6:22, Jo 16:23. Mid. (on the distinction bet. mid. and act., v. M, Pr., 160): absol., Mk 15:8, Jo 16:26, Ja 4:3; c. acc. rei, Mt 14:7, Mk 6:24, al.; c. acc. pers., Mt 27:20, Lk 23:25; c. acc. rei, seq. παρά, Ac 9:2; c. acc. et inf., Lk 23:23. c. inf. Ac 7:46, Eph 3:13 (cf. ἀπ-, ἐξ-, ἐπ-, παρ-, προσ- αιτέω).
that which has been asked for, a petition, request: Lk 23:24, Phl 4:6, Jo 5:15.†

cause, reason, occasion, case: Mt 19:3, Lk 8:47, Ac 10:21 22:24 28:20, II Ti 1:6,12, Tit 1:13, He 2:11 ; εἰ οὕτως ἐστιν ἡ αἰ. (cf. Lat. si ita res se habet, and v. MM. VGT, s.v.), Mt 19:10. In forensic sense, accusation: Ac 25:18,27; cause for punishment, crime: Mt 27:37, Mk 15:26, Jo 18:38 19:4,6, Ac 13:28 23:28 28:18. †

causative of, responsible for; as subst., ὁ αἰ., the cause, author: He 5:9; τὸ αἰ., the cause, Ac 19:40. blameworthy, culpable; as subst., ὁ αἰ., the culprit, the accused (Lat. reus); τὸ αἰ. (= αἰτία, 3), the crime, Lk 23:4,14,22. †
a charge, accusation: Ac 25:7.†
sudden, unexpected: Lk 21:34, I Th 5:3.†
captivity (Diod., al.): Re 13:10; pl., abstr. for concr., = αἰχμάλωτοι, Eph 4:8 (LXX).†
to lead captive: Eph 4:8 (LXX).†
to take or lead captive: seq. εἰς, Lk 21:24 (cf. To 1:10); metaph., Ro 7:23, II Co 10:5, II Ti 3:6.†
captive: Lk 4:18 (LXX).†

in cl., like Lat. aevum (LS, MM, VGT, s.v.), a space of time, as, a lifetime, generation, period of history, an indefinitely long period; in NT of an indefinitely long period, an age, eternity, usually c. prep. (MM, VGT); of the past: ἀπ’ αἰ. (cf. Heb. מֵעוֹלָם), Lk 1:70; of the future: εἰς τ. αἰ. (cf. לְעוֹלָם), forever, Mt 21:19; id., c. neg., never, Jo 4:14; more strongly, εἰς τὸν αἰ. τοῦ αἰ., He 1:8 (LXX); εἰς τοὺς αἰ., Mt 6:13; εἰς τοὺς αἰ. τῶν αἰ. (cf. Is 45:17, עַד־עוֹלְמֵי עַד), Ro 16:27, LT; cf. also Eph 3:21, II Pe 3:18, Ju 25, Re 14:11. οἱ αἰ., the worlds, the universe, "the sum of the periods of time, including all that is manifested in them": He :12 11:3 (cf. I Ti 1:17, where τῶν αἰ. are prob. "the ages or world-periods which when summed up make eternity". the present age (Heb. הָעוֹלָם הַזֶּה): ὁ αἰ., Mt 13:22; ὁ αἰ. οὗτος, Mt 12:32; ὁ νῦν αἰ., I Ti 6:17; ὁ ἐνεστὼς αἰ., Ga 1:4; similarly, of the time after Christ's second coming (הָעוֹלָם הַבָּא), ὁ αἰ. ἐκεῖνος, Lk 20:35; ὁ αἰ. μέλλων, Mt 12:32; ὁ αἰ. ὁ ἐρχόμενος, Mk 10:30.

age-long, eternal, of that which is without either beginning or end: Ro 16:26, He 9:14; of that which is without beginning: Ro 16:25, II Ti 1:9, Tit 1:2; of that which is without end (MM, VGT, s.v.): σκηναί, Lk 16:9 οἰκία, II Co 5:1; διαθήκη, He 13:20; εὐαγγέλιον, Re 14:6; παράκλησις, II Th 2:16; λύτρωσις, He 9:12; κληρονομία, ib. 15; κόλασις, Mt 25:46; κρίμα, He 6:2; κρίσις, Mk 3:29; ὄλεθρον, II Th 1:9; πῦρ, Mt 18:8; freq. c. ζωή, q.v.
uncleanness, impurity, physical (MM, VGT, s.v.): Mt 23:27; moral: Ro 1:24 6:19, II Co 12:21, Ga 5:19, Eph 4:19 5:3, Col 3:5, I Th 2:3 4:7. †
uncleanness: Re 17:4, Rec. (for τ. ἀκάθαρτα).†

unclean, impure; physically (LS, MM, VGT, s.v.); ceremonially: Ac 10:14,28 11:8, I Co 7:14, II Co 6:17, Re 18:2; morally: Eph 5:5, Re 17:4; c. πνεῦμα, as always in Gosp., Mt 10:1 12:43, Mk 1:23,26,27 3:11,30 5:2,8,13 6:7 7:25 9:25, Lk 4:33,36 6:18 8:29 9:42 11:24, Ac 5:16 8:7, Re 16:13 (cf. Cremer, 320). †
to have no opportunity (opp. to εὐκαιρέω): Phl 4:10.†
out of season, unseasonably: opp. to εὐκαίρως (q.v.), II Ti 4:2 (cf. Cremer, 740; MM, VGT, s.v.).†
as in cl. (Æsch., Plat., al.), of persons, simple, guileless: Ro 16:18, He 7:26 (cf. Cremer, 327); of things, undamaged (? MM, VGT, s.v.). †
a prickly plant, thorn, brier; in NT always pl.: Mt 7:16 13:7,22 27:29, Mk 4:7,18, Lk 6:44 8:7,14, Jo 19:2, He 6:8 (v. MM, VGT, s.v.).†
of thorns: Mk 15:17, Jo 19:5. of acantha-wood (Hdt.; π. ap. MM, VGT, s.v.). †
unfruitful, barren: fig., Mt 13:22, Mk 4:19, I Co 14:14, Eph 5:11, Tit 3:14, II Pe 1:8, Ju 12.†
not open to just rebuke, irreprehensible: Tit 2:8 (v. Cremer, 676; and for other exx., MM, VGT, s.v.).†
uncovered, unveiled: I Co 11:5, 13.†
uncondemned (EV): Ac 16:37, 22:25. = cl. ἄκριτος, without trial, not yet tried (MM, VGT, s.v.) Ac, ll. cc. †
indissoluble: He 7:16.†
that cannot cease, not to be restrained: c. gen. rei, II Pe 2:14, T, Tr. txt.†
instability (MM, VGT, s.v.); hence, confusion, tumult: I Co 14:33, Ja 3:16; pl. (Bl., §32, 6), Lk 21:9, II Co 6:5, 12:20 (Polyb., al.; v. Cremer, 739).†
unsettled, unstable: Ja 1:8, 3:8.†
that cannot be restrained: Ja 3:8 Rec. (for -στατος, q.v.).†
unmixed, pure, hence, metaph. (cf. MM, VGT, s.v.), guileless, simple: Mt 10:16, Ro 16:19, Phl 2:15.†
unbending, firm: metaph. (MM, VGT, s.v.). He 10:23.†
to be at the prime; of produce of the ground, to be ripe (Thuc.): Re 14:18 (MM, VGT, s.v.).†
a point, used as adv., at the present point of time, even now, even yet: Mt 15:16.†

hearing, the sense of hearing: I Co 12:17, II Pe 2:8; "Hebraic dative," ἀκοῇ ακούειν (freq. in LXX; V. M, Pr., 14, 75), Mt 13:14, Ac 28:26. organ of hearing, the ear (Arist., al.; MM, VGT, s.v.): II Ti 4:3-4; pl., Mk 7:35, Lk 7:1, Ac 17:20, He 5:11. a thing heard, i.e., a message, teaching: Jo 12:38 and Ro 16:16,17 (LXX), Ga 3:2,5 R, mg.; λόγος ἀκοῆς, I Th 2:13, He 4:2; a report, rumour: c. gen, pers., Mt 4:24, 14:1, 24:6; Mk 1:28 13:7 (Cremer, 82, 623; MM, VGT, s.v.).†

to accompany, follow: Mt 4:25, al. Metaph., of discipleship: Mt 9:9, Mk 9:38, Jo 12:26, al. Absol.: Mt 18:10; more freq., c. dat. (cl.), Mt 8:1, al.; seq. μετά, c. gen, (cl.; Eutherford, N.Phr., 458 f.), Lk 9:49; ὀπίσω, c. gen. (Heb. הָלַךְ אָהֲרֵי), Mt 10:38 (cf. ἐξ-, ἐπ-, κατ-, παρ-, συν-ἀκολουθέω).

to hear, listen, attend, perceive by hearing, comprehend by hearing. Intrans.: Mk 4:3 7:37, Ja 2:5, Re 2:7, al.; τ. ὠσίν, Mt 13:15 (LXX); c. cogn. dat., ακοῇ ἀ. (v.s. ἀκοή), Mt 13:14, Ac 28:26 (LXX); ὁ ἔχων ὦτα (οὖς) ἀκούειν, ἀκουσάτω, Mt 11:15, Mk 4:23, Re 2:7, al. Trans., prop. c. acc. rei, of thing heard, gen. pers., from whom heard (LS, s.v.): Ac 1:4; c. acc. rei, Mt 12:19, Jo 3:8 (Abbott, JG, 76), Ac 22:9, al.; c. dupl. acc., Jo 12:18, I Co 11:18; c. gen. rei, Jo 7:40 (Abbott, JV, 116); τ. φωνῆς (cf. Heb. שָׁמַע בְּקֹול, Ex 18:19), Jo 5:25, 28 Ac 9:7 (on the distinction bet. this and ἀ. φωνήν, ib. 4, v. M, Pr., 66; Field, Notes, 117; Abbott, Essays, 93f.); of God answering prayer, Jo 9:31, I Jo 5:14, 15; c. acc. rei, seq. παρά, Jo 8:26, 40 Ac 10:22, II Ti 2:2; id. seq. ἀπό, I Jo 1:5; c. gen. pars. seq. ptcp., Mk 14:58, Lk 18:36, al. (On NT usage generally, v. Bl., §36, 5; Cremer, 82.)
in Arist. and later writers = ἀκράτεια (Lft., Notes, 222 f.), want of power, hence want of self-control, incontinence: Mt 23:25, I Co 7:5.†
powerless, impotent; in moral sense, lacking self-control, incontinent: II Ti 3:3.†
unmixed, pure: οἶνος, Re 14:10.†
exactness, precision (for exx., v. MM, VGT, s.v.): Ac 22:3.†
exact, precise, careful, of things and persons: superl., Ac 26:5.†
to enquire with exactness, learn carefully: Mt 2:7, 16 (for similar ex., v. MM, VGT, sv.).†
with exactness, carefully: Mt 2:8, Lk 1:3, Ac 18:25, Eph 5:15, I Th 5:2 (M, Th., in l). Compar., ἀκριβέστερον (Milligan, NTD, 111; MM, VGT, s.v.), Ac 18:26 23:15, 20 24:22.†
a locust: Mt 3:4, Mk 1:6, Re 9:3, 7.†
a place of audience: Ac 25:23 (Plut.).†
the prepuce, foreskin (LXX), hence abstr., uncircumcision: Ac 11:3, Ro 2:25-27 3:30 4:10-12, I Co 7:18-19, Ga 5:6 6:15, Col 2:13 3:11 By meton., the uncircumcised: Ro 4:9, Ga 2:7, Eph 2:11.†
at the extreme angle: ὁ ἀ., the corner foundation stone, Eph 2:20, I Pe 2:6.†
prop., the top of a heap, hence, in pl., first-fruits (Xen.; MM, VGT, s.v.). In war, the choicest spoils (cf. Hdt., viii, 121 f.): He 7:4.†
highest, extreme; as subst., τὸ ἄ., the top, extremity: Mk 13:27, Lk 16:24, He 11:21; pl. (cf. MM, VGT, s.v.), Mt 24:31.†
to revoke, invalidate (MM, VGT, s.v.): Mt 15:6, Mk 7:13, Ga 3:17 (Plut.).†
without hindrance (so freq. in legal documents; MM, VGT, s.v.): Ac 28:31.†
unwilling: I Co 9:17.†
a box of alabaster (ἀλαβαστίτης) for ointment: Mt 26:7, Mk 14:3, Lk 7:37 (v. DCG, i, 41b; MM, VGT, s.v.).†
the character of an ἀλαζών, boastfulness, vainglory, vaunting: Ja 4:16 (Mayor, in l), I Jn 2:16.†
prop, a vagabond, hence, an impostor, a boaster: Ro 1:30, II Ti 3:2.†
prop, to raise a war-cry, shout with triumph or joy; rarely of grief, to wail: Mk 5:38 (cf. Je 4:8); of a cymbal, ἀλαλάζον (RV. clanging), I Co 13:1 (cf. ὀλολύζω).†
inexpressible, not to be uttered: Ro 8:26.†
dumb, speechless: Mk 7:37 9:17, 25.†
salt, lit, and fig.: Mt 5:13, Mk 9:50 Lk 14:34; like cl. ἅλες, wit, of wisdom and grace in speech: Col 4:6.†
a fisherman: Mt 4:18, 19, Mk 1:16, 17, Lk 5:2
to anoint, festally or in homage: c. acc rei or pers., Mt 6:17, Jo 12:3, Mk 16:1; seq. dat., ἐλαίῳ, Mk 6:13, Ja 5:14; μύρῳ, Lk 7:38, 46, Jo 11:2.†
cock-crowing, i.e. the third watch in the night: Mk 13:35.†
an Alexandrian: Ac 6:9 18:24.†
Alexan­drian: Ac 27:6 28:11.†
Alexander Son of Simon of Cyrene: Mk 15:21 A kinsman of the High Priest: Ac 4:6. A certain Jew: Ac 19:33. A coppersmith: I Ti 1:20. Perh. = 4 (v. Ellic. on I Ti, l.c.): II Ti 4:14.†

truth (v. DB, iv, 818f.). Objectively, "the reality lying at the basis of an appearance; the manifested, veritable essence of a matter" (Cremer, 86): Ro 9:1, al.; of religious truth, Ro 1:25, al.; esp. of Christian doctrine, Ga 2:5, al.; ἀ. θεοῦ, Ro 15:8. Subjectively, truthfulness, truth, not merely verbal (cl.), but sincerity and integrity of character: Jo 8:44, III Jo 3. In phrases (MM, VGT, s.v.): ἐπ’ ἀληθείας, Mk 12:14, al.; ἀ. λέγειν (εἰπεῖν, λαλεῖν), Ro 9:1, II Co 12:6, Eph 4:25, al.; ἀ. ποιεῖν, Jo 3:21, I Jo 1:6 (cf. DB, iv, 818b, ff.).
to speak the truth (R, mg., deal truly; Field, Notes, 192): Ga 4:16, Eph 4:15.†

of things, true, conforming to reality: Jo 4:18 5:31-32 6:55 (= ἀληθινός, q.v.) Jo 8:13-14, 17 10:41 19:35 21:24, Ac 12:9, Phl 4:8, Tit 1:13, I Pe 5:12, II Pe 2:22, I Jn 2:6, III Jn 12; of persons, truthful: Mt 22:16, Mk 12:14, Jo 3:33 7:18 8:26, Ro 3:4, II Co 6:8.†
to grind: Mt 24:41, Lk 17:35.†
to fish: Jo 21:3 (MM, VGT, s.v.).†
to salt, season with salt: Mt 5:13, Mk 9:49.†
pollution: Ac 15:20.†

stronger than δέ; prop. neuter pl. of ἄλλος, used adverbially, with changed accent; hence prop. otherwise, on the other hand (cf. Ro 3:31); opposing a previous negation, but: οὐ (μὴ) . . . ἀ., Mt 5:15, 17 Mk 5:39, Jo 7:16, al.; rhetorically subordinating but not entirely negativing what precedes, οὐ . . . ἀ., not so much . . . as, Mk 9:37, Mt 10:20, Jo 12:44, al.; with ellipse of the negation, Mt 11:7-9, Ac 19:2, I Co 3:6 6:11 7:7, II Co 7:1, Ga 2:3, al.; in opposition to a foregoing pos. sentence, ἀ. οὐ, Mt 24:6, I Co 10:23; οὐ μόνον . . . ἀ. καί, Jo 5:18, Ro 1:32, al.; elliptically, after a negation, ἀ. ἵνα, Mk 14:49, Jo 1:8 9:3, al.; = εἰ μή (Bl., §77, 13; M, Pr., 241; but cf. WM, §iii, 10), Mt 20:23, Mk 4:22. Without previous negation, to express opposition, interruption, transition, etc., but: Jo 16:20 12:27, Ga 2:14; before commands or requests, Ac 10:20 26:16, Mt 9:18, Mk 9:22, al.; to introduce an accessory idea, II Co 7:11; in the apodosis after a condition or concession with εἰ, ἐάν, εἴπερ, yet, still, at least, Mk 14:29, I Co 9:2, II Co 4:16, Col 2:5, al.; after μέν, Ac 4:17, Ro 14:20, I Co 14:17; giving emphasis to the following clause, ἀλλ’ ἔρχεται ὥρα, yea, etc., Jo 16:2; so with neg., ἀλλ’ οὐδέ, nay, nor yet, Lk 23:15. Joined with other particles (a practice which increases in late writers; Simcox, LNT, 166), ἀ. γε, yet at least, Lk 24:21, I Co 9:2; ἄ ἤ., save only, except, Lk 12:51, II Co 1:13; ἀ. μὲν οὖν, Phl 3:8 (on this usage, v. MM, VGT, s.v.).
to change: Ac 6:14, Ga 4:20.; to transform: I Co 15:51-52, He 1:12.; to exchange: c. acc, seq. ἐν (= בְּ, Ps 106:20) instead of simple gen. (Bl., § 36, 8), Ro 1:23
from another place: Jo 10:1.†
to speak allegorically (Cremer, 96 ff.): Ga 4:24.†
hallelujah, alleluia: Re 19:1, 3-4 19:6.†
of one another, mutually: Mt 25:32, Mk 4:41, Jo 13:22, al.
of another race, a foreigner ( = ἀλλόφυλος; Cremer, 150; MM, VGT, s.v.): Lk 17:18.†
to leap: Ac 3:8 14:10; of water, to spring up, Jo 4:14 (MM, VGT, s.v.).†

other, another: absol., Mt 20:3, al.; ἄ. δέ, I Co 3:10 12:8; pl., Mk 6:15; attached to a noun, Mt 2:12 4:21, al.; c. art., ὁ ἄ., the other, Mt 5:39, Jo 19:32 (Bl., §47, 8); οἱ ἄ., the others, the rest, Jo 20:25, I Co 14:29; ἄ. πρὸς ἄλλον = πρὸς ἀλλήλους (BL, §48, 10), Ac 2:12; ἄλλ’ (i.e. ἄλλο) ἤ (Bl., §77, 13), Lk 12:51; seq. πλήν, Mk 12:32; εἰ μή, Jo 6:22; παρά c. acc., I Co 3:11.
one who meddles in things alien to his calling: I Pe 4:15 (v. ICC, in l; Deiss., BS, 224-4; MM, VGT, s.v.).†

be-longing to another, not one's own (opp. to ἴδιος): Lk 16:12, Ro 14:4 15:20 (Field, Notes, 165 f.), II Co 10:15-16, I Ti 5:22, He 9:25.; foreign, strange, alien (opp. to οἰκεῖος; v. MM, VGT, s.v.): Mt 17:25-26, Jo 10:5, Ac 7:6, He 11:9, 34.†
foreign, of another race (MM, VGT, s.v.); as opp. to a Jew, a Gentile: Ac 10:28.†
otherwise: I Ti 5:25.†
to thresh: I Co 9:9 9:13; I Ti 5:18.†
without reason, irrational: ζῷα, II Pe 2:12, Ju 10.; contrary to reason: Ac 25:27 (v. MM, VGT, s.v.).†
the aloe, aloes (the powder of a fragrant wood): Jo 19:39.†
variant for ἅλας (q.v.): Mk 9:49, Rec. WH, mg., R, mg.†
salt: Ja 3:12.†
free from grief: Phl 2:28.†
(cf. λυσιτελέω), unprofitable: He 13:17.†
Alphæus.; Father of Levi: Mk 2:14.; Father of James: Mt 10:3, Mk 3:13, Lk 6:15, Ac 1:13.†
a threshing floor: Mt 3:12, Lk 3:17 (here prob. by meton. = the grain on the threshing floor).†
a fox: Mt 8:20, Lk 9:58; metaph., of Herod, Lk 13:32.†
a taking, capture: II Pe 2:12.†

at once (Lat. simul): Ac 24:26 27:40, Ro 3:12 (one and all = יַחַד, Ps 14:3), Col 4:3, I Ti 5:13, Phm 22; seq. σύν, I Th 4:17 5:10; as prep. c. dat., together with: Mt 13:29 (v. MM, VGT, s.v.); also, c. adv., ἅ. πρωΐ (cl., ἅ. ἕω, etc.), early in the morning: Mt 20:1.†
unlearned, ignorant: II Pe 3:16 (on the rareness of this word, v. MM, VGT, s.v.).†
of amaranth (Inscr.); hence un­fading: I Pe 5:4.†
un­fading (whence ὁ ἀ., the amaranth, an unfading flower): I Pe 1:4 (cf. MM, VGT, s.v.).†

to miss the mark (Hom., Æsch., al.), hence metaph. (Hom., al.), to err, do wrong; In LXX and NT, to violate God's law, to sin (for non-Christian exx., v. MM, VGT, s.v.): absol., Mt 18:25 27:4, Lk 17:3, Jo 5:14 8:11 9:2-3 Ro 2:12 3:23 5:12, 14 5:16 6:15, I Co 7:28 7:36 15:34, Eph 4:26, I Ti 5:20, Tit 3:11, He 3:17 10:26, I Pe 2:20, II Pe 2:4 2:4 I Jn 1:10 Jn 2:1 Jn 3:6-9 Jn 5:18; c. cogn. acc, ἁ. ἁμαρτίαν (cf. Ex 32:30, חֲטָאָה חָטָא), I Jn 5:16; seq. εἰς, Mt 18:21, Lk 15:18, 21 17:4, Ac 25:8 (καίσαρα). I Co 6:18 8:12 (Field, Notes, 173); ἐνώπιον, Lk 15:18, 21; πρὸς θάνατον (cf. Nu 18:22, מוּת חֵטְא), I Jn 5:16 (Cremer, 98, 633).†

an act of disobedience to divine law (Lft., Notes, 273), a sinful deed, a sin: Mk 3:28-29, Ro 3:25, I Co 6:18, II Pe 1:9, WH, mg.; αἰώνιωv ἀ. (DCG, i, 788a), Mk 3:29 (for exx. from π., v. MM, VGT, s.v.).†

prop. a missing the mark; in cl. (v. reff. to CR in MM, VGT, s.v.); guilt, sin (Plat., Arist., al.); more freq., from Æsch. down, a fault, failure. In NT (as LXX) always in ethical sense; as a principle and quality of action, = τὸ ἁμαρτάνειν, a sinning, sin: Ro 5:12, 13 20; ὑφ’ ἁμαρτίαν εἶναι, Ro 3:9; ἐπιμένειν, Ro 6:1; ἀποθνήσκειν, νεκρὸν εἶναι τῇ ἁ., Ro 6:2, 11; τὴν ἀ. γινώσκειν, Ro 7:7; σῶμα τῆς ἁ., Ro 6:6; ἀπάτη τῆς ἁ., He 3:13; personified as a ruling principle, ἁ. βασιλεύει, κυριεύει, etc., Ro 5:21 6:12, 14 7:17, 20; δουλεύειν, Ro 6:6; δοῦλος τῆς ἁ., ib. 17; νόμος τῆς ἁ., Ro 7:23 8:2; δύναμις τῆς ἁ., I Co 15:56 (cf. Ge 4:7). As a generic term (disting. fr. the specific terms ἁμάρτημα, q.v., etc.) for concrete wrongdoing, violation of the divine law, sin: Jo 8:46, Ja 1:15, al.; ποιεῖν (τὴν) ἁ., Jo 8:34, II Co 11:7, I Jo 3:8; εἴχειν ἁ., Jo 9:41 15:22, 24 19:11, I Jo 1:8; in pl. ἁμαρτίαι, sin in the aggregate, I Th 2:16 (v. Milligan, in l.); ποιεῖν ἁμαρτίας, Ja 5:15; πλῆθος ἁμαρτιῶν, Ja 5:20, I Pe 4:8; ἄφεσις ἁμαρτιῶν, Mt 26:28, Mk 1:4, al.; ἐν ἁμαρτίαις εἶναι, I Co 15:17; collectively, αἴρειν τὴν ἁ. τ. κόσμου, Jo 1:29; ἀποθνήσκειν ἐν τῇ ἁ., Jo 8:21. = ἁμάρτημα, a sinful deed, a sin: Mt 12:31, Ac 7:60, I Jo 5:16.
without witness: Ac 14:17.†
sinful, a sinner: of all men, I Ti 1:15; of those especially wicked, I Ti 1:9, I Pe 4:18; p1., Mt 9:10-13 11:19 26:45, al. (v. MM, VGT, s.v.; Cremer, 102, 634)
invincible (freq. in cl.).; abstaining from fighting, non-combatant (Xen.). Metaph. (cf. MM, VGT, s.v.), not contentious: I Ti 3:3, Tit 3:2.†
to reap: Ja 5:4.†
amethyst, a purple quartz: Re 21:20.†
absol., to be careless, not to care: Mt 22:5; c. gen., to be careless of, to neglect: I Ti 4:14, He 2:3 8:9 (v. MM, VGT, s.v.).†
blameless, free from fault (in π. of a marriage-contract; M, Th., I, 3:13; cf. MM, VGT, s.v.): Lk 1:6, Phl 2:15 3:6, I Th 3:13 (WH, mg., -ως) He 8:7.†
blamelessly (Lft., Notes, 28, 89; MM, VGT, s.v. -ος): I Th 2:10 3:13 WH mg., 5:23.†
free from anxiety or care: Mt 28:14, I Co 7:32 (for exx., v. MM, VGT, s.v.).†
immutable: He 6:18; as subat., τὸ ἀ., immutability, He 6:17 (v. MM, VGT, s.v.).†
immovable, firm: I Co 15:58.†
not repented of, unregretted: Ro 11:29, II Co 7:10.†
impenitent: Ro 2:5; = ἀμεταμέλητος (π., Philo, al.; v. Deiss., BS, 257; MM, VGT, s.v.).†
without measure: adverbially, εἰς τὰ ἄ., excessively, II Co 10:13 10:15†

As adj. (cf. Is, l.c.), ὁ ἀ., Re 3:14. As adv., in solemn assent to the statements or prayers of another (Nu, Ne, etc., ll. c.): ὁ ἀ., I Co 14:16; similarly, at the end of one's own prayer or ascription of praise: Ro 1:25 15:33, Ga 1:5, I Ti 1:17; in the Gospels, exclusively, introducing solemn statements of our Lord, truly, verily: Mt 5:18, 26 Mk 3:28 (v. Swete, in l.), Lk 4:24, al.; ἀ. ἀ., always in Jo 1:52 3:3 5:19, al.; τὸ ναί, καὶ . . . τὸ ἀ., II Co 1:20 (on usage in π., v. MM, VGT, s.v.).
of one without recorded genealogy, He 7:3 (cf. MM, VGT, s.v.)
undefiled, free from contamination (in π., of αἰθήρ; MM, VGT, s.v.): He 7:26 13:4, I Pe 1:4, Ja 1:27.†
Amminadab: Mt 1:4, Lk 3:33 (WH om.).†
sand, sandy ground: Mt 7:26, Ro 9:27, He 11:12, Re 18:1, Re 20:8.†
a lamb: fig., of Christ (DCG, ii, 620b), Jo 1:29, 36, Ac 8:32 (LXX), I Pe 1:19 (cf. ἀρνίον; Cremer, 102, 635).†
requital, recompense: I Ti 5:4 (for illustration from τ.. v. MM, VGT, s.v.).†
vine: Mt 26:29, Mk 14:25, Lk 22:18 Ja 3:12; fig., of Christ, Jo 15:1, 4-5; of his enemies (on the usage here, v. MM, VGT, s.v.): Re 14:18-19.†
a vine dresser: Lk 13:7.†
a vineyard: Mt 20:1 ff. Mt 21:28 ff, Lk 13:6 20:9 ff., I Co 9:7. Æschin., 49, 13; Diod., al.; v. MM, VGT, s.v.; LS, s.v. ἀμπελουργεῖον.)
Ampliatus: Ro 1:6 8:8.†
to ward off, etc. Mid.; to defend oneself against; to requite; = act., to defend, assist (Isa, l.c.): c. acc pers., Ac 7:24 (MM, VGT, s.v.).†
to clothe: Lk 12:28 (T, -έζει).†
= περιβάλλω, to throw around, as a garment: absol. (MM, VGT, s.v.), of casting a net: Mk 1:16 (Rec. βάλλονταν ἀμφίβληστρον).†
something thrown around, as a garment; spec., a casting-net: Mt 4:18.†
to clothe: Mt 6:30 11:8, Lk 7:25 (cf. ἀμφιάζω).†
Amphipolis, in Macedonia, so called because the river Strymon flowed around it: Ac 17:1.†
prop., a road around anything (RV, the open street): Mk 11:4, Ac 19:28, WH, mg.†
(replaces ἄμφω in κοινή, V. M, Pr., 57; used of more than two, Pr., 80; MM, VGT, s.v.), both of two: Mt 9:17, al.
blameless: II Pe 3:14.†
amomum, a fragrant plant of India (RV, spice): Re 18:13
of sacrificial victims, without blemish: of Christ, He 9:14, I Pe 1:19; etbically, unblemished, faultless: Eph 1:4 5:27, Phl 2:15, Col 1:22, Ju 24, Re 14:5 (Cremer, 425, 788; MM, VGT, s.v.).†
Amon, King of Judah: Mt 1:10 (Rec.).†
as in 2Ki, Lc. B (Α. Ἀμμών; Jos., Ἀμμών, "Αμωσσς), Amon: Mt 1:10.; Amos: Lk 3:25.†

which cannot usually be separately translated in English, its force depending on the constructions which contain it (see further, LS, s.v.; WM, §xlii; M, Pr., 165 ff.; MM, VGT, s.v.). In apodosis, c. indic, impf. or aor., expressing what would be or would have been if (εἰ c. impf., aor. or plpf.) some condition were or had been fulfilled: Lk 7:39 17:6, Jo 5:46, Ga 1:10, Mt 12:7 24:43, I Co 2:8, Ac 18:14, I Jo 2:19, al. The protasis is sometimes understood (as also in cl.): Mt 25:27, Lk 19:23. In hypothetical sentences, expressing unreality, ἄν (as often in late writers, more rarely in cl.) is omitted: Jo 8:39 15:24 19:11, Ro 7:7, Ga 4:15; c. opt., inf., ptcp. (cl.; v. LS, s.v.; M, Int., §275; M, Pr., 167:4). In combination with conditional, relative, temporal, and final words; as in cl., c. subj., in protasis with εἰ, in Attic contr. ἐάν, q.v.; in conditional, relative, and temporal clauses (coalescing with ὅτε, ἐπεί, etc.; v.s. ὅταν, ἐπάν, etc.), ever, soever; c. pres., ἡνίκα, II Co 3:15; ὃς ἄν, Ro 9:15 (LXX) 16:2, al.; ὅσοι ἄν, Lk 9:5; ὡς ἄν, Ro 15:24 (M, Pr., 167); c. aor., ὃς ἄν, Mt 5:21, 22, 31; ἕως ἄν, until, Mt 2:13, Mk 6:10, al.; ὡς ἄν, as soon as (M, Pr., 167), I Co 11:34, Phl 2:23. On the freq. use of ἐάν for ἄν with the foregoing words, v.s. ἐάν; in late Gk., when some actual fact is spoken of, c. indic.: ὅταν (q.v.); ὅπου ἄν, Mk 6:56 (M, Pr., 168); καθότι ἄν, Ac 2:45 4:35; ὡς ἄν, I Co 12:2. in iterative construction, c. impf. and aor. indic. (M, Pr., 167): Ac 2:45 4:35, I Co 12:2. c. optat., giving a potential sense to a question or wish: Ac 8:31 26:29. Elliptical constructions: εἰ μή τι ἄν (M, Pr., 169), I Co 7:5; ὡς ἄν, c. inf., as it were (op. cit. 167), II Co 10:9.

prep. (the rarest in NT; M, Pr., 98; MM, VGT, s.v.), prop.,; upwards, up, always c. acc; In phrases: ἀ. μέσον, among, between, c. gen., Mt 13:1-58 25:1-46, Mk 7:31, I Co 6:5 (M, Pr., 99), Re 7:17 [so in LXX for בְּתוׄך׃]; ἀ. μέρος, in turn, I Co 14:27 (both found in Polyb.; cf. MGr. ἀνάμεσα).; Distrib., apiece, by: Mt 20:9-10, Lk 9:3 (WH om.), Lk 9:14 Lk 10:1, Jo 2:6, Re 4:8.; Adverbially ("a vulgarism," B1., § 51, 5; cf. Deiss., BS, 139 f.), ἀ. εἷς ἕκαστος, Re 21:21.; As prefix, ἀ. signifies; up: ἀναβαίνειν; to: ἀναγγέλλειν; anew: ἀναγεννᾶν; back: ἀνακάμπτειν.†
a going up, an ascent (Pss, ll. c. ?).; a step (LXX); p1., a flight of stairs: Ac 21:35, 40. (On the formation -θμός, v. MM, VGT, s.v.)†

to go up, ascend,; of persons: ἐπί συκομωρέαν, Lk 19:4; εἰς τ. πλοῖον, Mk 6:51; εἰς Ἱεροσόλυμα, Mt 20:17; εἰς τ. ἱερόν, c. inf. (M, Pr., 205), Lk 18:10; with mention of place of departure, Mt 3:16 (ἀπό), Ac 8:39 (ἐκ); of things, to rise, spring up, come up: a fish, Mt 17:27; smoke, Re 8:4; plants growing, Mt 13:7; metaph., of things coming up in one's mind (as Heb. לֵב אֵל עָלָה; IV Ki 12:4, al.), Lk 24:38, I Co 2:9; of prayers, Ac 10:4; messages, Ac 21:31 (for late exx., v. MM, VGT, s.v.)
to defer, put off (MM, VGT, s.v.): mid., Ac 24:22.†
to make go up, draw up, as a ship (Xen.): σαγήνην, Mt 13:48 (metaph., MM, VGT, s.v.).†
to look up: Mk 8:24, al.; seq. εἰς, Mt 14:19, al. (Xen., Plat.).; to recover sight (Plat., Aristoph.; cf. MM, VGT, s.v.): Mt 11:5, Jo 9:11, al
recovery of sight: Lk 4:18 (Lxx).†
to cry out: Mt 27:46 (WH, ἐβόησεν; v. MM, VGT, s.v.).†
delay: Ac 25:17 (for exx. of other meanings, v. MM, VGT, s.v.).†
an upper room: Mk 14:15, Lk 22:12.†

to bring back word, report (Æsch., Thuc., al.): Jo 5:15 (WH, εἶπεν), Ac 14:27 15:4, II Co 7:7; Later, = ἀπαγγέλλω (MM, VGT, s.v.), to announce, declare (LXX; Cremer, 24): Mt 28:11 (WH, ἀπ-), Jo 4:25 16:13-15, Ac 19:18 20:20, 27 Ro 15:21, I Pe 1:12, I Jn 1:5.†
to beget again: metaph., of spiritual birth, I Pe 1:3 1:23 (cf. Cremer, 147; MM, VGT, s.v.).†

to know certainly, know again, recognize.; Of written characters, to read: Mt 24:15, Mk 13:14, Ac 15:31 23:34, Eph 3:4; c. acc rei, Mt 22:31, Mk 12:10 Lk 6:3, Jo 19:20, Ac 8:30, 32, II Co 1:13, Re 1:3; c. acc pers., Ἠσαίαν τ. προφήτην, Ac 8:28, 30; seq. ἐν, Mt 12:5 21:42, Mk 12:26 (so. ἐν τ. νόμῳ), Lk 10:26; seq. ὅτι, Mt 19:4 21:16; τί ἐποίησε, Mt 12:3, Mk 2:25; pass. II Co 3:2; of reading aloud (MM, VGT, s.v.), Lk 4:16, Ac 13:27 15:21, II Co 3:15, Col 4:16, I Th 5:27 (M, Th., in l).†

to necessitate, compel by force or persuasion, constrain: c. acc, II Co 12:11; id. c. inf., Mt 14:22, Mk 6:45, Lk 14:23, Ac 26:11 (on the impf. here, v. Field, Notes, 141; M, Pr., 128 f., 247), Ga 2:14 6:12; pass., C. inf., Ac 28:19, Ga 2:3 (for exx., v. MM, VGT, s.v.).†

necessary: Ac 13:46, I Co 12:22, II Co 9:5, Phl 2:25, Tit 3:14, He 8:3; comp. -αιότερον, Phl 1:24.; Of persons connected by bonds of nature or friendship, near, intimate (Field, Notes, 118; ΜΜ, VGT, s.v.): ἀ. φίλοι, Ac 10:24.†
necessarily or by constraint: opp. to ἑκουσίως, I Pe 5:2 (rare).†

necessity: ἔχειν ἀ-, c. inf., to be compelled, Lk 14:18 23:17 (Rec., R, mg.), I Co 7:37, Ju 3, He 7:27; ἐξ ἀ., κατ' ἀ., of necessity, II Co 9:7, He 7:12, Phm 14; ἀ. μοι ἐπίκειται, n. is laid on me, I Co 9:16; c. inf. (= ἀναγκαῖον ἐστι), Mt 18:7, Ro 13:5, He 9:16, 23; force, violence, hence pain, distress (Diod., al.; LXX; v. M, Th., 41; MM, VGT, s.v.; cf. θλίψις): Lk 21:23, I Co 7:26, I Th 3:7; pl. (v. B1., § 32, 6; Swete, Mk., 153), ἐν ἀ., II Co 6:4 12:10.†
to recognize: Ac 7:13 (WH, txt., ἐγνωρίσθη).†
recognition (Hdt.).; reading (Plat., al.): of the public reading of Scripture (Milligan, NTD, 173, 210 f.): Ac 13:15, II Co 3:14, I Ti 4:13 (Cremer, 158; MM, VGT, s.v.).†

to lead or bring up: seq. είς, c. acc loc., Mt 4:1, Lk 2:22 4:5 (WH om. είς, κ.τ.λ.), Ac 9:39 16:34; of raising the dead (cl.), ἐκ νεκρῶν, Ro 10:7, He 13:20; to produce and set before, τ. λαῷ, Ac 12:4 (MM, VGT, s.v.); in sacrificial sense (MM, 1 c.), to offer, θυσίαν, Ac 7:41. Mid., in nautical sense (Hom., Hdt., Thuc., al.), to put to sea: Lk 8:22, Ac 13:13 16:11 18:21 20:3, 13 21:1-2 27:2, 4 27:12, 21 28:10-11 (cf.ἐπ-ανάγω).†
to lift up and show, show forth, declare (cf. II Mac 2:8, v. MM, VGT, s.v.): Ac 1:24.; to consecrate, set apart, (Strab., Plut., Anth.): Lk 10:1.†
a sheaving forth, announcement: Lk 1:80.†
to assume, undertake (in π. freq. as legal term: MM, VGT, s.v.): ἐπαγγελίας, He 11:17.; = cl. ὑποδέχομαι, to receive: of guests, Ac 28:7.†
to give forth, send up, as of plants (Hdt., al.).; to give up, yield, hand over (MM, VGT, s.v.): Ac 23:33.†
to live again, regain life (cf. cl. ἀναβιόω; Cremer, 722; and for other exx., v MM, VGT, s.v.): metaph. of moral revival, Lk 15:24 (WH, mg., ἔζησεν); of sin, Ro 7:9.†
to look for or seek carefully ("specially of searching for human beings, with an implication of difficulty": MM, VGT, s.v.): Lk 2:44-45 Ac 11:25.†
to gird up: fig., τ. ὀσφύας τ. διανοίας, I Pe 1:13.†
to kindle afresh: metaph., II Ti 1:6 (for vernac. exx., v. MM, VGT, s.v.).†
to revive: Phl 4:10 (of MM, VGT, s.v.).†

Hellenistic for Attic ἀνάθημα (Bl., § 27, 2); prop. = τὸ ἀνατιθέμένον, that which is laid by to be kept, a votive offering (as ἀνάθημα in II Mac 2:13, Lk 21:5—where LT read -θεμα, v. M, Pr., 46).; [As equiv. in LXX for חֵרֶם,] devoted, a thing devoted to God (v. Driver, De., 98 f., and cf. Le 27:28-29), hence; of the sentence pronounced (De 13:15), a curse: Ac 23:14; of the object on which the curse is laid, accursed (De 7:26): Ro 9:3, I Co 12:3 16:22, Ga 1:8-9 (v. ICC on Ro.; Lft., Ga., ll. c.; Cremer, 547; Tr., Syn., § v; MM, VGT, s.v.).†

to devote to destruction, declare or invoke ana­thema: absol., Mk 14:71; ἐαντόν, to bind oneself under a curse: Ac 23:12, 14 23:21 (cf. καταναθεματίζω, and on the occurrence of the word in π., v. Deiss., LAE, 92 f.; MM, VGT, s.v.).†
to observe carefully, consider well: Ac 17:23, He 13:7 (Diod., al.).†
a gift set up in a temple, a votive offering: Lk 21:5 (LT, -θεμα).†
shamelessness, importunity: Lk 11:8 (for exx. from π., v. MM, VGT, s.v.).†
a taking up or away (Thuc.).; a destroying, slaying, murder (Field, Notes, 116; MM, VGT, s.v.): Ac 8:1.†

to take up: mid., Ac 7:21.; to take away, make an end of, destroy (for late exx. of various senses, v. MM, VGT, s.v.); of things (as freq. in cl. of laws, etc.): He 10:9; of persons, to kill: Mt 2:16, Lk 22:2 23:32, Ac 2:23 5:33, 36 7:28 9:23-24, 29 10:39 12:2 13:28 16:27 22:20 23:15, 21 23:27 25:3 26:10, II Th 2:8, WH, txt., R, txt.†
guiltless, innocent: Mt 12:5, 7.†
trans., to set up. Intrans., to sit up: Lk 7:15 (WH, mg., ἐκάθισεν), Ac 9:40 (freq. in medical writings: MM, VGT, s.v.). †
to renew: He 6:6 (Isocr., Plut.).†
= ἀνακαινίζω (cf. MM, VGT, s.v.),; to make new: II Co 4:16, Col 3:10 (v. Cremer, 323).†
renewal: Ro 12:2, Tit 3:5 (Cremer, 324; MM, VGT, s.v.).†
to unveil: metaph. of removing hindrance to perception of spiritual things, II Co 3:14 3:18.†
trans., to bend or turn back.; Intrans., to return: Mt 2:12, Ac 18:21, He 11:15; metaph. (cf. MM, VGT, s.v.), Lk 10:6.†

in cl., as pass. of ἀνατίθημ, to be laid up, laid: Mk 5:40 Rec.; In late writers (cf. MM, VGT, s.v.) = κεῖσθαι, κατακεῖσθαι, to recline at table: Mt 26:20; part. ἀνακείμενος, Mt 9:10 22:10-11 26:7, Mk 6:26 14:18 16:14, Lk 22:27, Jo 6:11 12:2 13:23, 28.†
to sum up, gather up, present as a whole: mid., Ro 13:9, Eph 1:10 (on WH. v. Lft., Notes, 321 L; AR, in l; Cremer, 354, 748).†
to lay upon, lean against, hence,; to lay down: Lk 2:7; to make to recline: Mk 6:39, WH, mg., Lk 12:37. Pass., to lie back, recline: Mt 8:11 14:19, Lk 13:29.†

to examine, investigate, question (Lft., Notes, 181 f.): Ac 17:11, I Co 2:14-15 4:3-4 9:3 10:25 10:27 14:24; in forensic sense (MM, VGT, s.v.; esp. of examination by torture; v. Field, Notes, 120 f.), Lk 23:14, Ac 4:9 12:19 24:8 28:18.†
an examination: spec. of legal preliminary investigation, Ac 25:26 (v. MM, VGT, s.v.).†
to roll up; to roll back: Mk 16:4 (Rec. ἀποκ-).†
to lift oneself up; bodily; Lk 13:11, Jo 8:7, 10; mentally, to be elated: Lk 21:28 (cf. MM, VGT, s.v.).†
to take up, raise: Mk 16:19, Ac 1:2, 11 1:22 10:16, I Ti 3:16.; to take up, take to oneself: Ac 7:43 20:13-14 23:31, Eph 6:13, 16, II Ti 4:11 (for late exx., v MM, VGT, s.v.).†
a taking up: Lk 9:51 (MM, VGT, s.v.).†; ἀνά-ληψις, -εως, ἡ, Rec. for ἀνάλημψις, q.v.
to expend.; to consume, destroy: Lk 9:54, Ga 5:15, II Th 2:8, Rec. WH, mg.†
proportion (MM, VGT, s.v.): Ro 12:6 (cf. Cremer, 397).†
to consider: He 12:3 (MM, VGT, s.v.).†
saltless, insipid: Mk 9:50.†
a loosing, e.g. of a vessel from its moorings, hence, departure: from life, II Ti 4:6.†
to unloose.; to unloose for departure, depart (MM, VGT, s.v.): from life, Phl 1:23; to return, Lk 12:36.†
without missing, unerring (Xen.).; In moral sense, faultless (Plat.), without sin: Jo 8:7 (v. Cremer, 102, 634; MM, VGT, s.v.).†
to await "one whose coming is expected, perhaps with the added idea of patience and confidence" c. acc, I Th 1:10 (v. M, Th., in l; MM, VGT, s.v.).†
to remind, call to one's remembrance: c. acc rei, I Co 4:17; c. inf., II Ti 1:6. Pass., to remember, call to mind: Mk 11:21 14:72, II Co 7:15, He 10:32.†
remembrance: εἰς τ. ἐμὴν ἀ., Lk 22:19 (WH om.), I Co 11:24-25; ἀ. ἁμαρτιῶν, He 10:3 (v. Abbott, Essays, 122 ff.; DCG, ii, 74a).†
to renew: pass., Eph 4:23 (v. Cremer, 428; MM, VGT, s.v.)†
to return to soberness: metaph., II Ti 2:26 (of. ἐκνήφω).†
Ananias; of Jerusalem: Ac 5:1, 3 5:5.; Of Damascus: Ac 9:10-13, 17 22:12.; High Priest: Ac 23:2 24:1.†
not to be contradicted, undeniable: Ac 19:36 (MM, VGT, s.v.).†
without contradiction: Ac 10:29.†
unworthy: c. gen., I Co 6:2 (MM, VGT, s.v.).†
in an unworthy manner: I Co 11:27.†
cessation, rest, refreshment: Mt 11:26 12:43, Lk 11:24, Re 4:8 14:11.†

to give intermission from labour, to give rest, refresh: Mt 11:28, I Co 16:18, Phm 20; pass., Phm 7, II Co 7:13. Mid., to take rest, enjoy rest: Mt 26:45, Mk 6:31 14:41, Lk 12:19, Re 6:11 14:13; as in Heb. ofIs 11:2 (עַל נוּחַ), τὸ πνεῦμα ἐφ' ὑᾶμς ἀ., I Pe 4:14. (In π. this word is used as a technical agricultural term; v. MM, VGT, s.v.; and cf. Le 2634 f.; Cremer, 826.)†
to per­suade, incite: Ac 18:13 (cf. MM, VGT, s.v.).†

to send up,; to a higher place (Æsch., Plat., al.); to a higher authority (Deiss., BS, 229; MM, VGT, s.v.; cf. also Field, Notes, 140): Lk 23:7, 15, Ac 25:21.; to send back (Pind.): Lk 23:11, Phm 11.†
to leap up: Mk 10:50 (Rec. ἀναστάς)
maimed, crippled: Lk 14:13, 21.†

(cl.) to fall back.; In late writers = ἀνα-κλίνομαι, to recline for a repast (MM, VGT, s.v.): at table, Lk 11:37 14:10 17:7 22:14, Jo 13:12 21:20; on the ground, Mt 15:35 Mk 6:40 8:6 Jo 6:10; to lean back, Jo 13:25 (T, ἐπιπεσών; v.s. ἀνάκειμαι, ad fin.).†

to fill up, make full (in π. of com­pleting contracts and making up rent; cf. MM, VGT, s.v.): τόπον, take one's place (cf. Heb. מָקוֹם שָׁלַם), I Co 14:16; άμαρτίας, complete the number, I Th 2:16; τ. νόμον, observe perfectly, Ga 6:2; pass., προφητεία, fulfilled, Mt 13:14.; to supply: τό ὑστέρημα, I Co 16:17, Phl 2:30 (Cremer, 838).†
without excuse, inexcusable (in Polyb., al., as a forensic term; v. Lft., Notes, 252): Ro 1:20 2:1.†
to unroll: τ. βιβλίον, Lk 4:17 (WH, R, ἀνοίξας).†
to kindle: Lk 12:49, Ja 3:5 (MM, VGT, s.v.).†
innumerable: He 11:12.†
to shake out, shake back, move to and fro (Thuc., a1.).; In late writers (Diod., al.; v. MM, VGT, s.v.), to stir up; metaph., to excite: τ. ὄχλον, Mk 15:11; τ. λαόν, Lk 23:5.†
prop, to pack up baggage, hence, to dismantle, ravage, destroy; metaph., to unsettle, subvert (MM, VGT, s.v.): ψυχάς, Ac 15:24.†
to draw up: Lk 14:5, Ac 11:10 (in π. of pulling up barley; MM, VGT, s.v.).†

a raising up, awakening, rising (in Inscr. of the erection of a monument, v. MM, VGT, s.v.): Lk 2:34.; a rising from the dead (v. DCG, ii, 605b); of Christ: Ac 1:22 2:31 4:33 Ro 6:5, Phl 3:10, I Pe 3:21; ἐξ ἀ. νεκρῶν, Ro 1:4 (ICC, in l); ἐκ νεκρῶν, I Pe 1:3; of persons in OT hist. (e.g. III Ki 17:17 ff.): He 11:35; of the general resurrection: Mt 22:23, 28 22:30 Mk 12:18, 23 Lk 20:27, 33 20:36, Jo 11:24, Ac 17:18 23:8 24:15, II Ti 2:18; ἀ. ἐκ νεκρῶν, Lk 20:35, Ac 4:2; τῶν νεκρῶν, Mt 22:31, Ac 17:32 23:6 24:21 26:23, I Co 15:12-13 15:21 15:42, He 6:2; ἀ. ζωῆς, resurrection to life (cf. II Mac 7:14, ἀ. εἰς ζωήν) and ἀ. τ. κρίσεως, τ. to judgment, Jo 5:29; ἀ. τ. δικαίων, Lk 14:14; κρείττων ἀ., He 11:35; on ἡ ἀ. ἡ πρώτη, Re 20:5-8, v. Swete, in l, Weste. on Jo 5:1-47, but v. also Thayer, s.v.; by meton. of Christ as Author of ἀ., Jo 11:25 (v. DB, iv, 231; Cremer, 307).†
to stir up, excite, unsettle: c. acc; to tumult and sedition: Ac 17:6 21:38; by false teaching: Ga 5:12 (v. Milligan, NTD, 73 f.).†
to impale (Hdt.). to raise on a cross, crucify (Polyb., al.). to crucify again: He 6:6 (v. Westc., in l).†
to sigh deeply: Mk 8:12.†

to overturn: Jo 2:15. to turn back, return: Ac 5:22 15:16. to turn hither and thither; pass., to turn oneself about, sojourn, dwell: Mt 17:22 Rec.; metaph. (like Heb. הָלַךְ, in κοινή writers and in π.; v. Deiss., LAE, 315; BS, 88, 194; MM, VGT, s.v.), to conduct oneself, behave, live: II Co 1:12, Eph 2:3, I Ti 3:15, He 10:33 13:18, I Pe 1:17, II Pe 2:18.†

a turning down or back, a wheeling about (Soph., Thuc., al.).; In late writers (Polyb., al.; v.s. ἀναστρέφω, and cf. Hort on Ja 3:13; MM, VGT, s.v.), manner of life, behaviour, conduct: Ga 1:13, Eph 4:22, I Ti 4:12, He 13:7, Ja 3:13, I Pe 1:15 1:18 2:12 3:1-2 3:16, II Pe 2:7 3:11.†
to arrange in order, bring together from memory (Blass., Phil. Gosp., 14 ff.; MM, VGT, s.v.): Lk 1:1.†

trans., to cause to rise: Mt 5:45.; Intrans., to rise: φῶς, Mt 4:16 (= Is 9:1); ὁ ἥλιος, Mt 13:6, Mk 4:6 16:2, Ja 1:11; νεφέλη, Lk 12:54; φωσφόρος, II Pe 1:19; ὁ Κύριος, prob. with ref. to metaph. of sun or star, He 7:14 (cf. ἐξ-ανατέλλω).†
to lay upon, set up, etc. Mid. -εμαι, in late writers (Plut., al.; v. also MM, VGT, s.v.), to set forth, declare: Ac 25:14, Ga 2:2.†
a rising: of light, Lk 1:78.; the sun-rising, the east (MM, VGT, s.v.): Mt 2:2, 9, Re 21:13; ἀ. ἡλίου, Re 7:2 16:12 (WΗ, p1.); pl., Mt 2:1 8:11 24:27, Lk 13:29.†
to overturn, destroy: Jo 2:15 WH, txt.; metaph., to subvert (MM, VGT, s.v.): II Ti 2:18, Tit 1:11.†
to nurse up, nourish, educate, bring up: Lk 4:16, WΗ, mg., Ac 7:20-21 22:3.†
to bring to light, make to appear: ἀναφάναντες τ. Κύπρον, i.e. having sighted C.: Ac 21:3 WH; pass., to appear, be made manifest: Lk 19:11

to carry or lead up: c. acc pers., Mt 17:1, Mk 9:2; pass., Lk 24:51 (WH, rejects, R, mg. omits); ἀ. τ. ἁμαρτίας ἐπί τ. ξύλον (v. Deiss., 135, 88 f.; ICC, in l; MM, VGT, s.v.): I Pe 2:24.; In LXX and NT, to bring to the altar, to offer (v. Hort on 1Pe, l.c.): θυσίας, etc., He 7:27 13:15, I Pe 2:5; ἐπί τ. θυσιαστήριον, Ja 2:21 (v. Mayor, in l).; to bear, sustain (cf. Nu 14:33, Is 53:12): He 9:28.†
to cry out, exclaim: Lk 1:42 (Arist., al.).†
a pouring out, overflowing, excess: metaph., I Pe 4:4 (MM, VGT, s.v.).†
to go back.; to withdraw: Mt 9:24; freq. in sense of avoiding danger (MM, VGT, s.v.), Mt 2:12 (but v. Thayer), Mt 2:13-14, 22 4:12 12:15 14:13 15:21 27:5, Mk 3:7, Jo 6:15, Ac 23:19 26:31.†
a refreshing: Ac 3:19.†
to refresh: c. acc pers., II Ti 1:16 (MM, VGT, s.v.; Cremer, 588).†
a slave-dealer, kidnapper: I Ti 1:10 (v. MM, VGT, s.v.).†
to make a man of. Mid., to play the man (cf. MM, VGT, s.v.): I Co 16:13.†
Andronicus: Ro 16:7.†
a man-slayer: I Ti 1:9 (cf. φονεύς, and v. MM, VGT, s.v.).†
not to be called to account, unreprovable: I Co 1:8, Col 1:22, I Ti 3:10, Tit 1:6-7.†
inexpressible: II Co 9:15 (MM, VGT, s.v.).†
unspeakable: I Pe 1:8.†
unfailing: Lk 12:33 (MM, VGT, s.v.).†
tolerable: compar., -ότερος, Mt 10:15 11:22, 24, Lk 10:12, 14 †
without mercy: Ro 1:13.†
merciless: Ja 2:13.†
to be driven by the wind: Ja 1:6.†

wind: Mt 11:7 14:24, 30 14:32, Mk 4:37, 39 4:41 6:48, 51, Lk 7:24 8:23-24, Jo 6:13, Ac 27:7, 14-15, Ja 3:4, Re 6:13 7:1; pl., Mt 7:25, 27 8:26-27, Lk 8:25, Ac 27:4, Ju 12; οἱ τέσσαρες ἄ. τῆς γῆς, Re 7:1; hence the four quarters of the heavens (v. Deiss., BS, 248; MM, VGT, s.v.), Mt 24:31, Mk 13:27; metaph., of variable teaching, Eph 414.†
impossible, inadmissible: Lk 17:1.†
unsearchable: Ro 11:33.†
patiently forbearing (cf. ἀνεξικακία, Wi 2:19; and v. MM, VGT, s.v.): II Ti 2:24.†
that cannot be traced out: Ro 11:33, Eph 3:8 (MM, VGT, s.v.).†
not to be put to shame: II Ti 2:15.†
without reproach: I Ti 3:2 5:7 6:14.†
to go up: Jo 6:3, Ga 1:17-18 (cf. ἐπανέρχ-; and on its use of "going up " to the capital, MM, VGT, s.v.).†
a loosening, relaxation: Ac 24:23 (RV, indulgence; cf. MM, VGT, s.v.); by St. Paul, opp. to θλίψις, expressed or understood, relief: II Co 2:12 7:5 8:13, II Th 1:7.†
to examine judicially: Ac 22:24, 29..†
prep. c. gen. (rarer than χωρίς, q.v.; cf. Ellic. on Eph 2:12; MM, VGT, 42),; without: Mt 10:29, I Pe 3:1 4:9.†
not well placed, not fit: Ac 27:12.†
to find out by search, discover (v. Field, Notes, 47 f.): Lk 2:16, Ac 21:4.†

to hold up; in NT always mid., to bear with, endure: in cl. most freq. c. acc, but in NT c. gen. pers., Mt 17:17, Mk 9:19, Lk 9:41, II Co 11:1 11:19, Eph 4:2, Col 3:13; seq. μικρόν τι, c. gen. pers. and c. gen. rei, II Co 11:1; c. dat. rei, II Th 1:4 (v M, Th., in l); seq. εἴ τις, II Co 11:20; absol., I Co 4:12, II Co 11:4; to bear with = to listen to, c. gen. pers., Ac 18:14; c. gen. rei, II Ti 4:3, He 13:22 (cf. προσανέχω and MM, VGT, s.v.).†
a cousin: Col 4:10 (MM, VGT, s.v.).†
anise: Mt 23:23.†
prop., to have come up to; in later writers, impers. it is due, it is befitting: in ethical sense (MM, VGT, s.v.), Eph 5:4, Col 3:18; τὸ ἀνῆκον, Phm 8.†
not tame, savage (MM, VGT, s.v.): II Ti 3:3.†

a man, Lat. vir. As opp. to a woman, Ac 8:12, I Ti 2:12; as a husband, Mt 1:16, Jo 4:16, Ro 7:2, Tit 1:6. As opp. to a boy or infant, I Co 13:11, Eph 4:13, Ja 3:2. In appos. with a noun or adj., as ἀ. ἁμαρτωλός, Lk 5:8; ἀ. προφήτης, 24:19; freq. in terms of address, as ἀ. ἀδελφοί, Ac 1:16; and esp. with gentilic names, as ἀ. Ἰουδαῖος, Ac 22:3; ἀ. Ἐφέσιοι, 19:35. In general, a man, a male person: = τις, Lk 8:41, Ac 6:11.

in pres., impf., fut. and 1 aor. act., causal, to set against.; In mid, and pass., also pf. and 2 aor. act., to withstand, resist, oppose: c. dat., Mt 5:39, Lk 21:15, Ac 6:10 13:8, Ro 9:19 13:2, Ga 2:11, Eph 6:13, II Ti 3:8 4:15, Ja 4:7, I Pe 5:9.†

to make a mutual agreement (Dem., Polyb.).; to acknowledge fully, confess (Diod., Polyb., cf. 1Esdras, l.c.).; C. dat. pers., to declare one's praises, speak fully in prayer or thanksgiving, give thanks to (cf. Ps, l.c.): Lk 2:38 (Cremer, 771; MM, VGT, s.v.).†
a flower: Ja 1:10-11. I Pe 1:24 (LXX).†
a heap of burning coals: Jo 18:18 21:9.†
coal, charcoal: . ἄ. πυρός, a burning coal, Ro 12:20.†
studying to please men: Eph 6:6, Col 3:22 (Cremer, 642; MM, VGT, s.v.).†

human, belonging to man: χεῖρες, Ac 17:25; σοφία, I Co 2:13; φύσις, Ja 3:7; κτίσις, I Pe 2:13 (MM, VGT, s.v.); ἀ. ἡμέρα, opp. to ἡ ἡμ. (I Co 3:13, God's Judgment-Day), human judgment, I Co 4:3 (v. Lft., Notes, 198); πειρασμὸς ἀ., temptation such as man can bear (AV, such as is common to man, v. Field, Notes, 175), I Co 10:13; ἀνθρώπινον λέγω, I speak in human fashion, with words not properly weighed, Ro 6:19 (v. Field, Notes, 156).†
a murderer, manslayer (Eur.; v. MM, VGT, s.v.): Jo 8:44, I Jn 3:16.†

man: generically, a human being, male or female (Lat. homo): Jo 16:21; c. art., Mt 4:4 12:35, Mk 2:27, Jo 2:25, Ro 7:1, al; disting. from God, Mt 19:6, Jo 10:33, Col 3:23, al.; from animals, etc., Mt 4:19, Lk 5:10, Re 9:4, al.; implying human frailty and imperfection, I Co 3:4; σοφία ἀνθρώπων, I Co 2:5; ἀνθρώπων ἐπιθυμίαι, I Pe 4:2; κατὰ ἄνθρωπον περιπατεῖν, I Co 3:3; κατὰ ἄ. λέγειν (λαλεῖν), Ro 3:5, I Co 9:8; κατὰ ἄ- λέγειν, Ga 3:15 (cf. I Co 15:32, Ga 1:11); by meton., of man's nature or condition, ὁ ἔσω (ἔξω) ἄ., Ro 7:22, Eph 3:16, II Co 4:16 (cf. I Pe 3:4); ὁ παλαιὸς, καινὸς, νέος ἄ., Ro 6:6, Eph 2:15 4:22, 24 Col 3:9, 10; joined with another subst., ἄ. ἔμπορος, a merchant, Mt 13:45 (WH, txt. om. ἄ.); οἰκοδεσπότης, Mt 13:52; βασιλεύς, 18:23; φάγος, 11:19; with name of nation, Κυρηναῖος, Mt 27:32; Ἰουδαῖος, Ac 21:39; Ῥωμαῖος, Ac 16:37; pl. οἱ ἄ., men, people: Mt 5:13, 16 Mk 8:24, Jo 4:28; οὐδεὶς ἀνθρώπων, Mk 11:2, I Ti 6:16. Indef., ἄ. = τις, some one, a man: Mt 17:14, Mk 12:1, al.; τις ἄ., Mt 18:12, Jo 5:5, al.; indef. one (Fr. on), Ro 3:28, Ga 2:16, al.; opp. to women, servants, etc., Mt 10:36 19:10, Jo 7:22, 23. > Definitely, c. art., of some particular person; Mt 12:13, Mk 3:5, al.; οὗτος ὁ ἄ., Lk 14:30; ὁ ἄ οὗτος, ἐκεῖνος, Mk 14:71, Mt 12:45; ὁ ἄ. τ. ἀνομίας, II Th 2:3; ἄ τ. θεοῦ (of Heb. אִישׁ אֱלֹהִים), I Ti 6:11, II Ti 3:17, II Pe 1:21; ὁ υἰὸς τοῦ ἀ., v.s. υἱός.
to be proconsul: Ac 18:12 Rec. (v.s. ἀνθύπατος).†
supreme, a consul, one acting in place of a consul, a proconsul, the administrator of a senatorial province (cf. ἡγεμών, and v. MM, VGT, 44): Ac 13:7-8, 12 18:12 19:38.†

to send up, produce, to send back.; to let go, leave without support: He 13:5 (cf. De 31:6; Hom., Iliad., ii, 71).; to relax, loosen (v. Field, Notes, 124 f.): Ac 16:26 27:40; hence, metaph., to give up, desist from: Eph 6:9.†
unwashed: Mt 15:20, Mk 7:5 (5 Rec).†

causal, in fut. and 1 aor. act., c. acc., to raise up: Ac 9:41; from death, Jo 6:39, Ac 2:32; to raise up, cause to be born or appear: Mt 22:24, Ac 3:22, 26. Intrans., in mid. and 2 aor act.; to rise: from lying, Mk 1:35; from sitting, Lk 4:16; to leave a place, Mt 9:9; pleonastically, as Heb. קוּם, before verbs of going, Mk 10:1, al. (v. Dalman, Words, 23; M, Pr., 14); of the dead, Mt 17:23, Mk 8:31; seq. ἐκ νεκρῶν, Mt 17:9, Mk 9:9; to arise, appear: Ac 5:36, Ro 15:12 (cf. ἐπ-, ἐξ- ἀνίστημι, and v. Cremer, 306, 738; MM, VGT, s.v.). SYN.: ἐγείρω.
Anna, a prophetess: Lk 2:36.†
Annas, the high priest: Lk 3:2, Jo 18:13-24, Ac 4:6.†
not thought on, not understood (Hom., Plat.).; not understanding, foolish (Hdt., al., LXX): Lk 24:25, Ro 1:14, Ga 3:1, 3, I Ti 6:9, Tit 3:3 (Cremer, 438, 790; MM, VGT, s.v.).†
folly, foolishness: II Ti 3:9; expressed in violent rage (cf. Plat., Tim., 86B): Lk 6:11.†

to open; trans., c. acc; a door or gate, Ac 5:19 12:14, Re 4:1; pass., Ac 12:10 16:26-27; metaph. of opportunity or welcome, Ac 14:27, Col 4:3, Re 3:20; pass., I Co 16:9, II Co 2:12, Re 3:8; absol. (sc. θύραν), Ac 5:23 12:16; c. dat. pers., Lk 12:36, Jo 10:3; metaph., Mt 7:7-8 25:11, Lk 11:9-10 13:25, Re 3:7; θησαυρούς (Si 43:14), Mt 2:11; τ. μνημεῖα, Mt 27:52; τάφος, Ro 3:13; τ. φρέαρ, Re 9:2; of heaven, Mt 3:16, Lk 3:21, Ac 10:11, Re 11:19 15:5 19:11; σφραγῖδα, Re 5:9 6:1 ff. Re 8:1; βιβλίον, βιβλαρίδιον, Lk 4:17, Re 5:2-5 10:2, 8 20:12; τ. στόμα, Mt 17:27; id. Hebraistically (Nu 22:28, Jb 3:1, Is 50:5, al.), of beginning to speak, Mt 5:2, Ac 8:32, 35 10:34 18:14; seq. εἰς βλαιφημίας, Re 13:6; ἐν παραβολαῖς (Ps 78:2), Mt 13:35; of recovering speech, Lk 1:64; of the earth opening, Re 12:16; τ. ὀφθαλμoύς, Ac 9:8, 40; id. c. gen. pers., of restoring sight, Mt 9:30 20:33, Jo 9:1 o ff. 10:21, 11:37; metaph., Ac 26:18; ἀκοάς, c. gen. pers., of restoring hearing, Mk 7:35.; Intrans. in 2 pf., ἀνέῳγα (M, Pr., 154); heaven, Jo 1:51; τ. στόμα, seq. πρός, of speaking freely, II Co 6:11 (cf. δι-ανοίγω and v. MM, VGT, 45).†
to build. again, rebuild (MM, VGT, s.v.): Ac 15:16.†
an opening (in MGr., springtime): ἐν ἀ., as often as I open, Eph 6:19.†

lawlessness, iniquity: Mt 7:23 13:41 23:28 24:12, Ro 6:19, II Co 6:14, II Th 2:3 2:7, Tit 2:14, He 1:9, I Jn 3:4; in pl. (as LXX, Ps 31:1, al.; v. 131., § 32, 6; Swete, Mk., 153), of acts or manifestations of lawlessness: Ro 4:7 (LXX), He 10:17.†
lawless, wicked: Mk 15:28, Lk 22:37, Ac 2:23, I Ti 1:9, II Pe 2:8; ὁ ἄ., II Th 2:8 (= ὁ ἄνθρωπος τῆς ἀνομίας, II Th 2:3). without law (= οἱ μὴ ὑπὸ νόμον, Ro 2:14): I Co 9:21 (MM, VGT, s.v.). †
lawlessly (2Mac, l.c.).; = χωρὶς νόμου, without law: Ro 2:12.†
to set upright or straight again, restore: of persons, Lk 13:13, He 12:12; of things, σκηνήν, Ac 15:16 (MM, VGT, s.v.; Cremer, 807).†
unholy, profane (Cremer, 464): I Ti 1:9, II Ti 3:2 (MM, VGT, s.v.).†
in cl., a holding back, delaying (MM, VGT, s.v.).; forbearance, delay of punishment: Ro 2:4 3:26.†
to struggle against: seq. πρός, c. acc, He 12:4.†
an exchange, the price received as an equivalent for an article of commerce: Mt 16:26, Mk 8:37 (cf. Si 26:14; and v. Swete, Mk., l.c.; Cremer, 90).†
to fill up in turn: Col 1:24 (v. Lft., in l; MM, VGT, s.v.).†

to give back as an equivalent, recompense, requital (the ἀντί ex­pressing the idea of full, complete return; v. Lft., Notes, 46); in favourable sense: Lk 14:14, Ro 11:35, I Th 3:9; in unfavourable sense: Ro 12:19, II Th 1:6, He 10:30.†
requital; in favourable sense: Lk 14:12; in unfavourable sense: Ro 11:9.†
recompense: Col 3:24 (MM, VGT, s.v.).†
to answer again, reply against: seq. πρός, c. acc rei, Lk 14:6; c. dat. pers., Ro 9:20.†
2 aor., without present in use, to speak against, gainsay: Lk 21:15, Ac 4:14.†

trans., to hold against.; Intrans., to withstand. Mid. 1. in cl., to hold out against.; (cf. MM, VGT, s.v.), to hold firmly to, cleave to: c. gen. (v. Bl., § 36, 2), Mt 6:24, Lk 16:13, I Th 5:14 (v. M, Th., in l), Tit 1:9.†

prop, in local sense, over against, opposite, hence; instead of, in place of, for (Hom., etc.): Mt 5:38 17:27, Lk 11:11, I Co 11:15, He 12:2; c. artic. inf. (cl.), Ja 4:15; of succession, Mt 2:22; χάριν ἀ. χάριτος, Jo 1:16 (M, Pr., 100); of price in exchange, He 12:16; λύτρον ἀ. πολλῶν, Mt 20:28, Mk 10:45 (M, Pr., 105); of requital, Ro 12:17, I Th 5:16, I Pe 3:9 (cf. Wi 11:15); ἀνθ' ὧν, because, Lk 1:20 19:44, Ac 12:23, II Th 2:10 (cl., LXX for אֲשֶׁר תַּחַת); id. therefore (cl., LXX), Lk 12:3; ἀ. τούτου (LXX for כֵּן נַעֲרָה)Eph 5:31. As a prefix, ἀντι- (before vowels ἀντ-, ἀνθ'-), denotes; over against, ἀντιπέραν; co-operation, ἀντιβάλλειν; requital, ἀντιμισθία; opposition, ἀντίχριστος; substitution, ἀνθύπατος.; Compounds of ἀ. usually govern dat. (B1., § 37, 7).†
to throw in turn, exchange: metaph., λόγους (cf. Lat. conferre sermons; v. Field, Notes, 81), Lk 24:17.†
in mid, to place oneself in opposition, oppose: II Ti 2:25 (EV; but v. Field, Notes, 215 f.; cf. MM, VGT, s.v.)
as subst., an opponent in a lawsuit, adversary: Mt 5:25, Lk 12:58 18:3, I Pe 5:8 (Cremer, 696; MM, VGT, s.v.).†
opposition: I Ti 6:20.†
causal in Pres. impf. fut. and 1 aor.; to replace, oppose.; Intrans. in pass. and 2 aor. act.; to supersede; to resist: He 12:4.†
to invite in turn: Lk 14:12.†
to lie opposite to.; to oppose, withstand, resist: c. dat., Lk 13:17 21:15, Ga 5:17, I Ti 1:10; as participial subst. (ὁ) ἀντικείμενος, I Co 16:9, Phl 1:28, II Th 2:4, I Ti 5:14 (Cremer, 746).†
in cl., outright; in κοινή (= cl. καταντικρύ), over against: Ac 20:15 (v. Bl., § 5, 4; 40, 7; Rutherford, NPhr., 500 f.; MM, VGT, s.v.).†

to take instead of or in turn. Mid., c. gen., to take hold of; of persons, to help (v. MM, VGT, s.v.): Lk 1:54, Ac 20:35; of things, to partake of: I Ti 6:2 (v. Field, Notes, 210; Cremer, 386; and cf. συν-αντιλαμβάνω).†
cοntradict, oppose, resist (v. Field, Notes, 106; MM, VGT, s.v.); absol.: Ac 28:19, Ro 10:21, Tit 1:9 2:9; c. dat., Jo 19:12, Ac 13:45; c. acc et inf., Lk 20:27 T; pass., Lk 2:34, Ac 28:22.†
cl. a laying hold of, an exchange.; Hellenistic (LXX, π.) help: pl. of ministrations of deacons; I Co 12:28 (DB, ii, 347 f.; Cremer, 386).†
gain-saying, strife (the latter sense being found in π.; v. MM, VGT, s.v.; cf. Field, Notes, 106): He 6:16 7:7 12:3, Ju 11.†
to revile in turn: I Pe 2:23.†
a ransom: I Ti 2:6 (v. CGT, in l; and cf. λύτρον).†
to measure in return: Lk 6:38 (WH, mg., μετρέω).†
a reward, requital: in good sense, II Co 6:13; in bad sense, Ro 1:27 (MM, VGT, s.v.).†
a citizen of Antioch, an Antiochian: Ac 6:5.†
to pass by opposite to: Lk 10:31-32 (MM, VGT, s.v.).†
Antipas: Re 2:13.†
Antipatris, bet. Joppa and Caesarea: Ac 23:31.†
on the opposite side: c. gen., Lk 8:26.†
to fall against or upon (Arist., Polyb.).; to strive against, resist (Arist.): c. dat., Ac 7:51
to make war against: c. dat., Ro 7:23.†
to range on battle against; mid., to set oneself against, resist: absol., Ac 18:6; c. dat., Ro 13:2, Ja 4:6 5:6, I Pe 5:5 (MM, VGT, s.v.).†

act. striking back; metaph., resisting, adverse.; Pass. struck back; metaph., corres­ponding to (MM, VGT, s.v.); as impression of a seal or copy of an archetype (τύπος) (RV, Like in pattern), He 9:24; as the reality (of which τύπος is the copy or adumbration) (RV, after a true likeness), I Pe 3:21 (Cramer, 357).†
Antichrist, "one who assuming the guise of Christ opposes Christ" (Westc., Epp. Jo., 70): I Jn 2:18 Jn 2:22 Jn 4:3, I Jn 1:7 pl. I Jn 2:18 (cf. ψευδόχριστος, and v. MM, VGT, s.v.).†
prop., to bale out.; Generally, to draw water: absol., Jo 2:8 4:15; ὕδωρ, Jo 2:9 4:7 (on its use of the water made wine, v. DCG, ii, 815a; MM, VGT, s.v.; Field, Notes, 84 f.).†
prop., what is drawn (Diosc.); a vessel to draw with, a bucket (Plut.; v. Abbott, Essays, 88): Jo 4:11.†

to look in the face, look straight at (Polyb.). Metaph., to face, withstand (Wis, l.c., Polyb.): c. dat., ἀ. τ. ἀνέμῳ, as nautical term, to beat up against the wind (v. DB, ext., 366 f.; MM, VGT, s.v.): Ac 27:15.†
waterless: τόποι, Mt 12:43, Lk 11:24; πηγαί, II Pe 2:17; νεφέλαι, Ju 12 (MM, VGT, s.v.).†
unfeigned: Ro 12:9, II Co 6:6, I Ti 1:5, II Ti 1:5, Ja 3:17, I Pe 1:22 (Cremer, 380; MM, VGT, s.v.).†
of things, not subject to rule: He 2:8; of persons, unruly: I Ti 1:9, Tit 1:6, 10 (MM, VGT, s.v.).†
up, upwards: Jo 11:41, He 12:15; above (opp. to κάτω): Act_2:19; with art. ἡ, Ga 4:26, Phl 3:14; τά, Jo 8:23, Col 3:1-2; ἕως ἄ. (up to the brim), Jo 2:7 (Cremer, 106; MM, VGT, s.v.).†

from above: ἀπὸ ἄ., Mt 27:51, Mk 15:38; ἐκ τῶν ἄ., Jo 19:28; meaning, from heaven: Jo 3:31 19:11, Ja 1:17 3:15, 17 .; from the first, from the beginning: Lk 1:3, Ac 26:5; whence; anew, again: Jo 3:3, 7, (so most, but v. Meyer, in l; cf. Field, Notes, 86 f.); πάλιν ἄ., Ga 4:9 (MM, VGT, s.v.).†
upper: Ac 19:1.†
only in neut., as adv. (cf. ἐξώτερος),; of motion, higher: Lk 14:10; of rest, above, before: He 10:8.†
unprofitable: Tit 3:9; neut. as subst., unprofitableness: He 7:18.†
an axe: Mt 3:10, Lk 3:9.†

Part One; of weight, worth (often c. gen., cf. Pr 315, 811), seq. πρός: Ro 8:18 (v. Field, Notes, 157); befitting, meet: c. gen., Mt 3:8, Lk 3:8 23:41, Ac 26:20, I Co 16:4 (v. M, Pr., 216); absol., II Th 1:3; of persons, worthy; Part Two; in good sense: c. gen. rei, Mt 10:10, Lk 7:4 10:7, Ac 13:46, I Ti 1:15 4:9 5:18 6:1; c. aor. inf. (v. M, Pr., 203): Lk 15:19, 21, Act_13:25, Re 4:11 5:2, 4 5:9, 12; seq. ἵνα: Jo 1:27; ἅς, Lk 7:4; absol., but of what understood: Mt 10:11, 13 22:8, Re 3:4; c. gen. pers., Mt 10:37-38, He 11:38; in bad sense; c. gen. rei, Lk 12:48 23:15, Ac 23:29 25:11, 25 26:31, Ro 1:32; absol., Re 16:6 (MM, VGT, s.v.).†

to deem worthy: c. acc et inf. (v. MM, VGT, s.v., and cf. κατ-αξιόω), Lk 7:7; id. et gen. rei, II Th 1:11; pass. c. gen. rei, I Ti 5:17, He 3:3 10:29; to think fit: c. inf. (v. M, Pr., 205), Ac 15:38 28:22.†
worthily: Ro 16:2, Eph 4:1, Phl 1:27; c. gen. (freq. in Inscr.; Deiss., BS, 248; MM, VGT, 51), ἀ. τ. Κυρίου, Col 1:10; τ. θεοῦ I Th 2:12, III Jn 6.†
unseen, invisible: Ro 1:20, Col 1:15-16, I Ti 1:17, He 11:27.†

of a messenger, speaker, or writer, to report, announce, declare: c. acc rei, Ac 4:23, al.; c. dat. pers., Mt 2:8, al.; seq. ὃτι, Lk 18:37; πῶς, Lk 8:36; περί, Lk 7:18 13:1, Ac 28:21, I Th 1:9; λέγων, Ac 22:26; c. acc et inf., Ac 12:14; seq. εἰς, Mk 5:14, Lk 8:34 (MM, VGT, s.v.; Cremer, 25)
to strangle; mid., to hang oneself (or, to choke; v. M, Pr., 155): Mt 27:5.†

to lead away: Lk 13:15, Ac 23:17 24:7 (R, mg.), I Co 12:2; esp. of leading to trial (so as law term in Attic), prison and death (MM, VGT, s.v.): Mt 26:57 27:2, 31, Mk 14:44, 53 15:16, Lk 21:12 22:66 23:26, Ac 12:19; of the direction of a way: Mt 7:13-14 (cf. συν-απ-άγω).†
uninstructed, ignorant: II Ti 2:23.†
to lift off, hence, to take away; pass.: Mt 9:15, Mk 2:20, Lk 5:35.†
to ask back, demand back: Lk 6:30 12:20 (MM, VGT, s.v.).†
prop., to cease to feel pain for (Thuc., ii, 61).; In late Gk.; to despair (Polyb., i, 35, 5); to become callous, reckless (Polyb., xvi, 12, 7; MM, VGT, s.v.): Eph 4:19.†
to remove, release: He 2:15; pass., to depart: Ac 19:12; in legal sense (MM, VGT, s.v.), seq. ἀπό, c. gen. pers., to be quit of: Lk 12:58 (Cremer, 90, 632).†
to alienate, estrange; pass.: Eph 2:12 4:18, Col 1:21 (MM, VGT, s.v.; Cremer, 95, 633).†
tender: Mt 24:32, Mk 13:28.†
to go to meet.; to meet; c. dat.: Mk 14:13, Lk 17:12 (WH, mg., ὑπ-; in Rec. freq. as v.1. for ὑπ-, q.v.).†
usually with v.l., ὑπ-; a meeting; εἰς ἀ., c. gen. or dat., to meet: Mt 25:6 27:32 (WH, txt., omits), Ac 28:15, I Th 4:17 (v. M, Th., in l; M, Pr., 14, 242; MM, VGT, s.v.; Lft., Notes, 69).†
once: II Co 11:25, Heb_9:26-27; ἔτι ἅ., He 12:26-27; ἅ. τ. ἐνιαυτοῦ, He 9:7; καί ἅ. κ. δίς, twice: Phl 4:16, I Th 2:18; once for all: He 6:4 9:28 10:2, I Pe 3:18, Ju 3 5 (MM, VGT, s.v.).†
inviolable, and so unchangeable: He 7:24 (v. Westc., in l; Cremer, 653; MM, VGT, s.v.).†
unprepared: II Co 9:4.†

to deny, i.e. to refuse to recognize, to ignore: c. acc, of oneself (DCG, ii, 598 f.), Mt 16:24, Mk 8:34 (MM, VGT, s.v.), Lk 9:23 (WH, mg., txt., ἀρν-) of Peter's denials of Christ, Mt 26:34-35, 75, Mk 14:30-31, 72, Lk 22:34, 61; pass., Lk 12:9 (Cremer, 111).†
from now, henceforth: Jo 13:19 14:7, Re 14:13.†
completion: Lk 14:28 (cf. MM, VGT, s.v.).†

the beginning of a sacrifice.; first fruits: τοῦ φυράματος (cf. Nu 15:20), Ro 11:16. Metaph., ἀ. τοῦ πνεύματος: Ro 8:23; of Christians: Ro 16:5, 1, I Co 16:15, II Th 2:13 (WH, mg., R, mg., txt., ἀπ' ἀρχῆς; v. Lft., Notes, 119 f.), Ja 1:18, Re 14:4; of Christ: I Co 15:20 15:23 (Cremer, 117; MM, VGT, s.v.).†

all, the whole, altogether: bef. subst. with art., as Lk 3:21; or after, as Mk 16:15]; absol., in masc., as Lk 5:26; in neut., as Ac 2:44; ἅ. οὗτοι, Ac 2:7 (LT); ἅ. ὑμεῖς, Ga 3:28 (TTr.). Most freq. in Lk, Ac (v. MM, VGT, s.v.)
to deceive: c. acc, Ja 1:26; c. acc pers., dat. rei, Eph 5:6; pass., I Ti 2:14 (on its infrequency in late writers, v. MM, VGT, s.v.; cf. ἐξαπατάω).†

deceit, deceitfulness: Col 2:8; τοῦ πλούτου, Mt 13:22, Mk 4:19 (MM, VGT, s.v.); τῆς ἀδικίας, II Th 2:10; τῆς ἁμαρτίας, He 3:13; αἱ ἐπιθυμίαι τῆς ἀ., Eph 4:22. pl., ἀπά ται (v. M, Th., i.e.; NTD, 75; MM, l.c.): II Pe 2:13 (WH, mg., R., txt., ἐν ἀγάπαις).†
fatherless.; without father (MM, VGT, s.v.), i.e., with no recorded genealogy: He 7:3.†
of light beaming from a luminous body, radiance, effulgence: He 1:3.†
disobedience (MM, VGT, s.v.): Ro 11:30, 32, He 4:6, 11; υἱοὶ τῆς ἀ. (gen. of definition, v. M, Pr., 73 f.), Eph 2:2 5:6, Col 3:6 (T, WH R, mg., omit).†
as in cl. (MM, VGT, s.v.); to disobey, be disobedient: absol., Ac 14:2 19:9, Ro 10:21 11:31 15:31, He 3:18 11:31, I Pe 3:20; c. dat., Jo 3:36, Ro 2:8 11:30, I Pe 2:8 3:1 4:17 (Cremer, 475).†
disobedient: absol., Lk 1:17, Tit 1:16 3:3; c. dat., Ac 26:19, Ro 1:30, II Ti 3:2.†
to threaten: I Pe 2:23; mid., Ac 4:17 (v. MM, VGT, s.v., and cf. προσαπειλέω).†
threatening, threat: Ac 4:29 9:1, Eph 6:9.†
to be absent: I Co 5:3, II Co 10:1 10:11 13:2 13:10 Phl 1:27, Col 2:5.†
to depart: Ac 17:10.†
to tell out.; to forbid (III Ki 11:2).; to renounce: 1 aor. mid. (WH, App., 164; MM, VGT, s.v.), II Co 4:2.†
untempted, untried, without experience: Ja 1:13 (v. Hort, in l; MM, VGT, s.v.).†
