without experience of: c. gen. rei, He 5:13 (MM, VGT, s.v.).†
to await or expect eagerly (Lft., Notes, 149; MM, VGT, s.v.): absol., I Pe 3:20; C. acc rei, Ro 8:19, 23 8:25, I Co 1:7, Ga 5:5; c. acc pers., Phl 3:20, He 9:28.†
a putting or stripping off: Col 2:11 (MM, VGT, s.v.).†
to strip off clothes or arms; mid., to strip off from oneself: Col 3:9; to strip, despoil (mid, for act., ICC, in l; but cf. Lft., Ellic.), Col 2:15.†
to drive away: Ac 18:16 (MM, s.v.).†
refutation, disrepute: ἐλθεῖν εἰς ἀ., Ac 19:27 (not elsewhere; v. MM, s.v.).†
a freedman: τ. κυρίου (MM, s.v.), I Co 7:22.†
Apelles: Ro 16:10.†
to give up in despair, despair of (Polyb., Diod., LXX).; to hope to receive from or in return (Field, Notes, 59; Cremer, 712; Soph., Lex., s.v.): c. acc (M; Pr., 65; MM, s.v.), Lk 6:35.†
adv. c. gen. (Hellenistic, common in LXX); over against (MM, s.v.): Mt 27:61, Mk 12:41, WH, mg.; before, in the presence of: Mt 27:24 (WH, mg.), Ac 3:16, Ro 3:18.; against: Ac 17:7.†
endless, interminable: I Ti 1:4.†
without distraction: I Co 7:35.†

uncir­cumcised; metaph. (τ.) καρδίαις (cf. Je 9:26, al.): Ac 7:51 (ἄσημος, found in π., appears to have been the word used by Greek-speaking Egyptians: v. Deiss., BS, 153; cf. also Cremer, 885; MM, s.v.)†

to go away, depart (also, in late writers, with "perfective" force, to arrive at a destination, the thought being carried on to the goal; M, Pr., 111f., 247; MM, s.v.); absol.: Mt 13:25, al.; ptcp., ἀπελθών, used pleonastically with other verbs as in Heb. (Dalman, Words, 21), Mt 13:28, al.; with mention of place or person: εἰς, Mt 14:15; ἐπί, Lk 24:24; πρός, Re 10:9; ἀπό, Lk 1:38; ἐξω, Ac 4:15; ἐκεῖ, Mt 2:22. As in LXX, seq. ὀπίσω, c. gen. (Heb. הָלַךְ אַחֲרֵי), to go after, follow: Mk 1:20, Jo 12:19; metaph., Mk 1:42, Re 21:1.

trans.,; to hold back, keep off; to have in full, to have received (on the " punctiliar " force of the compound, v. M, Pr., 109, 247): c. acc, Mt 6:2, 5 6:16, Lk 6:24, Phl 4:18, Phm 15 (for illustr. from π., where it is used in receipts, v. Deiss., BS, 229; LAE, 110 f.; MM, s.v.); impers., ἀπέχει (Field, Notes, 39), it is enough: Mk 14:41.; Intrans., to be away, distant: absol., Lk 15:20; seq. ἀπό, Mt 14:24 15:8, Mk 7:6, Lk 7:6 15:20 24:13. Mid., to abstain: c. gen., Ac 15:29, I Ti 4:3, I Pe 2:11; seq. ἀπό, Ac 15:20, I Th 4:3 5:22.†

to disbelieve, be faithless: Mk 16:11, 16, Lk 24:11, 41, Ac 28:24, I Pe 2:7; so prob. also Ro 3:3, II Ti 2:13 (ICC, CGT, in ll; MM, s.v.).; = ἀπειθέω (Hdt.; on this sense in Ro, 2Ti, ll. c., v. Vaughan on Ro, l.c.; Lft., Notes, 265; Thayer, s.v.).†
want of faith, unbelief: Mt 13:58, Mk 6:6 9:24 16:14, Ro 3:3 (but v.s. ἀπιστέω) Ro 4:20 11:20, 23, I Ti 1:13, He 3:12, 19 (DCG, ii, 775a; Cremer, 492).†

of things, incredible: Ac 26:8; of persons, without faith or trust, unbelieving: Mt 17:17, Mk 9:19, Lk 9:41 12:46, Jo 20:27, Tit 1:15, Re 21:8; specif., of unbelievers as opp. to Christians: I Co 6:6 7:12-15 10:27 14:22-24, II Co 4:4 6:14-15, I Ti 5:8 (cf. Lft., Notes, 265; Cremer, 491).†

simplicity, sincerity: Ro 12:8, II Co 11:3, Eph 6:5, Col 3:22; as manifested in generous, unselfish giving, liberality, graciousness: II Co 8:2 9:11 9:13 (v. ICC, Ro 12:8; Hort, Ja 1:5, and v.s. ἁπλῶς).†
simple, single: in a moral sense (DCG, ii, 628 f.), ἀφθαλμός, Mt 6:22, Lk 11:34. (In π. of a marriage dowry, v. MM, s.v.).†; ἁπλόος, v.s. ἁπλοῦς

simply, sincerely, graciously: Ja 1:5. ("Later writers comprehend under the one word the whole magnanimous and honour­able type of character in which ... singleness of mind is the central feature "-Hort, Ja., l.c.)†

from (i.e. from the exterior). Of separation and cessation; of motion from a place: Mt 5:29, 30 7:23, Lk 5:2 22:41, al.; in partitive sense (M, Pr., 72, 102, 245; MM, s.v.; Bl., §40, 2), Mt 9:16 27:21, Jo 21:10, Ac 5:2, al.; also after verbs of eating, etc.; of alienation (cl. gen. of separation), after such verbs as λούω (Deiss., BS, 227), λύω, σώζω, παύω, etc.; ἀνάθεμα ἀ., Ro 9:3; ἀποθνήσκειν ἀ., Col 2:20; σαλευθῆναι, II Th 2:2, καθαρός, -ίζειν, ἀ. (Deiss., BS, 196, 216), Ac 20:26, II Co 7:1, He 9:14; of position, Mt 23:34 24:31, al.; after μακράν, Mt 8:30; transposed before measures of distance, Jo 10:18 21:8, Re 14:20 (Abbott, JG, 227); of time, ἀπὸ τ. ὥρας, ἡμέρας, etc., Mt 9:22, Jo 19:27, Ac 20:18, Phl 1:5, al.; ἀπ’ αἰῶνος, Lk 1:70, al.; ἀπ’ ἀρχῆς, etc., Mt 19:4, Ro 1:20; ἀπὸ βρέφους, II Ti 3:15; ἀφ’ ἧς, since, Lk 7:45, al.; ἀπὸ τ. νῦν, Lk 1:48, al.; ἀπὸ τότε, Mt 4:17, al.; ἀπὸ πέρυσι, a year ago, II Co 8:10 9:2; ἀπὸ πρωΐ, Ac 28:23; of order or rank, ἀπὸ διετοῦς, Mt 2:16; ἀπὸ Ἀβραάμ, Mt 1:17; ἐβδομος ἀπὸ Ἀδάμ, Ju 14; ἀπὸ μικροῦ ἕως μεγάλου, Ac 8:10, He 8:11; ἄρχεσθαι ἀπό, Mt 20:8, Jo 8:9, Ac 8:35, al. Of origin; of birth, extraction, and hence, in late writers, of local extraction (cl. ἐξ; Abbott, JG, 227ff.), Mt 21:11, Mk 15:43, Jo 1:45, Ac 10:38, al.; οἱ ἀπὸ Ἰταλίας (WM, §66, 6; M, Pr., 237; Westc, Rendall, in l.), He 13:24; of membership in a community or society (BL, §40, 2), Ac 12:1, al.; of material (= cl. gen.; Bl. l.c.; M, Pr., 102), Mt 3:4 27:21; after verbs of asking, seeking, etc., Lk 11:50, 51 I Th 2:6 (Milligan, in l.); of the cause, instrument, means or occasion (freq. = ὑπό, παρά, and after verbs of learning, hearing, knowing, etc.; Bl., §40, 3), Mt 7:16 11:29, Lk 22:45, Ac 2:22 4:36 9:13 12:14, I Co 11:23, Ga 3:2, al.; ἀπὸ τ. ὄχλου, Lk 19:3 (cf. Jo 21:6, Ac 22:11); ἀπὸ τ. φόβου, Mt 14:26, al. (cf. Mt 10:26 13:44). Noteworthy Hellenistic phrases: φοβεῖσθαι ἀπό (M, Pr., 102, 107); προσέχειν ἀπό (M, Pr., 11. c.; Milligan, NTD, 50); ἀπὸ νότου (Heb. מִגֶּנֶב), Re 21:13; ἀπὸ προσώπου (מִפְּנֵי), II Th 1:9 (Bl., §40, 9); ἀπὸ τ. καρδιῶν (בְּלֵב), Mt 18:35; ἀπὸ ὁ ὤν (WM, §10, 2; M, Pr., 9), Re 1:4. In composition, ἀπό denotes separation, departure, origin, etc. (ἀπολύω, ἀπέρχομαι, ἀπογράφω); it also has a perfective force (M, Pr., 112, 247), as in ἀφικνεῖσθαι, q.v.
to step off, disembark: Lk 5:2, Jo 21:9; metaph., of events, to issue, turn out (Field, Notes, 74): Lk 21:13, Phl 1:19 (MM, s.v.).†
to throw off: Mk 10:50; metaph., to lose, let go (Field, Notes, 231 f.; MM, s.v.): He 10:35.†
to look away from all else at one object; hence, to look steadfastly: He 11:26 (cf. ἀφοράω).†
to be thrown away, rejected: I Ti 4:4 (Hom., Plut.).†
a throwing away, rejection: opp. to πρόσλημψις, Ro 11:15.; a losing, loss: Ac 27:22.†
to be away, removed from.; to depart life, to die (MM, s.v.): τ. ἀμαρτίαις, i.e. with ref. to sins, I Pe 2:24 (Cremer, 149, 668).†
a written copy.; As law term, a deposition (Demos.).; In late writers, a register, enrolment, census (MM, s.v.; Deiss., LAE, 160, 268 f.): Lk 2:2, Ac 5:37.†
to write out, copy.; to enrol; mid., to enrol oneself: Lk 2:1 (M, Pr., 162; but. v. ICC, in l), Lk 2:3, 5; pass., He 12:23 (v. reff, s.v. ἀπογραφή ).†

to bring out, show forth, exhibit (Lft., Notes, 200; ICC, in l): I Co 4:9.; to declare, show: Ac 2:22; to prove: Ac 25:7.; As freq. in late Gk., to proclaim to an office: seq. ὅτι, II Th 2:4 (Milligan, in l; MM, s.v.; Lft., Notes. 113.)†
a showing off.; As used by Gk. philosophers, demonstration, certain proof: I Co 2:4 (v. ICC, in l; MM, s.v.; Lft., Notes, 173).†
= ἀποδεκατόω, q.v.,; to tithe, pay a tenth of: Lk 18:12.†
c. acc rei, to tithe, pay a tenth of: Mt 23:23, Lk 11:42.; C. acc pers., to exact tithes from: He 7:5.; to decimate (Socr., HE, 573 A; v. Kennedy, Sources, 117).†
acceptable: I Ti 2:3 5:4.†
to accept gladly, welcome, receive: Lk 8:40 9:11, Ac 18:27 21:17 28:30; metaph., c. acc rei, Ac 2:41 24:3 (MM, s.v.; Cremer, 688).†
gone abroad (RV, sojourning in another country): Mk 13:34.†

to give up or back, restore, return: Mt 27:58, Lk 4:20 9:42 19:8; esp. of wages, debts, oaths, etc. (MM, s.v.), to render what is due, to pay (Deiss., LAE, 334 f.): absol., Mt 18:25, 28, Lk 7:42. c. acc, Mt 5:26 18:29-30, 34 20:8 21:41 22:21, Mk 12:17, Lk 10:35 12:59 20:25, Ro 13:7, He 12:11, Re 22:2; ὅρκους, Mt 5:33 (cf. Nu 30:3, De 23:21 al.); of conjugal duty, τ. ὀφειλήν, I Co 7:3; ἀμοιβάς, I Ti 5:4; μαρτύριον, to give (as in duty bound) testimony, Ac 4:33; λόγον, to render account, Mt 12:36, Lk 16:2, Ac 19:40, He 13:17, I Pe 4:5; hence of requital, recompense, both in good and bad sense, Mt 6:4, 6 6:18 16:27, Ro 2:6, II Ti 4:8 4:14 Re 18:6 22:12; κακὸν ἀντὶ κακοῦ, Ro 12:17, I Th 5:15, I Pe 3:9. Mid., to give up of one's own, hence to sell (fr. Hdt. on): c. acc rei, Ac 5:8, He 12:16; c. acc pers., Ac 7:9 (cf. ἀνταποδίδωμι) .†
to mark off, hence metaph. to make separations: Ju 19 (Cremer, 806).†
acceptance, approbation (Field, Notes, 203): I Ti 1:15 4:9 (Cremer, 686; MM, s.v.).†
a putting away: I Pe 3:21, II Pe 1:14.†
a storehouse, granary: Mt 3:12 6:26 13:30, Lk 3:17 12:18, 24.†
to treasure up, store away: I Ti 6:19.†
to press hard: Lk 8:45.†

to die: of natural death, Mk 5:35, al.; of violent death (pass. of ἀποκτείνω), esp. of Christ, Mt 26:35, Jo 12:33, He 10:28, al.; of spiritual death, Jo 6:50, Ro 8:13, al.; c. dat. ref., Ro 6:2, 10 14:7, 8, Ga 2:19; acc., ὅ, Ro 6:10; seq. ἐν, Mt 8:32, Jo 8:21, 24 I Co 15:22, He 11:37, Re 14:13; seq. ὑπέρ, περί, Jo 11:50, 51 18:14, Ro 5:6-8 14:15, I Co 15:3, II Co 5:15, I Th 5:10, I Pe 3:18; ἀπό, Col 2:20; ἐκ, Re 8:11; fig., I Co 15:31 (cf. συν-αποθνήσκω, and V. Milligan, NTD, 258f.; DCG, i, 791b; Cremer, 286; MM, s.v.; on the perfective force of this verb, M, Pr., 112, 114; and on the distinction bet. pres. and aor., ib. 113 f.).

to restore, i.e. to a former condition: of health, Mt 12:13, Mk 3:5 8:25, Lk 6:10; of social or political affairs, Mt 17:11, Mk 9:12, Ac 1:6.; to give back, bring back: He 13:19 (so in π., MM, s.v.; cf. also Cremer, 312).†

in general sense (cl.), to reveal, uncover, disclose,; of things: Mt 10:26, Lk 2:35 12:2, I Co 3:13; of persons: pass., Christ, Lk 17:30; Antichrist, II Th 2:3 2:6 2:8; In LXX and NT, in special sense of divine revelation: Mt 11:25 (on the tense, v. M, Pr., 136), ib. Mt 11:27 16:17, Lk 10:21-22, Jo 12:38, Ro 1:17-18 8:18, I Co 2:10 14:30, Ga 1:16 3:23, Eph 3:5, Phl 3:15, I Pe 1:5-12 5:1 (Westc., Eph., 178 f.; M, Th., 149 f.).†

an uncovering, laying bare (Plut.). Metaph., a reveal­ing, revelation: a disclosure of divine truth, or a manifestion from God: Lk 2:32 Ro 2:5 8:19 16:25, I Co 1:7 14:6 14:26, II Co 12:1 12:7, Ga 1:12 2:2, Eph 1:17 3:3 II Th 1:7 I Pe 1:7 1:13 4:13, Re 1:1.†
to watch with outstretched head, watch anxiously (Polyb., π.; v. Deiss., LAE, 374.5, 377 f.), Ro 8:19, Phl 1:20 (Lft., in l; Cremer, 177).†
to reconcile completely: Eph 2:16, Col 1:20-21.†
restoration: Ac 3:21 (in τ. of repairs and restorations of temples, v. MM, s.v.).†
to be laid up, in store, laid away: Lk 19:20. Metaph., C. dat. pers., to be reserved (Dem., Plat.; and v. MM, s.v.): Col 1:5, II Ti 4:8, He 9:27.†
to behead: Mt 14:10, Mk 6:16, 28 Lk 9:9.†
to shut fast: Lk 13:25.†
to cut off: Mk 9:43, 45, Jo 18:10, 26 Ac 27:32. Mid., to mutilate oneself, have oneself mutilated: Ga 5:12 (cf. De 23:1 LXX; and v. Cremer, 751; MM, s.v.).†

prop., a judicial sentence: II Co 1:9, R, mg.; an answer (v. Thayer, s.v.): II Co 1:9, R, txt. (In FlJ, Ant., xiv, 10, 6, of a rescript of the Senate; in Inscr. of an official decision, Deiss., BS, 257; a reply to a deputation, MM, s.v.: cf. also Cremer, 3'75).†

in cl., to separate, distinguish. to choose. Mid., to answer: Mt 27:12, Mk 14:61, Lk 3:16 23:9, Jo 5:17, 19 Ac 3:12. In late Gk. the pass, also is used in this sense, and pass. forms are the more freq. in NT (M, Pr., 39, 161; MM, s.v.); in general sense: absol., Mk 12:34; c. acc. rei, Mt 22:46; c. dat. pers., Mt 12:38; seq. πρός, Ac 25:16; Hebraistically like ענה, to begin to speak, take up the conversation (Kennedy, Sources, 124f.): Mt 11:25, al., redundant, as in the Heb. phrase וַיַּעַן וַיּאֹמֶר (Dalman, Words, 24f., 38; M, Pr., 14; Bl., §58, 4; 74, 2; Cremer, 374): ἀποκριθεὶς εἶπε, Mt 4:4; ἔφη, 8:8; λέγει, Mk 3:33; in Jo most freq. (ἀπεκ. κ. εἶπε, 1:49.
an answering, an answer: Lk 2:47 20:26, Jo 1:22 19:9.†
to hide, conceal, keep secret: c. acc, Lk 10:21; pass., I Co 2:7, Eph 3:9, Col 1:26 (MM, s.v.).†
hidden: Mk 4:22, Lk 8:17, Col 2:3 (v. Lft., in l; MM, s.v.).†
to kill: Mt 14:5, al.; seq. instr. ἐν (q.v.), Eph 2:16, Re 2:23, al. Metaph.: Ro 7:11; τ. ἔχθραν, Eph 2:16; τὸ γράμμα ἀποκτείνει II Co 3:6 (on the perfective force of this verb, v. M, Pr., 114)

prop., "the medical word for birth as the close of pregnancy" (Hort, Ja., 26 f.). In κοιν, "an ordinary syn. of τίκτω, but definitely 'perfectivised' (M, Pr., 111 ff.; MM, s.v.) by the; ἀπό, and so implying safe delivery," to bring forth, give birth to: Ja 1:15, 18.†
to roll away: Mt 28:2, Mk 16:3, Lk 24:2.†

to receive from another; absol., to receive as one's due: Lk 16:25 18:30 (v.l. λάβῃ) Lk 23:41, Ro 1:27, Ga 4:5, Col 3:24, II Jn 8.; to receive back: Lk 6:34 15:27.; to take apart or aside: Mk 7:33 (cf. use in π. of the recluses of the Serapeum; MM, s.v.).†
enjoyment: I Ti 6:17, He 11:26 (for late exx., v. MM, s.v.).†
to leave, leave behind (in π. a term. techn. in wills; v. MM, s.v.): II Ti 4:13 4:20, Tit 1:5; pass., to be reserved, remain: He 4:6, 9 10:26.; to desert, abandon: Ju 6.†
to lick up: Lk 16:21, Rec.†

Act.,; to destroy utterly, destroy, kill: Mk 124, 922, al.; τ. ψνχήν, Mt 10:28, al.; to lose utterly: Mt 10:42, al.; metaph., of failing to save, Jo 6:39 18:9.; Mid.,; to perish; of things: Mt 5:29, Jo 6:12, He 1:11 (LXX, al.; of persons: Mt 8:26, al. Metaph., of loss of eternal life, Jo 3:15-16 10:28 17:12, Ro 2:12, I Co 8:11 15:18, II Pe 3:9. In οἱ ἀπολλὺμενοι, the perishing, contrasted in I Co 1:18, al., with οἱ σωζόμενοι, the "perfective" force of the verb, WH. " implies the completion of the process of destruction," is illustrated (v. M, Pr., 114 f.; M, Th., ii, 2:10); to be lost: Lk 15:4 21:18. Metaph., on the basis of the relation between shepherd and flock, of spiritual destitution and alienation from God: Mt 10:6 15:24, Lk 19:10 (MM, s.v.; DCG, i, 191 f., ii, 76, 554; Cremer, 451)
Apollyon, i.e. the Destroyer: Re 9:11 (cf. Ἀβάδδων). (Cremer, 453; DB, i, 125, 172.) †
Apollonia, a city of Macedonia: Ac 17:1.†

to defend: c. acc, Ro 2:15.; to defend one's self: absol., Lk 21:14, Ac 26:1; seq. ὅτι, Ac 25:8; τί, to adduce something in one's defence, Lk 12:11, Ac 26:24 (ταῦτα) Ac 24:10 (τὰ περὶ ἐμαυτοῦ); περί, c. gen. rei, and ἐπί, c. gen. pers., Ac 26:2; c. dat. pers., Ac 19:33, II Co 12:19.†
a speech in defence: Ac 25:16, II Co 7:11, Phl 1:7, 16, II Ti 4:16; c. dat. pers., I Co 9:3, I Pe 3:15; seq. πρός, Ac 22:1.†
to wash off, wash away; mid., metaph., c. acc rei, to wash off oneself: ἀμαρτίας, Ac 22:16; absol., ἀπελούσασθε, ye washed yourselves clean (cf. Cremer, 406), I Co 6:11.†

release effected by pay­ment of ransom, redemption, deliverance; metaph., He 11:35; of deliverance thr. Christ from evil and the consequences of sin: Lk 21:28, Ro 3:24 (Vau., in l) 8:23, I Co 1:30, Eph 1:7, 14 4:30, Col 1:14, He 9:15. (On the extent to WH. the word retains the sense of ransom, v. ICC, Ro 3:24, Westc., He., 297 ff.; v. also ICC, Eph., 11; DCG, ii, 605; Cremer, 410; Deiss., LAE, 331; Lft., Notes, 271, 316; Tr., Syn., § 77.)†

to set free, release: Lk 13:12, Jo 19:10, al.; a debtor, Mt 18:27; metaph., of forgive­ness, Lk 6:37.; to let go, dismiss (Field, Notes, 9 f.): Mt 15:23, Lk 2:29 9:12, Ac 19:41, al.; of divorce, τ. γυναῖκα: Mt 1:19 5:31-32 19:3, 8 19:10 Mk 10:2, 4 10:11, Lk 16:18; with ref. to Gk. and Rom. (net Jewish) custom, τ. ἄνδρα: Mk 10:12. Mid., to depart: Ac 28:25 (MM, s.v.)
to wipe off, wire clean: mid., Lk 10:11.†
to assign, apportion: I Pe 3:7. (In π. of a Prefect who renders to all their dues; v. MM, s.v.)†
to wash off: mid. (reflex.), τ. χεῖρας, Mt 27:24.†
to fall off: Ac 9:18.†
to cause to go astray; metaph., of leading into error: Mk 13:22; pass., to be led astray: I Ti 6:10.†
to sail away: Ac 13:4 14:26 20:15 27:1 (Burton, 159).†
to wash off: v.l. for πλύνω, Lk 5:2, Rec.†
to choke: Mt 13:7, Lk 8:7; pass., of drowning (= καταποντίζομαι), Lk 8:33.†
to be at a loss, be perplexed: absol., Mk 6:20 (ἐποίει, R, mg.); mid., be in doubt: absol., II Co 4:8; c. acc, Ac 25:20; seq. περί, Lk 24:4; ἐν, Ga 4:20; περὶ τίνος λέγει, Jo 13:22.†
perplexity: Lk 21:25 (MM, s.v.; on the construction, v. Field, Notes, 74 f.).†
to throw away, cast forth: reflexively, Ac 27:43 (BV, cast themselves overboard; v. MM, s.v.).†
to be bereaved (prop., of a parent, Lft., Notes, 36); metaph., I Th 2:17 (where Field thinks it = χωρισθέντες, Notes, 199).†
to pack and carry off; mid., to pack and remove one's goods: Ac 21:15, Rec. (v. ἐπισ-).†; ἐπι-σκευάζω,; to equip, make ready; mid., to make one's preparations: Ac 21:15.†
a shadow: Ja 1:17 (MM, s.v.).†
to draw off or away, tear away (MM, s.v.): Ac 20:30; μάχαιραν, draw a sword, Mt 26:51; pass., to be parted or withdrawn (Field, Notes, 134; but v. Thayer, s.v.), Lk 22:41, Ac 21:1.†

defection, apostasy, revolt; in late Gk. (MM, Exp., viii; Lft., Notes, 111; Cremer, 308) for cl. ἀπόστασις, freq. in sense of political revolt, in LXX (e.g. Jos 22:22, II Ch 29:19, Je 2:19) and NT always of religious apostasy: Ac 21:21, II Th 2:3.†

in cl., only in phrase ἀποστασίου δίκη, an action against a freedman for forsaking his προστάτης (Dem.).; In LXX, βιβλίον ἀποστασίου, a bill of divorce: Mt 19:7, Mk 10:4; in same sense ἀ. alone (MM, s.v.), Mt 5:31 (for other late exx., v. MM, l.c.; Kennedy, Sources, 121).†
to unroof: Mk 2:4.†

prop., to send away, to dispatch on service; to send with a commission, or on service; of persons: Christ, Mt 10:40; the apostles, 10:16; servants, Mk 12:2; angels, 13:27; of things: ὄνος, Mt 21:3; τὸ δρέπανον, Mk 4:29; τ. λόγον, Ac 10:36; τ. ἐπαγγελίαν (i.e. the promised Holy Spirit), Lk 24:49, Rec.; seq. εἰς, Mt 20:2, Lk 11:49, Jo 3:17; ὀπίσω, Lk 19:14; ἔμπροσθεν, Jo 3:28; πρὸ προσώπου, Mt 11:10; πρός, Mt 21:34; with ref. to sender or place of departure: ἀπό, Lk 1:26 (Rec. ὑπό); παρά, Jo 1:6; ἐκ, ib. 1:19; ὑπό, Ac 10:17 (Rec. ἀπό); seq. inf., Mk 3:14, al.; ἵνα, Mk 12:2, al.; εἰς (of purpose), He 1:14; without direct obj.: seq. πρός, Jo 5:33; λέγων, Jo 11:3; ἀποστείλας, c. indic., Mt 2:16, Ac 7:14, Re 1:1. to send away, dismiss: Lk 4:18, Mk 5:10 8:26 12:3 (cf. ἐξ-, συν-αποστέλλω).

to defraud, deprive of, despoil (in cl. chiefly of the misappropriation of trust funds, Field, Notes, 33; cf. MM, s.v.): absol., Mk 10:19, I Co 6:8; c. acc pers., I Co 7:5. Mid., endure deprivation: I Co 6:7 (WM, § 38, 3; but v. Bl., § 54, 5; M, Pr., 162); pass., ἀπεστερημένοι, bereft of: I Ti 6:5.†

In cl., a sending away (MM, s.v.), as, an expedition (Hdt.).; In LXX; discharge, dis­missal (Ec 8:8); a gift (III Ki 9:16, I Mac 2:13).; In NT, the office of an Apostle of Christ, apostleship: Ac 1:25, Ro 1:5, I Co 9:2, Ga 2:8 (Cremer, 530).†

a fleet, an expedition (Dem.).; a messenger, one sent on a mission (Hdt., LXX, l.c., and π.; v. M, Pr., 37 f.; MM, s.v.; M, Th., i, 2:7 and reff.): Jo 13:16, II Co 8:23 Phl 2:25.; In NT, an Apostle of Christ; with special ref. to the Twelve: Mt 10:2, Mk 3:14, Lk 11:49, Eph 3:5, Re 18:20, al., equality with whom is claimed by St. Paul, Ga 1:1, 11 ff, I Ti 2:7, a1.; in a wider sense of prominent Christian teachers, as Barnabas, Ac 14:14, apparently also Silvanus and Timothy, I Th 2:6, and perhaps Andronicus and Junias (Junia?), Ro 16:7 (v. ICC, in l); of false teachers, claiming apostleship: II Co 11:5 11:13, Re 2:2. (On the different uses of the term in NT, v. Lit., Gal., 92-101; Cremer, 530; DB, i, 126; DCG, i, 105; Enc. Br., ii, 196 ff.)
In cl., to speak from memory, to dic­tate to a pupil (Plat.).; In late Gk., to catechize, question: Lk 11:53 (MM, s.v.).†

trans., c. acc,; to turn away, remove: Ro 11:26, II Ti 4:4; metaph., to turn away from allegiance, pervert: Lk 23:14; to turn back, return: μάχαιραν, Mt 26:52. Pass., reflex., to turn oneself away from: c. acc, Mt 5:42, II Ti 1:15, Tit 1:14, He 12:25; so act., absol., Ac 3:26 (cf. Si 8:5; Bl., § 53, 1; Cremer, 880).†
to abhor: Ro 12:9.†
expelled from the congregation (Field, Notes, 96), excommunicated: Jo 9:22 12:42 16:2 (Cremer, 64, 607).†
to set apart. Mid., in late Gk. (El., § 37, 1; Swete, Mk., 136 f.; MM, e. dat.,; to take leave of: Mk 6:46, Lk 9:61, Ac 18:18, 21, II Co 2:13; to forsake: Lk 14:33.†
to bring to an end, complete, accomplish (cf. MM, s.v.): Lk 13:32, Ja 1:15.†

to put off or aside; in NT always mid.,; to put of from oneself as a garment: τ. ἱμάτια, Ac 7:58; metaph., in ethical sense, to put of, lay aside: Ro 13:12, Eph 4:22, 25, Col 3:8, He 12:1, Ja 1:21, I Pe 2:1; to stow away, put: ἐν τ. φυλακῇ (MM, s.v.), Mt 14:3.†
to shake of: Lk 9:5, Ac 28:5.†
to pay off, repay: Phm 19 (MM, s.v.).†
to be quite bold, make a bold venture: Ro 10:20.†
steepness, sharpness; metaph., severity (MM, s.v.): Ro 11:22.†
abruptly, curtly, hence sharply, severely: II Co 13:10, Tit 1:13 (MM, s.v.).†
to turn away; mid., to turn oneself away from: c. acc, II Ti 3:5.†
absence (Æsch., Thuc.): Phl 2:12,; deficiency, waste (MM, s.v).†
to carry off, bear, or lead away: c. acc, Mk 15:1, I Co 16:3, Re 17:3 21:10. Pass., Lk 16:22, Ac 19:12.†
to flee from, escape: c. acc, II Pe 2:18 2:20; c. gen., II Pe 1:4.†
to speak forth, give utterance: Ac 2:4, 14 26:25 (MM, s. v.).†
to discharge a cargo (Field, Notes, 134), to unlade: c. acc, τ. γόμον, Ac 21:3.†
abuse, misuse: Col 2:22 (MM, s.v.).†
to go away, depart, withdraw: seq. ἀπό, Mt 7:23, Lk 9:39, Ac 13:13 (absol., Lk 20:20, Tr., mg.).†
to separate, part asunder: pass., Re 6:14; reflexively, to separate oneself: Ac 15:39.†
to breathe out life, expire (Thue.; LXX, l.c.).; to leave off breathing, faint (Hom., Od., xxiv, 348): seq. ἀπό, Lk 21:26.†
Appius; Ἀππίου Φόρον, Appii Forum (Market of Appius), a town in Italy: Ac 28:15.†
unapproachable: φῶς, I Ti 6:16.†
act., not causing to stumble: metaph., of not leading others into sin, I Co 10:32.; Pass., not stumbling, without offence, blameless: Ac 24:16, Phl 1:10 (for exx., v. MM, s.v.).†
without respect of persons, impartially: I Pe 1:17.†
without stumbling, sure-footed: metaph. (MM, s.v.), Ju 24.†

prop., to fasten to; hence, of fire, to kindle, light: Lk 8:16 11:33 15:8, Ac 28:2. Mid., c. gen., to fasten oneself to, cling to, lay hold of (so in π.; MM, s.v.): Mt 8:3, 15, Jo 20:17, al.; of carnal intercourse, I Co 7:1; with reference to levitical and ceremonial prohibitions, II Co 6:17, Col 2:21; of hostile action, I Jn 5:18 (cf. ἀν-, καθ-, περι- άπτω)
Apphia: Phm 2 (MM, s.v.).†
to thrust away. Mid., to thrust away from oneself, refuse, reject: c. acc pers. (MM, s.v.), Ac 7:27, 39 13:46, Ro 11:1-2, I Ti 1:19.†

destruction, waste, loss, perishing (in π., of money, v. MM, s.v.): Mt 26:8, Mk 14:4, Ac 8:20, Ro 9:22, I Ti 6:9, II Pe 2:1; in special sense of the loss of eternal life, perdition, the antithesis of σωτηρία: Mt 7:13, Jo 17:12, Phl 1:28 3:19, II Th 2:3, He 10:39, II Pe 2:3 3:7 3:16, Re 17:8, 11 (DB, iii, 744).†
a prayer (MM, s.v.).; (as in Homer) a curse, malediction: Ro 3:14 (LXX),†

then: prop. (as in cl.), the second word in the sentence, Ro 7:21 8:1, Ga 3:7; ἐπεὶ ἄρα, I Co 7:14 (with another word between) 5:10; as the first word, Lk 11:48, Ac 11:18, Ro 10:17, I Co 15:18, II Co 5:15 7:12, He 4:9; so prop. in apodosis after protasis with εἰ, Mt 12:28, Lk 11:20, Ga 2:21 3:29 5:11, He 12:8 (κενὸν ἄρα), I Co 15:14; often in interrogations, direct and indirect, τίς (τί) ἄρα, Mt 18:1 19:25, 27 24:45, Mk 4:41, Lk 1:66 8:25 12:42 22:23, Ac 12:18; εἰ ἄρα, Mk 11:13, Ac 8:22; εἴπερ ἄρα, I Co 15:15; οὐκ ἄρα, Ac 21:38; μήτι ἄρα, II Co 1:17; in strengthened forms, ἄρα γε, ἄραγε, Mt 7:20 17:26, Ac 17:27, and more freq. ἄρα οὖν (Epp. Paul.), so then, Ro 5:18 7:3, 25 8:12 9:16, 18 14:19, Ga 6:10, Eph 2:19, I Th 5:6, II Th 2:15 (Bl., §77, 2; 78, 5; MM, s.v.).†

implying anxiety or impatience, "quite rare and only in Luke and Paul, therefore a literary word" (Bl., §77, 2). (num igitur) expecting a neg. reply, Lk 18:8; ἆρά γε, Ac 8:30. (ergone) in apodosis, expecting an affirm. reply, Ga 2:17 (Bl., l.c.; Lft., Ga., in l.; MM, s.v.).†
Arabia: Ga 1:17 4:25.†
Aram: Mt 1:3-4, Lk 3:33 (R, txt., WH, Ἀρνεί).†
without seam: Jo 19:23.†
an Arabian: Ac 2:11.†
to be idle; τὸ κρίμα . . . ἀ., lingers (cf. MGr. ἀργά, late: MM, s.v.): II Pe 2:3.†
inactive, idle: Mt 20:3, 6, I Ti 5:13, Tit 1:12, II Pe 1:8. Metaph., of things, inactive, ineffective, worthless: ῥῆμα, Mt 12:36; πίστις, Ja 2:20 (v. Cremer, 259 f.).†
of silver: Ac 19:24 (WH, br.), II Ti 2:20, Re 9:20.†

prop., a piece of silver (Lft., Notes, 191); in NT,; silver: Ac 3:6 7:16 19:19 20:33, I Co 3:12, I Pe 1:18; money: Mt 25:18, 27, Mk 14:11, Lk 9:3 19:15, 23 22:5, Ac 8:20; a silver coin: p1., Mt 26:15 27:3-6, 9 28:12, 15, where the value is that of a shekel or tetradrachm; ἀργυρίου μυριάδες πέντε (prob. drachmas; MM, s.v.), Ac 19:19.†
a silversmith: Ac 19:24 (Plut.; 77., v. MM, s.v.).†
silver (on its relation to ἀργύριον, v. MM, s.v.): Mt 10:9, Ac 17:29, Ja 5:5, Re 18:12.†
Hill of Pres or Mars, Areopagus; also, the Court of Areopagus, the highest tribunal of Athens: Ac 17:19, 22.†
a judge of the Court of Areopagus: Ac 17:34.†
pleasing, desire to please: Col 1:19 In Gk. writers (Arist., Polyb.), most freq. in bad sense, but in π., Inscr., and in Philo, as above (v. Deiss., BS, 224; MM, s.v.; Cremer, 642).†

to please (Hom., Hdt., al.): c. dat. pers., Mt 14:6, Mk 6:22, Ro 8:8 15:2, I Th 2:15 4:1, I Co 7:32-34 Ga 1:10, II Ti 2:4; seq. ἐνώπισν (= Heb. בּעֵנֵי, Bl., § 37, 1; 40, 7), Ac 65.; In late Gk., esp. in Inscr., to render service to (v. M, Th., ICC, 1 Co., ll c.; Cremer, 640 f.); Ro 15:1, 3, I Co 10:33, I Th 2:4.†

pleasing, agreeable (Hdt., Xen., and later writers; v. Cremer, 641 f; MM, s.v.): c. dat. pers., Jo 8:29, Ac 12:3; seq. ἐνώπιον, c. gen. (Bl., § 37, 1; 40, 7), I Jn 3:22; ἀρεστόν ἐστιν, c. acc et inf (El., § 69, 5; 72, 5), Ac 6:2.†
Aretas, an Arabian king: II Co 11:32 (Deiss., BS, 183 f., thinks the proper spelling Ἀρέθας was changed, as Schürer suggests, "by desire to Hellenise a barbaric name by assimilation to ἀρετή").†

prop., whatever procures pre-eminent estimation for a person or thing, in Hom. any kind of conspicuous advantage. Later confined by philos. writers to intrinsic eminence-moral goodness, virtue; of God: II Pe 1:3; of men: Phl 4:8, II Pe 1:5; pl. (Isa, Es, ll. c.), excellencies: I Pe 2:9 (the usage appears to be a survival of an early comprehensive sense in which the original idea is blended with the impression which it makes on others, i.e. praise, renown; v. Hort, 1 Pe., 129. Deiss., BS, 95 f., thinks it means manifestations of divine power, as in current Gk. speech; cf. also MM, s.v.)†
a lamb: Lk 10:3.†
to number (esp. for payment, MM, s.v.): Mt 10:30, Lk 12:7, Re 7:9.†
number, a number: Lk 22:3, Jo 6:10, Ac 4:4 5:36 6:7 11:21 16:5, Ro 9:27, Re 5:11 7:4 9:16 13:17-18 15:2 20:8 (for exx. of mystical use in π., v. MM, s.v.).†
Aristarchus: Ac 19:29 20:4 27:2, Col 4:10, Phm 24
prop., to breakfast: Jo 21:12, 15; In late Gk., to take a meal, dine: Lk 11:37.†
left, on the left: ὅπλα, II Co 6:7; ἡ ἀ.. (sc. χείρ), Mt 6:3; ἐξ ἀριστερῶν, on the left (MM, s.v. ): Mk 10:37, Lk 23:33.†
Aristobulus, a Christian: Ro 16:10.†
1, prop., breakfast.; In late Gk. = cl. δεῖτνον, dinner: Mt 22:4, Lk 11:38 14:12.†
sufficient: Mt 6:34 (on the neut., v. B1., § 31, 2); seq. ἵνα (M, Pr., 210), Mt 10:25; c. inf., I Pe 4:3 (for exx., v. Deiss., BS, 257; MM, s.v.).†

to keep off; c. dat., to assist.; to suffice: c. dat. pers., Jo 67, II Co 12:9; impers., Mt 25:9, Jo 14:8 (MM, s.v.). Pass., to be satisfied: c. dat. rei, Lk 3:14, I Ti 6:8, He 13:5; seq. ἐπί, III Jn 10.†
a bear: Re 13:2. (This form is also found in late Inscr.; MM, s.v.)†
a chariot: Ac 8:28-29, 38, Re 9:9.†
Ἅρ,; indecl., Re 16:16, see, Ἁρμαγεδών; Μαγεδών,; Magedon: Re 16:16 (WH, Ἅρ M. for Ἁρμαγεδών, q.v.).†
to fit, join.; of marriage, to betroth. Mid.,; to join to oneself, marry, take to wife; (b) to give in marriage: II Co 11:2 (for this there is no direct parallel. But v. M, Pr., 160; MM, s.v.).†
a joining, joint: He 4:12.†
Arnei: Lk 3:33.†

to deny, say no, opp. to είπεῖν: absol., Mt 26:70, Lk 8:45; seq. ἅτι, I Jn 2:22; c. inf., He 11:24; In late Gk. (MM, s.v.), c. acc pers., to deny, refuse to acknowledge, disown: Ac 3:14 7:35; Ἰησοῦν, Mt 10:33, II Ti 2:12, I Jn 2:22, Ju 4; ἑαυτόν, Lk 9:23, II Ti 2:13 (prove false to); C. acc rei (in cl. to refuse), to deny, abjure: I Ti 5:8, Tit 2:12, II Ti 3:5 (cf. ἀπαρνέομαι)
a little lamb, a lamb: Jo 21:15, Re 2:7.†
later form of ἀρόω, to plough (MM, s.v.): Lk 17:7, I Co 9:10.†
a plough: Lk 9:62.†
pillage, plundering, robbery: Mt 23:25, Lk 11:39, He 10:34.†

prop., acc, to the rule of its formation (Bl., § 27, 2), actively, the act of seizing, robbery (Plut., Deu Puer. Educ., p. 12A), Phl 2:6, AV (Waterland, Works, II, 108; Cremer, 649 f.; Meyer, in l; cf. also JThS, July, 1909, April, 1911; MM, s.v.).; Passively = ἅρπαγμα (Ez 22:25, of a lion's prey, ), a thing seized, hence, a prize: Phi, l.c., RV (Lft., Ellic., ICC, in l; Donaldson, NCrat., 450 ff.; and esp. Gifford, The Incarnation, 59-71, and reff. in DB, ii, 835 B). The lexical data favour the active meaning, but as they also admit the possibility of the alternative, most modern expositors have accepted the latter as seeming to suit the logic of the passage better. The lexical difficulty, however, remains (MM, s.v., esp. the last ref.). As to the usage of St. Paul, he seems inclined to adopt the -μα form where it is appropriate (e.g. Ro 11:9, where cf. LXX; I Co 13:9, 2 Co 19), and there is certainly a presumption in favour of the active meaning here from the fact that he does not use the LXX ἅρπαγμα. Suggestions looking to a fresh exegesis are given in JThS, ll c.†

to seize, catch up, snatch away, carry off by force: c. acc rei, Mt 12:29 13:19, Jo 10:12, 28-29; τ. βασιλείαν τ. θεοῦ, Mt 11:12; c. acc pers., Jo 6:15, Ac 8:39 23:10, Ju 23; pass., seq. ἕως, II Co 12:2; εἰς, II Co 12:4, I Th 4:17; πρός, Re 12:5 (cf. δι-, συν-αρπάζω, and v. MM, s.v.).†
rapacious: Mt 7:15, Lk 18:11; as subst., a swindler, an extortioner (MM, s.v.), I Co 5:10-11 6:10.†

an earnest, part payment in advance for security, a first instalment: II Co 1:22 5:5, Eph 1:14. (The word is found in cl. and was prob. brought to Greece by the Phænicians (AR, Eph., l.c.). It is found in π. with both spellings (v. Milligan, NTD, 73). In MGr. ἀρραβῶνα is an engagement ring; v. MM, s.v.)†
unspoken (Hom., al.).; unspeakable (Hat., al.; freq. in Inscr.; MM, s.v.): II Co 12:4.†
feeble, sickly: Mt 14:14, Mk 6:5, 13 16:18, I Co 11:30.†
a sodomite: I Co 6:9, I Ti 1:10.†
Artemas: Tit 3:12.†
Artemis, an Asiatic goddess, to be disting. from the Gk. goddess of the same name: Ac 19:24, 27-28
a fore-sail or top-sail: Ac 27:40 (v. DB, ext., 366b, 399a; MM, s.v.).†

of coincidence, denoting strictly present time, as contrasted with past or future, just, just now, this moment: Mt 3:15 9:18 26:53, Jo 13:7, Ga 4:20, I Th 3:6 (v. Lft., Notes, 44; Milligan, in l), Re 12:10; opp. to past time, Jo 9:19, 25 13:33, I Co 16:7, Ga 1:9-10; to future, Jo 13:37 16:12, 31, I Co 13:12, II Th 2:7, I Pe 1:6 1:8; ἄχρι τῆς ἅ. ὥρας, I Co 4:11; ἕως ἄ., Mt 11:12, Jo 2:10 5:17 16:24, I Co 4:13 8:7 15:6, I Jn 2:9; ἀπ' ἄ., v.s. ἀπάρτι (v. Rutherford, NPhr., 70 f; MM, s.v.).†
new-born: I Pe 2:2 (Luc.).†
fitted, complete: II Ti 3:17 (MM, s.v.).†

bread, a loaf: Mt 4:3, 4 Mk 3:20, al.; ἄρτοι τ. προθέσεως, bread of the setting forth, i.e. the shewbread. Metaph., ὁ ἄ. τ. θεοῦ, τ. ζωῆς, ref. to Christ, Jo 6:33, 35; in general, food: Mt 6:11, al.; ἄ. φαγεῖν (Heb. אֲכֹל לֶחֶם), to eat (MM, s.v.), Lu 14:1, al.
to arrange, make ready (Hom.).; Of food (as in comic writers), to season (MM, s.v.): Mk 9:50, Lk 14:34, Col 4:6.†
Arphaxad: Lk 3:36.†
archangel, a chief angel: I Th 4:16, Ju 9 (Cremer, 24; MM, s.v.).†
Archelaus, son of Herod the Great, King of Judma, Samaria and Idumæa: Mt 2:22.†

beginning, origin; absol., of the beginning of all things: of God as the Eternal, the First Cause, Re 21:6 (cf. 18); similarly, of Christ, Re 22:13; of Christ as the uncreated principle, the active cause of creation, Re 3:14; in his relation to the Church, Col 1:18; ἐν ἀ., Jo 1:1-2; ἀπ' ἀ. (and ἀπ' ἀ. κτισεως), Mt 19:4, 8 24:21, Mk 10:6 13:19, Jo 8:44, II Th 2:13, II Pe 3:4, I Jn 1:1 Jn 2:13-14 Jn 2:24; κατ ἀρχἀς, He 1:10; relatively: He 7:3; ἀ. ὠδίνων, Mt 24:8, Mk 13:9; τ. σημείων, Jo 2:11; τ. ὑποστάσεως, He 3:14; τ. λογίων, He 5:12; ὁ τ. ἀρχῆς τ. Χριστοῦ λόγος, the account of the beginning, the elementary view of Christ, He 6:1; ἀρχὴν λαμβάνειν, to begin, He 2:3; ἐξ ἀ., Jo 6:64 16:4; ἀπ' ἀ., Lk 1:2, Jo 15:27, I Jn 2:7 Jn 2:24 Jn 3:11, II Jn 5-6; ἐν ἀ., Ac 11:15 26:4, Phl 4:15; τὴν ἀρχήν, adverbially, at all (Hdt., al.; v MM, s.v.): Jo 8:25.; an extremity, a corner: Ac 10:11 11:5.; sovereignty, principality, rule (cf. DB, i, 616 f.): Lk 12:11 20:20, Ro 8:38, I Co 15:24, Eph 1:21 3:10 6:12, Col 1:16 2:10, 15 Tit 3:1, Ju 6 (Cremer, 113).†

beginning, originating: more freq., as subst.; founder, author (Lat. auchor; so some­times in π., v. MM, s.v.; Milligan, NTD, 75): Ac 3:15 (R, mg.), He 2:10 (R, txt.; but v. Westc., in l, and Page, Ac., l.c.).; prince, leader (so in MGr., v. Kennedy, Sources, 153): Ac 3:15 (R, txt.) Ac 5:31, He 2:10 (cf. R, mg.) 122 (Cremer, 117).†
high-priestly: Ac 4:6

high-priest: Mk 2:26 14:47, al.; of Christ: He 2:17 3:1, al. In pl., chief priests, including ex-high-priests and members of high-priestly families: Mt 2:4, Mk 8:31, al. (Cremer, 294; DCG, i, 297f.; MM, s.v.).
found on an Egyptian mummy label (Deiss., LAE, 97 ff.; cf. MM, s.v.); used by modem Greeks of tribal chiefs; chief shepherd. of Christ, I Pe 5:4.†
Archippus: Col 4:17, Phm 2.†
ruler of a synagogue, an administrative officer, supervising the worship (הַכְּנֵםֶת רֹאשׁ): Mk 5:22, 35-36 5:38 Lk 8:49 13:14, Ac 13:15 18:8, 17 (Inscr., v. MM, s.v.; cf. also DB, ext., 101).†
a master-builder, architect: I Co 3:10 (in π. of building contractors, MM, s.v.).†
a chief tax-collector, chief publican: Lk 19:2.†
the superintendent of a banquet, whose duty it was to arrange the tables and food (DB, ii, 253): Jo 2:8-9.†

to begin.; to rule (v. DCG, ii, 538b.): c. gen., Mk 10:42, Ro 15:12. Mid., to begin: seq. ἀπό, Mt 16:21 20:8, Lk 14:18 23:5 24:27, 47, Jo 8:9, Ac 1:22 8:35 10:37, I Pe 4:17; c. inf., an Aramaic pleonasm, Mk 1:45 2:23 5:17, Lk 3:8, al. (v. M, Pr 14:1-35 f.; Dalman, Words, 27; MM, s.v.)

a ruler, chief: Jesus, Re 1:5; rulers of nations, Mt 20:25, Ac 4:26 7:35; magistrates, Ac 23:5, Ro 13:3; judges, Lk 12:58, Ac 7:27, 35 16:19; members of the Sanhedrin, Lk 14:1 23:13, 35 24:20, Jo 3:1 7:26, 48 12:42, Ac 3:17 4:5, 8 13:27 14:5; rulers of synagogues, Mt 9:18, 23, Lk 8:41 18:18; οἱ ἄ. τ. αἰῶνος τούτου, I Co 2:6-8; of the devil: ἄ. τῶν δαιμονίων, Mt 9:34 12:24, Mk 3:22, Lk 11:15; ὁ ἄ. τοῦ κόσμου, Jo 12:31 14:30 16:11; ἄ. τ. ἐξουσίας τ. ἀέρος, Eph 2:2 (MM, s.v.; DB, iii, 838; Ext., 99 f; DCG, ii, 419; DCG, s.v. Archon).†
unmoved, immovable: Ac 27:41; metaph., He 12:28.†
Asaph, an obvious error for Ἀσά, found in the best texts, and adopted by LTTr. and WH, R, mg.: Mt 1:7-8.†
unquenched, unquenchable: πῦρ, Mt 3:12, Mk 9:43, Lk 3:17.†

ungodliness, impiety: Ro 1:18 11:26, II Ti 2:16, Tit 2:12; ἔργα ἀσεβείας, ungodly deeds, Ju 15; ἐπιθυηίαι τ. ἀσεβειῶν, desires for ungodly things or deeds, Ju 18 (DB, iv, 532; Cremer, 523; MM, s.v.).†
to be ungodly, act profanely: II Pe 2:6; c. cogn. acc (MM, s.v.), Ju 15.†
un­godly, impious: Ro 4:5 5:6, I Ti 1:9, I Pe 4:18, II Pe 2:5-6 3:7, Ju 4 15.†
licentiousness, wantonness, excess: Mk 7:22, Ro 13:13, II Co 12:21, Ga 5:19 (Lft., in l), Eph 4:19, I Pe 4:3, II Pe 2:2 2:7 2:18, Ju 4.†
without mark (in π. of an uncircumcised boy: Deiss., BS, 153; MM, s.v.). Metaph. (MM, s.v.), unknown, obscure: litotes, οὐκ ἄ (Eur., al.), πόλις, Ac 21:39.†
Asher: Lk 2:36, Re 7:6.†

to be weak, feeble: Ac 20:35, Ro 8:3, II Co 11:21 12:10 13:4 13:9; c. dat., πίστει (Cremer, 527), Ro 4:19 14:1; same implied, Ro 14:2, 21, I Co 8:11-12, II Co 11:29; εἰς, II Co 13:3. Specif., of bodily debility, to be sick: Mt 25:36, 39, Lk 4:40, Jo 4:46 5:3, 7 5:13 11:1-3, 6 Ac 9:37, Phl 2:26-27, II Ti 4:20, Ja 5:14; οἱ ἀσθενοῦντες, the sick: Mt 10:8 (MM, s.v.), Mk 6:56, Lk 9:2, Ac 19:12.†
an infirmity (MM, s.v.): Ro 15:1.†

without strength, weak, feeble: I Co 1:27 4:10 12:22, II Co 10:10, Ga 4:9, I Th 5:14, He 7:18, I Pe 3:7. Rhetorically, τό ἀ. τ. θεοῦ, God's action of apparent weakness: I Co 1:25; of bodily debility, sick, sickly: Mt 25:39 (Rec.) Mt 25:43-44, Lk 9:2 (Rec.) Lk 10:9, Ac 4:9 5:15-16 In moral and spiritual sense (MM, s.v.; Cremer, 526), Mt 26:41, Mk 14:38, Ro 5:6, I Co 8:7 8:9-10 9:22 11:30.†
Asian, of Asia, Asiatic; as subst., ὁ (οἱ) Ἀ.: Ac 20:4.†

an Asiarch, one of ten officers elected by the various cities in the province of Asia whose duty it was to celebrate at their own charges the public games and festivals: Ac 19:31 (Strab., Inscr.; DB, s.v.).†
fasting, abstinence from food: Ac 27:21.†
fasting, without eating (cf. MM, s.v.): Ac 27:33.†
to adorn (poët.).; to practise, exercise (Hdt., Xen.).; to endeavour (Xen., al.): c. inf., Ac 24:16.†
a leather bottle, wine-skin: Mt 9:17, Mk 2:22, Lk 5:37-38.†
gladly: Ac 21:17.†
unwise, foolish: Eph 5:15.†

to welcome, greet, salute: c. acc pers., Mt 5:47, Mk 9:15, Ac 21:7, al.; id. seq. ἐν φιλήματι, Ro 16:16, I Co 16:20, II Co 13:12, I Th 5:26, I Pe 5:14; τ. ἐκκλησίαν (Deiss., BS, 257), Ac 18:22; as term. tech. for conveying greetings at the end of a letter (MM, s.v.), used by an amanuensis (Milligan, NTD, 23), Ro 16:22 (on the aoristic Pres., here and elsewhere, v. M, Pr., 119; Bl., § 56, 4); κατήντησαν . . . ἀσπασάμενοι (on this constr., v. El., § 58, 4; M, Pr., 132, 238), Ac 25:13 (cf. ἀπ-ἀπ-ασπάζομαι).†
to take leave of: c. acc: Ac 21:6.†
a salutation (so always in RV), greeting: oral, Mt 23:7, Mk 12:38, Lk 1:29, 41 1:44 11:43 20:46; written, I Co 16:21, Col 4:18, II Th 3:17.†
spotless, unstained: I Pe 1:19; metaph., I Ti 6:14, Ja 1:27, II Pe 3:14 (for exx., v. MM, s.v.).†
an asp: Ro 3:13.†
without truce (Thuc.).; admitting of no truce, implacable (Dem., al.): II Ti 3:3.†
an assarion, a farthing, one-tenth of a drachma: Mt 10:29, Lk 12:6 (MM, s.v.; DB, iii, 428; DCG, ii, 200).†
nearer: Ac 27:13 (RV, close in shore; v. B1., § 11, 3; 44, 3; poets, Ion, and late prose).†
Assos, a city on the E. coast of Asia Minor: Ac 20:13-14 (v.s. ἆσσον).†
to be unsettled, be homeless, lead a vagabond life (Cremer, 738 MM, s.v.): I Co 4:11 †
of the town.; (Like Lat. urbanus),; courteous,; elegant (in π., of clothing, MM, s.v.), comely, fair (as in Ex, l.c), He 11:23, Ac 7:20.†

a star: Mt 2:2, 7-10 :, Mk 13:25, I Co 15:41, Re 6:13 8:10-12 9:1 12:1, 4; metaph., ὁ ἀ. ὁ πρωϊνός Re 2:28 22:16; ἀ. πλαῆται, Ju 13; ἀ. ἑπτά, symbolizing the angels of the seven churches, Re 1:16, 20 2:1 3:1 (cf. ἄστρον, and v. DCG, ii, 674 f.; MM, s.v.).†
unstable, unsettled: II Pe 2:14 3:16.†
without natural affection: Ro 1:31, II Ti 3:3 (MM, s.v.).†
to miss the mark, fail: c. gen., I Ti 1:6 (so in π., MM, s.v.); seq. περί, I Ti 6:21, II Ti 2:18.†
lightning: Mt 24:27 28:3, Lk 10:18 17:24; pl., Re 4:5 8:5 11:19 16:18; of a lamp, shining brightness, Lk 11:36.†
to lighten, flash forth: Lk 17:24 24:4 (MM, s.v.).†
mostly in pl. (as in cl.), the stars: Lk 21:25, Ac 27:20, He 11:12; in sing. (Xen., al.), only of some noted star; the symbol or image of a star, Ac 7:43 (cf. ἀστήρ, and v. MM, s.v.).†
dissonant, discordant; metaph., at variance: πρὸς ἀλλήλους, Ac 28:25.†
without understanding or discernment: Mt 15:16, Mk 7:18 (Swete, in l), Ro 1:21, 31 10:19 (for an ex. of its use in the moral sense, v. MM, s.v.).†
false to engagements, not keeping covenant, faithless (MM, s.v.): Ro 1:31.†
Asyncritus: Ro 16:14.†
firmness.; certainty: Lk 1:4.; security: Ac 5:23, I Th 5:3.; (In π. it is used as a law-term, proof, security; v. MM, s.v.; M, Th., l.c.)†
certain, secure, safe: Ac 21:34 22:30 25:26, Phl 3:1, He 6:19 (MM, s.v.).†
to make firm, secure: mid., Mt 27:65-66, Ac 16:24; pass., Mt 27:64 (MM, s.v.).†
safely: Mk 14:44, Ac 16:23; assuredly: Ac 2:36.†
to act unbecomingly, behave dishonourably: I Co 13:5; seq. ἐπί, ib. I Co 7:36 (MM, s.v.).†
unseemliness: Ro 1:27 (MM, s.v.); euphemism for ἡ αἰσχύνη, as freq. in LXX, shame, nakedness: Re 16:15.†
shapeless.; uncomely, unseemly: I Co 12:23.†
prodigality, wastefulness, profligacy: Eph 5:18, Tit 1:6, I Pe 4:4 (MM, s.v.).†
wastefully: Lk 15:13

primarily, of soldiers marching, to be out of order, to quit the ranks; hence, metaph., to be remiss, fail in the performance of duty (in π., of truancy on the part of an apprentice): II Th 3:7 (on ἀ. and its cognates, v. M, Th., 152 ff.; MM, s.vv.).†

out of order, out of place (Lat. inordinatus), freq. of soldiers not keeping the ranks, or an army in disarray (cf. III Mac 1:19); hence, metaph., irregular, disorderly (v. previous word): I Th 5:14.†
disorderly, irregularly: II Th 3:6 3:11.†
childless: Lk 20:28-29.†
to look fixedly, gaze (MM, s.v.): c. dat. pers., gaze upon: Lk 4:20 22:56, Ac 3:12 10:4 14:9 23:1; seq. εἰς, c. acc pers., Ac 3:4 6:15 13:9; metaph., Ac 1:10 7:55 11:6, II Co 3:7 3:13.†
in cl. most freq. in poets; without, apart from: c. gen., Lk 22:6, 35 (for exx. from π., v. MM, s.v.).†
to dishonour, insult: Mk 12:4, TTr., mg., WH, Lk 20:11, Jo 8:49, Ro 2:23, Ja 2:6; pass.: Ac 5:41, Ro 1:24 (cf ἀτιμάω).†
to dishonour, despise: c. acc pers., Mk 12:4, LTr., txt. (cf. ἀἀτιμάζω).†
dishonour, disgrace: I Co 11:14, II Co 6:8; εἰς ἀ., Ro 9:21, II Ti 2:20; ἐν ἀ., I Co 15:43; κατ' ἀ., II Co 11:21; πάθη ἀτιμίας, base passions, Ro 1:26.†
without honour, dishonoured, despised: Mt 13:57, Mk 6:4, I Co 4:10; comp., I Co 12:23.†
= ἀτιμάζω, to dishonour, treat with indignity: Mk 12:4, Rec.†
vapour: Ja 4:14; ἀ. καπνοῦ, Ac 2:19 (LXX).†
indivisible; of time, ἄτομον, a moment: ἐν ἄ., I Co 15:52.†

out of place, not befitting.; marvellous, strange (of symptoms, Hipp.): Ac 28:6; hence, in late Greek, with ethical sense,; improper, unrighteous (so in LXX, and for exx. from π., v. M, Th., l.c.; MM, s.v.): Lk 23:41, Ac 25:5, II Th 3:2.†
Attalia, a city of Pamphylia: Ac 14:25.†
Trans. (cl.), to irradiate.; Intrans.; (poët.), to see clearly (so perh. 2 Co, l.c.; MM, s.v.); as in LXX, to shine forth: II Co 4:4 (cf. δι-, κατ-αυγάζω).†
brightness; Later (as in MGr.; MM, s.v.), daylight, dawn: Ac 20:11 (Cremer, 118).†
(Lat.), Augustus, the Roman Emperor: Lk 2:1 (cf. Σεβαστός; and v. MM, s.v.).†
self-pleasing, arrogant: Tit 1:7, II Pe 2:10 (Cremer, 654).†
self-chosen.; of one's own accord: II Co 8:3 8:17.†
to govern, exercise authority over: I Ti 2:12.†
to play on a flute, to pipe: mid., Mt 11:17, Lk 7:32, I Co 14:7.†

in Hom., an open courtyard before a house, hence, an enclosure in the open, a sheepfold: Jo 10:1, 16; the court, courtyard, round which a house is built: Mt 26:3, 58 26:69, Mk 14:54, 66 15:16 Lk 11:21 22:55, Jo 18:15; τ. ναοῦ, Re 11:2. a dwelling, a palace (so, acc to Grimm-Th., s.v.): Mt 26:3, 58, Mk 14:54 15:16, Lk 11:21, Jo 18:15 (but v. MM, s.v.; cf. also DB, ii, 25, 287).†
a flute-player: Mt 9:23, Re 18:22 (MM, s.v.).†
prop., to lodge in a courtyard.; to lodge in the open.; to pass the night, lodge (LXX; MM, s.v.): Mt 21:17, Lk 21:37.†
a pipe: I Co 14:7.†

trans., to make to grow: I Co 3:6-7, II Co 9:10. Pass., to grow, increase, become greater: Mt 13:32, Mk 4:8, II Co 10:15, Col 1:6; τῇ ἐπιγνώσει τ. θεοῦ, Col 1:10; εἰς σωτηρίαν, I Pe 2:2.; In later Gk. (but nowhere in LXX), intrans., to grow, increase: of plants, Mt 6:28, Lk 12:27 13:19; of infants, Lk 1:80 2:40; of a multitude, Ac 7:17; of the increase of the Gospel: ὁ λόγος ηὔξανε, Ac 6:7 12:24 19:20; of Christ as a leader, Jo 3:30; of Christian character: εἰς Χριοτόν, Eph 4:15; εἰς ναόν, Eph 2:21; ἐν χάριτι, II Pe 3:18; τὴν αὔξησιν τ. θεσῦ, Col 2:19 (cf. συν, ὑπερ-αυξάνω).†
increase, growth: Eph 4:16, Col 2:19.†
to-morrow: Mt 6:30, Lk 12:28, Ac 23:20 25:22, I Co 15:32, Lk 13:32-33, Ja 4:13; ἡ αὔ. (sc. ἡμέρα, MM, s.v.), Mt 6:34, Ac 4:3; ἐπὶ τὴν αὔ., Lk 10:35, Ac 4:5; τὸ (WH om.) τῆς Ja 4:14.†
prop., stringent, harsh to the taste. Metaph., in Inscr., of a rough country; of disposition and manners, strict, severe (as in π., of an inspector; MM, s v): Lk 19:21-22.†
sufficiency (MM, s.v.): in subjective sense (v. Milligan, NTD, 57), II Co 9:8; contentment: I Ti 6:6.†
as in cl., in philosophical sense, self-­sufficient, independent; subjectively, contented: Phl 4:11 (in non-lit. π., the word means simply enough, sufficient; MM, s.v.).†
self-condemned: Tit 3:11 (Eccl., Cremer, 377; MM, s.v.).†
of persons, acting of one's own will.; Of inanimate things and natural agencies, of itself, of its own accord: γῆ Mk 4:28 (MM, s.v.); πύλη, Ac 12:10.†
an eye-witness: Lk 1:2.†

Emphatic (so always in nom. exc. when preceded by the art., v. infr., iii); self (ipse), expressing opposition, distinction, exclusion, etc., αὐ. ἐκχυθήσεται, Lk 5:37; αὐ. ἐγινώσκεν, Jo 2:25; αὐ.ὑμεῖς, Jo 3:28; καὶ αὐ. ἐγώ, Ro 15:14; αὐ. Ἰησοῦς, Jo 2:24; αὐ. καὶ οἱ μετ’ αὐτοῦ, Mk 2:25; ὑμεῖς αὐ., Mk 6:31; esp. (as freq in cl.) αὐ. ὁ, Mt 3:4, Mk 6:17, Jo 16:27, I Th 3:11, al.; in late Gk., sometimes weakened, ἐν αὐτῇ τ. ὥρᾳ, in that hour, Lk 10:21 (M, Pr., 91; MM, s.v.); emphatic, he, she, it (M, Pr., 86; Bl., §48, 1, 2, 7), Mt 1:21, 12:50, Lk 6:35, al.; pointing to some one as master (cl.), Mt 8:24, Mk 4:38, al.; αὐ., καὶ αὐ. = οὗτος, ὁ δε (BL, §48, 1), Mt 14:2, Mk 14:15, 44, Lk 1:22, 2:28, al. In oblique cases (cl.), for the simple pron. of 3rd pers., he, she, it, Mt 7:9, 10:12, 26:44, al.; with ptcp. in gen. absol., Mt 9:18, Mk 13:1, al. (for irreg. constructions, V. Bl., §74, 5); pleonastically after the relative (cf. Heb. אֲשֶׁר לֹו; WM, 184ff.; Bl., §50, 4; MM, s.v.), Mk 7:25, Re 3:8, 7:2, al.; in constr. ad sensum, without proper subject expressly indicated, Mt 4:23, Ac 8:5, II Co 2:13, al.; gen. αὐτοῦ = ἐκείνου, Ro 11:11, I Th 2:19, Tit 3:5, He 2:4. ὁ, ἡ, τὸ αὐ., the same: He 1:12, 13:8; τὸ αὐ., ποιεῖν, Mt 5:46, 47, al.; φρονεῖν, Ro 12:16, 15:5, Phl 2:2, al.; τὰ αὐ., Ac 15:27, Ro 2:1, al.; κατὰ τὸ (τὰ) αὐ. (MM, s.v.), Ac 14:1, Lk 6:23, al.; ἐπὶ τὸ αὐ., together (MM, s.v.), Mt 22:34, Ac 1:15, al.; ἓν κ. τὸ αὐ., I Co 11:5, 12:11; c. dat. (cl.), I Co 11:5; with a noun, λόγος, Mk 14:39; μέτρος, Phl 1:30; πνεῦμα, I Co 12:4.
= ἑαυτοῦ (q.v.), Mt 6:34, Lk 12:17, al. (MM, s.v.)
prop. with ref. to theft, then generally, in the very act: as freq., neut. dat. after ἐπί, Jo 8:4 (Rec., ἐπαυτοφώρῳ).†
with one's own hand: Ac 27:19.†
to boast: c. acc (MM, s.v.), μεγάλα αὐχεῖ (Rec. μεγαλαυχεῖ, q.v.), Ja 3:5.†
dry; squalid, dismal: II Pe 1:19 (MM, s.v.).†

to take from, take away, take off: c. acc, τὸ ὠτίον, Mt 26:51, Mk 14:47 (ὠτάριον, WH), Lk 22:50 (οὖς); ὄνειδος, Lk 1:25; seq. ἀπό, Re 22:19, Lk 16:3 (mid.); pass., C. gen., Lk 10:42; ἀ. ἁμαρτίος, He 10:4, Ro 11:27 (mid.) (MM, s.v.).†
unseen, hidden: He 4:13.†
to make unseen, hide from sight (Xen., a1.).; Later (MM, s.v.); to destroy: Mt 6:19-20; to disfigure: Mt 6:16. Pass., to vanish: Ja 4:14; to perish: Ac 13:41(LXX).†
vanishing: He 8:13.†
invisible, hidden: Lk 24:31.†
a privy, drain: Mt 15:17, Mk 7:19 (ὀχετόν, WH, mg.).†; **ὀχετός, -οῦ, ὁ; a water-pipe, channel.; the intestinal canal: Mk 7:19, WH, mg. (for ἀφεδρών).†
extravagance.; unsparing treatment, severity: Col 2:23.†
= cl. ἀφέλεια (v. MM, s.v.),; simplicity: Ac 2:46†

dismissal, release: Lk 4:18.; Metaph., of sins (never in LXX), pardon, remission of penalty: ἁμαρτιῶν, Mt 26:28, Mk 1:4, Lk 1:77 3:3 24:47, Ac 2:38 5:31 10:43 13:38 26:18, Col 1:14; παραπτωμάτων, Eph 1:7; absol., Mk 3:29, He 9:22 10:18 (cf. DB, ii, 56; DCG, i, 437, ii, 605; Cremer, 297 f.).†
a joint (MM, s.v.): Eph 4:16, Col 2:19 (Lft., in l).†
incorruptibility, immortality: Ro 2:7, I Co 15:42 15:50 15:53-54, II Ti 1:10; ἀγαπώντων . . . ἐν ἀ., Eph 6:24 (v. AR, in l).†; ἀ-φθορία, -ας, ἡ; uncorruptness: Tit 2:7 (Rec. ἀφθορία).†
imperishable, immortal; of things: I Co 9:25, I Pe 1:4 1:23 3:4; of persons: of men, I Co 15:52; of God, Ro 1:23, I Ti 1:17 (MM, s.v.).†

to send forth, send away, let go: of divorce (DB, iii, 274a), τ. γυναῖκα (Hdt.), I Co 7:11-13; of death, τ. πνεῦμα (Ge 35:18, Hdt., al.), Mt 27:50; (φωνήν, to utter a cry, Mk 15:37; of debts, to remit, forgive (cl.), τ. δανεῖον, Mt 18:27; τ. ὀφειλήν, Mt 18:32; esp. of sins (Cremer 296f.), τ. ἁμαρτίας, ἁμαρτήματα, ἀνομίας, Mt 9:2, Ro 4:7 (LXX), I Jo 1:9, al.; punctiliar and iterative pres. (M, Pr., 119), Mk 2:5, Lk 11:4; Ion. pf., ἀφέωνται (M, Pr., 38), Lk 5:23. to leave alone, leave, neglect: Mt 4:11 5:24 15:14, Mk 1:20, 31 Jo 4:3, 28 al.; τ. ἐντολὴν τ. θεοῦ, Mk 7:8; τον̀ τ. ἀρχῆς τ. Χριστοῦ λόγον, He 6:1; τ. ἀγάπην τ. πρώτην, Re 2:4; ptcp., ἀφείς, pleonastic (as in Aram.; M, Pr., 14; Dalman, Words, 21f.), Mt 13:36 22:22, Mk 8:13, al. to let, suffer, permit: Mt 3:15; c. acc., Mt 3:15, 19:14, al.; c. acc. rei et dat. pers., Mt 5:40; c. inf. pres., Mt 23:14, al.; aor., Mk 5:37, al.; in late Gk. (M, Pr., 175f.), seq. ἵνα, Mk 11:16, Jo 12:7; c. subjunct. (M, Pr., l.c.; Bl., §64, 2), Mt 7:4 27:49, Mk 15:36, Lk 6:42 (see further MM, s.v.).
perfective of ἱκνέομαι, to come (M, Pr., 247), to arrive at, come to, reach: metaph. (MM, s.v.), Ro 16:19.†
without love of good: II Ti 3:3 (not elsewhere in Gk. lit., but v. MM, s.v.).†
without love of money, not avaricious; I Ti 3:3, He 13:5. (For other instances, v. MM, s.v.)†
in cl. usually, arrival; rarely, departure: Ac 20:29 (so in π., cf. MM, s.v.; M, Pr 26:1-28, n.).†

trans. in pres., impf., fut., 1 aor., to put away, lead away; metaph., to move to revolt: Ac 5:37.; Intrans. in pf., plpf., 2 aor., to stand off, depart from, withdraw from: c. gen., Lk 2:37; seq. ἀπό, Lk 4:13 13:27, Ac 5:38 12:10 15:38 19:9 22:29, II Co 12:8; metaph., ἀπὸ ἀδικίας, II Ti 2:19; ἀπὸ θεοῦ, (fall away, apostatize), He 3:12 Mid. (exc. 1 aor., WH. is trans.), to withdraw oneself from, absent oneself from: Lk 2:37; metaph., fall away, apostatize: absol., Lk 8:13; c. gen., I Ti 4:1 (MM, s.v.; Cremer, 308).†
suddenly: Ac 2:2 16:26 28:6.†
without fear: Lk 1:74, Phl 1:14, I Co 16:10, Ju 12.†
to make like: pass., He 7:3.†
to look away from all else at, fix one's gaze upon: metaph. (MM, s.v.), He 12:2; simply, to see: ἀφίδω (v.s. ἀπεῖδον, and Lft., Phi., in l; MM, s.v.), Phl 2:23 (v. Ellic., in l).†

to mark off by boundaries from, separate from: c. acc, Ac 19:9, Ga 2:12; id. seq. ἐκ (ἀπό), Mt 13:49 25:32 (MM, s.v.); of excom­munication, Lk 6:22. Pass., absol., II Co 6:17; to set apart, devote to a special purpose (seq. εἰς): c. acc, Ga 1:15. Mid., Ac 13:2, Ro 1:1 (DB, iii 588).†

prop., a starting point; in war, a base of operations; metaph., an occasion, incentive, opportunity (MM, s.v.): II Co 11:12, Ga 5:13; ἀφ. λαμβάνειν, Lk 11:24, WH, mg., Ro 7:8, 11; ἀφ. διδόναι, II Co 5:12, I Ti 5:14.*
to foam at the mouth: Mk 9:18, 20.†
foam: Lk 9:39 (MM, s.v.).†
foolishness: Mk 7:22, II Co 11:1 11:17 11:21.†

without reason, senseless, foolish, expressing "want of mental sanity and sobriety, a reckless and inconsiderate habit of mind" (Hort; cf. MM, s.v.): Lk 11:40 12:20, Ro 2:20, I Co 15:36, II Co 11:16 12:6 12:11, I Pe 2:15; opp. to φρόνιμος, II Co 11:19; to συνιέντες, Eph 2:17.†
to awake from sleep (Anth.).; = cl. καθυπνόω (MM, s.v.), to fall asleep: Lk 8:23.†
as in cl., to be late (Polyb., Sir, l.c.).; Trans., to keep back (Ne, i.e.; v. Mayor, Ja., 157 f.): pass., Ja 5:4 (MM, s.v.).†

dumb, speechless: Ac 8:32 (LXX); of idols (MM, s.v.), I Co 12:2; of beasts, II Pe 2:19; τοσαῦτα γένη φωνῶν καὶ οὐδὲν ἄ.—so many kinds of voices and none voiceless, i.e. without signification, unintelligible: I Co 14:10.†
Ahaz: Mt 1:9.†
Achaia, the Roman province: Ac 18:12, 27 19:21 Ro 15:26, I Co 16:15, II Co 1:1 9:2 11:10, I Th 1:7-8.†
Achaicus: I Co 16:17.†
ungracious, unpleasing; ungrateful, thankless: Lk 6:35, II Ti 3:2.†
Achim: Mt 1:14.†
not made by hands: Mk 14:58, II Co 5:1; metaph., περιτομή ἀ. (i.e. spiritual ), Col 2:11 (MM, s.v.).†
a mist, esp. a dimness of the eyes: Ac 13:11 (v. Tr., Syn., § c).†
useless, unprofitable: Mt 25:30, Lk 17:10 (MM, s.v.).†
to make useless, unprofitable: pass., Ro 3:12 (LXX).†
useless; unserviceable: opp. to εὔχρηστος, Phm 11.†

adv., utterly (Hom.).; Prep. c. gen., until, unto, as far as; of time Ac 3:21 22:22, Ro 1:13 5:13, I Co 4:11, II Co 3:14, Ga 4:2, Phl 1:6; ἄ. καιροῦ, Lk 4:13, Ac 13:11; ἄ. ἧς ἡμέρας, Mt 24:38, Lk 1:20 17:27, Ac 1:2 (τῆς ἡ. ἧς), Ac 1:22; ἄ. ταύτης τ. ἡμέρας (τ. ἡ. ταύτης), Ac 2:29 23:1 26:22; ἄ. ἡμερων πέντε, Ac 20:6; ἄ. αὐγῆς, Ac 20:11; ἄ. τοῦ νῦν, Ro 8:22, Phl 1:5; ἄ. τέλους, He 6:11, Re 2:26; of space: Ac 11:5 13:6 20:4 (R, txt., WH, mg.) Ac 28:15, II Co 10:13-14, He 4:12, Re 14:20 18:5; of measure or degree: ἄ. θανάτου, Ac 22:4, Re 2:10 12:11.; As conj., until; ἄχρι alone: c. subj. aor., Ga 3:19 (ἄ. οὗ T, WH, mg.); id. without ἄν (Bl., § 65, 10), Re 7:3 15:8 20:3, 5; c. indic. fut., Re 17:17; ἄ. οὗ (i.e. ἄ.. τούτου ᾧ): c. indic. aor., Ac 7:18; impf., Ac 27:33; c. subj. aor. (Bl., ut supr.), Lk 21:24, Ro 11:25, I Co 11:26 15:25, Ga 3:19, T, WH, mg.; id. with ἄν, Re 2:25; c. indic. pres., while, He 3:13 (cf. μέχρι).†
chaff: Mt 3:12, Lk 3:17.†
free from false-hood, truthful: Tit 1:2.†
wormwood: as a proper name, Re 8:11.†
inanimate, lifeless: I Co 14:7.†
beta, b, the second letter. As a numeral, β' = 2; β, = 2000.

Baal: Ro 11:4 (LXX). The fem. art. here agrees with the usage of LXX, where, following a similar Hebrew practice (בֹּשֶׁת for בַּעַל), αἰσχύνη appears to have been substituted in reading for the written Βάαλ (cf. III Ki 18:19), and to account for the freq. use of the fem. art. bef. Β. The usage, however, is not general, and in the passage cited in Ro (III Ki 19:18), LXX reads τῷ Β. †
Babylon: Mt 1:11, 12 17, Ac 7:43 (LXX); symbolically, of Rome: Re 14:8 16:19 17:5 18:2, 10, 21, and prob. also I Pe 5:13.†
a step (IV Ki, l.c., of degrees of a dial); metaph., a degree, standing: I Ti 3:13.†

depth: Mt 13:5, Mk 4:5, Ro 8:39, Eph 3:18; τὸ β., the deep sea: Lk 5:4; metaph., β. πλούτου . . . Θεοῦ, Ro 11:33; τὰ β. τ. Θεοῦ (the Divine counsels), I Co 2:10; ἡ κατὰ βάθους πτωχεία, deep poverty, II Co 8:2.†
to deepen: Lk 6:48.†
deep; Jo 4:11; metaph., ὄρθρου βαθέως (v. supr.), early dawn, Lk 24:1; ὕπνος, Ac 20:9; τὰ β. τοῦ Σατανᾶ, Re 2:24.†
a palm-branch: Jo 12:13 (DB, i, 314).†
Balaam (Nu 22-24): II Pe 2:15, Ju 11, Re 2:14.†

prop., of a weapon or missile; then generally, of things and persons, lit. and metaph., to throw, cast, put, place: c. acc., seq. εἰς, Mt 4:18, and freq. ἐπί, Mt 10:34; κάτω, Mt 4:6; ἔξω, Mt 5:13; ἀπό, Mt 5:29; ἐκ, Mk 12:44; δρέπανον, Re 14:19; μάχαιραν, Mt 10:34; κλῆρον, Mt 27:35; of fluids, to pour: Mt 9:17, Jo 13:5; pass., to be laid, to lie ill: Mt 9:2; ἐβλήθη (timeless aor., M, Pr., 134), Jo 15:6; intrans., to rush (Bl., §53, 1): Ac 27:14. Metaph., β. εἰς τ. καρδίαν, Jo 13:2 (cf. usage in π., without idea of violence; also of liquids; MM, Exp., x; v. also Cremer, 120, 657; cf. ἀμφι-, ἀνα-, ἀντι-, ἀπο-, δια-, ἐκ-, ἐμ-, παρ-εμ-, ἐπι-, κατα-, μετα-, παρα-, περι-, προ-, συμ-, ὑπερ-, ὑπο-βάλλω).

to dip, immerse, sink; generally (in Polyb., iii, 72, of soldiers wading breast-deep; in i, 51, of the sinking of ships); metaph., to overwhelm (Is, l.c.; cf. MM, Exp., x); c. cogn. acc., βάπτισμα β., Mk 10:38, 39 Lk 12:50. Mid., to perform ablutions, wash oneself, bathe (Ki, Jth, Si, ll. c.): Mk 7:4; aor. pass, in same sense, Lk 11:38. Of ablution, immersion, as a religious rite, to baptize; (a) absol.; Mk 1:4, Jo 1:25, 26 28 3:22, 23, 26 4:2 10:40, I Co 1:17; ὁ βαπτίζων (= ὁ βαπτιστής, M, Pr., 127), Mk 6:14, 24; c. acc., Jo 4:1, Ac 8:38, I Co 1:14, 16; c. cogn. acc., τὸ βάπτισμα, Ac 19:4 (cf. Mk 10:38, supr.); pass., to be baptized, receive baptism: Mt 3:13, 14, 16, Mk 16:16, Lk 3:7, 12 21 7:29 (τ. βάπτισμα) ib. 30, Ac 2:41 8:12, 13 36 9:18 10:47 16:15, 33 18:8; mid., 22:16 (M, Pr., 163); with prepositions: ἐν, of the element, Mt 3:6, 11 Mk 1:4, 5 8, Lk 3:16, Jo 1:26, 31 33 3:23, Ac 1:5 2:38 10:48 11:16, I Co 10:2; εἰς, of the element, purpose or result (Lft., Notes, 155), Mt 3:1 28:19, Mk 1:9, Ac 8:16 19:3, 5 Ro 6:3, I Co 1:13, 15 10:2 12:13, Ga 3:27; c. dat., ὕδατι, Lk 3:16, Ac 1:5 11:16; ὑπὲρ τῶν νεκρῶν, perh. to fulfil the wish of a dead friend, I Co 15:29 (v. ICC, in l.; cf. DB, i, 238ff.; DCG, i, 169a; ii, 605b; Cremer, 126). †

immersion, baptism; metaph., of affliction: Mk 10:38, 39 Lk 12:50. Of the religious rite of baptism; of John's baptism: Mt 3:7 21:25, Mk 11:30, Lk 7:29 20:4, Ac 1:22 10:37 18:25 19:3; β. μετανοίας, Mk 1:4, Lk 3:3, Ac 13:24 19:4; of Christian baptism; Ro 6:4, Eph 4:5, Col 2:12 (Tr., -μῷ, q.v.), I Pe 3:21 (cf. Cremer, 130; Tr., Syn. §xcix). †

a dipping, washing, lustration: Mk 7:4; of Jewish ceremonial. He 9:10; in He 6:2, βαπτισμῶν διδαχήν (-ῆς), "the pl. and the peculiar form seem to be used to include Christian baptism with other lustral rites" (Westc, in l.). baptism: FlJ, Ant., 18, 5, 2 (of John's baptism), and some Fathers (v. Soph., s.v.). Not so in NT, unless ἐν τ. βαπτισμῷ, in the act of baptism, Col 2:12, be read with Tr. (Rec., WH, R, -ματι). †
to dip: Lk 16:24, Jo 13:26 (ἐμβ-, L); to dip in dye, to dye: Re 19:13 (Rec.; ῥεραντισμένον, WH; περιρεραμμένον, T; ῥεραμμένον, Swete, in l., q.v.). †
β. Ἰωνᾶ, son of Jonah, Mt 16:17, Rec. (L, T, WH, Βαριωνᾶ, q.v.).†
Barabbas: Mt 27:16, 17 20, 21, 26, Mk 15:7, 11 15, Lk 23:18, Jo 18:40. (In Mt 27:16, some MSS. read Ἰησοῦν Β.; v. WH, App., 19f.).†
Barak (Jg 4:6): He 11:32.†
Barachiah: Mt 23:35, v.s. Ζαχαρίας.†

barbarous, barbarian, strange to Greek language and culture (and also, after the Persian war, with the added sense of brutal, rude): Ac 28:2, 4 Ro 1:14, I Co 14:11, Col 3:11 (v. Lft., in l., and Notes, 249).†
to depress, weigh down. In NT, in pass. only: Mt 26:43, Lk 9:32 21:34, II Co 1:8 5:4, I Ti 5:16.†
heavily, with difficulty: Mt 13:15, Ac 28:27 (LXX).†
Bartholomew, the Apostle (v.s. Ναθαναήλ): Mt 10:3, Mk 3:18, Lk 6:14, Ac 1:13.†
Bar-Jesus: Ac 13:6 (v.s. Ἐλύμας).†
Bar-Jonah, a surname of Peter: Mt 16:17.†

weight; a weight, burden, lit. and metaph.: Mt 20:12, Ac 15:28, II Co 4:17, Re 2:24; ἀλλήλων τὰ β., one another's faults, Ga 6:2; ἐν β., burdensome: I Th 2:6, R, txt., but v. infr.; in late Gk. (Soph., Lex., s.v.), dignity, authority: ἐν βάρει, I Th 2:6 (R, mg.; v. Milligan, ICG, in l.).†
Barsabbas: the surname of one Joseph: Ac 1:23. The surname of one Judas: Ac 15:22. †
Bartimæus: Mk 10:46.†
to weigh down = βαρέω (q.v.): Lk 21:34, Rec.†

heavy: Mt 23:4. Metaph., burdensome: ἐντολή, I Jo 5:3; severe (perh. impressive): ἐπιστολή, II Co 10:10; weighty: τὰ βαρύτερα τ. νόμου, Mt 23:23; αἰτιώματα, Ac 25:7; violent, cruel (EV, grievous): λύκος, Ac 20:29.†
of great value, very costly: Mt 26:7 (T, πολυτίμου) .†

prop., to rub on the touchstone, put to the test. >to examine by torture, hence, generally, to torture, torment, distress: Mt 8:6, 29 14:24, Mk 5:7 6:48, Lk 8:28, II Pe 2:8, Re 9:5 11:10 12:2 14:10 20:10. †
torture, torment: Re 9:5 14:11 18:7, 10, 15.†
prop., a torturer; used of a gaoler, Mt 18:34.†
prop., touchstone, a dark stone used in testing metals. examination by torture. torment, torture: Mt 4:24, Lk 15:23, 28. †

prop. abstract, sovereignty, royal power, dominion: Lk 1:33 22:29, Jo 18:36, Ac 1:6, He 1:8, I Co 15:24; λαβεῖν β., Lk 19:12, 15 Re 17:12; δοῦναι τὴν, ib. 17; ἔχειν β., ib. 18; ἔρχεσθαι ἐν τ. (εἰς τὴν) β., Mt 16:28, Lk 23:42; β. τ. θεοῦ, Re 12:10. By meton., concrete (MM, Exp., x), a kingdom, the territory or people over whom the king rules (Es 5:3, al.): Mt 4:8 12:25, 26 24:7, Mk 3:24 6:23, Lk 4:5, He 11:33, al.; the royal majesty (cf. our phrase His Majesty), the king himself (τ. σπέρμα τῆς β., IV Ki 11:1). In LXX (Wi 6:5, To 13:1, al.), Targ. and NT, of the Messianic rule and kingdom, ἡ β. τ. θεοῦ, τ. οὐρανῶν (Heb. מַלְכוּת שָׁמַיִם, Aram. מַלְכוּתָא דִשׁמַיָּא; v. Dalman, Words, 91-147; Cremer, 132, 658), the kingdom of God (on the equivalence of the two phrases, v. Dalman, op. cit., 93, 218f.); τ. θεοῦ, Mt 6:33 12:28, al.; τ. οὐρανῶν, Mt 3:2 4:17, al.; τ. Χριστοῦ (מַלִכוּת דִמְשִׁיחא, Targ. Jon. on Is 53:10), Eph 5:5; τ. κυρίου, II Pe 1:11, Re 11:15; τ. Δαυείδ, Mk 11:10; absol., ἡ β., Mt 4:23, Ja 2:5, al. The kingdom is regarded as present: Mt 11:12, Lk 17:21, Ro 14:17, al.; as that which is to be consummated in the future, Mt 6:10, Mk 9:1, Jo 3:5, II Pe 1:11, al. Noteworthy phrases are: ζητεῖν τὴν β., Mt 6:33; δέχεσθαι, Mk 10:15; κλρονομεῖν, Mt 25:34; διδόναι, Lk 12:32; παραλαμβάνειν, He 12:28; αὐτῶν (τοιούτων) εστὶν ἡ β., Mt 5:3, 10 19:14, Mk 10:14, Lk 18:16; διὰ τὴν β., Mt 19:12; ἕνεκεν τῆς β., Lk 18:29; εὐαγγελίζεσθαι, κηρύσσειν, διαγγέλλειν τὴν β., Lk 4:43 9:2, 60; ἤγγικεν ἡ β., Mt 3:2, Mk 1:15; κλεῖς τῆς β., Mt 16:10; κλείειν τὴν β., Mt 23:14; υἱοὶ τῆς β., Mt 8:12 13:38 (cf. Cremer, 132, 658).
a capital city. Freq. in pl., τὰ β., a palace: Lk 7:25. †
royal: I Pe 2:9 (LXX) (v. Hort, in l.).†

a king: Mt 1:6 2:1; used by courtesy of Herod the Tetrarch, Mt 14:9; of the Roman Emperor, as freq. in κοινή (Deiss., LAE, p. 367), I Pe 2:13, 17; of the Christ, in the phrase ὁ β. τ. Ἰουδαίων, Mt 2:2, al.; τοῦ Ἰσραήλ, Mk 15:32, Jo 1:50 12:13; of God, Mt 5:35, I Ti 1:17, Re 15:3; β. βασιλέων, Re 17:14 19:16; β. τ. βασιλευόντων, I Ti 6:15 (on the associations of the word to Jewish Hellenists, v. Cl. Rev., i, 7).†

to be king, to reign, rule: I Ti 6:15; c. gen. (cl.), Mt 2:22; seq. ἐπί, c. acc. (= Heb. מלךְ על; Bl., §36, 8), Lk 1:33 19:14, 27 Ro 5:14; ἐπὶ τ. γῆς, on earth, Re 5:10; of God, Re 11:15, 17 19:6; of Christ, Lk 1:33, I Co 15:25, Re 11:15; of Christians, Re 5:10 20:4 (constative aor., M, Pr., 130), ib. 6 22:5. Metaph., Christians, Ro 5:17, I Co 4:8; θάνατος, Ro 5:14, 17; ἁμαρτία, Ro 5:21 6:12. Ingressive aor. (M, Pr., 109), to begin to reign: I Co 4:8, Re 11:17 19:6 (Cremer, 137).†

royal, belonging to a king: χώρα, Act 12:20; ἐσθής, Ac 12:21; νόμος β., a supreme law, "a law which governs other laws and so has a specially regal character" (Hort), or because made by a king (LAE, p. 3673), Ja 2:8; τις, one in the service of a king, a courtier, Jo 4:46, 49 (WH, mg., βασιλίσκος).†
prop., a petty king: Jo 4:46, 49 WH, mg. (v.s. βασιλικός).†
a step (Æsch., al.). Hence, a foot (Plat.; Wi 13:18): Ac 3:7.†
to slander (Dem.). to blight by the evil eye, to fascinate, bewitch: Ga 3:1.†

to take up with the hands, to lift: λίθους, Jo 10:31. to bear, to carry, as a burden, and metaph., to endure; Mt 3:11 20:12, Mk 14:13, Lk 7:14 10:7 11:27 14:27 22:10, Jo 16:12 19:17, Ac 3:2 9:15 15:1 21:35, Ro 11:18 15:1, Ga 5:10 6:2, 5 17, Re 2:2, 3 17:7. In late writers (MM, Exp., ii, iii, x), to take away; Mt 8:17 (Is 53:4, Heb.); to carry off, steal: Jo 12:6 20:15. †
a bramble-bush: Lk 6:44, Ac 7:30, 35; ἐπὶ τοῦ (τῆς) β., in the place concerning the bush: Mk 12:26, Lk 20:37.†
bath, a Jewish liquid measure, = μετρητής (q.v.), or about 8 3/4 gals.: Lk 16:6.†
a frog: Re 16:13.†
to stammer, repeat idly: Mt 6:7 (Cremer, 765).†
an abomination, a detestable thing: Lk 16:15, Re 17:4, 5 21:27; τὸ β. τ. ἐρημώσεως (Da LXX 12:11, cf . I Mac 1:54; DB, i, 12f.; DCG, i, 6f.), Mk 13:14, Mt 24:15 (Cremer, 138).†
abominable, detestable: Tit 1:16 (Cremer, 137).†
in cl., mid. only (Attic, -ττομαι); to make foul; pass., Re 21:8; mid., to turn away in disgust from, to detest: Ro 2:22 (Cremer, 137).†

firm, secure: ἄγκυρα, He 6:19; metaph., sure (esp. "in the sense of legally guaranteed security," Deiss., BS, 109; cf . two foll. words): ἐπαγγελία, Ro 4:16; ἐλπίς, II Co 1:6; λόγος, He 2:2; παρρησία, He 3:6; ἀρχή (τ. ὑποστάσεως), He 3:14; διαθήκη, He 9:17; κλῆσις κ. ἐκλογή, II Pe 1:10; comp. (-ότερος), προφητικὸς λόγος, II Pe 1:19.†

to confirm, establish, secure, of things (cl.): λόγον, Mk 16:[20]; ἐπαγγελίας, Ro 15:8; of persons (DCG, ii, 605): I Co 1:8, II Co 1:21. Pass., I Co 1:6, Col 2:7, He 2:3 13:9 (as an Attic legal term, to guarantee the validity of a purchase, establish or confirm a title; v. next word, Cremer, 139; cf. δια-β.).†
confirmation: τ. εὐαγγελίου, Phl 1:7; εἰς β., He 6:16, a phrase freq. in π. of guarantee in a business transaction (Deiss., BS, 104ff.; Cremer, 140).†
permitted to be trodden, accessible (v. DCG, ii, 422b); hence, (opp. to ἱερός) unhallowed, profane: of things, I Ti 4:7 6:20, II Ti 2:16; of men, I Ti 1:9, He 12:16 (cf. κοινός; Cremer, 140).†
to profane: τ. σάββατον, Mt 12:5; τ. ἱερόν, Ac 24:6 (Cremer, 141).†
Beelzebul, Beelzebub, a name of Satan: Mt 10:25 12:24, 27 Mk 3:22, Lk 11:15, 18 19.†
Belial, a name of Satan: II Co 6:15, Rec. See next word.†
Beliar, a name of Satan: II Co 6:15 (v. DB, i, 269).†
a sharp point, as of a spear. a needle: Lk 18:25 (Rec. ῥαφίς, q.v.).†
a missile, a dart: Eph 6:16.†
neut. as adv., better, very well: II Ti 1:18 (also Ac 10:28 D). On elative use in these passages, v. M, Pr., 78, 236.†
Benjamin: Ac 13:21, Ro 11:1, Phl 3:5, Re 7:8.†
Bernice, Berenice, dau. of Herod Agrippa I: Ac 25:13, 23 26:3o.†
Berœa, a city of Macedonia: Ac 17:10, 13.†
Berœan: Ac 20:4.†
Beor, father of Balaam: II Pe 2:15 (Rec. Βοσόρ).†
Bethabara: Jo 1:28, Rec. (WH, R, βηθανία).†

Bethany; a village fifteen furlongs from Jerusalem, the modern El Azerîyeh: Mt 21:17 26:6, Mk 8:22 (WH, mg.) 11:1, 11, 12 14:3 Lk 19:29 24:50, Jo 11:1, 18 12:1. A place on E. bank of Jordan: Jo 1:28 (R, mg., Βηθαβαρά, q.v.).†
Bethesda, a pool in Jerusalem: Jo 5:2, Rec. (Βηθζαθά, WH, Βηθσαϊδά, WH, mg.).†
Bethzatha: Jo 5:2, WH (Rec. Βηθεσδά, q.v.).†
Bethlehem, a town 6 m. S. of Jerusalem: Mt 2:1, 5 6, 8, 16, Lk 2:4, 15 Jo 7:42.†

Bethsaida, a town on NE. shore of the Sea of Galilee: Lk 9:10. It is generally supposed that a second B. on the W. shore is referred to in Mt 11:21, Mk 6:45 8:22, Lk 10:13, Jo 1:45 12:21 (DB, i, 282f.; but v. Swete on Mk 6:45). 2. v.l. for Βηθζαθά, Βηθεσδά, Jo 5:2. †
Bethphage: Mt 21:1, Mk 11:1, Lk 19:29.†

a step, stride, pace: Ac 7:5. a raised place, a platform reached by steps, originally that in the Pnyx at Athens from which orations were made; freq. of the tribune or tribunal of a Roman magistrate or ruler: Mt 27:19, Jo 19:13, Ac 12:21, 18:12, 16, 17 25:6, 10, 17; β. τοῦ θεοῦ, Ro 14:10; τ. Χριστοῦ, II Co 5:10. †
beryl, a jewel of sea-green colour: Re 21:20.†
strength, force, violence: Ac 5:26 21:35 24:7 27:41.†

to force, constrain, rare in act. (poet, and late prose), but found in cl. in pass., and so perh. βιάζεται, suffereth violence, Mt 11:12, EV (but v. infr.), whether in good sense, of disciples (Thayer, al.), or in bad sense, of the enemies of the kingdom (Meyer, in l.; Dalman, Words, 139ff.; Cremer, 141ff.). Mid., advanceth violently, Mt, l.c. (Deiss., BS., 258; Banks, v. ref. in DCG, ii, 803f.); seq. εἰς, to press violently, or force one's way into, Lk 16:16 (v. ICC, in l., and in Mt, l.c.; cf. παραβιάζομαι and v. MM, s.v.).†
violent: Ac 2:2.†
strong, forceful. violent (Philo): Mt 11:12 (v.s. βιάζω).†
a little book: Re 10:2, 8 (WH, βιβλιόν, T2, 7 βιβλιδάριον) 9, 10. Not hitherto found elsewhere.†

a paper, letter, written document: β. ἀποστασίου, bill of divorce, Mt 19:7, Mk 10:4. a book, a roll: Lk 4:17, 20 Jo 20:30 21:25, Ga 3:10, II Ti 4:13, He 9:19 10:7, Re 1:11 5:1-9 6:14 10:8 20:12 22:7-19; β. τ. ζωῆς, Re 13:8 17:8 20:12 21:27.†

a book, a roll, used much less freq. than βιβλίον, and with a "connotation of sacredness and veneration" (MM, Exp., x), Mt 1:1 Mk 12:26, Lk 3:4 20:42 Ac 1:20 7:42 19:19; β. τ. ζωῆς, Phl 4:3, Re 3:5 20:15.†
to eat: Jo 6:13.†
Bithynia, a province in Asia Minor: Ac 16:7, I Pe 1:1.†
period or course of life, life: Lk 8:14, I Ti 2:2, II Ti 2:4, I Jo 2:16. living, livelihood, means (in Pr 31:14 for לֶחֶם; v. DCG, ii, 39a): Mk 12:44, Lk 8:43 15:12, 30 21:4, I Jo 3:17.†
to spend life, to live: τ. χρόνον βιῶσαι (cl., more freq. 2 aor., -ναι), I Pe 4:2 (cf. Jb, l.c.).†
manner of life: Ac 26:4.†
pertaining to life, hence, worldly (Field, Notes, 171): Lk 21:34, I Co 6:3, 4.†
hurtful: I Ti 6:9.†
to hurt, injure: c. acc., Mk 16:[18], Lk 4:35.†
to sprout: Mt 13:26, Mk 4:27, He 9:4. In late Gk., causal, to make to grow, produce: c. acc., Ja 5:18.†
Blastus, chamberlain of Agrippa: Ac 12:20.†

to speak lightly or profanely of sacred things (in cl., opp. of εὐφημέω), esp. to speak impiously of God, to blaspheme, speak blasphemously: absol., Mt 9:3 26:65, Mk 2:7, Jo 10:36, Ac 26:11, I Ti 1:20, II Pe 2:12; τ. θεόν, Ac 19:37, Re 16:11, 21; τὸ ὄνομα τ. θεοῦ, Re 13:6 16:9; δόξας, Ju 3, II Pe 2:10; εἰς τὸ πνεῦμα τὸ πνεῦμα τὸ ἅγιον, Mk 3:29, Lk 12:10. to revile, rail at, slander: absol., Lk 22:65, Ac 13:45 18:6, I Pe 4:4; c. acc., Mt 27:39, Mk 3:28 15:29, Lk 23:39, Tit 3:2, Ja 2:7, Ju 10. Pass.: Ro 2:24 3:8 14:16, I Co 10:30, I Ti 6:1, Tit 2:5, II Pe 2:2 (Cremer, 570).†

railing slander: Mt 12:31 15:19, Mk 3:28 7:22, Eph 4:31, Col 3:8, I Ti 6:4, Ju 9, Re 2:9; spec., impious speech against God, blasphemy: Mt 26:65, Mk 14:64, Lk 5:21, Jo 10:33, Re 13:5; ὄνομα βλασφημίας, Re 13:1 17:3; c. gen. obj. Mt 12:31; πρὸς τ. θεόν, Re 13:6 (Cremer, 570; DB, i, 305; DCG ii, 423).†
evil-speaking, slanderous, blasphemous: Ac 6:11, II Ti 3:2, II Pe 2:11 (cf. Ju 9); as subst. a blasphemer: I Ti 1:13 (Cremer, 570).†
a look, a glance: βλέμματι καὶ ἀκοῇ, II Pe 2:8, sight and hearing, a sense not found for β. in Gk. lit., but perh. recognized in the vernacular (ICC, in l.)†

of bodily sight; to see, have sight (opp. to τυφλὸς): Mt 12:22, Jo 9:7, Ac 9:9, Ro 11:8, Re 3:18, al.; to perceive, look (at), see: absol., Ac 1:9; c. acc., Mt 7:3, Mk 5:31, Lk 6:41, Jo 1:29, al.; ὅραμα, Ac 12:9; γυναῖκα, Mt 5:28; βιβλίον, Re 5:3, 4; τ. βλεπόμενα, II Co 4:18. Metaph., of mental vision; to see, perceive, discern: absol., Mt 13:13, Lk 8:10; δι ̓ ἐσόπτρου, I Co 13:12; c. acc., He 2:9 10:25; seq. ὅτι, He 3:19, Ja 2:22; to consider, look to, take heed: absol., Mk 13:23, 33; c. acc., I Co 1:26, al.; seq. πῶς, c. indic., Lk 8:18, I Co 3:10, Eph 5:15; seq. τί, c. indic., Mk 4:24; seq. εἰς πρόσωπον, of partiality, Mt 22:16, Mk 12:14. Colloq. (for ex. from π., V. Deiss., LAE, 122; M, Pr., 107; MM, Exp., x; Milligan, NTD, 50), β. ἑαυτόν: Mk 13:9; seq. ἵνα μή, II Jo 8; β. ἀπό, Mk 8:15 12:38; seq. μή (cl. ὁρᾶν), c. fut. indic., Col 2:8, He 3:12; id. c. aor. subj., Mt 24:4, Mk 13:5. Of situation and direction (Lat. specto), to look, face (towards), places, etc. (seq. πρός, Xen, Hell., vii, 1, 17; Ez 40:23, 24): seq. κατά, c. acc., Ac 27:12 (cf. ἀνα-, ἀπο-, δια-, ἐμ-, ἐπι-, περ-, προ-βλέπω), v. DCG, i, 446; ii, 596.
(that which) one must put: Lk 5:38.†
Boanerges: Mk 3:17.†
absol., to cry, call out: Mt 3:3, 27:46, Mk 1:3 15:34, Lk 3:4 9:38 18:38, Jo 1:23, Ac 8:7 17:6 25:24, Ga 4:27. C. dat., to call on for help (Heb. זעק על, Ho 7:14, al.), Lk 18:7.†
a cry: Ja 5:4.†
help: He 4:16; pl., helps, "frapping," a technical nautical term (MM, Exp., x; DB, ext., 367): Ac 27:17.†
to come to aid, to help, succour: absol., Ac 21:28; c dat., Mt 15:25, Mk 9:22, 24 Ac 16:9, II Co 6:2 (LXX), He 2:18, Re 12:16.†
(poët. -όος), hasting to the war-cry (Hom.). helping, auxiliary; as subst. (Hdt.), a helper: He 13:6 (LXX).†
a throw; λίθου β. (Thuc., v, 65, 2), a stone's throw: Lk 22:41.†
to heave the lead, take soundings: Ac 27:28.†
a dart, javelin: He 12:20, Rec. (LXX).†
mud, filth: II Pe 2:22.†
Boreas, the North wind. the north: Lk 13:29, Re 21:13.†
prop., of a herdsman, to feed: Mt 8:33, Mk 5:14, Lk 8:34 15:15; metaph., of Christian pastoral care, Jo 21:15, 17. Pass., of cattle, to feed, graze: Mt 8:30, Mk 5:11, Lk 8:32.†
grass, fodder. green herb: He 6:7.†
a cluster of grapes: Re 14:18 (cf. στραφυλή) .†
a councillor, a senator; of a member of the Sanhedrin: Mk 15:34, Lk 23:50.†

to take counsel, deliberate, resolve. In mid., to take counsel with oneself, consider: seq. εἰ, Lk 14:31. to determine with oneself, resolve: c. inf., Ac 5:33 27:39; c. acc., II Co 1:17; seq. ἵνα, Jo 11:53 12:10 (cf. παρα-, συμ-).†

counsel, purpose (in cl., esp. of the gods): Lk 23:51, Ac 4:28 5:38 19:1 27:12, 42; pl., I Co 4:5; of the Divine purpose, He 6:17; τ. βουλὴν τ. θελήματος αὐτοῦ, Eph 1:11; β. τ. Θεοῦ, Lk 7:30, Ac 2:23 13:36 20:27.†
purpose, will: Ac 27:43, Ro 9:19, I Pe 4:3.†

to will, wish, desire, purpose, be minded, implying more strongly than θέλω (q.v.), the deliberate exercise of volition (v. Hort on Ja 1:18): c. inf. (M, Pr., 205; Bl., §69, 4), Mk 15:15, Ac 5:28, 33 12:4 15:37 17:20 18:15, 27 19:30 22:30 23:28 27:43 28:18, II Co 1:15, I Ti 6:9, He 6:17, II Jo 12, III Jo 10, Ju 5; c. acc., II Co 1:17; c. acc. et inf., Phl 1:12, I Ti 2:8 5:14, Tit 3:8, II Pe 3:9; of the will making choice between alternatives, Mt 1:19 11:27, Lk 10:22, Ac 25:20, I Co 12:11, Ja 3:4 4:4; εἰ βούλει (cl., a courteous phrase = θέλεις, colloq.; Bl., §21, 8; LS, s.v.), Lk 22:42; c. subjc., adding force to a question of deliberation (Bl., §64, 6), Jo 18:39; βουληθείς, of set purpose (v. Hort, in l.), Ja 1:18; impf., ἐβουλόμην (= cl. βουλοίμην ἄν; Bl., §63, 5; Lft., Phm. 13), Ac 25:22, Phm 13 (v. also Cremer, 143).†
a hill: Lk 3:5 (LXX) 23:30.†
a prize in the games: I Co 9:24; metaph., of the Christian's reward, Phl 3:14.†

prop., to act as umpire; hence, generally, to arbitrate, decide (Isocr., Dem.; Lft., Col., l.c.; MM, s.v.): Col 3:15; in some late writers, to direct, rule, control (so in Col., l.c., acc. to Thayer, s.v., Meyer, in l.), (cf. κατα-βραβεύω).†
trans., to retard (Soph., Is, l.c.). More freq. intrans., to be slow, to tarry: I Ti 3:15, II Pe 3:9.†
to sail slowly: Ac 27:7.†
slow: εἰς τὸ λαλῆσαι, Ja 1:19; metaph., of the understanding: β. τ. καρδίᾳ, assoc. with ἀνόητος, Lk 24:25.†
slowness: II Pe 3:9.†
the arm; as in OT, β. Κυρίου, metaph., for the Divine power: Lk 1:51, Jo 12:38 (LXX), Ac 13:17.†

short; of time; short, little: βραχύ, Ac 5:34; μετὰ β., Lk 22:58; β. τι, a short time, He 2:7, 9 RV, mg.; of distance: Ac 27:28; of quantity or value, little, few: Jo 6:7, He 2:7, 9 RV, txt.; pl., διὰ βραχέων, in few words, He 13:22.†
an unborn child: Lk 1:41, 44. a newborn child, a babe: Lk 2:12, 16 18:15, Ac 7:19, I Pe 2:2; ἀπὸ βρέφους, from infancy, II Ti 3:15.†

to wet: Lk 7:38, 44. In late Gk. writers and vernac. = ὕειν, to send rain, to rain (Kennedy, Sources, 39, 155): Mt 5:45; trop., β. πῦρ κ. θεῖον, Lk 17:29; impers., βρέχει, it rains: Ja 5:17; with ὐετός as subj., Re 11:6. †
= βροχετός, a wetting (in π., of irrigation in Egypt; Deiss., LAE, 77). As in MGr. (Kennedy, Sources, 153), = ὑετός, rain: Mt 7:25, 27.†
a noose, a slip-knot, a halter: metaph., a restraint (not, as AV, R, txt., a snare): I Co 7:35.†
a biting, a gnashing of teeth: Mt 8:12 13:42, 50 22:13 24:51 25:30, Lk 13:28.†
to bite or eat greedily. to gnash, grind, with the teeth: Ac 7:54.†
to be full to bursting; of the earth producing vegetation. Of plants putting forth buds. Of springs, to gush with water: Ja 3:11.†
food: Ro 14:15, 20 I Co 8:8, 13 10:3; pl., Mt 14:15, Mk 7:19, Lk 3:11 9:13, I Co 6:13, I Ti 4:3, He 9:10 13:9; trop., of spiritual food, Jo 4:34, I Co 3:2 (cf. βρῶσις).†
eatable: Lk 24:41.†

eating: β. καὶ πόσις, Ro 14:17, Col 2:16 (v. Lft., ICC, in l.); c. gen. obj., I Co 8:4; metaph., corrosion, rust: Mt 6:19, 20. As also in cl. (Hom., al.) = βρῶμα, food: Jo 6:27a, II Co 9:10, Col 2:16 (EV, but v. supr.). He 12:16; metaph., of spiritual nourishment, Jo 4:32 6:27b, 55.†
trans., to cause to sink, to sink: metaph., εἰς ὄλεθρον, I Ti 6:9; pass., to sink, intrans.: Lk 5:7.†
the bottom. the depth of the sea, the deep sea: II Co 11:25.†
made of βύσσος, fine linen: Re 18:12, 16 19:8, 14.†
byssus, a fine species of flax, also the linen made from it: Lk 16:19.†
any raised place, a platform. an altar: Ac 17:23 (cf. θυσιαστήριον and v. DB, i, 75).†
Gabbatha, the Greek transliteration of an uncertain Aramaic word (DB, s.v.; Dalman, Words, 7), used as the equivalent of λιθόστρωτον, stone pavement: Jo 19:13.†
the archangel Gabriel: Lk 1:19, 26.†
a gangrene, an eating sore, which leads to mortification: II Ti 2:17.†
Gadarene, of Gadara: Mt 8:28 (Rec. Γεργεσηνῶν), Mk 5:1, Rec. (Edd., Γερασηνῶν), Lk 8:26, 37 Rec. (Edd., Γερασηνῶν).†
treasure: Ac 8:27.†
Gaza, in OT, one of the five chief cities of the Philistines: Ac 8:26.†
treasury: also, apparently, the trumpet-shaped chests into which the peoples' temple-offerings were thrown (DB, iv, 96; DCG, ii, 748): Mk 12:41, 43 Lk 21:1, Jo 8:20.†
Gaius, the name of a Christian; of Macedonia: Ac 19:29. Of Derbe: Ac 20:4. Of Corinth: Ro 16:23, I Co 1:14. The one to whom in Ep. Jo is addressed: III Jo 1.†

milk: I Co 9:7. Metaph., of elementary Christian teaching: I Co 3:2, He 5:12, 13; τὸ λογικὸν ἄδολον γ., the rational (spiritual) genuine milk (v. Hort, in l.), I Pe 2:2 (in support of AV, milk of the word, v. ICC, in l.).†
a Galatian: Ga 3:1.†
Galatia; a gentilic region in Asia Minor, settled by Gauls (iii/B.C). A Roman Province which included this region (DB, ii, 85ff.): I Co 16:1, Ga 1:2, II Ti 4:10 (T, Tr., mg., Γαλλίαν), I Pe 1:1.†
Galatian, belonging to Galatia: Ac 16:6 18:23.†
Galilee, the name of the northern region of Palestine in NT times: Γ. τῶν ἐθνῶν, Mt 4:15 (LXX); θάλασσα τῆς Γ., Mt 15:29 (cf. Jo 6:1).
Gaul: T., Tr., mg., for Γαλατία, II Ti 4:10.†
Gallio, proconsul of Achaia: Ac 18:12, 14 17.†
Gamaliel the elder, a Pharisee and Doctor of the Law: Ac 5:34 22:3.†

to marry; of the man, to marry, take to wife (ducere): absol., Mt 19:10 22:25, 30 24:38, Mk 12:25, Lk 17:27, 20:34, 35, I Co 7:28, 33; c. acc.: Mt 5:32 19:9, Mk 6:17 10:11, Lk 14:20 16:18. Of the woman, mid. (and in late writers, pass.), to give oneself in marriage, marry (nubere): I Co 7:39; in Hellenistic (M, Pr., 159), act. (as of the man), to marry: absol., I Co 7:28, 34 I Ti 5:11, 14. c acc., Mk 10:12. Of both sexes: absol., I Ti 4:3, I Co 7:9, 10 36.†
to give in marriage, a daughter: I Co 7:38. Pass., Mt 22:30 24:38, Mk 12:25, Lk 17:27 20:35 (WH, mg., γαμίσκονται; cf. γαμίζω).†
a wedding, esp. a wedding-feast: Mt 22:8, 10 11, 12, Jo 2:1-3, Re 19:7, 9; pl. (Field, Notes, 16), Mt 22:2-4, 9 25:10, Lk 12:36 14:8. marriage: He 13:4 (Cremer, 666).†

verily then, hence, in truth, indeed, yea, then, why, and when giving a reason or explanation, for, the usage in NT being in general accord with that of cl.; explicative and epexegetic: Mt 4:18 19:12, Mk 1:16 5:42 16:4, Lk 11:3o, Ro 7:1, I Co 16:5, al. Conclusive, in questions, answers and exclamations: Mt 9:5 27:23, Lk 9:25 22:27, Jo 9:30, Ac 8:31 16:37 19:35, Ro 15:26, I Co 9:10, Phl 1:18 (Ellic., in l.), I Th 2:20, al. Causal: Mt 1:21 2:2, 5, 6, 3:23, Mk 1:22, 9:6, Lk 1:15, 18, Jo 2:25, Ac 2:25, Ro 1:9, 11, I Co 11:5, Re 1:3, al.; giving the reason for a command or prohibition, Mt 2:20 3:9, Ro 13:11, Col 3:3, I Th 4:3, al.; where the cause is contained in an interrog. statement, Lk 22:27, Ro 3:3 4:3, I Co 10:29; καὶ γάρ, for also, Mk 10:45, Lk 6:32, I Co 5:7, al. id. as in cl. = etenim, where the καί loses its connective force (Bl., §78, 6; Kühner 3, ii, 854f.), Mk 14:70, Lk 1:66 22:37, II Co 13:4. The proper place of γάρ is after the first word in a clause, but in poets it often comes third or fourth, and so in late prose: II Co 1:19. Yet "not the number but the nature of the word after which it stands is the point to be noticed" (v. Thayer, s.v.).
the belly: metaph., a glutton, Tit 1:12. the womb: ἐν γ. ἔχειν, to be with child, Mt 1:18, 23 (LXX) 24:19, Mk 13:17, Lk 21:23, I Th 5:3, Re 12:2; εν γ. συλλαμβ., to conceive, Lk 1:31.†

indeed, at least, even (but not always translatable into English); used alone: Lk 11:8 18:5 Ro 8:32. More freq. with other particles: αλλά γε, Lk 24:21, I Co 9:2; ἄρα γε, Mt 7:20 17:26, Ac 17:27; ἆρά γε, Ac 8:30; εἴ γε (Rec. εἴγε), II Co 5:3, Ga 3:4, Eph 3:2 4:21, Col 1:23 (v. Meyer, Ellic., on Ga, Eph, ll. c.; Lft., on Ga, Col, ll. c.); εἰ δὲ μήγε, following an affirmation, Mt 6:1, Lk 10:6 13:9; a negation, Mt 9:17, Lk 5:36, 37 14:32, II Co 11:16; καί γε (Rec. καίγε, cl. καὶ . . . γε), Lk 19:42 (WH om.), Ac 2:18 17:27; καίτοιγε (L καίτοι γε, Tr. καί τοι γε), Jo 4:2; μενοῦνγε (v. s.v.); μήτι γε, v.s. μήτι; ὄφελόν, I Co 4:8.†
Gideon (Jg 6-8): He 11:32.†

Gehenna, a valley W. and S. of Jerusalem, which as the site of fire-worship from the time of Ahaz, was desecrated by Josiah and became a dumping-place for the offal of the city.
