In composition, ἐπί signifies: up, ἐπαίρω; upon, ἐπίγειος, ἐπιδημέω, ὠπικαθίζω; towards, επιβλέπω, ὠπεκτείνω; over (of superintendence), ἐπιστάτης; again, in addition, ἐπαιτέω; against, ἐπιορκέω, ἐπιβουλή.

to get up on, mount: seq. ἐπί, c. acc, Mt 21:5 (LXX); to embark in (a boat), go aboard: c. dat., Ac 27:2; seq. εἰς, Ac 21:6 (Rec.); absol., Ac 21:2.; to go up to, go on to, enter: seq. εἰς, Ac 20:18 21:4; c. dat., Ac 25:1.†

trans., to cast, lay or put upon: c. acc et dat., Mk 11:7, I Co 7:35; c. acc, seq. ἐπί c. acc, Re 18:10, WH, mg.; τ. Χεῖρα (-ας) ἐπί (B1., § 37, 7), of seizing a prisoner, Mt 26:50, Lk 20:19 21:12, Jo 7:30, Ac 5:18 21:27; c. dat. (Polyb.), Mk 14:46 Ac 4:3; c. inf., Ac 12:1; τὴν χ. ἐπ' ἄροτρον, Lk 9:62; ἐπίβλημα ἐπὶ ἱμάτιον, Lk 5:36; ἐπὶ ἱματίῳ, Mt 9:16.; Intrans.,; to throw oneself or rush upon: τ. κύματα εἰς τ. πλοῖον, Mk 4:37; metaph., to put one's mind upon (but v. Field, Notes, 41 ff.), ἐπιβαλὼν ἔκλαιεν, when he thought thereon (sc. τ. ῥήματι), he wept (EV, txt.; R, mg., he began to weep; cf. M, Pr., 131): Mk 14:72 (v. also Swete, in l); to fall to one's share: τὸ ἐπιβάλλον (sc. dat.; Hdt., a1., a technical formula freq. in π.; Deiss., BS, 230, LAE, 152), Lk 15:12.†
to put a burden on, be burdensome: fig., absol., II Co 2:6; c. acc pers., I Th 2:9, II Th 3:8 (cf. M, Th., I, 29).†
to place upon: c. acc pers., Lk 10:34 19:35, Ac 23:24.†
to look upon. In NT, as in LXX (I Ki 1:11 9:1, Ps 25:16; To 3:3, al.), to look on with favour: seq. ἐπί c. acc pers., Lk 1:48 9:38, Ja 2:3.†
that which is thrown over, a cover.; a tapestry, hanging (Is, l.c.).; that which is put on; embroidery; a patch: Mt 9:16, Mk 2:21, Lk 5:36.†
to cry out: Ac 25:24 (Rec., for βοάω, q.v.).†
a plan against, a plot: Ac 9:24 20:3, 19 23:30.†
to enter into affinity with: c. dat. (LXX, H. c., exc. Ge 38:8).; to marry (as deceased husband's next of kin, cf. Ge 38:8): c. acc, Mt 22:24.†
of the earth, earthly: τὰ ἐ., Jo 3:12 Phl 2:10 3:19 (anarth.); σώματα, I Co 15:40; οἰκία, II Co 5:1; σοφία, Ja 3:15 (Cremer, 153).†
to arrive, arise, come on: Ac 28:13.†

"directive" of γινώσκω (AR, Eph., 249), as in cl.; to observe, perceive, discern, recognize; absol.: Ac 25:10, I Co 13:12; seq. ὅτι, Lk 1:22; τ. πνεύματι, seq. ὅτι, Mk 2:8; c. acc rei: Lk 1:4 5:22, Ac 12:14 27:39, Ro 1:32, II Co 1:13, Col 1:6, I Ti 4:3; ἐν ἐαυτῷ, Mk 5:30; seq. ὅτι, I Co 14:37; c. acc pers.: Mt 11:27 14:36 17:12, Mk 6:33 (T, αὐτούς, but LTr., WH, R, omit the prop., and LTr., WH, txt., read ἔγνωσαν), Mk 6:54 Lk 24:16, 31, I Co 16:18, II Co 1:14; seq. ἀπό, c. gen. rei, Mt 7:16, 20; seq. ὅτι, Ac 3:10 4:13, II Co 13:5; pass., I Co 13:12; opp. to ἀγνοούμενοι, II Co 6:9.; to discover, ascertain, determine: Ac 9:30; seq. ὅτι, Lk 7:37 23:7, Ac 19:34 22:29 24:11 28:1; c. acc rei, seq. quæst., Ac 23:28; δι' ἣν αἰτίαν, Ac 22:24; παρά, c. gen. pers., seq. περ, c. gen. rei, Ac 24:8; τ. ὁδὸν τῆς δικαιοσύνης, II Pe 2:21 (cf. Lft., Col., 136; Cremer, 159; M, Pr., 113; AR, Eph., 248 ff.).†

acquaintance, discernment, recognition (Plut., al.): Phl 1:9, Col 3:10; c. gen. rei, Col 1:9 2:2, Phm 6; τ. ἀληθείας, I Ti 2:4, II Ti 2:25 3:7, Tit 1:1, He 10:26; τ. ἁμαρτίας, Ro 3:20; c. gen. pers., of God: Eph 1:17, Col 1:10, II Pe 1:2-3; of Christ: Eph 4:13, II Pe 1:8 2:20; of God and Christ: II Pe 1:2; κατ ̓ ἐ., Ro 10:2; ἔχειν ἐν ἐ., Ro 1:28 (v. AR, Eph., 248 ff.; and for a somewhat different view, Thayer, s.v.; Lft. on Col, 1:9; Tr., Syn., LXXv; Cremer, 159 f.; cf. αἴσθησις).†
to write upon, inscribe: Mk 15:26, Ac 17:23, Re 21:12; fig., He 8:10 (LXX) He 10:16.†

to show, exhibit, display: c. acc et dat., Mt 16:1 22:19 24:1, Lk 17:14. Mid., to display for oneself or as one's own (but cf. El., § 55, 1): Ac 9:39.; to show, point out, prove: c. acc, He 6:17; c. acc et inf., Ac 18:28 (cf. MM, Exp., xiv).†

in cl., of things, to allow of, admit of (Dem., Arist., al.). In late writers,; to accept besides (Polyb.), to accept (in π. of the terms of a lease; v. ICC, on 3Jo, l.c.): III Jn 9.; (a) to receive besides (Menand.); to receive hospitably (1Mac, Sir, ll c.): III Jn 10†
to be at home (Thuc., Plat., al.),; to stay in a place, sojourn (Plat., Xen., al.; and v. MM, Exp., xiv): Ac 2:10 17:21; seq. ἐν, Ac 18:27 (WH, mg.).†
to add provisions to a document: Ga 3:15 (cf. ἐπιδιαθήκη, a second will, F1J, BJ, ii, 2, 3; the word is used of wills in π., cf. Deiss., LAE, 87).†
to give over, to hand: c. acc rei et dat. pers., Mt 7:9, 19, Lk 11:11-12 24:30, 42, Ac 15:30; pass. c. dat. pers., Lk 4:17.; to give in, give way: absol., Ac 27:15.†
to set in order further: Tit 1:5 (Inscr.; Cremer, 8O8).†
to go down, set (of the sun): Eph 4:26.†
seemly, fitting (Hom.).; equitable, fair, moderate: I Ti 3:3, Tit 3:2, I Pe 2:18, Ja 3:17; τὸ ἐ. (Thuc., i, 76), Phl 4:5 (cf. Mayor, Ja, l.c., and v.s. ἐπιεικία).†; ἐπιείκεια v.s. ἐπιεικία
fairness, moderation, gentleness ("sweet reasonableness," Matthew Arnold): Ac 24:4; c. πραΰτης, II Co 10:1.†

"directive" of ζητέω (MM, Exp., xiv),; to inquire for, seek after, wish for: c. acc rei, Mt 6:32 12:39 16:4, Lk 12:30, Ac 19:39, Ro 11:7, Phl 4:17, He 11:14 13:14; c. acc pers., Lk 4:42, Ac 12:19; c. inf., Ac 13:7.†
condemned to death: I Co 4:9.†
a laying on: χειρῶν, Ac 8:18, I Ti 4:14, II Ti 1:6, He 6:2 (cf. Westc., He., l.c.; CGT on 1Ti, l.c.).; an attack, assault (2Mac, ll.c.).†

to set one's heart upon, desire, lust after, covet: absol., Ja 4:2, Ro 7:7 13:9 (LXX), I Co 10:6 (of. IV Mac 2:6); seq. κατά (against, in opposition to), Ga 5:17; prop. (as in cl.) c. gen., Ac 20:33, I Ti 3:1; in late Gk. also c. acc (M, Pr., 65), Mt 5:28 (Rec. αὐτῆς; T omits; cf. Ex 20:17, Mi 2:2, Wi 16:3, al.); c. inf., Mt 13:17, Lk 15:16 16:21 17:22, I Pe 1:12, Re 9:6; c. acc et inf., He 6:11; as in Hebrew, ἐπιθυμία ἐπεθύμησα, Lk 22:15.†
one longing for, lustful after: κακῶν, I Co 10:6.†

desire, longing: Lk 22:15 (v.s. ἐπιθυμέω), Phl 1:23, I Th 2:17, Re 18:14; p1., Mk 4:19; esp. with ref. to forbidden things, desire, lust (Vg., concupiscentia): Ro 7:7-8, Ja 1:14-15, II Pe 1:4; pl., Ga 5:24, I Ti 6:9, II Ti 2:22 4:3, I Pe 1:14 4:2; πάθος ἐπιθυμίας, I Th 4:5; ἐ. κακή, Col 3:5; c. gen., μιασμοῦ, II Pe 2:10 (v. Mayor, in l); τ. καρδιῶν, Ro 1:24; τ. κόσμου (aroused by the world), I Jn 2:17; τ. σώματος, Ro 6:12; τ. ἀπάτης, Eph 4:22 (v. ICC, in l); τ. σαρκός, I Jn 2:16, II Pe 2:18 (without art.), Ga 5:16; τ. ὀφθαλμῶν, I Jn 2:16; σαρκικαὶ ἐ., I Pe 2:11 (cf. IV Mac 1:32); κοσμικαί, Tit 2:12; εἰς ἐπιθυμίας, Ro 13:14; ποιεῖν τὰς ἐ., Jo 8:44; ὑπακούειν ταῖς ἐ., Ro 6:12; δουλεύειν, ἄγεσθαι, ἐπιθυμίαις, Tit 3:3, II Ti 3:6; πορεύειθαι ἐν ἐ., I Pe 4:3; κατά, Ju 16 18, II Pe 3:3; ἀναστρέφεσθαι ἐν ταῖς ἐ., Eph 2:3.†
to sit upon: Mt 21:7.†

to call, name, surname: c. acc (cl.), Mt 10:25; pass., Ac 1:23 4:36 10:5, 18 10:22 11:13 12:12, 25, He 11:16; τ. ὄνομα, seq. ἐπί (denoting possession, as Heb. עַל. . שֻׁם קָרָא), Ac 15:17 (LXX), Ja 2:7 (see. CB on Am 9:12).; Mid. (so also act.; cl., LXX), to call upon, invoke, appeal to (θεόν, θεούς, Hdt., Xen., al.; cf. Deiss., LAE, 426): Καίσαρα (Σεβαστόν, Ac 25:25), Ac 25:11-12, 21 26:32 28:19; sc. τ. Κύριον Ἰησοῦν, Ac 7:59; μάρτυρα (cl.) τ. θεόν, II Co 1:23; πατέρα, I Pe 1:17; τ. κύριον, Ro 10:12, II Ti 2:22; τ. ὄνομα κυρίου (μου, σου; like Heb. יְהֹוָה שֻׁם קָרָא), Ac 2:21 (LXX) Ac 9:14, 21 22:16, Ro 10:13-14 (LXX) I Co 1:2 (Cremer, 335, 742).†
a cover, veil: metaph., τ. κακίας, I Pe 2:16.†
to cover over, cover up: metaph., Ro 4:7 (LXX).†
accursed: Ga 3:10 (LXX) Ga 3:13 (LXX κεκαταραμένος) (Cremer, 109).†
to be placed, lie on: Jo 21:9; seq. ἐπί, c. dat., Jo 11:38; fig., He 9:10; ἀνάγκη, I Co 9:16; χειμῶν, to threaten, come on: Ac 27:20; of persons, to press upon: Lk 5:1 23:23.†
of a ship, to run ashore: c. acc, Ac 27:41.†
a poll-tax: Mk 12:14 (WH, mg., for κῆνσον, as in D, Syrr. Sin. pesh., 124, etc.).†
aid, assistance: Ac 26:22.†
an Epicurean, a follower of Epicurus: Ac 17:18.†
to decree, give sentence: c. acc et inf., Lk 23:24.†

always mid. in LXX and NT (v. Cremer, 758), to lap hold of: c. gen. pers., Mt 14:31, Ac 17:19 21:30, 33; c. acc pers. (not cl.), Lk 9:47 14:4 23:26 (WH, but v. Bl., 1015), Ac 9:27 16:9 18:17; c. gen. rei, Mk 8:23, Ac 23:10, He 8:9 (LXX); c. gen. pers. et rei, Lk 20:20, 26; τ. αἰωνίου (ὄντως) ζωῆς, I Ti 6:12 6:19. Metaph. (as in Si 4:11), He 2:16 (v. Westc., in l).†

to forget, neglect: c. inf., Mt 16:5, Mk 8:14; c. gen., He 6:10 13:2, 16; c. acc (as occasionally in cl.; MM, Exp., xiv), Phl 3:13; ὁποῖος ἦν, Ja 1:24; pass. ptcp. (cf. Is 23:16, Si 3:14 23:14, Wi 2:4), Lk 12:6.†
to say in addition (Hdt.).; to call by name, to call: Jo 5:2.; to choose; mid., to choose for oneself: Ac 15:40.†
to fail: c. acc pers., He 11:32.†
to lick over: c. acc, Lk 16:21 (of. MM, Exp., xiv).†
forgetful­ness: ἀκροατὴς ἐ. (gen. of qual.), Ja 1:25.†
still left, remaining: χρόνος, I Pe 4:2.†
release.; solution, interpretation: II Pe 1:20.†
to loose, release.; to solve, settle, explain: Mk 4:34, Ac 19:39.†
to bear witness to: c. acc et. inf., I Pe 5:12,†
attention, care: Ac 27:3 (v. Field, Notes, 143).†
to take care of: c. gen., Lk 10:34-35, I Ti 3:5.†
carefully: Lk 15:8.†

to stay on, tarry or abide still: seq. έν, I Co 16:8; αὐτοῦ, there, Ac 15:34 (WH, txt., RV, txt., omit) Ac 21:4; c. dat., τ. σαρκί, Phl 1:24; seq. παρά, c. dat. pers., Ac 28:14; πρός, c. acc pers., I Co 16:7, Ga 1:18; c. acc temp., Ac 10:48 21:4, 10 28:12, 14, I Co 16:7. Metaph., to continue in a pursuit or state: c. dat., τ. ἀμαρτίᾳ, Ro 6:1; τ. ὰπιστίᾳ, Ro 11:23; τ. πίστει, Col 1:23; αὐτοῖς (v. CGT, in l), I Ti 4:16; τ. χρηστότητι, Ro 11:22; c. ptcp. (cf. Bl., § 73, 4; 76, 2), Jo 8:7, Ac 12:16.†
to nod in command or approval, to nod approval, consent: Ac 18:20.†
a thought, design: Ac 8:22.†
to swear falsely, forswear oneself: Mt 5:33.†
of oaths, sworn falsely.; Of persons, perjured; as subst., a perjurer, false swearer: I Ti 1:10.†

found only in the phrase ἄρτος ἐ., EV, daily; R, mg., for the coming day: Mt 6:11, Lk 11:3. (Several derivations find support, each pointing to a different meaning.; < ἐπιοῦσα (sc. ἡμέρα) (or, < ἐπὶ τὴν ἰοῦσαν (sc. ήμέραν), Zorell, s.v.), hence, for the morrow or for the coming day (R, mg.).; (a) < ἐπί + οὐσία, hence, for subsistence, needful (Am. R, mg.); < ἐπί + εἶναι in fern. ptcp. form, hence, pertaining to (the day). For renderings of versions and views of various writers, v. reff. in DB, ext., 36 f.; DCG, ii, 58 f., 62a; ICC on Lk, l.c. The EV, daily, is based on the Vg. (Lk; OL, Mt, Lk, quotidianus). "It is difficult not to think that τὸν ἐ. rests upon misunderstanding of an original Aramaic phrase, or upon a Greek corruption" (ICC on Mt, l.c.; cf. also Cremer, 239).†

to fall upon (Field, Notes, 25): c. dat. pers., Mk 3:10 (v. Swete, in l), Ac 20:10; seq. ἐπὶ τ. τράχηλον (as Ge 46:29, To 11:8, III Mac 5:49, al.), Lk 15:20, Ac 20:37. Metaph., φόβος, Lk 1:12, Ac 19:17, Re 11:11; ὀνειδισμοί, Ro 15:3 (LXX); of the Holy Spirit: seq. ἐπί, c. dat., Ac 8:16; ἐπί, c. acc, Ac 10:44 11:15; absol., Ac 23:7.†
to strike at, to punish.; to rebuke, reprove: I Ti 5:1.†
to long for, desire: c. inf., Ro 1:11, II Co 5:2, I Th 3:6, II Ti 1:4, Phl 2:26 (WH, [txt.]); c. acc rei, I Pe 2:2; c. acc pers., II Co 9:14, Phl 1:8 2:26 (WH, mg); absol., Ja 4:5 (v. Mayor, in l).†
longing: II Co 7:7 7:11.†
greatly desired, longed for: Phl 4:1.†
longing: Ro 15:23.†
to travel, journey to: seq. πρός, c. acc pers., Lk 8:4.†
to sew upon: seq. ἐπί, c. acc, Mk 2:21.†
to cast at.; to cast or place upon: c. acc seq. ἐπί, c. acc, Lk 19:35; metaph., τ. μέριμναν, I Pe 5:7 (LXX).†
bearing a mark; of money, stamped, coined.; Metaph.,; in good sense, notable, illustrious: Ro 16:7; in bad sense, notorious: Mt 27:16.†
a foraging.; provisions, food: Lk 9:12.†

to inspect, examine.; (a) to visit: c. acc, Ac 7:23 15:36 (cf. Jg 15:1); especially, the sick and afflicted (as in MGr. and sometimes in cl.), Mt 25:36, 43, Ja 1:27 (cf. Si 7:35); in LXX and NT (as פָּקַד in Ge 21:1, Ex 4:31, Ps 8:5, al.), to visit with help, to care for: Lk 1:68, 78 7:16, Ac 15:14, He 2:6; to visit with punishment (Je 9:25, Ps 89:33, al.; cf. MM, Exp., xiv; Cremer, 863).†
to tent upon, spread a tabernacle over: metaph., seq. ἐπ' ἐμέ (RV, rest upon, cover), II Co 12:9.†

to throw a shadow upon, overshadow: c. dat., Ac 5:15; of a shining (Mt, l.c., and cf. Ex 40:29, 35, II Mac 2:8) cloud, c. dat., Mk 9:7; c. acc, Mt 17:5, Lk 9:34; metaph. (cf. Pss, Pr, ll.c.), of the Holy Spirit, Lk 1:35.†
to look upon, observe, examine: seq. μή, He 12:16.; As ἐπισκέπτομαι in LXX, NT, to visit, care for: I Pe 5:2 (R, txt.; WH cm.; Cremer, 527).†

a visiting, visitation (εἰς ἐ. τοῦ παιδός, Lucian, dial. deor., 20, 6); as in LXX (after Heb.), of God's visitation in mercy, or in judgment (Le 19:20 Jb 10:12, Je 6:15, Wi 2:20, al.): Lk 19:44, I Pe 2:12 (v. Hort, in l).; office, charge, esp. office of an ἐπίσκοιος (q.v.): Ac 1:20 (LXX), I Ti 3:1 (Cremer, 527 f., 864; DCG, ii, 809b).†

a superintendent, guardian, overseer (cl.; for exx. v. LS, s.v.): Ac 20:28, I Pe 2:25 (ICC, in l); as technical term for a religious office (Deiss., BS, 230 f.), in later Paul. epp. of the head of a church (Vg. episcopus), a bishop: Phl 1:1, I Ti 3:2, Tit 1:7 (v. reff. s.v. ἐπισκοπή).†
to draw on: mid., in peculiar sense of effacing signs of Judaism (cf. I Mac 1:15, FlJ, Ant., xii, 5, i; v. Thayer, s.v.), to become as uncircumcised: I Co 7:18.†
to sow upon or besides: ἀνὰ μέσον, Mt 13:25.†

to know, know of, understand: c. acc pers., Ac 19:15; c. ptcp., Ac 24:10; c. acc rei, Mk 14:68, Ac 18:25, I Ti 6:4, Ja 4:14, Ju 10; seq. περί, Ac 26:26; ὅτι, Ac 15:7 19:25 22:19; ὡς, Ac 10:28; πῶς, Ac 20:18; ποῦ, He 11:8.†; SYN: γινώσκω (q.v.), οἶδα

a stopping, halting (as of soldiers): ὄχλου, collecting a crowd (v. Rack-ham, Acts, l.c.): Ac 24:12 (WH, Rec. ἐπισύστασις).; superintendence, attention (but v. Thayer, s.v.; Field, Notes, 185 f.): II Co 11:28 (WH, Rec. ut supr.).†
a chief, commander, master: Lk 5:5 8:24, 45 9:33, 49 17:13 (cf. Dalman, Words, 336 ff.).†
to send to.; to send a message by letter, to write word (MM, Exp., xiv): c. dat. pers., Ac 21:25, He 13:22; seq. τοῦ, c. inf., Ac 15:20.†
knowing, skilled: Ja 3:13.†
to make stronger, confirm: c. acc, Ac 14:22 15:32, 41.†

a message.; a letter, an epistle: Ac 9:2, I Co 5:9, al.; pl., Ac 22:5, I Co 16:3, al.; ἐ. σνστατικαί, II Co 3:1 (cf. Milligan, NTD, 254 f.). (On the NT ἐπιστολαί, cf. Milligan, Th., 121 ff.; NTD, 85 ff.; Deiss., BS, 3 ff.; St. Paul, 8 ff.)
to bridle; metaph., to stop the mouth, to silence: Tit 1:11.†

trans., to turn about, round or towards, hence metaph., to turn, cause to return (to God, virtue, etc.): Lk 1:16-17 (cf. Ma 3:24), Ja 5:19-20.; Intrans.,; to turn, turn oneself around: Ac 16:18; c. inf., Re 1:12; seq. πρός, Ac 9:40; so also pass. (cl.), Mk 5:30 8:33, Jo 21:20; metaph., of turning to God (v. Field, Notes, 246 ff.), ἐπὶ τ. κύριον (θεόν), Ac 9:35 11:21 14:15 15:19 26:20; πρὸς τ. θεόν, I Th 1:9, II Co 3:16; ἀπὸ σκότους εἰς φῶς, Ac 26:18; pass., I Pe 2:25; to return (as in MGr.): Lk 8:55, Ac 15:36; seq. ὀπίσω, c. inf., Mt 24:18; seq. εἰς, Mt 12:44, Mk 13:16, Lk 2:39 17:31; ἐπί, II Pe 2:22; metaph., seq. ἐπί, Ga 4:9; πρός, Lk 17:4; of moral reform, Mt 13:15, Mk 4:12, Lk 22:32, Ac 3:19 28:27; pass., Mt 10:13 (Cremer, 531, 881).†
a turning about; metaph., conversion (Field, Notes, 246): Ac 15:3.†
to gather together: Mt 23:37 24:31, Mk 13:27, Lk 13:34; pass., Mk 1:33, Lk 12:1 17:37, (cf. Ps 102:23 106:47, II Mac 1:27, al.).; to gather together against (Mi 4:11, Za 12:3, I Mac 3:58, al.).†
a gathering together, assembly: He 10:25; seq. ἐπί, II Th 2:1 (cf. 2Mac, l.c.).†
to run together again: Mk 9:25 (v. Swete, in l).†
a gathering, a riotous throng: Rec. (for ἐπίστασις, q.v.), Ac 24:12, II Co 11:28.†
prone to fall (Plat.).; dangerous (Hipp., Plut., al.): Ac 27:9.†
to make stronger (Sir, l.c.).; to grow stronger; metaph., be more urgent: Lk 23:5.†
to heap together; metaph., διδασκάλους, II Ti 4:3.†
= cl., ἐπίταγμα,; a command, Ro 16:26, I Co 7:6 7:25, II Co 8:8, I Ti 1:1, Tit 1:3 (for use in Inscr. of divine commands, v. MM, Exp., xiv); μετὰ πάσης ἐ, with all authority: Tit 2:15.†
to command, charge: c. acc rei, Lk 14:22; c. dat. pers., Mk 1:27 9:25, Lk 4:36 8:25; id. c. acc rei, Phm 8; id. c. inf., Mk 6:39, Lk 8:31, Ac 23:2; id. c. imperat., Mk 9:25; c. acc et inf., Mk 6:27.†

to complete, accomplish, execute: c. acc rei, Ro 15:28, II Co 7:1 8:6 8:11, Phl 1:6, He 8:5; of religious services (cf. Hdt., ii, 37, al.), He 9:6; art. inf., II Co 8:11. Mid.,; to complete for oneself, make an end (R, mg.; pass., R, txt; cf. Meyer, in l): Ga 3:3; to pay in full, pay the tax, be subject to: c. acc (cf. Xen., Mem., iv, 8, 8), I Pe 5:9 (pass., RV, etc.; cf. Thayer, s.v.; ICC, in 1).†
suitable, convenient,; useful, necessary: τὰ ἐ., necessaries, Ja 2:16,†

to lay, set or place upon: c. acc rei, seq. ἐπί, c. acc rei, Mt 23:4, Lk 15:5, Jo 9:6 (WH, txt. Jo 9:15), Ac 15:10 28:3; ἐπί, c. gen. rei, Mt 27:29; ἐν, ib.; c. dat. pers., σταυρόν, Lk 23:26; στέφανον, Jo 19:2; ὄνομα, Mk 3:16-17; πληγάς, Lk 10:30, Ac 16:23; ἐπί c. acc pers., Re 22:18; of the laying on of hands, τ. χεῖρα (-ας), seq. ἐπί c. acc pers., Mt 9:18, Mk 16:13, Ac 8:17 9:17; c. dat. pers., Mt 19:13, 15, Mk 5:23 6:5 7:32 8:23, Lk 4:40 13:13, Ac 6:6 8:19 9:12 13:3 19:6 28:8, I Ti 5:22. Mid.,; to provide: Ac 28:10 (RV, put on board; cf. Field, Notes, 149); to throw oneself upon, attack: c. dat. pers., Ac 18:10.; to add to: Re 22:18 (v. supr., and cf. Swete, in l).†

to honour.; to raise in price; to mete out due measure; to award; to censure, rebuke, admonish: absol., II Ti 4:2; c. dat., Mt 8:26 17:13 19:13, Mk 4:39 8:32 10:13, Lk 4:39, 41 8:24 9:21, 42 9:55 17:3 18:15 19:39, Ju 9; seq. ἵνα, Mt 12:16 16:20 20:31, Mk 3:12 8:30 10:48, Lk 18:39; seq. λέγων, λέγει, etc., Mt 16:22, Mk 1:25 8:33 9:25, Lk 4:35 23:40.†
citizenship, franchise.; As in Inscr. (LS, s.v.), LXX, l.c. (= cl. τὸ ἐπιτίμιον), punishment, penalty: II Co 2:6.†

to turn to, commit, entrust.; to yield, permit: I Co 16:7, He 6:3; c. dat. pers., Mk 5:13, Jo 19:38; id. c. inf. (cf. M, Pr., 205), Mt 8:21 19:8, Lk 8:32 9:52, 61 Ac 21:39-40 27:3, I Ti 2:12; c. inf., Mk 10:4. Pass., c. dat. et inf., Ac 26:1 28:16, I Co 14:34.†
to govern: Lk 3:1 (WH, mg., for ἡγεμονεύοντος, an obvious correction for precision).†
power to decide, authority: Ac 26:12.†
an administrator, a steward: Mt 20:3, Lk 8:3.; a guardian (c. gen. pers., 2Mac, ll. c.): Ga 4:2.†
to light upon.; to obtain, attain to: Ja 4:2, c. gen. rei (as in cl.), He 6:15 11:33; c. acc (late Gk.), Ro 11:7 (Rec. τούτου).†
to show forth.; (= pass. in cl.) to appear: Ac 27:20; c. dat. pers., Lk 1:79; metaph., Tit 3:4; c. dat., Tit 2:11 (Cremer, 567).†
a manifestation, appear­ance: II Th 2:8, I Ti 6:14, II Ti 1:10 4:1 4:8, Tit 2:13 (cf. M, Th., 148 f.).†
renowned, illustrious, notable: Ac 2:20 (LXX) (cf. MM, Exp., xiv).†
to shine forth: fig., c. dat., Eph 5:14 (on v.l. -ψαύσει, v. ICC, Westc., AR, in l).†
to bring upon or against: κρίσιν, Ju 9.; to impose, inflict: Ro 3:5.†
to call out, shout: c. acc rei, Ac 21:34; c. dat. pers., Ac 22:24; seq. λέγοντες, Lk 23:21; prat. rect., Ac 12:22.†
to let shine.; to dawn (cf. MM, Exp., xiv): Lk 23:54; seq. εἰς, Mat_28:1.†
to pat one's hand to.; to take in hand, attempt: c. inf., Lk 1:1, Ac 9:29 19:13.†
to pour upon: Lk 10:34.†
to supply, provide: c. acc rei, II Pe 1:5; id. c. dat. pers., II Co 9:10, Ga 3:5; pass., Col 2:19, II Pe 1:11 (cf. χορηγέω, and v. MM, Exp., xiv).†
a supply: Eph 4:16, Phl 1:19.†
to spread on, anoint: c. acc, Jo 9:11; id. seq. hi-I, c. acc, Jo 9:6 (cf. MM, Exp., xiv).†
in NT, always metaph., of the spiritual life regarded as a building (Cremer, 449); to build upon: I Co 3:10 3:12 3:14; pass., Eph 2:20.; to build up: Col 2:7, I Pe 2:5 (T, οἰκοδ- WH, Rec.), Ju 20.†
to name, call by a name, surname: pass., Ro 2:17.†
to watch (in Hom., as an overseer; cf Ps, ll. c.), look upon: I Pe 2:12 3:2.†
an overseer (LXX, ll. c.).; a spectator: II Pe 1:16 (of ἐ. as applied to God, v. parallels in Inscr., MM, Exp., xiv; of the use of this term in the mysteries, v. Mayor on 2Pe, l.c.; Thayer, s.v.).†
a word: ὡς ἔ. εἰπεῖν (cl.), so to speak: He 7:9.†

in or of heaven, heavenly (in Hom., of the Gods): οἱ ἐ., opp. to ἐπίγειοι and καταχθόνιοι, Phl 2:10; to χοϊκός, I Co 15:48-49; σώματα (v. Lft., Col., 376), I Co 15:40; βασιλεία, II Ti 4:18; παπρίς, He 11:16; Ἱερουσαλήμ, He 12:22; κλῆσις (cf. Lft. on Phl 3:14), He 3:1; τὰ ἐ., He 8:5 9:23; opp. to ἐπίγειος, Jo 3:12; id., of the heavenly regions, Eph 1:3, 20 2:6 3:10 6:12; ἡ δωρεὰ ἡ ἐ., He 6:4 (Cremer, 468).†
indecl.,; seven: Mt 12:45 18:22 (cf. ἑβδομηκοντάκις), Mk 8:5, al.; οἱ ἐ, Ac 21:8
seven times: Mt 18:21-22, Lk 17:4.†
seven thousand: Ro 11:4.†
Erastus; a companion of St. Paul, Ac 19:22, and prob. II Ti 4:20.; The treasurer of Corinth, Ro 16:23.†
to search, examine: Jo 7:52; c. acc rei, Jo 5:39, Ro 8:27, I Co 2:10, Re 2:23; seq. orat. obliq., I Pe 1:11.†

intrans.,; to work, labour: Mt 21:28, Lk 13:14, Jo 5:17 9:4 b, Ac 18:3, I Co 9:6, II Th 3:10-12; τ. χερσίν, I Co 4:12, I Th 4:11; νυκτὸς κ. ἡαέρας, I Th 2:9, II Th 3:8; of working for pay, Mt 21:28; for reward, Ro 4:4-5; to work at a trade or business, to trade: seq. Iv (Dem.), Mt 25:16.; Trans.,; to work, work out, do, produce, perform: c. acc, II Co 7:10, Col 3:23, II Th 3:11, Ja 1:20, II Jn 8, seq. εἰς, III Jn 5; ἔργον, Ac 13:41 (LXX); id. seq. εἰς, Mt 26:10; ἐν, Mk 14:6; ἔργα, Jo 3:21; τὰ ἔ. τ. θεοῦ, Jo 6:28 9:4; τὸ ἔ. κυρίου, I Co 16:10; τ. ἀγαθόν, Ro 2:10, Eph 4:28 (v. AR, Eph.) 190); id. seq. πρός, Ga 6:10; κακόν, seq. dat. pers. (more freq. dupl. acc, in cl.), Ro 13:10; δικαιοσύνην, Ac 10:35, He 11:33; ἀνομίαν, Mt 7:23; ἁμαρτίαν, Ja 2:9; σημεῖον, Jo 6:30; τ. ἱερά, I Co 9:13; τ. θάλασσαν (work the sea, i.e. make one's living from it), Re 18:17; to work for, earn by working (cl.): Jo 6:27 (cf. κατ-, περι-, προσ-εργάζομαι; Cremer, 258; on the force of the aorist of this verb, v. M, Pr., 116).†
work, business: Ac 16:16, 19 19:24-25; δὸς ἐ. (Lat. da operam), Lk 12:58.; working, performance: Eph 4:19.†

prop., a field labourer, husbandman: Mt 9:37-38 20:1-2, 8, Lk 10:2, Ja 5:4 (cf. Wis, l.c.).; Generally, a workman, labourer: Mt 10:10, Lk 10:7, Ac 19:25 (opp. to τεχνίτης), I Ti 5:18; of Christian teachers, II Co 11:13, Phl 3:2, II Ti 2:15.; a worker, doer: τ. ἀδικίας, Lk 13:27 (cf. 1Mac, l.c.).†

work, task, employment: Mk 13:34, Jo 4:34 17:4, Ac 13:2, Phl 1:22 2:30, I Th 5:13, al.; of an enterprise or undertaking (De 15:10, Wi 2:12), Ac 5:38. a deed, action: Tit 1:16, Ja 1:25 . listing, from λόγος, Lk 24:19, Ro 15:18, II Th 2:17, I Jo 3:18; ἐν λόγοις κ. ἔ., Ac 7:22; of acts of God, Jo 9:3, Ac 13:41 (LXX), He 4:10, Re 15:3; of Christ, Mt 11:2; esp. in Jo, e.g. 5:20, 36 7:3 10:38 14:11, 12 15:24; in ethical sense, of human actions (AR, Eph., 190), bad or good, Mt 23:3, Lk 11:48, Jo 3:20, 21 Ja 2:14ff. 3:13, Re 2:5 3:8; τὸ ἔ., collectively, Ga 6:4, Ja 1:4, I Pe 1:17, Re 22:12; τὸ ἔ. τ. νόμου, Ro 2:15; ἔ. ἀγαθόν, Ro 2:7, Col 1:10, II Th 2:17, Tit 1:16, al.; καλόν, Mt 26:10, Mk 14:6; pl. (as freq. in cl.), Mt 5:16, I Ti 5:10, 25 He 10:24; ἔ. πίστεως, I Th 1:3, II Th 1:11; ἔ. πονηρά, Col 1:21, II Jo 11; νέκρα, He 6:1 9:14; ἄκαρπα, Eph 5:11; ἔ. ἀσεβείας, Ju 15; τ. σκότους, Ro 13:12, Eph 5:11; ἔ. νόμου, Ro 3:20, 28 Ga 2:16 3:2, 5 10. that which is wrought or made, a work: I Co 3:13-15; τ. χειρῶν, Ac 7:41; of the works of God, He 1:10; γῆ κ. τὰ ἐν αὐτῇ ἔ., II Pe 3:10; τὸ ἔ. τ. θεοῦ, Ro 14:20.
to stir up, provoke (as in cl.): Col 3:21.; In good sense (cf. ἐρεθισμός, excitement, in MGr.), to stir up, stimulate: II Co 9:2.†
to prop, fix firmly: act., as mid., ἐρείσασα, of a ship driving ashore (RV, struck), Ac 27:41.†

to spit or spue out.; Prop., of oxen (Hom.), to bellow, roar; whence, as in LXX, to speak aloud, utter: Mt 13:35 (LXX). (For other examples of softened force of words in late Gk., cf. σκύλλω, τρώγω, χορτάζω.) †
a solitude, wilderness: Mt 15:33, Mk 8:4, II Co 11:26, He 11:38.†

solitary, lonely, desolate, deserted:; of persons, γυνή, Ga 4:27 (LXX); of places, Mt 14:13, 15 23:38 (WH, om.), Mk 1:36 6:32, Lk 4:42 9:12, al.; as subst., ἡ ἔ. (sc. χώρα; as in Hdt., ii, 32, al.), the desert, Mt 3:1, 3, Mk 1:3-4, Jo 3:14, al.; pl., αἱ ἔ., desert places, Lk 1:80 5:16 8:29
to desolate, lay waste: Mt 12:25, Lk 11:17, Re 17:16 18:16, 19.†
a making desolate, laying waste: Lk 21:20; βδέλυγμα ἐρημώσεως (Da, ll. c., I Mac 1:54), Mt 24:15 (LXX), Mk 13:14.†
to wrangle, strive: Mt 12:19 (LXX, κεκράζεται).†
ambition, self-seeking, rivalry: Ja 3:14, 16; κατ' ἐριθίαν, Phl 2:3; οἱ ἐξ ἐ., Ro 2:8, Phl 1:17; pl. (Bl., § 32, 6; WM, 220; Swete, Mk., 153), II Co 12:20, Ga 5:20.†
wool: He 9:19, Re 1:14.†
strife, wrangling, contention: Ro 1:29 13:13, I Co 3:3, II Co 12:20, Ga 5:20, Phl 1:15, I Ti 6:4, Tit 3:9; pl. (v.s. ἐριθία), Ro 13:13, WH, mg., I Co 1:11, Ga, l.c., WH, mg.†
Mt 25:33, Lk 15:29 (ἔριφον, WH, txt.).†
a kid: Mt 25:32, Lk 15:29, WH, txt.†
Hermas, a Christian: Ro 16:14.†
to explain.; to interpret: Lk 24:27 (WH, mg.), Jo 1:39, 43 9:7, He 7:2.†
interpretation: I Co 12:10 14:26.†
acc, Ἑρμῆν, ὁ,; Hermes; the Greek god (Lat. Mercurius): Ac 14:12; a Christian: Ro 16:14.† (see)
Hermogenes, a Christian: II Ti 1:15.†
a creeping thing, reptile: Ac 10:12 11:6, Ro 1:23, Ja 3:7.†
red: ἡ ἐ. θάλασσα, the Red Sea, Ac 7:36, He 11:29.†

to come; of persons, either as arriving or returning from elsewhere: Mt 8:9, Mk 6:31, Lk 7:8, Jo 4:27, Ro 9:9, al.; seq. ἀπό, Mk 5:35 7:1, Jo 3:2, al.; ἐκ, Lk 5:17, Jo 3:31, al.; εἰς, Mk 1:29, al.; διά seq. εἰς, Mk 7:31; ἐν (Cremer, 263f., but v.s. ἐν), Ro 15:29, I Co 4:21; ἐπί, c acc., Mk 6:53 11:13, Jo 19:33, al.; κατά, c. acc., Lk 10:33 Ac 16:7; παρά, c gen., Lk 8:49; c. acc., Mt 15:29, Mk 9:14, al.; c. dat. comm., incomm. (M, Pr., 75, 245), Mt 21:5, Re 2:5, 16; with adverbs: πόθεν, Jo 3:8, al.; ἄνωθεν, Jo 3:31; ὄπισθεν, Mk 5:27; ὧδε, Mt 8:29; ἐκεῖ, Jo 18:3; ποῦ, He 11:8; seq. ἕως, Lk 4:42; ἄχρι, Ac 11:5; with purpose expressed by inf., Mk 5:14, Lk 1:59, al.; by fut. ptcp., Mt 27:49; ἵνα, Jo 12:9; εἰς τοῦτο, ἵνα, Ac 9:21; διά, c. acc., Jo 12:9; before verbs of action, ἔρχεται καί, ἦλθε καί, etc.: Mk 2:18, Jo 6:15, al.; ἔρχου καὶ ἴδε, Jo 1:47 11:34; ἐλθών (redundant; Dalman, Words, 20 f.), Mt 2:8 8:7, Mk 7:25, Ac 16:39, al.; similarly ἐρχόμενος, Lk 15:25, al.; of coming into public view: esp. of the Messiah (ὁ ἐρχόμενος, Mt 11:3, al.; v. Cremer, 264), Lk 3:16, Jo 4:25; hence, of Jesus, Mt 11:19, Lk 7:34, Jo 5:43, al.; of the second coming, Mt 10:23, Ac 1:11, I Co 4:5, I Th 5:2, al.; of time: ἔρξονται ἡμέραι (pres. for fut.: Bl., §56, 8), Lk 23:29, He 8:8 (LXX); fut., Mt 9:15, Mk 2:20, al.; ἔρξεται ὥρα, ὅτε, Jo 4:21, 23. al.; ἦλθεν, ἐλήλυθε ἡ ὥρα, Jo 13:1 16:32 17:1; ἡ ἡμέρα τ. κυρίου, I Th 5:2; καιροί, Ac 3:19; of things and events: κατακλυσμός, Lk 17:27; λιμός, Ac 7:11; ἡ ὀργή, I Th 1:10; ὁ λύχνος, Mk 4:21 (v. Swete, in l.). Metaph., τ. ἀγαθά, Ro 3:8; τ. τέλειον, I Co 13:10; ἡ πίστις, Ga 3:23, 25; ἡ ἐντολή, Ro 7:9; with prepositions: ἐκ τ. θλίψεως, Re 7:14; ἐις τ. χεῖρον, Mk 5:26; εἰς πειρασμόν, ib. 14:38, al. to go: ὀπίσω, c. gen. (Heb. הָלַךְ אַחֲרֵי), Mt 16:24, Mk 8:34, Lk 9:23; σύν, Jo 21:3; ὁδόν, Lk 2:44. (Cf. ἀν-, ἐπ-αν-, ἀπ-, δι-, εἰς, ἐπ-εἰσ-, συν-εἰσ-, ἐξ-, δι-εξ-, ἐπ-, κατ-, παρ-, ἀντι-παρ-, περι-, προ-, προσ-, συν-έρχομαι.)

to ask, question (cl.): absol., Lk 19:31 22:68, Jo 8:7 c. acc pers., Jo 9:21 16:19, 30 8:21; seq. λέγων, Mt 16:13, Lk 23:3, Jo 1:19, 21 5:12 9:19 16:5; c. dupl. acc (WM, § 32, 4a), Mt 21:24, Mk 4:10, Lk 20:3, Jo 16:23 (M, Pr., 66„); c. acc pers., seq. περί, Lk 9:45, Jo 18:19.; In late Gk. (Milligan, NTD, 51; not, as Cremer, 716, Thayer, s.v., a "Hebraism"), = αἰτέω (q.v.), to ask, request: c. acc pers., Jo 14:16; seq. imperat., Lk 14:18-19 Phl 4:3; λέγων, Mt 15:23, Jo 12:21; seq. ἵνα (M, Pr., 208), Mk 7:26, Lk 7:36 16:27, Jo 4:47 17:15 19:31, 38, I Th 4:1, II Jn 5; ὅπως, Lk 7:3 11:37, Ac 23:20; c. inf., Lk 5:3 8:37, Jo 4:40, Ac 3:3 10:48 23:18, I Th 5:12; c. acc pers., seq. περί, Lk 4:38 Jo 17:9, 20, I Jn 5:16; ὑπέρ, II Th 2:1-2; τὰ (WH, txt., om. τὰ) πρὸς εἰρήνην, Lk 14:32 (cf. δι-, ἐπ-ερωτάω)
clothing, raiment: Lk 23:11 24:4, Ac 10:30 12:21, Ja 2:2-3.†
clothing: pl., Ac 1:10.†

to eat; absol.: Mt 14:20, 21 Mk 6:31, Jo 4:31, al.; ἐν τ. φαγεῖν (on this aor. form, v. M, Pr., 111), I Co 11:21; διδόναι φαγεῖν, c. dat. pers., Mk 5:43, al.; ἐ. καὶ πίνειν, Mt 6:25, 31 Lk 10:7, al.; of ordinary use of food and drink, I Co 9:4 11:22; of partaking of food at table, Mk 2:16, Lk 5:30, al.; opp. to fasting, Mt 11:18, Lk 5:33, al.; of revelling, Mt 24:49, Lk 12:45 . c. acc. rei: Mt 6:25, Mk 1:6, Jo 6:31, Ro 14:2, al.; ἄρτον (Heb. אָכַל לֶחֶם), Mt 15:2, Mk 3:20, al.; τὸν ἑαυτοῦ ἄ., II Th 3:12; ἄ. seq. παρά, gen. pers., II Th 3:8; τά seq. id., Lk 10:7; τ. πάσχα, Mt 26:17, Mk 14:12 al; τ. κυριακὸν δεῖπνον, I Co 11:20; τ. θυσίας, I Co 10:18; seq. ἐκ (= cl. part. gen.), Jo 6:26, 5o, 51, I Co 11:28; ἀπό (cf. Heb. אָכַל מִן), Mt 15:27, Mk 7:28; metaph., to devour, consume: He 10:27, Ja 5:3, Re 17:16 (cf. κατ-, συν-εσθίω) .
Esli, an ancestor of Jesus: Lk 3:25.†
a mirror: I Co 13:12, Ja 1:23.†
(sc. ὥρα), evening: Lk 24:29, Ac 4:3 20:15 28:23; (so. χώρα), the west.†
of the evening, evening: Lk 12:38 (WH, - mg. -).†
Esrom (AV), Hezron (RV), an ancestor of Jesus: Mt 13:1-58, Lk 3:35.†

last, utmost, extreme; of place: of the lowest or least honoured place, Lk 14:9-10; τ. ἔσχατον, c. gen. part., Ac 1:8 13:47; of time: Mt 20:12, 14, Mk 12:6, 22, opp. to πρῶτος, Mt 20:8, I Co 15:45, Re 2:19, al.; τὰ ἔ. καὶ T. πρῶτα, Mt 12:45, Lk 11:26, II Pe 2:20; of the Eternal, ὁ πρῶτος καὶ ὁ ἔ., Re 1:17 2:8 22:13; in phrases relating to the Messianic age and the consummation of the Kingdom of God: ἐπ' ἐσχάτου (-ων) τ. ἡμερῶν, He 1:2, II Pe 3:3; τ. χρόνων, I Pe 1:20; ἔ. ὥρα, I Jn 2:18; ἐπ' ἐ. χόνου, Ju 18; ἐν ἐ. ἡμέραις, Ac 2:17, Ja 5:3, II Ti 3:1; neut., ἔσχατον, as adv., Mk 12:22, I Co 15:8; of rank: Mk 9:35, I Co 4:9
extremely, utterly; ἐ. ἔχειν (= Lat. in extremis esse), only in late writers (cf. ἐν ἐσχάτοις εἶναι, FlJ, Ant., ix, 8, 6), to be at the point of death: Mk 5:28.†

prop., after verbs of motion (to) within, into: Mt 26:58, Mk 14:54; c. gen., Mk 15:16.; As freq. in cl. (= cl. ἔνδον), after verbs of rest, within: Jo 20:26, Ac 5:23; οἱ ἔ. (opp. to οἱ ἔξω), I Co 5:12; ὁ ἔ. ἄνθρωπος, Ro 7:22, II Co 4:16, Eph 3:16.†
from within: Mk 7:21, 23, Lk 11:7.; within: Mt 7:15 23:25-28, II Co 7:5, Re 4:8 5:1; τὸ ἔ., Lk 11:40; id. c. gen., Lk 11:39.†
inner: Ac 16:24; τὸ ἐ., He 6:19.†
a companion, comrade: Mt 11:16 (WH, ἑτέροις); voc., as term of address, my friend: Mt 20:13 22:12 26:50.†
of alien speech, of another tongue (v. Cremer, 681): I Co 14:21 (aliter in LXX).†
to teach other or different doctrine: I Ti 1:3 6:3 (cf. CGT, in l; Milligan, NTD, 102).†
to be unequally yoked: metaph., c. dat. pers., II Co 6:14.†

distributive pron., prop. dual (BL, §13, 5; 51, 6), denoting the second of a pair, but in late Gk. encroaching on ἄλλος (M, Pr., 79f.); of number, other; c. art., the other; of two, Lk 5:7 9:56, al.; opp. to ὁ πρῶτος, Mt 21:30; ὁ εἷς, Mt 6:24, Lk 7:41, Ac 23:6, al.; ἕ. μὲν . . . ἕ. δέ, the one . . . the other: I Co 15:40; the next: Lk 6:6 9:56 (sc. ἡμέρα, Xen.), Ac 20:15 27:3; = ὁ πλησίον, one's neighbour: Ro 2:1 13:8, I Co 6:1, al.; of more than two, another: Mt 8:21 11:3, Lk 6:6 22:65, Jo 19:37, Ro 8:39, al.; pl., Ac 2:13; οἱ μὲν . . . ἄλλοι δὲ . . . ἕ. δέ, Mt 16:14; τινὲς . . . ἕ. δέ, Lk 11:16. Of kind or quality, other, another, different (Plat., Dem., al.): Mk 16:[12], Lk 9:29, Ac 2:4, I Co 14:21, II Co 11:4, Ga 1:6, al. (cf. ἑτερό-γλωσσος, -διδασκαλέω, -ζυγέω).
differently, otherwise: Phl 3:16.†

yet, as yet, still; of time; of the present (adhuc): Mk 5:35, I Co 3:3 15:17, Ga 1:10, al.; of the past, mostly c. impf.: Mt 12:46, Lk 8:49 15:20, Jo 20:1, Ac 9:1, Ro 5:6, 8, II Th 2:5, He 7:10 9:8, al.; of the future: Lk 1:15, II Co 1:10; with a neg.: Mt 5:13, Lk 16:2 20:36, He 10:2, Re 3:12 20:3, al.; Of degree, even, yet, still, further: c. compar., Phl 1:9, He 7:15; of what remains, Mk 12:6, Jo 4:35 7:33, al.; of what is added, Mt 18:16 26:65, He 11:32 12:26-27; of con­tinuance apart from the idea of time, Ro 3:7 6:2 9:19, Ga 5:11; ἔτι δἐ, Ac 2:26 (LXX), He 11:36; ἔτι τε καί, Lk 14:26, Ac 21:28

to prepare, make ready; absol., of hospitable preparation: Mk 14:15, Lk 9:52 12:47 22:9, 12; c. inf., Mt 26:17; ἵνα, Mk 14:12; c. acc rei: Mt 22:4 26:19, Mk 14:16, Lk 12:20 17:8 22:8, 13 23:56 24:1, Jo 14:2-3, Phm 22, Re 9:7 16:12; seq. εἰς, II Ti 2:21; of God's ordaining coming events (Dalman, Words, 128); of blessing, Mt 20:23 25:34, Mk 10:40, Lk 2:31, I Co 2:9, He 11:16, Re 12:6; of judgment, Mt 25:41; of preparation for the Messiah, τ. ὁδὸν κυρίου, Mt 3:3, Mk 1:3, Lk 1:76 3:4 (LXX); c. acc pers.: Lk 1:17, Ac 23:23, Re 19:7, seq. ἵνα, Re 8:6; εἰς, II Ti 2:21, Re 9:7, 15 21:2.†

= ἑτοιμότης,; readiness (Hipp.); preparation (LXX; e.g. ἑ. τ. καρδίας, Ps 10:17): Eph 6:15, EV.; foundation, firm footing (Ps 89:14): Eph, l.c. (Hatch, Essays, 55; Exp. Times, ix, 38; but v. also Abbott, Essays, 95).†

prepared, ready; of things: Mt 22:4, 8, Mk 14:15, II Co 9:5 10:16, I Pe 1:5; ἔρχεσθε ὅτι ἤδη ἕτοιμά ἐστιν (Field, Notes, 67), Lk 14:17; ὁ καιρός, Jo 7:6; of persons: Mt 24:44 25:10, Lk 12:40, Ac 23:21; seq. πρός, Tit 3:1, I Pe 3:15; c. inf., Lk 22:23; τοῦ, c. inf. (WM, § 44, 4a; Robertson, Gr., 1068), Ac 23:15; ἐν ἑ. ἔχω (MM, Exp., xiv), c. inf., II Co 10:6.†
readily: I Pe 4:5; ἑ. ἔχω, to be ready (Deiss., BS, 252; MM, Exp., xiv): c. inf., Ac 21:13, II Co 12:14.†

a year: Lk 3:1, He 1:12, Re 20:3, al.; ἔτη ἔχειν, Jo 5:5 8:57; εἶναι, γίνεσθαι, ἐτῶν, Mk 5:42, Lk 2:42, Ac 4:22, I Ti 5:9; dat. pl. of space of time, Jo 2:20, Ac 13:20; acc, in ans. to how long? Mt 9:20, Mk 5:25, Lk 2:36, Ac 7:6, He 3:9, al.; preceded by a prep.: dim, Lk 8:43, Ro 15:23; διά, c. gen. (v.s. διά), Ac 24:17, Ga 2:1; ἐκ, Ac 24:10; εἰς, Lk 12:19; ἐπί, c. acc, Ac 19:10; μετά, c. acc, Ga 1:18 3:17; πρό, c. gen., II Co 12:2; κατ' ἔτος, yearly, Lk 2:41

well: εὖ γιν., Eph 6:3 (LXX); εὖ ποιεῖν, c. dat. (cf. Si 12:1-2), to do good, Mk 14:7 (where Nestle suggests εὐποιεῖν, q.v.); εὖ πράσστειν, to fare well, Ac 15:29; in replies (= εὖγε), good! well done! Mt 25:21, 23 Lk 19:17 (εὖγε, WH, txt.).†; εὖ-γε,; in replies, well! good! well done!: Lk 19:17 (WH for Rec. εὖ, q.v.).†
Eve, wife of Adam: II Co 11:3, I Ti 2:13.†

to bring or announce glad tidings; act. (only in late writers): c. acc pers., Re 10:7; seq. ἐπί, c. acc pers., Re 14:6; pass., of things, to be proclaimed as glad tidings: Lk 16:16, Ga 1:11, I Pe 1:25; impers., I Pe 4:6; of persons, to have glad tidings proclaimed to one: Mt 11:5, Lk 7:22, He 4:2, 6; Depon. mid. (cl.), to proclaim glad tidings, in NT esp. of the Christian message of salvation: absol., Lk 9:6, Ro 15:20, al.; c. dat. pers., Lk 4:18 (LXX), Ro 1:15, al.; in same sense c. acc pers. (not cl.), Lk 3:18, Ac 16:10, Ga 1:9, I Pe 1:12; c. acc rei, εἰρήνην, Ac 10:36, Ro 10:15 (LXX); τ, βασιλείαν τ. θεοῦ, Lk 8:1; c. dat. pers., Lk 1:19 4:43, Eph 2:17 3:8; αὐτῷ τ. Ἰησοῦν, Ac 8:35 17:18; c. dupl. acc, Ac 13:32; c. acc pers. et inf., Ac 14:15; τ. κώμας (πολεῖς), Ac 8:25, 40 14:21 (cf. προ-ευαγγελίζομαι)

in cl.,; a reward for good tidings (Hom.; pl., LXX, II Ki 4:10); in pl., εὐ. θύειν, to make a thank-offering for good tidings (Xen., al.).; Later (Luc., Plut., al.), good tidings, good news; in NT of the good tidings of the kingdom of God and of salvation through Christ, the gospel: Mk 1:15, Ac 15:7, Ro 1:16, Ga 2:2, I Th 2:4, al.; c. gen. obj., τ. βασιλείας, Mt 4:23; τ. Χριστοῦ, Ro 15:19, al.; τ. κυρίου ἡμῶν Ἰησοῦ, II Th 1:8; τ. υἱοῦ τ. θεοῦ, Ro 1:9; τ. δόξης τ. μακαρίου θεοῦ, I Ti 1:11; τ. δόξης τ. Χριστοῦ, II Co 4:4; of the author, τ. θεοῦ, Ro 15:16, al.; of the teacher, ἡμῶν, Ro 2:16, II Co 4:3, I Th 1:5, II Ti 2:8; of the taught, τ. περιτομῆς, τ. ἀκροβυστίας, Ga 2:7; ἡ ἀλήθεια τοῦ εὐ., Ga 2:5, 14 Col 1:5; ἡ ἐλπὶς (πίστις) τοῦ εὐ., Col 1:23, Phl 1:27 (v. Cremer, 31 ff.; and on the later eccl. use of the word„ M, Th., 143 f.)
an evangelist; in NT, a preacher of the gospel: Ac 21:8, Eph 4:11, II Ti 4:5; later, a writer of a gospel (eccl.).†
to be well pleasing: τ. θεῷ (LXX, ll. c.), He 11:5-6. Pass., to be well pleased: c. dat., He 13:16.†
well-pleasing, acceptable: Ro 12:2; c. dat. pers., Ro 12:1 14:16, II Co 5:9, Eph 5:10, Phl 4:18; id. seq. ἐν, Tit 2:9 (κυρίῳ), Col 3:20; ἐνώπιον, He 13:21 (for ex. in Inser., v. Deiss., BS, 215).†
acceptably: τ, θεῷ, He 12:28.†
Eubulus, a Christian: II Ti 4:21.†
well born, of noble race: Lk 19:12, I Co 1:26.; noble-minded: compar., -έστερος, Ac 17:11.†
fair weather: Mt 16:2 (Rec., R, txt.).†

c. inf. (Polyb., al.), to be well pleased, to think it good, to give consent (so freq. in π. in legal docu­ments; Milligan, Th., 22 f.): Lk 12:32, Ro 15:26-27, I Co 1:21, Ga 1:15, Col 1:19, R, mg. (ICC, in l, but v. infr.), I Th 2:8 3:1; μᾶλλον εὐ., II Co 5:8; c. acc et inf. (Polyb., i, 8, 4), Col, l.c., R, txt. (Lft., in l).; to be well pleased or take pleasure with or in a person or thing; c. dat. (Polyb., al.; I Mac 1:43, I Es 4:39): II Th 2:12; as freq. in LXX,; c. acc: Mt 12:13, He 10:5, 8 (LXX); seq. ἐν (cf. Heb. בּ רָצָה, Ps 149:4): Mt 3:17 17:5, Mk 1:11, Lk 3:22 (on the tense, v. M, Pr., 134 f.; DCG, i,308 b), I Co 10:5, II Co 12:10, He 10:38 (LXX); seq. εἰς: II Pe 1:17. (cf. συν-ευδοκέω, and v. Cremer, 213 f.; Field, Notes, 48 f.; DCG, i, 355a.)†

good pleasure, good-will, satisfaction, approval: Mt 11:26, Lk 10:21, Ro 10:1, Eph 1:5, 9, Phl 1:15 2:13; c. gen. obj., II Th 1:11 (v. Milligan, in l); ἐν ἀνθρώποις εὐδοκία, Rec., R, mg., WH, mg. (v. Field, Notes, 48 f.), Lk 2:14; -ας, Lk, l.c., R, txt., WH, txt. (v. ICC, in l; WH, App., in l).†
a good deed, kindness, benefit: I Ti 6:2; c. gen. pers. (εὐ. πόλεως, Plat., leg., 805b), Ac 4:9,†
to do good, bestow benefit: Ac 10:33.†
a benefactor: Lk 22:25 (for contemp. usage, v. Deiss., LAE, 248).†
ready for use, fit: of things, c. dat., He 6:7; seq. εἰς, Lk 14:35; of persons, c. dat., Lk 9:62 (for rabbinic parallels, v. Dalman, Words, 119 f.).†
straightway, at once, directly: Ga 1:16, Ja 1:24, III Jn 14 (cf. Dalman, Words, 28 f.), Re 4:2, and freq. in Mt, Lk, Jo, Ac (in Mk, εὐθύς), q.v.)
of ships, to run a straight course (Philo): Ac 16:11 21:1.†
trans., to make cheerful (Æsch.).; Intrans. (Eur., Plut.; so mid. in Xen., Plat.), to be of good cheer: Ac 27:22, 25, Ja 5:13.†
kind (Hom.).; of good cheer (Æsch., al.): Ac 27:36.†
cheerfully: Ac 24:10.†
to direct: Ja 3:4.; to make straight: Jo 1:23 (LXX, ἑτοιμάσατε).†

straight, direct: τρίβοι, Mt 3:3, Mk 1:3, Lk 3:4 (LXX); εἰς εὐθειας, (sc. ὁδούς), Lk 3:5; εὐ. ὐδός, fig., Ac 13:10, II Pe 2:15; as pr. name of a street, Ac 9:11.; In moral sense, straightforward, right: καρδία, Ac 8:21 (cf. Ps 7:11 32:11, al.).†; εὐθύς,; = εὐθέως, straightway, directly: Mt 3:16 13:20-21 14:27 21:2-3 26:74, Lk 6:49, Jo 13:30, 32 19:34, Ac 10:16, 42 times in Mk.†
uprightness: He 1:8 (LXX).†
to have leisure or opportunity: I Co 16:12; c. inf., Mk 6:31; seq. εἰς, to devote one's leisure to, Ac 17:21.†
fitting time, opportunity: seq. ἵνα, Mt 26:16; τοῦ, c. inf., Lk 22:6.†
timely, seasonable, suitable (Cremer, 740): ἡμέρα, Mk 6:21 (or empty, as in Byz. and MGr.; v. MM, Exp., xiv); βοήθεια, He 4:16.†
seasonably, in season: Mk 14:11; opp. to ἀκ- (Kühner3, iv, 346 d), II Ti 4:2.†
with easy labour, easy: compar., -ώτερόν ἐστι, c. inf., Mt 9:5, Mk 2:9, Lk 5:23; c. acc et inf., Mt 19:24, Mk 10:25, Lk 16:17 18:25 (Polyb.; the adv. -ως occurs in Aristoph., Fr., 615).†
caution, discretion (Soph., Plat., al.).; In later Gk. (Diod., Plut., al.), also reverence, godly fear: He 5:7 12:28.†
to be cautious, to beware: Ac 23:10 (Rec.; φοβηθείς, WH, RV).; to reverence: He 11:7 (cf. Cremer, 388).†
cautious, circumspect.; devout, religious, reverent: Ac 2:5 8:2 22:12; δίκαιος καὶ εὐ., Lk 2:25.†

to speak well of, praise (cl.; LXX De 8:10, al.): τ. θεόν, Lk 1:64 2:28 24:51, 53 (αἰνοῦντες, T, WH, mg.), Ja 3:9; absol., to give praise, Mt 14:19 26:26 (v. Swete on Mk 14:22), Mk 6:41 14:22 (v. Swete, in l), Lk 24:30, I Co 14:16.; As in LXX (= בָּרַךְ pi.); to bless, invoke blessings on (Ge 24:60, Nu 23:20, al.): absol., I Co 4:12, I Pe 3:9; c. acc pers., Lk 2:34 6:28 24:50-51, Ro 12:14, He 7:1, 6-7 11:20-21; εὐλογημένος (= בָּרַךְ; v. Lft., Notes, 310; DCG, i, 189), blessed, Mt 21:9 23:39 (LXX), Mk 11:9-10, Lk 13:35 19:38 (LXX), Jo 12:13; c. acc rei, Mk 8:7, Lk 9:16, I Co 10:16; with God as subject (Ps 44:3, al.), to bless, prosper, bestow blessings on: c. acc pers., Ac 3:26, Ga 3:9, Eph 1:3 (Lft., Notes, 311), He 6:14; εὐλογημένος, Lk 1:28 (WH, tit., R, tit., omit) Lk 1:42; εὐλογημένοι τ. πατρός (cf. Is 61:9), Mt 25:34; pass. Ac 3:25 (cf. ἐν-, κατ-ευλογέω).†

blessed; of men (Ge 12:2 A, De 7:14, Jg 17:2 B, Ru 2:20, I Ki 15:13); of God (Lft., Notes, 310 f.), as chiefly in LXX (Ge 9:26, Ex 17:10, Ps 18:46, al.): Lk 1:68, Ro 1:25 9:5 (ICC, in l), II Co 1:3 11:31, Eph 1:3, I Pe 1:3; absol., ὁ εὐλογητός (Dalman, Words, 200; JThS, v, 453), Mk 14:61 (Cremer, 769).†

fair speaking, flattering speech: χρηστολογίας καὶ εὐ., Ro 16:18.; praise: of God (as in late Inscr.; LS, s.v.) and Christ, Re 5:12-13 7:12; In LXX and NT: blessing, benediction; the act of blessing: I Co 10:16, He 12:17, Ja 3:10; concrete, a blessing: Ro 15:29, II Co 9:5-6, Ga 3:14, Eph 1:3, He 6:7, I Pe 3:9 (cf. De 11:26, Si 7:32, al.).†
ready to impart: assoc. with κοινωνικός (for the distinction between the two, v. Field, Notes, 213; CGT, in l), I Ti 6:18.†
Eunice, Timothy's mother: II Ti 1:5.†
to be favourable, kindly disposed: c. dat., Mt 5:25.†
goodwill: Eph 6:7 (of slaves; cf. MM, Exp., xiv).†
to make a eunuch of, castrate: pass., Mt 19:12; metaph., εὐ. έαυτόν, ib.†

an emasculated man, a eunuch: Mt 19:12; one such holding, as was common, high office, as of chamberlain, at court, Ac 8:27, 34-39; metaph., of one naturally incapacitated for or volun­tarily abstaining from wedlock, Mt 19:12.†
Euodia (not as AV, Euodias), a Christian woman: Phl 4:2.†

to help on one's way (Soph., al.). Pass., to have a prosperous journey; metaph. (Hdt., al.), to prosper, be prospered, be successful: III Jn 2, Ro 1:10, I Co 16:2 (on the tense, v. M, Pr., 54; ICC, in l).†
constantly attendant or waiting on: τ. κυρίῳ, I Co 7:35 (Rec. εὐπρόσ-).†
ready to obey, compliant: Ja 3:17.†
of sins, readily besetting: He 12:1 (on form and sense of the word, v. Westc., in l).†
to do good (whence εὐποιία, q.v.): εὐποιῆσαι, Mk 14:7 B (also Is 41:23 B, al.; v. Nestle, in Exp. T., xxiii, 7).†
beneficence, doing good: He 13:16.; a benefit (FlJ, Ant., ii, ll, 2, al.).†
to prosper, be well off: Ac 11:29.†
facility.; plenty, wealth: Ac 19:25.†
goodly appearance, comeliness: Ja 1:11.†
more usual than δέκτος, q.v., acceptable: Ro 15:16, 31, II Co 6:2 8:12, I Pe 2:5.†
Rec. for εὐπάρεδρος, q.v.: I Co 7:35.†
to look well, make a fair show: metaph. (as in 7.; v. Deiss., LAE, 96), Ga 6:12.†
the Euraquilo, a N.E. wind (i.e. between Eurus and Aquilo): Ac 27:14.†

to find, with or without previous search: absol., opp. to ζητέω, Mt 7:7, 8 Lk 11:9, 10; c. acc., Mt 2:8, Mk 1:37, Ac 13:22, II Ti 1:17, al.; pass., οὐχ εὑ., of disappearance, He 11:5, Re 16:20, al.; γῆ κ. τὰ ἐν αὐτῇ ἔργα εὑρεθήσεται (for conjectures as to the meaning of this reading, v. Mayor, ICC, in l.), II Pe 3:10, WH, R, mg. Metaph., to find, find out by inquiry, learn, discover: Lk 19:48, Ac 4:21; αἰτίαν, Jo 18:38, Ac 13:28, al.; pass., Mt 1:18, Lk 17:18, Ro 7:10, I Co 4:2, Ga 2:17, I Pe 1:7, Re 5:4, al.; of attaining to the knowledge of God, εὑ. θεόν, Ac 17:27; pass., Ro 10:20 (LXX). Mid., to find for oneself, gain, procure, obtain: c. acc. rei, λύτρωσιν, He 9:12; act. in same sense (so cl. poets, but not in Attic prose), Mt 10:39 11:29, Lk 1:30, Ac 7:46, II Ti 1:18, al. (cf. ἀν-ευρίσκω).
Euroclydon (prob. a sailor's corruption of Εὐρακύλων, q.v.): Ac 17:14, Rec,†
spacious, broad: Mt 7:13.†

piety, reverence (towards parents and others).; piety towards God, godliness: Ac 3:12, I Ti 2:2 4:7-8 6:5-6 6:11, II Pe 1:3 1:6-7,; τὸ τῆς εὐ. μυστήριον, I Ti 3:16; ἡ κατ' εὐ. διδασκαλία, I Ti 6:3; ἡ ἀλήθεια ἡ κατ' εὐ., Tit 1:1; μόρφωσις εὐσεβείας, II Ti 3:5; pl. (v. Bl., § 32, 6; Mayor on Ja 2:1), II Pe 3:11 (on the use of εὐ. and cognates in Past. Epp., v. CGT, on I Ti 2:2; cf. also Cremer, 524).†
to reverence, show piety towards; c. acc (else­where more freq. seq. εἰς., περί, πρός): οἶκον, I Ti 5:4; θεόν, Ac 17:23 (Cremer, 525).†
pious, godly, devout: Ac 10:2, 7, II Pe 2:9.†
piously, religiously: II Ti 3:12, Tit 2:12.†
conspicuous (cf. Ps, l.c.).; clear to the understanding, distinct: I Co 14:9.†
in Hippocr., as medical term (LS, s.v.).; Metaph. (cf. εὐσιλαγχνία, Eurip., Rhes., 192), in NT, tenderhearted, compassionate: Eph 4:32, I Pe 3:8.†
decorously, becomingly: I Co 14:40; περιπατεῖν, Ro 13:13, I Th 4:12.†
seemliness, comeliness: I Co 12:23.†

elegant, graceful, comely (Eur., Plat., al.): τὰ εὐ. ἡμῶν (opp. to τὰ ἀσχ- ἡμ-), I Co 12:24; in moral sense, seemly, becoming, I Co 7:35.; Also in late Gk. (v. Swete, Mk., l.c.; MM, Exp., xiv), wealthy, influential (RV, of honourable estate): Mk 15:43, Ac 13:50 17:12.†
vigorously, vehemently: Lk 23:10, Ac 18:28.†
versatility, wit, facetiousness (Hippocr., Plat., al.).; = βωμολογία, coarse jesting, ribaldry (Abbott, Essays, 93): Eph 5:4.†
Butychus, a young man: Ac 20:9.†
good report, praise: opp. to δυσφημία, II Co 6:8.†
primarily, utter­ing words or sounds of good omen, hence,; avoiding ill-omened words, religiously silent.; fair-sounding, auspicious (R, mg., gracious): Phl 4:8.†
to be fruitful: Lk 12:16.†

to cheer, gladden: c. acc pers., opp. to λυπεῖν, II Co 2:2. Pass., to be happy, rejoice, make merry: Lk 15:32, Ac 2:26 (LXX) Ro 15:10 (LXX), Ga 4:27 (LXX), Re 11:10 12:12; seq. ἐν, Ac 7:41; ἐπί c. dat., Re 18:20; of merry-making at a feast (III Ki 4:20; of. Kennedy, Sources, 155; Field, Notes, 69 f.), Lk 12:19 15:23-24, 29 (LXX) (λαμπρῶς) Lk 16:19.†
the river Euphrates: Re 9:14 16:12.†
rejoicing, gladness: Ac 2:28 (LXX) Ac 14:17.†

to be thankful, give thanks (chiefly in late writers and Inscr.; cf. Milligan, Th., 5; Ellic. on Col 1:12; Lft., Notes, 9): Ro 1:21, I Co 14:17, I Th 5:18; of giving thanks before meat, Mt 15:36 26:27, Mk 8:6 14:23, Lk 22:17, 19, Jo 6:11, 23, I Co 11:24; c. dat. pens., τ. θεῷ, Lk 17:16, Ac 27:35 28:15, Ro 14:6 16:4, I Co 14:18, Phl 1:3, Col 1:3, 12, Phm 4; seq. διὰ Ἰ. Χριστοῦ, Ro 1:8 7:25 R, WH, mg., Col 3:17; ἐν ὀνόματι Χρ., Eph 5:20; seq. περί, I Th 1:2, II Th 1:3; ὅτι, Ro 1:8, II Th 2:13; ἐπι, c. dat. rei, I Co 1:4; ὐπέρ, I Co 10:30, Eph 1:16 5:20; ὅτι, Lk 18:11, Jo 11:41, I Co 1:14, I Th 2:13, Re 11:17; pass. (Deiss., BS, 122 f.), II Co 1:11.†

thankfulness, gratitude (Polyb.; Es, Sir, 2Mac, ll. c.): Ac 24:3.; giving of thanks, thanksgiving (so in π. and Inscr.; M, Th., 41 f.): I Co 14:16, II Co 4:15, Eph 5:4, Phl 4:6, Col 2:7 4:2, I Th 3:9, I Ti 4:3-4, Re 4:9 7:12; c. dat. pers., II Co 9:11 (cf. τ. θεοῦ, Wis, l.c.); pl., II Co 9:12, I Ti 2:1 (Cremer, 904).†
= εὔχαρις, winning, gracious, agreeable (Pr, l.c.).; grateful, thankful: Col 3:15.†
a prayer: Ja 5:15.; a vow: Ac 18:18 21:23.†

to pray: c. acc rei, II Co 13:9; c. dat. pers., τ. θεῷ, Ac 26:29; seq. πρὸς τ. θεόν, II Co 13:7; c. acc et inf., Ac 27:29, III Jn 2; seq. ὑπέρ, Ja 5:16; ηὐχόμην εἶναι (On impf. here, v. ICC, in l, Lft., Phm 13), Ro 9:3 (Cremer, 718).†
useful, serviceable: c. dat. pers., II Ti 2:21; id. seq. εἰς, c. dat. rei, II Ti 4:11; opp. to ἄχρηστος, Phm 11.†
to be of good courage: Phl 2:19.†
fragrance: metaph., Χριστοῦ εὐ,., II Co 2:15; ὀσμὴ εὐωδίας (a metaphor of sacrifice, most freq. in Pent. and Ez.), Eph 5:2, Phl 4:18.†
of good name or omen.; Euphemistic for ἀριστερός, left: Ac 21:3, Re 10:2; ἐξ εὐωνύμων, on the left: Mt 20:21, 23 25:33, 41 27:38, Mk 10:40 15:27.†
to leap upon: seq. ἐπί c. acc pers. Ac 19:16.†
once for all (Eupol.): Ro 6:10 He 7:27 9:12 10:10.; at once: I Co 15:6.†
Ephesian: Re 2:1, Rec. (ἐν Ἐφέσῳ, WH, RV).†
an inventor, contriver: κακῶν (cf. κακίας εὑρετής, II Mac 7:31), Ro 1:30.†
a course of daily services (Ne 13:30, I Ch 25:8, al.).; a class or course of priests detailed for service in the temple (I Ch 23:6, al.): Lk 1:5, 8 (cf. MGr., ἐφημέριος, priest).†
lasting for a day.; daily, for the day: Ja 2:15.†
to come to, to reach: seq. ἄχρι, II Co 10:13; εἰς, II Co 10:14.†

causal in pres., impf., fut., 1 aor., to set upon or by, set up, etc. (Æsch., Hdt., Arist., al).; Intrans. in mid, and in pf. and 2 aor. act.; to stand upon; to be set over; to stand by, be present, be at hand, come on or upon: Lk 2:38 10:40 20:1, Ac 6:12 12:7 22:13, 20 23:27, II Ti 4:2; c. dat. pars., Lk 2:9 24:4, Ac 4:1 23:11; c. dat. bc., Ac 17:5; seq. έπί, c. acc, Ac 10:17 11:11; of rain, Ac 28:2; of evils impending, c. dat. pers., I Th 5:3; seq. έπί (Wi 6:9), Lk 21:34; of time, II Ti 4:6 (cf. κατ-, συν-εφίστημι).†
Ephraim, a town near Jerusalem: Jo 11:54.†
ephphatha, be opened: Mk 7:34.†
yesterday: Jo 4:52, Ac 7:28, He 13:8 (on the form, v. Rutherford, NPhr., 370 f.).†

enmity: Lk 23:12, Ro 8:7, Ga 5:20, Eph 2:15-16, Ja 4:4.†; ἀηδία, -ας, ἡ; of things or persons, unpleasantness, odiousness (Hipp., Dem., al.); dislike (Plat.). disagreement (MM, VGT, s.v.): Lk 23:12 D.†

hated, hateful (Hom.): opp. to ἀγαπητός, Ro 11:28.; Actively, hating, hostile: Ro 5:10, I Co 15:25, II Th 3:15; c. gen. pers. (cl.), Ja 4:4; τ. διανοίᾳ, Col 1:21; ἐ. ἄνθρωπος, Mt 13:28; as subst., ὁ ἐ., an enemy, I Co 15:26; the devil, Mt 13:39, Lk 10:19; c. gen. pers., Mt 22:44 Mk 12:36, Lk 20:43, Ac 2:35, I Co 15:25, He 1:13 10:13 (LXX); Mt 5:43-44 10:36 13:25, Lk 1:71, 74 6:27, 35 19:27, 43, Ro 12:20, Ga 4:16, Re 11:5, 12; c. gen. rei, Ac 13:10, Phl 3:18.†
a viper: Ac 28:3; metaph., γεννήματα ἐχιδνῶν, Mt 3:7 12:34 23:33, Lk 3:7.†

(on the Aktionsart of the various tenses, v. M, Pr., 110, 145, 150, 183), to have, as in cl., in various senses and constructions. Trans.; 1. to have, hold, hold fast, etc.; to hold, as, in the hand: Re 5:8 14:6, al.; ἐν τ. χειρί, Re 1:16 10:2, al.; of arms and clothing, = φέρω, φορέω, to bear, wear: Mt 3:4 22:12, al.; so freq. pres. ptcp. (LS, s.v., A, I, 6; Bl., 74, 2), Mk 11:13, Jo 18:10, Re 9:17, al.; of a woman, ἐν γαστρὶ ἔ, to be with child: Mk 13:17, Ro 9:10; to hold fast, keep: Lk 19:20; metaph., of the mind and conduct, Mk 16:8 (cf. Jb 21:6, Is 13:8; Deiss., BS, 293; Field, Notes, 44f.), Jo 14:21, Ro 1:28, I Ti 3:9, II Ti 1:13, Re 6:9, al.; to involve: He 10:35 (LXX), Ja 1:4, I Jo 4:18; (f) = Lat. habere (Bl., §34, 5; 73, 5), to hold, consider: c. acc. et predic. ptcp., Lk 14:18; c. acc, seq. ὡς, Mt 14:5; εἰς (Hebraism), Mt 21:46; on (Bl., §70, 2), Mk 11:32. to have, possess; in general, c. acc. rei: Mt 19:22, Mk 10:22, Lk 12:19, Jo 10:16, I Co 11:22, al.; of wealth or poverty, absol., ἔχειν (neg. οὐκ, μή), Mt 13:12 25:29, II Co 8:12; ἐκ τ. ἔχειν, according to your means, II Co 8:11; of relationship, association, et.: πατέρα, Jo 8:41; γυναῖκα (MM, xiv), I Co 7:2; φίλον, Lk 11:5; βασιλέα, Jo 19:15; ποιμένα, Mt 9:36; c. dupl. acc, Mt 3:9, al.; of parts or members: ὦτα, Mt 19:15; μέλη, Ro 12:4; θεμελίους, c. acc, as periphrasis of verb: μνεῖαν ἔ. (= μεμνῆσθαι), I Th 3:6; ἀγάπην, Jo 13:35; γνῶσιν, I Co 8:1; πεποίθησιν, II Co 3:4; θλίψιν, Jo 16:33, etc. (Thayer, s.v., I, 2, f., g.); of duty, necessity, etc.: ἀνάγκην, I Co 7:37; νόμον, Jo 19:7; ἐπιταγήν, I Co 7:25; ἀγῶνα, Phl 1:30; κρίμα, I Ti 5:12; of complaints and disputes; κατά, c. gen. pers., Mt 5:23, Mk 11:25; id. seq. ὅτι, Re 2:4, 20; c. acc. seq. πρός, Ac 24:19, al.; c. inf., (cl.) to be able (Field, Notes, 14): Mt 18:25, Mk 14:8 (sc. ποιῆσαι), Lk 12:4, Ac 4:14, al; of necessity (BL, §69, 4): Lk 12:50, Ac 23:17-19 28:19. Intrans. (BL, §53, 1), to be in a certain condition: ἑτοίμως ἔ., c. inf., Ac 21:13, II Co 12:14; ἐσχάτως (q.v.), Mk 5:23; κακῶς, to be ill, Mt 4:24, al.; καλῶς, Mk 16:[18]; κομψότερον, Jo 4:52; πῶς, Ac 15:36; impers., ἄλλως εἴχει, it is otherwise, I Ti 5:25; οὕτως, Ac 7:1, al.; τὸ νῦν ἔχον, as things now are (To 7:11), Ac 24:25. Mid., -ομαι, to hold oneself fast, hold on or cling to, be next to: c. gen., τ. ἐχόμενα σωτηρίας, He 6:9 (Rendall, in l.); ptcp., ὁ ἐχόμενος, near, next: of place, Mk 1:38; of time, τ. ἐχομένη (ἡμέρα, expressed or understood), Lk 13:33, Ac 20:15 21:26; (σαββάτῳ), Ac 13:44. (Cf. ἀν-, προσ-αν-, ἀντ-, ἀπ-, ἐν-, ἐπ-, κατ-, μετ-, παρ-, περι-, προ-, προσ-, συν-, ὑπερ-, ὑπ-έχω.)

expressing the terminus ad quem (cf. Burton, §321ff.). As conjunction; till, until; of a fact in past time, c. indic.: Mt 2:9, al. (Wi 10:14, al.); ἕως ἄν, c. subjc. aor.: Mt 2:13 5:18, Mk 6:10, al.; without ἄν (M. Pr., 168f.; Lft., Notes, 115), Mk 14:32 (Burton, §325), Lk 12:59, II Th 2:7, al.; c. indic., pres. (Burton, §328; BL, §65, 10): Mk 6:45, Jo 21:22, 23 I Ti 4:13. C. indic., as long as, while (Burton, §327): Jo 9:4 (Plat., Phaedo, 89c). As an adverb (chiefly in late writers). Of time, until, unto; as prep. c. gen. (BL, §40, 6; M, Pr., 99): τ. ἡμέρας, Mt 26:29, Lk 1:80, Ro 11:8, al.; ὥρας, Mt 27:45, al.; τέλους, I Co 1:8, II Co 1:13; τ. νῦν, Mt 24:21, Mk 13:19 (I Mac 2:33); ἐτῶν ὀγ. (Field, Notes, 49f.), Lk 2:37; τ. ἐλθεῖν, Ac 8:40; before names and events, Mt 1:17 2:15, Lk 11:51, Ja 5:7, al.; seq. οὗ, ὅτου, with the force of a conjc. (Burton, §330; M, Pr., 91); ἕ. οὗ (Hdt., ii, 143; Plut., al.): c. indic., Mt 1:25 (WH br., οὗ) 13:33, al.; c. subjc. aor., Mt 14:22, al.; ἔ. ὅτου: c. subjc., Lk 13:8; c. indic., Mt 5:25 (until), Jo 9:18; c. adv. (ἔ. ὀψέ, Thuc, iii, 108): ἄρτι, Mt 11:12, Jo 2:10, I Co 4:13, al.; πότε (M, Pr., 107), Mt 17:17, Mk 9:19, Jo 10:24, al. Of place, as far as, even to, unto (Arist., al.); as prep. c. gen. (v. supr.): Mt 1123, Lk 1015, al.; c. adv. (BL, §40, 6): ἄνω, Jo 2:7; ἔσω, Mk 14:54; κάτω, Mt 27:51, Mk 15:38; ὧδε, Lk 23:5; c. prep.: ἔξω, Ac 21:5; πρός, Lk 24:50 (Field, Notes, 83). Of quantity, measure, etc.: Mt 18:21, Mk 6:23, Lk 22:51, al.
Zebulun, Jacob's tenth son: the tribe of Z., Mt 4:13, 15, Re 7:8.†
Zaccai, Zacchaeus, a publican: Lk 19:2, 5 19:8 (cf. II Mac 10:19).†
Zerah, an ancestor of Jesus: Mt 1:3.†
Zacharias, father of John the Baptist: Lk 1:5, 12-13 1:18, 21 1:40, 59 1:67 3:2.; Zechariah, the son of Jehoiada (in txt. wrongly called son of Barachiah; cf. II Ch 24:19 ff.): Mt 23:35, Lk 11:51.†

prop., to live, be alive (v. Syn., s.v. βίος; in cl. usually of animal life, but sometimes of plants, as Arist., Eth. N, i, 7, 12): Ac 20:12, Ro 7:1-3, I Co 7:39, Re 19:20, al.; ἐν αὐτῷ ζῶμεν, Ac 17:28; ἐμοὶ τὸ ζῆν Χριστός, Phl 1:21; διὰ παντὸς τοῦ ζῆν (M, Pr., 215, 249), He 2:15; ὃ δὲ νῦν ζῶ ἐν σαρκί, Ga 2:20; ζῇ ἐν ἐμοὶ Χριστός, Ga 2:20; (ὁ) ζῶν, of God (אֵל חַי and cognate phrases, Jos 3:10, Ho 2:1 (1:10), Is 37:4, al.; v. DCG, ii, 39a), Mt 16:16, Jo 6:57, Ro 9:26, I Th 1:9, He 3:12, Re 7:2, al.; in juristic phrase, ζῶ ἐγώ (חַי־אָנִי, Nu 14:21, al.), as I live, Ro 14:11; ζῆν ἐπ’ ἄρτῳ, Mt 4:4, al.; ἐκ, I Co 9:14; of coming to life, Mk 16:[11], Ro 6:10 14:9, II Co 13:4; opp. to νεκρός, Re 1:18 2:8; metaph., Lk 15:32; ζῆν ἐκ νεκρῶν, Ro 6:13; of the spiritual life of Christians, Lk 10:28, Jo 5:25, Ro 1:17 8:13; εἰς τ. αἰῶνα, Jo 6:51, 58; σὺν Χριστῷ, I Th 5:10; ὄνομα ἔχεις ὅτι ζῇς, Re 3:1. As sometimes in cl., = βιόω, to live, pass one's life: Lk 2:36, Ac 26:5, Ro 7:9, Col 2:20; ἐν πίστει, Ga 2:20; ἐν τ. ἁμαρτίᾳ, Ro 6:2; εὐσεβῶς, II Ti 3:12; ἀσώτως, Lk 15:13; c. dat. (cl.), ἑαυτῳ (Field, Notes, 164), Ro 14:7, II Co 5:15; τ. δικαιοσύνῃ, Lk 20:38, Ro 6:10, 11 Ga 2:19; τ. Χριστῷ, II Co 5:15; τ. θεῷ, I Pe 2:24; πνεύματι, Ga 5:25; κατὰ σάρκα, Ro 8:12, 13; Of inanimate things, metaph.: ὕδωρ ζῶν (i.e. springing water, as opp. to still water), in a spiritual sense, Jo 4:10, 11 7:38 (DCG, ii, 39f.): ἐλπὶς ζῶσα, I Pe 1:3; ὁδὸς ζῶσα, He 10:20 (cf. ἀνα-, συν-ζάω; Cremer, 270, 721).
Zebedee, father of James and John the Apostles: Mt 4:21 10:2 20:20 26:37 27:56, Mk 1:19-20 3:17 10:35, Lk 5:10, Jo 21:2.†
boiling hot (Strab., al.): metaph., Re 3:15-16.†
a yoke of beasts: Lk 14:19.; a pair of any­thing, Lk 2:24 (LXX).†
fit for joining. As subst.,; ζευκτήριον, τό = ζυγόν, a yoke; ζευκτηρία, -ας, ἡ = ζεύγλη, the crossbar of a double rudder: Ac 27:40 (found nowhere else).†
gen., Διός, dat., Διΐ, acc, Δία (Δίαν, D, al.),; Zeus (Lat. Jupiter): Ac 14:12-13.†
to boil, be hot; metaph., of anger, love, zeal: ptcp., fervent: τ. πνεύματι, Ac 18:25, Ro 12:11.†
to envy, be jealous.; to be zealous: Re 3:19.†

zeal: II Co 7:11 9:2; κατά ζῆλος, Phl 3:6; c. gen. obj., Jo 2:17 (LXX), Ro 10:2; seq. ὑπέρ, II Co 7:7; c. gen. subj., θεοῦ, II Co 11:2; πυρός, He 10:27 (cf. Is 26:11, Wi 5:18, and cf. Westc., in l).; jealousy: Ro 13:13, I Co 3:3 3:2 II Co 12:20, Ga 5:20 (WH, txt, RV), Ja 3:14, 16; πλησθῆναι ζήλου Ac 5:17 13:45; pl., ζῆλοι (v. B1., § 32, 6), Ga 5:20, WH, mg.†

to burn with envy or jealousy, to be jealousy: absol., Ac 7:9 17:5, I Co 13:4, Ja 4:2 (R, mg., cf. Mayor, in l).; to seek or desire eagerly: c. acc rei, I Co 12:31 14:1 14:39 (cf. Si 50:18, Wi 1:12); c. acc pers., II Co 11:2, Ga 4:17; pass., Ga 4:18.†

in cl. an emulator, zealous admirer (Plat., al.).; eagerly desirous, zealous; absol., as in OT, ll. c.; c. gen. obj.: (zealous to acquire or to defend), I Co 14:12, Tit 2:14, I Pe 3:13; τ. νόμου (2Mac, l.c.), Ac 21:20; παραδόσεων, Ga 1:14; c. gen. pers., θεοῦ, Ac 22:3.; In FlJ, NT, a Zealot, member of the Jewish party so called: as surname of the Apostle Simon, Lk 6:15, Ac 1:13.†
In FlJ, NT,; a Zealot, member of the Jewish party so called: as surname of the Apostle Simon, Lk 6:15, Ac 1:13.†
damage, loss: Ac 27:10, 21 Phl 3:8; opp. to κέρδος, Phl 3:7.†
to damage. Pass., to suffer loss, forfeit, lose: absol., I Co 3:15; seq. ἐν, II Co 7:9; c. acc rei (v. B1., § 34, 6), τ. ψυχήν, Mt 16:26, Mk 8:36; ἑαυτόν, Lk 9:25; τ. πάντα, Phl 3:8.†
Zenas: Tit 3:13.†

to seek, seek for: Mt 7:7, 8 Lk 11:9, 10; c. acc. pers., Mk 1:37, Lk 2:48, Jo 6:24, al.; id. seq. ἐν, Ac 9:11; c. acc. rei, Mt 13:45, Lk 19:10; seq. ἐν, Lk 13:6, 7; ψυχήν, of plotting against one's life ( Ex 4:19, al.), Mt 2:20, Ro 11:3 (LXX). Metaph., to seek by thinking, search after, inquire into: Mk 11:18, Lk 12:28, Jo 16:19; τ. θεόν, Ac 17:27. to seek or strive after, desire: Mt 12:46, Mk 12:12, Lk 9:9, Jo 5:18, Ro 10:3, al.; τ. θάνατον, Re 9:6; τ. βασιλείαν τ. θεοῦ, Mt 6:33 (Dalman, Words, 121f.); τὰ ἄνω, Col 3:1; εἰρήνην, I Pe 3:11 (LXX). to require, demand: c. acc. rei, Mk 8:12, Lk 11:29, I Co 1:22, II Co 13:3; seq. παρά, Mk 8:11, al.; ἵνα, I Co 4:2 (cf. ἀνα-, ἐκ-, ἐπι-, συν-ζητέω).
an inquiry, question: Ac 15:2 18:15 23:29 25:19 26:3.†
a seeking, search.; a questioning, inquiry, debate: Ac 15:2, 7, II Ti 2:23, Tit 3:9; seq. περί, Jo 3:26, Ac 25:20, I Ti 6:4.†
zizanium (EV, tares), a kind of darnel, resembling wheat: Mt 13:25-40 (cf. DB, s.v. "Tares").†
Zerubbabel (I Ch 3:19, al.): Mt 1:12-13 Lk 3:27.†
in Hom, the gloom of the under-world; hence, darkness, deep gloom (poët. and late prose writers): He 12:18, II Pe 2:4 2:17, Ju 6 13.†; ὁμίχλη, -ης, ἡ,; a mist: II Pe 2:17
a yoke; metaph., of bondage or submission to authority: Mt 11:29-30, Ac 15:10, Ga 5:1, I Ti 6:1.; a balance: Re 6:5 (of. Is 40:12, al.).†

leaven: Mt 13:33, Lk 13:21; τ. ἄρτου, Mt 16:12. Metaph., of a moral influence or tendency, always, exc. in the Parable of the Leaven (Mt 13:33, Lk 13:21), for evil: I Co 5:6-8, Ga 5:9; ζ. τ. Φαρισαίων, Mt 16:6, 11, Mk 8:16, Lk 12:1 (Cremer, 723).†
to leaven: Mt 13:33, Lk 13:21, I Co 5:6, Ga 5:9.†
to catch alive, take captive: metaph., Lk 5:10; pass., II Ti 2:26 (on the meaning and construction, v. Ellic., CGT, in l).†

life (in Hom., Hdt., = βίος, q.v.; later, existence, vita quâ vivimus, as distinct from βίος, vita quam vivimus; opp. to θάνατος); of natural life: Lk 16:25, Ac 8:33, I Co 15:19, I Ti 4:8, He 7:3, Ja 4:14; πνεῦμα ζωῆς, Re 11:11; ψυχὴ ζωῆς ( Ge 1:30), Re 16:3; of the life of one risen from the dead, Ro 5:10, He 7:16. Of the life of the kingdom of God, the present life of grace and the life of glory which is to follow (Dalman, Words, 156ff.; Westc, Epp. Jo., 214ff.; Cremer, 272ff.): Jo 6:51, 53 Ro 7:10 8:6, 10 Phl 2:16, Col 3:4, II Pe 1:3; αἰώνος (reff. supr.; DCG, i, 538a, ii, 30f.), Jo 4:36 12:50 17:3, I Jo 1:2, al.; τ. φῶς τῆς ζ., Jo 8:12; ὁ Λόγος τ. ζ., I Jo 1:1; ὁ ἄρτος τ. ζ., Jo 6:35, 48; δικαίωσις ζωῆς, Ro 5:18; μετάνοια εἰς ζ., Ac 11:18; ἐν αὐτῷ ζ. ἦν, Jo 1:4; ζ. ἡ ἐν. Χ. Ἰ., II Ti 1:1; τὰ πρὸς ζωήν, II Pe 1:3, al.; στέφανος τῆς ζ., Ja 1:12, Re 2:10; χάρις ζωῆς (gen. expl.), I Pe 3:7; ζ. καὶ εἰρήνη, Ro 8:6; ζ. καὶ ἀφθαρσία, II Ti 1:10; ἀνάστασις ζωῆς, Jo 5:29; βίβλος ζωῆς, Phl 4:3, Re 3:5; ξύλον ζωῆς, Re 2:7; ὕδωρ ζωῆς, Re 22:17; meton., of that which has life: τ. πνεῦμα, Ro 8:10; ῥήματα, Jo 6:63; of one who gives life, Jo 11:25 14:6, I Jo 1:2; ἡ ἐντολή, Jo 12:50.
a belt, girdle: Mt 3:4, Mk 1:6, Ac 21:11, Re 1:13 15:6; as a receptacle for money, Mt 10:9, Mk 6:8.†
to gird: c. acc pers., Jo 21:18. Mid., to gird oneself: Ac 12:8 (cf. ἀνα-, δια-, περι-, ὑπο-ζώννυμι).†
in cl., to engender, produce alive, endue with life.; In LXX. and NT, to preserve alive (DCG, ii, 606; Cremer, 274): Lk 17:33, Ac 7:19, I Ti 6:13 (EV, quickeneth; R, mg., preserveth).†
a living creature, an animal: Re 4:6-9 5:6 ff. Re 6:1 ff. Re 7:11 14:3 15:7 19:4; ζῴων τ. αἷμα, He 13:11; ἄλογα ζ., II Pe 2:12, Ju 10.†

in cl. (= ζωογονέω), to produce alive.; In LXX and NT, to make alive, cause to live, quicken (DCG, ii, 606a; Cremer, 275): Jo 5:21 6:53, Ro 4:17 8:11, I Co 15:45, II Co 3:6, Ga 3:21. Pass., I Co 15:22 15:36, I Pe 3:18.†
eta, the seventh letter. As a numeral, η' = 8; η, = 8000.

disjunctive, or; between single words: Mt 5:17 Mk 6:56, Lk 2:24, Jo 6:19, Ro 1:21, al.; before a sentence expressing a variation, denial or refutation of a previous statement, freq. in interrog. form: Mt 7:4, 9 Mk 12:14, Lk 13:4, Ro 3:29 6:3 9:21, I Co 6:9, 16 9:6, II Co 11:7; ἤ . . . ἤ, either . . . or, Mt 6:24, Lk 16:13, I Co 14:6; in a disjunctive question (as Lat. an after utrum): Mt 9:5, Mk 2:9, Lk 7:19, al.; after πότερον, Jo 7:17; μή, I Co 9:8; μήτι, II Co 1:17; ἤ . . . ἤ . . . ἤ, Mk 13:35. Comparative, than: after comparatives, Mt 10:15, Lk 9:13, Jo 3:19, Ro 13:11, al.; after ἕτερον, Ac 17:21; θέλω (Khüner 3, iv, 303), I Co 14:19; πρὶν ἤ, before, seq. acc. et inf., Mt 1:18 Mk 14:30; after a positive adj. (Ge 49:12; cf. Robertson, Gr., 661), Mt 18:8, 9 Mk 9:43, 45 47. with other particles: ἀλλ’ ἤ, v.s. ἀλλά; ἤ γάρ, v.s. γάρ; ἢ καί, or even, or also, Mt 7:10, Lk 11:11, 12 Ro 2:15 4:9, al; ἤτοι . . . ἤ, Ro 6:16 (cf. Wi 11:19).
to lead the way.; to lead in war, command (of. Ramsay, Was Christ born at Bethlehem?; DCG, ii, 463 f.).; to be governor of a province: c. gen. loc., Lk 2:2 3:1.†
rule, sovereignty: Lk 3:1.†

a leader, guide.; a commander.; a governor of a province (pro­consul, proprietor, legate, or procurator; but cf. ἀνθύπατος): Mt 10:18, Mk 13:9, Lk 21:12, I Pe 2:14; of the Procurator of Judæa, Mt 27:2, 11 27:14-15, 21 27:27 28:14, Lk 20:20, Ac 23:24, 26 23:33 24:1, 10 26:30.; For Heb. אַלְפֵי (LXX, χίλιαι) misread אַלֻּפֵי, leaders: Mt 2:6 (OT).†

to lead; to guide, go before; to rule, be leader: pres. ptcp., ἡγούενος, a ruler, leader (MM, Exp., xiv), Mt 2:6 (LXX), Lk 22:26, Ac 7:10 14:12 15:22, He 13:7, 17 13:24.; to suppose, believe, consider, think (Hdt., Soph., al.; of. Lat. duco): c. dupl. acc, Ac 26:2, Phl 2:3, 6 3:7, I Ti 1:12 6:1, He 10:29 11:11, 26, II Pe 1:13 2:13 3:9 3:15; c. acc seq. ὡς, c. acc, II Th 3:15; c. acc seq. adv., I Th 5:13; ὅταν, Ja 1:2; ἀναγκαῖον, c. inf., II Co 9:5, Phl 2:25; δίκαιον, c. inf., II Pe 1:13; c. acc et inf., Phl 3:8 (of. δι-, ἐκ-δι-, ἐξ- προ-ηγέομαι).†
gladly, with pleasure: Mk 6:20 12:37, II Co 11:19; superlat., ἥδιστα, very gladly (B1., § 11, 3), II Co 12:9 12:15.†
in NT, always of time; now, already: Mt 3:10, Mk 4:37, Lk 7:6, Jo 4:36, al.; νῦν . . . ἤ., now already, I Jn 4:3; ἤ. ποτέ, now at length, c. fut., Ro 1:10 (cf. ἄρτι)
pleasure: II Pe 2:13; pl., Lk 8:14, Tit 3:3, Ja 4:1, †
sweet-smelling; as subst., τὸ ἡ., mint: Mt 23:23, Lk 11:42.†
1, a haunt, abode.; = ἔθος, custom, manner: pl., I Co 15:33.†

pf. with pres. meaning (hence impf. = plpf.), to have come, be present: Mt 24:50, Mk 8:3 (late pf., ἧκα, v. Swete, in l; WH, App., 169), Lk 12:46 15:27, Jo 8:42, He 10:7, 9 10:37, I Jn 5:20, Re 2:25 3:3, 9 15:4; seq. ἀπό, c. gen. loc., Mt 8:11, Lk 13:29; ἐκ, Ro 11:26; id. seq. εἰς, Jo 4:47; μακρόθεν, Mk 8:3; ἐπί, c. acc, Re 3:3. Metaph., of discipleship: Jo 6:37; of time and events: absol., Mt 24:14, Jo 2:4, II Pe 3:10, Re 18:8; seq. ἐπί c acc pers., Mt 23:36, Lk 19:43 (cf. ἀν-, καθ-ήκω).†
Eli, my God: Mt 27:46 (cf. ἐλωΐ).†
Heli, Joseph's father: Lk 3:23.†

always of age or maturity; "a stage of growth whether measured by age or stature"; (a) age: Mt 6:27, Lk 12:25 (R, mg.), He 11:11; full age, maturity: Jo 9:21, 23, Eph 4:13.; stature: Lk 19:3 (Mt 6:27, Lk 12:25, AV, R, txt.; but the prevailing usage in LXX and π. favours the former meaning in these doubtful passages; cf., Ellic., ICC, AR, on Eph, l.c.; Milligan, NTD, 74 f., and esp., MM, Exp., xv; e contra, Field, Notes, 6).†
prop., as big as, as old as.; As indirect interrog., what sized, what, how great, how small (the sense to be determined by the context): Col 2:1, Ja 3:5, Ga 6:11 (WH, mg.; πηλ-, WH, txt., RV).†
a nail: Jo 20:25.†

day; as distinct from night: gen. ἡμέρας, by day (WM, §30, 11), Re 21:25; ἡ. κ. νυκτός (ν. κ. ̔ἡ.), Ac 9:24, I Th 2:9, II Th 3:8, Re 4:8 (BL, §36, 13); ἡμέρας μέσης, at mid-day, Ac 26:13; acc. durat., τ. ἡμέρας, Lk 21:37; ὅλην τὴν ἡ., Ro 8:36; ἐν ἡμέρα, Jo 11:9, Ro 13:13; ἡμέρας ὁδός, a day's journey, Lk 2:44; ἡ. γίνεται, Lk 4:42 22:66; κλίνει, Lk 9:12, al.; metaph., Jo 9:4, Ro 13:12, I Th 5:4, 5 8, II Pe 1:19. Of a civil day of 24 hours, incl. night: Mt 6:34, Mk 6:21, Lk 13:14, al.; τρίτῃ ἡ., Mt 16:21; ἡμέρᾳ κ. ἡ. (cf. יוֹם בְּיֹום, Es 3:4), II Co 4:16; ὅλην τ. ἡ., Ro 8:36 10:21; pl., Jo 2:12, Ac 9:19, al.; ἡ. τῶν ἀζύμων, Ac 12:3; τ. σαββάτου, Lk 13:14, 16; ἡ κυριάκη ἡ., Re 1:10. In Messianic sense, of the last day: ἡ ἡ. (ἐκείνη, τ. κυρίου, etc.), Mt 7:22, Lk 6:23, Ro 13:12, I Co 1:8, I Th 5:2, II Th 2:2, II Pe 3:10, al; by meton., as compared with the divine judgment on that day, ἡ. ἀνθρωπίνη, of a human tribunal, I Co 4:3 (EV, man's judgment). As in Heb. (also in Gk. writers; Bl, §46, 9; M, Pr., 81), of time in general: Jo 8:56 14:20, II Co 6:2, Eph 6:13, II Pe 3:18; pl. Ac 15:7, Eph 5:16, He 10:32; πᾶσας τὰς ἡ. (cf. כָּל הַיָּמִים, De 4:40, al.; MM, Exp., xv), Mt 28:20; ἐλεύσονται ἡ. ὅταν (ὅτε), Mt 9:15, Mk 2:20, Lk 5:35 17:22; αἱ ἡ., c. gen. pers. (Ge 26:1, al.), Mt 2:1, Lk 1:5, Ac 7:45, I Pe 3:20; ἀρχ̀ ἡμερῶν, He 7:3.
our: Ac 2:11 24:6 26:5, Ro 15:4, II Ti 4:15, I Jn 1:3 Jn 2:2; τὸ ἡ., Lk 16:12, WH, txt., R, mg. (τὸ ὑμ., Rec., WH, mg., R, txt.); oἱ ἡ., our (people), Tit 3:14.†
half-dead: Lk 10:30.†

as adj., agreeing in gender and number with the substantive following, τὰ ἡμίσια τ. ὑταρχόντων, Lk 19:8.; As neut. subst., τὸ ἥμισυ, the half; ἥ. (anarth.), a half: c. gen., ἥ. καιροῦ, Re 12:14; ἕως ἡμίσους τ. βασιλείας μου, Mk 6:23; after a cardinal number, ἡμέρας τρεῖς κ. ἥμισυ, Re 11:9, 11.†
half an hour: Re 8:1.†
rel. adv. of time,; at which time, when; seq. αν, c. subjc., whensoever: II Co 3:15-16.†
mild, gentle: I Th 2:7 (WH, R, mg., νήπιος); seq. πρός, II Ti 2:24.†
Er, an ancestor of Jesus: Lk 3:28.†
quiet, tranquil (Luc., al.): I Ti 2:2.†; SYN: ἡσύχιος, q.v

Herod; Herod the Great: Mt 2:1-23, Ac 23:35. Herod Antipas (ὁ τετραάρχης, Mt 14:1): Mt 14:1, 3 14:6, Mk 6:1-56, Mk 8:15, Lk 1:5 3:1, 19 8:3 9:7, 9 13:31, 23, Ac 4:27 13:1. Herod Agrippa I: Ac 12:1, 6 12:11, 19 12:21 (cf. Ἀγρίππας (II)).†
Herodians, partisans of Herod (cf. τὸυς τὰ Ἡρῴδου φρονοῦνιτας, FlJ, Ant., xiv, 15, 10): Mt 22:16, Mk 3:6 12:13.†
Herodias, granddaughter of Herod the Great: Mt 14:3, 6, Mk 6:17, 19 6:22, Lk 3:19.†
Herodion: Ro 16:11.†
indecl. (Heb. עֵשָׂו, Ge 25:25),; Esau: Ro 9:13 (LXX) He 11:20 12:16.†
inferior, less; neut., τὸ ἧ., adverbially, less: II Co 12:15; εἰς τὸ ἧ., for the worse (opp. to κρεῖττον): I Co 11:17.†
to be still; to rest from labour: Lk 23:56; to live quietly: I Th 4:11; to be silent: Lk 14:3, Ac 11:18 21:14 (cf. Jb 32:7, Ne 5:8).†
quietness: II Th 3:12.; stillness, silence: Ac 22:2, I Ti 2:11-12 †
quiet, tranquil: I Ti 2:2, I Pe 3:4.†
disjunct. part.,; whether: Ro 6:16.†
pass.,; to be inferior: seq. ὑπέρ, II Co 12:13.; to be overcome: absol., II Pe 2:20; c. dat., II Pe 2:19.†
defect, loss, defeat: Ro 11:12 (cf. Isa, l.c.), I Co 6:7 (cf. Field, Notes, 160 f., 171 f.; Lft., Notes, 212).†
to sound: I Co 13:1 (cf. ἐξ-, κατ-ηχέω).†
a noise, sound: Ac 2:2; ἦ. θαλάσσης, Lk 21:25; σάλπιγγος, He 12:19; a report: seq. πεφί, Lk 4:37.†
Thaddæus: Mt 10:3, Mk 3:18 (WH, mg., Λεββαῖος, q.v.).†

the sea: Mt 23:15, Mk 11:23, Lk 21:25, Ro 9:27, He 11:12, Ja 1:6, Ju 13, Re 7:1, al.; τὸ πέλαγος τῆς θ. (v. Tr., ut infr.), Mt 18:6; ὁ οὐρανὸς κ. ἡ γῆ κ. ἡ θ., of the whole world, Ac 4:24, al. (Ha 2:7); θ. ὑαλίνη, Re 4:6 15:2; of the Mediterranean, Ac 10:6, 32 17:14; of the Red Sea, ἐρυθρὰ θ., Ac 7:36, I Co 10:1-2, He 11:20; of an inland lake (as Heb. יָם), θ. τ. Γαλιλαίας, Mt 4:18 15:29, Mk 1:16 7:31; τ. Τιβεριάδος, Jo 21:1; τ. Γ. τ. T., Jo 6:1; of the same, simply ἡ θ., Mt 4:15, Mk 2:13, al
to heat, warm; metaph.,; to inflame (Trag.); to foster, cherish: Eph 5:29, I Th 2:7.†
Tamar: Mt 1:3.†
to be amazed.; In late Gk., to astonish, terrify (II Ki 22:5): pass., Mk 1:27 10:32; seq. ἐπί c. dat rei, Mk 10:24.†
amazement: Lk 4:36 5:9, Ac 3:10.†
deadly: Mk 16:18.†
deadly, death-bringing: Ja 3:8.†

death; of the death of the body, whether natural or violent: Jo 11:13, Phl 2:27, He 7:23, al; opp. to ζωή, Ro 8:38, Phl 1:20; of the death of Christ, Ro 5:10, Phl 3:10, He 2:9; ῥυέσθαι (σώζειν) ἐκ θ., II Co 1:10, He 5:7; περίλυπος ἕως θανάτου, Mt 26:38, Mk 14:34; μέχρι (ἄχρι), Phl 2:8, Re 2:10; πληγὴ θανάτου, a deadly wound. Re 13:3; ἰδεῖν θάνατον, Lk 2:26, He 11:5; γεύεσθαι θανάτου, Mk 9:1; ἔνοχος θανάτου, Mk 14:64; θανάτῳ τελευτᾶν ( Ex 21:17, מוּת יוּמָת), Mk 7:10; death personified, Ro 6:9, I Co 15:26, Re 21:4; pl., of deadly perils, II Co 11:23. Of spiritual death: Jo 5:24 8:51, Ro 7:10, Ja 1:15, 5:20, I Jo 3:14 5:16, al.; of eternal death, Ro 1:32 7:5, al.; ὁ θ. ὁ δεύτερος, Re 2:11 21:8 (cf. Cremer, 283ff.; DB, iii, 114ff.; DCG, i, 791f.).
to put to death: c. acc, Mt 10:21 26:59 27:1, Mk 13:12 14:55, Lk 21:16, II Co 6:9, I Pe 3:18; pass., Ro 8:36. Metaph.: Ro 8:13; pass., c. dat, (in relation to), Ro 7:4.†
to be of good cheer or courage, to be confident: II Co 5:6 5:8, He 13:6; τ. πεποιθήσει, II Co 10:2; seq. εἰς, II Co 10:1; ἐν, II Co 7:16.†
to be of good courage: imperat., θάραει, -εῖτε, Mt 9:2, 22 14:27, Mk 6:50 10:49, Jo 16:33, Ac 23:11.†
courage: Ac 28:15.†
a wonder: II Co 11:14.; wonder: Re 17:6.†

to marvel, wonder, wonder at: absol., Mt 8:10, 27 9:33 15:31 21:20 22:22 27:14, Mk 5:20 15:5, Lk 1:21 (R, txt.; ICC, in l, but v. infr.), Lk 1:63 8:25 11:14 24:41, Jo 5:20 7:15, Ac 2:7 4:13 13:41, Re 17:7-8; c. acc pers., Lk 7:9; c. acc rei, Lk 24:12 (WH, R, mg. om.), Jo 5:28, Ac 7:31; θαῦμα μέγα, Re 17:6; πρόσωπον (LXX for פָּנִים נָשָׂא, De 10:17, al.), Ju 16; seq. διά, c. acc, Mk 6:6, Jo 7:21; seq. ἐν, c. dat. obj., Lk 1:21 (? R, mg., but v. supr); seq. ἐπί, c. dat. rei, Lk 2:33 4:22 9:43 20:26, Ac 3:12; περί, Lk 2:18; ὀπίσω, Re 13:3; ὅτι, Lk 11:38, Jo 3:7 4:27, Ga 1:6; εἰ, Mk 15:44, I Jn 3:13. Pass. (Si 38:3, Wi 8:11): seq. ἐν, c. dat. pers., II Th 1:10 (cf. ἐκ-θαυμάζω).†
wonderful; n. pl., wonders: Mt 21:15.†
wonderful, marvellous: Mt 21:42 (LXX) Mk 12:11, Jo 9:30, I Pe 2:9, Re 15:1, 3.†
a goddess: Ac 19:27.†

to behold, look upon, contemplate, view (in early writers with a sense of wondering), in NT apparently always in literal, physical sense of "careful and deliberate vision which interprets . . . its object": c. acc rei, Mt 11:7, Lk 7:24 23:55, Jo 1:14, 32 4:35 11:45, Ac 22:9, I Jn 1:1; c. acc pers., Mt 22:11, Ac 21:27, Ro 15:24, I Jn 4:12; c. ptcp., Mk 16:14, Lk 5:27, Jo 1:38, Ac 1:11; seq. ὅτι, Jo 6:5, I Jn 4:14; pass., Mt 6:1 23:5, Mk 16:11.†
to make a spectacle of, expose to contempt (eccl.; ἐκθ-, Polyb.): pass., He 10:33.†
a theatre (used also as a place of assembly): Ac 19:29, 31.; Collective for οἱ θεαταί, the spectators.; = θέα, θέαμα, a spectacle, show: metaph., I Co 4:9.†
divine: δύναμις, II Pe 1:3; φύσις (for parallel in π., v. MM, Exp., xv), II Pe 1:4; τὸ θ.,; the Deity (so in cl.; of God, in Philo and FlJ), Ac 17:29.†
divine nature, divinity: Ro 1:20 (for ex. from π., v. MM, Exp., xv).†
of brimstone, sulphureous: Re 9:17.†

will,; objectively = that which is willed: Mt 18:14, Lk 12:47, Jo 5:30, I Co 7:37, I Th 5:18, II Ti 2:26, He 10:10, Re 4:11; θ. τ. θεοῦ, Ac 22:14, Ro 2:18 12:2, Eph 1:9, Col 1:9 4:12, I Pe 4:2; τ. κυρίου, Eph 5:17; pl., of precepts, Mk 3:35, WH, mg., Ac 13:22 (LXX); ἐστιν τὸ θ., c. gen. pers., seq. ἵνα, Jo 6:39-40, I Co 16:12; c. inf., I Pe 2:15; c. acc et inf., I Th 4:3; subjectively = τὸ θέλειν (cf. θέλησις): Lk 23:25, Jo 1:13, I Pe 3:17, II Pe 1:21; ποιεῖν, Mt 7:21 12:50 21:31, Mk 3:35 (pl., WH, mg., v. supr.), Jo 4:34 6:38 7:17 9:31, Eph 6:6, He 10:7, 9 10:36 13:21, I Jn 2:17; γίνεσθαι, Mt 6:10 26:42, Lk 22:42, Ac 21:14; ἡ εὐδοκία ( βουλὴ) τοῦ θ., Eph 1:5, 11; ἐν τῷ θ. τοῦ θεοῦ, Ro 1:10; διὰ θ. θεοῦ, Ro 15:32, I Co 1:1, II Co 1:1 8:5, Eph 1:1, Col 1:1, II Ti 1:1; κατὰ τὸ θ. τ. θεοῦ, Ga 1:4, I Pe 4:19, I Jn 5:14; pl., Eph 2:3 (Cremer, 728).†
in colloq. and MGr. = τὸ θέλειν,; will: He 2:4.†

to will, be willing, wish, desire (more freq. than βούλομαι, q.v., in vernac. and late Gk., also in MGr.; for various views as to its relation to β., v. Thayer, 286; but v. also BL, §24, s.v.): absol., Ro 9:16, I Co 4:19 12:18, Ja 4:15; τ. θεοῦ θέλοντος, Ac 18:21; c. acc. rei, Mt 20:21, Mk 14:36, Jo 15:7, Ro 7:15, 16 I Co 4:21 7:36, Ga 5:17; c. inf., Mt 5:40, Mk 10:43, Jo 6:21, 67 Ro 7:21, Ga 4:9; c. acc. et inf., Mk 7:24, Lk 1:62, Jo 21:22, 23 Ro 16:19, I Co 14:5, Ga 6:13; οὐ θέλω, Mt 18:30, al.; id. c. inf., Mt 2:18, Mk 6:26, Jo 5:40, I Co 16:7; seq. ἵνα, Mt 7:12, Mk 6:25, Jo 17:24; opp. to ποιέω, πράσσω, ἐνεργέω, Ro 7:15, 19 II Co 8:10, 11 Phl 2:13; seq. ἤ (ICG, in l.; Deiss., LAE, 179:24), I Co 14:19; θέλων ἐν ταπεινοφροσυνῄ (of his own mere will, by humility, R, mg), Col 2:18; in OT quotations, for Heb. חפץ, c. acc. pers., Mt 27:43; c. acc. rei, Mt 9:13 12:7, He 10:5, 8; c. inf., I Pe 3:10; for אמר, c. inf., Ac 7:28 (v. Cremer, 726ff.).

of or for a foundation; as subst., ὁ θ. (sc. λίθος), a foundation stone, foundation: Lk 6:48-49 14:29 (but v. Deiss., BS, 123); pl., οἰ θ. (cl.), He 11:10 Re 21:14, 19; neut., τὸ θ. (Arist., Phys., vi, 6, 10, LXX and later writers), Ac 16:26; metaph., Ro 15:20, I Co 3:10-12 Eph 2:20, I Ti 6:19, II Ti 2:19, He 6:1.†
to lay the foundation of, to found: c. acc, τ. γῆν, He 1:10 (LXX); pass., Mt 7:25, Lk 6:48; metaph., I Pe 5:10 (R, mg., settle); pass., Eph 3:18, Col 1:23.†
taught of God (cf. διδακτοὶ θεοῦ, Jo 6:45): I Th 4:9.†
one who treats of the Divine nature (applied in cl. to the old poets and philosophers).; In eccl., a theologian, divine: Re, tit., Rec.†
to fight against God: Ac 23:9 (Rec.).†
fighting against God: Ac 5:39.†
inspired by God: II Ti 3:16.†

a god or deity, God. In polytheistic sense, a god or deity: Ac 28:6, I Co 8:4, II Th 2:4, al.; pl., Ac. 14:11 19:26, Ga 4:8, al. Of the one true God; anarthrous: Mt 6:24, Lk 20:38, al.; esp. c. prep. (Kühner 3, iii, 605), ἀπὸ θ., Jo 3:2; ἐκ, Ac 5:39, II Co 5:1, Phl 3:9; ὑπό, Ro 13:1; παρὰ θεοῦ, Jo 1:6; παρὰ θεῷ, II Th 1:6, I Pe 2:4; κατὰ θεόν, Ro 8:27, II Co 7:9, 10; also when in gen. dependent on an anarth. noun (Bl., §46, 6), Mt 27:43, Lk 3:2, Ro 1:17, I Th 2:13; as pred., Lk 20:38, Jo 1:1, and when the nature and character rather than the person of God is meant, Ac 5:29, Ga 2:6, al. (M, Th., 14); more freq., c. art.: Mt 1:23, Mk 2:7, al. mult.; c. prep., ἀπὸ τ. θ., Lk 1:26; ἐκ, Jo 8:42, al.; παρὰ τοῦ θ., Jo 8:40; π. τῷ θ., Ro 9:14; ἐν, Col 3:3; ἐπὶ τῷ θ., Lk 1:47; ἐπὶ τὸν θ., Ac 15:19; εἰς τ. θ., Ac 24:15; πρὸς τ. θ., Jo 1:2; c. gen. pers., Mt 22:32, Mk 12:26, 27, Lk 20:37, Jo 20:17, al.; ὁ θ. μου, Ro 1:8, Phi 1:3, al.; ὁ θ. καὶ πατήρ κ. τ. λ., Ro 15:6, Eph 1:3, Phi 4:20, al.; c. gen. rei, Ro 15:5, 13, 33, II Co 1:3, I Th 5:23; τὰ τ. θεοῦ, Mt 16:23, Mk 12:17, I Co 2:11; τὰ πρὸς τὸν θ., Ro 15:17, He 2:17 5:1; τ. θεῷ, as a superl. (LXX, Jos 3:3), Ac 7:20, II Co 10:4; Hebraistically, of judges (Ps 81(82):6), Jo 10:34 (LXX), 35.
fear of God, godliness: I Ti 2:10.†
God-fearing, godly: Jo 9:31.†
passive, as freq. in cl., hateful to God: Ro 1:30 (R, txt., cf. Lit., Notes, 256).; Active, hating God: lb. (R, mg., cf. ICC, in l).†
deity, Godhead: Col 2:9†
Theophilus: Lk 1:3, Ac 1:1.†
service.; healing: Lk 9:11 (Field, Notes, 60), Re 22:2.; Collective, household attendants, servants: Lk 12:42 (LXX, ll. c.).†

to do service, serve: c. acc pers., pass., Ac 17:25.; As medical term, to treat (MM, Exp., xv), cure, heal: Mt 12:10, Mk 6:5, Lk 6:7, al.; c. acc pers., Mt 4:24, Mk 1:34, al.; seq. ἀπό, Lk 5:15 6:18 7:21 8:2, 43; θ. νόσον (μαλακίαν), Mt 4:23, al; SYN: ἰάομαι (v. Field, Notes, 60; MM, Exp., l.c.)
an attendant, servant: He 3:5 (LXX)
to reap: Mt 6:26, Lk 12:24, Ja 5:4; fig., Mt 25:24, 26, Lk 19:21-22, Jo 4:36-38, II Co 9:6, Ga 6:7, 9, Re 14:15; c. acc, τ. σαρκικά, I Co 9:11; φθοράν, ζωὴν αἰώνιον, Ga 6:8; τ. γῆν, Re 14:16.†
harvest; the act: Jo 4:35; the time: fig., Mt 13:30, 39, Mk 4:29; the crop: fig., Mt 9:37-38, Lk 10:2, Re 14:15.†
a reaper: Mt 13:30, 39†
to warm, heat; mid., to warm oneself: Mk 14:54, 67, Jo 18:18, 25 Ja 2:16.†
heat: Ac 28:3.†
a Thessalonian: Ac 20:4 27:2, I Th 1:1, II Th 1:1.†
Thessalonica, a city of Macedonia: Ac 17:1, 11 17:13, Phl 4:16, II Ti 4:10.†
Theudas: Ac 5:36.†

(cl.), to look at, gaze, behold: absol., Mt 27:55, Mk 15:40, Lk 23:35; seq. πῶς, Mk 12:41; ποῦ, Mk 15:47; c. acc pers., Jo 6:40, 62 12:45 16:10-19, Ac 3:16 20:38 25:24, Re 11:11-12; id. c. ptcp., Mk 5:15, Lk 10:18, Jo 6:19 10:12 20:12, 14, I Jn 3:17; c. acc rei, Mt 28:1, Lk 14:29 21:6 23:48, Jo 2:23 6:2 7:3, Ac 4:13 8:13; id. c. ptcp., Jo 20:6, Ac 7:56 10:11; seq. ὅτι, Ac 19:26.; In popular lang. (Kennedy, Sources, 155; EL, § 24, s.v. ὁρᾶν), in pres. and impf. = ὁράω, to see, perceive, discern: seq. ὅτι, Mk 16:4, Jo 4:19 12:19, Ac 19:26 27:10; πόσαι, Ac 21:20; πηλίκος, He 7:4; c. acc rei, Mk 5:38; id. c. ptcp., Ac 17:16 28:6; c. acc pers., Mk 3:11, Jo 14:19, Ac 9:7 17:22; πνεῦμα, Lk 24:37; τὸ π., Jo 14:17; seq. ὅτι, Jo 9:8; c. ptcp., Lk 24:39.; Hebraistically, to experience, partake of: τ. θάνατον, Jo 8:51 (cf. Ps 89:49); τ. δόξαν, Jo 17:24 (cf. ἀνα-, παρα-θερρέω).†
a viewing.; = θεώρημα, a spectacle, sight: Lk 23:48 (both senses in cl.).†
a receptacle, chest, case: of the sheath of a sword, Jo 18:11.†
of the mother, to suckle: Mt 24:19, Mk 13:17, Lk 21:23.; Of the young, to suck: Mt 21:16; μαστούς, Lk 11:27 (cf. Jb 3:12, Ca 8:1, al.).†
female: as subst., ἡ θ., a female, a woman: Ro 1:26-27; τὸ θ.., Mt 19:4, Mk 10:6, Ga 3:28.†
a hunting, chase (Hat., Xen., al.).; prey, game (c1.).; As in Ps 35:8 = רֶשֶׁת, a net: Ro 11:9 (but v. Thayer, s.v.).†
to hunt, ensnare, catch: metaph., Lk 11:54.†
to fight with wild beasts (Diod., al.): I Co 15:32.†
a wild beast, beast: Mk 1:13, Ac 11:6 28:4-5, Tit 1:12, He 12:20, Ja 3:7, Re 6:8; of Antichrist, Re 11:7, 13-19.†

to lay up, store up: of riches, Ja 5:3; id. c. dat. pers., Lk 12:21, II Co 12:14; c. acc rei, I Co 16:2; θησαυροὺς ἑαυτῷ, Mt 6:19-20; pass., II Pe 3:7; metaph., ὀργὴν ἑαντῷ, Ro 2:5 (cf. Pr 1:18, Pss. Sol 9:9).†

a place of safe keeping; a casket: Mt 2:11; a treasury (I Mac 3:29 and freq. in cl.); a storehouse (Ne 13:12, De 28:12, al.): Mt 13:52; metaph., of the soul, Mt 12:35; τ. καρδίας, Lk 6:45; a treasure: Mt 6:18-21 13:44, Lk 12:33-34, He 11:26; θ. ἐν οὐρανῷ (v. Dalman, Words, 206 ff.), Mt 19:21, Mk 10:21, Lk 18:22; of the knowledge of God through Christ, II Co 4:7; τ. σοφίας κ. γνώσεως, Col 2:3.†
to touch, handle: Col 2:21, He 12:20 (LXX).; to injure (like Heb. נָגַע, and as in Eur., Iph. Aul., 1351): c. gen., He 11:28.†
