to press: c. acc pers., Mk 3:9; ὁδὸς τεθλιμμένη, a narrow (compressed) way, Mt 7:14. Metaph. (as freq. in LXX), to oppress, afflict, distress: c. acc pers., II Th 1:6; pass. (Vg., tribulor, tribulation em patior), II Co 1:6 4:8 7:5, I Th 3:4, II Th 1:7, I Ti 5:10, He 11:37 (cf. ἀπο-, συν-θλίβω).†

pressure (Arist.). In LXX and NT metaph., tribulation, affliction, distress: Mt 24:9, 21 24:29, Mk 13:19, 24, Jo 16:21, Ac 7:11 11:19, Ro 12:12, II Co 1:4 1:8 4:17 6:4 7:4 8:2 8:13, Phl 4:14, II Th 1:6, Ja 1:27, Re 1:9 2:9, 22 7:14; c. ἀνάγκη (q.v.), I Th 3:7; στενοχωρία (which from the order of the words would appear to be the stronger term), Ro 2:9 8:35; διωγμός, Mt 13:21, Mk 4:17, II Th 1:4; θ. ἔχω, Jo 16:33, I Co 7:23, Re 2:10; ἔρχεσθαι ἐπί, Ac 7:11; ἐν θλίψει I Th 1:6; pl., Ac 7:10 14:22 20:28, Ro 5:3, Eph 3:13, I Th 3:3, He 10:33; τ. Χριστοῦ, Col 1:24; θ. τῆς καρδίας, II Co 2:4; θ. ἐγείρειν, Phl 1:17.†
to die; pf. (M, Pr., 114), to be dead: Mt 2:20, Mk 15:44, Lk 7:12 8:49, Jo 11:44 19:33, Ac 14:19 25:19; metaph., of spiritual death, I Ti 5:6 (cf. ἀπο-, συν-απο-θνήσκω).†
subject to death, mortal: Ro 6:12 8:11, I Co 15:53-54, II Co 4:11 5:4.†
to make a noise or uproar: mid., of loud and ostentatious lamentation, Mt 9:23, Mk 5:39, Ac 20:10.; Trans., to trouble, throw into confusion: τ. πόλιν, Ac 17:5.†
a noise, uproar, tumult, as of an excited mob: Mt 26:5 27:24, Mk 14:2, Ac 20:1 21:34 24:18; of mourners, = ὄχλος θορυβούμενος, Mk 5:38.†
to disturb, trouble: pass., Lk 10:41.†
to break in pieces, shatter; metaph., to break down: Lk 4:18 (LXX).†
a nurseling, esp. of animals (Eur., Plat., al.).; cattle: Jo 4:12.†
intrans., to lament, wail: Mt 11:17, Lk 7:32, Jo 16:20.; Trans., to bewail: c. acc pers., Lk 23:27.†
a lamentation: Mt 2:18, Rec.†
religion in its external aspect (MM, Exp., xv), worship: Ac 26:5, Ja 1:26-27; θ. τῶν ἀγγέλων, Col 2:18.†
religious, careful of the outward forms of divine service (see previous word)): Ja 1:26.†

to triumph (and rarely, c. acc, to triumph over; so perh. Col 2:15, but v. infr.).; to lead in triumph: c. acc pers., II Co 2:14; hence, generally, to make a spectacle or show of: Col 2:15 (but v. supr.; cf. MM, Exp., xv; and esp. Field, Notes, 181).†
in cl.,; to cry aloud, make an outcry.; to utter aloud.; In NT (and LXX), pass., to be troubled, as by an alarm: Mt 24:6, Mk 13:7, Lk 24:37 (WH, mg.), II Th 2:2 (cf. Kennedy, Sources, 126).†
a lump, a clot of blood (DCG, ii, 685b): αἵματος, Lk 22:44 (WH, R, mg. omit the passage, v. WH, App., 64 ff.).†

in Hom., a seat, chair. Later, a throne, chair of state, seat of authority; of kings: metaph., of God, Mt 5:34, Ac 7:49 (LXX), Re 1:4, al.; by meton., for kingly power, sovereignty, Lk 1:32, 52, Ac 2:30; for an angelic hierarchy, Col 1:16; of Christ, Mt 19:28, Re 3:21, al.; of Satan, Re 2:13; τ. θηρίου, Re 16:10; of the Apostles, Mt 19:28, Lk 22:30, cf. Re 20:4; of πρεσβύτεροι, Re 4:4 11:16 (on θ. τῆς χάριτος, He 4:16, v. Westc., in l; Deiss., BS, 135)
Thyatira, a city of Lydia: Ac 16:14, Re 1:11 2:18, 24.†

daughter: Mt 9:18 10:35, 37 14:6 15:22, 28, Mk 5:35 6:22 7:26, 29, Lk 2:36 8:42, 49 12:53, Ac 2:17 (LXX) Ac 7:21 21:9, He 11:24. In NT, as in OT, not in cl.; as a form of friendly address (cf. Ru 2:2, 22 al.): Mt 9:22, Mk 5:34, Lk 8:48; metaph.: sc. κυρίου, II Co 6:18 (cf. Is 43:6); of posterity: θ. Ἀαρών, Lk 1:5; Ἀβραάμ, Lk 13:16 (cf. Is 16:2, IV Mac 15:28, al); of habita­tion: θ. Σιών, Ἱερουσαλήμ, Mt 21:5 (LXX), Lk 23:28, Jo 12:15 (cf. Is 1:8, Za 9:9, al.).†
a little daughter, a term of endearment used in late Gk. (cf. B1., § 27, 4): Mk 5:23 7:25.†
a hurricane, cyclone, whirlwind: He 12:18.†
thyme: ξύλον, Re 18:12 (Diosc.).†
fragrant stuff for burning, incense: ἡ ὥρα τοῦ θ., Lk 1:10; θυσιαστήριον τοῦ θ. (Ex 30:27, al.), Lk 1:11; pl., Re 5:8 8:3-4 18:13.†

as in cl. (Hdt., iv, 162; Thuc., vi, 46) and LXX, a censer: He 9:4 (but v. infr., and cf. Westc., in l).; As in Philo., rer. div., § 46, FlJ, Ant., iv, 2, 4, al., the altar of incense: He, l.c. (but v. supr. and cf. MM, Exp., xv).†
to burn incense: Lk 1:9.†
to fight desperately, have a hot quarrel: c. dat. pers., Ac 12:20.†

passion, hot anger, wrath: He 11:27; ὀργὴ καὶ θ., Ro 2:8, cf. Col 3:8; πικρία κ. θ., Eph 4:31; πλησθῆναι, πλήρης θυμοῦ, Lk 4:28, Ac 19:28; θ. ἔχειν, Re 12:12; οἶνος τ. θυμοῦ τ. πορνείας (cf. Je 51:7), Re 14:8 18:3 (cf. Re 17:2); οἶνος τ. θ. τ. θεοῦ, Re 14:10; τ. ὀργῆς τ. θεοῦ, Re 16:19 19:15; ὁ θ. τ. θεοῦ, Re 14:19 15:1, 7 16:1; pl., impulses or outbursts of anger: ἔρις, ζῆλος, θυμοὶ, ἐριθίαι, II Co 12:20, Ga 5:20 (Cremer, 287, 733).†
pass. (and mid.),; to be wroth or very angry: Mt 2:16.†

a door: κλείειν (ἀποκ-) τὴν θ., Mt 6:6, Lk 13:25; pass., Mt 25:10, Lk 11:7, Jo 20:19, 26, Ac 21:30; ἀνοίγειν, Ac 5:19; pass., Ac 16:26-27; κρούειν, Ac 12:13; διὰ τῆς θ., Jo 10:1-2; πρὸς τὴν θ., Mk 1:33 11:4 (WH om. τήν), Ac 3:2; τὰ πρὸς τὴν θ., the space by the door, Mk 2:2; πρὸς τῇ θ., Jo 18:16; ἐπὶ τῇ θ, Ac 5:9; πρὸ τῆς θ., Ac 12:6; ἐπὶ τῶν θ., Ac 5:23; ἡ θ. τ. μνημείου, Mt 27:60, Mk 15:46 16:3. Metaph., of Christ, ἡ θ. τ. προβάτων, Jo 10:7, 9; of the Kingdom of Heaven, Lk 13:24; of opportunities, θ. πίστεως, Ac 14:27; θ. μεγάλη, I Co 16:9; θ. τ. λόγου, Col 4:3; θ. ἀνεῳγμένη (ἠνεῳγ-), II Co 2:12, Re 3:8 4:1; of Christ, ἑστηκὼς ἐπὶ τὴν θ. καὶ κρούων, Re 3:20; of his second coming, ἐπὶ θύραις εἶναι, Mt 24:33, Mk 13:29; πρὸ θυρῶν ἑστηκέναι, Ja 5:9.†

in Hom., a door-stone.; In late Gk. (Polyb., Plut.), the scutum, a large oblong shield: θ. τ. πίστεως, Eph 6:16 (cf. Wi 5:20, where ὁσιότης is likened to the ἀσπίς, the clypeus or small round shield of the light-armed soldier).†
a window: Ac 20:9, II Co 11:33.†
a door-keeper, porter: ὁ, Mk 13:34, Jo 10:3; ἡ, Jo 18:16-17†

actively, an offering, sacrifice (Hdt., al.); Objectively, that which is offered, a sacrifice: Mt 9:13 12:7 (LXX), Mk 9:49 (WH, mg.), Eph 5:2, He 10:5, 26; pl. (as usually in cl.), Mk 12:33, Lk 13:1, He 9:23 10:1, 8, (θ. καὶ προσφοράς); θ. ἀνάγειν, Ac 7:41; ἀναφέρειν, He 7:27; προσφέρειν, Ac 7:42, He 5:1 8:3 (δῶρά τε καὶ θ.) He 10:11-12 11:4; δοῦναι, Lk 2:24; pass., He 9:9; διὰ τῆς θ. αὐτοῦ, He 9:26; ἐσθίειν τὰς θ. (Le 7:15 ff) I Co 10:18. Metaph., Phl 4:18, He 13:16; θ. πνευματικαί, I Pe 2:5; θ. ζῶσα, Ro 12:1; θ. αἰνέσεως, He 13:15; θ. . . . τ. πίστεως, Phl 2:17.†

an altar:; generally, Ja 2:21; pl., Ro 11:3 (LXX); metaph., He 13:10 (v. Westc., in l, and esp. his add, note on the history of the word, 455 ff.); of the altar of burnt-offering in the Temple, Mt 5:23-24 23:18-20, 35, Lk 11:51, I Co 9:13 10:18, He 7:13, Re 11:1; of the altar of incense in the sanctuary (Ex 30:1, al.), Lk 1:11; symbolically in Heaven, Re 6:9 8:3 9:13 14:18 16:7 (Cremer, 292).†

as in c1.; to offer first fruits to a god.; to sacrifice by slaying a victim, offer sacrifice: Ac 14:13; c. dat. pers., Ac 14:18; id. c. acc rei, I Co 10:20.; to slay, kill: Jo 10:10, Ac 10:13 11:7; c. acc rei, Lk 15:23, 27 15:30; pass., Mt 22:4; τὸ πάσχα (Ex 12:21), Mk 14:12; pass., Lk 22:7, I Co 5:7.†
a breastplate: Re 9:9, 17; θ. τ. δικαιοσύνης, Eph 6:14 (cf. Is 59:17, Wi 5:18-19); θ. πίστεως, I Th 5:8.†
Jairus: Mk 5:22, Lk 8:41.†

Jacob; The patriarch: Mt 1:2 8:11, Jo 4:5-6, Ac 7:8, al,; as in Heb. (cf. Nu 23:7, Is 41:8, Si 23:12, al.), of his descendants, Ro 11:26 (LXX).; The father-in-law of Mary: Mt 1:15-16 (on the form as distinct from that of the next word, v. Deiss., BS, 3161)

James; Son of Zebedee: Mt 4:21, Mk 1:19, 29, Ac 1:13 12:2, al.; Son of Alphæus: Mt 10:3, Mk 2:14, al.; commonly identified with Ἰ. ὁ μικρός, James the little, son of Mary (v.s. Μαρία, 3; Κλωπᾶς), Mt 27:56, Mk 15:40 16:1 (cf. Jo 19:25).; The Lord's brother (v.s. ἀδελφός): Mt 13:55, Mk 6:3, Ac 12:17, al., I Co 15:7 (probably), Ga 1:19 2:9, 12, Ja 1:1, Ju 1.; The father of the apostle, Ἰούδας Ἰακώβου: Lk 6:16, Ac 1:13
most freq. in cl., a means of healing, remedy (Thuc., al.; Wi 11:4 10:9).; = ἴασις (q.v.), a healing (Plat.; Jer, l.c.): pl., I Co 12:9 12:28 12:30.†
Jambres (cf. Ex 7:11-12): II Ti 3:8.†
Jannai: Lk 3:24.†
Jannes (cf. Ἰαμβρῆς): II Ti 3:8.†
Jared (Ge 5:15): Lk 3:37.†
a healing, cure: Ac 4:22, 30; pl., Lk 13:32.†
jasper, apparently not the modern stone of that name, but a translucent stone (DB, s.v.): Re 4:3 21:11, 18-19.†
Jason: Ac 17:5-7, 9; perhaps the same, Ro 16:21.†
a physician: Mt 9:12, Mk 2:17 5:26, Lk 4:23 5:31 8:43 (om. WH, R, mg.), Col 4:14 (on the status of physicians, v. MM, Exp., xv.).†

prop., 2 aor. imperat. of ὁράω, q.v.; As interjection, apart from the construction of the sentence, and used where one or many are addressed, see! behold! lo!: Mt 25:20, 22 25:25, Mk 2:24 3:34 11:21 13:1, 21 15:4, 35 16:6, Jo 1:29, 36 1:48 3:26 5:14 7:26 11:3, 36 12:19 16:29 18:21 19:4, 14 19:26-27, Ga 5:2.†

one's own; of that which is private and personal (in cl. opp. to κοινός, δημόσιος; cf. infr. 3); of property, friends, home, country, etc. (in cl. opp. to ἀλλότριος; in late writers often, like ἑαυτοῦ, with weakened sense, v. M, Pr., 87ff.; Deiss., BS, 123f.): Lk 6:41, Jo 1:42 5:43, Ac 2:6 20:28, I Co 11:21, Ga 6:5, II Ti 1:9, He 7:27, Ju 6, al.; πράσσειν τὰ ἴ., I Th 4:11; κατὰ τὰς ἰ. ἐπιθυμίας, II Ti 4:3; οἱ ἴδιοι, Jo 1:11 (M, Pr., 90f.; Field, Notes, 84) 13:1, Ac 4:23, I Ti 5:8; τὰ ἴδια, one's home (Field, Notes, l.c.), Lk 18:28, Jo 1:11 16:32 19:27. peculiar, distinct, appropriate, proper: τὸ ἴ. σῶμα, I Co 15:38; ἐν τ. ἰ. τάγματι, I Co 15:23; εἰς τ. τόπον τ. ἴ., Ac 1:25; = αὐτοῦ (v. Deiss., ut. supr.), Mt 22:5, Jo 1:42 (cf. Wi 10:1). Adverbially (v. supr., 1 (a); and cf. WM, 739:2); ἰδίᾳ, severally, separately: I Co 12:11; κατ’ ἰδίαν, apart, privately, in private: Mt 14:13, 23 20:17, Mk 4:34 7:33, Lk 10:23, Ac 23:19, al.

a pri­vate person, as opp. to the State or an official (βασιλεῖς κ. ἰδιῶται, Pr, l.c.; and cf. MM, Exp., xv).; one without professional knowledge, unskilled, uneducated, unlearned: I Co 14:16 14:23-24 (R, mg., without gifts); ἀγράμματοι κ. ἰ., Ac 4:13; c. dat. (= cl. c. gen. rei), λόγῳ, II Co 11:6.†

lo, behold, see: Mt 10:16 11:8 13:3, Mk 3:32, Lk 2:48, I Co 15:51, Ja 5:9, Ju 14, Re 1:7, al.; after gen. absol., Mt 1:20 2:1, 13 12:46, al.; καὶ ἰδού, Mt 2:9 (and freq.), Lk 1:20 10:25, Ac 12:7, al.; in elliptical sentences, taking the place of copula or predicate (like הִנֵּה in Heb.), Mt 3:17, Lk 5:12 22:31, 47 Ac 8:27, 36 al.
Idumæa: Mk 3:8.†
sweat: Lk 22:44 (WH, omit).†
Jezebel (III Ki 16:31, al.): symbolically, Re 2:20 (v. Swete, in l).†
Hierapolis: a city in the Lyons valley in the Province of Asia: Col 4:13.†
priesthood, office of priest: Lk 1:9, He 7:5.†
a priesthood, body of priests: ἱ ἅγιον, I Pe 2:5; βασ. ἱ, I Pe 2:9 (LXX, Ex, l.c.).†
to be a priest, officiate as a priest: Lk 1:8 (the word is freq. in Inscr.; v. LS, s.v.; Deiss., BS, 215; LAE, 70; Cremer, 734).†
Heb. Jeremiah the prophet: Mt 2:17 16:14 27:9 (a ref. to Za 11:13).†

a priest: ἱ. τ. Διός, Ac 14:13; of Jewish priests, Mt 8:4 12:4-5, Mk 1:44 2:26, Lk 1:5 5:14, Jo 1:19, He 8:4, al.; of Christ, He 5:6 (LXX) He 10:21; of Christians, Re 1:6 5:10 20:6 (Cremer, 293; on the acc pl., ἱερεῖς, v. Thack., Gr., 147 f.; Bl., § 8, 2)
suited to a sacred character, reverend (RV, reverent): Tit 2:3 (cf. Tr., Syn., § xcii).†

in Hom., marvellous, mighty, divine.; (Also in Hom, and later cl.) consecrated to the deity, sacred: pl., ἱ. γράμματα, II Ti 3:15.; As subst.,; (so in Hom.), τὰ ἱ., sacrifices, sacred rites, sacred things: I Co 9:13; later, τὸ ἱ.,., a consecrated or sacred place, a temple: τ. Ἀρτέμιδος, Ac 19:27; of the temple at Jerusalem, i.e. the entire precincts or some part thereof (as distinct from ὁ ναός, q.v., the Sanctuary proper): I Co 9:13, and freq. in Gosp. and esp. in Ac, Mt 12:6, Mk 13:3, Ac 4:1, al. (on the use of ἱ. in Imperial Iuser., v. Deiss., LAE, 380 f.)

Jerusalem: Mt 2:1, Mk 3:8, Jo 1:19, al.; its inhabitants, Mt 2:3 3:5 23:37, Lk 13:34, Symbolically, ἡ- ἄνω Ἱ., Ga 4:26, contrasted with ἡ νῦν Ἱ., Ga 4:25; Ἱ. ἐπουράνιος, He 12:22; ἡ καινὴ Ἱ., Re 3:12 21:2, 10
an inhabitant of Jerusalem: Mk 1:5, Jo 7:25.†
to rob a temple (commit sacrilege, R, mg.): Ro 2:22.†
robbing temples: Ac 19:37.†
to perform sacred rites; c. acc, to minister in priestly service (minister in sacrifice, R, mg.), τὸ εὐαγγέλιον, Ro 15:16.†
priesthood: He 7:11-12, 24.†
Jephthah: He 11:32.†
Jechoniah: Mt 1:11-12.†

JESUS: Mt 1:21, al.; ὁ Ἰ, ib. 3:13, al.; Ἰ. Χριστός, ib. 1:1, Mk 1:1, al.; Χρ. Ἰ., Ro 2:26, al.; κύριος Ἰ., Ac 28:31, al.; Ἰησοῦ, voc., Mk 1:24, al. Joshua: Ac 7:45, He 4:8. Jesus, son of Eliezer: Lk 3:28. Jesus, surnamed Justus: Col 4:11. v.s. βαραββᾶς.

of persons, suffcient, competent, fit: c. inf., Mt 3:11, Mk 1:7, Lk 3:16, I Co 15:9, II Co 3:6, II Ti 2:2; seq. πρός, II Co 2:16; seq. ἵνα, Mt 8:8, Lk 7:6.; Of things, in number, quantity or size, sufficient, enough, much, many: absol., ἱκανοί, Lk 7:11 (WH, R, omit) Lk 8:32, Ac 12:12 14:21 19:19, I Co 11:30; ὄχλος ἱ., Mk 10:46, Lk 7:12, Ac 11:24, 26 19:26; κλαυθμός, Ac 20:37; ἀργύρια, Mt 28:12; λαμπάδες, Ac 20:8; λόγοι, Lk 23:9; φῶς, Ac 22:6; ἱ, ἐστιν (cf. לָכֶם רַב, LXX ἱκανούσθω, De 3:26), Lk 22:38; τὸ ἱ. ποιεῖν (Lat. satisfacere; cf. Je 48:30), Mk 15:15; τὸ ἱ. λαμβάνειν (Lat. satis accipere; v. M, Pr 20:1-30 f.), Ac 17:9; of time, ἡμέραι ἱ., Ac 9:23, 43 18:18 27:7; ἱ. χρόνος, Lk 8:27, Ac 8:11 14:3 27:9; pl., Lk 20:9; ἐκ χρόνων ἱ., Lk 23:8; ἀπὸ ἱ. ἐτῶν, Ro 15:23 (WH); ἐφ ̓ ἱκανόν (cf. II Mac 8:25), Ac 20:11.†
sufficiency, ability (Plat.): II Co 3:5.†
to make sufficient, render fit: c. dupl. acc, II Co 3:6; c. acc pers. seq. εἰς, Col 1:12.†
of a suppliant; as subst., ἡ ἱ. (Sc. ῥάβδος),; in cl., an olive-branch, carried by a suppliant.; In late Gk. = ἱκεσία, supplication: pl., δεήσεις κ. ἱ., He 5:7
moisture: Lk 8:6.†
Iconium, a city of the province of Galatia: Ac 13:51 14:1, 19 14:21 16:2, II Ti 3:11.†
cheerful, joyous: II Co 9:7 (Pr 22:8 (LXX))†
cheerfulness: Ro 12:8.†

in cl., c. acc pers., to conciliate, appease, propitiate (= ἐξιλάσκομαι, Ge 32:20, Pr 16:14, Ma 1:9, al.).; In LXX (Thackeray, Gr., 270, 1.), Inscr. (Deiss., BS, 224 f.), and NT, to be propitious, merciful (c. dat. rei, Ps 79:9, al.): c. dat pers. (IV Ki 5:18), Lk 18:13.; As in Philo (= ἐξιλάσκ-, in LXX: Ez 43:22, al.), to expiate, make propitiation for: τ. ἁμαρτίας, He 2:17 (Cremer, 301 ff., 735).†
an appeasing (Plut.).; a means of appeasing, propitiation (Philo; Nu, Ez, ll.c.): I Jn 2:2 Jn 4:10.; In LXX also forgiveness (Ps, Da TH, ll.c.).†

propitiatory (μνῆμα, FlJ, Ant., xvi, 7, 1; θάνατος, 2Mac, l.c.): of Christ, Ro 3:25; as subst., το ἱ. (sc. ἐπίθεμα, Ex 25:16-17, where the word first occurs in LXX and where ἱ. ἐ. = כַּפֹּרֶת (q.v. in BDB, s.v.), elsewhere rendered simply τὸ ἱ; cf. Deiss., 124 ff.; Westc., He., in l), He 9:5.†
propitious, merciful: τ. ἀδικίαες, He 8:12 (Je, l.c.; cf.1 Ki, l.c.); ἵ. σοι (sc. ἔστω ὁ θεός), Mt 16:22 (cf. 1Sam, l.c.).†
Illyricum, a region bordering on the Adriatic Sea: Ro 15:19.†
a thong, strap: for binding prisoners (Ma, Sir, ll. c.), Ac 22:25; for fastening sandals, Mk, Lk 3:16, Jo 1:27.†
to clothe: Mk 5:15, Lk 8:35 (elsewhere only in π.; cf. MM, Exp., xv; Deiss., LAE, 78 f.).†

a garment, but in usage always (exc. in p1., v. infr.) of an outer garment, a mantle, cloak (thrown over the χιτών; v. Rutherford, NPhr., 22; DCG, i, 499a): Mt 9:16, 20-21 Mk 2:21 5:27-28, 30 Jo 19:2, Ac 12:8, al.; opp. to χιτών, Mt 5:40, Lk 6:29, Ac 9:39; pl., garments, clothes (i.e. the cloak and the tunic), Mt 17:2 26:65 27:31, 35, Mk 5:30 15:20, 24, Jo 19:23-24, Ja 5:2, al
clothing, apparel (usually of sumptuous attire; v. Tr., Syn., § 1): Lk 7:25 9:29, Jo 19:24 (Ps 22:19, LXX for לְבוּשׁ), Ac 20:33, I Ti 2:9.†

adverb (poët., Hom., al.), of place, where, whither. of circumstance, when. Conjunction, prop., final, denoting purpose or end (cl.), that, in order that, usually the first word in the clause, but sometimes (cl. also) preceded by an emphatic word (Ac 19:4, Ro 11:31 (?), Ga 2:10, al.); c. optat. (so in cl. after historic tenses): after a pres., Eph 1:17 (but WH, mg., subjc.; v. Burton, §225, Rem., 2); c. subjc.: after a pres., Mk 4:21, Lk 6:34, Jo 3:15, Ac 2:25, Ro 1:11, al.; after a pf., Mt 1:22, Jo 5:23 I Co 9:22, al.; after an imperat. (pres. or aor.), Mt 7:1, Mk 11:25, Jo 10:38, I Co 7:5, al.; after a delib. subjc., Mk 1:38, al.; after a fut., Lk 16:4, Jo 14:3, I Co 15:28, al.; after historic tenses (where optat. in cl.; WM, 359f.; M, Pr., 196f.), Mk 6:41 (impf.), Jo 4:8 (plpf.), Mk 3:14 (aor.), al.; in late writers (M, Pr., 35; Burton, §§198, 199), c. indic., fut: Lk 20:10, I Pe 3:1, al.; as often in eccl. writers (Thayer, s.v.), c. indic. pres.: I Co 4:6, Ga 4:17, al. (?; but V. Burton, §198, Rem.); εἰς (διὰ) τοῦτο, ἵνα: Jo 18:37, I Ti 1:16, al.; τούτου χάριν, Tit 1:5; elliptical constructions: omission of the principal verb, Jo 1:8, II Th 3:9, I Jo 2:19, al.; of the final verb, Ro 4:16, II Co 8:13, al. In late writers, definitive, = inf. (WM, 420; Bl, §69, 1), that; after verbs of wishing, caring, striving, etc.: θέλω, Mt 7:12, al.; ζητῶ, I Co 4:2 14:12; ζηλόω, I Co 14:1, al.; after verbs of saying, asking, exhorting: εἰπεῖν, Mt 4:3, al.; ἐρωτῶ, Mk 7:26, al.; παρακαλῶ, Mt 14:36, I Co 1:10, al., etc.; after words expressing expediency, etc.: συμφέρει, Mt 18:6, Jo 11:50, al.; ἱκανός, Mt 8:8, Lk 7:6; χρείαν ἔχω, Jo 2:25, al, etc.; after substantives, adding further definition: ὥρα, Jo 12:23 13:1; χρόνος, Re 2:21; συνήθεια, Jo 18:39; μισθός, I Co 9:18. In late writers, ecbatic, denoting the result, = ὥστε, that, so that (M, Pr., 206ff.; WM, 572; Bl., §69, 3; Burton, §223): Ro 11:11, I Co 7:29, I Th 5:4, al. (but v. Thayer, s.v.); so with the formula referring to the fulfilment of prophecy, ἵνα πληρωθῇ, Mt 1:22 2:14, Jo 13:18, al.
the Jordan: Mt 3:5, Mk 1:5, al
an arrow.; rust (Ez, l.c.): Ja 5:3 (cf. MM, Exp., xv).; poison: fig., Ro 3:13 (Ps. l.c.), Ja 3:8.†
to can-form to Jewish practice, to Judaize: Ga 2:14.†
Jewish: Tit 1:14.†
adv.; in Jewish fashion: Ga 2:14.†

Jewish: ἀνήρ, Ac 10:28 22:3; ἄνθρωπος, Ac 21:39; ψευδοπροφήτης, 13:6; ἀσχιερεύς, 19:14; γυνή, 16:1 24:24; γῆ, Jo 3:22; χώρα, Mk 1:5. Substantively, Ἰουδαῖος, ὁ, a Jew: Jo 4:9, Ac 18:24, Ro 2:28; pl., Re 2:9 3:9; οἱ Ἰ., Mt 2:2, Mk 7:3, Jo 2:6, al.; Ἰ. τε καὶ Ἕλληνες, Ac 14:1, al.; κ. προσήλυτοι, Ac 2:10; ἔθνη τε κ. Ἰ., Ac 14:5; οἱ κατὰ τὰ ἔθνη, Ac 21:21; of Jewish Christians, Ga 2:13; of the ruling class who opposed Jesus, Jo 1:19 2:18 5:10 11:8 13:33, al.; Ἰουδαία, -ας, ἡ (sc. γῆ, χώρα, cf. Jo 3:22, Mk 1:5), (Heb. יְהוּדָה), Judæa: Mt 2:1, Lk 1:5, Jo 4:3, al.
Judaism, the observance of Jewish rites: Ga 1:13-14.†

dat. -ᾳ,; acc -αν; Judah, son of Jacob: Mt 1:2-3, Lk 3:33; φυλή Ἰ., Re 5:5 7:5; by meton., of the tribe, He 7:14; of its confines, γῆ Ἰ., Mt 2:6;πόλις Ἰ., Lk 1:39.; Judah (unknown): Lk 3:30.; Judas Iscariot (v.s. Ἰσκαριώτης): Mt 10:4, Mk 3:19, Lk 6:16, Jo 6:71 13:2, al.; Judas, the Lord's brother (v.s. ἀδελφός): Mt 13:55, Mk 6:3 (prob.), Ju 1.; Judas the Apostle, son of James (v.s. Θαδδαῖος): Lk 6:16, Jo 14:22, Ac 1:13.; Judas, of Damascus: Ac 9:11.; Judas, surnamed Βαρσαββᾶς (q.v.): Ac 15:22, 27 15:32.; Judas the Galilean: Ac 5:37; Ἰωδά; Joda: Lk 3:26.†
Julia: Ro 16:15.†
Julius: Ac 27:1, 3.†
Junias: Ro 16:7.†
Justus, the surname of,; Joseph Barsabbas: Ac 1:23.; Titus, of Corinth: Ac 18:7.; Jesus, a Christian of Rome: Col 4:11.†
a horseman: Ac 23:23, 32.†
of a horse or of horsemen, equestrian; as subst., τὸ ἱ (sc. στράτευμα), cavalry: He 9:16.†
a horse: Ja 3:3, Re 6:2 ff. Re 9:7 ff. Re 14:20 18:13 19:11 ff,†
Iris, the messenger of the gods.; a rain­bow or halo: Re 4:3 10:1.; The plant Iris (cf. Ex., l.c.).†
indecl.; Isaac (Ge 17:19, al.): Mt 1:2, Ro 9:10, al
like or equal to angels: Lk 20:36.†
Iscariot: surname of Judas, ll. c. supr., also Mt 10:4 26:14, Mk 14:43 (WH, R, omit), Lk 22:3, Jo 12:4 13:2 14:22; of his father Simon, Jo 6:71 13:26.†

equal, the same in size, number, quality, etc.: δωρεά, Ac 11:17; μαρτυρίαι, Mk 14:56, 59; ἴ. ποιεῖν, c. acc et dat., Mt 20:12; ἑαυτὸν τ. θεῷ, Jo 5:18; τὰ ἴ. ἀπολαβεῖν, Lk 6:34, n. pl., ἴσα, adverbially, Re 21:16; τ. θεῷ, Phl 2:6.†
equality: II Co 8:13-14.; equity, fairness: τὸ δίκαιον κ. τὴν ἰ., Col 4:1 (for dis­tinction bet. τὸ δ. and ἡ ἰ, v. ICC, in l).†
equally privileged, held in equal honour: πίστις, II Pe 1:1 (R, mg., equally precious, but v Field, Notes, 240; Mayor, in l).†
of equal spirit (Æsch., Agam., 1470).; like-minded: Phl 2:20.†

Israel: ὁ οἶκος Ἰ., Ac 7:42 (LXX), al.; λαός, Ac 4:10; υὁοί, Ac 5:21, al.; αἱ φυλαὶ τοῦ Ἰ., Mt 19:28, al. By meton., for the Israelites, Mt 2:6, Lk 1:54, Ro 11:2, al.; ὁ λαὸς Ἰ., Ac 4:10; γῆ Ἰ., Mt 2:20-21; βασιλεὺς Ἰ., Mt 27:42, Jo 1:50; ἡ ἐλπὶς τοῦ Ἰ., Ac 28:20; ὁ Ἰ. τοῦ θεοῦ (of Christians), Ga 6:16; ὁ Ἰ. κατὰ σάρκα, I Co 10:18
an Israelite, the name expressive of theocratic privilege (v.s. Ἑβραῖος): Ro 9:4 11:1, II Co 11:22; ἀληθῶς Ἰ., Jo 1:48; ἄνδρες Ἰ., Ac 2:22 3:12 5:35 13:16 21:23.†
Issachar: Re 7:7.†

Trans, in pres., impf., fut. and 1 aor. act. and in the tenses of the pass. to make to stand, to place, set, set up, establish, appoint: c. acc. pers., Mk 7:9, Ac 1:23 6:13 17:31, He 10:9; id. seq. ἐπί, c. acc. loc, Mt 4:5, Lk 4:9; ἐν μέσῳ, Mt 18:2, Mk 9:36, Jo 8:[3]; ἐνώπιον, Ac 6:6; παρ’ ἑαυτῷ, Lk 9:47; ἐκ δεξιῶν, Mt 25:33; mid., to place oneself, to stand: Re 18:15; so also pass., to be made to stand, to stand: Mt 2:9, Lk 11:18 19:8, II Co 13:1, al. to set in a balance, to weigh (cl.; LXX for שׁקל, Is 46:6, al.): Mt 26:15, Intrans., in pf., plpf. (with sense of pres. and impf.; M, Pr., 147f.) and 2 aor. act., to stand, stand by, stand still: Mt 20:32 26:73, Mk 10:49, Lk 8:44, Jo 1:35 3:29, Ac 16:9, al.; seq. ἐν, Mt 6:5, al.; ἐνώπιον, Ac 10:30, al.; πρός, c. dat. loc., Jo 18:16; ἐπί, c. gen. loc., Lk 6:17, Ac 5:23 25:10, al.; ἔμπροσθεν, Mt 27:11; κύκλῳ, Re 7:11; ἐκ δεξιῶν, Lk 1:11; ἐπί, c. acc., Mt 13:2, Re 3:20; παρά, Lk 5:2; ἐκεῖ, Mk 11:5; ὧδε, Mk 9:1; ὅπου, Mk 13:14; ἔξω, Mt 12:46; μακρόθεν, Lk 18:13; πόρρωθεν, Lk 17:12. Metaph., to stand ready, stand firm, be steadfast: I Co 7:37 10:12, Eph 6:11, 13 14, Col 4:12; τ. πίστει, Ro 11:20; ἐν τ. ἀληθείᾳ, Jo 8:44; εν τ. χάριτι, Ro 5:2; ἐν τ. εὐαγγελίῳ, I Co 15:1 (cf. ἀν-, ἐπ-ἀν-, ἐξ-ἀν, ἀνθ-, ἀφ-, δι-, ἐν-, ἐξ-, ἐπ- (-μαι), ἐφ-, κατ-ἐφ-, συν-ἐφ-, καθ-, ἀντι-καθ-, ἀπο-καθ-, μεθ-, παρ-, περι-, προ-, συν-ίστημι).

c. acc rei, to inquire into, learn by inquiry.; C. acc pers., to inquire of or about.; to narrate, record.; In late writers, to visit, become acquainted with: Ga 1:18 (v. Ellic., in l, and cf. MM, Exp., xv).†

strong, mighty, powerful; of persons, as to body or spirit: Mt 12:29, Mk 3:27, Lk 11:21-22, I Co 4:10 (opp. to ἀσθενής), He 11:34 (ἐν πολέμῳ), Re 5:2 10:1 18:21 19:18; οἱ πλούσιοι κ. οἱ ἰ, Re 6:15; τὰ ἰ. = oἱ ἰ. (cf. IV Ki 24:15), I Co 1:27; of God (cf. De 10:17), Re 18:8; compar., Mt 3:11, Mk 1:7, Lk 11:22, I Co 1:25 (τὸ ἀσθενὲς τ. θεοῦ) I Co 10:22; of things: λιμός, Lk 15:14; ἐπιστολαί ( βαρεῖαι κ. ἰ.), II Co 10:10; κραυγή, He 5:7; φωνή, Re 18:2; παράκλησις, He 6:18; πόλις, Re 18:10; βρονταί, Re 19:6.†

strength, might, power, force, ability: Re 5:12 7:12; ἰ. κ. δύναμις, II Pe 2:11; τ. κράτος τῆς ἰ. (Is 40:26), Eph 1:19 6:10; ἡ δόξα τῆς ἰ., II Th 1:9; ἐξ ἰ., I Pe 4:11; ἐν ὅλῃ τ. ἰ., Mk 12:30, 33 (LXX) Lk 10:27 (LXX).†

to be strong in body: Mt 9:12, Mk 2:17.; to be powerful, have power, prevail: Ac 19:20, Re 12:8; seq. κατά, c. gen. pers., Ac 19:16; c. inf., to be able (MM, Exp., xv): Mt 8:28 26:40, Mk 5:4 9:18 (inf. understood) Mk 14:37, Lk 6:48 8:43 13:24 14:6, 29-30 16:3 20:26, Jo 21:6, Ac 6:10 15:10 25:7 27:16; c. acc, Phl 4:13, Ja 5:16; of things, to avail, be serviceable (MM, Exp., l.c.): Mt 5:13, Ga 5:6, He 9:17 (cf. ἐν-, ἐξ-, ἐπ-, κατ-ισχύω).†
equally.; perhaps: Lk 20:13.†
Italian: σπεῖρα Ἰ., Ac 10:1.†
Ituræan (in cl. always ὁι Ἰ., the Ituræans) χώρα (ἡ Ἰτουραίων ὀρεινή, τὰ τῶν Ἰ. μέρη, Strabo, XVI, ii, 16, 20), Lk 3:1 (cf. Exp. (1894), ix, 51 ff., 143 ff., 288 ff.).†
a little fish: Mt 15:34, Mk 8:7.†
a fish: Mt 7:10, Mk 6:38, al.
a track, footstep: metaph. (as freq. in cl.), στοιχεῖν τοῖς ἴ., Ro 4:12; περιπατεῖν τοῖς ἴ., II Co 12:18; ἐπακολουθεῖν τοῖς ἴ., I Pe 2:21 (cf. MM, Exp., xv).†
Jotham, King of Judah: Mt 1:9.†
Joanna: Lk 8:3 24:10.†
Joanan (cf. Ἰωάνης): Lk 3:37.†

John ( I Es 8:38(41)*), viz., John the Baptist: Mt 3:1, al. John the Apostle, son of Zebedee: Mt 4:21, Mk 1:19, Lk 5:10, Ac 1:13, al. The father of St. Peter: Jo 1:43 21:15-17. John surnamed Mark: Ac 12:12, 25 13:5, 13 15:37. The writer of the Apocalypse, traditionally identified with 2: Re 1:1, 4 9.; John: Ac 4:6 13:5, Tr., WH, Re 22:8 (cf. Ἰωάνης).†
Job: Ja 5:11.†
Jo bed (Obed): Mt 1:5, Lk 3:32.†
Joda Lk 3:26.†
Joel: Ac 2:16.†
Jonam: Lk 3:30.†
Jonah, the prophet: Mt 12:39-41 16:4, Lk 11:29-30, 32.†
Joram, Jehoram: Mt 1:8.†
indecl.,; Jorim: Lk 3:29.†
Jehoshaphat: Mt 1:8.†
Josiah: Mt 1:10-11 †
Joses; brother of our Lord: Mk 6:3, Mt 13:55 (Rec., v.s. Ἰωσήφ). Son of Mary: Mt 27:56 (-σήφ), WH, txt), Mk 15:40, 47 v.s. Βαρνάβας.†

Joseph; the Son of Jacob: Jo 4:5, Ac 7:9, 13-14 7:18, He 11:21-22, Re 7:8.; In the genealogy of our Lord,; the son of Matthias: Lk 3:24; the son Joram: Lk 3:30.; The husband of Mary, the Lord's mother Mt 1:16 ff, Lk 1:27, Jo 1:46, al.; One of the brethren of our Lord (v.s. ἀδελφός): Mt 13:55.; Son of Mary: Mt 27:56 (-σῆς, WH, mg., RV).; Joseph of Arimatbæa: Mt 27:57, 59, Mk 15:43, 45, Lk 23:50, Jo 19:38.; v.s. Βαρνάβας.; v.s. Βαρσαβᾶς
Josech: Lk 3:26.†
iota (Heb. י, i.e. the smallest letter): Mt 5:18.†
just as, according as: Mt 27:10 (LXX), Lk 1:2, D (cf. BL, § 78, 1; Phil. Gosp., 8 f.).†
a pulling down, destruction: fig., κ. ὀχυρωμάτων, II Co 10:4; opp. to οἰκοδομή, II Co 10:8 13:10.†

to take down: c. acc pers. (the technical term for removal after crucifixion, Field, Notes, 44), Mk 15:36, 46, Lk 23:53, Ac 13:29.; to put down by force, pull down, destroy: ἀποθήκας, Lk 12:18 (opp. to οἰκοδομεῖν); δυνάστας, Lk 1:52; ἔθνη, Ac 13:19; pass., Ac 19:27 (diminished, Field, Notes, 129 f.); fig., to refute: λογισμούς, II Co 10:5.†
to cleanse: of pruning, Jo 15:2 (cf. καθαρίζω).†
to fasten on, put upon, c. acc; Act. for mid. (cf. Bl., § 53, 3), to lay hold of, attack: c. gen., χειρός, Ac 28:3.†

to cleanse, make clean.; In physical sense: c. acc rei, fig., Mt 23:25-26, Lk 11:39; of disease (leprosy), c. acc pers., Mt 8:2-3 10:8 11:5, Mk 1:40-42 Lk 4:27 5:12-13 7:22 17:14, 17; ἡ λέπρα ἐκαθερίσθη (on the spelling v. supr.), Mt 8:3.; In ethical sense: τ. καρδίας, Ac 15:9 (cf. Si 38:10); τ. χεῖρας, Ja 4:8; λαὸν ἑαυτῷ, Tit 2:14; τ. ἐκκλησίαν, Eph 5:26; c. acc pers. (rei), seq. ἀπό (131., § 36, 9; Deiss., BS, 216 f.), II Co 7:1, He 9:14, I Jn 1:7 Jn 1:9.; In ceremonial sense: Mk 7:19, Ac 10:15 11:9, He 9:22-23 10:2 (cf. δια-καθαρίζω).†

cleansing, purification: Jo 3:25; c. gen. subjc., τ. Ἰουδαίων, Jo 2:6; c. gen. obj., of women after childbirth, Lk 2:22; of lepers, Mk 1:44, Lk 5:14; c. gen. rei, τ. ἁμαρτιῶν, He 1:3, II Pe 1:9 (Cremer, 319).†

pure, clean.; Physically: Mt 23:26 27:59, Jo 13:10-11 (fig.), Jo 15:3 (fig., as of a vine cleansed by pruning), He 10:22, Re 15:6 19:8, 14 21:18, 21.; Ceremonially: Lk 11:41, Ro 14:20, Tit 1:15.; Ethically; of persons: Jo 13:16, Ac 18:6, Tit 1:15; ό κ. τῇ καρδίᾳ (καθαρὸς χεῖρας, Hdt., i, 35), Mt 5:8; seq. ἀπό (cl. c. gen. simp.; ΒΙ., § 36, 11; Deiss., BS, 196; MM, Exp., xv), Ac 20:26; of things: καρδία, I Ti 1:6, II Ti 2:22; συνείδησις, I Ti 3:9, II Ti 1:3; θρησκεία, Ja 1:27.†
purity, cleanness: c. gen., He 9:13.†
a chair, seat: Mt 21:12, Mk 11:16; of teachers, Mt 23:2.†
to sit down, sit: Jo 20:12; seq. ἐν, Mt 26:55, Lk 2:46, Jo 11:20, Ac 6:15; seq. ἐπί, c. gen., Ac 20:9; id. c. dat., Jo 4:6 (cf. παρα-καθέζ-, κάθημαι).†; καθ ̓ εἷς, v.s. (εἷς.)
successively, in order: Lk 1:3, Ac 11:4 18:23; τῶν κ.. (those that succeeded him), Ac 3:24.; after­wards: ἐν τῷ κ. (sc. χρόνῳ), Lk 8:1.†

to sleep: Mt 8:24 9:24 13:25 25:5 26:46, 43 26:45, Mk 4:27, 38 5:39 14:37, 40-41, Lk 8:52 22:46, I Th 5:7. Metaph.,; of death (as Ps, Da, ll. c.): I Th 5:10 (cf. Mt 9:24, Mk 5:39, Lk 8:52, and v. Swete, Mk., l.c); of moral and spiritual insensibility: Mk 13:36, Eph 5:14, I Th 5:6.†
prop., a guide.; a master, teacher (MGr. professor): Mt 23:16.†
to come down, come to.; to be fit, proper: impers., c. acc et inf., Ac 22:22 (on the tense, v. Bl., § 63, 4); τὰ μὴ καθήκοντα, Ro 1:28.†

in cl. pres. and impf. only (prop. pf. and plpf. of καθέζομαι; cf. Bl., § 24), in LXX and NT fut. also, to sit, be seated: Mt 11:16 22:44 (LXX), Mk 2:6, Jo 6:3, Ac 2:2, Ja 2:3 (on the vulgar imper. κάθου, v. Kennedy, Sources, 162), Re 4:3, al.; seq. prep. c. acc, ἐπί, Mt 9:9, Mk 2:14, Jo 12:16; παρά, Mt 13:1, Mk 10:46; περί, Mk 3:32, 34; πρός, Lk 22:56; ὑπό, Ja 2:3; εἰς, Mk 13:3; μετά, c. gen. pers., Mt 26:58; ἐκ δεξιῶν, Mt 22:44; ἐπάνω, c. gen., Mt 28:2; ἀπέναντι, c. gen., Mt 27:61; ἐπί, c. dat., Ac 3:10; id. c. gen., Ac 8:28; ἐκεῖ, Mt 15:29; pleonastic (M, Pr., 230, 241; Dalman, Words, 22), Mt 13:2, Ac 23:3, Re 18:7; metaph., Mt 4:16, Lk 1:79 (LXX); of one's domicile (Ne 11:6, Si 50:26; Hdt., v, 63), Lk 21:31, Ac 2:2, Re 14:6 (cf. συν-κάθημαι)
daily (MGr. καθημερνός): Ac 6:1.†

causal, to make to sit down, set, appoint: Ac 2:30, I Co 6:4, Eph 1:20. Intrans., to sit down, be seated, sit: Mt 5:1, Mk 9:35, Lk 7:15, Jo 8:2, al.; c. inf. tel., I Co 10:7; seq. εἰς, II Th 2:4; ἐπί, c. acc, Mk 11:2, Jo 12:14; id. c. gen., Jo 19:13, Ac 12:21; ὧδε, Mk 14:32; αὐτοῦ, Mt 26:36; ἐν δεξιᾷ, He 1:3; ἐκ δεξιῶν, Mt 20:21, 23; ἐν, Re 3:21; καθίσας pleonastic (M, Pr 14:1-35; Dalman, Words, 22), Mt 13:48, Lk 5:3 14:31 16:6; of settling in a place (ἐς χωρίον, Thuc., iv, 93), seq. ἐν, Lk 24:49 (cf. ἀνα-, ἐπι-, παρα-, περι-, συν-καθίζω)
to send or let down: seq. εἰς, Lk 5:19; διά, c. gen., ib., Ac 9:25; ptcp., seq. ἐπί, c. gen., Ac 10:11; ἐκ, Ac 11:5.†

to set down; to bring down to a place (Hom., Xen., al.; II Ch 28:15, I Ki 5:3): Ac 17:15. to set in order, appoint, make, constitute: Tit 1:5, II Pe 1:8; c. dupl. acc, κριτήν, Lk 12:14; ἡγούμενον, Ac 7:10; ἄρχοντα, Ac 7:27, 35 (LXX); ἀρχιερεῖς, He 7:28; seq. ἐπί, c. gen., Mt 24:45 25:21, 23, Lk 12:42, Ac 6:3; id. c. dat., Mt 24:47, Lk 12:44; id. c. acc, He 2:7 (LXX) (WH, R, mg. omit); pass. (v. Mayor, Ja., 115 f.), Ro 5:19, Ja 3:6 4:4; seq. εἰς c. inf., He 8:3; τὰ πρὸς τ. θεόν, He 5:1 (cf. ἀντι-, ἀπο-καθίστημι). †
as, according as: Ro 8:26, II Co 8:12, I Pe 4:13.†
on the whole, in general: μή κ., not at all, Ac 4:18.†
to arm fully: pass., Lk 11:21.†
to look down.; to discern clearly: Ro 1:20.†
in dl., according as, just as (Ex, l.c.): Ac 2:45 4:35.; In late Gk. = διότι (Tob, l.c.), because: Lk 1:7 19:9, Ac 2:24 17:31.†

according as, even as, just as, as: Lk 1:2 (v.s. καθά), 24:39, Jo 5:23, Ac 7:48, I Co 8:2, Ga 3:6, al.; seq. οὕτως, Lk 11:30, Jo 3:14, II Co 1:5, Col 3:13, I Jo 2:6, al.; seq. καί, Jo 15:9, I Co 15:49, I Jo 2:18, al.; οὕτως . . . κ., Lk 24:24; id. with ellipsis of οὕτως, Mt 21:6, Mk 16:7, Ro 1:13, al.; with other elliptical constructions, Jo 6:58 17:21, 22 Ac 15:8, I Th 2:13, I Ti 1:3, I Jo 3:2, 3 12; καθὼς γέγραπται (Deiss., BS, 249), Mt 26:24, Mk 9:13, Ro 1:17, al.; introducing subst. clause as object of verb (as in Heb.), Mt 21:6, Mk 11:6, Lk 5:14, al.; after verbs of speaking, Ac 15:14; of proportion and degree, Mk 4:33, I Co 12:11, 18 al.; of time (Ne 5:6, II Mac 1:31), Ac 7:17.
even as: II Co 3:8 (WH, mg.), He 5:4.†

and Copulative. Connecting single words; in general: Mt 2:18, 16:1, Mk 2:15, Lk 8:15, He 1:1, al. mult.; repeated before each of the terms in a series, Mt 23:23, Lk 14:21, Ro 7:12, 9:4, al. connecting numerals (WM, §37, 4): Jo 2:20, Ac 13:20; joining terms which are not mutually exclusive, as the part with the whole: Mt 8:33, 26:59, Mk 16:17, Ac 5:29, al. Connecting clauses and sentences: Mt 3:12, Ac 5:21, al. mult.; esp. where, after the simplicity of the popular language, sentences are paratactically joined (WM, §60, 3; M, Pr., 12; Deiss., LAE, 128ff.): Mt 1:21, 7:25, Mk 9:5, Jo 10:3, al.; joining affirmative to negative sentences: Lk 3:14, Jo 4:11, IIIJo 10; consecutive, and so: Mt 5:1, 23:32, He 3:19, al.; after imperatives, Mt 4:19, Lk 7:7, al.; = καίτοι, and yet: Mt 3:14, 6:26, Mk 12:12, Lk 18:7 (Field, Notes, 72), I Co 5:2, al.; beginning an apodosis (= Heb. וְ; so sometimes δέ in cl.), then: Lk 2:21, 7:12, Ac 1:10; beginning a question (WM, §53, 3a): Mk 10:26, Lk 10:29, Jo 9:36. Epexegetic, and, and indeed, namely (WM, §53, 3c): Lk 3:18, Jo 1:16, Ac 23:6, Ro 1:5, I Co 3:5, al. In transition: Mt 4:23, Mk 5:1, 21, Jo 1:19, al.; so, Hebraistically, καὶ ἐγένετο (וַי:הִי; also ἐγένετο δέ), Mk 1:9 (cf. Lk 5:1; V. Burton, §§357-60; M, Pr., 14, 16). καὶ . . . καί, both . . . and (for τε . . . καί, v.s. τε); connecting single words: Mt 10:28, Mk 4:41, Ro 11:33, al.; clauses and sentences: Mk 9:13, Jo 7:28, I Co 1:22, al. Adjunctive, also, even, still: Mt 5:39, 40; Mk 2:28, al. mult.; esp. c. pron., adv., etc., Mt 20:4, Jo 7:47, al; ὡς κ., Ac 11:17; καθὼς κ., Ro 15:7; οὑτω κ., Ro 6:11; διὸ κ., Lk 1:35; ὁ κ. (Deiss., BS, 313ff.), Ac 13:9; pleonastically, μετὰ κ.. (Bl., §77, 7; Deiss., BS, 265f,), Phl 4:3; τί κ., 1 Co 15:29; ἀλλὰ κ., Lk 14:22, Jo 5:18, al.; καίγε (M, Pr., 230; Burton, §437), Ac 17:27; καίπερ, He 5:8; κ. ἐάν, v.s. ἐάν.
Caiaphas (on the name, v. Exp. Times, x, 185): Mt 26:3, 57, Lk 3:2, Jo 11:4 18:13-14, 24 18:28 Ac 4:6.†; Καΐφας, for Καιάφας, q.v.: Lk 3:2 (L)
From and G1065
indecl.; Cain: He 11:4, I Jn 3:12, Ju 11.†
Cainam, Cainan; son of Enos (Ge 5:9): Lk 3:37.; Son of Arphaxad (Ge 10:24 (LXX): Lk 3:36.†

of that which is unused or unaccustomed, new in respect to form or quality, fresh, unused, novel: opp. to παλαιός, ἀρχαῖος, Mt 9:17 13:52, Mk 2:21-22 Lk 5:36, 38, II Co 5:17, Eph 4:24; πλήρωμα, Mk 2:21; μνημεῖον, Mt 27:60, Jo 19:41; διαθήκη (T, WH, R, txt., omit), Lk 22:20, I Co 11:25, II Co 3:6, He 8:8 (LXX), He 8:13 9:15; οὐρανοί, γῆ, II Pe 3:13, Re 21:1 (LXX) Ἰερουσαλήμ, Re 3:12 21:2; ἄνθρωπος, Eph 2:15 (cf. Ez 18:31); πάντα, Re 21:5; γέννημα τ. ἀμπέλου, Mt 26:29, Mk 14:25; διδαχή, Mk 1:27, Ac 17:19; ἐντολή, Jo 13:34, I Jn 2:7-8, II Jn 5; ὄνομα, Re 2:17 (LXX); ᾠδή, Re 5:9 14:3 (of. Ps 144:9); κτίσις, II Co 5:17, Ga 6:15; γλῶσσαι, Mk 16:17; compar., Ac 17:21.†
novelty (Thuc., Isocr., LS, s.v.).; freshness, newness: ἐν κ. ζωῆς (v. Lft., Notes, 296), Ro 6:4; ἐν κ. πνεύματος, Ro 7:6.†
although: c. ptcp., Phl 3:4, He 5:8 7:5 12:17, II Pe 1:12.†

due measure, fitness, proportion (Eur., Xen., al.).; Of Time (cl. also) in the sense of a fixed and definite period, time, season (Kennedy, Sources, 153): Mt 11:25, Mk 1:15, Lk 21:8, Ro 13:11, Eph 6:18, He 11:15, I Pe 1:5 1:11 Re 1:3, al.; c. gen., πειρασμοῦ Lk 8:13; τ. καρπῶν, Mt 21:34; σύκων, Mk 11:13; pl., Mt 21:41; χρόνοι ἢ (καὶ) κ., Ac 1:7, I Th 5:1; ἐθνῶν, Lk 21:24; of opportune or seasonable time, Ac 24:25, Ga 6:10, Eph 5:16, Col 4:5; c. inf., He 11:15; ὁ κ. οὗτος, Mk 10:30, Lk 18:30; ὁ νῦν κ. (Dalman, Words, 148), Ro 8:18; ὁ κ. ὁ ἐμός, Jo 7:6; κ. δεκτῲ, II Co 6:2 (LXX); δουλεύειν τῷ κ., Ro 12:11, R, mg.; τ. σημεῖα τῶν κ., Mt 16:3; adverbial usages: ἐν κ., Mt 24:45, I Pe 5:6 (cf. καιρῷ, Lk 20:10; τῷ κ., Mk 12:2); ἄχρι καιροῦ, Lk 4:13; πρὸς καιρόν, Lk 8:13, I Co 7:5; κατὰ καιρόν, Ro 5:6; πρὸ καιροῦ, Mt 8:29
Cæsar: Mt 22:17, Lk 2:1, Jo 19:12, Ac 25:8 ff., al
Cæsarea; Cæsarea Philippi, at the foot of Lebanon: Mt 16:13, Mk 8:27.; Cæsarea of Palestine, on the sea-coast: Ac 8:4 9:30 10:1, 24 11:11 12:19 18:22 21:8, 16 23:23, 33 25:1, 4 25:6, 13.†
concessive particle, [in LXX: IV Mac 2:6 * ;]; and yet, although: Ac 14:17; c. ptcp., He 4:3.†
strengthened form of καίτοι, q.v. (and v.s. γε): Jo 4:2.†

to kindle, light: c. acc, λύχνον, Mt 5:15; pass., to be lighted, to burn: ptcp., Lk 12:35, Re 4:5 8:10 19:20; πυρί He 12:18, Re 8:8 21:8; metaph., Lk 24:32, Jo 5:35.; to burn, destroy by fire: pass., Jo 15:6, I Co 13:3.†
of place, and from thence, and thence: Mk 9:30, Lk 11:53, Ac 7:4 14:26 16:12 20:15 21:1 27:4 28:15.†

badness in quality (opp. to ἀρετή, excellence).; wickedness, depravity, malignity: Ac 8:22, Ro 1:29, I Co 5:8 14:20, Eph 4:31, Col 3:8, Tit 3:3, Ja 1:21, I Pe 2:1 2:16.; In late Gk., evil, trouble, affliction (Am 3:6, I Ki 6:9, Ec 7:15, Si 19:6, al.): Mt 6:34 (cf. MM, Exp., xv).†
malignity, malevolence: Ro 1:29 (Cremer, 329).†
to speak ill of, revile, abuse: c. acc pers., Mt 15:4, Mk 7:10 (LXX) Mk 9:39; c. acc rei, Ac 19:9.†
distress, affliction: Ja 5:10.†
to suffer evil, endure Affliction: II Ti 2:9 4:5, Ja 5:13.†
to do harm, to do evil: Mk 3:4, Lk 6:9, I Pe 3:17, III Jn 11 (Cremer, 329).†
doing evil; as susbt., an evil-doer: I Pe 2:12 2:14 4:15.†

in general, opp. to ἀγαθός, καλός, in various senses, bad, mean, base, worthless (cl.). In ethical sense, base, evil, wicked: of persons, Mt 21:41 24:48, Phl 3:2, Re 2:2; διαλογισμοί, Mk 7:21; ὁμιλίαι, I Co 15:33; ἐπιθυμία (Pr 12:12), Col 3:5; ἔργον, Ro 13:3; neut., κακόν, τὸ κ., evil: Jo 18:23, Ac 23:9, Ro 7:21 14:20 16:19, I Co 13:5, He 5:14, I Pe 3:10-11, III Jn 11; pl., Ro 1:30, I Co 10:6, I Ti 6:10, Ja 1:13; κ. (τὸ, τὰ κ.) ποιεῖν (πράσσειν), Mt 27:23, Mk 15:14, Lk 23:22, Jo 18:30, Ro 3:8 7:19 13:4, II Co 13:7, I Pe 3:12; κατεργάζεσθαι, Ro 2:9; of wrongs inflicted, Ac 9:13, Ro 12:17, 21 13:10, I Th 5:15, II Ti 4:14, I Pe 3:9. pernicious, harmful, evil: Lk 16:25, Ac 16:28 28:5, Tit 1:12, Ja 3:8, Re 16:2 (Cremer, 325, 741). †
a malefactor, criminal: Lk 23:32-33, 39, II Ti 2:9.†
to ill-treat, hurt, torment: pass. ptcp., He 11:37 13:3.†
to ill-treat, afflict, distress: c. acc pers., Ac 7:6, 19 12:1 18:10, I Pe 3:13.; (not in cl.), to embitter (Ps 106:32): Ac 14:2,†

badly, ill; in physical sense: κ. ἔχειν, to be ill, Mt 4:24 8:16 9:12 14:35 17:15, Mk 1:32, 34 2:17 6:55 5:31 7:2; πάσχειν, Mt 17:15 (WH, mg.); δαιμονίζεσθαι, Mt 15:22; κακοὺς κ. ἀπολέσει (as freq. in cl., v. LS, s.v.; MM, Exp., xv), evil that they are, he will evilly, etc., Mt 21:41; in moral sense, wrongly (I Mac 7:42, 4Mac, l.c., al.): κ. λαλεῖν, Jo 18:23; είπεῖν, c. acc pers., Ac 23:5; αἰτεῖσθαι, Ja 4:8,†
ill-treatment: Ac 7:34 (LXX),†
a stalk of corn, stubble: I Co 3:12.†

a reed: Mt 11:7 12:20 (LXX) Lk 7:24; hence, acc, to its various uses,; a reed-pipe, flute; a reed-staff, staff (cf. IV Ki 18:21, ῥάβδος καλαμίνη): Mt 27:29-30, 48, Mk 15:19, 36; a measuring reed or rod (Ez, l.c.): Re 11:1 21:15-16; a writing reed, a pen: III Jn 13 (cf. Milligan, NTD, 9, 7).†

to call, summon: c. acc. pers., Mt 20:8 25:14, Mk 3:31, Lk 19:13, Ac 4:18; seq. ἐκ, Mt 2:15 (LXX); metaph., I Pe 2:9. to call to one's house, invite: Lk 14:16, I Co 10:27, Re 19:9; εἰς τ. γάμους, Mt 22:3, 9 Lk 14:8, 9 Jo 2:2; ὁ καλέσας, Lk 7:39; οἱ κεκλημένοι, Mt 22:8; metaph., of inviting to partake of the blessings of the kingdom of God (Dalman, Words, 118f.): Ro 8:30 9:24, 25 I Co 7:17, 18; seq. εἰς, I Co 1:9, I Th 2:12, I Ti 6:12; ὁ καλῶν (καλέσας), of God, Ga 1:6 5:8, I Th 5:24, I Pe 1:15, II Pe 1:3; οἱ κεκλκλημένοι, He 9:15; seq. ἐν (ἐπί), I Co 7:15, Ga 5:13, Eph 4:4, I Th 4:7; κλήσει, Eph 4:1, II Ti 1:9. to call, name call by name: pass., Mt 2:23, Lk 1:32, al.; καλούμενος, Lk 7:11, Ac 7:58, al.; ὁ κ. (Deiss., BS, 210), Lk 6:15 22:3 23:33, Ac 10:1, Re 12:9, al.; c. pred nom., Mt 5:9, Lk 1:35, Ro 9:26, Ja 2:23, I Jo 3:1. (Cf. ἀντι-, ἐν-, εἰσ- (-μαι), ἐπι-, μετα-, παρα-, συν-παρα-, προ-, προσ-, συν-καλέω.)
the garden olive (opp. to ἀγριέλ-): Ro 11:24.†
compar. of καλός, v.s. καλῶς
a teacher of that which is good: Tit 2:3.†
Fair Havens, a harbour in Crete: Ac 27:8.†
to do well, act honourably: II Th 3:13 (cf. Ga 6:9 τὸ καλὸν π.).†

primarily, of outward form ("related to . . . ἀγαθός as the appearance to the essence," Cremer, 339), fair, beautiful: λίθοι (BV, goodly), Lk 21:5. In reference to use, of that which is well adapted to its ends, good, excellent: of fish, τ. καλά (opp. to σαπρά), Mt 13:48; σπέρμα, Mt 13:24, 27, 37, 38; καρπός, Mt 3:10 7:17-19 12:33, Lk 3:9 [WH] 6:43; δένδρον (opp. to σαρπόν), Mt 12:33, Lk 6:43; γῆ, Mt 13:8, 23 Mk 4:8, 20 Lk 8:15; τ. ἅλας, Mk 9:50, Lk 14:34; ὁ νόμος, Ro 7:16, I Ti 1:8; διδασκαλία, I Ti 4:6; καρδία κ. καὶ ἀγαθή, Lk 8:15; παραθήκη, II Ti 1:14; μέτρον, Lk 6:38; βαθμός, I Ti 3:13; θεμέλιος, I Ti 6:19; τὸ κ., I Th 5:21; μαργαρίται, Mt 13:45; οἶνος, Jo 2:10; ποιμήν, Jo 10:11, 14; διάκονος, I Ti 4:6; οἰκονόμος, I Pe 4:10; στρατιώτης, II Ti 2:3; στρατεία, I Ti 1:18; ἀγών, I Ti 6:12, II Ti 4:7; ὁμολογία, I Ti 6:12, 13; ἔργον, Mt 26:10, Mk 14:6, Jo 10:33, I Ti 3:1; pl., Jo 10:32; καλόν, c. inf. et dat., Mt 18:8, 9 I Co 7:1, 26 9:15; id. c. acc. et inf., Mt 17:4, Mk 9:5, 43, 45, 47, Lk 9:33, He 13:9; seq. εἰ, Mt 26:24, Mk 9:42 14:21; ἐάν, I Co 7:8. Ethically, good, in the sense of right, fair, noble, honourable: Ga 4:18, He 5:14; ἔργα, Mt 5:16, I Ti 5:10, 25 6:18, Tit 2:7, 14 3:8, 14 (Field, Notes, 223f.), He 10:24, I Pe 2:12; ἀναστροφή, Ja 3:13, I Pe 2:12; συνείδησις, He 13:18; seq. ἐνώπιον, Ro 12:17, II Co 8:21, I Ti 2:3; το] κ. ποιεῖν (κατεργάζεσθαι), Ro 7:18, 21 II Co 13:7, Ga 6:9, Ja 4:17; καλόν ἐστιν, c. inf., Mt 15:26 (T, ἔξεστιν), Mk 7:27, Ro 14:21, Ga 4:18; μαρτυρία, I Ti 3:7; ὄνομα, Ja 2:7; καύχημα, I Co 5:6 (neg.); θεοῦ ῥῆμα, He 6:5. κ. does not occur in Re.†
a covering, veil: II Co 3:13-16 †

in cl., rare in prose,; to cover: c. acc pers., Lk 23:30; c. acc rei et dat., Lk 8:16; pass., Mt 8:24; metaph., to veil, conceal: pf. ptcp. pass., Mt 10:26, II Co 4:3; of the forgiveness of sins (cf. Ps 32:5 85:2; DB, ii, 56b): I Pe 4:8, Ja 5:20; (v.l. for καιομένη, WH, mg., Lk 24:32).†

finely, rightly, well: Lk 6:48, I Co 14:17, Ga 4:17 5:7, Ja 2:3; λέγειν, λαλεῖν, etc., Mt 15:7, Mk 7:6 12:28, Lk 6:26 20:39, Jo 4:17 8:48 13:13 18:23, Ac 28:25; as exclamation of approval, Mk 12:32, Ro 11:20; κ. ποιεῖν, Mt 12:12, I Co 7:37-38 Ja 2:8, 19; c. dat. pers. (cl. acc; WM, § 32, 1 β), Lk 6:27; c. acc rei, Mk 7:37; c. ptcp., Ac 10:33 (M, Pr., 131), Phl 4:14, II Pe 1:19, III Jn 6; προϊστάναι (-ασθαι), I Ti 3:4 3:12 5:17; διακονεῖν, I Ti 3:13; ἀνατρέφεσθαι, He 13:18; ironically, Mk 7:9, II Co 11:4 (but v. CGT, in l); κ. ἔχειν, to be well: Mk 16:18. Compar., κάλλιον (for superl., B1., § 44, 3), very well: Ac 25:10.†
camel: Mt 3:4, Mk 1:6; in proverbs, Mt 19:24 23:24, Mk 10:25, Lk 18:25 (on the v.l. κάμιλος, v. WH, Notes, 151).†; κάμιλος, v.s. κάμηλος, and cf. Thayer; LS, s.v
to shut the eyes: τ. ὀφθαλμούς, Mt 13:15, Ac 28:27 (Isa, l.c.).†
to work; hence, from the effect of continued work,; to be weary: He 12:3; to be sick: Ja 5:15.†
to bend, bow: c. acc rei, γόνυ, τὰ γ.; c. dat. pers., τῇ Βάαλ, Ro 11:4 (LXX); πρὸς τ. πατέρα, Eph 3:14; by meton., πᾶν γόνυ for πᾶς, Ro 14:11 (LXX) Phl 2:10 (cf. ἀνα-, συν-κάμπτω).†

by crasis for καὶ ἄν (= ἐάν; WH, App., 145b; Thayer, s.v.), c. subjunc.,; and if: Mk 16:18 Lk 12:38, Jo 8:55, I Co 13:2-3, Ja 5:15; c. ellips., Lk 13:9.; Concessive, even if: Mt 21:21 26:35, Jo 8:14 10:38 11:25, He 12:20.; As intensive of simple καί (M, Pr., 167; WM, 730; Jannaris, Gr., 598), even, at least: Mk 5:28 6:56, Ac 5:15, II Co 11:16.†
indecl.,; Cana, of Galilee: Jo 2:1, 11 4:46 21:2.†
a Cananæan or Zealot (cf. ζηλωτής): Mt 10:4, Mk 3:18 (Rec. -νίτης).†
Candace: Ac 8:27.†

a rod or bar (Jth, l.c.).; a measuring rule; hence, metaph,; a rule or standard: Ga 6:16.; a limit (RV, province): II Co 10:13-16. (For the history of the word and esp. its later meanings, v. Westc., Canon, App. A; cf. also MM, Exp., xv; Cremer, 744.)†
to make a trade of (RV, mg., make merchandise of), or perhaps (cf. Isa, l.c.) to corrupt (RV, tit.): II Co 2:17.†
Cappadocia, a province of Asia Minor: Ac 2:9, I Pe 1:1.†

the heart, the bodily organ which is regarded as the seat of life ( II Ki 18:14, IV Ki 9:24, al.). In a psychological sense, the seat of man's collective energies, the focus of personal life, the seat of the rational as well as the emotional and volitional elements in human life, hence that wherein lies the moral and religious condition of the man (DB, ii, 317f.; DGG, ii, 344a); of the seat of physical life ( Jg 19:5, Ps 101 (102):5 103 (104):15): Ac 14:17, Ja 5:5; of the seat of spiritual life: Mt 5:8, Mk 7:19, Lk 1:51, Ac 5:3, Ro 10:9, 10 Eph 6:5, al.; pl., Mt 9:4, Mk 2:6, al.; opp. to στόμα, χείλεα, πρόσωπον, Mt 15:8, Mk 7:6, Ro 10:8, 9 II Co 5:12; περιτομὴ καρδίας, Ro 2:29; ἐκ κ., Ro 6:17, I Pe 1:22; ἀπὸ τῶν κ., Mt 18:35; ἐν ὅλῃ (ἐξ ὅλης), Mt 22:37, Mk 12:30 (LXX); γινώσκειν (ἐρευνᾶν, δοκιμάζειν) τὰς κ., Lk 16:15, Ro 8:27, I Th 2:4; to think, etc., ἐν τ. κ., Mt 9:4, Mk 2:6, Lk 12:45, Ro 10:6; συνιέναι (νοεῖν) τῇ κ., Mt 13:15, Jo 12:40; ἐπαχύνθη ἡ κ., Mt 13:15 (LXX); πωροῦν τὴν κ., Jo 12:40; κ. εὐθεῖα, Ac 8:21; πονηρά, He 3:12; ἀμετανόητος, Ro 2:5; εἶναι (ἔχειν) ἐν τῇ κ., II Co 7:3, Phl 1:7; ὀδύνη τῇ κ., Ro 9:2. Of the central or innermost part of anything (of the pith of wood, Arist.): τ. γῆς, Mt 12:40 (Cremer, 343ff.).
knower of hearts: Ac 1:24 15:8.†

fruit: of trees, Mt 12:33 21:19, Mk 11:14, Lk 6:44 13:6-7; of vines, Mt 21:34, Mk 12:2, Lk 20:10, I Co 9:7; of fields, Mk 4:29, Lk 12:17, II Ti 2:6, Ja 5:7; βλαστάνειν, Ja 5:18; ποιεῖν (cf. Heb. פְּרִי עָשָׂה), Mt 3:10 7:17-19 13:26, Lk 3:9 6:43 8:8 13:9, Re 22:2; διδόναι, Mt 13:8, Mk 4:7-8; φέρειν, Mt 7:18, Jo 12:24 15:2, 4-5 15:8, 16; ἀποδιδόναι, Mt 21:41, Re 22:2; ὁ κ. τ. κοιλίας (בֶּטֶן פְּרִי, De 28:4), Lk 1:42; τ. ὀσφύος (Ge 30:2, al.), Ac 2:30.; Metaph.,; of works, deeds: Mt 3:8 7:16, 20 21:43, Lk 3:8, Jo 15:3, 16; τ. πνεύματος, Ga 5:22; τ. φωτός, Eph 5:9; τ. δικαιοσύνης, Phl 1:11; σφραγίζεσθαι τὸν κ. (Deiss., BS, 238 f.), Ro 15:28; κ. ἀγαθοί, Ja 3:17; of advantage, profit: Phl 1:22 4:17; ἔχειν, Ro 1:13 6:21-22. συνάγειν, Jo 4:36; κ. τ. δικαιοσύνης, He 12:11, Ja 3:18; of praise, καρπὸν χειλέων (Ho 14:2, al.; cf. Æsch., Eum., 830): He 13:15.†
Carpus: II Ti 4:13.†
to bear fruit: χόρτον, Mk 4:28 (cf. Wis, l.c.). Metaph., of conduct: Mt 13:23, Mk 4:20, Lk 8:15, Ro 7:4-5, Col 1:10; mid., Col 1:6.†
fruitful: Ac 14:17.†
to be steadfast, patient: He 11:27 (cf. προσ-καρτερέω).†
a small dry stalk, a twig; metaph., of a minor fault: Mt 7:3-5, Lk 6:41-42.†

down, downwards. C. gen. (WM, §47, k; Bl., §42, 2). C. gen. rei, in local sense; down, down from: Mt 8:32, Mk 5:13, Lk 8:33, I Co 11:4; throughout (late usage; Bl, l.c.): κ. ὅλης κ.τ.λ., Lk 4:14 23:5, Ac 9:31 10:37; in a peculiar adjectival phrase: ἡ κ. βάθους, deep or extreme poverty, II Co 8:2. C. gen. pers., usually in hostile sense; against (in cl. only after verbs of speaking, witnessing, etc.): opp. to ὑπέρ, Mk 9:40; μετά, Mt 12:30; after ἐπιθυμεῖν, Ga 5:17; λαλεῖν, Ac 6:13; διδάσκειν, Ac 21:28; ψεύδεσθαι, Ja 3:14; after verbs of accusing, etc., Mt 5:23, Lk 23:14, Ro 8:33, al.; verbs of fighting, prevailing, etc., Mt 10:35, Ac 14:2, I Co 4:6, al.; of swearing, by: όμνυμι κ. (BL, §34, 1), He 6:13,16, cf. Mt 26:63. C. acc. (WM, §49d; BL, §42, 2). Of motion or direction; through, throughout: Lk 8:39 9:6 10:4, Ac 8:1, 36 al.; to, towards, over against: Lk 10:32 (Field, Notes, 62), Ac 2:1o 16:7, Ga 2:11, Phl 3:14, al.; in adverbial phrases, at, in, by, of: κατ’ οἶκον, at home, Ac 2:46; κατ’ ἰδίαν (v.s. ἴδιος); καθ’ ἑαυτόν, Ac 28:16, Ro 14:22, Ja 2:17; c. pron. pers., Ac 17:28 18:15, Ro 1:15, Eph 1:15, al. Of time, at, during, about: Ac 8:26 12:1 19:23, Ro 9:9 He 1:10, al. Distributive; of place: κ. τόποὐς, Mt 24:7, al.; κ. πόλιν, Lk 8:1, 4 al.; κ. ἐκκλησίαν, Ac 14:23. of time: κ. ἔτος, Lk 2:41; ἑορτήν, Mt 27:15, al.; of numbers, etc.: καθ’ ἕνα πάντες, I Co 14:31 (on καθ’ εἷς, v.s. εἷς); κ. ἑκατόν, Mk 6:40; κ. μέρος, He 9:5; κ. ὄνομα, Jo 10:3. Of fitness, reference, conformity, etc.; in relation to, concerning: Ro 1:3, 4 7:22 9:3, 5, I Co 12:6 10:18, Phl 1:12; κ. πάντα, Ac 17:22, Col 3:20, 22 He 2:17 4:15; according to, after, like: Mk 7:5, Lk 2:27, 29 Jo 7:24 Ro 8:4 14:15, Eph 2:2, Col 2:8, Ja 2:8, al. In composition, κ. denotes, down, down from (καταβαίνω), etc.), hence, metaph.; victory or rule over (καταδουλόω, -κυριεύω, etc.); "perfective" action (M, Pr., 111ff.). under (κατακαλύπτω), etc.). in succession (καθεξῆς). after, behind (καταλείπω). Hostility, against (καταλαλέω).

to go or come down, descend.; Of persons: Mt 3:16 24:17, Lk 2:51 6:17 10:31 17:31 19:5-6, Jo 4:47, 49 4:51 5:7, Ac 7:34 8:15 10:20 20:10 23:10 24:1, 22 Eph 4:10. seq. ἀπό, Mt 8:1 14:29 27:40, 42 Mk 3:22 15:30, Lk 10:30, Jo 6:38, Ac 25:7, I Th 4:16; ἐκ, Mt 17:9; ἐκ τ. οὐρανοῦ, Mt 28:2, Mk 9:9, Jo 1:32 3:13 6:33, 41-42 6:50-51, 58 Re 10:1 18:1 20:1; εἰς, Mk 1:10, Lk 10:30 18:14, Jo 2:12, Ac 7:15 8:38 14:25 16:8 18:22 25:6, Ro 10:7, Eph 4:9; ἐπί, c. acc loc., Jo 6:16; c. acc pers., Lk 3:22, Jo 1:33, 51; ἐν, Jo 5:4; πρός, c. acc pers., Ac 10:21 14:11, Re 12:12.; Of things: σκεῦος, Ac 10:11 11:5; βροχή, Mt 7:25, 27; λαῖλαψ, Lk 8:23; seq. ἀπό, Lk 9:54, Ac 8:26, Ja 1:17; ἐπὶ τ. γῆν, Lk 22:44 (WH, R, mg., reject); ἐκ τ. οὐρανοῦ seq. ἀπό, Re 3:12 21:2, 10; id. seq. εἰς, Re 13:13; ἐπί, c. acc pers., Re 16:21. Fig., κ. ἕως ᾄδον, Mt 11:23, Lk 10:15, WH, txt., Tr., mg. (καταβιβασθήση, T, WH, mg., RV), (cf. συν-καταβαίνω).†
to cast down, prostrate: metaph., pass., II Co 4:9.; to put down, lay down: metaph., mid., c. acc, θεμέλιον, He 6:1.†
to weigh down: metaph., c. acc pers., II Co 12:16.†
= καταβαρέω: pass., Pres. ptcp., Mk 14:40.†
to cause to go down, cast down: pass., ἕως ᾅδου, Mt 11:23 (WH, R, mg.), Lk 10:15 (WH, mg.).†

a laying down: εἰς κ. σπέρματος, He 11:11 (EV, to conceive seed).; a foundation (of a house, ii Mac, l.c.): metaph., ἀπὸ κ. κόσμου, Mt 13:35 (LXX) (om. ἀπὸ κ. κόσμου, WH, R, mg.), Mt 25:34, Lk 11:50, He 4:3 9:26, Re 13:8 17:8; πρὸ κ. κόσμου, Jo 17:24, Eph 1:4, I Pe 1:20.†
to give judg­ment against, condemn (v. Field, Notes, 196; Abbott, Essays, 104 f.): Col 2:18.†
a proclaimer, herald (in Inscr., κ. ἀγώνων, Deiss., LAE, 97): c. gen. obj., Ac 17:18.†

to pro­claim, declare: c. acc rei, Ac 3:24 16:21 17:23; τ. ἀνάστασιν, Ac 4:2; τ. λόγον τοῦ Θ., τ. Κ., Ac 13:5 15:36; ὁδὸν σωτηρίας, Ac 16:17; φῶς, Ac 26:23; τ. μυστήριον τοῦ Θ., I Co 2:1; τ. εὐαγγέλιον, I Co 9:14; τ. θάνατον τοῦ Κ., I Co 11:26; pass., ἄφεσις, Ac 13:33; ὁ λόγος τοῦ Θ., Ac 17:13; ἡ πίστις ὑμῶν, Ro 1:8; c. acc pers., of Christ, ὅν, Ac 17:3, Col 1:28; τ. Χριστόν, Phl 1:17; pass., Phl 1:18.; to denounce (Xen., al.); (for comparison with ἀγγέλλω, ἀναγ-, ἀπαγ-, v. Westc. on I Jn 1:5; and cf. προ-καταγγέλλω).†
to deride, laugh scornfully at: c. gen. pers., Mt 9:24, Mk 5:40, Lk 8:53.†
to blame, condemn: c. gen. pers., I Jn 3:20-21; pass., κατεγνωσμένος ἦν (RV, he stood condemned, v. Ellie., in l; but cf. Field, Notes, 188): Ga 2:11.†
to break: c. acc rei, Mt 12:20 (LXX), Jo 19:31-33.†
to bring down: c. acc pers., Ac 22:30, Ro 10:6; id. seq. εἰς, Ac 9:30 23:15, 20 23:28; as nautical term, to bring to land: τ. πλοῖον ἐπὶ τ. γῆν, Lk 5:11; pass., seq. εἰς, Ac 27:3 2:12.†
to struggle against.; to conquer, overcome: He 11:33.†
to bind up: τ. τραύματα (cf. Si 27:21), Lk 10:34.†
quite manifest, evident: He 7:15.†

to pass sentence upon, condemn; in cl., c. gen. pers. (acc rei); in late writers (so LXX), c. acc pers. (θανάτῳ, Wis, l.c.): Mt 12:7, Ja 5:6; absol. (as Plat., Legg., 958c), Lk 6:37; pass., Mt 12:37, Lk 6:37.†; δικάζω,; to judge: Lk 6:37 (Tr., mg.; v.s. καταδ-; Cremer, 199).†
sentence, condemnation: Ac 25:15.†
"perfective" compound (M, Pr., 116), to pursue closely, follow up; with hostile intent (Thuc., i, 49, Ge 31:36 al.); with kindly intention (Ps 23:6, I Ki 30:22, cf. Si 27:17): Mk 1:36.†
to enslave: II Co 11:20, Ga 2:4.†
to exercise power over, oppress: c. acc pers. (Xen.; LXX, Mi 2:2, Wi 2:10, al.); c. gen. pers., Ja 2:6 (ὑμᾶς, T); pass., Ac 10:38 (cf. MM, Exp., xv).†
a curse ("perh. somewhat stronger than ἀνάθεμα" Swete, Re., l.c.): Re 22:3 (cf. ἀνάθεμα).†
to curse vehemently: Mt 26:74 (cf. ἀναθεμ-).†

to disgrace, dishonour, put to shame: c. acc rei, I Co 11:4-5; c. acc pers., I Co 1:27 11:22; pass., to be ashamed: Lk 13:17, II Co 7:14 9:4, I Pe 3:16; as in LXX (Ps 22:6 25:2-3, al.), of unfulfilled hopes: Ro 5:5; pass., Ro 9:33 10:11, I Pe 2:6 (LXX).†

to burn up, burn completely: c. acc rei, Mt 13:30 Ac 19:19; pass., I Co 3:15, He 13:11, II Pe 3:10, Re 8:7; seq. πυρί Mt 3:12 13:40, Lk 3:17 (cf. Ex 29:14, al.); ἐν πυρί (De 9:21, al.): Re 17:16 18:8.†
to cover up; mid., to cover or veil oneself: I Co 11:6; τ. κεφαλήν, I Co 11:7.†
to boast against, exult over: c. gen., Ro 11:18, Ja 2:13; seq. κατά, c. gen., Ja 3:14 (T, om. κατά).; seq. ἐν, to glory in (Za., l.c., Je 27:38).†

to lie down.; to lie sick: Mk 1:30 2:4, Jo 5:6, Ac 28:8; seq. ἐπί c. gen., Ac 9:33; id. c. acc, Lk 5:25; ἐν, Jo 5:3.; to recline at meals (cf. ἀνάιειμαι): Mk 14:3, Lk 5:29; seq. ἐν, Mk 2:15, Lk 7:37, I Co 8:10.†
to break up, break in pieces: Mk 6:41, Lk 9:16.†
to shut up:. c. acc pers., seq. ἐν φυλακῇ (-αῖς), Lk 3:20, Ac 26:10.†
Ac 13:19, Rec., = -νομέω, q.v.†
to distribute by lot or as an inheritance (Nu 34:18, Jos 14:1, al.): Ac 13:19.; to receive by inheritance (De 1:38, al.).†
to lay down, make to lie down, esp. for meals: c. acc pers., Lk 9:14-15; mid., to recline at meals: Lk 7:36 24:30; seq. εἰς, Lk 14:8 (cf. Jth, Lc.).†
to inundate, deluge: pass., II Pe 3:6.†
a flood, deluge: Mt 24:38-39 Lk 17:27, II Pe 2:5.†
to follow after: Lk 23:55; c. dat. pers., Ac 16:17.†
to cut up, cut in pieces (cf. Is 27:9, Je 21:7, II Ch 34:7): ἑαυτὸν λίθοις, Mk 5:5.†
to throw over a precipice, cast down head­long: Lk 4:29.†
penalty (RV, condemnation; but cf. Deiss., BS, 264 f.; MM, Exp., xv): Ro 5:16, 18 8:1.†

to give judgment against, condemn: Ro 8:34; c. acc pers., Mk 14:64, Jo 8:10-11; disting. fr. κρίνειν, Ro 2:1, I Co 11:32; seq. θανάτῳ (cl. -ου or -ον), Mt 20:18, Mk 10:33; pass., Mt 27:3, Mk 16:16, Ro 14:23, I Co 11:32, II Pe 2:6. Metaph., of condemning through a good example: Mt 12:41-42, Lk 11:31-32, Ro 8:3, He 11:7 †
condemnation: II Co 3:9 7:3 (cf. Deiss., LAE, 91 f.).†
to gain or exercise dominion (over); absol. (Arist.); c. gen. (Arist., al.): Mt 20:25, Mk 10:42, Ac 19:16, I Pe 5:3.†
to speak evil of, rail at: in cl., c. acc; in LXX,; c. gen.,; seq. κατά, c. gen.; in NT, c. gen. (M, Pr., 65): Ja 4:11, I Pe 2:12; pass., I Pe 3:16,†
evil-speaking, railing: p1., II Co 12:20, I Pe 2:1.†
a railer, defamer: Ro 1:30.†

to lap hold of, seize, appropriate: Mk 9:18; c. acc rei, I Co 9:24, Phl 3:12-13; to overtake: as carrel, of διώκω (Field, Notes, 158 f.), Ro 9:30; ἡ ἡμέρα, I Th 5:4; of evils, Jo 1:5 12:35 (cf. 617 T); hence, to surprise, discover: Jo 8:3-4],; Of mental action, to apprehend, comprehend; so mid., in NT (M, Pr., 158): Eph 3:18; seq. ὅτι, Ac 4:13 10:34; c. acc et inf., Ac 25:25 (MM, Exp., xv).†

to lay down; mid. (in Hom.), to lie down.; to narrate (LXX, ll. c.).; to choose out, hence, to enrol (as of soldiers, Hdt., Thuc., a1., v. LS, s.v.): of widows, pass., I Ti 5:9 (cf. Ellic.; CGT, in l).†
a remnant: Ro 9:27, Rec. (for ὑπόλειμμα, q.v.).†

1, to leave behind, leave: c. acc pers. (rei), Mt 4:13, Mk 12:19, 21, Lk 20:31, Ac 24:27 25:14, He 11:27; of sailing by a place, Ac 21:3; ptcp., καταλιπών, redundant (Dalman, Words, 21 f.), Mt 16:4 21:17; pass., Jo 8:9, I Th 3:1; metaph., εὐθεῖαν ὁδόν, II Pe 2:15.; to forsake, abandon: Mt 19:5, Mk 10:7 (LXX) Mk 14:52, Lk 5:28 15:4, Ac 6:2, Eph 5:31 (LXX).; to leave remaining, reserve: c. acc et inf., Lk 10:40; ἐμαυτῷ, Ro 11:4 (LXX); pass., He 4:1 (cf. ἐν-κατα-λείπω).†
to cast stones at, to stone: Lk 20:6.†
exchange.; reconciliation: Ro 5:11; κ. κόσμου, Ro 11:15; διακονία τῆς κ., II Co 5:18; λόγος τῆς κ., II Co 5:19.†

prop., to change, exchange (esp. of money); hence, of persons, to change from emnity to friendship, to reconcile (for exx. in cl., v. Thayer„ LS): of the reconciliation of man to God (Lft., Notes, 288; ICC on Ro, l.c.; DCG, ii, 474, 797), II Co 5:18-19; pass Ro 5:10, II Co 5:20; of a woman returning to her husband, I Co 7:11 (cf. ἀπο-καταλλάσσω).†
left remaining: ἱο κ. τ. ἀνθρώπων, Ac 15:17 (LXX).†
= cl. καταγώγιον (cf. πανδοχεῖον), an inn, lodgingplace: Lk 2:7 (so Ex, l.c., and MGr.).; a guest-room (1Sam,l.c.): Mk 14:14, Lk 22:11.†

to destroy, cast down: Mt 24:2, Mk 13:2, Lk 21:6; τ. ναόν, Mt 26:61 27:40, Mk 14:58 15:29, Ac 6:14; οἰκίαν, II Co 5:1; opp. to οἰκοδομεῖν, Ga 2:18. Metaph., to overthrow, annul, abrogate: Ac 5:38-39; τ. ἔργον τ. θεοῦ, Ro 14:20; τ. νόμον, Mt 5:17 (II Mac 2:22).; to unloose, unyoke (e.g. horses), hence intrans., of travellers (cf. κατάλυμα), to take up one's quarters, lodge (cl., Ge 19:2, al.): Lk 9:12 19:7.†
to learn thoroughly, observe well, consider carefully (on distinction bet. κ. and μανθάνω, cf. M, Pr., 117): Mt 6:28.†
to bear witness againt: c. acc rei et gen. pers., Mt 26:62 27:13, Mk 14:60.†
to remain permanently, abide: Ac 1:13, I Co 16:6, WH (παραμ-, T, EV).†
Rec. for κατὰ μόνας, v.s. μόνος
Rec. for κατάθεμα, q.v
to use up, spend.; to consume: of fire, ptcp., He 12:29 (LXX).†
to cause to grow numb.; Intrans., to grow numb; hence metaph., to be inactive, be burdensome to c. gen., II Co 11:9 12:13-14; pass., to be quite numb (Hippocr.).†
to nod assent,; to make a sign by nodding the head: c. dat. pers., Lk 5:7.†

to take note of, perceive, consider carefully: Ac 7:31-32; c. acc rei, Mt 7:3, Lk 6:41 12:24, 27 20:23, Ac 11:6 27:39, Ro 4:19; c. acc pers., He 3:1 10:24, Ja 1:23-24 (on the distinction bet. κ. and νοέω simplex, v. M, Pr., 117).†

to come to, arrive at: seq. εἰς, c. acc loc., Ac 16:1 18:19, 24 21:7 25:13 (v. M, Pr., 132) Ac 27:12 28:13; seq. ἀντικρύ, c. gen., Ac 20:15. Metaph., seq. εἰς, c. acc pers., I Co 10:11 14:36; id. c. acc rei, to attain to: Ac 26:7, Eph 4:13, Phl 3:11.†
a pricking.; (Perhaps through resembl. of κατανύσσω to -νυστάζω), torpor of mind, stupefaction: Ro 11:8 (LXX) (v. ICC, in l; Field, Notes, 157).†
to strike or prick violently.; to stun.; Of strong emotion, pass., to be smitten: τὴν καρδίαν, Ac 2:37 (v.s. κατάνυξις).†
to deem worthy: c. acc pers. et gen. rei, II Th 1:5; pass. seq. inf., Lk 20:35, Ac 5:41.†
to tread down, trample under foot: Mt 7:6, Lk 12:1; pass., Mt 5:13, Lk 8:5. Metaph., τ. υἱὸν τ. θεοῦ, He 10:29.†
in cl., a putting to rest, causing to cease.; In LXX and NT, rest, repose: Ac 7:49 (LXX), He 3:11, 18 4:1, 3 4:5, 10-11†
trans.,; to cause to cease, restrain: Ac 14:18; to cause to rest: He 4:8.; Intrans., to rest: seq. ἀτό, He 4:4 (LXX), He 4:10.†
in NT always the inner veil or curtain of the Temple (or Tabernacle): Mt 27:51, Mk 15:38, Lk 23:45, He 6:19 9:3; fig., ἡ σὰρξ αὐτοῦ He 10:20.†
to drink down, swallow: Mt 23:24, Re 12:16.; to devour: I Pe 5:8. Metaph., to swallow up, consume: pass., I Co 15:54 (LXX), II Co 2:7 5:4, He 11:29.†
to fall down: Ac 28:6; seq. εἰς, Ac 26:14; ἐπί c. acc, Lk 8:6.†
to sail down, sail to land, put in: εἰς τ. χώραν, Lk 8:26.†
to wear down, oppress, treat hardly: pass., Ac 7:24, II Pe 2:7.†
to throw into the sea, sink or drown therein: Mt 14:30; pass., Mt 18:6.†
a curse: Ga 3:10, 13 He 6:8, II Pe 2:14; opp. to εὐλογία, Ja 3:10; concrete, of Christ, Ga 3:13 (v. Lft. in l).†
to curse: c. acc, Mk 11:21; opp. to εὐλογέω, Lk 6:26, Ro 12:14, Ja 3:9; pass. pf. ptcp., accursed, under a curse (v. M, Pr., 221): Mt 25:41.†

to make idle or inactive (χέρας, Eur., Phœn., 753): of soil occupied by an unfruitful tree, Lk 13:7. Metaph. (Inscr.), to render inoperative or invalid, to abrogate, abolish: Ro 3:3, 31, I Co 1:28 6:13 13:11 15:24, Ga 3:17, Eph 2:15, II Th 2:8, II Ti 1:10, He 2:14; pass., Ro 4:14 6:6, I Co 2:6 13:8 13:10 15:26, II Co 3:7 3:11-14 Ga 5:11; seq. ἀπό (of persons), to be separated, discharged or loosed from, Ro 7:2, 6, Ga 5:4.†
to number or count among: seq. ἐν, Ac 1:1.†

to render ἄρτιος, i.e. fit, complete; to mend, repair: Mt 4:21, Mk 1:19; to furnish completely, complete, equip, prepare: pass., Lk 6:40, Ro 9:22, He 11:3; mid., Mt 21:16 (LXX), He 10:5 (LXX); in ethical sense, to prepare, complete, perfect: Ga 6:1 (EV, restore), I Pe 5:10; pass., I Co 1:10 (Field, Notes, 167), II Co 13:11, He 13:21 (cf. προ-καταρτίζω).†
a strengthening, making fit: in ethical sense, II Co 13:9.†
= κατάρτισις (but v. ICC, Eph. l.c.): Eph 4:12.†
to shake down.; Of the hand, to shake or wave as a signal: τ. χεῖρα, Ac 19:33; τ. χειρί, Ac 13:16; id. c. dat. pers., Ac 21:40; seq. inf., Ac 12:17.†
to dig down: Ro 11:3 (LXX).†
to prepare, make ready: τ. ὁδόν, Mt 11:10, Mk 1:2, Lk 7:27; οἶκον, He 3:3-4; σκηνήν, He 9:2, 6; κιβωτόν, He 11:7, I Pe 3:20; pass. pf. ptcp., λαον κ., Lk 1:17.†
to pitch one's tent, lodge, dwell: seq. ἐν, Mt 13:32, Lk 13:19; ὑπό, c. acc, Mk 4:32; ἐπ' ἐλπιδι, Ac 2:26 (LXX).†
prop., an encamping, taking up one's quarters (Polyb., al., v. LS; and cf. LXX, ll. c.).; a lodging, abode: of birds, Mt 8:20, Lk 9:58.†
to overshadow: c. acc, He 9:5.†
to view closely, inspect, spy out: c. acc, Ga 2:4.†
a spy: He 11:31.†
to deal craftily with, outwit: Ac 7:19 (LXX) †
to let down, lower.; to keep down, restrain: c. acc, Ac 19:35-36 †
condition, of health, etc.; demeanour: Tit 2:3 (for exx. v. Field, Notes, 220).†
a letting down, checking.; steadiness, quietness in demeanour.; LXX and NT (cf. Plut., ii, 65 D; -ίζω = vestire), a garment, dress, attire: I Ti 2:9 (but v. Ellic., in l).†
to turn down, turn over; as, the soil.; to overturn, overthrow: Mt 21:12, Mk 11:15; pass. pf. ptcp., Ac 15:16 (LXX).†
to wax wanton against: c. gen., I Ti 5:11
overthrow: II Pe 2:6 (WH, om.).; Metaph., subversion, upsetting (cf. καθαίρεσις, II Co 13:10): II Ti 2:14.†
to strew or spread over.; to lay low, overthrow: I Co 10:5.†
to pull down.; to drag away: c. acc pers., Lk 12:58.†
to kill off, slay: c. acc, Lk 19:27.†
to seal up, secure with a seal: Re 5:1.†
a holding back.; LXX and NT, a holding fast, possession: Ac 7:5, 45.†
to lay down, deposit, lay by: Mk 15:46, T; mid., to lay up for oneself: χάριν (Hdt., al., v. LS, s.v.), c. dat. pers., Ac 24:27 25:9.†
incision.; excision, concision, mutilation: in sarcasm, by paronomasia, in contrast to (true) περιτομή (v3), of Judaizing Christians, Phl 3:2 (v. Lft., in l; Cremer, 883).†
to strike down with an arrow, shoot dead: He 12:20 (LXX) (Rec.; WH, R, om.).†
to run down: seq. ἐπί, c. acc pers., Ac 21:32.†
to shine down: II Co 4:4.†
v.s. κατεσθίω..
to bring down: αἰτιώματα, Ac 25:7; ψῆφον, to cast a ballot, Ac 26:10; pass., to be borne down: ὕπνῳ, ἀπὸ τ. ὕ., Ac 20:9.†
to flee for refuge: seq. εἰς, Ac 14:6; metaph., c. inf., He 6:18.†
1 to destroy entirely.; In moral sense (as LXX), to deprave, corrupt: pass. pf. ptcp., seq. τ. νο ν, II Ti 3:8.†
to kiss fervently, kiss affectionately: Mt 26:49, Mk 14:45, Lk 7:38, 45 15:20, Ac 20:37.†
to think little of, despise: c. gen., Mt 6:24 18:10, Lk 16:13, Ro 2:4, I Co 11:22, I Ti 4:12 6:2, He 12:2, II Pe 2:10.†
a despiser: Ac 13:41.†
to pour down upon: c. gen. (cl.), Mk 14:3; seq. ἐπί, c. gen., Mt 26:7.†
subterranean, under the earth (in cl., of the infernal gods): of the departed in Hades, opp. to ἐπουράνιος, ἐπίγειος, Phl 2:10.†
to make full use of, use to the uttermost, use up: I Co 7:31; c. dat., I Co 9:18 (for other senses, v. LS, s.v.)..†
to cool: c. acc, Lk 16:24.†
full of idols: Ac 17:16.†
over against, opposite, before: ἡ, κ. κώμη, Lk 19:30; as prep., c. gen., Mt 21:2 27:24 (ἀπ-, WH, mg.), Mk 11:2 12:41 (ἀπ-, WH, mg.) Mk 13:3; metaph., before, seq. θεοῦ, Ro 4:17, II Co 2:17 12:19.†
over against, before: c. gen., τ. δόξης, Ju 24; metaph. (cf. κατέναντι, and v. Lft., Col., l.c.), τ. θεοῦ, Eph 1:4, Col 1:22.†
to exercise authority over: c. gen. pers., Mt 20:25, Mk 10:42.†; SYN: (κατακυριεύω) (v. Swete, Mk., l.c.)

to effect by labour, achieve, work out, bring about: c. acc, Ro 4:15 5:3 7:8, 15-20, II Co 7:10, Eph 6:13, Ja 1:3; pass., II Co 12:12; c. acc rei et dat. pers., Ro 7:13, II Co 4:17 7:11 9:11; id. seq. διά, c. gen. pers., Ro 15:18; τ. σωτηρίαν, Phl 2:12; c. acc pers. seq. εἰς, II Co 5:5 (RV, wrought); of evil deeds, Ro 1:27 2:9, I Co 5:3, I Pe 4:3.†

to come down, go down: seq. εἰς, Lk 4:31, Ac 8:5 13:4 15:30 19:1, Τ; ἀπό, Lk 9:37, Ac 15:1 18:5 21:10; ἀπό et εἰς, Ac 11:27 12:10; of coming to port by ship, Ac 18:22 21:3 27:5; seq. πρός, c. acc pers., Ac 9:32; metaph., of gifts from God, Ja 3:15.†

to eat up, devour: c. acc, of seed, Mt 13:4, Mk 4:4, Lk 8:5; τέκνον, Re 12:4; βιβλαρίδιον, Re 10:9-10; metaph., οἰκίας, Mt 23:13, Mk 12:40, Lk 20:47; τ. βίον, Lk 15:30; c. acc pers., Jo 2:17 (LXX), II Co 11:20, Ga 5:15, Re 11:5 20:9.†
to make or keep straight, direct, guide: metaph., τ. ὁδόν, I Th 3:11; τ. πόδας εἰς ὁδὸν εἰρήνης, Lk 1:79; τ. καρδίας εἰς τ. ἀγάπην, II Th 3:5.†
to bless fervently: Mk 10:16 (v. Swete, in l).†
to rise up against: Ac 18:12.†

perfective of ἔχω (M, Pr., 116; M, Th., 155),; to possess, hold fast: Lk 8:15, Jo 5:4, Ro 1:18 (Lft., Notes, 251), I Co 7:30 11:2, II Co 6:10, I Th 5:21, He 3:6, 14 10:23; to lay hold of, get possession of: Lk 14:9.; to hold back, detain, restrain (M, Th., 156 f.): c. acc seq. τοῦ μή c. inf., Lk 4:42; seq. πρός, c. acc, Phm 13; absol., τὸ κατέχον (ὁ κ.), II Th 2:6-7.; Intrans., as nautical term, to put in, make for (LS, s.v.): Ac 27:40.†

to make accusation, accuse,; in general: absol., Ro 2:15; c. gen. pers. (cl., WM, 254), Jo 5:45; irreg. c. acc pers., Re 12:10; before a judge: absol., Ac 24:2, 19; c. gen. pers., Mt 12:10, Mk 3:2, Lk 6:7 11:54 (WH, txt., R, om.), Lk 23:2, 10, Jo 8:6 Ac 25:5 28:19; id. c. acc rei (cl., but v. WM, l.c.), Mk 15:3-4; c. gen. rei (Dem.), Ac 24:8 25:11; seq. περί, c. gen. rei (Thuc., viii, 85), Ac 24:13; c. acc rei, seq. κατά c. gen. pers. (WM, § 28, 1), Lk 23:14. Pass. (B1., § 54, 3), seq. ὑπό c. gen., Mt 27:12, Ac 22:30; ὁ κατηγορούμενος, Ac 25:16.†
an accusation, charge: c. gen. pers., Jo 18:29; seq. κατά, c. id., I Ti 5:19; c. gen. rei, Tit 1:6.†
an accuser: Ac 23:30, 35 24:8 (WH, R, txt. om.) Ac 25:16, 18.†
= κατήγορος,; an accuser: Re 12:10.†
dejection: Ja 4:9.†

to resound.; to teach by word of mouth, instruct, inform (v. 131., Phil. Gosp., 20, 31): Ga 6:6; c. acc pers., I Co 14:19; pass. c. acc rei, Lk 1:4 (ICC, in l), Ac 18:25 21:24 (cf. Lk, l.c.), Ga 6:6; seq. κ, c. gen. rei, Ro 2:18; περί, c. gen. pers., Ac 21:21.†
to rust over; pass., become rusted over: Ja 5:3.†
to overpower, prevail against, prevail: absol., Lk 23:23; c. inf., Lk 21:36; c. gen., Mt 16:18.†

trans., to inhabit, dwell in: c. acc, Lk 13:4, Ac 1:10 2:9, 14 4:16 9:32, 35 19:10, 17. Re 17:2; of God, Mt 23:21.; Intrans., to settle, dwell: Ac 22:12; seq. ἐν (cl.), Ac 1:20 (LXX) Ac 2:5 7:2, 4 7:48 9:22 11:29 13:27 17:24, He 11:9, Re 13:12; seq. εἰς (B1., § 39, 3; M, Pr., 62 f., 234 f.), Mt 2:23 4:13, Ac 7:4; ἐπὶ τ. γῆς (Nu 13:33, al.), Re 3:10 6:10 8:13 11:10 13:8, 14 17:8; ἐπὶ παντὸς προσώπου τ. γ., Ac 17:26; ὅπου, Re 2:13; ἐκεῖ (of demons), Mt 12:45, Lk 11:26. Metaph., of divine indwelling: ὁ Χριστός, Eph 3:17; τ. πνεῦμα, Ja 4:5 (κατῴκισεν, T, WH, R, txt.); τ. πλήωρμα (τ. θεότητος), Col 1:19 2:9; δικαιοσύνη (cf. Wi 1:4), II Pe 3:13 (cf. ἐν-κατοικέω).†; κατοικίζω,; to cause to dwell: metaph., c. acc, τὸ πνεῦμα, Ja 4:5 (Rec., R, mg., κατῴκησεν).†
dwelling: Mk 5:3.†
a habitation, dwelling-place: Eph 2:22, Re 18:2.†
a dwelling: Ac 17:26.; a settlement (Polyb.).†
to show as in a mirror. Mid., to see oneself mirrored (v. MM, Exp., xv); c. acc rei (R, txt., but v. mg.), to reflect as a mirror: II Co 3:18 (cf. Abbott, Essays, 94).†
Rec, for διόρθωμα (q.v.), Ac 24:3.†

down, downwards (with verbs of motion), Mt 4:6, Lk 4:9, Jo 8:6, 8, Ac 20:9.; below, beneath: Mk 14:66, Ac 2:19 (LXX); ἕως κ. (Ez 1:27, al.), Mt 27:51, Mk 15:38. τὰ κ. (opp. to τ. ἄνω), Jo 8:23. Compar. κατωτέρω: ἀπὸ διετοῦς καὶ κ. (cf. I Ch 27:21), Mt 2:16.†

lower; τὰ. κ. τῆς γῆς (v. AR, Eph., l.c; for rendering this lower earth, v. ICC, Eph, l.c.), the lower parts of the earth (cf. Ps 139:15; cf. also MGr., ἡ κάτου γῆ, the underworld, Thumb, MGV, 334): Eph 4:9.†
Cauda, Clauda, an island near Crete: Ac 27:16.†
to burn or scorch up: c. acc seq. ἐν πυρί, Re 16:8. Pass., Mt 13:14, Mk 4:6; seq. καῦμα μέγα, Re 16:9.†
burning: He 6:8.†
only in pass.,; to burn with fever (Galen., al.).; In NT, to burn with great heat: II Pe 3:10 3:12 (V. Mayor, in l).†
to mark by branding, brand (AV, scar, but v. CGT, in l): metaph., pass. pf. ptcp., I Ti 4:2 (cf. καυτήριον, IV Mac 15:22 *).†

burning heat (Ge, Isa (?), Jth, ll.c., Si 18:16): Mt 20:12, Lk 12:55 (Ja 1:11, AV).; a hot wind from the east (Heb. קָדִים, v. LXX, ll.c.), the modern sirocco (v. CGT on Am 4:9): Ja 1:11 (RV, the scorching wind; cf. R, mg., the hot wind, Mt, Lk, ll.c.).†

to boast or glory (in LXX, of joyous exultation, and so in the NT quotations, infr.; cf. DB, ii, 790b; Hort on Ja 1:9): absol., I Co 1:31 (LXX) I Co 4:7 13:3, II Co 10:13 10:17 (LXX) II Co 11:16 11:18 12:1 12:6, Eph 2:9, Ja 4:16; c. acc rei, II Co 9:2 11:30; seq. ἐν (LXX), Ro 2:23 5:3, I Co 3:21, II Co 5:12 10:15 11:12 12:5 12:9, Ga 6:13-14 Ja 1:9; ἐν (τ.) θεῷ, Ro 2:17 5:11; ἐν κυρίῳ, I Co 1:31 (LXX) II Co 10:17 (LXX); ἐν Χ. Ἰησοῦ, Phl 3:3; seq. ἐπί c. dat., Ro 5:2; περί, c. gen., II Co 10:8; εἰς, II Co 10:16; ὑπέρ, c. gen. pers., II Co 7:14 12:5; ἐνώπιον τ. θεοῦ, I Co 1:29 (cf. ἐν, κατα-καυχάομαι).†

a boast (Pind.): II Co 5:12 9:3 (Thayer, s.v.; e. contra, 2, Ellic., Lft., on Ga 6:4; Lft., Notes, 204, 277).; ground or matter of glorying: Ro 4:2, I Co 5:6 9:15-16, II Co 1:14, Ga 6:4, Phl 1:26 2:16, He 3:6 (cf. καύχησις).†

a boasting, glorying: Ro 3:27, II Co 11:10 11:17, Ja 4:16; seq. ὑπέρ, II Co 7:4 8:24; ἐτί, c. gen., II Co 7:14; ἔχω τὴν κ. ἐν Χρ. Ἰησ., Ro 15:17; στέφανος καυχήσεως (Ez. l.c., al.), I Th 2:19; of the cause of glorying, a boast ( = καύχημα), II Co 1:12.†
Capernaum: Mt 4:13, Mk 1:21, Jo 2:12, al

a cedar: χείμαρρος τῶν Κ. (as in 2Sam, 1Ki, ll. c.), Jo 18:1 (Rec. Tr., WH, R, mg.; τοῦ Κέδρου, T, WH, mg., v.s. Κεδρών, and cf. Westc., in l; WH, App., 89 f.; Abbott, JG, 513 ff).†; Κεδρών; indecl.; Cedron (OT, Kidron): χείμαρρος τοῦ Κ., Jo 18:1 (L, Tr., mg., R, txt.; cf. Bl., 10, 5; Lft., Essays, 172 ff).†

used as passive of τίθημι (LS, s.v.), to be laid, to lie; of persons: an infant, Lk 2:12, 16; a dead body, Mt 28:6, Lk 23:53, Jo 20:12; of things, to lie, be laid or set, stand: Mt 5:14, Jo 2:6 19:29 20:5-7 21:9, Re 4:2 21:16; trop., Θεμέλιος, I Co 3:11; seq. prep. c. acc, πρός, Mt 3:10, Lk 3:9; εἰς, Lk 12:19; ἐπί, trop., κάλυμμα, II Co 3:15. Metaph., ὁ κόσμος ἐν τ. πονηριῷ κ., I Jn 5:19; to be laid down, appointed: of law, c. dat. pers., I Ti 1:9; seq. εἰς c. acc (of purpose), Lk 2:34, Phl 1:16, I Th 3:3; (cf. ἀνά-, συν-ανά-, ἀντί-, ἀπό-, ἐπί-, κατά-, παρά-, περί-, πρό-κειμαι).†
a vernacular word,; 1, a bed-cord (Aristoph., AV., 816; Pr, l.c.).; In pl., swathings (cf. Field, Notes, 96 f.): Jo 11:44.†
to cut short the hair, shear: a sheep, Ac 8:32 (Isa, l.c.). Mid., to have one's hair cut off, be shorn: absol., I Co 11:6; τ-. κεφαλήν, Ac 18:18.†
Kish: Ac 13:21.†
a call, summons, shout of command: I Th 4:16 (v. M, Th., in l).†

to urge on, bid by word of mouth, order, command (mostly of one in authority): c. acc et. inf. aor., Mt 14:19, 28 18:25 27:64, Lk 18:40, Ac 4:15 5:34 8:38 22:30 23:10 25:6, 17; with ellipse of acc, Mt 8:18 14:9 27:58, Ac 12:19 21:33; c. acc et. inf. Pres., Ac 21:34 22:24 23:3, 35 25:21 27:43; with ellipse of acc, Ac 16:22; ptcp. aor., Ac 25:23.†
to tread on emptiness: ἐώρᾳ (αἰώρα) κ. (conjec. for ἃ ἑόρακμν ἐμβ., Lft., in l), Col 2:18 (cf. also ICC, in l).†
foolish fancy, vain opinion, error (LXX, ll. c.).; vain­glory, groundless conceit: Phl 2:3.†
vain-glorious: Ga 5:26.†

empty (Ge 37:24, Jg 7:16). Metaph.,; empty, vain: λόγοι, Eph 5:6; ἀπάτη, Col 2:8; κήρυγμα, πίστις, I Co 15:14; vain, fruitless: ἡ χάρις, I Co 15:10; κόπος, I Co 15:50; ἡ εἴσοδος, I Th 2:1; κενά, Ac 4:25 (LXX); εἰς κενόν, in vain, to no purpose (Diod., LXX; cl. διὰ κενῆς), II Co 6:1, Ga 2:2, Phl 2:16, I Th 3:5; of persons, empty-handed: Mk 12:3, Lk 1:53 20:10-11; vain, Ja 2:20.†
empty talk, babbling: pl., I Ti 6:20, II Ti 2:16.†

to empty. Metaph., to empty, make empty, vain or of no effect: καύχημα, I Co 9:15; ἑαυτόν, of Christ, Phl 2:7 (v Lft.; ICC, in 1, and esp. Gifford, Incarn., 54 ff.); pass., πίστις, Ro 4:14; ὁ σταυρός, I Co 1:17; καύχημα, II Co 9:3†
a sting (4Mac, l.c.): Re 9:10. Metaph. (as Ho 13:14): τ. θανάτου, I Co 15:55 (LXX), I Co 15:56,; a goad: pl., Ac 26:14.†
a centurion: Mk 15:39, 44-45 (Mt, Lk, use ἑκιτόνταρχος (-ης), q.v).†
Cenchreæ, a port of Corinth: Ac 18:18, Ro 16:1.†
in vain, to no purpose: Ja 4:5.†
a little horn: of the point or extremity which distinguishes some Heb. letters from others (e.g. ד from ר; DCG, ii, 733), Mt 5:18, Lk 16:17.†
a potter: Ro 9:21; ὁ ἀγρὸς τοῦ κ., Mt 27:7, (LXX).†
(cl.) of a potter (e.g. γῆ).; In LXX and NT, = cl., κεραμεοῦς (Plut., κεράμειος, Polyb., -μαῖος, etc), earthen: Re 2:27.†
an earthen vessel, a jar or jug: ὕδατος, Mk 14:13, Lk 22:10.†
potter's clay.; an earthen vessel.; a tile: Lk 5:19.†
to mix, mingle, chiefly of the diluting of wine: Re 18:6; by oxymoron, κεκεράσμενος ἄκρατος, Re 14:10.†
a horn: Re 5:6 12:3 13:1, 11 17:3, 7 17:12, 16; of the projections at the corners of the altar (Ex 29:12, al.): Re 9:13. Metaph., as symbol of strength, κ. σωτηρίας (cf. Ps 18:3, al.): Lk 1:69.†
a little horn (Arist.).; In pl. (the fruit of the κερατέα), carob-pods: Lk 15:16.†

to gain: c. acc, Mt 25:16-17, 20 25:22; τ. κόσμον, Mt 16:26, Mk 8:36, Lk 9:25; absol., to make profit, get gain: Ja 4:13. Metaph., c. acc rei, to save oneself from, avoid: Ac 27:21 (Field, Notes, 145); c. acc pers., to gain, win: Mt 18:15, I Co 9:19-22, Phl 3:8; pass., I Pe 3:1.†
gain: Phl 1:21 3:7, Tit 1:11.†
a slice, hence,; a small coin: pl., Jo 2:15.†
a money changer: Jo 2:14.†
of the head; metaph., principal, chief; mostly as subst., κεφάλαιον, τό; the chief point: He 8:1.; the sum total, amount: Ac 22:28 (other meaning, LS, s.v.).†

the head: Mt 5:35, Mk 6:24, Re 1:14 9:7, al. mult.; fig., ἄνθρακες ἐπὶ τὴν κ., Ro 12:20 (LXX); αἷμι, Ac 18:6; metaph., of a husband, c. gen., I Co 1:13, Eph 5:23; of Christ, I Co 11:3, Eph 4:15 5:23, Col 1:18 2:10, 19; of things, κ. γωνίας, Mt 21:42 (LXX)
(-αιόω) to sum up (Thuc., al.).; (In NT, only) to wound on the head: Mk 12:4.†
a little head.; an extremity, capital (of a column).; (As in Ex 2:9, Ps 40:8, Es 6:2) a roll: κ. βιβλίου, He 10:7 (LXX).†
to muzzle: I Co 9:9 (TTr., WH, mg.) (cf. φιμόω).†
a poll-tax: Mt 17:25 22:17, Mk 12:14 (WH, mg., ἐπικεφάλαιον); τ. νόμισμα τοῦ κ., Mt 22:19 (v. MM, Exp., xv).†
a gardener: Jo 20:15.†
honeycomb: κ. μελίσσιον, Lk 24:42 (Rec.; WH, txt., R, txt., omit).†

in cl.,; that which is cried by a herald, a proclamation. In NT (v. Lft., Notes, 161), of God's heralds, proclamation, message, preaching (i.e. the substance as distinct from the act which would be expressed by † κήρυξις): Mt 12:41, Lk 11:32, I Co 1:21, II Ti 4:17, Tit 1:3; c. gen. cubic., τὸ κ. μου, I Co 2:4; ἡμῶν, I Co 15:14; c. gen. obj., Ἰησοῦ Χρ., Ro 16:25.†
a herald: I Ti 2:7, II Ti 1:11, II Pe 2:5.†

to be a herald, to proclaim: Mk 1:45 7:36, Lk 4:18-19 (LXX) (but v. Field, Notes, 174) Lk 8:39, Ro 2:21, I Co 9:27, Ga 5:11, al.; in NT, chiefly of the proclamation of the Gospel, to proclaim, preach: τὸ εὐαγέλιον, Mt 4:23 9:35 24:14 26:13, Mk 1:14 13:10 14:9 16:15, Ga 2:2, Col 1:23, I Th 2:9; seq. εἰς, Mk 1:39 13:10, Lk 4:44, I Th 2:9; ἵνα, Mk 6:12; c. inf.. Ro 2:21; κ. Χριστόν, Ἰησοῦν, Ac 8:5 9:20 19:13, I Co 1:23 15:12, II Co 1:19 11:4, Phl 1:15; I Ti 3:16 (cf. προ-κηρύσσω)
a huge fish, sea-monster: Mt 12:40 (LXX).†
a wooden box or chest: of Noah's ark, Mt 24:38, Lk 17:27, He 11:7, I Pe 3:20; of the ark of the covenant, He 9:4, Re 11:19.†
a lyre, harp: I Co 14:7, Re 5:8 14:2 15:2.†
to play upon the lyre or harp: I Co 14:7, Re 14:2.†
one who plays and sings to the lyre, a harper: Re 14:2 18:22.†
Cilicia, a province of Asia Minor: Ac 6:9 15:23, 41 21:39 22:3 23:34 27:5, Ga 1:21.†
to be daring, to venture.; to be in danger: Lk 8:23, Ac 19:27, 40, I Co 15:30.†
danger, peril: Ro 8:35; pl., II Co 11:26.†

to set in motion, move: Mt 23:4; τ. κεφαλήν (Ps 22:8, al.), Mt 27:39, Mk 15:29; pass. (cf. Ge 7:21), Ac 17:28.; to remove: Re 2:5 6:14.; to excite, stir up: Ac 24:5; pass., Ac 21:30 (cf. μετα-, συν-κινέω).†
a moving: Jo 5:3.†
cinnamon: Re 18:13.†
a young tender shoot broken off for grafting; then, a branch: Mt 13:32 21:8 24:32, Mk 4:32 13:28, Lk 13:19; metaph., of descendants (cf. Si 40:15), Ro 11:16-19, 21.†

of any loud expression of pain or sorrow, esp. for the dead, to weep, lament; intrans.: Mk 5:38-39 14:72 (M, Pr., 131) Mk 16:10, Lk 7:13, 32 7:38 8:52, Jo 11:31, 33 16:20 20:11, 13 20:15 Ac 9:39 21:13, I Co 7:30, Phl 3:18, Ja 4:9 5:1, Re 5:5 18:15, 19; πολύ, Re 5:4; πολλά, Ac 8:24 (WH, mg.); πικρῶς, Mt 26:75, Lk 22:62; opp. to γελάω, Lk 6:21, 25; χαίρω, Ro 12:15; seq. ἐπί, c. acc, Lk 19:41 23:28, Re 18:9; trans., c. acc pers., to weep or lament for, bewail: Mt 2:18.†
a breaking: Lk 24:35, Ac 2:42.†
a broken piece, fragment: Mt 14:20 15:37, Mk 6:43 8:8, 19-20, Lk 9:17, Jo 6:12-13 †
Claudia: II Ti 4:21.†
Claudius; the Emperor: Ac 11:28 18:2.; A military tribune, C. Lysias: Ac 23:26.†
crying, weeping, Ac 20:37; κ. καὶ ὀδυρμός, Mt 2:18 (LXX); ὁ κ. καὶ ὁ βρυγμός, Mt 8:12 13:42, 50 22:13 24:51 25:30, Lk 13:28.†
to break, break in pieces: of bread, Mt 14:19 15:36 26:26, Mk 8:6 14:22, Lk 22:19 24:30, Ac 2:46 20:7, 11 27:35, I Co 10:16 11:24; seq. εἰς, c. acc pers., Mk 8:19 (cf. ἐκ-, κατα-κλάω).†
a key. Fig., τ. βασιλείας τ. οὐρανῶν, Mt 16:19; τ. γνώσεως, Lk 11:52; of David (cf. LXX, l.c.), Re 3:7; τ. θανάτου κ. τ. ᾅδου, Re 1:18; τ. ἀβύσσαυ, Re 20:1; τ. φρέατος τῆς ἀ., Re 9:1.†

to shut: θύραν, Mt 6:6; τ. ἄβυσσον, Re 20:3; pass., θύρα, Mt 25:10, Lk 11:7 (pl.), Jo 20:19, 26, Ac 21:30; δεσμωτήριον, Ac 5:23; πυλῶνες, Re 21:25. Metaph., τ. οὐρανόν, Lk 4:25, Ro 11:6; τ. σπλάγχνα, I Jn 3:17; τ. βασιλείαν, Mt 23:14; id. absol., Re 3:7; τ. θύραν, Re 3:8. (cf. ἀπο-, ἐκ-, κατα-, συν-κλείω.) †
a thing stolen (Arist., LXX); = κλοπή, theft (Plato, al.): pl., Re 9:21.†
Cleopas: Lk 24:18.†
a rumour, report.; good report, fame, glory: I Pe 2:20.†

a thief: Mt 6:19-20 24:43, Lk 12:33, 39, Jo 10:1, 10 12:6, I Co 6:10, I Pe 4:15. Fig., ὡς κ. ἐν νυκτί, I Th 5:2 5:4 (κλέπτας, WH, txt., R, mg.; v. Lft., Notes, 73; but cf. also M, Th., l.c.), II Pe 3:10, Re 3:3 16:15. Metaph., of false teachers, Jo 10:8.†
a vine-twig, vine-branch: Jo 15:2, 4-6.†
Clement: Phl 4:3.†

to receive by lot.; to inherit (in cl., usually c. gen. rei): absol., Ga 4:30 (LXX); in general, to possess oneself of, receive as one's own, obtain (as De 4:5, al., cf. Ps 25:3, Is 61:7): c. acc rei (as generally in late Gk., v. M, Pr., 65), of the Messianic Kingdom (cf. Ps 37:11, Si 4:13 37:26, and v. Dalman, Words, 125 ff.) and its bless­ings and privileges, τ. γῆν, Mt 5:5 (cf. LXX); τ. βασιλείαν, β. θεοῦ, Mt 25:34, I Co 6:9-10 15:50, Ga 5:21; ζωὴν αἰώνιον, Mt 19:29, Mk 10:17, Lk 10:25 18:18; σωτηρίαν, He 1:14; τ. ἐπαγγελίας, He 6:12; ἀφθαρσίαν, I Co 15:50; ὄνομα, He 1:4; τ. εὐλογίαν, He 12:17, I Pe 3:9; ταῦτα, Re 21:7 (cf. κατα-κληρονομέω).†

prop., an inherited property, an inheritance: Mt 21:38, Mk 12:7, Lk 12:13 20:14; in general, a possession, inheritance: Ac 7:5, He 11:8; of the Messianic Kingdom and its blessings, Ac 20:32, Ga 3:18, Col 3:24, Eph 1:14, 18 5:5, He 9:15, I Pe 1:4.†

(as in cl.) an heir: Mt 21:38, Mk 12:7, Lk 20:14, Ga 4:1; of those who as sons of God inherit the privileges of the Messianic Kingdom; of Christ himself, He 1:2; of Abraham, Ro 4:13-14; of Christians, Ro 8:17, Ga 3:29, Tit 3:7, Ja 2:5.; (As in LXX: Jg, Mi, Je, ll. c.) a possessor: He 6:17 11:7 (Cremer, 359 f.).†

a lot; that which is cast or drawn: Mt 27:35, Mk 15:24, Lk 23:34, Jo 19:24 (LXX), Ac 1:26; that which is obtained by casting: Ac 1:17 8:21; of a part in the Kingdom of God (cf. Wis 55), Ac 26:18, Col 1:12; pl. of the "cure" of a presbyter, I Pe 5:3 (v. ICC, in l).†
to cast lots.; to choose by lot.; to assign by lot, assign a portion: pass., ἐν ᾧ καὶ ἐκληρώθημεν, Eph 1:11 (on the various interpretations, v. ICC; AR; Ellic., in l).†
a calling, call; in NT, always of the Divine call to salvation: Ro 11:29, I Co 1:26 7:20, Eph 1:18 4:1, 4, Phl 3:14, II Th 1:11, II Ti 1:9, He 3:1, II Pe 1:10 (Cremer, 332).†

called, invited (as to a banquet, Æsch., 1Sa 1:41, III Mac 5:14); in NT, always of the Divine call; to some office: κ. ἀπόστολος, Ro 1:1, I Co 1:1; to salvation: Ro 8:28, I Co 1:24, Ju 1; κ. καὶ ἐκλεκτοὶ κ. πιστοί, Re 17:14; in gosp. (not in pl., v.s. καλέω) disting. fr.ἐκλεκτός, Mt 20:16 (WH, txt., R, omit), Mt 22:14; κ. Ἰησοῦ Χρ., Ro 1:6; κ. ἅγιοι, saints by calling, Ro 1:7, I Co 1:2.†
