in cl., a clibanus, cribanus, an earthen vessel for baking bread.; In LXX and NT, a furnace (cf. MM, Exp., xv), an oven: Mt 6:30, Lk 12:28.†
an inclination, slope, esp. the slope from the equator to the pole (Arist).; a region (Polyb., al.): pl., Ro 15:23, II Co 11:10, Ga 1:21.†
dimin, of κλίνη,; a couch: Ac 5:15 (cf. κλινίδιον).†
dimin. of κλίνη,; a conch: Lk 5:19, 24 (cf. κλενάριον).†

to make to bend, to bow: τ. κεφαλήν (of one dying), Jo 19:30; τ. πρόσωτον (of terrified persons), Lk 24:5.; to make to lean, to rest: τ. κεφαλήν (in sleep), Mt 8:20, Lk 9:58.; As in Hom., of soldiers, to turn (to flight), παρεμβολάς, He 11:34.; In late Gk. (as mid, in cl.), to decline: intrans., ἡ ἡμέρα, Lk 9:12 24:29.†
a place for reclining; hence,; a hut; an easy chair; a couch.; a company reclining: pl., Lk 9:14 (cf. FlJ, Ant., xii, 2, 12)
theft: pl., Mt 15:19, Mk 7:22.†
a billow, surge: Lk 8:24, Ja 1:6.†
to be tossed by waves; metaph., to be tossed like waves (cf. FlJ, Ant., ix, 11, 3): Eph 4:14.†
Clopas: Jo 19:25.†
to scratch.; to tickle; pass., to itch: II Ti 4:3.†
Cnidus, a city (and peninsula) on S.W. coast of Asia Minor: Ac 27:7.†
a quadrans (AV, farthing): Mt 5:26, Mk 12:42.†

the belly (stomach or intestines or both): Mt 12:40 15:17, Mk 7:19, Lk 15:16, Ro 16:18, I Co 6:13, Phl 3:19, Re 10:9-10.; (As often in LXX) the womb: Lk 1:41-42, 44 2:21 11:27 23:29, Jo 3:4; ἐκ κ. μητρός (cf. Ps 22:11, Jb 1:21, al.), Mt 19:12, Lk 1:15, Ac 3:2 14:8, Ga 1:15.; Metaph. (as Heb. בֶּטֶן, cf. Jb 15:35, Pr 20:27, Si 19:12), of the heart: Jo 7:38.†

to lull to sleep, put to sleep. Mid and pass., to fall asleep (M, Pr., 162; M, Th., 1, 4, 13): Mt 28:13, Lk 22:45, Jo 11:12, Ac 12:6. Metaph, of death: Mt 27:52, Jo 11:11 Ac 7:60 13:36, I Co 7:39 11:30 15:6 15:18 15:20 15:51, I Th 4:13-15, II Pe 3:4 (cf. Is 14:8 43:17, II Mac 12:45).†
a reclining, resting: Jo 11:13.†

common (general; = Lat. communis): Ac 2:44 4:32; κ. πίστις, Tit 1:4; σωτηρία, Ju 3; common (ordinary; = vulgaris); hence in LXX (I Mac 1:47, al.) and NT, unhallowed, unclean (cl., βέβηλος, q.v.): Mk 7:2, 5, Ac 10:14, 28 11:8, Ro 14:14, He 10:29, Re 21:27.†

in cl., to make common.; In LXX, l.c., and NT (as κοινός, 2), to make ceremonially unclean, to profane (= cl., βεληλόω): Mt 15:11, 18 15:20, Mk 7:15, 18 7:20, 23, Ac 21:28; pass., He 9:13.; to count unclean (cf. δικαιόω): Ac 10:15 11:9.†

to have a share of, go shares in (something) with (some one), take part in: c. gen. rei (as usually in cl., so Pr, l.c.), He 2:14; c. dat. rei, Ro 12:13 15:27, I Ti 5:22, I Pe 4:13, II Jn 11; c. dat. pers., seq. εἰς, Phl 4:15; ἐν, Ga 6:6 (cf. συν-κοινωνέω).†

fellowship, communion: Ac 2:42, II Co 6:14, Phl 1:5; τ. υἱοῦ, I Co 1:9; τ. αἵματος, σώματος Χρ., I Co 10:10 : παθημάτων αὐτσῦ, Phl 3:10; τ. πνεύματος, II Co 13:13, Phl 2:1; δεξιὰς κοινωνίας, Ga 2:9; τ. πίστεώς σου, Phm 6; seq. μετὰ: τ. πατρός, I Jn 1:3 Jn 1:6; ἡμῶν, ἀλλήλων, I Jn 1:3 Jn 1:7.; contribution (as outcome of fellowship): Ro 15:26, II Co 8:4 9:13, He 13:6 (cf. Art. Communion, DB, i, 460 ff.; MM, Exp., xv).†
sociable.; ready to com­municate or impart (R, mg., ready to sympathize, v. Field, Notes, 213 f.): I Ti 6:18.†

as adj., = κοινός.; As subst., ὁ, ἡ κ.,; a partner, associate, companion: II Co 8:23, Phm 17; c. dat. pers., Lk 5:10; c. gen. pers., He 10:33; id. seq. ἐν, Mt 23:30; a partaker, sharer: c. gen. rei, I Co 10:18 10:20, II Co 1:7, I Pe 5:1, II Pe 1:4 (v. Deiss., BS, 368 n2).†
a bed: Lk 11:7; esp. the marriage-bed: κ. ἀμίαντος, He 13:4; κ. ἔχειν, of a woman conceiving, Ro 9:10 (cf. peculiar phrases in LXX, Le 15:18, al.); of illicit intercourse, pl., Ro 13:13.†
a bed-chamber; ὁ ἐπὶ τοῦ κ., a chamberlain: Ac 12:20.†
scarlet: Mt 27:28, He 9:19, Re 17:3; neut., without substantive, of clothing, Re 17:4 18:12, 16,†
to curtail, dock, prune.; to check, restrain.; to chastise, correct, punish: pass., II Pe 2:9; mid., cause to be punished (III Mac 7:3): Ac 4:21.†
flattery: I Th 2:5 (v. Lft., Notes, 23).†
correction, penalty, punishment: Mt 25:46, I Jn 4:18.†
a Colossian: pl., Col., tit. (and subscr., Rec., Tr.).†
to strike with the fist, to buffet: Mt 26:67, Mk 14:65, II Co 12:7; pass., I Co 4:11, I Pe 2:20.†

to glue or cement together.; Generally, to unite, to join firmly. Pass., to cleave to, join (oneself to): c. dat. pers., Mt 19:5(LXX), Lk 10:11 15:15, Ac 5:13 (but v. Field, Notes, 118) Ac 9:26 10:28 (v. Field, l.c.) Ac 17:34; τ. πόρνῃ, I Co 6:16; τ. Κυρίῳ, I Co 6:17; c. dat. rei, ἅρματι, Ac 8:29; τ. ἀγαθῴ, Ro 12:9; of sins joining together, ἄχρι τ. οὐρανοῦ, Re 18:5, of dust, Lk 10:11 (cf. τροσ-κολλάω).†
a small bread roll (LXX, ll. c.).; (Usually in pl., LS, s.v.) an eye salve shaped like a roll: Re 3:18.†
a money-changer: Mt 21:12, Mk 11:15, Jo 2:15 (of. κερματιοτής).†
to cut off, amputate (LXX), hence, to curtail, shorten: Mt 24:22, Mk 13:20.†
Colossæ, a city on the Lycus in Phrygia: Col 1:2.†

prop., the bosom: Jo 13:23; fig., of close association, ἐν (εἰς τὸν) τοῖς κ. Ἀβραάμ, Lk 16:22-23 (cf. IV Mac 13:16); ὁ ὢν εἰς τὸν κ. τ. πατρός, Jo 1:18; The bosom or fold of a loose garment falling over a girdle, used as a pocket, hence fig., εἰς τὸν κ. (Is 65:6, Je 32:18 : Lk 6:38; A bosom-like hollow, as a bay or gulf: Ac 27:39.†
to dive, plunge into the sea: Ac 27:43 (cf. ἐκ-κολνμβάω).†
a swimming pool, pool: Jo 5:2, 4 5:7 9:7.†
a colony: Ac 16:12 (v. Lft., Phi., 50 f.).†
to wear long hair: I Co 11:14-15.†
the hair: I Co 11:15.†

to take care of.; to carry off safe.; to carry off as booty.; to bear or carry: Lk 7:37. Mid., to bear for oneself, hence,; to receive: He 10:36 11:13, 39, I Pe 1:9 5:4, II Pe 2:13; to receive back, recover (in cl. so also act.): Mt 25:27, He 11:19; metaph., of requital, II Co 5:10, Col 3:25; παρὰ Κυρίου, Eph 6:8 (cf. ἐκ-, συν-κομίζω).†
well-dressed, elegant, fine; compar. neut., κομψότερον ἔχειν (cf. κόμψως ἔχειν, Epict., and colloq. Eng., "to be doing finely"): Jo 4:52.†
to plaster or whiten over: of tombs, Mt 23:27; fig., of a hypocrite, Ac 23:3.†
in cl., dust stirred up (Ex 9:9, Is 5:24); in NT, simply dust: Mt 10:14, Lk 9:5 10:11, Ac 13:51 22:23.†
to grow weary; of the wind (Hdt., Jh., l.c.), to abate, cease raging: Mt 14:32, Mk 4:39 6:51.†
= cl. κομμός, a beating of the head and breast, lamentation: seq. ἐπί c. dat. pers., Ac 8:2.†
in cl., a stroke, a pounding (as in a mortar).; In LXX, a smiting in battle: He 7:1 (LXX).†

(as in cl.) to grow weary: Mt 11:28, Jo 4:6, Re 2:3 (cf. Is 40:31).; Hence, in LXX and NT, to work with effort, to toil: absol., Mt 6:23, Lk 5:5 12:27, Jo 4:38, Ac 20:35, I Co 4:12, Eph 4:28, II Ti 2:5; c. acc rei, Jo 4:38; freq. in Paul. Epp., of ministerial labour: I Co 15:10 16:16; seq. ἐν, Ro 16:12, I Th 5:12 (v. M, Th., in l), I Ti 5:17; εἰς, Ro 16:6, Ga 4:11, Phl 2:16, Col 1:29, I Ti 4:10.†

a striking, beating (in Je 45:3 = κοπετός); laborious toil, trouble: Jo 4:38, I Co 3:8 15:58, I Th 3:5; κ. τ. ἀγάπης, I Th 1:3; ἔργα καὶ κ., Re 2:2; κ. καὶ μόχθος, II Co 11:27, I Th 2:9, II Th 3:8; pl., ἐν κ., II Co 6:5 10:15 11:23; ἐκ τ. κ., Re 14:13; κόπονς (-ον) παρέχειν (in cl. more freq. π. πράγματα, πονον), c. dat. pers., Mt 26:10, Mk 14:6, Lk 11:7 18:5, Ga 6:17.†
a dung hill (I Ki 2:8, Ps 113:7 al.): Lk 14:35.†; κόπριον, -ου, τό,; = κόπρος, dung: pl., Lk 13:8 (WH, mg., κόφινον κοπρίων).†

to strike, smite.; to cut off: c. acc rei, seq. ἀπό, Mt 21:8; ἐκ, Mk 11:8. Mid., to beat one's breast with grief, to mourn, bewail: Mt 11:17 24:30; c. acc pers., Lk 8:52 23:27; seq. ἐπί, c. acc, Re 1:7 18:9 (cf. ἀνα-, ἀπο-, ἐκ-, ἐν-, κατα-, προ-, προσ-κόπτω).†
a raven: Lk 12:24.†
a colloquial word which survives in MGr. (Kennedy, Sourcs, e154), girl, maiden: Mt 9:24-25 14:11, Mk 5:41-42 6:22, 28.†
an offering, a gift offered to God: Mk 7:11 (cf. κορβανᾶς).†
the Temple treasury: Mt 27:6 (cf. κορβάν).†
Korah: Ju 11.†
to satisfy: pass., τροφῆς, Ac 27:38; metaph., of spiritual things, I Co 4:8.†
Corinthian; as subst., ὁ Κ., a Corinthian: Ac 18:8 27:1-44 (WH, txt., R, omit), II Co 6:11; 1Co, 2Co, tit.†
Cornelius: Ac 10:1 ff.†
a cor, a Hebrew measure (AV, RV, measure): Lk 16:7.†

to order, arrange, prepare (in Hom. esp. of marshalling armies): Mt 25:7 (cf. Si 50:9, al.).; to adorn, furnish: οἶκον, pass., Mt 12:44, Lk 11:25; μνημεῖα, Mt 23:29; τὸ ἱερόν, pass., Lk 21:5; θεμέλιοι, Re 21:19; νύμφην, pass., Re 21:2; ἐαυτάς, seq. ἐν, I Ti 2:9. Metaph., c. acc pers., I Pe 3:5; c. acc rei, Tit 2:10.†
pertaining to the world or universe.; of this world, earthly. He 9:1.; In ethical sense, worldly: ἐπιθυμίαι, Tit 2:12.†
orderly, decent, modest: I Ti 2:9 (WH, mg., -ίως, q.v.) I Ti 3:2.†
decently, fittingly: I Ti 2:9 (WH, mg.).†

in Orphic hymns, al. (v. AR, Eph., l.c.), a ruler of the whole world (and so in Rabbinic writings: קוֺזמוֺקְרָטוֺר).; a ruler of this world (in contrast to παντο κράτωρ): οἱ κ. τ. σκότους τούτου, the rulers of this dark world, Eph 6:12.†

order (Hom., Plat., al.). ornament, adornment, esp. of women (Hom., al.): I Pe 3:3. Later, the world or universe, as an ordered system (Plat., al.): Ac 17:24, Ro 4:13, I Co 3:22, Phl 2:15, He 4:3, al. In late writers only, the world, i.e. the earth (= ἡ οἰκουμένη, cf. Mt 4:8 with Lk 4:5): Mt 4:8, Mk 16:[15], Col 2:20, I Ti 6:7, al.; hence by meton., of the human inhabitants of the world: Mt 5:14 15:38, Mk 14:9, Jo 1:10 4:42 12:47, Ro 3:6, I Co 4:13, II Co 5:19, II Pe 2:5, al.; of worldly affairs or possessions: Mt 16:26, Mk 8:36, Lk 9:25, I Co 7:31, I Jo 2:16, al.; in ethical sense, of the ungodly: Jo 7:7 14:17, 27 I Co 1:21, Ja 1:27, I Jo 4:4, al.; metaph.: ὁ κ. τῆς ἀδικίας, Ja 3:6.
(Lat.), Quartus: Ro 16:23.†
koum (arise): Mk 5:41.†
intrans., to be light (poetic chiefly).; to lighten, make light: c. acc, Ac 27:38.†
a basket, probably of wicker-work, such as were carried by Jews for food: Mt 14:20 16:9, Mk 6:43 8:19 9:17 13:8, Jo 6:13 (cf. σφυρίς).†
a camp bed, pallet: Mk 2:4, 9 2:11-12 6:55, Jo 5:8-11, Ac 5:15 9:33 (v. Swete, Mk., 24, and cf. κλίνη).†

in cl. chiefly poët.,; prop. onomatop., of the raven, to croak, hence generally, of inartic. cries, to scream, cry out (Æsch., al.): Mk 5:5 9:26 15:39 (Rec., R, mg.), Lk 9:39, al.; of crying for vengeance (cf. Ge 4:10), Ja 5:4.; to cry, call out with a loud voice: c. acc rei, Ac 19:32; seq. orat. dir., Mk 10:48, Lk 18:39, al.; (ἐν) φωνῇ μεγάλῃ, Mk 5:7, Re 14:15, al.; λέγων, Mt 8:29, al.; of public teaching, Jo 1:15, Ro 9:27, al.; of importunate prayer (cf. Jb 35:12, Ps 3:5, al.), Ro 8:15, Ga 4:6; pf. with Pres. sense (vernac.; M, Pr., 147), Jo 1:15
drunken nausea (EV, surfeiting): Lk 21:34.†
in cl., an edge, border.; In LXX (v. supr.) and NT, a tassel or corner: Mt 9:20 14:36 23:5, Mk 6:56, Lk 8:44.†
strong, mighty: I Pe 5:6.†
to strengthen; pass., to wax strong: Lk 2:40, I Co 16:13; πνεύματι, Lk 1:80; δυνάμει κ. διὰ τ. πνεύματος, Eph 3:16.†

to be strong, mighty, hence, to rule, be master, prevail (so chiefly in cl.; in LXX: Es 1:1, I Es 4:38, Wi 14:19, al.).; to get possession of, obtain, take hold of (Hdt., Thuc., al.): c. gen. rei (M, Pr., 65), Ac 27:13; τ. χειρός, Mt 9:25, Mk 1:31 5:41 9:27, Lk 8:54; c. acc rei, Mt 12:11; c. acc pers., Mt 14:3 18:28 21:46 22:6 26:4, 48 ff., Mk 3:21 6:17 12:12 14:1, 44 ff, Ac 3:11 24:6, Re 20:2 (cf. II Ki 6:6).; to hold, hold fast (Æsch., Polyb., al.): c. acc rei, ἐν τ. δεξιᾷ, Re 2:1. Metaph.: c. acc pers., pass., Ac 2:24; c. acc rei, Re 2:13, 25 3:11; τ. κεφαλήν (i.e. Christ), Col 2:19; τ. παράδοσιν (-εις), λόγον, διδαχήν, Mk 7:3-4, 8 9:10, II Th 2:15, Re 2:14-15; c. gen. rei, He 4:14 6:18; of sins, to retain, Jo 20:23; of re­straint, seq. ἵνα μή, Re 7:1; pass., seq. τοῦ μή, Lk 24:16.†

superl, of κρατύς (Hom.),; strongest, mightiest (Hom.).; noblest, best (cf. κρείσσων), most excellent (find., Soph., al.): voc., κρατίστε, as title of honour and respect (DCG, ii, 727a), Lk 1:3, Ac 23:26 24:3 26:25.†

strength, esp. as in Hom., of bodily strength.; power, might: He 2:14; τὸ κ. τῆς ἰσχύος αὐτοῦ, Eph 1:19 6:10 (Is 40:26, Da TH Da 4:27); τ. δόςης αὐτοῦ, Col 1:11; κατὰ κράτος, mightily, Ac 19:20; a mighty deed, an act of power, Lk 1:51; in doxologies, I Ti 6:16, I Pe 4:11 5:11, Ju 25, Re 1:6 5:13.†

of animals, to bay, to croak, etc.; Of men, to cry out, shout: Mt 12:19, Jo 12:13 19:15 Ac 22:23; seq. λέγων, Jo 18:40 19:6, 12; καὶ λέγων, Lk 4:41 (WH, κράζ -); φωνῇ μεγάλῃ, Jo 11:43 (cf. Abbott, JV, 269 f.).†
crying, outcry, clamour: Mt 25:6, Lk 1:42, Ac 23:9, Eph 4:31, He 5:7, Re 21:4.†
flesh, meat: Ro 14:21, I Co 8:13.†

better; as to ad­vantage or usefulness: I Co 11:17, He 11:40 12:24; πολλῷ μᾶλλον κ., Phl 1:23; κρεῖσσον ποιεῖν, I Co 7:38; ἐστιν, seq. inf., I Co 7:9, II Pe 2:21; as to excellence: He 1:4 6:9 7:7, 19 7:22 8:6 9:23 10:34 11:16, 35; κ. ἐστι, seq. inf., I Pe 3:17.†

trans., to hang, suspend: c. acc pers., seq. ἐπὶ ξύλου, Ac 5:30 10:39; pass., Lk 23:39; seq. περί, Mt 18:6. Mid., κρέμαμαι, intrans., to hang: seq. ἐκ, Ac 28:4; ἐπὶ ξύλου, Ga 3:13 (LXX); metaph., seq. ἐν, Mt 22:40.†
a steep bank: Mt 8:32, Mk 5:13, Lk 8:33.†
a Cretan: Ac 2:11, Tit 1:12.†
Crescens: II Ti 4:10.†
barley: pl. (as usually in cl.), Re 6:6.†
of barley: Jo 6:9, 13

the issue of a judicial process, hence,; judgment, the decision passed on the faults of others: Mt 7:2; in forensic sense, c. gen. pun., Lk 24:20; esp. of the judgment of God, Ro 2:2 5:16 11:33 (ICC, in l), II Pe 2:3, Ju 4; κ. λαμβάνεσθαι, Mt 23:13 (Rec., R, mg.), Mk 12:40, Lk 20:47, Ro 13:2, Ja 3:1; ἔχειν, I Ti 5:12; βαστάζειν, Ga 5:10; ἐσθίειν ἑαυτῷ, I Co 11:29; εἰς κ. συνέρχεσθαι, I Co 11:34; εἶναι ἐν τ αὐτῷ κ., Lk 23:40; c. gen. obj., Ro 3:8, I Ti 3:6, Re 17:1; of God's judgment through Christ, Jo 9:39; τὸ κ. ἄρχεται, I Pe 4:17; τ. κ. τ. μέλλον, Ac 24:25; κ. αἰώνιον, He 6:2; ἔκρινεν ὁ Θεὸς τ. κ. ὐμῶν, Re 18:20; of the right of judgment, Re 20:4.; a matter for judgment, a law-suit, a case: I Co 6:7.†
a lily: Mt 6:28, Lk 12:27.†

to separate, select, choose (cl.; in LXX: II Mac 13:15). to approve, esteem: Ro 14:5. to be of opinion, judge, think: Lk 7:43, I Co 11:13; seq. τοῦτο ὅτι, II Co 5:14; c. acc. et inf., Ac 16:15; c. acc. et pred., Ac 13:46 26:8. to decide, determine, decree: c. acc., Ac 16:4, Ro 14:13, I Co 7:37, II Co 2:1; c. inf. (Field, Notes, 167), Ac 20:16 25:25, I Co 2:2 5:3, Tit 3:12 (cf. I Mac 11:33, Wi 8:9, al.); c. acc. et inf., Ac 21:25 27:1. to judge, adjudge, pronounce judgment: absol., Jo 8:16, 26; seq. κατά, c. acc., Jo 7:24 8:15; κρίσιν κ., Jo 7:24; τ. δίκαιον, Lk 12:57 (Deiss., LAE, 118); in forensic sense, Jo 18:31, Ac 23:3, al.; pass., Ro 3:4 (LXX); of God's judgment, Jo 5:30 8:50, Ro 2:16 3:6, II Ti 4:1, I Pe 4:5, al. = κατακρίνω, to condemn (cl.): Ac 13:27; of God's judgment, Jo 3:18 5:22 12:47, 48, Ac 7:7, Ro 2:12, I Co 11:32, He 10:30 (LXX), Ja 5:9, Re 19:2, al. As in LXX (for שׁפט), to rule, govern ( IV Ki 15:5, Ps 2:10, al.): Mt 19:28, Lk 22:30, I Co 6:3. to bring to trial (cl.); mid., to go to law: c. dat. pers., Mt 5:40; seq. μετά, c. gen. pers. (of the opponent), ἐπί, c. gen. (of the judge), I Co 6:1, 6 (cf. ἀνα-, ἀπο-, ἀντ-απο- (-μαι), δια-, ἐν-, ἐπι-, κατα-, συν-, ὑπο- (-μαι), συν-υπο- (-μαι)).

a seperating, selection (Arist., al.); a decision, judgment (cl.): Jo 8:16, I Ti 5:24, II Pe 2:11, Ju 9; κ. κρίνειν, Jo 7:24; in forensic sense, Ac 8:33 (LXX) (v. Page, in l); esp. of the Divine judgment, Jo 3:19 5:24, 27 5:29-30 12:31 16:8, 11, II Th 1:5, He 10:27, Ja 2:13 5:12, II Pe 2:4, Re 18:10; pl., Re 16:7 19:2; of the last judgment, Mt 10:15 11:22, 24 12:36, 41-42 Lk 10:14 11:31-32, He 9:27, II Pe 2:9 3:7, I Jn 4:17, Ju 6 15; τῆς γεέννης, Mt 23:33.; By meton. (as in LXX for מִשְׁפָּט, Is 5:7, al.; דִּישׁוֹן, Da 7:10), of the standard of judgment, right, justice: Mt 12:18, 20 (LXX, Isa 42:43) Isa 23:23, Lk 11:42; of the tribunal (a local court), Mt 5:21-22†
Crispus: Ac 18:8, I Co 1:14.†
a means of judging, test, criterion.; a tribunal: I Co 6:2 6:4, Ja 2:6.†

a judge: Mt 5:25, Lk 12:14, 58 18:2; τ. ἀδικίας, Lk 18:6; c. gem rei (obj.), Ac 18:15, Ja 4:11; (qual.), διαλογισμῶν πονηρῶν, Ja 2:4; of a Roman procurator, Ac 24:10; of God, He 12:23, Ja 4:12; Christ, Ac 10:42, II Ti 4:8, Ja 5:9; of those whose conduct is made a standard for judging, Mt 12:27, Lk 11:19; in the OT sense (Jg 2:16, Ru 1:1, al), of a ruler in Israel, Ac 13:20.†
critical, able to discern or judge: c. gen. obj., He 4:12.†
c, acc, τ. αὐλαίαν, Jth 14:14 * ;]; to strike, knock: at a door (Κόπτειν, in Att..), Mt 7:7-8, Lk 11:9-10 12:36, Ac 12:16, Re 3:20; c. acc, τ. θύραν, Lk 13:25, Ac 12:13.†
a crypt, cellar: Lk 11:33.†

hidden, secret: Mt 10:26, Mk 4:22, Lk 8:17 12:2; ὁ κ. τῆς καρδίας ἄνθρωπος, I Pe 3:4; neut., ἐν τῷ κ., Mt 6:4, 6; ἐν κ., Jo 7:4, 10 18:20; ὁ ἐν κ. Ἰουδαῖος, Ro 2:29; pl., τὰ κ. τ. σκότους, I Co 4:5; τ. ἀνθρώπων, Ro 2:16; τ. καρδίας, I Co 14:25; τ. αἰσχύνης, II Co 4:2.†; κρυφαῖος, -αία, -αῖον; hidden, secret: ἐν τῷ κ., Mt 6:18.†

to hide, conceal: c. acc, Mt 13:44 25:18; seq. ἐν, Mt 25:25 (pass., Mt 13:44, Col 3:3); pass., Mt 5:14, He 11:23, I Ti 5:25, Re 2:17; ἐκρύβη (on the tense and its formation, v. M, Pr., 161; Bl., § 19, 3) κ. ἐξῆλθεν Jo 8:59; seq. εἰς, Lk 13:21, Re 6:15; ἀπό (in cl. more freq. dupl. acc), Re 6:16; pass., Jo 12:36, (Bl., § 34, 4). Metaph.: Mt 11:25 13:35, Lk 11:52, WH, mg., Lk 18:34 19:42, Jo 19:38 (cf.ἀτο-, ἐν-, περι-κρύπτω).†
to shine like crystal, be crystal-clear: Re 21:11 (ἅπ, λεγ.).†
crystal: Re 4:6 22:1.†
secretly, in secret: Eph 5:12.†

in pres., impf., fut. and aor., to procure for oneself, get, gain, acquire (the pf. and plpf., to have acquired, hence to possess, do not occur in NT): c. acc rei, Mt 10:9, Lk 18:12, Ac 8:20; c. gen. pret., Ac 22:28; ἐκ c. gen. pret., Ac 1:18; τ,ψυχὰς ὑμῶν (MM, xvi), Lk 21:19; τ. ἑαυτοῦ σκεῦος κτᾶσθαι, I Th 4:4 (where if σ. = body, κ. must = pf., κέκτημαι; v. MM, xvi; M, Th., in l; Field, Notes, 72 f. But σ. is most freq. taken as = wife; v. Thayer, s.v.; Lft., Notes, 53 ff.; ICC, in l).†
a possession, property: Mt 19:22, Mk 10:22, Ac 2:45 5:1.†
a beast, (in late Gk. esp.) a beast of burden: Lk 10:34 pl. (as chiefly in cl.), Ac 23:24, Re 18:13; of quadrupeds, as Opp. to fishes and birds (cf. Ge, l.c.), I Co 15:39.†
a possessor: Ac 4:34.†

in cl., to people or found a region or city (1Es, l.c.).; In LXX and NT, of God, to create: Mk 13:19, I Co 11:9, Col 1:16 3:10 Eph 3:9, I Ti 4:3, Re 4:11 10:6; ὁ κτίσας, Mt 19:4 (WH, R, mg.), Ro 1:25; of the divine operation on the soul, Eph 2:10, 15 4:24 (cf. Ps., l.c.).†

a founding, settling, foundation (cl.).; In LXX and NT,; the act of creating, creation: Mk 10:6 (Swete, in l), Mk 13:19, Ro 1:20, II Pe 3:4; that which has been created, creation: Ro 1:25 8:39, He 4:13; καινὴ κ., II Co 5:17, Ga 6:15; πάσῃ ἀνθρωπίνῃ κ. (Hort., in l), I Pe 2:13; collectively, of the sum of created things (Wi 19:6, Jth 16:14), Mk 16:15, Col 1:15, 23 He 9:11, Re 3:14; of the irrational creation, Ro 8:19-22.†
(cl.) a colony.; a created thing, creature: I Ti 4:4, Ja 1:18, Re 5:13 8:9.†
(cl.) a founder.; a creator: of God, I Pe 4:19.†
steering, pilotage (Plat.).; Metaph., government: pl., I Co 12:28.†
a steersman, pilot: Ac 27:11, Re 18:17.; Metaph., a guide, governor (Eur., Plat.).†
dice-playing; metaph., trickery, sleight: Eph 4:14.†
to make a circle, go round.; to encircle, surround: c. acc pers., Jo 10:24 (Tr., WH, mg.); c. acc rei, Re 20:9.†
from all sides, round about: Re 4:3-4, 8,†
a ring, circle. Dat., κύκλῳ, as adverb., round about, around: Mk 3:34 6:6, 36, Lk 9:12, Ro 15:19; c. gen., Re 4:6 5:11 7:11†
to move in a circle, revolve.; to surround, encircle: c. acc pers., Jo 10:24 (WH, txt., cf. -εύω), Ac 14:20; pass., Lk 21:20, He 11:30 (cf. περι-κυκλόω).†
a roll.; = κυλισμός (q.v.), a rolling, wallowing (or, as κυλίστρα, Xen., Eq., v. 3, a rolling place): II Pe 2:22 (Rec.).†
= cl. κύλισις, a rolling, wallowing: II Pe 2:22 (cf. κύλισμα)†
to roll, roll along. Pass., to be rolled; of persons (in Hom, as sign of grief), to roll or wallow: Mk 9:20.†
crooked, crippled: Mt 15:30-31 (WH, txt. om.); maimed: Mt 18:8, Mk 9:43.†
a wave: pl., Mt 8:24 14:24, Mk 4:37; κ. θαλάσσης, fig., Ju 13.†
a cymbal: I Co 13:1.†
cummin: Mt 23:23.†
a little dog: Mt 15:26-27 Mk 7:27-28 †
of Cyprus, Cyprian: Ac 4:36 11:20 21:16.†
to bow the head, stoop down: Mk 1:7; seq. κάτω, Jo 8:6, 8 (cf. ἀνα-, παρα-, συν-κύπτω).†; κατα-κύπτω,; to bend down, stoop: Jo 8:8 (κάτω κύψας, Rec., WH, mg.).†
of Cyrene, a Cyrenæan: Mt 27:32, Mk 15:21, Lk 23:2, Ac 6:9 11:20 13:1.†
Cyrene, a city in Libya: Ac 2:10.†
Quirinus, prop. Quirinius: Lk 2:2.†
a lady: II Jn 1 Jn 5 (on the interpretation, v. ICC, 167 ff.).†

as freq. in Inscr. (LS, s.v.; Deiss., BS, 217 f.), of the lord or master, imperial.; of the Lord (i.e. Christ): δεῖπνον, I Co 11:20; ἡμέρα, Re 1:10. (cf. λόγια κ., Papias, Eus., HE, iii, 39, 1; γραφαὶ κ., Clem. Alex., etc; for eccl. usage, cf. Soph., Lex., s.v.)†
to be lord or master of, to rule (over): C. gen. obj., Lk 22:25, Ro 14:9, II Co 1:24; absol., I Ti 6:15; metaph., ὁ θάνατος, Ro 6:9; ἡ ἁμαρτία, Ro 6:14; ὁ νόμος, Ro 7:1 (cf. κατα-κυριεύω).†

having power (κῦρος) or authority; as subst., ὁ κ., lord, master; in general: c. gen. rei, Mt 9:38 20:8, Mk 12:9 13:35, Lk 19:33; τ. σαββάτου, Mt 12:8, Mk 2:28, Lk 6:5; c. gen. pers., δούλου, etc., Mt 10:24, Lk 14:21, Ac 16:16, al.; absol, opp. to οἱ δοῦλοι, Eph 6:5, 9 al.; of the Emperor (Deiss., LAE, 161), Ac 25:26; θεοὶ πολλοὶ καὶ κ. πολλοί, I Co 8:5; of a husband, I Pe 3:6; in voc, as a title of respect to masters, teachers, magistrates, etc., Mt 13:27 16:22 27:63, Mk 7:28, Lk 5:12, Jo 4:11, Ac 9:5, al. As a divine title (freq. in π.; Deiss., LAE, 353 ff.); in NT, of God: ὁ κ., Mt 5:33, Mk 5:19, Lk 1:6, Ac 7:33, He 8:2, Ja 4:15, al.; anarth. (Bl., §46, 6), Mt 21:9, Mk 13:20, Lk 1:17, He 7:21, I Pe 1:25, al.; κ. τ. οὐρανοῦ καὶ τ. γῆς, Mt 11:25; τ. κυριευόντων, I Ti 6:15; κ. ὁ θεός, Mt 4:7, 10 al.; id. seq. παντοκράτωρ, Re 4:8; κ. σαβαώθ, Ro 9:29; (ὁ) ἄγγελος κυρίου, Mt 1:20 2:13, Lk 1:11, al.; πνεῦμα κυρίου, Lk 4:18, Ac 8:39; of the Christ: Mt 21:3, Mk 11:3, Lk 1:43 20:44, al.; of Jesus after his resurrection (Dalman, Words, 330), Ac 10:36, Ro 14:8, I Co 7:22, Eph 4:5, al.; ὁ κ. μου, Jo 20:28; ὁ κ. Ἰησοῦς, Ac 1:21, I Co 11:23, al.; id. seq. Χριστός, Eph 1:2, al.; ὁ κ. ἡμῶν, I Ti 1:14, He 7:14, al.; id. seq. Ἰησοῦς, I Th 3:11, He 13:20, al.; Χριστός, Ro 16:18; Ἰ Χ., I Co 1:2, I Th 1:3, al.; Ἰ. Χ. (Χ. Ἰ) ὁ κ. (ἡμῶν), Ro 1:4, Col 2:6, Eph 3:11, al.; ὁ κ. καὶ ὁ σωτὴρ, II Pe 3:2; id. seq. Ἰ. Χ., ib. 18; anarth., I Co 7:22, 25 Ja 5:4, al.; κ. κυρίων, Re 19:16; c. prep., ἀπὸ (κατὰ, πρὸς, σὺν, etc.) κ., Col 3:24, al.
lordship, dominion: Eph 1:21, II Pe 2:10, Ju 8; pl., Col 1:16 (cf. Lft., Col,; Mayor, Ju., in ll.; DB, i, 616 f.).†
to confirm, ratify, make valid: II Co 2:8; pass., Ga 3:15 (cf. προ-κυρόω).†
a dog: Lk 16:21, II Pe 2:22; metaph., as a word of reproach, Mt 7:6, Phl 3:2, Re 22:15.†
a limb, member of a body,; hence, carcase: He 3:17 (LXX).†

to hinder, re­strain, forbid, withhold: c. acc et inf., Mt 19:14, Lk 23:2, Ac 8:36 16:6 24:23, I Th 2:16, He 7:23; inf. om., Mk 9:38-39 10:14, Lk 9:49-50 11:52 18:16, Ac 11:17, Ro 1:13, III Jn 10; acc om., I Ti 4:3; c. acc pers. et gen. rei, Ac 27:43; c. acc rei, I Co 14:39, II Pe 2:16; id. seq. τοῦ μή, Ac 10:47; id. seq. ἀπό (like Heb. מִן כָּלָא, Ge 23:6, al.), Lk 6:29 (cf. δια-κωλύω).†

a village or country town, prop, as opp. to a walled city: Mt 14:15, Mk 6:6, al.; πόλεις καὶ κ., Mt 9:35, al.; with the name added, Βηθλεέμ, Jo 7:42; Βηθανΐα, Jo 11:1; with the name of the district, τὰς κ. Καισαρίας, Mk 8:27; Σαμαρειτῶν, Lk 9:52, Ac 8:25
a country town: Mk 1:38 (v. Swete, in l).†
a revel, carousal: Ro 13:13, Ga 5:21, I Pe 4:3.†
a gnat: Mt 23:24.†
Cos, an island in the Ægean Sea: acc Κῶ, Ac 21:1 (Κῶν, Rec.).†
Cosam: Lk 3:28.†
blunt, dull. Metaph., of the senses, esp.; of speech, dumb: Mt 9:32-33 12:22 15:30-31, Lk 1:22 11:14; of hearing, deaf: Mt 11:5, Mk 7:32, 37 9:25, Lk 7:22.†
lambda, l, the eleventh letter. As a numeral, λ' = 30; λ, = 30,000.
to obtain by lot, to obtain (in cl., c. gen.): c. inf. art. (B1., § 36, 3; 71, 3), Lk 1:9; c. acc rei, Ac 1:17, II Pe 1:1.; to draw lots: seq. περί, Jo 19:24
colloquial abbreviation of Ἐλεαζάρ (άζαρος), q.v.),; Lazarus; of Bethany: Jo 11:1 ff. Jo 12:1-2, 9-10 12:17.; The beggar in the parable: Lk 16:20, 23-25.†
a hurricane, whirlwind: Mk 4:37, Lk 8:23, II Pe 2:17.†
to kick: Ac 26:14.†

to utter: of inanimate things, Re 4:1 10:4; metaph., He 11:4 12:24. to talk, speak, say: absol., Mt 9:33 12:46, Mk 5:35, Lk 8:49; seq. ὡς, I Co 13:11, Re 13:11; εἰς, I Co 14:9; ἐκ, Mt 12:34; c. acc. rei, Mt 10:19, Mk 11:32, Jo 8:30, al.; c. dat. pers., Mt 12:46, Lk 24:6, Ro 7:1, al.; c. acc. rei et dat. pers., Mt 9:18, Jo 10:6, al.; c. prep., πρός, μετά, περί, Mk 6:50, Lk 1:19 2:33, al.; ἐν, ἐξ, ἀπό, Mt 13:3, Jo 12:49 14:10, al.; λ. τ. λόγον, Mk 8:32, al.; seq. orat. dir. (not cl.), Mk 14:31, He 5:5 11:18; Hebraistically (Dalman, Words, 25f.), ἐλάλησε λέγων, Mt 14:27, Jo 8:12, Ac 8:26, al.
loquacity = Very talkative.; talk, speech, conversation: Mt 26:73 (cf. Ca 43), Jo 4:42 8:43.†
why: Mt 27:46 (WH, mg., λεμά TTr., WH, txt., λεμά L), Mk 15:34 (λεμά LT, λαμμᾶ, Rec.).†

to take, lay hold of: absol., Mt 26:26, Mk 14:22; c. acc. rei, Mt 5:40 26:52, al. mult.; c. acc. pers., Mt 21:35, Mk 12:3, al.; pleonastic λαβών (M, Pr., 230; Bl., §74, 2), Mt 13:31 14:19, al.; so also indic., Mk 7:27, Jo 19:1, 40 Re 8:5, al.; metaph., c. acc. rei, ἀφορμήν, Ro 7:8, 11; ὑδόδειγμα, Ja 5:10; id. c. acc. pers., φόβος, Lk 7:16; πνεῦμα, Lk 9:39; πειρασμός, I Co 10:13; aoristic pf. (M, Pr., 145, 238; BL, §59, 4), Re 5:7 8:5, al. to receive: absol., opp. to αἰτεῖν, Mt 7:8, al.; διδόναι, Mt 10:8, Ac 20:35; c. acc. rei, Mt 27:6, Mk 10:3o, al. mult.; c. acc. pers., Jo 6:21 13:20 19:27, II Jo 10; ῥαπίσμασιν (a vulgarism; Bl., §38, 3), Mk 14:65; metaph., τ. λόγον, Mt 13:20, Mk 4:16; τ. μαρτυρίαν, Jo 3:11; τ. ῥήματα, Jo 12:48; πρόσωπον (Heb. נָשָׂא פָּנִים, Dalman, Words, 30), Lk 20:21, Ga 2:6; ζωὴν αἰώνιον (Dalman, op. cit., 124f.), Mk 10:30 (cf. ἀνα-, ἀντι-, συν-αντι- (-μαι), ἀπο-, ἐπι-, κατα-, μετα-, παρα-, συν-παρα-, προ-, προσ-, συν-, συν-περι-, ὑπο-λαμβάνω).
Lamech (Ge 5:25): Lk 3:36.†
a torch (freq. fed, like a lamp, with oil): Mt 25:1 ff., Jo 18:3, Ac 20:8, Re 4:5 8:10.†
bright, brilliant: ποταμός, Re 22:1 (ΕΥ, clear); ἀστήρ, Re 22:16; of clothing, brilliant, splendid: Lk 23:11, Ac 10:30, Ja 2:2-3, Re 15:6 18:14 19:8.†
brightness, brilliancy: τ. ἡλίου, Ac 26:13.†
splendidly: of sumptuous fare (as freq.; cf. ἐδέσματα λαμπρά, Si 29:22), Lk 16:19.†
to shine: Mt 5:15-16 17:2, Lk 17:24, Ac 12:7, II Co 4:6 (cf. ἐκ-, περι-λάμπω).†

to escape notice, be hidden (from): Mk 7:24, Lk 8:47; c. acc pers., Ac 26:26, II Pe 3:5 3:8; as in common cl. idiom, seq. ptcp., ἔλαθον ξενίσαντες, entertained unawares, He 13:2 (cf. ἐκ-, ἐπι-λανθάνω).†
hewn (in stone); Lk 23:53 (elsewhere κοινή writers use λατομητός, IV Ki 12:12, al.; cf. λατομέω).†
a Laodicean: Col 4:16.†
Laodicea, a city on the Lycus in Phrygia: Col 2:1 4:13, 15-16, Re 1:11 3:14.†

a word rarely found in Att. prose; the people at large (Hom., al.), esp. of people assembled: Mt 27:25, Lk 1:21 3:15 al.; pl. (Hom., al., π.; v. MM, xvi), Ac 4:27. a people, those of the same race and language (Pind., Æsch., al.: in LXX, Ge 26:11, Ex 9:16, al.): joined with γλῶσσα, φυλή, ἔθνος, Re 5:9 7:9 11:9, al.; pl., Lk 2:31, Ro 15:11; esp. as almost always in LXX, of Israel, Mt 4:23, Mk 7:6, Lk 2:10, Jo 11:50, He 2:17, al.; opp. to τ. ἔθνη, Ac 26:17, 23 Ro 15:10; πρεσβύτεροι (πρῶτοι, etc.) τοῦ λ., Mt 21:23, Lk 19:17, Ac 4:8, al.; ὁ λ. μου (αὐτοῦ, τ. θεοῦ), Mt 2:6, Lk 1:68, He 11:25, al.; of the people disting. from the rulers and priests ( I Es 1:10, Jth 8:9, al.), Mt 26:5, Lk 20:19, He 5:3, al.; of Christians, as the people of God, Ac 15:14, Ro 9:25, 26 He 4:9; περιούσιος, Tit 2:14; εἰς περιποίησιν, I Pe 2:9 (LXX).
the larynx, throat: metaph., of speech (cf. Si 6:5), Ro 3:13 (LXX).†
Lasea, a city of Crete, otherwise un­known: Ac 27:8.†

(in cl., poët.) to clang, crash, crack; in late prose, to crack or burst noisily: Ac 1:18 (ἐλάκησεν, perh., however, from λακέω, q.v.; Bl., in l).; (in cl., prose) to scream, shout.†; λακέω, Dor. for ληκέω = λάσκω, q.v
to hew, hew out stones: Mt 27:60, Mk 15:46.†
hired service, service.; (in cl. also) divine service, worship: Jo 16:2, Ro 9:4 12:1, He 9:1, 6.†

to work for hire.; to serve; in cl., also of divine service, to serve, worship, and so always in NT: c. dat. pers., τ. θεῷ, Mt 4:10, Lk 4:8 (LXX), Ac 7:7 24:14 27:23, He 9:14, Re 7:15 22:3; of idol worship (cf. Ex 20:5, Ez 20:32), Ac 7:42, Ro 1:25; τ. θεῷ. ἐν τ. πνεύματί μου, Ro 1:9; id. ἐν καθαρᾷ συνειδήσει, II Ti 1:3; μετ' εὐλαβείας κ. δέους, He 12:28; ἐν ὁσιότητι κ. δικαιοσύνῃ, Lk 1:74; (without θεῷ) νηστείαις κ. δεήσεσι, Lk 2:37; πνεύματι θεοῦ, Phl 3:3; absol., Ac 26:7; ὁ λατρεύων, the worshipper, He 9:9 10:2; of ministerial service, c. dat. rei, He 8:5 13:10.†
a garden herb, vegetable: Lk 11:42; usually in pl., Mt 13:32, Mk 4:32, Ro 14:2.†
Lebbæus: Mt 10:3, Mk 3:18 (WH, mg.; Θαδδαῖος, q.v., Rec., WH, txt., RV, cf. WH, App., 11, 24. In Lk 6:15, Ac 1:13, he is called Σίμων ὁ Ζηλωτής.)†

in Hom., to pick out, gather, reckon, recount. In Hdt. and Att., to say, speak, affirm, declare: absol., Ac 13:15, 24:10; seq. orat. dir., Mt 9:34, Mk 3:11, Jo 1:29, al.; seq. ὅτι recit., Mk 3:21, Lk 1:24, Jo 6:14, al.; acc. et. inf., Lk 11:18, Jo 12:29, al.; after another verb of speaking, προσφωνεῖν κ. λέγειν, Mt 11:17, al.; ἀπεκρίθη (ἐλάλησεν) λέγων (καὶ λέγει; Dalman, Words, 24 ff.), Mt 25:9, Mk 3:33, 7:28, Lk 24:6, 7, al.; of unspoken thought, λ. ἐν ἑαυτῷ, Mt 3:9, Lk 3:8, al.; of writing, II Co 8:8, Phl 4:11, al.; λέγει ἡ γραφή, Ro 4:3, Ja 2:23, al.; c. acc. rei, Lk 8:8, 9:33, Jo 5:34, al.; σὺ λέγεις (a non-committal phrase; Swete, Mk., 359, 369f.), Mt 27:11, Mk 15:2, Lk 23:3, Jo 18:37; c. dat. pers., seq. orat. dir., Mt 8:20, Mk 2:17, al. mult.; id. seq. ὅτι, Mt 3:9, al.; c. prep., πρός, μετά, περί, etc., Mk 4:41, Jo 11:56, He 9:5, al.; to mean (cl.), Mk 14:71, Jo 6:71, I Co 10:29, al.; to call, name, Mk 10:18; pass., Mt 9:9, Mk 15:7, al (cf. ἀντι-, δια- (-μαι), προ-, συλ-λέγω).
a remnant: Ro 11:5.†
smooth: opp. to τραχύς, Lk 3:5 (LXX).†

trans., to leave, leave behind; pass., to be left behind, to lack seq. prep. (as more usual in cl.), ἐν, Ja 1:4; c. gen. rei, Ja 1:5 2:15.; Intrans., to be gone, to be wanting: c. dat. pers., Lk 18:22, Tit 3:13; τὰ λείποντα, Tit 1:5; (cf. ἀπο-, δια-, ἐκ-, ἐπι-, κατα-, ἐν-κατα-, περι-, ὑπο-λείπω).†

in cl., at Athens, to supply public offices at one's own cost, render public service to the State, hence, generally,; to serve the State, do a service, serve (of service to the Gods, Diod., i, 21): of the official service of priests and Levites (Ex 29:30, Nu 16:9, Si 4:14, I Mac 10:42, al.; cf. Deiss., BS, 140 f.), He 10:11; of Christians: c. dat. pers. seq. ἐν, Ro 15:27 (cf. Si 10:25); τ. κυρίῳ, Ac 13:2.†

in cl. (chiefly of Athens), the discharge of a public office at one's own expense (v. LS, s.v.), hence,; a service, ministry; in π. (Deiss., BS, 140 f.) and in LXX (though here also of secular service, III Ki 1:4, al.), of religious service or ministration; and so in NT: of priestly ministrations, Lk 1:23, He 8:6 9:21; fig., θυσία καὶ λ. τῆς πίστεως ὑμῶν, Phl 2:17; of Christian beneficence, II Co 9:12, Phl 2:30.†
of or for service, ministering: πνεύματα, He 1:14.†

in cl., one who discharges a public office at his own expense, then, generally,; a public servant, a minister, servant: τ. ἁγίων λ., He 8:2 (cf. Ne 10:39, Sir, l.c.); Ἰησοῦ Χριστοῦ, Ro 15:16; pl., τ. θεοῦ, Ro 13:6, He 1:7 (LXX); λ. ὑμῶν τ. χρείας μου, Phl 2:25.†
a linen cloth, towel: Jo 13:4-5.†
a scale: Ac 9:18†
leprosy: Mt 8:3, Mk 1:42, Lk 5:12-13†
(in cl.) scaly, rough.; leprous; chiefly as subst., ὁ λ., a leper: Mt 8:2 10:8 11:5, Mk 1:40, Lk 4:27 7:22 17:12; of Simon, formerly a leper, Mt 26:6, Mk 14:3.†
peeled.; fine, thin, small, light; hence, in late Gk., as subst. τὸ λ., a small coin (one-eighth of an as, AV, mite): Mk 12:42, Lk 12:59 21:2.†
Levi; the son of Jacob: He 7:5, 9, Re 7:7.; Son of Melchi: Lk 3:24.; Son of Simeon: Lk 3:29.; Son of Alphæus (cf. Μαθθαῖος): Mk 2:14 (WH, mg., Ἰάκωβον), Lk 5:27, 29.†
a Levite: Lk 10:32, Jo 1:19, Ac 4:36.†
Levitical: He 7:11.†
to whiten, make white: c. acc rei, Mk 9:3, Re 7:14.†

white linen: Re 19:14 (WH, mg.).†; λευκός, ή, -όν; bright, brilliant: of clothing, Mt 17:2, Mk 9:3 16:5, Lk 9:29, Ac 1:10, Re 3:5 4:4 6:11 7:9, 13 19:14 (cf. Ec 9:8); ὡς χιών, Mt 28:3; ἐν λ.. (sc. ἱματίοις), Jo 20:12, Re 3:4; θρόνος, Re 20:11.; white: Mt 5:36, Re 1:14 2:17 4:4 6:2 14:14 19:11; fig., of garments, Re 3:18; of ripened grain, Jo 4:35.†
forgetfulness: λ. λαβεῖν (on the phrase, v. Mayor, in l): II Pe 1:9.†
receiving: δόσις καὶ λ., Phl 4:15.†
a trough or vat; esp. for the treading of grapes: Mt 21:33, Re 14:20 19:16; τὴν λ. . . . τὸν μέγαν (a solecism perhaps inadvertent), Re 14:19 (cf. ὑπολήνιον).†
silly talk, nonsense: Lk 24:11.†
very, exceedingly: Mt 2:16 4:8 8:28 27:14 Mk 1:35 6:51 (Rec. λ. ἐκ περισσοῦ) Mk 9:3 16:2, Lk 23:8, II Ti 4:15, II Jn 4, III Jn 3 (cf. ὑτερλίαν).†
in cl., the frankincense-tree.; (Occas. in cl.) frankincense (so Le 2:1; cf. λιβανωτός): Mt 2:11, Re 18:13.†
in cl. (and LXX), frankincense, the gum of the libanus.; = Late Gk., λιβανωτρίς, a censer: Re 8:3, 5 (the same form appears in Inscr.; MM, xvi).†
a freedman: ἡ συναγωγὴ ἡ λεγομένη Λιβερτίνων Ac 6:9 (Bl. thinks the original reading was Λιβυστίνων, Phil. Gosp., 69 f.).†
Libya: Ac 2:10.†

to throw stones (Arist., Polyb., al.).; = λιθοβολέω (LXX, NT), to pelt with stones, to stone: c. acc pers., Jo 8:6 10:31-31 11:8, Ac 14:10; pass., Ac 5:26, II Co 11:25, He 11:37 (v. DB, Art., " Crimes and punish­ments," and cf. κατα-λιθάζω).†
of stone: Jo 2:6, II Co 3:3, Re 9:20.†
to pelt with stones, to kill by stoning, to stone (cf. λιθάζω): c. acc pers., Mt 21:35 23:37, Lk 13:34 Ac 7:58-59 14:5; pass., He 12:20 (LXX).†

a stone: Mt 4:6, al.; pl., Mt 3:9, al.; at the entrance of a tomb, Mt 27:60, 66 28:2, Mk 15:46 16:3-4, Lk 24:2, Jo 11:38, 32 11:41 20:1; λ. μυλικός, Lk 17:2, cf. Re 18:21; of building stones, Mt 21:42, [44], Mt 24:2, Mk 12:10 13:1-2, Lk 19:44 20:17-18 21:5-6 Ac 4:11, I Pe 2:7; metaph., of Christ, λ. ἀκρογωναῖος, ἐκλεκτός, ἔντιμος, I Pe 2:6 (LXX); λ. ζῶν, I Pe 2:4; προσκόμματος, I Pe 2:8, Ro 9:33; of Christians, λ. ζῶντες, I Pe 2:5; of precious stones, λ. τίμιος, Re 17:4 18:12, 16 21:11, 19; ἴασπις, Re 4:3; ἐνδεδυμένοι λ. καθαρόν, Re 15:6 (λίνον, Rec., R, mg., v. Swete, in l); metaph., λ. τίμιοι, I Co 3:12; of the tables of the law, II Co 3:7; of idols, Ac 17:29
paved with stones, esp. of tessallated work (Ca, i.e.); as subst., τὸ λ., a tessallated pavement: Jo 19:13 (cf. Γαββαθᾶ).†

in cl., to winnow (so Ru, l.c.).; In LXX (ll c., exc. Ru), to scatter (as chaff or dust): Lk 20:18 (RV, scatter as dust, Deiss., BS, 225 f., quotes ex. in π. which suggests the meaning ruin, destroy; cf. Vg. comminuet, AV, grind to powder; cf. also Kennedy, Sources, 126), Mt 21:44 [WH], R, txt.†
a harbour, haven: Ac 27:8, 12 (cf. Καλοὶ Λιμένες).†
a lake: of the Sea of Galilee (Mt, Mk, v.s. θάλασσα), Lk 5:2 8:22-23, 33; λ. Γεννησαρέτ (q.v.), Lk 5:1; λ. τ. πυρός, Re 19:20 20:10, 14-15; καιομένη πυρί, Re 21:8.†
hunger, famine: Lk 4:25 15:14, 17, Ac 7:11 (LXX) Ac 11:28, Ro 8:35, Re 6:8 18:8; λ. καὶ δίψος, II Co 11:27; pl., Mt 24:7, Mk 13:8, Lk 21:11.†
flax: Mt 12:20 (LXX).; linen: Re 15:6 (R, mg., v.s. λίθος).†
Linus: II Ti 4:21.†
oily, fatty; metaph., of living, rich, dainty: τὰ λ. καὶ τ. λαμπρά, Re 18:14.†
a Sicilian coin = Rom. libra or as.; In weight, a pound: Jo 12:3 19:39.†
the SW. wind: βλέποντα κατὰ λ., Ac 27:12 (v. Page, in l; Deiss., ES, 141).†
a collection: I Co 16:1-2.†

prop., of numerical calculation, to count, reckon: c. acc seq. μετά, Mk 15:23 (LXX) (Rec., R, mg.), Lk 22:37.; Metaph., without reference to numbers, by a reckoning of characteristics or reasons; to reckon, take into account: c. acc rei, I Co 13:5; id. seq. dat. pers., Ro 4:3 (LXX), Ro 4:4, 6 4:8 (LXX), II Co 5:19, II Ti 4:16; seq. εἰς (cf. Heb. ל חָשַׁב; Bl., § 33, 3), Ac 19:27, Ro 2:26 4:3, 5 4:9-11, 22-24 9:8 Ga 3:6 (LXX), Ja 2:23 (LXX); to consider, calculate: c. acc rei, Phl 4:8; seq. ὅτι, Jo 11:50, He 11:10; τοῦτο, ὅτι, II Co 10:11; c. acc pers., c. inf., Ro 6:11; seq. ὡς, Ro 8:36 (LXX); to suppose, judge, deem: I Co 13:11; ὡς, I Pe 5:12; οὕτως, I Co 4:1; c. acc rei, II Co 3:5; id. seq. εἰς, II Co 12:6; ὅτι, Ro 8:18; τοῦτο, ὅτι, Ro 2:3, II Co 10:7; c. inf., II Co 11:5; acc et inf., Ro 3:28 14:14, Phl 3:13; c. acc pers. seq. ὡς, II Co 10:2; to purpose, decide: c. inf. (Eur., Or., 555), II Co 10:2; (cf. ἀνα-, δια-, παρα-, συλ-λογίζομαι).†
reasonable, rational: λατρεία, Ro 12:1; τὸ λ. (i.e. spiritual) γάλα (v. Hort, in l; MM, xvi), I Pe 2:2 (in support of AV, milk of the word, v. ICC, in l).†
an oracle: Ac 7:38, Ro 3:2, He 5:12, I Pe 4:11 (on the eccl., λόγια τ. Κυρίου, v. Lft., Essay on Sup. Rel., 172 ff.).†
in cl., learned (Ac, l.c., R, txt.).; In late Gk., eloquent: Ac 18:24 (v. Page, in l; Field, Notes, 129).†
a reasoning, thought: Ro 2:15, II Co 10:5.†
to strive with words: II Ti 2:14.†
a strife of words: pl., I Ti 6:4.†

Of that by which the inward thought is expressed, Lat. oratio, sermo, vox, verbum. a word, not in the grammatical sense of a mere name (ἔπος, ὄνομα, ῥῆμα), but a word as embodying a conception or idea: Mt 8:8, Lk 7:7, I Co 14:9, 19 He 12:19, al. a saying, statement, declaration: Mt 19:22 (T om.), Mk 5:36 7:29, Lk 1:29, Jo 2:22 6:60, Ac 7:29, al.; c. gen. attrib., Ac 13:15, Ro 9:9, He 7:28, al.; of the sayings, commands, promises, etc., of teachers, Mt 7:24 10:14, Mk 8:38, Lk 9:4, Jo 14:24, al.; λ. κενοί, Eph 5:6; ἀληθινοί, Re 19:9; πιστοί, Re 22:6; esp. of the precepts, decrees and promises of God, ὁ λ. τ. θεοῦ, the word of God: Mk 7:13, Jo 10:35, Ro 13:9, I Co 14:36, Phl 1:14, al.; absol., ὁ λ., Mt 13:21, 22 Mk 16:[20], Lk 1:2, Ac 6:4, He 4:12, al. speech, discourse: Ac 14:12, II Co 10:10, Ja 3:2; opp. to ἐπιστολή, II Th 2:15; disting, from σοφία, I Co 2:1; ἀναστροφή, I Ti 4:12; δύναμις, I Co 4:19, I Th 1:5; ἔργον, Ro 15:18; οὐδενὸς λ. τίμιον (not worthy of mention), Ac 20:24; of the faculty of speech, Lk 24:19, II Co 11:6; of the style of speech, Mt 5:37, I Co 1:5; of instruction, Col 4:3, I Pe 3:1; c. gen. pers., Jo 5:24 8:52, Ac 2:41, al.; ὁ λ. ὁ ἐμός, Jo 8:31; c. gen. obj. (τ.) ἀληθείας, II Co 6:7, Col 1:5, Ja 1:18; τ. καταλλαγῆς, II Co 5:19; τ. σταυροῦ, I Co 1:18; of mere talk, I Co 4:19, 2o, Col 2:23, I Jo 3:18; of the talk which one occasions, hence, repute: Col 2:23. subject-matter, hence, teaching, doctrine: Ac 18:15, II Ti 2:17, al.; esp. of Christian doctrine: Mt 13:20-23, Mk 4:14-20 8:32, Lk 1:2, Ac 8:4, Ga 6:6, I Th 1:6, al.; c. gen. pers., τ. θεοῦ, Lk 5:1, Jo 17:6, Ac 4:29, I Co 14:36, I Jo 1:10, Re 6:9, al.; τ. Κυρίου, Ac 8:25, I Th 1:8, al.; τ. Χριστοῦ, Col 3:16, Re 3:8; c. gen. appos., Ac 15:7; c. gen. attrib., He 5:13. a story, tale, narrative: Mt 28:15, Jo 21:23, Ac 1:1 11:22; seq. περί, Lk 5:15. That which is spoken of (Plat., al.; V. Kennedy, Sources, 124), matter, affair, thing: Mt 21:24, Mk 1:45 11:29, Lk 20:3, Ac 8:21; of a matter in dispute, as a case or suit at law, Ac 19:38; pl. (I Mac 7:33, al.), Lk 1:4. Of the inward thought itself, Lat. ratio. reason, of the mental faculty (Hdt., Plat., al.): κατὰ λόγον, Ac 18:14; a reason, cause: τίνι λόγῳ, Ac 10:29; παρεκτὸς λόγου πορνείας, Mt 5:32 19:9, WH, mg., R, mg. account, regard: Ac 20:24, Rec.; reckoning: Phl 4:15, 17; συναίρειν (q.v.) λ., Mt 18:23 25:19; in forensic sense, Ro 14:12, He 13:17, I Pe 4:5; c. gen. rei, Lk 16:2; seq. περί, Mt 12:36, Ac 19:40, I Pe 3:15. proportion, analogy: Phl 2:16 (Field, Notes, 193 f.). ὁ λ., the Divine Word or Logos: Jo 1:1, 14; τ. ζωῆς, I Jo 1:1; τ. θεοῦ, Re 19:13 (v. Westc, Swete, CGT, in ll.; reff. in Artt., Logos, DB, DCG).
a spear-head.; a lance, spear: Mt 27:49 ([WH], R, mg.), Jo 19:34.†
to abuse, revile: c. acc pers., Jo 9:28, Ac 23:4; pass., I Co 4:12, I Pe 2:23 (cf. ἀντι-λοιδορέω).†
abuse, railing: I Ti 5:14, I Pe 3:9.†
railing, abusive; as subst., ὁ λ., a railer: I Co 5:11 6:10.†
pestilence: pl., Lk 21:11; metaph. (as in cl.; LXX: Ps 1:1, Pr 21:24, I Mac 15:21, al.), of persons, a pest: Ac 24:5 (also as adj., ἄνδρες λοιμοί, I Mac 10:61, al.).†

the remaining, the rest,; pl., οἱ λ.: c. subst., Mt 25:11, Ac 2:37, Ro 1:13, al.; absol., Mt 22:6, Mk 16:13, Lk 24:10, al.; οἱ λ. οἱ (B1., § 47, 8), Ac 28:9, I Th 4:13, Re 2:24; οἱ λ. τ. ἀνθρώπων (LS, s.v., ad. init.), Re 9:20; τὰ λ., Mk 4:19, Re 3:2, al.; Neut. sing. (acc ref.), adverbially, τὸ λ.; for the future, henceforth: Mk 14:41, I Co 7:29 (Lft., Notes, 232 f.), He 10:13; anarth. (Deiss., LAE, 17616, 1885, 20), Ac 27:20, II Ti 4:8; τοῦ λ. (sc. χρόνου; LS, s.v.; M, Pr., 73; Bl., § 36, 13), Ga 6:17, Eph 6:10; besides, moreover, for the rest: Phl 3:1 4:8; anarth., I Co 1:16 4:2, I Th 4:1 (M, Th., in l; Lft., Notes, 51)
Luke: Lk, tit., Col 4:14, II Ti 4:11, Phm 24.†
Lucius: Ac 13:1, Ro 16:21.†
a washing, bath: τ. ὕδατος, Eph 5:26; τ. παλιγγενεσίας, Tit 3:5 (v. AR, Eph., l.c.).†

to bathe, wash the body: c. acc pers., Ac 9:37 (of a dead body); id. seq. ἀπό (Deiss., BS, l.c.), Ac 16:33; pass. ptcp. pf., Jo 13:10, He 10:22; mid., to wash oneself (Mayor, in l; M. Pr., 155 f., 238 f.), II Pe 2:22; metaph., Re 1:5, Rec., R, mg. (cf. ἀπο-λούω).†
Lydda (modern Ludd): Ac, ll. c.†
Lydia, a woman of Thyatira: Ac 16:14, 40.†
Lycaonia, a region in Asia Minor: Ac 14:6.†
in Lycaonian (speech): Ac 14:11.†
Lydia, a region of Asia Minor; Ac 27:5.†
to outrage, maltreat: c. acc, Ac 8:3.; to corrupt, defile (Ez 16:25, Pr 23:8, IV Mac 18:8, al.).†

to distress, grieve, cause pain or grief: c. acc pers., II Co 2:2 2:5 7:8; pass., Mt 14:9 17:23 18:31 19:22 26:22, Mk 10:22 14:19, Jo 16:20 21:17, Ro 14:15, II Co 2:4, I Th 4:13, I Pe 1:6; λ. καὶ ἀδημονεῖν, Mt 26:37; opp. to χαίρειν, II Co 6:10; κατὰ θεόν, II Co 7:9 7:11; τ. πνεῦμα τ. ἅγιον, Eph 4:30 (cf. συν-λνπέω),†

pain of body or mind, grief, sorrow: Jo 16:6, II Co 2:7; opp. to χαρά, Jo 16:20, He 12:11; ἀπὸ τῆς λ., Lk 22:45; ἐκ λ., II Co 9:7; ἡ κατὰ θεὸν λ., opp. to ἡ τ. κόσ-μου λ., II Co 7:10; λ. μοι ἐστιν, Ro 9:2; λ. ἔχω, Jo 16:21-22; id. seq. ἀπό, II Co 2:3; λ. ἐπὶ λ. ἔχω, Phl 2:27; ἐν λ. ἐλθεῖν, II Co 2:1 (to come sad and cause sadness); pl. (cf. Ge 3:16, Pr 15:13, al.), I Pe 2:19.†
Lysanias: Lk 3:1.†
Lysias (Claudius L., Ac 23:26), Ac 24:7, 22.†
a loosing: of divorce, I Co 7:27.†
prop., to indemnify, pay expenses.; to be useful, to profit; usually impers., λυσιτελεῖ, it profits: c, dat. pers., seq. εἰ . . . ἤ, Lk 17:2.†
and (in Ac 14:8 16:2, 2Ti, l.c.) -ων, τά (cf. Λύδδα),; Lystra, a city of Lycaonia: Ac 14:6, 8 14:21 16:1-2, II Ti 3:11.†

a ransom (as for a life, Ex 21:30; for slaves, Le 19:20; for captives, Is 45:13): ἀντὶ πολλῶν, Mt 20:28, Mk 10:45 (v. Swete, in l, and for discussion of λ. and its cognates, Westc., He., 295 f.; Deiss., LAE, 331 f.; cf. also ἀντί-λύτρον).†
to release on receipt of ransom; mid., to release by paying ransom, to redeem: in spiritual sense, Tit 2:14; pass, I Pe 1:18; in general sense, to deliver (cf. Ex 6:6, Ps 69:18, al.): Lk 24:21.†
a ransoming, redemption (αἰχμαλώτων, Plut., Arat., 11): of the mediatorial work of Christ, He 9:12; in general sense, deliverance(cf. Ps 4:8, l.c.): Lk 1:68 2:38.†
a redeemer, deliverer: Ac 7:35 (not found elsewhere).†

a lampstand: Mt 5:15, Mk 4:21, Lk 8:16 11:33; of that in the Tabernacle, He 9:2; metaph., of the two witnesses, Re 11:4; of the seven churches of Asia, Re 1:12-13, 20 2:1; of the removal of a church from its position, κινεῖν τ. λυχνίαν κ.τ.λ., Re 2:5.†

a lamp (portable, and usually set on a stand, λυχνία): Mt 5:15, Lk 11:36; ἔρχεται ὁ λ., Mk 4:21; λ. ἅπτειν Lk 8:16 11:33 15:8; φῶς λύχνου, Re 18:23; id. opp. to φ.ἡλίου, Re 22:5; metaph., of the eye, Mt 6:22 Lk 11:34; of John the Baptist, Jo 5:35; of the Lamb, Re 21:23; of prophecy, II Pe 1:19; of spiritual readiness, pl., λύχνοι (as always in LXX; freq. in Att.. λύχνα), Lk 12:35.†

to loose, unbind, release: of things, Mk 1:7, Lk 3:16, al.; of beasts, Mt 21:2, Lk 13:15, al.; of persons, Jo 11:44, Ac 22:30; of Satan, Re 20:3, 7; metaph., of the marriage tie, I Co 7:27; of one diseased, Lk 13:16; of release from sin, Re 1:5, WH, R, txt. (v.s. λούω).; To resolve a whole into its parts, loosen, dissolve, break up, destroy: Jo 2:19, Ac 27:41, Re 5:2; metaph., II Pe 3:11; of an assembly, to dismiss: Ac 13:43; τ. μεσότοιχον τ. φραγμοῦ, Eph 2:14; τ. στοιχεῖα, II Pe 3:10; οὐρανοί, II Pe 3:12; τ. ἔργα τ. διαβόλου, I Jn 3:8; τ. ὠδῖνας τ. θανάτου, Ac 2:24; of laws, etc., to break, annul, cancel (MM, xvi): ἐντολήν, Mt 5:19; τ. νόμον, Jo 7:23; τ. σάββατον, Jo 5:18; τ. γραφήν, Jo 10:35.; (cf. ἀνα-, ἀπο-, δια-, ἐκ-, ἐπι-, κατα-, παρα-λύω.)
Lois: II Ti 1:5.†
indecl.,; Maath: Lk 3:26.†

Magadan, an unidentified place on the coast of the Sea of Galilee: Mt 15:39 (Rec. Μαγδαλά; cf. Mk 8:10, where for Δαλμανουθά, D* has Μελεγαδά, D1 Μαγαιδά, some cursives Μαγαδά, and Euseb. Onomast. Μεγαιδάν; cf. DB, iii, s.v.).†
Magdala: Mt 15:39 (Rec. for Μαγαδάν, q.v.).†
Magedon : Re 16:16 (WH, Ἅρ Μ. for Ἁρμαγεδών, q.v.).†
to be a Magus, or skilled in Magian lore.; to practise magic: Ac 8:9.†
the lore of the Magians (Plat.).; magic: pl., magic arts, sorceries: Ac 8:11.†

one of the Μάγοι, a Median tribe (Hat).; a Magian, one of a sacred caste, originally Median, who seem to have conformed to the Persian religion, while retaining some of their old beliefs (v. DB, I vol., 565 f.; DB, iii, 203 ff.): Mt 2:1, 7 2:16; a wizard, sorcerer: Ac 13:6, 8 (cf. Wi 17:7, Ac 8:9; ?Ac 8:1).†
Magog, associated with Gog: Re 20:8 (v. Swete, in l).†
Midian; son of Abraham (Ge 25:2).; An Arabian tribe (Ge 36:35, Ps 83:9, al).; γῆ Μ. (Heb. מִדְיָן אֶרֶץ), the land of Midian (Ex 2:15, al.): Ac 7:29.†
the breast: Re 1:13 (L for μαστός, q.v).†

intrans. (as prop. vb. in -εύω, and so Plut., mor. 837 c. and elsew.), to be a disciple: c. dat., Mt 27:57 (Rec., WH, mg.).; Trans., to make a disciple: c. acc, Mt 28:19, Ac 14:21; pass., seq. dat., τ. Ἰησοῦ, Mt 27:57 (WH, R); τ. βασιλείᾳ, Mt 13:52.†

a disciple: opp. to διδάσκαλος, Mt 10:24, Lk 6:40; Ἰωάννου, Mt 9:14, Lk 7:18, Jo 3:25; τ. Φαρισσίων, Mt 22:16, Mk 2:18, Lk 5:33; Μωυσέως, Jo 9:28; Ἰησοῦ, Lk 6:17 7:11 19:37, Jo 6:66 7:3 19:38; esp. the twelve, Mt 10:1 11:1, Mk 7:17, Lk 8:9, Jo 2:2, al.; later, of Christians generally, Ac 6:1, 2 7 9:19, al.; τ. κυρίου, Ac 9:1.
a female disciple: Ac 9:36.†
Matthew: Mt title., Mt 9:9 10:3, Mk 3:18, Lk 6:15, Ac 1:13 (cf. Λευεί).†
Matthan: Mt 1:15.†
Matthat: Lk 3:29 (cf. Ματθάτ).†; Matthat: Lk 3:24 (T, Μαθθάθ),†; Ματθάτ (v.s. Μαθθάτ),
Matthias: Ac 1:23, 26.†
Methuselah: Lk 3:37.†
to rage, be furious.; to rave, be mad: Jo 10:29, Ac 12:15 26:24-25, I Co 14:23 (cf. ἐμ-μαίνομαι).†
to bless, pronounce blessed or happy: c. acc pers., Lk 1:48, Ja 5:11.†

blessed, happy (DCG, i, 177, 213): θεός (δυνάστης), I Ti 1:11 6:15; ἐλπίς, Tit 2:13; esp. in congratulations, usually with the omission of the copula (M, Pr., 180; B1., § 30, 3), μ. ὁ, Mt 5:3 ff., Lk 6:20 ff. Jo 20:29, Re 1:3, al.; seq. ptcp., Lk 1:45, al.; ὅς, Mt 11:6, Lk 7:23, Ro 4:7-8; ὅτι, Mt 13:16, al.; ἐάν, Jo 13:17, I Co 7:40; compar., μ. . . . μᾶλλον, Ac 20:35; -ώτερος, I Co 7:40
a declaration of blessedness, felicitation: Ro 4:6, 9, Ga 4:15 (Plat., Arist.).†
Macedonia: Ac 16:9-10, I Co 16:5, II Co 1:16, Phl 4:15, al.; M. καὶ Ἀχαία, Ac 19:21, Ro 15:26, I Th 1:7-8
a Macedonian: Ac 16:9 19:29 27:2, II Co 9:2 9:4.†
a meat-market: I Co 10:25 (v. Deiss., LAE, 274; MM, xvi).†

a long way, far: Lk 15:20, Ac 22:21; seq. ἀπό, Mt 8:30, Lk 7:6, Jo 21:8, Ac 17:27; id. metaph., Mk 12:34; οἱ εἰς μ., Ac 2:39 (cf. Is 2:2); metaph., οἱ ποτὲ ὄντες μ. (opp. to ἐγγύς), Eph 2:13; οἱ μ., Eph 2:17.†

actively = καρτερέω, to persevere (Plut., 2, 593 F).; Passively, to be patient, long-suffering: absol., I Co 13:4, He 6:15, Ja 5:8; seq. ἕως, c. gen., Ja 5:7; ἐπί, c. dat., ib. (Si 2:4); πρός, c. acc, I Th 5:14; ἐπί, c. dat., Mt 18:26, 29, Lk 18:7; εἰς, II Pe 3:9.†

patience, longsuffering: of men, esp. in experiencing troubles and difficulties, Col 1:11, II Ti 3:10, He 6:12, Ja 5:10; of God's forbearance, Ro 2:4 9:22, II Co 6:6, Ga 5:22, Eph 4:2, Col 3:12, I Ti 1:16, II Ti 4:2, I Pe 3:20, II Pe 3:15.†
with forbearance, patiently: Ac 26:3.†
of space and time, long: μακρὰ προσεύχεσθαι, Mk 12:40, Lk 20:47.; of distance, far, far distant: χώρα, Lk 15:13 19:12.†
of long duration, longlived: Eph 6:3 (LXX).†

Pos., very, very much, exceedingly (cl.; LXX ut supr.; in NT its place is taken by λίαν, σφόδρα, etc.).; Compar., μᾶλλον.; Of increase, more; with qualifying words: πολλῷ, Mk 10:48, Lk 18:39, Ro 5:15, 17, Phl 2:12, al.; πόσῳ, Lk 12:24, Ro 11:12, al.; τοσούτῳ . . . ὅσῳ, He 10:25.; Of comparison, the more: Lk 5:15, Jo 5:18, Ac 5:14, I Th 4:1, 10, II Pe 1:10; ἔτι μ. καὶ μ., Phl 1:9; c. compar., Mk 7:36, II Co 7:13; πολλῴ μ. κρεῖσον, Phl 1:23; μ. διαφέρειν, c. gen., Mt 6:26; μ. ἤ, Mt 18:13; c. gen., I Co 14:18; as periphr. for compar., Ac 20:35, I Co 9:15, Ga 4:27; μ. δέ (EV, yea rather), Ro 8:34.; Of preference, rather, the rather, sooner: with qualifying words, πολλῷ, Mt 6:30, al.; πολύ, He 12:25; πόσῳ, Mt 7:11, al.; in a question, οὐ μ., I Co 9:12; after a neg., Mt 10:6, al.; θέλω (εὐδοκῶ) μ., I Co 14:5, II Co 5:8; ζηλῶ, I Co 14:1; c. subst., τ. σκότος ἢ τ. φῶς, Jo 3:19; μ. δέ, Ga 4:9.; Superl., μάλιστα, most, most of all, above all: Ac 20:38 25:26, Ga 6:10, Phl 4:22, I Ti 4:10 5:8, 17, II Ti 4:13, Tit 1:10, Phm 16, II Pe 2:10; μ. γνώστης, Ac 26:3
prop., softness, effeminacy (Hdt., Thuc., al).; In NT, as in LXX, = ἀσθένεια, weakness, sickness: νόσος καὶ μ., Mt 4:23 9:35 10:1.†

soft; prop., to the touch (opp. to σκληρός): of clothing, pl., Mt 11:8, Lk 7:25.; Of persons and their mode of living; mild, gentle; soft, effeminate: I Co 6:9 (prob. in obscene sense, cf. Deiss., LAE, 150, 4; MM, xvi; Zorell, s.v.).†
Mahalaleel: Lk 3:37.†
Malchus: Jo 18:10.†
in cl., a child's name for mother.; In late Gk. (= cl., τήθη), a grandmother: (LXX, l.c.), II Ti 1:5.†
mammon, riches: Mt 6:24, Lk 16:9, 11 16:13.†
Manaen: Ac 13:1.†
Manasseh; (a) the first-born son of Joseph; the tribe which bore his name: Re 7:6.; King of Judah: Mt 1:10.†

to learn, esp. by inquiry: absol., I Co 14:31, I Ti 2:11, II Ti 3:7; c. acc rei, Jo 7:15 (sc. αὐτά), Ro 16:17, I Co 14:35, Phl 4:9, II Ti 3:14, Re 14:3; seq. quaes. indir., Mt 9:13; Χριστόν, Eph 4:20 (ICC, in l); seq. ἀπό, c. gen. rei, Mt 24:32, Mk 13:28; ἀπό, c. gen. pers., Mt 11:29, Col 1:7; παρά, c. gen. pers., II Ti 3:14; ἐν, c. dat. pers., I Co 4:6; "point" aorist (M, Pr., 117), to ascertain, seq. ὅτι, Ac 23:27; c. acc seq. ἀπό, Ga 3:2.; to learn by use and practice, acquire the habit of, be accustomed to: c. inf. (Bl., § 69, 4), I Ti 5:4, Tit 3:14; id. c. nom, in pred. (El., § 72, 1), Phl 4:11; c. acc rei seq. ἀπό, He 5:8; ἀργαὶ μανθάνουσιν (EV, they learn to be idle; Bl., § 73, 5; Field, Notes, 210), I Ti 5:13.†
frenzy, madness: Ac 26:24.†
indecl.; manna: Jo 6:31, 49, He 9:4; symb., Re 2:17.†
to divine, practise divination: Ac 16:16.†

in cl.,; prop., to quench fire; pass., of fire, to die away, go out.; In various relations, to quench, waste, wear out (cf. Wi 19:21); pass., to waste away; in later writers (Plut., Luc., al.), of the withering of flowers and herbage (act., Jb 15:30; pass., Jb 24:24, Wi 2:8): Ja 1:11 (cf. ἀμάραντον).†
Maranatha, i.e. the Lord cometh (but v. Dalman, ll. c.; Field, Notes, 180; ICC, in l): I Co 16:22.†
a pearl: Mt 13:45-46, I Ti 2:9, Re 17:4 18:12, 16 21:21 (-ῖται, WH); proverbially, Mt 7:6.†

Mary. In NT; the mother of Jesus: Mt 1:16 ff. Mt 2:11 13:55, Mk 6:3, Lk 1:27 ff. Lk 2:5, 16 2:19, 34, Ac 1:14; M. Magdalene (q.v.).; The wife of Clopas (Jo 19:25) and mother of James the little, and Joses: Mt 27:56, 61 28:1, Mk 15:40, 47 16:1, Lk 24:10.; The sister of Martha and Lazarus: Lk 10:39, 42 Jo 11:1-2, 19 ff. Jo 12:3.; The mother of John Mark: Ac 12:12.; A Christian greeted by St. Paul: Ro 16:6 (on the signification of the name, v. Zorell, s.v.; on the use of the alternative forms in NT, DB, iii, 278 bn).†
Mark: Mk., title., Ac 12:12, 25 15:37, 39, Col 4:10, II Ti 4:11, Phm 24, I Pe 5:13 (v. Swete, Mk., Intr., xiii ff.; DB, iii, 245 ff).†
any crystalline stone (Hom., Eur., al.).; In later writers, marble: Re 18:12.†

prop., to be a witness, bear witness, testify: absol. (find., al.), Jo 15:27, Ac 26:5; parenthetical (Bl., § 79, 7; MM, xvi), II Co 8:3; c. dat. pers. (comm. et incomm.; El., § 37, 2), Ac 22:5, He 10:15; id. seq. ὅτι, Mt 23:31, Ro 10:2, al.; acc et inf., Ac 10:43; c. acc rei (cl.), Jo 3:11, Re 22:16, 20; c. acc cogn., seq. περί, Jo 5:32, I Jn 5:10; c. dat. rei, Jo 5:33, Ac 14:3, al.; seq. περί, c. gen. (pers. et rei), Jo 1:7-8, 15 2:25 18:23 21:24, al.; id. seq. ὅτι, Jo 5:36 7:7; ὅτι, Jo 1:34 4:44 al.; ὅτι recit., Jo 4:39; κατά seq. ὅτι, I Co 15:15; pass., He 7:8; ptcp., Ro 3:21; impers., He 7:17; in late Gk., to witness favourably, give a good report, approve (Bl., § 54, 3; MM, xvi; Deiss., BS, 265): c. dat. pers., Lk 4:22; seq. ἐπί c. dat. rei, He 11:4; pass., Ac 6:3; seq. ἐν, I Ti 5:10, He 11:2; διά, c. gen. rei, He 11:39; c. gen. pers., Ac 10:22, al.; impers., III Jn 12 (cf. ἐπι, συν-επι-, κατα-, συν-μαρτυρέω)

witness, testimony, evidence: Mk 14:56, Lk 22:71, Jo 5:34 19:35 21:24, I Ti 3:7, Tit 1:13, III Jn 12, Re 11:7; c. gen. subj., Mk 14:59, Jo 8:17 (LXX aliter), I Jn 5:9; seq. κατά, c. gen. pers., Mk 14:55; esp. of witness concerning Christ and divine things, Jo 1:7 3:11, 32-33 5:32, 36 Re 6:9; c. gen. subj., Jo 1:19 5:31 8:13-14, Ac 22:18, I Jn 5:9-11, Re 12:11; c. gen. obj., Re 1:2, 9 12:17 19:10 20:4; μ. ἔχειν, Re 6:9 12:17 19:10.†

a testimony, witness, proof (Hdt., Thuc., al.): c. gen. subj., II Co 1:12, II Th 1:10; c. gen. obj., Ac 4:33, I Co 1:6 2:1 (WH, txt., R, txt., μυστήριον; II Ti 1:8; εἰς μ., Mt 8:4 10:18 Mt 24:14, Mk 1:44 6:11 13:9, Lk 5:14 9:5 21:13, He 3:5, Ja 5:3; τὸ μ. καιροῖς ἰδίοις (CGT, in l), I Ti 2:6; ἡ σκηνὴ τοῦ μ. (LXX for מוֹעֵד אֹהֶל), Ac 7:44, Re 15:5.†

to summon as witness (M, Th., 25 f.; Hort., 1Pe., 53 f.; Lft., Notes, 29; Ga 203), hence,; to protest, affirm solemnly: seq. ὅτι, Ac 20:26, Ga 5:3; to adjure, beseech: c. dat. pers., Ac 26:22; c. acc et inf., Eph 4:17; seq. εἰς, I Th 2:12 (cf. δια-, προ-μαρτύρομαι).†

a witness: Ac 10:41, I Ti 6:12, II Ti 2:2, He 12:1 (Westc., in l); in forensic sense, Mt 18:16 26:65, Mk 14:63, Ac 6:13 7:58, II Co 13:1, I Ti 5:19, He 10:28; c. gen. obj., Lk 24:48, Ac 1:22 2:32 3:15 5:32 10:39 26:16, I Pe 5:1; c. gen. poss., Ac 1:8 13:31, Re 11:3; c. dat. pers., Lk 11:48, Ac 22:15; of Christ, Re 1:5 3:14; of God, Ro 1:9, II Co 1:23, Phl 1:8, I Th 2:5 2:10; of those who have witnessed for Christ by their death (in later Xn. lit., martyr: Swete, Ap., 35), Ac 22:20, Re 2:13 17:6.†
to bite, chew: Re 16:10.†
to whip, scourge: c. acc, Ac 22:25.†
a whip, scourge: Ac 22:24, He 11:36; metaph., of disease or suffering as a divine chastisement (cf. Ps 89:33, Pr 3:12, II Mac 9:11), Mk 3:10 5:29, 34, Lk 7:21
the breast: pl., Lk 11:27 23:29, Re 1:13 (T, μασθοῖς; WH, App., 149; L, μαζοῖς).†
idle or foolish talk: I Ti 1:6.†
talking idly: Tit 1:10.†

vain, useless: ἀνωφελὴς κ. μ., Tit 3:9; πίστις, I Co 15:17; θρησκεία, Ja 1:26; διαλογισμοί, I Co 3:20 (LXX); ἀναστροφή, I Pe 1:18; of idols and heathen gods, τὰ μ. (Je 2:5, IV Ki 17:15, al.): Ac 14:15
vanity, emptiness, frailty, folly: Ro 8:20, II Pe 2:18; τ. νοός, Eph 4:17 (elsewhere only in Pollux, 6, 134, and Eccl.).†
to make vain, foolish: Ro 1:21.†
in vain, to no purpose: Mt 15:9, Mk 7:7 (LXX).†
indecl. (Heb. מַתַּתָּה),; Mattatha: Lk 3:31.†
Mattathias (cf. Μαθθίας): Lk 3:25-26.†

(in Hom., al.) a large knife or dirk, for sacrificial purposes (Ge 22:6, 10, Jg 19:20 A).; a short sword or dagger (as disting. from ῥομφαία, a large broad sword and ξίφος, a straight sword for thrusting): Mt 26:47 ff., Mk 14:43, 47-48, Lk 22:36 ff., Jo 18:10-11 Ac 16:27, He 11:37, Re 6:4 13:10, 14; στόμα μαχαίρης (as in Heb. חֶרֶב פֶּה, Ge 34:26, al.), the edge of the sword: Lk 21:24, He 11:34; μ. δίστομος, He 4:12; ἀναιρεῖν μαχαίρῃ, Ac 12:2; τὴν μ. φορεῖν, Ro 13:4. Metaph., Mt 10:34 (opp. to εἰρήνη), Ro 8:35; μ. τοῦ πνεῦματος, Eph 6:17.†
a fight.; a strife, contention, quarrel: II Co 7:5, II Ti 2:23, Ja 4:1; pl., Tit 3:9.†
to fight: Ac 7:26.; to quarrel, dispute: II Ti 2:24, Ja 4:2; πρὸς ἀλλήλους, Jo 6:52 (cf. δια-μάχομαι).†
to boast great things: Ja 3:5 (Rec. for μεγάλα αὐχεῖ, WH).†
magnificent, splendid (Xen., Plut., al.) : Ac 2:11.†
splendour, magnificence: Lk 9:43, Ac 19:27, II Pe 1:16 (freq. in π. as a ceremonial title, MM, xvi).†
befitting a great man, magnificent, majestic: II Pe 1:17 (cf. MM, xvi).†
to make great: Mt 23:5, Lk 1:58.; to declare great, extol, magnify: Lk 1:46, Ac 5:13 10:46 19:17, II Co 10:15; pass., seq. ἐν, Phl 1:20.†
greatly: Phl 4:10.†
greatness, majesty: He 1:3 8:1, Ju 25 (elsewhere Eccl. only).†

great; of external form, bodily size, measure, extent: λίθος, Mt 2:60; δράκων, Re 12:3; ἰχθῦς, Jo 21:11; πόλις, Re 11:8; μάχαιρα, Re 6:4, al. Of intensity and degree: δύναμις, Ac 4:33; φόβος, Mk 4:41; ἀγάπη, Jo 15:13; ἄνεμος, ib. 6:18; κραυγή, Ac 23:9; φῶς, Mt 4:16; πυρετός, Lk 4:38; θλίψις, Mt 24:21. Of rank; of persons: θεός (MM, xvi), Tit 2:13; Ἄρτεμις, Ac 19:27; compar. (v. infr.), Mt 18:1 (cf. Dalman, Words, 113f.); neut. for masc. (Bl., §32, 1), Mt 12:6; of things: ἁμαρτία, Jo 19:11; μυστήριον, Eph 5:32; = μεγίστη (v. infr., and cf. Field, Notes, 16f.), Mt 22:36; compar. for superl. (M, Pr., 78), I Co 13:13. Compar., μείζων: Mt 11:11 23:17, al.; neut. pl., μείζονα, contr. μείζω, Jo 1:51; double compar., μειζότερος (M, Pr., 236; Bl., §11, 4), III Jo 4; superl, μέγιστος (Deiss., BS, 365), II Pe 1:4.
greatness: Eph 1:19 (cf. MM, xvi, s.v. μέγας).†
usually pl., οἱ μ., the chief men, nobles (Manetho, FlJ, al.): Mk 6:21, Re 6:15 18:23.†
to translate, interpret: Mt 1:23, Mk 5:41 15:22, 34, Jo 1:38, 42, Ac 4:36 13:8 (cf. ἑρμηνεύω).†
drunkenness: Lk 21:34; pl., Ro 13:13, Ga 5:21 †

to change, remove: c. acc rei, ὄρη, I Co 13:2 (cf. Is 54:10); c. acc pers.: seq. εἰς, Col 1:13; seq. ἐκ, pass., Lk 16:4; of causing death (cf. similar intrans. sense, Eur., Alc., 21, al.), Ac 13:22. Metaph. (cf. τ. καρδίαν μ., Jos 14:8), c. acc pers., to pervert: Ac 19:26.†
craft, deceit: Eph 4:14 6:11 (not found elsewhere; v. AR, in l).†
Rec. for ὅριον (q.v.),; a border, boundary: Mk 7:24.†
causal of μεθύω,; to make drunk, intoxicate; pass., to get drunk: Lk 12:45, Eph 5:18, I Th 5:7.†
drunken: I Co 5:11 6:10.†
to be drunken: Mt 24:49, Jo 2:10, Ac 2:15, I Co 11:21, I Th 5:7; metaph., Re 17:2, 6.†
black: Re 6:5, 12; opp. to λευκός, Mt 5:36; neut., τὸ μ., ink : II Co 3:3, II Jn 12, III Jn 13.†
indecl., ὁ (Heb. מְלֵאָה),; Melea: Lk 3:31.†

c. gen., to care for (Hes.).; C. acc to attend to, practise: I Ti 4:15 (RV, be diligent in; cf. Souter in Exp., VIII, vi, 429, but v. infr.).; to study, ponder: Ac 4:25 (LXX) I Ti 4:15 (AV, meditate on; cf. CGT, in l, but v. supr.; cf. προ-μελετάω).†
honey: Re 10:9-10; ἄγριον (q.v.), Mt 3:4, Mk 1:9.†
made by bees: Lk 24:42 (Rec., WH, R, mg.).†
Melita, Melitene (mod. Malta) : Ac 28:1.†

to be about to be or do; c. inf. (Bl., §62, 4; 68, 2; M, Pr., 114); of intending or being about to do of one's own free will: c. inf. praes., Mt 2:13, Lk 10:1, Ac 3:3 5:35, He 8:5, II Pe 1:12 (Field, Notes, 240), al.; c. inf. aor. (Bl., §58, 3), Ac 12:6, Re 3:16; of compulsion, necessity or certainty: c. inf. praes., Mt 16:27, Lk 9:31, Jo 6:71, Ro 4:24, al.; c. inf. aor., Ro 8:18, Ga 3:23, Re 3:2 12:4. Ptcp., ὁ μέλλων: absol., Ro 8:38, I Co 3:22; τὰ μ., Col 2:17; εἰς τὸ μ. (Field, Notes, 65); c. subst., Mt 3:7 12:32 (ὁ αἰὼν ὁ μ.; LXX for עַד), Ac 24:25, I Ti 4:8, He 2:5, al.

a member, limb of the body: I Co 12:14 12:19 12:26 Eph 4:16 (WH, mg.), Ja 3:5; pl. (as always in cl.), τὰ μ. : Mt 5:29-30, Ro 6:13, 19 7:5, 23 12:4, I Co 12:12 ff, Col 3:5, Ja 3:6 4:1. Metaph., πόρνης, I Co 6:15; of Christians, μ. ἀλλήλων, Ro 12:5, Eph 4:25; Χριστοῦ, I Co 6:15; σώματος Χριστοῦ, I Co 12:27, Eph 5:30.†
Melchi: Lk 3:24, 28.†

intrans., to be an object of care, be a care; commonly in third pers.: c. dat. pers., Ac 18:17; very freq. impers., I Co 7:21; seq. ὅτι, Mk 4:38, Lk 10:40; c. gen. rei (as freq. in Att..), I Co 9:9; seq. περί, Mt 22:16, Mk 12:14, Jo 10:13 12:6, I Pe 5:7.; Trans., in act. and mid., to care for (not in LXX or NT).†
parchment: II Ti 4:13.†
to blame, find fault: absol., Ro 9:19; c. acc, αὐτούς (WH, txt.; αὐτούς, Rec., WH, mg.; on rendering with αὐτούς v. Westc., in l), He 8:8.†
complaining of one's fate, querulous: Ju 16 †

It is generally untranslatable and is not nearly so frequent in NT as in cl. Like δέ, it never stands first in a clause. Answered by δέ or some other particle: μὲν . . . δέ, indeed . . . but, Mt 3:11, Lk 3:16, al.; with pronouns, ὃς μὲν . . . ὃς δέ, one . . . another, Mt 21:35, al.; pl., Phl 1:16, 17; ὃ μὲν . . . ὃ δὲ . . . ὃ δέ, some . . . some . . . some, Mt 13:8; τοῦτο μὲν . . . τοῦτο δέ, partly . . . partly, He 10:33; μὲν . . . ἔπειτα, Jo 11:6; μὲν . . . καί, Lk 8:5. μέν solitarium, answered by no other particle: πρῶτον μέν (Bl., l.c.), Ro 1:8 3:2, I Co 11:18; μὲν οὖν in narrative, summing up what precedes or introducing something further (Bl., §78, 5), so then, rather, nay rather: Lk 11:28 (WH, μενοῦν), Ac 1:6 9:31, al.; μὲν οὖν γε (Phl 3:8, WH): v.s. μενοῦνγε.
Menna: Lk 3:31.†
= μὲν οὖν γε; nay rather: Ro 9:20 10:18, Phl 3:8.†
= μέν τοι,; yet, however: Jo 4:27, al.; εἰ μ., Ja 2:8 (if indeed).

to stay, abide, remain. Intrans.; of place: seq. ἐν, Lk 8:27, al.; παρά, c. dat. pers., Jo 1:40, al; σύν, Lk 1:56; καθ’ ἑαυτόν, Ac 28:16; c. adv., ἐκεῖ, Mt 10:11; ὧδε, Mt 26:38; metaph., I Jo 2:18; of the Holy Spirit, Jo 1:32, 33 14:17; of Christ, Jo 6:56 15:4, al.; ὁ θεός, I Jo 4:15, conversely, of Christians, Jo 6:56 15:4, I Jo 4:15, al.; ὁ λόγος τ. θεοῦ, I Jo 2:14; ἡ ἀλήθεια, II Jo 2, al. Of time; of persons: Phl 1:25; seq. εἰς τ. αἰῶνα, Jo 12:34, He 7:24, I Jo 2:17; ὀλίγον, Re 17:10; ἕως ἔρχομαι, Jo 21:22, 23; of things, lasting or enduring: cities, Mt 11:23, He 13:14; λόγος θεοῦ, I Pe 1:23; ἁμαρτία, Jo 9:41. Of condition: c. pred., μόνος, Jo 12:24; ἄγαμος, I Co 7:11; πιστός, II Ti 2:13; ἱερεύς, He 7:3; c. adv., οὕτως, I Co 7:40; ὡς κἀγώ, ib. 8; seq. ἐν, ib. 20, 24. Trans. (Bl., §34, 1; Field, Notes, 132): c. acc. pers., Ac 20:5, 23 (cf. ἀνα-, δια-, ἐν-, ἐπι-, κατα-, παρα-, συν-παρα-, περι-, προσ-, ὑπο-μένω).

to divide; to divide into parts : metaph., pass., I Co 7:34 (WH, R, ing.), I Co 7:34 (Rec., R, txt.) ( reading and punctuation, v. ICC, in l); μεμέρισται ὁ Χριστός, I Co 1:13; as in late authors, of factional division (cf. Polyb., viii, 23, 9), καθ' ἑαυτοῦ, Mt 12:25; ἐφ' εαυτόν, Mt 12:26, Mk 3:24-26; to distribute: c. acc rei et dat. pers., Mk 6:41; as in later usage (cf. Polyb., xi, 28, 9), to bestow: Ro 12:3, I Co 7:17, II Co 10:13, He 7:2; mid., c. acc rei seq. μετά, Lk 12:13 (cf. δια-, συμ-μερίζω).†
care, anxiety: I Pe 5:7; pl., Lk 8:14 21:34; c. gen. obj., Mt 13:22, Mk 4:19, II Co 11:28.†

to be anxious: absol., Mt 6:27, 31, Lk 12:25; μηδὲν μ., Phl 4:6; c. dat. rei, Mt 6:25, Lk 12:22; seq. περί, Mt 6:28, Lk 10:41 12:26; πῶς, Mt 10:19, Lk 12:11; εἰς τὴν αὔριον, Mt 6:34.; to care for: c. acc, τὰ τ. κυριου, I Co 7:32-34; τὰ τ. κόσμου, I Co 7:34; τὰ περί ὑμῶν, Phl 2:20; seq. ὑπέρ, I Co 12:25; c. gen. (a construction otherwise unknown), ἑαυτῆς (WH; τὰ ἑ. Rec.; v. Bl., § 35, 7), Mt 6:34 (cf. προ-μεριμνάω).†
(as in cl.) a part, portion: Lk 10:42, Ac 8:21, II Co 6:15, Col 1:12.; In later Gk (v. MM, xvi), as geographical term, a division, district: Ac 16:12.†
a dividing, division: ψυχῆς κ. πνεύματος (i.e. between them or of the things themselves, v. Westc., in l), He 4:12.; a dis­tribution, bestowal (cf. μερίζω, 2); pl., He 2:4.†
a divider: Lk 12:14.†

a part, share, portion: Jo 13:8, Ac 19:27 (Page, in l), Re 20:6 22:19; hence (cl.), lot, destiny, Mt 24:51, Lk 12:46, Re 21:8.; a part as opp. to the whole : Lk 11:36, Jo 19:23, Ac 5:2 23:6, Eph 4:16, Re 16:19; c. gen. (of the whole), Lk 15:12 24:42; τ. Φαρισαίων, Ac 23:9; pl., Jo 21:6; of the divisions of a province, Mt 2:22, Ac 2:10 19:1 20:2; of the regions belonging to a city, Mt 15:21 16:13, Mk 8:10; c. gen. appos., Eph 4:9; in adverbial phrases, ἀνὰ (κατὰ) μέρος, I Co 14:27, He 9:5; μέρος τι, ἀπὸ μ., in part, Ro 11:25 15:15, 24, I Co 11:18, II Co 1:14 2:5; ἐκ μ., I Co 12:27 13:9 13:12; τὸ ἐκ μ., I Co 13:10; A class or category (in cl. usually ἐν μ. τιθέναι, λαβεῖν, etc.) :ἐν μ., in respect of, Col 2:16; ἐν τ. μ, τούτῳ, in this respect, II Co 3:10 9:3.†
noon: Ac 22:6.; the South: Ac 8:26.†
to interpose, mediate: ὅρκῳ, He 6:17 (MM, ii, 111).†

an arbitrator, mediator: Ga 3:19; c. dupl. gen. pers., θεοῦ κ. ἀνθρώπων, I Ti 2:5; c. gen. rei, διαθήκης, He 8:6 9:15 12:24; ὁ δε μ. ἑνὸς οὐκ ἔστιν, Ga 3:20 (v. Lft., in l; and for exx. of this word in π., v. MM, xvi).†

of or at midnight; as subst., neut., τὸ μ., midnight (Arist. and late writers) : gen., Lk 11:5; μέχρι μ., Ac 20:7; κατὰ τὸ μ., Ac 16:25; acc (Rec., gen.; v. Bl., § 34, 8), Mk 13:35.†; μεσανύκτιον, see. μεσονύκτιος
Mesopotamia: Ac 2:9 7:2.†

middle, in the middle or midst; prop., as an adj.: Lk 23:45, Jo 19:18, Ac 1:18; c. gen. pl., Lk 22:55, Jo 1:26; gen. temp. (Bl., § 36, 13), μέσης νυκτός, Mt 25:6; μ. ἡμέρας, Ac 26:13.; In adverbial phrases, neut., μέσον, τὸ μ., as subst.: ἀνὰ μέσον, c. gen., between (cl.; in LXX: Ge 1:4, al.), elliptically (but v. M, Pr., 99), I Co 6:5; = ἐν μ., among, in the midst of (El., § 39, 2; 40, 8; cf. in LXX: Jos 19:1, Si 27:2), Mt 13:25, Mk 7:31, Re 7:17; διὰ μέσου, c. gen., Lk 4:30; διὰ μέσον (Rec. -ου, v. 81., § 42, 1), between, Lk 17:11 (ICC, in l); εἰς τὸ μ. (v.s. εἰς), Mk 3:3, Lk 4:35 5:19 6:8, Jo 20:19, 26; εἰς μ., Mk 14:60; ἐν τῷ μ., Mt 14:6; ἐν μ., Jos 8:3, 9, Ac 4:7; c, gen. loc., Mk 6:47, Lk 21:21 22:55, Ac 17:22, He 2:12 (LXX), Re 4:6 5:6 22:2. c. gen. pl., Mt 10:16 18:2, 20, Mk 9:36, Lk 2:46 8:7 10:3 22:27 24:36, Ac 1:15 2:22 27:21, I Th 2:7, Re 1:13 2:1 5:6 6:6; κατὰ μέσον τ. νυκτός, Ac 27:27 (Bl., § 47, 6); ἐκ τοῦ μ. (Lft., in l; Deiss., BS, 252 f.), Col 2:14; ἐκ μ.., II Th 2:7; ἐκ τοῦ μ., c. gen., Mt 13:49, Ac 17:33 23:10, I Co 5:2, II Co 6:17.; Neut., μέσον, adverbially, c. gen., in the midst of, Mt 14:24 (WH, txt., R, mg., aliter), Phl 2:15 (διὰ μέσου­v. supr.-also Jo 8:50, R, mg.).†
a partition wall: Eph 2:14 (not elsewhere, but v. LS, s.v. μεσότοιχος).†
the zenith, mid-heaven: Re 8:13 14:6 19:17.†
to be in the middle, esp. of time: τ. ἑορτῆς μεσούσης, in the middle of the feast, Jo 7:14.†
Messiah: Jo 1:42 4:22.†
full: c. gen. rei, Jo 19:29 21:11, Ja 3:8; metaph., of thoughts and feelings, Mt 23:28, Ro 1:29 15:14, II Pe 2:14, Ja 3:17 (cf. Pr, l.c.).†
to fill: pass., c. gen. rei, Ac 2:13.†

C. gen., among, amid: Mk 1:13, Lk 22:37 (LXX, ἐν) 24:5, Jo 18:5, al.; διωγμῶν, Mk 10:30. Of association and companionship, with (in which sense it gradually superseded σύν, than which it is much more freq. in NT; cf. Bl., §42, 3): c. gen. pers., Mt 8:11 20:20 Mk 1:29 3:7 Lk 5:30, Jo 3:22, Ga 2:1, al. mult.; εἶναι μετά, Mt 5:25, Mk 3:14, al.; metaph., of divine help and guidance, Jo 3:2, Ac 7:9, Phl 4:9, al.; opp. to εἶναι κατά, Mt 12:30, Lk 11:23; in Hellenistic usage (but v. M, Pr., 106, 246f.), πολεμεῖν μετά = cl. π., c. dat., to wage war against (so LXX for נִלְחַם עִם, I Ki 17:33), Re 2:16, al.; c. gen. rei, χαρᾶς, Mt 13:20, Mk 4:16, al.; ὀργῆς, Mk 3:5, al. C. acc, of place, behind, after: He 9:3. Of time, after: Mt 17:1, Mk 14:1, Lk 1:24, Ac 1:5, Ga 1:18, al.; μετὰ τοῦτο, Jo 2:12, al.; ταῦτα, Mk 16:[12], Lk 5:27, Jo 3:22, al; c. inf. artic. (BL, §71, 5; 72, 3), Mt 26:32, Mk 1:14, al. In composition, of association or community: μεταδίδωμι, μετέχω, etc. Exchange or transference: μεταλλάσσω, μετοικίζω, etc. after: μεταμέλομαι.

to pass over from one place to another : Mt 17:20, Lk 10:7; with reference to the point of departure only, to withdraw, depart: Mt 8:34 11:1 12:9 15:29, Jo 7:3, Ac 18:7; of removal from this life, ἐκ τ. κότμου πρὸς τ. Πατέρα, Jo 13:1; metaph., ἐκ τ. θανάτου εἰς τ. ζωήν, Jo 5:24, I Jn 3:14.†
to turn about, change. Pass. and mid., to turn oneself about; metaph., to change one's mind: Ac 28:6.†
in Xen., Plut., and later writers, to transfer, transport (so LXX).; In sense other­wise unknown (v. Hort, in l), to turn about, direct: Ja 3:3-4.†

to give a share of, impart: c. dat. pers. et acc rei (in cl. more freq., c. gen. part., but acc of that which is imparted, whether part or whole, so here, v. Bl., § 36, 1), Ro 1:11, I Th 2:8, and (with ellipse of acc) Lk 3:11; c. dat. pers., Eph 4:28; absol., ὁ μεταδιδούς, Ro 12:8.†
change of position, removal : He 11:5.; change, as of that which has been established : He 7:12 12:27.†
trans., to remove (LXX, ll. c.).; (not cl.) to depart: Mt 13:53 19:1 (cf. Aq.: Ge 12:9).†
to call from one place to another. Mid., to send for: c. acc, Ac 7:14 10:32 20:17 24:25.†
trans.,; to move away, remove (ὅρια, Deu, l.c.). Mid., to remove oneself, remove, shift: metaph., ἀπὸ τ. ἐλπίδος, Col 1:23.†
to have or get a share of, partake of: c. gen. rei, II Ti 2:6, He 6:7 12:10; τροφῆς, Ac 2:46 27:33-34; c. acc rei (of the whole), to get: καιρόν, Ac 24:25 (v. Bl., § 36, 1; MM, xvi).†
participation, taking, receiving: of food, I Ti 4:3.†
to exchange: τ. ἀλήθειαν . . . ἐν τ. ψεύδει, the truth for a lie (v. Bl., § 36, 8), Rom_1:25.; to change: c. acc seq. εἰς, Rom_1:26 (ἀλλάσσω).†
to regret, repent one: Mt 21:30, 32 27:3, II Co 7:8, He 7:21 (LXX)†
to transform, trans­figure: pass., of Christ's transfiguration, Mt 17:2, Mk 9:2 (cf. Lk 9:29); of Christians, Ro 12:2, II Co 3:18.†

to change one's mind or purpose, hence, to repent; in NT (exc. Lk 17:3-4), of repentance from sin, involving amendment: seq. ἀπό, Ac 8:22; ἔκ, Re 2:21-22 9:20-21 16:11 (מִן שׁוּב); ἐπί, II Co 12:21; absol., Mt 3:2 4:17 11:20 12:41, Mk 1:15 6:12, Lk 11:32 13:3, 5 15:7, 10 16:30 17:3-4, Ac 2:38 3:19 17:30 26:20 2:5, 16 2:21 3:3, 19; c. inf., Re 16:9; ἐν σάκκῳ κ. σποδῷ, Mt 11:21, Lk 10:13.†

after-thought, change of mind, repentance: He 12:17; of repentance from sin, Mt 3:8, 11 Lk 3:8 15:7 24:47, Ac 26:20, II Co 7:9-10; βάπτισμα (q.v.) μετανοίας, Mk 1:4, Lk 3:3, Ac 13:24 19:4; ἡ εἰς θεὸν Ac 20:21; μ. ἀπὸ νεκρῶν ἔργων, He 6:1; εἰς μ. καλεῖν, Lk 5:32; id. ἄγειν, Ro 2:4; ἀνακαινίζειν, He 6:6; εἰς μ. χωρῆσαι, II Pe 3:9; μ. δοῦναι, Ac 5:31 11:18, II Ti 2:25.†

adv. of place and time (in NT time only); between: ἐν τῷ μ. (s.c. χρόνῳ), Jo 4:31; in late writers (FlJ, Plut., al.), like μετά (adv.), after, afterwards: τὸ μ. σάββατον, Ac 13:42 (cf. Cl., Ro., I Co., 44, 2).; Prep. c. gen., between: of place, Mt 23:35, Lk 11:51 16:26, Ac 12:6; of persons, as to mutual relation, Mt 18:15, Ac 15:9, Ro 2:1-29 15:1-33.†
to send after or for: pass., Ac 10:29 a. Chiefly in mid., to send for, summon Ac 10:5, 22 10:29 b Ac 11:13 20:1 24:24, 26 25:3.†

to turn about, turn, change: pass., Ac 2:20 (LXX), Ja 4:9 (WH, txt., μετατρέπω, q.v.); in evil sense, to pervert, corrupt (cf. primary sense reverse) : Ga 1:7.†; μετα-τρέπω; to turn about, turn (Hom., al., but not found in Att..) : c. acc, Ja 4:9 (WH, txt.; cf. μεταστρέφω).†

to change in fashion or appearance: c. acc rei, τ. σῶμα, Phl 3:21; mid., seq. εἰς, II Co 11:13-14; seq. ὡς, II Co 11:15; of a rhetorical device, to transfer by a fiction (Field, Notes, in l), seq. εἰς, I Co 4:6.†

to transfer to another place: c. acc, pass., He 11:5 (LXX); seq. εἰς, Ac 7:16; to change: c. acc, pass., He 7:12; seq. εἰς, fig., i.e. to make one thing a pretext for another, χάριν εἰς ἀσέλγειαν, Ju 4. Mid., to change oneself, pass over: seq. ἀπό et εἰς, Ga 1:6 (cf. 2Mac, l.c.).†
after­wards: He 12:17.†

to partake of, share in: ἐπ' ἐλπίδι τοῦ μετέχειν, I Co 9:10; c. gen. rei, I Co 9:12 10:21 10:30, He 2:14; in sacramental sense, ἑκ τ. ἐνὸς ἄρτου μ., I Co 10:17 (cf. MM, xvi); metaph., γάλακτος, He 5:13; of belonging to a tribe, He 7:13.†

to raise on high (Thue., Xen., al.; Ob, Mi, Ez, ll c.). Metaph.,; to buoy up; pass., to be elated, puffed up (Polyb., al., Ps 2:1-12, 3 Mac, ll. c.); to be anxious, in suspense (Polyb., v. 70, 10; FlJ, BJ, iv, 2, 5) : Lk 12:29.†
change of abode, migration: of the Babylonian exile, μ. Βαβυλῶνος, Mt 1:11-12, 17.†
to remove to a new abode, cause to migrate: Ac 7:4, 43 (LXX).†
sharing, fellowship: II Co 6:14.†
sharing in, partaking of: c. gen. rei, He 3:1 6:4 12:8; τ. Χριστοῦ, He 3:14.; As subst., ὁ μ., a partner, associate: Lk 5:7, He 1:9 (LXX)

to measure, of space, number, value, etc.: c. acc rei, Re 11:2 21:15, 17; c. dat. instr., Re 11:1 21:16. Metaph., ἑαυτὸν ἐν ἑαυτῷ, II Co 10:12.; to measure out, give by measure: prov., ἐν ὧ μέτρῳ κ.τ.λ., Mt 7:2, Mk 4:24, Lk 6:38 (WH, mg., cf. ἀντι-μετρέω).†
a measurer (Plat.).; = ἀμφορεύς, an Attic measure, = 11⁄2 Roman amphoræ or about 9 Eng. gallons: Jo 2:6.†
to hold one's passions or emotions in restraint; hence, to bear gently with, feel gently towards: He 5:2.†
moderately: litotes, οὐ μ., exceedingly, Ac 20:12.†

that which is used for measuring, a measure; a vessel: fig., Mt 23:32, Lk 6:38; ἐκ μ., by measure, Jo 3:34; a rod or rule: Re 21:15, 17; fig., Mt 7:2, Mk 4:24.; That which is measured, measure: c. gen. rei, Ro 12:3, II Co 10:13, Eph 4:7, 13 4:16.†

as prep., c. gen., as far as, even to, until; of place: Ro 15:19; of time : Mt 11:23 13:30 28:15, Lk 16:16, Ac 10:30 20:7, Ro 5:14, I Ti 6:14, He 3:6, 14 9:10; of measure or degree : Phl 2:8, 30, II Ti 2:9, He 12:4 (μ. αἵματος, cf. II Mac 13:14).; As conjunct. (as long as), until: Eph 4:13; μ. οὗ (Thuc., iii, 28, but more freq. μ. ἄν v. BI., § 65, 10), Mk 13:30, Ga 4:19 (μ. is prop, an adv., cf. Lat. usgue, seq. prep. or adv.; LS, s.v., and cf. ἄχρι).†

used where the negation depends on a condition or hypothesis, expressed or understood, as distinct from οὐ, which denies absolutely. μή is used where one thinks a thing is not, as distinct from an absolute negation. As a general rule, οὐ negatives the indic, μή the other moods, incl, ptcp. [In LXX for אֵין ,אַיִן ,אַל ] As a neg. adv., not; with ref. to thought or opinion: Jo 3:18, Tit 1:11, II Pe 1:9. In delib. questions, c. subjc. (M, Pr., 185): Mk 12:14, Ro 3:8. In conditional and final sentences, after εἰ, ἐάν, ἄν, ἵνα, ὅπως: Mt 10:14, Mk 6:11 12:19, Lk 9:5, Jo 6:50, Ro 11:25, al. C. inf. (v. M, Pr., 234f., 239, 255), after verbs of saying, etc.: Mt 2:12 5:34, Mk 12:18, Ac 15:38, Ro 2:21, al.; c. artic. inf.: after a prep., Mt 13:5, Mk 4:5, Ac 7:19, I Co 10:6, al.; without a prep., Ro 14:13, II Co 2:1, 13, 1 Th 4:6; in sentences expressing consequence, after ὥστε: Mt 8:28, Mk 3:20, I Co 1:7, II Co 3:7, al. C. ptcp. (v. M, Pr., 231f., 239), in hypothetical references to persons of a certain character or description: Mt 10:28 12:30, Lk 6:49, Jo 3:18, Ro 4:5, I Co 7:38, I Jo 3:10, al.; where the person or thing being definite, the denial is a matter of opinion: Jo 6:64, I Co 1:28 4:7, 18, II Co 5:21, al.; where the ptcp. has a concessive, causal or conditional force, if, though, because not: Mt 18:25, Lk 2:45, Jo 7:49, Ac 9:26, Ro 2:14 5:13, II Co 3:14, Ga 6:9, Ju 5; where the ptcp. has a descriptive force (being such as), not: Ac 9:9, Ro 1:28, I Co 10:33, Ga 4:8, He 12:27, al. μή prohibitive, in indep. sentences, c. subjc. praes., 1 pers. pl.: Ga 5:26 6:9, I Th 5:6, I Jo 3:18; c. imperat. praes., usually where one is bidden to desist from what has already begun (cf. M, Pr., 122ff.): Mt 7:1, Mk 5:36, Lk 6:30, Jo 2:16 5:45, Ac 10:15, Ro 11:18, Ja 2:1, Re 5:5, al.; forbidding that which is still future: c. imperat. aor., 3 pers., Mt 24:18, Mk 13:15, Lk 17:31, al.; c. subjc. aor., 2 pers., Mt 3:9 10:26, Mk 5:7, Lk 6:29, Jo 3:7, Ro 10:6, al.; c. optat., in wishes: II Ti 4:16 (LXX); μὴ γένοιτο (v. M, Pr., 194; Bl., §66, 1), Lk 20:16, Ro 3:3, al.; μή τις, Mk 13:5, al. As a conj., after verbs of fearing, caution, etc., that, lest, perhaps (M, Pr., 192f.): c. subjc. praes., He 12:15; c. subjc. aor., Mt 24:4, Mk 13:5, Lk 21:8, Ac 13:40, Ga 5:15, al.; ὅρα μή (v. M, Pr., 124, 178), elliptically, Re 19:10 22:9; c. indic, fut. (M, Pr., l.c.), Col 2:8. in order that not: c. subjc. aor., Mk 13:36, II Co 8:20 12:6. Interrogative, in hesitant questions (M, Pr., 170), or where a negative answer is expected: Mt 7:9, 10, Mk 2:19, Jo 3:4, Ro 3:3 10:18, 19, I Co 1:13, al.; μή τις, Lk 22:35, al.; seq. οὐ (Ro 10:17, al. in Pl.), expecting an affirm, ans.; οὐ μή, Lk 18:7, Jo 18:11. οὐ μή as emphatic negation (cf. M, Pr., 188, 190ff.; Bl. §64, 5), not at all, by no means: c. indic, fut., Mt 16:22, Jo 6:35, He 10:17, al.; c. subjc. aor., Mt 24:2, Mk 13:2, Lk 6:37, Jo 13:8, I Co 8:13, al.
by no means, not at all. μ., Κύριε (sc. τοῦτο γένοιτο), Ac 10:14 11:8.†

negative particle, related to οὐδέ as μή to οὐ,; as conic., continuing a negation or prohibition, but not, and not, nor: preceded by μή, Mt 6:25 22:29, Mk 12:24, Lk 14:12, al.; ἵνα μή, Jo 4:15; ὅπως μή, Lk 16:26; μηδέ . . . μηδέ, neither . . . nor, Mt 10:10, I Co 10:8-9.; As adv., strengthening a negation, not even: Mk 2:2, I Co 5:11, al

related to οὐδείς as μή to οὐ,; no, none, no one; neut., nothing: Mt 16:20, Mk 5:43 6:8, Lk 3:14, Ac 8:24, Ro 13:8, al.; c. gen., Ac 4:17 24:23; neut. acc, μηδέν, adverbially, in no respect, Ac 10:20 11:12; as acc. obj. after verb, βλάπτειν, Lk 4:35; ὠφελεῖσθαι, Mk 5:26; ὑστερεῖν, II Co 11:5; μεριμνᾶν, Phl 4:6; in double negation, strengthening the denial, μηκέτι μ., Mk 11:14, Ac 4:17; μὴ . . . μηδέν (μηδένα, μηδεμίαν), II Co 13:7, II Th 2:3, I Pe 3:6; μηθείς, see. μηδείς
never: II Ti 3:7.†
not yet: He 11:7.†
a Mede, Median: pl., Ac 2:9.†

no more, no longer: c. 2 aor. subjc., Mk 9:25; οὐ μ., Mt 21:19; c. praes. subjc., Ro 14:13; c. praes. imperat., Lk 8:49, Jo 5:14 8:11 Eph 4:28, I Ti 5:23; c. optat., Mk 11:14; ἵνα μ., II Co 5:15, Eph 4:14; c. inf., Mk 1:45 2:2, Ac 4:17 25:24, Ro 6:6, Eph 4:17, I Pe 4:2; c. ptcp., Ac 13:34, Ro 15:23, I Th 3:1 3:5.†
length: Eph 3:18, Re 21:16.†
to lengthen, extend: of causing plants to grow, Isa, l.c.; pass. (mid., Swete, in l), to grow: Mk 4:27.†
a sheepskin: He 11:37.†
a particle of assurance, verily, truly; εἰ (εἶ) μ. (= cl., ἦ μ. in LXX and π.), now verily, full surely: He 6:14 (LXX).†
to disclose, declare, make known: Lk 20:37, I Co 10:28; in forensic sense, to inform, report: Jo 11:57; pass., c. dat. pers., Ac 23:30.†

negative particle, related to οὔποτε as μή to οὐ.; As neg. particle, never: He 9:17 (R, mg., but v. infr.; WH, txt., μή τότε).; As conjc., lest ever, lest haply (the idea of chance rather than of time seems to prevail in NT) : Mt 4:6 (LXX) Mt 5:25 7:6 13:15 (LXX), Mt 13:29 15:32 27:64, Mk 4:12 (LXX) Mk 14:2, Lk 4:11 12:58 14:12, 29, Ac 28:27; after verbs of fearing or taking heed, Lk 21:34, He 2:1 3:12 4:1; with ellipse of the verb or ptcp., Lk 14:8, Ac 5:39; in later writers (v. M, Pr., 192 f.), perhaps, Mt 25:9.; As interrogative; in direct questions, like μή, expecting a negative answer: Jo 7:26, He 9:17, (R, txt., cf. Westc., in l; but v. supr.); in indirect questions, whether haply, if haply: Lk 3:15, II Ti 2:25.†
not yet: c. ptcp., Ro 9:11; c. acc et inf., He 9:8.†

or μή πως (so WH),; negative particle,; as conjc., lest haply: in final sentences, I Co 9:27, II Co 2:7 9:4; after verbs of fearing or taking heed, I Co 8:9, II Co 11:3 12:20, Ga 4:11; with an ellipse of ptcp. (sc. φοβούμενος; cf. B1., § 65, 3; Burton, § 225), I Th 3:5 (but v. infr.).; As interrogative, whether haply: Ga 2:2, I Th 3:5 (cf. M, Th., in l, but v. supr.).†; μήπου; lest anywhere, lest haply: Ac 27:29.†
the thigh: Re 19:16.†

negative particle, differing from οὔτε as μή from οὐ, neither, nor: μήτε . . . μήτε, neither . . .; nor, Mt 11:18, Lk 7:33 9:3, Ac 23:12, 21 27:20, He 7:3; μὴ (μηδὲ) . . . μήτε . . . μήτε, Mt 5:34, 36, Mk 3:20 T, Ac 23:8, II Th 2:2, I Ti 1:7, Ja 5:12, Re 7:1, 3.†

gen.,; μητρός, ἡ,; mother: Mt 1:18 2:11, al.; fig., of one who takes the place of a mother, ἰδοὺ, ἡ μ. μου, Mt 12:49 (cf. Mt 12:50, Mk 3:35, Jo 19:27, Ro 16:13, I Ti 5:2); of a city, ἥτις ἐσὶν μ. ἡμῶν, Ga 4:26; symbolically of Babylon, ἡ μ. τ. πορνῶν, Re 17:5
