interrog. particle, expecting a negative answer: Mt 7:16 26:22, 25, Mk 4:21 14:19, Lk 6:39, Jo 8:22 18:35, Ac 10:47, II Co 12:18, Ja 3:11; in hesitant questions (v. M, Pr., 170.), μ οὗτός ἐστιν,; can this be, Mt 12:23, Jo 4:29; μ. ἄρα, II Co 1:17; On εἰ μήτι (Lk 9:13, cf. Bl., § 65, 6), v.s. εἰ.†
strengthened form of μήτι,; let alone: i.e. according to context; much less; much more: I Co 6:3.†
(v.s. μή יׇקְמְעָם, I, III, and cf. Thayer, v.s. μήτις)
the womb: Lk 2:23 (LXX), Ro 4:19.†
a matricide: I Ti 1:9 (AV, R, txt., but v. infr.); a smiter of his mother: I Ti 1:9 (R, mg., cf. Ex 21:15, and v. Ellic., CGT, in l).†
a metropolis, chief city: ITi, subscr. (Rec.).†
to dye or stain.; to stain, defile, soil; in physical sense; in moral sense : Tit 1:15, He 12:15, Ju 8; in ritual sense (cf. Le 22:5, al.): Jo 18:28.†
chiefly in trag. and late writers; a stain, defilement: pl., II Pe 2:20.†
prop., the act of defiling.; = μίασμα (q.v.) : II Pe 2:10 (cf. Plut., Mor., 393c).†
a mixture: Jo 19:39 (ἕλιγμα, WH, R, mg.).†
to mix, mingle: c. acc et dat., Re 15:2; c. acc seq. ἐν, Re 8:7; seq. μετά, Mt 27:34, Lk 13:1.†

small, little; of persons; lit., of stature: Mk 15:40 (MM, iii, xvi; on the view that age is meant, v. Deiss., BS, 144), Lk 19:3; οἱ μ., the little ones, Mt 18:6, 10 18:14, Mk 9:42; hence metaph., of rank or influence (cf. Dalman, Words, 113 f.) : Mt 10:42, Lk 17:2, Ac 8:10 26:22, He 8:11 (LXX), Re 11:18 13:16 19:5, 18 20:12; compar., -ότερος, Mt 11:11, Lk 7:28 9:48.; Of things; of size : Mt 13:32 Mk 4:31, Ja 3:5; of quantity: Lk 12:32, I Co 5:6, Ga 5:9, Re 3:8; of time : Jo 7:33 12:35, Re 6:11 20:3.; Neut., μικρόν, used adverbially; of distance: Mt 26:39, Mk 14:35; of quantity: II Co 11:1 11:16; of time : Jo 13:33 14:19 16:16-19, He 10:37; μετὰ μ., Mt 26:73, Mk 14:70.†
a maritime city of Caria : Ac 20:15, 17, II Ti 4:20.†
a Roman mile (1680 yds.) : Mt 5:41.†
to imitate: II Th 3:7 3:9 He 13:7, III Jn 11.†
in NT always (like the verb) in good sense, an imitator: I Co 4:16 11:1, Eph 5:1, I Th 1:6 2:14, He 6:12.†

to remind: mid, and pass.; reflexive, to remind oneself of, hence, to remember: c. gen. rei, Mt 26:75, Lk 1:54, 72 24:8, Ac 11:16, II Pe 3:2, Ju 17; c. neg., of sins, = to forgive, He 8:12 10:17 (LXX); c. gen. pers., Lk 23:42; seq. ὅτι, Mt 5:23 27:63, Lk 16:25, Jo 2:17, 22 12:16; ὡς, Lk 24:6; pf., μέμνημι, in Pres. sense (cl.), c. gen. pers. (rei), I Co 11:2, II Ti 1:4; pres., μιμνήσκομαι (only in late writers), c. gen. pers., in sense of caring for, He 2:6 (LXX) He 13:3; in passive sense, to be remembered, aor., ἐμνήσθην : seq. ἐνώπιον, c. gen. pers. (cf. Ez 18:22), Ac 10:31, Re 16:19 (cf. ἀνα-, ἐπ-ανα-, ὑπο- μιμνήσκω. The tenses of this verb are from the older μνάομαι).†

to hate: c. acc pers. Mt 5:43 24:10, Lk 1:71 6:22, 27 19:14, Jo 7:7 15:18-19, 23-26 17:14, Tit 3:3, I Jn 2:9 Jn 2:11 Jn 3:13 Jn 3:15 Jn 4:20 Re 17:16; pass., Mt 10:22 24:9, Mk 13:13, Lk 21:17; c. acc rei, Jo 3:20, Ro 7:15, Eph 5:29, He 1:9, Ju 23, Re 2:6; pass., Re 18:2. As the Heb. שָׂנֵא is sometimes found with the modified sense of indifference to or relative disregard for one thing in comparison with another (cf. Ge 29:30-31, De 21:15-16, Ma 1:3) so prob. μ. in the foll.: Mt 6:24, Lk 14:26 16:13, Jo 12:25, Ro 9:13 (LXX).†
pay­ment of wages, recompense; meton.,; of reward: He 10:35 11:26; of punishment : He 2:2.†
one who pays wages; meton., a rewarder: He 11:6.†
hired; as subst., ὁ μ., a hired servant: Lk 15:17, 19 15:21 (Anth., Plut.).†

prop., wages, hire: Mt 20:8, Lk 10:7, Ro 4:4, I Ti 5:18, Ja 5:4, Ju 11; μ. ἀδικίας, Ac 1:18, II Pe 2:13 (but v. Mayor and ICC, in l), II Pe 2:15.; Generally, reward: Jo 4:36, I Co 9:18; esp. of divine rewards, Mt 5:12 6:1-2, 5 6:16 10:41-42 Mk 9:41, Lk 6:23, 35, I Co 3:8 3:14, II Jn 8, Re 11:18 22:12; ἔχειν μ., Mt 5:46, I Co 9:17.†
to let out for hire. Mid., to hire: c. acc, Mt 20:1, 7.†
price, hire (cl, and LXX).; In sense not found elsewhere, a hired dwelling: Ac 28:30.†
hired; as subst., ὁ μ., a hired servant, hireling: Mk 1:20, Jo 10:12-13.†
Mytilene, Mitylene, chief city of Lesbos: Ac 20:14.†
Michael, the Archangel (cf. Da 12:1) : Ju 9, Re 12:7.†
a mina (Let.), mna, in Attic a weight and sum of money = 100 δραχμαί (q.v.) : Lk 19:13, 16 19:18, 20 19:24-25.†
Mnason: Ac 21:16.†

remembrance, mention (= μνήμη) : Phl 1:3; μ. ποιεῖσθαι, c. gen. pers., Ro 1:9, Eph 1:16, I Th 1:2, Phm 4 (cf. Ps 111:4); μ. ἔχειν, c. gen. pers., I Th 3:6, II Ti 1:3 (on the v.l. in Ro 12:13, v. ICC, in I.; Field, Notes, 163).†
a memorial.; a sepulchral monument, a sepulchre, tomb: Mk 5:3, 5 15:46 16:2 (WH, μνημεῖον), Lk 8:27 23:53 24:1, Ac 2:29 7:16, Re 11:9.†
a memorial, record (cl., cf. Wi 10:7).; (a) (cl.) a monument: Lk 11:47; a sepulchre, tomb (Ge 23:6, 9, Is 22:16, al.): Mt 23:29, Mk 5:2, Lk 11:44, Jo 5:28, and freq. in Gospels, Ac 13:29

memory, remembrance, mention: μ. ποιεῖσθαι, c. gen., to remember, II Pe 1:15 (but in cl., π., μ. π. more freq. = to make mention, and so perh. here, cf. Mayor, in l; and for ex. from π., v. Zorell, s.v.).†

to call to mind, remember : absol., Mk 8:18; c. gen. pers., Lk 17:32, Col 4:18, I Th 1:3, He 11:15 (but v. infr.) He 13:7; τ. πτωχῶν, Ga 2:20; c. gen. rei, Jo 15:20 16:4, 21, Ac 20:35; c. acc obj. (as more freq. in cl.), of persons, II Ti 2:8; of things, Mt 16:9, I Th 2:9, Re 18:5; seq. ὅτι, Ac 20:31, Eph 2:11, II Th 2:5; πόθεν, Re 2:5; πῶς, Re 3:3.; to make mention of: c. gen., He 11:15 (but v. supr., and cf. M, Th., I, 18); seq. περί, He 11:22.†
a memorial: Mt 26:13, Mk 14:9, Ac 10:4 (where cf. Le 2:9, 16 5:12, Num_5:28, Si 45:16, al.).†
to woo and win, espouse.; to promise in marriage, betroth; pass., of the woman, to be be­trothed: c. dat. pers., Mt 1:18, Lk 1:27 2:5.†
speaking with difficulty: Mk 7:32 (Tr., txt., μογγιλάλος, thick-voiced, v. Swete, in l).†
with toil or difficulty, hardly: Lk 9:39 (μόγις, WH).†
an adulteress: Ro 7:3; meton., for μοιχεία, II Pe 2:14. Metaph., of infidelity to God (cf. Ez 16:15 ff. Ez 23:43 ff., al.), Ja 4:4; as an adj., Mt 12:39 16:4, Mk 8:8.†
to commit adultery with: c. acc, fem. In NT always mid, in same sense; of the man : absol., Mt 5:32 19:9 (WH, txt., R, mg., om.); seq. ἐπ' αὐτήν, Mk 10:11; of the woman: Mk 10:12.†

to commit adultery: absol., Mt 5:27 19:18, Mk 10:19, Lk 16:18 18:20, Ro 2:22 13:9, Ja 2:11; c. acc fem., Mt 5:28. Pass., of the woman, Mt 5:32 19:9 WH, mg.), Jo 8:4. Metaph., of idolatry (v.s. μιοιχαλίς, and cf. Je 3:9, a1.), seq. μετ' αὐτῆς, Re 2:22.†
an adulterer: Lk 18:11, I Co 6:9, He 13:4.†
post-Hom. alternative for μόγις,; with difficulty, hardly, scarcely: Lk 9:39 (T, μόγις), Ac 14:8 27:7-8, 16, Ro 5:7, I Pe 4:18 (LXX).†
Moloch, the god of the Ammonites : Ac 7:43 (LXX).†
to stain, soil, defile; in NT always symb. and fig.: I Co 8:7, Re 3:4 14:4.†
defilement: c. gen. obj., II Co 7:1 (Plut., FlJ).†
poët. form of μέμψις,; blame, com­plaint: Col 3:13.†
in cl.,; a staying, abiding; continuance (LXX, 1 c); In late Gk.,; a statson (Paus.); an abode: Jo 14:2, 23; a monastery (cf. MM, iii, xvi; so in MGr.).†
only, only begotten (DCG, ii, 281), of sons and daughters : Lk 7:12 8:42 9:38, He 11:17; of Christ, Jo 3:16, 18, I Jn 4:9; μ. παρὰ πατρός, Jo 1:14; μ. θεός, Jo 1:18.†

adj., alone, solitary, forsaken: c. verb., Mt 14:23, Mk 6:47, Lk 9:36, al.; c. pron., Mt 18:15, Mk 9:2, al.; c. subst., Mk 9:8, Lk 4:8, al.; pleonast., οὐκ . . . εἰ μὴ μ., Mt 12:4, Lk 6:4, al.; attrib., only, (ὁ) μ. θεός, Jo 5:44 17:3, Ro 16:27, I Ti 1:17, Ju 25. As adv., neut., (μόνον, alone, only: referring to verb or predic., Mt 9:21, Mk 5:36, Ja 1:22, al. (v. Bl., §44, 2); οὐ (μὴ) μ., Ga 4:18, Ja 1:22; οὐ μ. . . . ἀλλά (Bl, §77, 133), Ac 19:26, I Jo 5:6, al.; id. seq. καί (Bl., §81, 12), Ro 5:3 9:10, II Co 8:19, al.; κατὰ μόνας, alone (Bl., §44, 1), Mk 4:10, Lk 9:18.
Ionic and κοινή,; one-eyed, having one eye: Mt 18:9, Mk 9:47.†
to leave alone, forsake: of a childless widow, pf. ptcp. pass., I Ti 5:5.†
form, shape, appearance (Hom., Eur., . sch., al.); in philos. lang. the specific character or essential form (Arist., v. Gifford, Inc., 26 ff.) : Mk 16:12, Phl 2:6-7.†
to form: fig., Ga 4:19 (cf. μετα-, συμ-μορφόω)
a forming, shaping (Theophr.).; form, outline, semblance: Ro 2:20; opp. to δύναμις, II Ti 3:5.†
to make a calf (as an image) : Ac 7:41 (LXX, ἐποίησε μόσχον).†
a young shoot or twig.; ὁ, ἡ, μ., offspring; of men; of animals; most freq. (as always in LXX), a calf, bullock, heifer: Lk 15:23, 27 15:30, He 9:12, 19 Re 4:7.†
skilled in the arts, esp. in music; as subst., ὁ μ., a minstrel, musician: Re 18:22.†
toil, labour, hardship, distress: II Co 11:27, I Th 2:9, II Th 3:8.†
marrow: He 4:12.†
to initiate into the mysteries (so chiefly in cl.; LXX, l.c.); hence, to instruct: pass., Phl 4:12 (RV, I have learned the secret).†
speech, con­versation.; (a) a story, narrative (Hom.); later, opp. to λόγος (a true narrative) = Lat. fabula, a myth, fable, fiction: I Ti 1:4 4:7, II Ti 4:4, Tit 1:14, II Pe 1:16.†
prop., of oxen (onomatop.), to low, bellow; of a lion, to roar: Re 10:3.†
to turn up the nose or sneer at, mock: pass., Ga 6:7 (cf. ἐκ-μυκτηρίζω).†
of a mill: λίθος μ., Lk 17:2.†
made of mill-stone (C.l. 3371); = μυλικός: Re 18:21 (μύλον, T).†
= μύλη, a mill (Strab., Plut., LXX) : Mt 24:41, Re 18:22.; a mill-stone (Anth.) : Re 18:21 (T); μ. ὀνικός, Mt 18:6, Mk 9:42 (v. Swete, in l).†
a mill-house: Mt 24:41 (Rec.; μύλος, WH, R).†
Myra, a city of Lycia : Ac 27:5.†
ten thousand, a myriad: pl., Ac 19:19, Re 5:11 9:16; hyperb., of vast numbers, Lk 12:1, Ac 21:20, He 12:12, Ju 14.†
Ionic and poët. (comic),; to anoint: Mk 14:8.†
numberless, countless, infinite: I Co 4:15 14:19.; As a definite numeral, in pl., μύριοι, -αι, -α, ten thousand: Mt 18:24.†
Mysia, a province of Asia Minor: Ac 16:7-8.†

that which is known to the μύστης (initiated), a mystery or secret doctrine, mostly in pl., τὰ μ. (Æsch., Hdt., al.).; In later writers (Menand., Incert., 168), that which may not be revealed (not, however, as in the modern sense, intrinsically difficult to understand), a secret or mystery of any kind (To, Jth, 2Mac, ll, c.).; In NT, of the counsels of God (cf. Th.: Jb 15:8, Ps 25:14 for סוֹד), once hidden but now revealed in the Gospel or some fact thereof; of the Christian revelation generally : Ro 16:25, I Co 2:7, Col 1:26-27, Eph 3:3, 9; τ. βασιλείας τ. θεοῦ, Mk 4:11; τ. θεοῦ, I Co 2:1, Re 10:7; τ. θ., Χριστοῦ, Col 2:2; τ. Χριστοῦ., Col 4:3, Eph 3:4; τ. θελήματος αὐτοῦ, Eph 1:9; τ. εὐαγγελίον, Eph 6:19; τ. πίστεως, I Ti 3:9; τ. εὐσεβείας, I Ti 3:16; of particular truths, or details, of the Christian revelation : Ro 11:25, I Co 15:51, Eph 5:32, II Th 2:7, Re 1:20 17:5, 7; pl., τὰ μ., I Co 13:2 14:2; θεοῦ, I Co 4:1; τ. βασιλείας τ. οὐρανῶν (θεοῦ), Mt 13:11, Lk 8:10 (cf. Westc., Eph., 180 ff.; AR, Eph., 234 ff.; Lft., Col., 165 f.; Hatch, Essays, 57 f.; DB, iii, 465 ff.; DCG, ii, 213 ff.).†
to be short-sighted: II Pe 1:9 (R, mg., closing his eyes; v. ICC, in l).†
a bruise, wound from a stripe: I Pe 2:24 (LXX) (Arist., Plut., al.).†
poët. and late prose,; to find fault with, blame: II Co 8:20; pass., II Co 6:3.†
in cl. poets and late prose, blame, disgrace.; In LXX, perb. because of resemblance to a physical blemish (cf. ἄμωμος, I Pe 1:19, and v. Hort., in l); metaph., of licentious persons, II Pe 2:13.†
cl., to be foolish, play the fool.; LXX and NT, causal, to make foolish: I Co 1:20; pass., to become foolish: Ro 1:22; of salt that has lost its flavour, become tasteless: Mt 5:13, Lk 14:34.†
foolish talking: Eph 5:4.†

prop., of the nerves, dull, sluggish (Hipp., Arist.).; Of the mind, dull, stupid, foolish: Mt 5:22 (v. Field, Notes, 3 ff.) Mt 7:26 23:17, 19 (T, WH, txt., R, om.) Mt 25:2-3, 8, I Co 3:18 4:10; of things, παράδοσις, Mk 7:13 (T, WH, txt., R, om.) : ζητήσεις, II Ti 2:23, Tit 3:9; τὸ μ. τ. θεοῦ, I Co 1:25; τὰ μ. τ. κόσμου, I Co 1:27.†
Moses: Mt 8:4 17:3-4, al.; νόμος Μωυσέως, Lk 2:22 24:44, Jo 7:23, Ac 13:39 15:5 28:23, I Co 9:9, He 10:28; by meton., of the books of Moses, Lk 16:29 24:27, Ac 15:21, II Co 3:15
Naasson: Mt 1:4, Lk 3:32.†
indecl.,; Naggai: Lk 3:25.†
Ναζαρέθ (Mt 21:11, Ac 10:38),; Ναζαρέτ (so always Rec.; WH, in foll, instances, where -έθ, T), ἡ,; indecl. (Semitic form uncertain),; Nazareth: Mt 2:23, Mk 1:9, Lk 1:26 2:4, 39 2:51, Jo 1:45-46.†
Nathan: Lk 3:31.†
Nathaniel, prob. to be identified with Bartholomew (q.v.): Jo 1:45-49 21:2.†

particle of affirmation,; yea, verily, even so; in answer to a question: Mt 9:28 13:51 17:25 21:16, Jo 11:27 21:15-16, Ac 5:8 22:27, Ro 3:29; seq. λέγω ὑμῖν, Mt 11:9, Lk 7:26; repeated for emphasis, ναὶ ναί (opp. to oὒ oὔ): Mt 5:37; ἤτω ὑμῶν τὸ ναὶ ναί, Ja 5:12; ν. καὶ οὔ, II Co 1:18-19; ἵνα ᾖ . . . τὸ ναὶ ναί, II Co 1:17; τὸ ν., II Co 1:20; in assent to an assertion: Mt 15:27, Mk 7:28, Re 14:13 16:7; in confirmation of a previous assertion: Mt 11:26, Lk 10:21 11:51 12:5, Phl 4:3, Phm 20; in solemn asseveration Re 1:7 22:20.†
Naaman: Lk 4:27.†
Nain, a village of Galilee: Lk 7:11.†

a temple (Hom., Find., al.).; The inmost part of a temple, the shrine (Hat., Xen., al.); in NT,; generally: pl., Ac 17:24; of silver models of a heathen shrine, Ac 19:24; of the temple building proper, or sanctuary, at Jerusalem, as distinct from τ. ἱερόν (q.v.), the whole temple enclosure: Mt 23:16-17, 35 27:5, 40, Mk 14:58 15:29 Jo 2:19-20, Re 11:2; (τοῦ) θεοῦ, Mt 26:61 27:51, Mk 15:38, Lk 1:9, 21-22 23:45, I Co 3:17, II Co 6:16, II Th 2:4, Re 11:1; of the temple in the Apocal. visions, Re 3:12 7:15 11:19 14:15, 17 15:5-6, 8 16:1, 17 21:22 a. Metaph., of Christians, I Co 3:16 6:19, II Co 6:16, Eph 2:21; of Christ's body, Jo 2:21 (cf. Jo 2:19); ὁ θεὸς ν. αὐτῆς ἐστιν, Re 21:22 b.†
Nahum: Lk 3:25.†
nard; an Indian plant, the Nardostachys nardus jatamansi, used for the preparation of a fragrant ointment; ointment of nard: Mk 14:3, Jo 12:3.†
Narcissus: Ro 16:11.†
to suffer shipwreck: II Co 11:25; metaph., seq. περὶ τ. πίστιν, I Ti 1:19.†
a shipowner, shipmaster: Ac 27:11.†
a ship: Ac 27:41 (elsewhere in NT always τ. πλοῖον; v. M, Pr 25:1-28 f.; Bl., Gosp., 186 f.).†
a seaman, sailor: Ac 27:27, 30, Re 18:17.†
Nahor: Lk 3:34.†
a young man, youth: Mt 19:20, 22, Mk 14:51 16:5, Lk 7:14, Ac 2:17 (LXX) Ac 23:18, 22, I Jn 2:13-14; of an attendant (cf. Ge 14:24, al.) : Ac 5:10.†
Rec. for Νέα Πόλις (WH), the more freq. form (LS, s.v.),; Neapolis, a maritime city of Macedonia: Ac 16:11.†

dead, as adj., prop.: Ac 5:10 20:9, Ja 2:26, Re 1:18, al.; ὡσεὶ ν., Mt 28:4, Mk 9:26, Re 1:17; of that which is subject to death, Ro 8:10. Metaph., of persons: Lk 15:24, 32; of those immersed in worldly cares, Mt 8:22, Lk 9:60; of spiritual death, Jo 5:25, Ro 6:13, Eph 5:14, Re 3:1; τ. παραπτώμασιν, Eph 2:1, 5 Col 2:13; of the opposite condition, ν. τῇ ἁμαρτίᾳ, Ro 6:11; of things regarded as inoperative, devoid of power: ἁμαρτία, Ro 7:8; πίστις, Ja 2:17, 26; ἔργα, He 6:1 9:14. As subst., νεκρός, ὁ (Hom., al.), chiefly in pl. (οἱ) ν., the dead: Mt 11:5, Mk 12:26, Lk 20:37, I Co 15:15, al.; ἀνάστασις (τ.) νεκρῶν, Mt 22:31, Ac 17:32, al.; ν. . . . ζῶντες, Mt 22:32, Mk 12:27, Ac 10:42, al.; ἀπὸ νεκρῶν, Lk 16:30; ἐκ ν., Mk 6:14, Lk 24:46, Jo 12:1, Ac 13:34, Ro 10:7, al.; πρωτότοκος ἐκ τῶν ν., Col 1:18; ζωὴ ἐκ ν., Ro 11:15; constr. praegn., ἐκ ν. ζῶντες, Ro 6:13.
to make dead, put to death; pass., to be dead: hyperbolically, of impotent age, He 11:12; σῶμα, Ro 4:19. Trop., of carnal impulses, τὰ μέλη, Col 3:5.†
a putting to death.; a state of death, death: Ro 4:19, II Co 4:10 (v. Deiss., LAE, 94).†
new moon: of the Jewish festival, Col 2:16.†

young, youthful: Tit 2:4.; new (prop., in respect of time; v.s. καινός): οἶνος (cf. οἶ. καινός, Mt 26:20), Mt 9:17, Mk 2:22, Lk 5:37-39; φύραμα (fig.), I Co 5:7; διαθήκη (cf. καινὴ δ., He 9:15), He 12:24; metaph., ἄνθρωπος (cf. καινὸς ἀ, Eph 2:15), Col 3:10.; Compar., -ώτερος, -α, -ον, younger: Lk 15:12-13 22:26, Jo 21:18; pl., οἱ ν., Ac 5:6 (Rackham, in l), I Ti 5:11, Tit 2:6; opp. to πρεσβύτεροι, I Ti 5:1, I Pe 5:5; αἱ ν., I Ti 5:2 5:14.; Νέα Πόλις, Neapolis: Ac 16:11 (Rec., Νεάπολις, q.v.); νεώτερος, v.s. νέος
newly planted (LXX). Metaph., as subst., ὁ ν., a new convert, neophyte, novice: I Ti 3:6†
Nero: 2Ti subscr. (Rec.).†
to nod or beckon, as a sign : c. dat. pers. et inf., Jo 13:24, Ac 24:10 (cf. δια-, ἐκ-, ἐν-, ἐπι-, κατα-νεύω).†

a cloud (single and specific as opp. to νεφος, a great indefinite mass of vapour): Mt 17:5 24:30 26:64, Mk 9:7 13:26 14:62, Lk 9:34-35 12:54 21:37, Ac 1:9, I Th 4:17, Ju 12, Re 1:7 10:1 11:12 14:14-16; of the pillar of cloud in the wilderness (Ex 14:19-20, Ps 105:39, al.): I Co 10:1-2.†
indecl. (Heb. נַפְתָּלִי); Naphtali: Mt 4:13, 15 (LXX) Re 7:6.†
a mass of clouds, a cloud (cf. νεφέλη); metaph. as in Hom., Hdt., al.), of a dense throng: He 12:1.†
a kidney; pl., the kidneys, reins; metaph., of the will and affections: ν. καί καρδίαι (thoughts), Re 2:23.†
a temple-keeper; as honorary title given to a city (v. DB, i, 722 b) : Ac 19:35.†
= νεανικός,; youthful, esp. of qualities: ἐπιθυμίαι, II Ti 2:22 (Polyb.).†
by: c. acc, I Co 15:31.†
to spin: Mt 6:28, Lk 12:27.†
to be a babe: I Co 14:20.†

infant; of children and minors: Mt 21:16 (LXX), I Co 13:11, Ga 4:1 (v. Lft., in l). Metaph., childish, unskilled, simple (Ps 19:8, Pr 1:32 al.): Mt 11:25, Lk 10:21, Ro 2:20, Ga 4:3, Eph 4:14, I Th 2:7 (WH, fox ἤπιοι); opp. to τέλειος, He 5:13; ν. ἐν Χριστῷ, I Co 3:1.†
Neri: Lk 3:27.†
Nereus: Ro 16:15.†
a small island: Ac 27:16.†

fasting, a fast; of voluntary abstinence from food: Mt 17:21 (WH, R, txt., om.), Mk 9:29 (WH, txt., R, txt., om.), Lk 2:37, Ac 14:23; of the Day of Atonement, Ac 27:9; of involuntary abstinence: II Co 6:5 11:27.†
in cl., chiefly poët.,; not eating, fasting: Mt 15:32, Mk 8:3.†
in cl., of drink, not mixed with wine.; In later writers (Plut., al.), of persons, sober, temperate: I Ti 3:2 3:11, Tit 2:2.†
to be sober, abstain from wine; metaph., of moral alertness, to be sober, calm, circumspect: I Th 5:6 5:8, II Ti 4:5 (v. Ellic., in l), I Pe 1:13 4:7 5:8 (cf. ἐκ-, ἐκ-νήφω, and v. MM, xvii).†
Niger: Ac 13:1.†
Nicanor: Ac 6:5.†

to conquer, prevail: absol., of Christ, Re 3:21 6:2; C. inf., Re 5:5; of Christians, Re 2:7, 11 2:17, 26 3:5, 12 3:21 21:7; seq. ἐκ (RV, come victorious from), Re 15:2; as law-term (cl.), Ro 3:4 (LXX); c. acc pers., Lk 11:22, Re 11:7 13:7 ([WH], R, mg., om.); of Christ, Jo 16:33 (τ. κόσμον), Re 17:14; of Christians, I Jn 4:4; τ. πονηρόν, I Jn 2:13-14; αὐτόν (ref. to ὁ κατήγωρ, I Jn 2:10), Re 12:11; c. acc rei, τὸν κόσμον, Jo 16:33, I Jn 5:4-5; τὸ κακόν, Ro 12:21; pass., μὴ νικῶ ὑπὸ τ. κακοῦ, ib. (cf. ὑπερ-νικάω).†
victory: I Jn 5:4.†
a Nicolaitan: pl., Re 2:6, 15.†
Nicolaus: Ac 6:5.†
Nicopolis, prob. the city of that name in Epirus (CGT, in l): Tit 3:12†
victory: Mt 12:20 (Is 42:3, LXX ἀλήθεια), I Co 15:54 (Is 25:8, Aq., Th.), I Co 15:55 (Ho 13:14, LXX δίκη), I Co 15:57.†
a Ninevite: Mt 12:41, Lk 11:30, 32.†
Nineveh: Lk 11:32, Rec.†
a basin: Jo 13:5.†

to wash, usually of a part of the body: c. acc pers., Jo 13:8; τ. πόδας, Jo 13:5-6, 8 13:12, 14, I Ti 5:10; mid., reflexive,; to wash oneself: Jo 9:7, 11 9:15; τ. χεῖρας, Mt 15:2, Mk 7:3; τ. πόδας, Jo 13:10; τ. πρόσωπον, Mt 6:17 (in cl. Att.. prose, used only in compounds; cf. ἀπο-νίπτω).†; νίζω, v.s. νίπτω

to perceive with the mind, understand (for the phrase νοῶν κ. φρονῶν, in wills, v. MM, xvii): absol., Mt 16:9, Mk 8:17; c. acc, Eph 3:4, I Ti 1:7; c. dat. instr., τ. καρδίᾳ, Jo 12:40; pass., Ro 1:20; seq. ὅτι, Mt 15:17 16:11, Mk 7:18; c. acc et inf., He 11:8.; to think, consider: absol., Mt 24:15, Mk 13:14, Eph 3:20; c. acc rei, II Ti 2:7; (cf. -εὐ, κατα-, μετα-, προ-, ὑπο-νοέω).†
a thought, purpose, design: II Co 2:11 10:5 11:3, Phl 4:7. Meton., of the mind, II Co 3:14 4:4.†
a bastard, base born, i.e. born of a slave or concubine: He 12:8.†
a pasture, pasturage: fig., Jo 10:9; a grazing, feeding; metaph., of a spreading sore, II Ti 2:17 (Polyb.).†
to practise, hold by custom: Ac 16:13 (Rec., but v. infr.).; to deem, consider, suppose: Mt 5:17 10:34 20:10, Lk 2:44 3:23, Ac 7:25 8:20 14:19 16:13, 27 17:29 21:29, I Co 7:26 7:36, I Ti 6:5.†
relating to law: μάχαι, Tit 3:9.; learned in the law; as subst., ὁ ν. (EV, lawyer): Mt 22:35, Lk 10:25, Tit 3:13; pl., Lk 7:30 11:45-46, 52 14:3 (cf. MM, xvii).†
rightly, lawfully: I Ti 1:8, II Ti 2:5.†
that which is established by usage, a custom.; The current coin of a state: Mt 22:19.†
a teacher of the law: Lk 5:17, Ac 5:34, I Ti 1:7 (NT and eccl. only; cf. νομοδείκτης, -διδάκτης, Plut.).†
legislation, lawgiving: Ro 9:4.†
intrans., to make laws; pass., to be furnished with laws: He 7:11.; Trans., to ordain by law, enact: pass., He 8:6.†
a law­giver: Ja 4:12.†

that which is assigned, hence, usage, custom, then law; in NT (only in Mt, Jo, Ja, and the Lucan and Pauline bks.); of law in general: Ro 3:27 5:13b; pl., of divine laws, He 8:10 10:16; ὁ ν. τ. Χριστοῦ, Ga 6:2; (τ.) ἐλευθερίας, Ja 1:25 2:12; βασιλικιός (Hort., in l.; Deiss., LAE, 267:3), Ja 2:8. Of a force or influence impelling to action: Ro 7:21, 23a, 25 8:2. Of the Mosaic law: Mt 5:18, Lk 2:27, Jo 1:17, Ac 6:13, Ro 2:15, I Co 9:8, I Ti 1:8, He 7:19; al.; Μωυσέως, Lk 2:22, Jo 7:23, Ac 15:5, al.; κυρίου, Lk 2:39; κατὰ τὸν ν., Ac 22:12, He 7:5 9:22. As printed, Abbott-Smith mistakenly numbers this as 3.Anarthrous (Bl, §46, 8; ICC on Ro 2:12, 13), νόμος, of law in general: Ro 2:12, 14b 3:20, 21 4:15, al.; of the Mosaic law in its quality as law: Ro 2:14a 5:20 10:4, Ga 2:19, al.; οἱ ἐκ ν., Ro 4:14; ὑπὸ νόμον, I Co 9:20, Ga 4:5; ν. πράσσειν (πληροῦν), Ro 2:25 13:8. Of Christian teaching: ν. πίστεως, Ro 3:27; τ. Χριστοῦ, Ga 6:2. By meton., of the books which contain the law; of the Pentateuch: Mt 12:5, Jo 1:45, al.; ὁ ν. καὶ οἱ προφῆται, Mt 5:17, Lk 16:16, al.; ὁ ν. καὶ προφῆται κ. ψαλμοί, Lk 24:44. of the OT Scriptures in general (as Heb. תֹּורָה): Jo 10:34 12:34 15:25, I Co 14:21, al.
to be sick: metaph., of mental ailment, seq. περί, I Ti 6:4 (cf. Plat., Mor., 546 d).†
sickness: Jo 5:4.†
late form of cl., νεοσσιά,; a nest of birds.; a brood of young birds: Lk 13:34.†
a young bird: Mt 23:37.†
a young bird: Lk 2:24 (LXX).†

in Hom., as depon., to turn away (from), abandon.; After Hom., in act., to set apart, remove. Mid., to set apart for oneself, peculate, purloin: absol., Tit 2:10 (for ex. in π., v. MM, xvii); seq. ἀπό, Ac 5:2-3.†
prop., the south wind: Lk 12:55, Ac 27:13 28:13; South: Lk 13:29, Re 21:13; the South, as a region (cf. נֶגֶב): Mt 12:42, Lk 11:31.†
= cl. νουθέτησις; admonition: I Co 10:11, Eph 6:4, Tit 3:10 (Aristoph., Diod., al.).†
to admonish, exhort: c. acc pers., Ac 20:31, Ro 15:14, I Co 4:14, Col 1:28 3:16, I Th 5:12 5:14, II Th 3:15.†
sensibly, discreetly: Mk 12:34.†

prop., of the ruling faculty, mind, understanding, reason (v. Lft., Notes, 88 f.; Vaughan on Ro 7:23): Lk 24:45, Ro 1:28 7:23 12:2 14:5, Eph 4:17, 23 Phl 4:7, II Th 2:2, I Ti 6:5, II Ti 3:8, Tit 1:15, Re 13:18 17:9; ν. τ. σαρκός (ICC, in l), Col 2:18; opp. to σάρξ, Ro 7:25; to πνεῦμα, I Co 14:14-15; to γλῶσσα, I Co 14:19; By meton., of an act of mind, a mind, thought, purpose: Ro 11:34 = I Co 2:16 (LXX), I Co 1:10.†; νόος, v.s. νοῦς
Nympha (v. M, Pr., 48): Col 4:15, WH, R, mg.†
Nymphas: Col 4:15, R, txt. (cf. ICC, Lft., in l).†

cl., a bride, young wife, young woman: Mt 25:1, WH, mg., Jo 3:29, Re 18:23 21:2, 9 22:17.; As freq. in LXX (Ge 38:11, al., for כַּלָּה; bride; daughter-in-law) and in MGr. (νύφφη, νύφη), a daughter-in-law: Mt 10:35, Lk 12:53.†

the bride-chamber (Heb. חֻפָּה, LXX, παστός, Ps 19:5, Jl 2:16): Mt 22:10 (WE; γάμος, RV); οἱ υἱοὶ τοῦ ν. (cf. cl. νυμφαγωγός, νυμφευτής), the bridegroom's friends who have charge of the nuptial arrangements: Mt 9:15, Mk 2:19, Lk 5:34.†

prop., of time, now, i.e. at the present time: as opp. to past, Jo 4:18, Ac 7:52, Ro 13:11, II Co 7:9, Col 1:24, al.; opp. to fut., Jo 12:27, Ro 11:31, al.; c. art., ὁ (ἡ, τὸ) et subst., the present: Ro 3:26, Ga 4:25, I Ti 6:17, Tit 2:12, al.; απὸ τοῦ ν. (LXX for מֵעַתָּה), Lk 1:48, Ac 18:6, al.; ἄχρι τοῦ ν., Ro 8:22, Phl 1:5; ἕως τοῦ ν. (LXX for עַד עַתָּה), Mt 24:21, Mk 13:19; τὰ ν., as regards the present, Ac 5:38; c. pret., just now, but now, Mt 26:65, Jo 11:8 21:10; c. fut., now, presently, Jo 12:31, Ac 20:22; so c. praes., presently, forthwith, Jo 12:31 17:13; καὶ ν., Jo 11:22 17:5, al.; ἀλλὰ ν., Lk 22:36; ἔτι ν., I Co 3:2; τότε (πότε) . . . ν. (δέ), Ro 6:21 11:30; ν. ἤδη, I Jo 4:3; ν. οὖν, Ac 10:33, al. Of logical sequence (often difficult to disting. from the temporal sense; cf. Lft., Notes, 113f.), now, therefore, now, however, as it is: Lk 11:39; καὶ ν., Ac 3:17, II Th 2:6, I Jo 2:28; id. seq. δεῦρο, Ac 7:34; ν. δέ, Jo 8:40 9:41 15:22, 24, 18:36, I Co 5:11 7:14 12:20, al. (cf. WM, 57911).

now; of time: c. praes., Ac 24:13, Ro 15:23, 25, I Co 13:13, II Co 8:11 8:22, Phm 9 11; c. pf., Ro 3:21; c. pret., Ro 6:22 11:30 (WH, mg.) Ro 7:6, Eph 2:13, Col 1:21 3:8; ἡ ν. ἀπολογία, Ac 22:1.; Of logical sequence (not so in cl.): Ro 7:17, I Co 5:11 (νῦν, WH) I Co 12:18 (νῦν, WH, txt.) I Co 15:20, He 8:6 (νῦν, WH, txt.), He 9:26 (cf. WM, 24, 579n).†

night: Mt 12:40, Mk 6:48, Jo 13:30, al.; gen. temp. (of the time within which something happens; M, Pr., 73; B1., § 36, 13), νυκτός, by night, Mt 2:14, Jo 3:2, I Th 5:7, al.; ν. κ. ἡμέρας, Mk 5:5, I Th 2:9, al.; ἡμέρας κ. ν., Lk 18:7, Re 4:8, al.; μέσης ν., Mt 25:6; dat., νυκτί, in ans. to the question, "when?" (rare in cl.; Hdt., Soph.), ταύτῃ τ. ν., Lk 12:20, al.; ἐκείνῃ Ac 12:6; ἐπιούσῃ, Ac 23:11; acc durat. (Bl., § 34, 8; Kühner3, III, 314b), ν. κ. ἠμέραν, Lk 2:37 Ac 20:31; τ. νύκτας, Lk 21:37; διὰ νυκτός (= cl. νυκτός; Bl., § 42, 1; 46, 7), Ac 5:19 16:9 17:10 23:31; δι' ὅλης ν., Lk 5:5; κατὰ μέσον τῆς ν. (Bl., § 47, 6), Ac 27:27. Metaph.: Jo 9:4, Ro 13:12, I Th 5:5
to pierce: τ. πλευρὰν λόγχῃ, Jo 19:34, [Mt 27:49], WH.†
to nod in sleep, fall asleep: Mt 25:5. Metaph., of negligence or delay, ἡ ἀπώλεια αὐτῶν οὐ νυστάζει (cf. Ps 121:4, Is 5:27) : II Pe 2:3.†
lasting a night and a day; as subst., (τὸ) ν., a night and a day: II Co 11:25 (pl., Or. Sib., 8, 203).†
sluggish, slothful: He 5:11 6:12 (for similar usage in π., v. MM, xvii).
/the back: Ro 11:10 (LXX).†

hospitality, enter­tainment: Phm 22 (cf. ICC, in l, but v. infr.). By meton., a place of entertainment, a lodging-place: Ac 28:23, and so perh. Phm 22 (Lft., in l, Phi., p. 9; but v. supr., and cf. MM, xvii).†

to receive as a guest, entertain: c. acc pers., Ac 10:23 28:7, He 13:2; pass., Ac 10:6, 18 10:32 21:16.; In late writers (Polyb., al.; 2Mac, l.c.), to surprise, astonish by strangeness: Ac 17:20; pass., I Pe 4:4 4:12.†
to entertain strangers: I Ti 5:10.†

foreign, alien: δαιμόνια, Ac 17:18; διδαχαί He 13:9; c. gen. rei, strange to, estranged from, ignorant of: Eph 2:12; strange, unusual: I Pe 4:12.; As subst., ὁ ξ.,; a foreigner, stranger: Mt 25:35, 38 25:43-44 27:7, Ac 17:21, III Jn 5; ξέίνοι κ. τάροικοι (opp. to συμπολῖται, οίκεῖοι), Eph 2:19; ξ. καὶ παρεπίδημοι, He 11:13; one of the parties bound by ties of hospitality; the guest; the host (= ξενοδόκος, Hom., Ii, xv, 532) : Ro 16:23.†
a sextarius (about a pint).; In NT, a pitcher of wood or stone : Mk 7:4.†

to dry up, parch, wither. c. acc, τ. χόρτον, Ja 1:11; pass., to become or be dry or withered. of plants, Mt 13:6 21:19-20, Mk 4:6 11:20-21, Lk 8:6, Jo 15:6, I Pe 1:24; of ripened crops, Re 14:15; of liquids, Mk 5:20, Re 16:12; of members of the body, to waste away, Mk 3:1 (cf. III Ki 13:4) Mk 9:18.†

dry: metaph. (of a sinner), ξύλον ξ., Lk 23:31; of members of the body shrunken by disease, withered: Jo 5:3; of the hand, Mt 12:10 Mk 3:3, Lk 6:6, 8; of the dry land, ἡ ξηρά (sc. γῆ, cf. Ge 1:9-10; Jh 1:19, al.): Mt 23:15; γῆ, He 11:29.†
wooden: II Ti 2:20, He 9:20 (cf. Ep. Je 4:1-31 ff).†

wood: I Co 3:12, Re 18:12.; a piece of wood, hence, anything made of wood, as,; a cudgel, staff: pl., Mt 26:47, 55, Mk 14:43, 48, Lk 22:52; stocks, for confining the feet (Jb 33:11, סַד) : Ac 16:24; a beam to which malefactors were bound (late Gk.), in LXX, of a gibbet (De 21:22-23), in NT, of the Cross: Ac 5:30 10:39 13:29, Ga 3:13, I Pe 2:24.; In late writers (v. MM, xvii), a tree (Ge 1:29, Is 14:8, al.) : Lk 23:31; ξ. τῆς ζωῆς, Re 2:7 22:2, 14 22:19.†
late form of ξυρέω (q.v.) : I Co 11:6 (ξυρᾶσθαι, Rec. and Edd., but v.s. ξύρω).†
to shave: pass. and mid., to shave oneself, have oneself shaved, aor., Ac 21:24; pf. (Att..), I Co 11:5.†

As demonstr. pron. As freq. in Hom., absol., he (she, it), his (etc.): Ac 17:28 (quoted from the poet Aratus). Distributive, ὁ μὲν . . . ὁ δέ, the one . . . the other: I Co 7:7, Ga 4:22; pl., Ac 14:4, 17:32, Phl 1:16, al.; οἱ μὲν . . . ἄλλοι δέ, Mt 16:14, Jo 7:12; οἱ μεν̀ . . . ὁ δέ, He 7:21, 23. In narration (without ὁ μὲν preceding), ὁ δέ, but he: Mt 2:14, Mk 1:45, Lk 8:21, Jo 9:38, al. mult. As prepositive article, the, prefixed, to nouns unmodified: ὁ θεός, τὸ φῶς, etc.; to abstract nouns, ἡ σοφία, etc., to pl. nouns which indicate a class, οἱ ἀλώπεκες, foxes, Mt 8:20, al.; to an individual as representing a class, ὁ ἐργάτης, Lk 10:7; c. nom. = voc. in addresses, Mt 11:26, Jo 19:3, Ja 5:1, al.; to things which pertain to one, ἡ χεῖρ, his hand, Mk 3:1; to names of persons well known or already mentioned; usually to names of countries (originally adjectives), ἡ Ἰουδαία, etc. To modified nouns: c. pers. pron. gen., μοῦ, σοῦ, etc.; c. poss. pron., ἐμός, σός, etc.; c. adj. between the art. and the noun, ὁ ἀγαθὸς ἄνθρωπος, Mt 12:35; the noun foll, by adj., both c. art., ὁ ποιμὴν ὁ καλός, Jo 10:11 (on ὁ ὄχλος πολύς, Jo 12:9, v. M, Pr., 84); before adjectival phrases, ἡ κατ’ ἐκλογὴν πρόθεσις, Ro 9:11. To Other parts of speech used as substantives; neuter adjectives: τ. ἀγαθόν, etc.; cardinal numerals: ὁ εἶς, οἷ δύο, etc.; participles: ὁ βαπτίζων (= ὁ Βαπτιστής, Mt 14:2), Mk 6:14; πᾶς ὁ, c. ptcp., every one who, etc.; adverbs: τὸ πέραν, τὰ νῦν, ὁ ἔσω ἄνθρωπος; infinitives: nom., τὸ θέλειν, Ro 7:18, al.; gen., τοῦ, after adjectives, ἄξιον τοῦ πορεύεσθαι, I Co 16:4; verbs, ἐλαχεν τοῦ θυμιᾶσαι, Lk 1:9; and freq. in a final sense, ἐξῆλθεν ὁ σπείρειν, Mt 13:3 (on the artic. inf., v. Bl., §71). In the neut. to sentences, phrases or single words treated as a quotation: τὸ Ἐι δύνῃ, Mk 9:23; τὸ ἔτι ἅπαξ, He 12:27; τὸ ἀνέβη, Eph 4:9, al. To prepositional phrases: οἱ ἀπὸ Ἰταλίας, He 13:24; οἱ ἐκ νόμου, Ro 4:14; neut. acc. absol., in adverbial phrases, τὸ καθ' ἡμέραν, daily, Lk 11:3; τὸ κατὰ σάρκα, as regards the flesh, Ro 9:5. To nouns in the genitive, denoting kinship, association, etc.: ὁ τοῦ, the son of (unless context indicates a different relationship), Mt 10:2, al.; τὰ τοῦ θεοῦ, the things that pertain to God, Mt 16:23; τὰ τῆς εἰρήνης, Ro 14:19 (cf. M, Pr., 81ff.; Bl, §§46, 47).
eighty: Lk 2:37 16:7.†

the eighth. Lk 1:59, Ac 7:3 (LXX), Re 17:11 21:20; one of eight, with seven others (usually, in this sense, with αὐτός added, but cf. Plat., Legg., iii, 695 c; Plut., Pelop., 13; II Mac 5:27): II Pe 2:5.†
bulk, mass; metaph., an encumbrance: He 12:1.†

referring prop, to what is present, can be seen or pointed out: of a person just named, τῇδε (= ταύτῃ), Lk 10:39; neut. pl., τάδε (λέγει), referring to words which follow (so in Att.., and v. MM, xvii) : Ac 21:11, Re 2:1, 8 2:12, 18 3:1, 7 3:14; εἰς τήνδε τ. πόλιν (= Att.. τῇ καὶ τῇ, Plat., Legg., iv, 721 B), such and such a city, Ja 4:13.†
to travel, journey: Lk 10:33 (cf.δι-, συν-οδεύω).†
to lead on one's way, to guide: c. acc pers., Mt 15:14, Lk 6:39; id. seq. ἐπί, Re 7:17. Metaph., to guide, instruct, teach: Ac 8:31; seq. εἰς τ. ἀλήθειαν (ἐν τ. ἀ., WH, mg.), Jo 16:13 (cf. Ps 25:5).†
a leader on the way, a guide: Ac 1:16. Fig., ὁ. τυφλῶν, Ro 2:19; pl., Mt 15:14 23:16, 24.†
to travel, journey: Ac 10:9.†
a journey. Jo 4:6, II Co 11:26.†

a way, path, road: Mt 2:12, Mk 10:46, Lk 3:5 al.; κατὰ τὴν ὁ., Lk 10:4, al.; παρὰ τὴν ὁ., Mt 13:4, al.; c. gen. pers, (subj.), τὴν ὁ. ἑτοιμάζειν (fig.), Mt 3:3, Mk 1:3, al.; c. gen. term. (obj.), ἐθνῶν, Mt 10:5; τ. ἁγίων (fig.), He 9:8; acc., ὁδόν, with force of prep. (like Heb. דֶּרֶךְ; Bl., §34, 8; 35, 5), ὁ. θαλάσσης, Mt 4:15 (LXX). A traveller's way, journey: ἐν τ. ὁ., Mt 5:25, Mk 8:27, al.; ἐξ ὁ., Lk 11:6; εἰς ὁ., Mt 10:10; τ. ὁδὸν πορεύεσθαι, Ac 8:39; ὁ. ἡμέρας, Lk 2:44; ὁδὸν ποιεῖν (= cl., ὁ. ποιεῖσθαι; V. Field, Notes, 25), to make one's way, i.e. proceed on one's journey, Mk 2:23. Metaph. (cl.; but esp. freq. in Heb.; v. Cremer, 442ff.), of a course of conduct, a way of thinking or acting: Ac 14:16, I Co 4:17 12:31, Ja 1:8 5:20; τοῦ Κάϊν, Ju 11; τ. Βαλαάμ, II Pe 2:15; εἰρήνης, Ro 3:17; ζωῆς, Ac 2:28; ἡ ὁ. ἡ ἀπάγουσα εἰς τ. ζωήν (Dalman, Words, 160), Mt 7:14; τ. δικαιοσύνης, Mt 21:32; σωτηρίας, Ac 16:17; αἱ ὁ. τ. θεοῦ (κυρίου), Ac 13:10, Ro 11:33, Re 15:3 (cf. Ho 14:9 Ps 94 (95):10, Si 39:24, al.); ἡ ὁ. τ. θεοῦ (the way approved by God), Mt 22:16, Mk 12:14, Lk 20:21; id., of the Christian religion, Ac 18:26; so, absol., ἡ ὁ., Ac 9:2 19:9, 23 24:22; of Christ as the means of approach to God, Jo 14:6. Ellipsis of ὁ.: ποίας (sc. ὁδοῦ), Lk 5:19; ἐκείνης, ib. 19:4 (v. Bl., §36, 13; 44, 1).
to cause pain or suffering; pass. and mid., to suffer pain, be tormented or greatly distressed: Lk 2:48 16:24-25 (ὀδυνᾶσαι, v. M, Pr., 53 f.); seq. ἐπί, Ac 20:38.†
pain, distress, of body or mind : Ro 9:2, I Ti 6:10.†
lamentation, mourning: Mt 2:18 (LXX), II Co 7:7.†
to smell (i.e. emit a smell): Jo 11:39.†

whence; of direction or source: Mt 12:44, Lk 11:24, Ac 14:26 28:13; = ἐκεῖθεν ὅπου, Mt 25:24, 26 (cf. Thuc., i, 89, 3); ὅ. γινώσκομεν, I Jn 2:18; of cause, whence, wherefore: Mt 14:7, Ac 26:19, He 2:17 3:1 7:25 8:3 9:18 11:19.†
fine linen (Hom., al.).; Later, a sheet or sail: Ac 10:11 11:5.†
a piece of fine linen, a linen cloth; Lk 24:12 (WH, R, mg., om.), Jo 19:40 20:5-7.†

to have seen or perceived, hence, to know, have knowledge of: c. acc. rei, Mt 25:13, Mk 10:19, Jo 10:4, Ro 7:7, al.; c. acc. pers., Mt 26:72, Jo 1:31, Ac 3:16, al.; τ. θεόν, I Th 4:5, Tit 1:16, al.; c. acc. et inf., Lk 4:41, al.; seq. ὅτι, Mt 9:6, Lk 20:21, Jo 3:2, Ro 2:2 11:2, al.; seq. quaest. indir., Mt 26:70, Jo 9:21, Eph 1:18, al.; c. inf., to know how (cl.), Mt 7:11, Lk 11:13, Phl 4:12, I Th 4:4, al.; in unique sense of respect, appreciate: I Th 5:12 (but v. also ICC on I Th 4:4).

in or of the house (opp. to ξένος, ἀλλότριος); of things; τὰ οἰ., household affairs or goods; of persons, of the same family or kin; as subst., οἱ οἰ., kinsmen: I Ti 5:8; c. gen. pers., of the family of: metaph., τ. θεον, Eph 2:19; τ. πίστεως (Lft., in l), Ga 6:10.†; SYN,: συγγενής, ἴδιος (v. Cremer, 446; Deiss., BS, 123)
a household (of servants): Mt 24:45.†
a house-servant: Lk 16:13, Ro 14:4; pl., Ac 10:7, I Pe 2:18 (In Plat., Hdt., Si 4:30 6:11, the pl. includes all the inmates of the house, the familia, οἰκετεία.)†

trans., to inhabit: c. acc, I Ti 6:16; intrans., to dwell: seq. μετά (of married life), I Co 7:12-13; metaph., seq. ἐν: ἀγαθόν, Ro 7:18; ἁμαρτία, Ro 7:20; πνεῦμα θεοῦ, Ro 8:9, 11, I Co 3:16 (cf. ἐν-, κατ-, ἐν-κατ-, παρ-, περι-, συν-οικέω).†
a dwelling. As a euphemism for other definite terms (e.g. brothel. Hdt., ii, 121; cf. Ez, l.c.), a prison (Thus., iv, 47 f.); Ac 12:7.†
a habitation: Ju 6; trop., II Co 5:2.†

a house, dwelling: Mt 2:11 7:24-27, Mk 1:29, al.; ἐν οἰκίᾳ (= cl. κατ ̓ οἰκίαν), at home, Lk 8:27; εἰς οἰ., II Jn 10; οἰ, c. gen. pers., usually has the art. (Mt 8:14, al., but cf. οἶκος and v. Bl., § 46, 9); ἡ οἰ. τ. πατρός μου, Jo 14:2.; Metaph.,; of the body as the dwelling of the soul: II Co 5:1; of property (as בַּיִת, Ge 45:18, LXX, τ. υπάρχοντα; III Ki 13:8, LXX, οἶκος) = οἶκος (q.v.): Mk 12:40, Lk 20:47; of the inmates of the dwelling, the household: Mt 12:25; c. gen. pers., Jo 4:53, I Co 16:15
belonging to the household, one's own: Mt 10:36; opp. to οἰκοδεσπότης, Mt 10:25.†
to rule a household: I Ti 5:14.†
the master of a house, a householder: Mt 10:25 13:27 20:11 24:43, Mk 14:14, Lk 12:39 13:25 14:21; ἄνθρωπος οἰ., Mt 13:52 20:1 21:33; pleonast., oἰ. τ. οἰκίας, Lk 22:11 (v. Bl., § 81, 4).†

to build a house, to build: absol., Lk 11:48 14:30 17:28; οἱ οἰκοδομοῦντες, the builders (as Ps 118:22, בָּנָה), Mt 21:42, Mk 12:10, Lk 20:17, I Pe 2:7 (LXX); ἐ π ̓ ἀλλότριον θεμέλιον οἰ., proverb., Ro 15:20; c. acc rei, Ga 2:18; πύργον), Mt 21:33, Mk 12:1, Lk 14:28; ἀποθήκας, Lk 12:18; ναόν, Mk 14:58; pass., Jo 2:20; οἰκία, Lk 6:48; c. acc rei seq. dat. pers. (cf. Ge 8:20, Ez 16:24), Lk 7:5, Ac 7:47, 49; acc seq. ἐπί, Mt 7:24, 26 Lk 6:49; πόλιν ἐπ ̓ ὄρους, Lk 4:29; of rebuilding, or restoring, Mt 23:29 26:61 27:40, Mk 15:29, Lk 11:47, Metaph., τ. ἐκκλησίαν, Mt 16:18; of the growth of Christian character (cf. בָּנָה, in Ps 28:5, Je 24:6, al.), to build up (AV, edify): absol., Ac 20:32, I Co 8:1 10:23; c. acc pers., I Co 14:4, I Th 5:11; pass., Ac 9:31, I Co 14:17, I Pe 2:5; of blameworthy action (AV, embolden), I Co 8:10 (cf. ἀν-, ἐπ-, συν-οικοδομέω).†; οἰκο-δόμος, -ου, ὁ; a builder: Ac 4:11.†

= cl. οἰκοδομία (q.v.), -δόμησις (Thuc., Plat.),; the act of building; in NT always metaph., building up, edifying: Ro 14:19 15:2, I Co 14:26, II Co 10:8 13:10, Eph 4:29; c. gen. obj., I Co 14:12, II Co 12:19, Eph 4:12, 16; λαλεῖν, λαβεῖν, οἰ., I Co 14:3.; = οἰκοδόμημα, a building: Mt 24:1, Mk 13:1-2; metaph., I Co 3:9, II Co 5:1, Eph 2:21.†
the act of building: metaph., I Ti 1:4 (BE for οἰκοδομία, q.v.).†
to manage as house-steward, be a steward: absol., Lk 16:2; hence, generally (v.s. οἰκονομία), to manage, regulate, arrange (cl., 2Mac, Lc., III Mac 3:2 R).†

prop. (Plat., Arist.), the office of οἰκονόμος, stewardship: Lk 16:2-4.; In later writers (Plut., al.; v. AR on Eph 1:10; MM, xviii), generally, administration, dispensation: I Co 9:17, Eph 1:10 3:2, 9, Col 1:25, I Ti 1:4.†

prop., the manager of a household or estate, a house- or land-steward (usually a slave or freedman): Lk 12:42 16:1, 3 16:8, I Co 4:2, Ga 4:2; ὀ οἰ. τ. πόλεως (RV, treasurer; cf. I Es 4:49), Ro 16:23.; Metaph. (in wider sense; cf. οἰκονομία), an administrator, a steward: of Christian ministers, I Co 4:1, Tit 1:7; of Christians generally, I Pe 4:10.†

prop., a house, dwelling: Ac 2:2 19:16; c. gen. poss., Mt 9:6, 7 Mk 2:11, Lk 1:23, al.; c. gen. attrib., ἐμπορίου, Jo 2:16; προσευχῆς, Mt 21:13, al.; of a sanctuary (Hdt., Eur.): οἶ. τ. θεοῦ, of the tabernacle, Mt 12:4, al.; the temple, Mt 21:13, al.; metaph. of a city: Mt 23:38, Lk 13:35; of the body, Mt 12:44, Lk 11:24; of Christians, I Pe 2:5; ἐν οἴ (M, Pr., 81f.), at home, Mk 2:1, I Co 11:34 14:35; so κατ ̓ οἶκον, Ac 2:46 5:42; οἱ εἰς (= οἱ ἐν; v.s. εἰς) τ. οἶ., Lk 7:10 15:6; κατ ̓οἴκους, from house to house, Ac 8:3 20:20; εἰς (κατ ̓) οἶκον, c. gen. (Bl., §46, 9), Mk 8:3, Lk 14:1, Ro 16:5, al. By meton., a house, household, family: Lk 10:5, Ac 7:10, I Co 1:16, I Ti 3:4, 5 al.; of the Church, ὁ οἶ. τ. θεοῦ, I Ti 3:15, He 3:2, I Pe 4:17; of descendants, οἶ Ἰσραήλ (Δαυείδ, Ἰακώβ; Bl, §47, 9), Mt 10:6, Lk 1:27, 33 al. (cf. Ex 6:14, I Ki 2:30, al.).

the inhabited earth; in cl., the countries occupied by Greeks, as disting. from barbarian lands (Hdt., Dem., al.); in later writers, the Roman world: Lk 2:1, Ac 11:28 24:5; by meton., of its inhabitants : Ac 17:6 19:27; in LXX (Ps 23:1 71:8, al.) and NT, also of the whole inhabited world: Mt 24:14, Lk 4:5 21:26, Ro 10:18, He 1:6, Re 3:10 16:14; by meton. (ut supr.), Ac 17:31, Re 12:9; of the Messianic age, ἡ οἰ. ἡ μέλλουσα = ὁ αἰὼ ὁ μέλλων: He 2:5.†
working at home: Tit 2:5 (Rec. οἰκουρός, q.v.).†
watching or keeping the house; as subst., ἡ οἰ., a housekeeper (Soph., Eur.; v. LS, s.v.).; keeping at home: Tit 2:5, Rec. (v. Field, Notes, 220 ff.; CGT, in l, and cf. οίκουργός).†
to pity, have compassion on. c. acc pers., Ro 9:15 (LXX).†
compassion, pity. σπλάγχνα οἰκτιρμοῦ, a heart of compassion, Col 3:12; in pl. (as LXX for Heb. רַחַם), οἰ. τ. θεοῦ, Ro 12:1, He 10:28; ό πατὴρ τῶν οἰ, II Co 1:3; σπλάγχνα κ. οἰ., Phl 2:1.†
merciful: Lk 6:36, Ja 5:1.†
a wine-drinker, wine-bibber: Mt 11:19, Lk 7:34.†
wine; Mt 9:17, Lk 1:15, Jo 2:3, al.; οἴνῳ προσέχειν, I Ti 3:8; δουλοῦσθαι, Tit 2:3. Metaph., Re 14:8, 10 16:19 17:2 18:3 19:15. By meton. for ἄμπελος, Re 6:6
drunkenness, debauchery: I Pe 4:3.†
to suppose, expect, imagine; c. acc et inf., Jo 21:25; c. inf., Phl 1:17; seq. ὅτι, Ja 1:7.†; οἶμαι, v.s. οἴομαι

relat. pron., qualitative (related to ὅς as qualis to qui), what sort or manner of, such as, in NT usually without its correl. τοιοῦτος : Mt 24:21, Mk 9:3, II Co 12:20, I Th 1:5, II Ti 3:11, Re 16:18; seq. τοιοῦτος, I Co 15:48 15:2 II Co 10:11; id. redundant, Mk 13:19; τ. αὑτὸν . . . σἷον, Phl 1:30; οὐχ οἷον δὲ ὅτι, elliptically, but it is not as though (RV), Ro 9:6.†
to shrink from doing, hesitate to do (Hom., Thuc., al.); hence, to delay c. inf., Ac 9:38 (cf. Nu, l.c., and v. MM, xviii).†
shrinking, hesitating, timid: c. dat. (Bl., § 38, 2), Ro 12:11; hence, slothful: Mt 25:26. Of things, that which causes shrinking, irksome: Phl 3:1.†
of the eighth day, eight days old: c. dat. ref., περιτομῇ., Phl 3:5 (words of this class denote duration, cf. τεταρταῖος).†
indecl.,; eight: Lk 2:21, Jo 5:5, al
destructive, deadly: δίκην, II Th 1:9, L, txt (for ὄλωεθρος, q.v.).†
ruin, destruction, death: I Th 5:3, I Ti 6:9; αἰώνιος, II Th 1:9 (L, txt., ὀλέθριος, q.v.); εἰς ὄ. τῆς σαρκός, for physical discipline, to destroy carnal lusts, I Co 5:5.†
little faith or trust: Mt 17:20.†
of little faith or trust: Mt 6:30 8:26 14:31 16:8, Lk 12:28.†

of number, quantity, size, few, little, small, slight: Mt 9:37 15:34, Mk 6:5 8:7, Lk 10:2 12:48 (sc. πληγάς, opp. to πολλάς), I Ti 5:23, He 12:10, Re 3:4 12:12; οὐκ ὀ. (in the best uncials written οὐκ ὁ.; v. WH, App., 143; M, Pr., 44; Thackeray, Gr., 126 f.), Ac 12:18 14:28 15:2 (c. gen. part.) Ac 17:4, 12 19:23-24 27:20; pl., absol., Mt 7:14 20:16 (WH, txt., RV, om.) Mt 22:14, Lk 13:23, I Pe 3:20. Neut. sing (τὸ) ὀ.: Lk 7:47, II Co 8:15; πρὸς ὀλίγον, I Ti 4:8, Ja 4:14; ἐν ὀ., Ac 26:28-29 (with little effort; v. Page, in l); id., in brief, Eph 3:3; adverbially, ὀλίγον, of time, Mk 6:31, I Pe 1:6 5:10, Re 17:10; of space, Mk 1:19, Lk 5:3; pl., ὀλίγα, Lk 10:42, Re 2:14; ἐπ' ὀλίγα, Mt 25:21, 23; δι' ὀλίγων, in few words, briefly, I Pe 5:12 (cf. Plat., Legg., vi, 778 e).†; **ὀλίγως, adv.; a little, almost, all but: II Pe 2:18.†
faint-hearted: I Th 5:14.†
to esteem lightly, think little of: c. gen., He 12:5 (LXX),†
a destroyer: I Co 10:10 (not elsewhere).†
to destroy: He 11:28 (cf. ἐξ-ολοθρεύω).†; ὀλεθρεύω, v.s. ὀλοθρεύω
a whole burnt offering: Mk 12:33, He 10:6, 8 (LXX) (of. Kennedy, Sources, 113 f.).†
completeness, soundness: Ac 3:16.†
complete, entire; in NT in ethical sense (as Wis, 4Mac, ll. c.), I Th 5:23; ὁ. καὶ τέλειοι, Ja 1:4.†
to cry aloud: Ja 5:1.†

of persons and things, whole, entire, complete; of indefinite ideas, c. subst. anarth.: Lk 5:5, Ac 11:26 28:30, Tit 1:11; ὅλον ἄνθρωπον (an entire man; v. Field, Notes, 93), Jo 7:23; ὅλη Ἰερουσαλήμ (= πᾶσα Ἰ, Mt 2:3; v. Bl., §47, 9), Ac 21:31. Definite, c. art.; preceding subst.: Mt 4:23, 24 Lk 8:39, I Co 12:17, al.; following subst.: Mk 1:33, Lk 9:25, Jo 4:53, Ac 21:30, al.; between art. and subst., where subst. is an abstract noun (Plat., al.). Attached to adj. or verb: Mt 13:33, Lk 13:21, Jo 9:34, al.; adverbially, δι ̓ ὅλου (MM, xviii), Jo 19:23.
complete, perfect.. I Th 5:23.†
Olympas: Ro 16:15.†
an unripe fig, which grows in winter and usually falls off in the spring : Re 6:13.†
altogether, assuredly, actually (c. neg., at all) : Mt 5:34, I Co 5:1 6:7 15:29.†
a storm of rain, a shower: Lk 12:54.†
to desire earnestly, yearn after: I Th 2:3.†
to be in company with, consort with; hence, to converse with: Ac 20:11; c. dat., Ac 24:26; seq. πρός, Lk 24:14-15.†
company, association: I Co 15:33.†
a crowd, throng: Re 18:17, Rec.†
an eye: p1., Mt 20:34 Mk 8:23.†

to swear, affirm by oath: Mt 26:74, Mk 14:71, He 7:21; seq. εἰ (q.v), He 3:11 4:3; c. dat. pers., Mk 6:23; id. c. inf., He 3:18; seq. ὅρκῳ, Ac 2:30; ὀ. ὅρκον, πρός, c. acc pers. (cl.), Lk 1:73; c. acc (of that by which one swears; cl., v. MM, xviii), Ja 5:12; seq. κατά, c. gen. (LXX; Bl., § 34, 1), He 6:13, 16; seq. ἐν (εἰς), as in Heb. (El., § 39, 4), Mt 5:34, 36 23:16, 18 23:20-22 Re 10:6 (Bl., § 70, 3).†

with one mind, with one accord: Ac 1:14 2:46 4:24 5:12 7:57 8:6 12:20 15:25 18:12 19:29, Ro 15:6 (Hatch, Essays, 63 f., argues that the un-cl. sense together, which is found in Jb 3:18 38:33, Nu 24:24, Wi 18:5, 12 (but not Wi 10:20), al., should be attached to the NT instances, but v. Abbott, Essays, 96; MM, xviii).†
to be like: Mt 23:27 (L, Tr., txt., WH, mg.) Mt 26:73 (WH, mg.) (not found elsewhere. cf. παρ-ομοιάζω.) †
of like feelings or affections: c. dat., Ac 14:15, Ja 5:17.†

like, resembling, such as, the same as: c. dat., of form or appearance, Jo 9:9, Re 1:13 (WH, mg., R, but v. infr.) Re 1:15 2:18 4:6-7 9:7, 10 (B1., § 37, 62) Rev_9:19; Rev_11:1; Rev_13:2; Rev_13:11; ὁράσει, Rev_4:3; of nature, condition, ability, etc., Mat_22:39, Act_17:29, Gal_5:21, 1Jn_3:2, Rev_13:4; Rev_18:18; Rev_21:11; Rev_21:18; of comparison in parables, Mat_13:31 ff. Mat_20:1, Luk_13:18-19; Luk_13:21; of thinking, acting, etc., Mat_11:16; Mat_13:52, Luk_6:47-49; Luk_7:31-32 (T, c. gen.; 131., § 36, 11) Luk_12:36, Joh_8:55, Jud_1:7; c. acc, Rev_1:13 (WH, txt.; Swete, Hort, in l) Rev_14:14.†
likeness: καθ' ὁμοιότητα, in like manner, He 4:15; id. c. gen. (MM, xviii), after the likeness (of), He 7:15.†

to make like, c. gen. et dat.; pass., to be made or become like: Mt 6:8 13:24 18:23 22:2 25:1, Ac 14:11, He 2:17; seq. ὡς (cf. Ez 32:2, Heb.), Ro 9:29.; to liken, compare: c. dat., acc, Mt 11:16, Lk 7:31 13:18, 20; πῶς όμοιώσωμεν, Mk 4:30; pass., Mt 7:24, 26 (cf. ἀφ-ομοιόω).†
that which is made like something; concrete, an image, like­ness (Ps 106:20, Ez 1:5, I Mac 3:48, al.) : Re 9:7; abstract, like­ness, resemblance: Ro 5:14 6:5 8:3, Phl 2:7; ἐν ὁ. εἰκόνος, Ro 1:23.†
likewise, in like manner, equally: Mt 22:26, Mk 4:16, Lk 10:37, al.; c. dat., Mt 22:39, Lk 6:31; ὁ. καί, Mt 22:26, Mk 15:31, al.; ὁ. καθώς, Lk 17:28; καθὼς . . . ὁ., Lk 6:31; ὁ. μέντοι καί, Ju 8
a making like, becoming like (Plat.).; likeness: Ja 3:9 (LXX).†

to speak the same language (Hdt.).; to agree with (Hdt., Plat., al.).; to agree, confess, acknowledge (Plat., al.) : absol., Jo 1:20 12:42; pass., Ro 10:10; seq. ὅτι, ib., He 11:13; c. acc rei, Ac 23:8, I Jn 1:9, Re 3:5; id. c. dat. pers., Ac 24:14; c. acc cogn., I Ti 6:12; c. acc pers., I Jn 2:23 Jn 4:3; id. seq. pred. acc (Bl., § 34, 5; 73, 5), Jo 9:22, Ro 10:9, I Jn 4:2 Jn 4:15, II Jn 7; c. inf. (M, Pr., 229), Tit 1:16; c. dat. pers. seq. ὅτι, Mt 7:23; seq. ἐν, c. dat. pers. (M, Pr., 104; Bl., § 41, 2), Mt 10:32, Lk 12:8.; to agree, promise: τ. ἐπαγγελίαν, Ac 7:17; c. inf. obj. (Bl., § 61, 3), Mt 14:7.; = ἐξμολογέω, to praise: He 13:15 (Westc., in l).; (cf. ἀνθ-ομολογέομοι, ἐξμολογέω.) †
in cl., an agreement assent, compact (in π., of a contract; Deiss., BS, 249).; confession (prob. always in an objective sense): II Co 9:13, I Ti 6:12-13 He 3:1 4:14 10:13.†
as agreed, conformably with.; confessedly, by common consent: I Ti 3:16.†
practising the same craft, of the same trade: Ac 18:3.†
together; prop., of place: Jo 21:2, Ac 2:1; without idea of place: Jo 4:36 20:4.†
agreeing, of one mind: I Pe 3:8.†
yet: ὅ. μέντοι,; but yet, nevertheless, Jo 12:42; by hyperbaton, out of its proper position, I Co 14:7, Ga 3:15 (but v. Bl., § 77, 14).†
indecl., used only in nom, and acc sing. (the other cases are supplied by ὄνειρος), a dream: κατ' ὄ. (in later writers only), in a dream, Mt 1:20 2:12-13, 19 2:22 27:19.†
a young ass: Jo 12:14.†

to reproach, upbraid: absol., Ja 1:5; c. acc pers. (in cl. more freq. c. dat. pers.; Bl., § 34, 2; WM, 278), Mt 5:11, Mk 15:32, 34, WH, mg., Lk 6:22, Ro 15:3 (LXX); τ. πόλεις, Mt 11:20; pass., I Ti 4:10, WH, mg., I Pe 4:14; c. acc rei, Mk 16:14; c. dupl. acc, Mt 27:44.†
a reproach: Ro 15:3, He 10:33; εἰς ὀ. ἐμπεαεῖν, I Ti 3:7; ὁ ὀ. τοῦ Χριστοῦ He 11:26 13:13.†
reproach, censure, blame.; matter of reproach, disgrace: Lk 1:25.†
Onesimus: Col 4:9, Phm 10 (a common name among slaves; v. MM, iii, xviii).†
Onesiphorus: II Ti 1:16 4:19.†
of or for an ass. μύλος ὀ., Mt 18:6, Mk 9:42 (elsewhere only in π.; v. MM, xviii).†
to profit, benefit, help; mid., to have profit, derive benefit: optat. (M, Pr., 195), c. gen., Phm 20.†

in general, the name by which a person or thing is called: Mt 10:2, Mk 3:16, Lk 1:63, Jo 18:10, al.; ἄνθρωπος (etc.), ᾧ (οὗ) ὄ. (τ. ὄ), sc. ἦν or ἐστίν (BL, §30, 3), Mk 14:32, Lk 1:26, 27; with same ellipsis, καὶ τ. ὄ. αὐτοῦ, Lk 1:5, Jo 1:6, al.; ὀνόματι, seq. nom. prop., Mt 27:32, Mk 5:22, Lk 1:5, Ac 5:1, al.; acc. absol. (Bl., §34, 7), τοὔνομα (= τ. ὄνομα), Mt 27:57; ὄ. μοι (sc. ἐστίν; cf. Hom., Od., ix, 366), Mk 5:9 (cf. Lk 8:30); ἔξειν ὄ., Re 9:11; καλεῖν (ἐπιτιθέναι) ὄ. (Bl., §33, 1), Mt 1:21, Mk 3:16; τ. ὄ. ἐν (τ.) βίβλῳ ζωῆς (cf. Deiss., LAE, 121), Phl 4:3, Re 13:8, cf. Lk 10:20 (ἐν τ. οὐρανοῖς); ὄ. βλασφημίας, Re 13:1; the name as opp. to the reality, Re 3:1 (cf. Hdt., vii, 138); as a title: Eph 1:21, Phl 2:9, 10 (Lft., in l.). By a usage similar to that with ref. to Heb. שֵׁם (Lft., Notes, 106f.), but also common in Hellenistic (M, Pr., 100; Bl., §39, 4; Deiss, BS, 146f., 196f.; LAE, 123:4, of all that the name implies, of rank, authority, character, etc.: of acting on one's authority or in his behalf, ἐν (εἰς) ὄ., c. gen. pers. (v. reff. supr.), Mt 10:41 21:9 28:19, Mk 11:9, Lk 13:35, Jo 5:43, Ac 8:16, I Co 1:13; of the name Christian, I Pe 4:16; esp. of the name of God as expressing the divine attributes: ἁγιάζειν (ἅγιον) τὸ ὄ. (τ. Πατρός, Κυρίου), Mt 6:9, Lk 1:49 11:2; ψάλλειν (ὁμολογεῖν) τῷ ὀ., Ro 15:9, He 13:15; δοξάζειν (φανεροῦν, φοβεῖσθαι) τὸ ὄ., Jo 12:28 17:6, 26 Re 11:18 15:4; βλασφημεῖν, Ro 2:24, I Ti 6:1, Re 13:6; similarly, of the name of Christ: τ. καλὂν ὄ. (Deiss., LAE, 276); πιστεύειν τῷ ὀ., I Jo 3:23; π. εἰς τ. ὄ. (Bl., §39, 4), Jo 1:12 2:23 3:18; ὀνομάζειν τὸ ὄ., II Ti 2:19; κρατεῖν, Re 2:13; οὐκ ἀρνεῖσθαι, Re 3:8; ἐν τ. ὀ. (v. reff. supr.), Mk 9:38 16:[17], Lk 10:17, Jo 14:13 16:23, 24 20:31, Ac 3:6 4:12, Eph 5:20, I Pe 4:14, al.; εἰς τ. ὄ. συνάγεσθαι, Mt 18:20; ἕνεκεν τοῦ ὀ., Mt 19:29; διὰ τὸ ὄ., Mt 10:22, Mk 13:13, al.; διὰ τοῦ ὀ., I Co 1:10; ὑπὲρ τοῦ ὀ., Ac 9:16, Ro 1:5, al.; id. absol., Ac 5:41, III Jo 7; πρὸς τὸ ὄ., Ac 26:9. cause, ground, reason (in cl., usually in bad sense, pretext): Mk 9:41 (Swete, in l.; Dalman, Words, 305f.). In late Greek (Deiss., BS., 196f.), an individual, a person: Ac 1:15, Re 3:4 11:13.

to name, mention, or address by name: Ac 19:13; pass., Ro 15:20, Eph 1:21 5:3; of the use of the Divine name in praise and worship, II Ti 2:19 (LXX, Nu 16:26; cf. Is 52:11, Am 6:10).; to name, call, give a name to: Mk 3:14 (T, R, txt. om.), Lk 6:13-14; pass., I Co 5:11; seq. ἐξ (cl.), Eph 3:15 (cf. ἐπ-ονομάζω).†
really, actually, truly: Mk 11:32, Lk 23:47 24:34, Jo 8:36, I Co 14:25, Ga 3:21 4:1-31 ἡ ὄ. ζωή, I Ti 6:19; ἡ ὄ. χήρα, I Ti 5:3 5:5 5:16 †
sour wine (posca, vin-Deu pays), the ordinary drink of labourers and common soldiers: Mt 27:48, Mk 15:36, Lk 23:36, Jo 19:29-30.†
sharp: Re 1:16 2:12 14:14, 17-18 19:15.; Of motion, swift: Ro 3:15 (LXX ταχινός).†
an opening, a hole: Ja 3:11 (cf. Ex 33:22), He 11:33 (cf. Ob 3).†
behind, after: Mt 9:20, Mk 5:27, Lk 8:44, Re 4:6 5:1. As prep. c. gen.: Mt 15:23, Lk 23:26, Re 1:10 (WH, mg.).†

of place and time,; prop., as in cl., adv.,; of time (not in NT); of place, back, behind, after: Mt 24:18, Lk 7:38; τὰ ὀ., Phl 3:13; εἰς τὰ ὀ., Mk 13:16, Lk 9:62 17:31, Jo 6:66 18:6 20:14.; By a usage not found in cl., and in LXX representing the Heb. prep. אַחַר (Bl., § 40, 8; Thackeray, Gr., 46 f.), but also prob. general in vernacular (M, Pr., 99), as prep. c. gen.; of time, after: Mt 3:11, Mk 1:7 Jo 1:15, 27 1:30; of place, behind, after: Mt 4:19 10:38 16:23-24, Mk 1:17, 20 8:33-34, Lk 9:33 14:27 19:14 21:8, 2Pe 2;10, Ju 7, Re 1:10 12:15; in constr. praegn. (v. Swete on Re, l.c.), Jo 12:19, Ac 5:17 20:30, I Ti 5:15, Re 13:3.†
to make ready, equip; of soldiers, to arm. Mid., to arm oneself; fig., ἔννοιαν: I Pe 4:1 (cf. θράσος ὁ., Soph., Elec., 995), (cf. καθ-ὁπλίζω).†
a tool, implement, instrument: ὅπλα ἀδικίας (Opp. to ὅ. δικαιοσύνης), Ro 6:13.; Freq., in pl., arms, weapons: Jo 18:3, II Co 10:4; metaph., τ. φωτός, Ro 13:12; τ. δικαιοσύνης, II Co 6:7.†
of what sort: I Co 3:13, Ga 2:6, I Th 1:9, Ja 1:24; τοιοῦτος ὁ., such as, Ac 26:29.†
when: Lk 6:3, Rec. (WH, R, ὅτε).†

of place, correlat. of ποῦ (q.v.), where.; Prop., of place,; where; in relative sentences, c. indic: Mt 25:24, 26, Mk 2:4 4:5, 15 5:40 13:14, Jo 3:8 6:62 7:34, 36 11:32 14:3 17:24 20:19, Ro 15:20, Re 2:13; after nouns of place, for relat. prepositional phrase (ἐν ᾧ., etc.), Mt 6:19-20 13:5 26:57 28:6, Mk 6:55 9:48 Lk 12:33, Jo 1:28 4:20, 46 6:23 7:42 10:40 11:30 12:1 18:1, 20 19:18, 20 19:41 20:12, Ac 17:1, Re 2:13 11:8 20:10; seq. ἐκεῖ., Mt 6:21, Lk 12:34 17:37 Jo 12:26; id. pleonast. (= Heb. שָׁם . . . אֲשֶׁר; Aram. תַּמָּן . . דּ; of. Ge 13:3), ὅ. . . . ἐκεῖ, Re 12:6, 14; ὅ. . . . ἐπ' αὐτῶν, Re 17:9; ὅ. ἄν, wherever (M, Pr., 168), c. impf. indic., Mk 6:56; c. Pres. subjc., Mt 24:28; ὅ. ἐάν, Mt 26:13, Mk 6:10 9:18 14:9, 14 a; in quaest. indir., c. aor. subjc.: Mk 14:14 b, Lk 22:11.; In late writers (sometimes also in cl.; Bl., § 25, 2), with verbs of motion, = ὅποι, whither: c. indic., Jo 8:21-22 13:33, 36 14:4 21:18, He 6:20, Ja 3:4; ὅ. ἄν, whithersoever, c. pres. ind., Re 14:4; subjc., Lk 9:57; ὅ. ἐάν, Mt 8:19.; Without strict local sense,; of time or condition: Col 3:11, He 9:16 10:18, Ja 3:16, II Pe 2:11.; Of cause or reason (AV, whereas): I Co 3:3.†
late present as from ὤφθην (= ὁράω); mid., ὀπτάνομαι, to allow oneself to be seen, to appear. c. dat., Ac 1:3. (For exx. from π., v. Deiss., LAE, 79, 2526; MM, ii, xviii.) †
an appearing, coming into view (Ma, Es, Sir, ll. c.).; a vision: Lk 1:22 24:23, Ac 26:19, II Co 12:1 (Da, ll. c., also in MGr.).†
roasted, boiled Lk 24:42.†

late summer, early autumn (the time between the risings of Sirius and Arcturus, i.e. late July, all August and early September).; By meton. (as being fruit-time), ripe fruits Re 18:14 (cf. φθινοπωρινά, Ju 12).†

Relat. adv. of manner, as, how: c. indic., Lk 24:20.; Conj., c. subjc. (in cl. also c. opt., indic.: so in Mt 26:59, LT, Tr.), in order that, to the end that, that; final, denoting purpose or design (in which the original idea of modality has been merged): after pres., Mt 6:2, al.; pf., Ac 9:17, al.; impf., Ac 9:24; aor., Ac 9:2, al.; plpf., Jo 11:57; fut., Mt 23:35; imperat., Mt 2:8, al.; ὅ. μή (M, Pr., 185), Mt 6:18, Lk 16:26, Ac 20:16, I Co 1:29; ὅ. πληρωθῇ, Mt 2:23 8:17 13:35; ὅ. ἄν (B1., § 65, 2; WM, § 42, 5), Lk 2:35, Ac 3:19 15:17, Ro 3:4 (cf. Ge 12:13, Ps 59:7. 1Mac 1032, al.).; After verbs of asking, exhorting, etc.: Mt 9:38, Lk 7:3, Ja 5:16, al. (in late writers its place is often taken by the correl. πῶς, q.v.)
that which is seen; a sight, spectacle: Mt 17:9, Ac 7:31; an appearance, vision: Ac 9:10, 12 (Rec.) Ac 10:3, 17 10:19 11:5 12:9 16:9-10 18:9 (cf. ὀπτασία).†
in Arist. and later writers, the act of seeing, the sense of sight, and by meton., pl., the eyes.; appearance (Nu 24:4, Ez 1:5, Si 41:20, al.): Re 4:3.; = ὅραμα, a vision: Ac 2:17 (LXX), Re 9:17.†
visible: τὰ ὁ., Col 1:16.†

[in LXX chiefly for ראה, also for חזה, etc. ;] in "durative" sense (hence aor. act., εἶδον, pass., ὤφθην, fut., ὄψομαι, from different roots; v. M, Pr., 110f.), to see (in colloq. even the pres. is rare, its place being generally taken by θεωρέω, v. BL, §24). Of bodily vision, to see, perceive, behold: absol., Mk 6:38, al.; ἔρχου καὶ ἴδε, Jo 1:46, al.; seq. ὅτι, Mk 2:16, al.; c. acc., Mt 2:2, Mk 1:10 16:7, Ga 1:19, al.; θεόν, Jo 1:18, I Jo 4:20, al. to see with the mind, perceive, discern: absol, Ro 15:21; c. acc. rei., Mt 9:2 27:54, Ac 8:23, Col 2:18, al. to see, take heed, beware: ὅρα μή, c. aor. subjc., Mt 8:4 18:10, Mk 1:44, I Th 5:15; id., sc. μὴ ποήσῃς, Re 19:10 22:9 (Bl., §81, 1); seq. imperat. Mt 9:30 16:6, Mk 8:15 to experience: τ. θάνατον, Lk 2:26, He 11:5; ζωήν, Jo 3:36; τ. διαφθοράν, Ac 2:27. to visit: c. acc. pers., Lk 8:20, Jo 12:21, Ro 1:11, al.; c. acc. loc, Ac 19:21. to see to, care for: Mt 27:4, Ac 18:15 (cf. ἀφ-, καθ-, προ-, συν-οράω).

1, impulse, propensity, disposition.; anger, wrath; of men: Mk 3:5, Eph 4:31, Col 3:8, I Ti 2:8, Ja 1:19-20; of God; that reaction of the divine nature against sin which in anthropomorphic language is called anger: Ro 1:18 9:22 12:19, (ICC, in l), I Th 1:10 2:16, He 3:11 4:3 (LXX) Re 14:10 16:19 19:15; of the effect of God's anger: Mt 3:7, Lk 3:7 21:23, Jo 3:36, Ro 2:5, 8 3:5 4:15 5:9 13:4-5 Eph 5:6, Col 3:6, I Th 5:9, Ja 1:20, Re 6:16-17 11:18; σκεύη ὀργῆς, Ro 9:22; τέκνα ὀργῆς, Eph 2:3.†

to make angry, provoke to anger; in cl. most freq. in pass., and so always in NT, to be provoked to anger, be angry: absol., Mt 18:34 22:7, Lk 14:21 15:28, Eph 4:26 (LXX), Re 11:18; c. dat., Mt 5:22; seq. ἐπί, c. dat. (III Ki 11:9, al.), Re 12:17 (cf. παρ-ὀργίζω).†
inclined to anger, passionate: Tit 1:7.†
the length of the outstretched arms, a fathom: Ac 27:28.†

to reach, stretch out; pass. and mid., to stretch oneself out, reach forth; metaph., to reach after, grasp at, aspire to: c. gen. rei, I Ti 3:1, He 11:16; φιλαργυρίας (v. Ellic. and CGT, in l), I Ti 6:10.†
mountainous, hilly; ἡ ὀ. (sc. χώρα), the hill-country (LXX for הַר): Lk 1:39, 65 †
the most general ward for all kinds of desire, longing, appetite: of lust, Ro 1:27
= cl. εὐθυπορέω, to walk straight: metaph., Ga 2:14 (not elsewhere).†
straight; in height, straight, upright: Ac 14:10; in line, straight, direct: fig., He 12:13 (LXX).†
to cut straight, as a road (τ. ὁδούς, fig., Pr, ll c.). Metaph., τ. λόγον τ. ἀληθείας, II Ti 2:15 (V. Ellic. and CGT, in l; not found elsewhere).†
= cl. poët., ὀρθρεύω, to rise early: seq. πρός, c. acc pers. (as Ps, l.c., al.), Lk 21:38 (v. Thumb, Hellen., 123).†
late form of ὄρθριος (q.v.), early: Lk 24:22.†
early, in the early morning: Lk 24:22, Rec. (v.s. ὀρθρινός).†
daybreak, dawn: ὄρθρου βαθέως (M, Pr., 73), at early dawn, Lk 24:1; ὄρθρου, Jo 8:2; ὑπὸ τὸν ὄ., Ac 5:21 (cf. MM, xviii).†

to separate, mark off by boundaries (so Nu 34:6, Jo 13:27).; to determine, appoint, designate: of time, c. acc, Ac 17:26, He 4:7; c. acc pers., Ac 17:31; c. inf., Ac 11:29; pass., Lk 22:22, Ac 2:23 10:42, Ro 1:4 (cf. ὀφ-, ἀπο- δι-, τρο-ορίζω),†
a boundary, bound; chiefly in pl., and so always in NT: Mt 2:16 4:13 8:34 15:22, 39 19:1, Mk 5:17 7:24, 31 10:1, Ac 13:50.†
to make one swear (Xen., Polyb., a1.).; to adjure: c. dupl. acc, Mk 5:7, Ac 19:13 (cf. ἐν-, ἐξ-ορκίζω).†
affirmation on oath, an oath: He 7:20-21, 28.†
causal, to set in motion, urge on.; Intrans., to hasten on, rush: seq. εἰς, Mt 8:32, Mk 5:13, Lk 8:33, Ac 19:29; ἐπί, c. acc, Ac 7:57.†
a violent movement, impulse: Ja 3:4; a hostile movement, onset, assault. Ac 14:5.†
a rush: Re 18:21.†
= ὄρνις: Lk 13:34 (T; WB, ὄρνις).†
a bird; specif., a cock, a hen: Mt 23:3, Lk 13:34 (WH).†
a setting of boundaries; in pl., bounds; Ac 17:26.†

a mountain: Mt 4:8 17:1, Mk 9:2, Jo 4:20, II Pe 1:18, al.; opp. to βουνός, Lk 3:5 (LXX); ὄ. τ. ἐλαιῶν, Mt 21:1 24:3, al. (v.s. ἐ.); ὄ. Σιών (Σ., prob. in gem appos.), He 12:22, Re 14:1; ὄ. Σινά, Ac 7:30, 38 Ga 4:24-25; τὸ ὄ., of the hill district as distinct from the lowlands, esp. the hills above the Sea of Galilee, Mt 5:1 8:1, Mk 3:13 6:46, al.; τὰ ὄ., Mt 18:12, Mk 5:5, He 11:38, Re 6:14, al.; proverbially (cf. Rabbinic, הדים עקר), of overcoming difficulties, accomplishing marvels, ὄρη μεθιστάνειν, I Co 13:2, cf. Mt 17:20 21:21, Mk 11:23
to dig: c. acc, ληνόν, Mt 21:33; ὁπολήνιον, Mk 12:1; γῆν, Mt 25:18 (cf. δι-, ἐξ-ορύσσω).†
prop., orphan, fatherless: Mk 12:40, WH, mg, Ja 1:27.; In a general sense (as also in cl.; v. LS, s.v.; and cf. MM, xviii), bereft, friendless, desolate: Jo 14:18.†

As demonstr. pron. = οὗτος, ὅδε, this, that, also for αὐτός, chiefly in nom.: ὅς δέ, but he (cf. ἦ δὲ ὅς, freq. in Plat.), Mk 15:23, Jo 5:11; ὃς μὲν . . . ὃς δέ, the one . . . the other, Mt 21:35, 22:5, 25:15, Lk 23:33, Ac 27:14, Ro 14:5, I Co 11:21, II Co 2:18, Ju 22; neut., ὃ μὲν . . . ὃ δέ, the one . . . the other, some . . . some, Mt 13:8, 23, Ro 9:21; ὃς (ὃ) μὲν . . . (ἄλλος (ἄλλο)) . . . ἕτερος, Mk 4:4, Lk 8:5, I Co 12:8-10; οὓς μέν, absol., I Co 12:28; ὃς μὲν . . . ὁ δέ, Ro 14:2. As relat. pron., who, which, what, that; agreeing in gender with its antecedent, but differently governed as to case: Mt 2:9, Lk 9:9, Ac 20:18, Ro 2:29, al. mult. In variation from the common construction; in gender, agreeing with a noun in apposition to the antecedent: Mk 15:16, Ga 3:16, Eph 6:17, al.; constr. ad sensum: Jo 6:9, Col 2:19, I Ti 3:16, Re 13:14, al.; in number, constr. ad sensum: Ac 15:36, II Pe 3:1; in case, by attraction to the case of the antecedent (Bl., §50, 2): Jo 4:18, Ac 3:21, Ro 15:18, I Co 6:19, Eph 1:8, al. The neut. ὅ with nouns of other gender and with phrases, which thing, which term: Mk 3:17 12:42, Jo 1:39, Col 3:14, al.; with a sentence, Ac 2:32, Ga 2:10, I Jo 2:8, al. With ellipse of a demonstrative (οὗτος or ἐκεῖνος), before or after: before, Mt 20:23, Lk 7:43, Ro 10:14, al.; after, Mt 10:38, Mk 9:40, Jo 19:22, Ro 2:1 al. Expressing purpose, end or cause: Mt 11:10 (who = that he may), Mk 1:2, He 12:6 al. C. prep, as periphrasis for conjc.: ἀνθ’ ὧν ( = ἀντὶ τούτων ὧν), because, Lk 1:20, al.; wherefore, Lk 12:3; ἐξ οὗ, since, for that, Ro 5:12; ἀφ’ οὗ, since (temporal), Lk 13:25; ἐξ οὗ, whence, Phl 3:20; etc. With particles: ὃς ἄν (ἐάν), v.s. ἄν, ἐάν; ὃς καί, Mk 3:19, Jo 21:20, Ro 5:2, al.; ὃς καὶ αὐτός, Mt 27:57. Gen., οὗ, absol., as adv. (v.s. οὗ).
relat. adv.,; as often as: seq. ἐάν (q.v.), I Co 11:25-26, Re 11:6,†

religiously right, right­eous, pious, Holy: of men, Tit 1:8. He 7:26; by meton., ὁ. χεῖρας, I Ti 2:8 (cf. De 32:4); of God, Re 15:4 16:5; as subst., ὁ ὅ., of the Messiah, Ac 2:27 13:35 (LXX); τὰ ὅ. Δανεὶδ τ. πιστά (Field, Notes, 121), Ac 13:34 (LXX).†
piety, holiness: assoc. with δικαιοσύνη, Lk 1:75, Eph 4:24.†
piously, holily: ὁ. καὶ δικαίως κ. ἀμέμπτως (on the distinction here between these synonyms, v. M, Th., 24 f.), I Th 2:10.†
a smell, odour: Jo 12:3; metaph. (EV, savour), II Co 2:14 2:16; of the effect of sacrifice (cf. נִיחוֹחַ רֵיחַ, Ge 8:21, al., v.s. εὐωδία), ὀ. εὐωδίας, Eph 5:2, Phl 4:18.†

how much, how many, how great, how far, how long, as much as, etc. (= Lat. quantus); of number and quantity: m. pl., Mt 14:36, Mk 3:10, Ro 2:12, al.; n. pl., Mt 17:12, Mk 10:21, Lk 11:8, al.; πάτνες (πάντα) ὅ., Mt 13:46, Lk 4:40, al.; seq. οὗτοι (ταῦτα), Ro 8:14, Phl 4:8; c. indic., Mk 6:56, Re 3:19; c. subjc. Mk 3:28, al.; ὅ. ἄν, Mt 18:18, Jo 11:22, al.; of measure and degree: Mk 3:8, Lk 8:39, Ac 9:13; in compar. sent., ὅσον seq. μᾶλλον, Mk 7:36; καθ’ ὅσον, c. compar.. He 3:3; seq. τοσοῦτο, He 7:20; οὕτως, He 9:27; τοσαύτῳ, c. compar. seq. ὅσῳ, c. compar., He 1:4; ἐφ’ ὅσον, inasmuch as, Mt 25:40, 45 Ro 11:13; of space and time: Re 21:16; ἐφ’ ὅσον, as long as, Mt 9:15, II Pe 1:13; ἐφ’ ὅ. χρόνον, Ro 7:1, I Co 7:39, Ga 4:1; ἔτι μικρὸν ὅσον ὅσον, yet how very short a time, He 10:37 (LXX).
a bone: contr., ὀστοῦν (v. supr.), Jo 19:36 (LXX); uncontr. (as in Hom., Hdt.), ὀστέα, Lk 24:39; ὀστέων, Mt 23:27, He 11:22.†

whoever, anyone who; of an indef. person or thing: in general statements, Mt 5:39, 41 13:12, and freq., Lk 14:27, Ga 5:4, al.; in relative sentences, Mt 7:26, Lk 15:7, Phl 3:7, al.; πᾶς, c. indic., Mt 7:24 10:32; ὅ ἄν (ἐάν), c. subjc., Mt 12:50 13:12, Jo 14:13, I Co 16:2, Ga 5:10, al.; of a definite person or thing, indicating quality, "either generic, which, as other like things, or essential, which by its very nature" (Hort on I Pe 2:11), who is such as: Mt 2:6 7:26, Lk 2:10 7:37, Jo 8:53, Ac 7:53, Ro 6:2, I Co 3:17, Ga 4:24, Eph 1:23, al.; where the relative sentence expresses a reason, consequence, etc. (M, Pr., 92), seeing that he (it, they), and he (it, they): Lk 8:3 10:42, Ac 10:47 11:28, Phl 4:3, al.; as in Ionic and late Greek (Bl., §50, 1; M, Pr., l.c.), differing but little from ὅς: Lk 2:4 9:30, Ac 17:10, Re 12:13.
made of clay, earthen: II Co 4:7, II Ti 2:20.†
the sense of smell, smell­ing: I Co 12:17.†

the loin: Mt 3:4, Mk 1:6; metaph., περιζώννυσθαι (ἀναζ-) τ. ὀσφύας, Lk 12:35, Eph 6:14, I Pe 1:13; regarded, as by the Hebrews, as the seat of generative power, He 7:5, 10; metaph., καρπὸς τ. ὀσφύος, Ac 2:30

with a conditional sense, usually of things expected to occur in an indefinite future; prop., whenever; (a) c. subjc. praes.: Mt 6:2, 5 Mk 14:7, Lk 11:36, Jo 7:27, Ac 23:35, I Co 3:4, al.; ἕως τ. ἡμέρας ἐκείνης, ὅ., Mt 26:29, Mk 14:25; seq. τότε, I Th 5:3; c. subjc. aor. (M, Pr., 185): Mt 5:11, Mk 4:15, Lk 6:22, Jo 2:10 8:28 (Field, Notes, 94), 10:4, al. As in Hom. (LS, s.v.), but not in cl. prose, c. indic., when (M, Pr., 167f.; Bl., §65, 9): c. impf., Mk 3:11(cf. Ge 38:9, al.); c. praes., Mk 11:25; c. fut.. Re 4:9 (Swete, in l.); c. aor., Mk 11:19, Re 8:1 (Swete, in ll.; M, Pr., 168, 248; Field, Notes, 35).

when; c. indic., (so generally in cl., but also c. optat., subjc.; LS, s.v.), most freq. c. aor., Mt 9:25, Mk 1:32, Lk 4:25, Jo 1:19, Ac 1:13, Ro 13:11, Ga 1:15, Re 1:17, al.; c. impf., Mk 14:12, Jo 21:18, Ro 6:20, I Th 3:4, al.; c. pf., since, now that, I Co 13:11 (B, ἐγένομην); c. praes., Mk 11:1, Jo 9:4, He 9:17, c. fut. (Hom.; of a def. fut. as opp. to the indef. fut. of ὅταν c. subjc.), Lk 17:22, Jo 4:21, 23 5:25 16:25, Ro 2:16 (T, txt., WH, mg.), II Ti 4:3 (in all which instances, and c. pres., Jo, l.c., ὅ. follows a subst. of time, and is equiv. to a rel. phrase, ἐν ᾧ or ᾗ).

As conjc, introducing an objective clause, that; after verbs of seeing, knowing, thinking, saying, feeling: Mt 3:9 6:32 11:25, Mk 3:28, Lk 2:49, Jo 2:22, Ac 4:13, Ro 1:13 8:38 10:9, Phl 4:15, Ja 2:24, al.; elliptically, Jo 6:46, Phl 3:12, al. After εἶναι (γίνεσθαι): defining a demonstr. or pers. pron., Jo 3:19 16:19, Ro 9:6, I Jo 3:16 al.; c. pron. interrog., Mt 8:27, Mk 4:41, Lk 4:36, Jo 4:22 al.; id. elliptically, Lk 2:49, Ac 5:4, 9, al.; Untranslatable, before direct discourse (ὅτι recitantis): Mt 7:23, Mk 2:16, Lk 1:61, Jo 1:20, Ac 15:1, He 11:18, al. (on the pleonastic ὡς ὅτι, v.s. ὡς). As causal particle, for that, because: Mt 5:4-12, Lk 6:20, 21, J0 1:30 5:27, Ac 1:5, I Jo 4:18, Re 3:10, al. mult.; διὰ τοῦτο ὅτι, Jo 8:47 10:17, al.; answering a question (διὰ τί), Ro 9:32, al.; οὐκ ὅτι . . . ἀλλ’ ὅτι, Jo 6:26 12:6.

adv. of place, where, whither; in answer to the question "where?" (= ubi): Mt 2:9 18:20, Lk 4:16-17 23:53, Ac 1:13 2:2 7:29 12:12 16:13 20:6, 8 25:10 28:14, Ro 9:26 (LXX), Col 3:1, He 3:9 (LXX), Re 17:15; of condition, Ro 4:15 5:20, II Co 3:17; in answer to the question "whither?" (= quo): Mt 28:16, Lk 10:1 24:28; seq. ἐάν, c. subjc., I Co 16:6.†

not, no, used generally c. indic, and for a denial of fact (cf . μή); absol. (accented), οὔ, no: Mt 13:29 Jo 1:21 21:5; οὒ οὕ, Mt 5:37 Ja 5:12. Most freq. negativing a verb or other word, Mt 1:25 10:26, 38, Mk 3:25 9:37, Jo 8:29, Ac 7:5, Ro 1:16, Phl 3:3, al.; in litotes, οὐκ ὀλίγοι (i.e. very many), Ac 17:4, al.; οὐκ ἄσημος, Ac 21:39; πᾶς . . . οὐ, c. verb, (like Heb. כֹּל . . . לֹא), no, none, Mt 24:22, Mk 13:20, Lk 1:37, Eph 5:5, al.; in disjunctive statements, οὐκ . . . ἀλλά, Lk 8:52 Jo 1:33 Ro 8:2o, al.; c. 2 pers. fut. (like Heb. לֹא, c. impf.), as emphatic prohibition, Mt 4:7, Lk 4:12, Ro 7:7, al. With another negative, strengthening the negation: Mk 5:37, Jo 8:15 12:19, Ac 8:39, al.; making an affirmative: Ac 4:20, I Co 12:15. With other particles: οὐ μή (v.s. μή); οὐ μηκέτι, Mt 21:19; with μή interrog., Ro 10:18, I Co 9:4, 5 11:22. Interrogative, expecting an affirmative answer (Lat. nonne): Mt 6:26, Mk 4:21, Lk 11:40, Jo 4:35, Ro 9:21, al.
of wonder or irony, ah! ha!: Mk 15:29.†

alas! woe! most freq. c. dat. pers.. Mt 11:21 23:14, Mk 13:17 14:21, Lk 6:24-26 Ju 11, al.; c. vocat. (nom.), Re 18:10, 16 18:19 (cf. Is 1:24, al.); c. acc, Re 12:12, seq. ἐκ, Re 8:13; c. dat. seq. ἀπό (v. M, Pr., 246), Mt 18:7. As subst., I Co 9:16 (cf. Je 6:4); ἡ οὐ., Re 9:12 11:14; pl., Re 9:12; οὐ., οὐ., οὐ., Re 8:13
in no wise, by no means: Mt 2:6 (OT).†

As conjc., and not, also not, neither, nor: Mt 6:15, Lk 16:31, Ro 4:15, al.; οὐ . . . οὐδέ, Mt 5:15 10:24, Mk 4:22, Lk 6:43, 44, Jo 6:24, Ac 2:27, Ro 2:28, al. (v. Bl., §77, 10). As adv., not even: Mt 6:29, Mk 6:31, Lk 7:9, I Co 5:1; οὐδὲ εἷς, Ac 4:32, Ro 3:10 (LXX).

no, no one, none: with nouns, Lk 4:24, Jo 10:41, Ro 8:1, al.; absol., Mt 6:24, Mk 3:27, Lk 1:61, Jo 1:18, Ac 18:10, Ro 14:7, al. mult.; c. gen. partit., Lk 4:26, Jo 13:28, al.; neut., οὐδέν, Mt 10:26, al.; id. c. gen. partit., Lk 9:36, Ac 18:17, al.; οὐδὲν εἰ μή, Mt 5:13, Mk 9:29, al.; c. neg., strengthening the negation, Mk 15:4, 5 Lk 4:2, Jo 3:27, al.; adverbially, Ac 25:10, Ga 4:12, al.
no longer, no more: Mt 19:6, Mk 10:8, Lk 15:19, Jo 4:42, Ro 6:9, Ga 3:25 Eph 2:19 He 10:18, al.; c. neg. (to strengthen the negation), Mt 22:46 Mk 5:3, Ac 8:39, al
with the negative element lost, therefore, so then: Jo 18:37.†

expressing consequence or simple sequence (never standing first in a sentence), wherefore, therefore, then: Mt 3:10, Lk 3:9, Jo 8:38, Ac 1:21, Ro 5:9, al.; in exhortations, Mt 3:8, Lk 11:35, Ac 3:19, Ro 6:12, al.; in questions, Mt 13:28, Mk 15:12, Jo 8:[5], Ro 6:1, al.; continuing a narrative or resuming it after a digression, Mt 1:17, Lk 3:18, Jo 1:22 2:18 (and very freq. in this Gospel), Ac 26:22, al.; ἄρα οὖν (v.s. ἄρα); ἐπεὶ οὖν, He 2:14; οὖν c. ptcp. (= ἐπεὶ οὖν), Ac 2:30, Ro 5:1, al.; ἐὰν οὖν (where οὖν rather in sense belongs to the apodosis), Mt 5:23, Lk 4:7, Jo 6:62, Ro 2:26, al.; ὡς οὖν, Jo 4:1, al.
neg. adv. of time,; not yet: Mt 24:6, Mk 13:7, Jo 2:4 3:24 6:17, al.; c. neg., Mk 11:2, Lk 23:53; interrog., Mt 16:9, Mk 4:40 8:17, 21
from heaven: Ac 14:17 26:13.†

heaven; of the vault or firmament of heaven, the sky and the aerial regions above the earth: opp. to ἡ γῆ, He 1:10, II Pe 3:5, 10; ὁ οὐ. καὶ ἡ γῆ, i.e. the world, the universe, Mt 5:18, Mk 13:31, Lk 10:21, Ac 4:24, Re 10:6, al.; ἀπ’ ἄκρων οὐ. ἕως ἄ. αὐτῶν (on the absence of art. aft. prep., v. Bl, §46, 5), Mt 24:31; ὑπὸ τὸν οὐ., Ac 2:5, Col 1:23; ὑψωθῆναι ἕως τοῦ οὐ., fig., Mt 11:23, Lk 10:15; σημεῖον ἐκ τοῦ οὐ., Mt 16:1, Mk 8:11, al.; αἱ νεφέλαι, Mt 24:30, al.; τὰ πετεινὰ τοῦ οὐ., Mt 6:26, Mk 4:32, al.; οἱ ἀστέρες τοῦ οὐ., Re 6:13, al.; pl. (οἱ) οὐ. (Bl., §32, 5), Mt 3:16, Mk 1:10, Jo 1:32, II Pe 3:7, 13 al. Of the abode of God and other blessed beings: of angels, Mt 24:36, Mk 12:25, Ga 1:8, Re 10:1, al.; of Christ glorified, Mk 16:[19], Lk 24:51, Ac 3:21, Ro 10:6, al.; of God, Mt 5:34, Ro 1:18, al.; ὁ Πατὴρ ὁ ἐν τοῖς οὐ. (Dalman, Words, 184ff.), Mt 5:16 6:1, al.; θησαυρὸς ἐν οὐ., Mt 6:20, Mk 10:21, al. By meton., of the inhabitants of heaven: Re 18:20 (cf. ib. 12:12, Jb 15:15, Is 44:23); as an evasive reference to God, characteristic of later Judaism (Dalman, Words, 204ff.): Mt 21:25, Mk 11:30, Lk 15:18, Jo 3:27, al.; ἡ βασιλεία τῶν οὐ. (= τοῦ Θεοῦ); v.s. βασιλεία).
Urban: Ro 16:9.†
Uriah: Mt 1:6.†

the ear: Mt 13:16, Mk 7:33, Lk 22:50, I Co 2:9 12:16, I Pe 3:12; ἐν τ. ὠσί, Lk 4:21; εἰς τ. ὦτα ἀκούεσθαι, Ac 7:57; γίνεσθαι, Lk 1:44; εἰσέρχεσθαι, Ja 5:4; εἰς τ. οὖς ἀκούειν, Mt 10:27; πρὸς τ. οὖς λαλεῖν, Lk 12:3; τὰ ὦ. συνέχειν (MM, xviii), Ac 7:57. Metaph., of understanding, perceiving, knowing: Mt 13:16; ὁ ἔχων (εἴ τις ἔχει) οὖς ἀκουσάτω, Re 2:7, 11 2:17, 29 3:6, 13 13:9; ὁ ἔχων (ὃς ἔχει, εἴ τις ἔχει) ὦτα (ἀκούειν) ἀκουέτω, Mt 11:15 13:9, 43, Mk 4:9, 23 7:16 (R, mg.), Lk 8:8 14:35; τοῖς ὠ. βαρέως ἀκούειν, Mt 13:15 Ac 28:27 (LXX); ὦ. ἔχοντες οὐκ ἀκούειν, Mk 8:18; ὦ. τοῦ μὴ ἀκούειν, Ro 11:8; θέσθε εἰς τὰ ὦ., Lk 9:44; ἀπερίτμητος τοῖς ὠ., Ac 7:51.†
substance, property: Lk 15:12-13.†

negative particle, related to μήτε as οὐ to μή,; and not, neither, nor: οὐδεὶς . . . οὔτε, Re 5:4; οὐδὲ . . . οὔτε, Ga 1:12; οὔτε . . . καί, Jo 4:11; after a question with μή interrog., Ja 3:12; οὔτε . . . οὔτε, neither . . . nor, Mt 6:20, Mk 12:25, Jo 4:21, Ac 15:10, Ro 8:38-39, Ga 5:6, al

this; as subst., this one, he; absol.: Mt 3:17, Mk 9:7, Lk 7:44, 45, Jo 1:15, Ac 2:15, al.; expressing contempt (cl.), Mt 13:55, 56, Mk 6:2, 3, Jo 6:42, al.; εἰς τοῦτο, Mk 1:38, Ro 14:9; μετὰ τοῦτο (ταῦτα; V. Westc. on Jo 5:1), Jo 2:12 11:7, al.; epanaleptic (referring to what precedes): Mt 5:19, Mk 3:35, Lk 9:48, Jo 6:46, Ro 7:10, al.; proleptic (referring to what follows): seq. ἵνα (Bl., §69, 6), Lk 1:43, Jo 3:19 (and freq.) 15:8, Ro 14:9, al.; seq. ὅτι, Lk 10:11, Jo 9:3o, Ac 24:14, Ro 2:3, al.; ὅπως, Ro 9:17; ἐάν, Jo 13:35; special idioms: τοῦτο μὲν . . . τ. δέ (cl), partly . . . partly. He 10:33; καὶ τοῦτο (τοῦτον, ταῦτα), and that (him) too, Ro 13:11, I Co 2:2, He 11:12; τοῦτ’ ἐστιν, Mt 27:46. As adj., c. subst.; c. art. before the art.: Mt 12:32, Mk 9:29, Lk 7:44, Jo 4:15, Ro 11:24, Re 19:9, al.; after the noun: Mt 3:9, Mk 12:16, Lk 11:31, Jo 4:13, Ac 6:13, Ro 15:28, I Co 1:20, Re 2:24, al.; c. subst. anarth. (with predicative force; Bl., §49, 4): Lk 1:36 2:2 24:21, Jo 2:11 4:54 21:14, II Co 13:1.

in this way, so, thus; referring to what precedes: Mt 5:16 6:30, Mk 10:43 14:59, Lk 1:25 2:48 15:7, Jo 3:8, Ro 1:15, I Co 8:12, al.; οὕτως καί, Mt 17:12, Mk 13:29, al.; pleonastically, resuming a ptcp. (cl.; v. Bl., §74, 6), Ac 20:11 27:17. Referring to what follows: Mt 1:18 6:9, Lk 19:31, Jo 21:1, I Pe 2:15; bef. quotations from OT, Mt 2:5, Ac 7:6, I Co 15:45, He 4:4. C. adj. (marking intensity): He 12:21, Re 16:18; similarly c. adv., Ga 1:6 (cl.). As a predicate (Bl., §76, 1): Mt 1:18 9:33, Mk 2:1, 2 4:26, Ro 4:18 9:20, I Pe 2:15; οὕ ἔχειν (Lat. sic or ita se habere), Ac 7:1, al.; ἐκαθέζετο (as he was, without delay or preparation), Jo 4:6. In comparison, with correlative adv.: καθάπερ . . . οὕ., Ro 12:4, 5 al.; καθὼς . . . οὕ., Lk 11:30, al.; οὕ. . . . καθώς, Lk 24:24, al.; ὡς . . . οὕ., Ro 5:15, al.; οὕ . . . ὡς, Mk 4:26, al; ὥσπερ . . . οὕ., Mt 12:40, al.; οὕ. . . . οὕ., I Co 7:7.

strengthened form of οὐ,; not; in neg. sentences, not, not at all: Lk 1:60 12:51, Jo 13:10, al.; more freq. in questions where an affirm. ans. is expected (Lat. nonne) : Mt 5:46-47, Lk 6:39, Jo 11:9, al.

a debtor: c. gen. (of the amount), Mt 18:24. Metaph., of obligation or duty in general, with reference to favours received or injury done, etc.: Mt 6:12, Ro 1:14 8:12 15:27, Ga 5:3; of sinners, in relation to God (= Heb. חַיָּב; cf. Sir (He 8:5) (6)), Lk 13:4.†
a debt: Mt 18:32; metaph., one's due: Ro 13:7, I Co 7:3 (found also in π.; v. Deiss., BS, 221; MM, xviii).†
that which is owed, a debt: Ro 4:4; metaph. (as Aram. חוֺבָא חוֺב), of sin as a debt, Mt 6:12.†

to owe, be a debtor: c. acc rei, Mt 18:28, Lk 7:41 16:7, Phm 18; id. c. dat. pers., Mt 18:28, Lk 16:5. Pass., to be owed, to be due: τ. ὀφειλόμενον, Mt 18:30, 34. Metaph.: absol. (= Rabbinic חַיָּב; v. McNeile, in l), Mt 23:16, 18; c. acc rei et dat. pers., Ro 13:8; c. inf., to be bound or obliged to do (of. Westc., Epp. Jo., 50), Lk 17:10, Jo 13:14 19:7, Ac 17:29, Ro 15:1, 27, I Co 5:10 7:36 9:10 11:7 11:10, II Co 12:14, Eph 5:28, II Th 1:3 2:13, He 2:17 5:3, 12, I Jn 2:6 Jn 3:16 Jn 4:11, III Jn 8; ὤειλον συνίστασθαι, I ought to have been commended, II Co 12:11. In peculiar Aram. sense of having wronged one (v.s. όφείλημα; but of. also Inscr. ἁμαρτίαν ὀφείίλω, Deiss., BS, 225), c. dat. pers., Lk 11:4 (cf. προσ-οφίελω).†

in cl. with an infin. (chiefly poët.),; would that: with indic. aor., I Co 4:8; impf., II Co 11:1, Re 3:15; fut., Ga 5:12 (a practicable wish, v. 131., 206 f., 220. The construction with indic. is only found in late writers.)†
advantage, help: I Co 15:32, Ja 2:14, 16.†
eye-service: Eph 6:6, Col 3:22 (not found elsewhere).†

the eye (as in cl., chiefly pl.): Mt 5:38, Mk 9:47, Lk 6:41, Jo 9:6, al.; τοὺς ὀ. ἐξορύθσσειν (fig.), Ga 4:15; ἐπᾶραι, Lk 6:20, Jo 6:5; ἀνοῖξα, Ac 9:40; id., of restoring sight, Mt 20:33, Jo 9:10, al.; ἐν ῥιπῇ ὀφθαλμοῦ, I Co 15:52; by anthropom., of God, He 4:13, I Pe 3:12; pleonastically (cf. Thackeray, Gr., 42f.), εἶδον οἱ ὀ. μοθ, Lk 2:30 (similarly, ib. 4:20 10:23, Jo 12:40, I Co 2:9, I Jo 1:1, Re 1:7). Metaph. (as otherwise in cl.; v. LS, s.v.); of ethical qualities: ὀ. πονηρός (meton., for envy; cf. Heb. עַיִן רַע, Pr 28:22; cf. Si 14:10 34:13), Mt 6:22, 23 Mk 7:22, Lk 11:34; ἁπλοῦς, Mt 6:22, Lk 11:34; ἐπιθυμία (q.v.) ὀφθαλμῶν (cf. Ec 4:8, Si 14:9), I Jo 2:16; ὀ. μεστοὶ μοιχαλἰδος, II Pe 2:14; of mental vision: Mt 13:15, Mk 8:18, Lk 19:42, Jo 12:40, Ro 11:8, Ga 3:1, Eph 1:18, al.; ἐν ὀφθαλμοῖς seq. gen. (on the absence of the art., v.Bl, §46, 9II; M, Pr., 81), Mt 21:42, Mk 12:11.

a serpent, snake: Mt 7:10 Mk 16:18, Lk 10:19 11:11, Jo 3:14, I Co 10:9, Re 9:19; as typical of wisdom and cunning, Mt 10:16 23:23, II Co 11:3 (cf. Ge 31:1-55); of Satan (cf. Ge 3:1, Wi 2:23-24, IV Mac 18:8), Re 12:9, 14 12:11 20:2.†
an eyebrow, the brow of a hill: Lk 4:29.†
to move, disturb; hence, generally, to trouble, vex: pass., Ac 5:6 (act. absol., = pass., to be in a tumult, 3Mac, l.c.; cf. ἐν-, παρ-εν-οχλέω, and v. MM, xviii).†
to gather a crowd, make a riot: Ac 17:5 (not elsewhere).†

a moving crowd or multitude of persons, a throng: Mt 9:23, Mk 2:4, Lk 5:1, Jo 5:13, al.; pl., Mt 5:1, Mk 10:1, Lk 3:7, and freq.; ὄ. ἱκανός, Mk 10:46, al.; τοσοῦτος, Mt 15:33; οὐ μετ’ ὄχλου, Ac 24:18; ἄτερ ὄχλου, Lk 22:6; πᾶς ὁ ὄ., Mt 13:2, Mk 2:13, al.; ὄ. πολύς, Mt 20:29, Mk 5:21, al.; ὁ πολὺς ὄ. (ὄ. π.), the populace, the common people, Mk 12:37 (Swete, in l.; Field, Notes, 37), Jo 12:9 (Westc, in l.). (As also cl., opp. to δῆμος, q.v., and cf. Tr., Syn., §xcviii), the populace, the common people (cf. ὁ πολὺς ὄ., supr.), Mt 14:5 21:26, Mk 12:12, Jo 7:12b; so with contempt (cl.), Jo 7:49. In a more general sense, a multitude: c. gen., ὀνομάτων (v.s. ὀ.), Ac 1:15; μαθητῶν, Lk 6:17, al.
a stronghold, fortress (Ps 89:40, Na 3:12, 14 al.); in LXX and NT, also metaph. of that in which confidence is placed (Pr 10:29 21:22, al.): II Co 10:4.†

long after, late.; late in the day, at evening (opp. to πρωί); in late writers used almost as an indecl. noun (v. MM, xviii): Mk 11:11, 19 13:35.; C. gen., late in or on; and, in late writers also after (M, Pr., 72 f.), a sense which seems to be required in Mt 28:1.†
poët. and late for ὄψιος, late: ὑετὸς ὄ.,; the latter rain (v. DB, s.v. "rain"), with ellipsis of ὑετός (v. WM, 740), Ja 57.†
late: ἡ ὥρα, Mk 11:11 (Rec., WH, mg.). In late writers, ἡ ὀψία (sc. ὥρα), as subst., evening; Mt 8:16 14:15, 23 16:2 20:8 26:20 27:57, Mk 1:32 4:35 6:47 14:17 15:42, Jo 6:16 20:10.†
the act of seeing, the sense of sight.; face, countenance: Jo 11:44, Re 1:16.; appear­ance: κατ' ὄ. κρίνειν (v. MM, xviii), Jo 7:24.†
provisions, provision-money, soldiers' pay: Lk 3:14, I Co 9:7.; Generally, wages, hire: II Co 11:8; ὄ. τῆς ἁμαρτίας, Ro 6:23 (v. Deiss, BS, 148, 266).†
to ensnare: metaph., c. acc, ἐν λόγῳ, Mt 22:15 (not elsewhere).†
poët. (Aristoph., al.) and late for πάγη, a trap, snare; metaph. (as also in cl.): Lk 21:35, Ro 11:9 (LXX) I Ti 3:7 6:9, II Ti 2:26.†

that which befalls one, a suffering, affliction: pl., Ro 8:18, II Co 1:6-7, Col 1:24, II Ti 3:11, He 2:10 10:32, I Pe 5:9; of Christ's sufferings: τὰ εἰς Χ., I Pe 1:11; τ. Χριστσῦ, I Pe 5:1; id. as shared by Christians, II Co 1:5, Phl 3:10, I Pe 4:13.; a passive emotion, affection, passion: Ga 5:24; τ. ἀμαρτιῶν, Ro 7:5; = τὸ πάσχειν, an enduring or suffering: c. gen. obj., He 2:9.†
one who has suffered.; subject to suffering (R, mg., v. M, Pr., 222) or destined to suffer (AV, R, txt.): Ac 26:23.†

like πάθημα; that which befalls one, that which one suffers; a passive emotion or affection (esp. of violent emotion), a passion, passionate desire; in NT always in bad sense: Col 3:5; π. ἀτιμίας, Ro 1:26; π. ἐπιθυμίας, I Th 4:5.†
a guide, guardian, trainer of boys, a tutor (disting. from διδάσκαλος, Xen., Lac., 3, 1), usually a trusty slave: opp. to πατήρ, I Co 4:15; fig., of the Law, π. εἰς Χριστόν, Ga 3:24-25.†
a little boy, a lad (in late and colloq. Gk. the word seems to be used with greater latitude and even to lose its dimin. force entirely; cf. To 6:2-3, and v. MM, xviii): Jo 6:9.†
