the rearing of a child (Æsch.).; training, learning, instruction (Plat., al.): Eph 6:4, II Ti 3:16.; As in LXX (Pr 3:11 15:5, al.), chasten­ing, discipline: He 12:5 (LXX), He 12:7-8, 11.†
prop., a teacher, instructor: Ro 2:20.; a corrector, one who disciplines (cf. Ho, l.c.) : He 12:9.†

as in cl., to train children, hence, generally, to teach, instruct: Ac 7:22 22:3, I Ti 1:20, Tit 2:12.; As in LXX (Ps 6:2, Pr 19:18, Wi 3:5, al., and for prob. ex. from π., v. MM, xviii), to chasten, correct, chastise: Lk 23:16, 22, II Ti 2:25, He 12:7, 10; of divine chastening, I Co 11:32, II Co 6:9, He 12:6, Re 3:19.†
= cl. ἐκ παιδός, παιδίον, from childhood: Mk 9:21.†

a young child, a little one: Mt 2:8-9, 11, ff., Lk 1:59, 66 1:76, 80 2:17, 27 2:40, Jo 16:21, He 11:23; of older children, Mt 18:2, 4-5, Mk 5:39-41 7:30 9:24, 36, Lk 9:47-48 18:17, Jo 4:49; in pl., Mt 11:16 14:21 15:38 18:3 19:13-14, Mk 7:28 10:13 ff., Lk 7:32 11:7 18:16, He 2:13-14 Metaph., I Co 14:20. Colloq. in familiar address (as Eng. colloq., "lads "-v. M, Pr., 170n and Irish use of "boys"): Jo 21:5, I Jn 2:13 Jn 2:18 Jn 3:7 †

a young girl, a maiden (נַעֲרָה, Ru 4:12).; Colloq., a young female slave, a maid-servant (v. Kennedy, Sources, 40 f.; Deiss., LAE, 186, 332.2): Mt 26:69, Mk 14:66, 69, Lk 12:45 22:56, Jo 18:17, Ac 12:13 16:16; of Hagar, Ga 4:22-23, 30 (LXX); id., metaph., Ga 4:31.†
prop., to play as a child, hence, generally, to play (as with singing and dancing) : I Co 10:7 (LXX) (cf. ἐμ-παίζω).†

a child, boy, youth, maiden: ὁ π., Mt 17:18, Lk 2:43 9:42, Ac 20:12; ἡ π. Lk 8:51, 54 (on the artic. fern, of address, v. M, Pr., 70 f., 235; B1., § 33, 4); pl., Mt 2:16 21:15; of parentage, c. gen., Jo 4:51; Like Heb. עֶבֶד, Lat. Auer, Fr. garcon, Eng. boy (Æsch., Aristoph., Xen., al.), servant, slave, attendant: Mt 8:6, 8 8:13 Lk 7:7 12:45 15:26; in late writers (Diod., LXX: Ge 41:37, al.), of a king's attendant or minister : Mt 14:2; so (= Heb. יְהֹוָה עֶבֶד) π. τ. θεοῦ (Ps 69:18, Is 41:8, Wi 2:13, al.), of Israel, Lk 1:54; of David, Lk 1:69, Ac 4:25; of Jesus (but v. Dalman, Words, 277 f.), Mt 12:18 (LXX), Ac 3:13, 26 4:27, 30.†; τέκνον, child, with emphasis on parentage and the consequent community of nature; υἱός, son, with emphasis on the privileged position of heirship; π. refers both to age and parentage, but with emphasis on the former. Cf. also (παιδάριον), (παιδίον), (παιδίσκη), and v. Westc. on I Jn 3:1.; v.s. θεράπων, and cf. Thackeray, Gr., 7 f
to strike, smite: with the hand or fist, Mt 26:68, Lk 22:64; with a sword, Mk 14:47, Jo 18:10; of a reptile, to sting: Re 9:5.†
Pacatiana, the Western part of the Province of Phrygia, as constituted in 4/A.D.: 1Ti subscr. (Rec.).†

long ago, of old, in time past (denoting past time absolutely, as πρότερον relatively) : Mt 11:21, Lk 10:13, He 1:1, Ju 4; as adj., c. art., II Pe 1:9; of time just past, Mk 6:47 (WH, mg.), Mk 15:44 (WH, mg., R, txt.); c. durst. praes. (RV, all this time), II Co 12:19.†

old, ancient; opp. to νέος, καινός: οἶνος, Lk 5:3; διαθήκη, II Co 3:14; ἐντολή, I Jn 2:7; ζύμη, I Co 5:7-8; ὁ π. ἄςθρωπος (for similar phrases, v. Westc., Eph., 68), Ro 6:6, Eph 4:22, Col 3:9; neut. pl., καινὰ καὶ π., Mt 13:52; of things not merely old, but worn by use (as Jo, l.c., LXX), Mt 9:16-17, Mk 2:21-22, Lk 5:36-37.†
oldness: γράμματος, Ro 7:6.†

to make or declare old: He 8:13; pass., to become old: of things worn out by time and use (cf. Jo 9:13, Is 50:9, al., and v.s. παλαιός), Lk 12:33, He 1:11 (LXX); τὸ παλαιούμενον, He 8:13 (where this and the act., v. supr., may have the sense of abrogate, v. LS, Zorell, s.v.).†
wrestling, hence, generally, fight, contest: fig., of the spiritual combat of Christians, Eph 6:12.†

of place, back, backwards (LS, s.v.). Of time, again, once more: Mt 4:8, Mk 2:13, Lk 23:20, Jo 1:35 (and freq.), Ac 17:32, Ro 11:23, Ga 1:9, He 1:6, al; pleonastically, π. ἀνακάμπτειν, Ac 18:21; ὑποστρέφειν, Ga 1:17; εἰς τὸ π., II Co 13:2; π. ἐκ τρίτου (Bl., §81, 4), Mt 26:44; ἐκ δευτέρου, Mt 26:42, Ac 10:15; π. δεῦτερον, Jo 4:54 21:16; π. ἄνωθεν ( Wi 19:6), Ga 4:9. Rhetorically, again; further, moreover: Mt 5:33, Lk 13:20, Jo 12:39, al.; in turn, on the other hand (Soph.; LXX: Wi 13:8 16:23, al.): Lk 6:43, I Co 12:21, II Co 10:7, I Jo 2:8.

new birth, renewal, restoration, regeneration; of persons (Plut., Phil., al.), of spiritual regeneration, διὰ λουτροῦ παλινγενεστίας (gen. attr., v. Ellic., in l), Tit 3:5; of the world, as in Stoics, Jewish Apocal., al. (v. Dalman, Words, 177 ff.), Mt 19:28.†
very much, very great: Mk 8:1, Rec. (RV, Edd., πάλιν πολλοῦ).†
Pamphylia, a province of Asia Minor: Ac 2:10 13:13 14:24 15:38 27:5.†
late form of Att.. πανδοκεῖον,; an inn (khân, caravanserai): Lk 10:34.†
late form of the Att.. πανδοκεύς (T, in l),; an innkeeper, host: Lk 10:35.†
prop., a national festal assembly in honour of a god; hence, generally, any festal assembly: He 12:23 (for exx. in π., v. MM, xviii).†
with all the household: Ac 16:34.†
full armour: Lk 11:22; metaph. (cf. Wis, l.c.), τ. θεοῦ, Eph 6:11, 13 †
cleverness, in cl. nearly always in bad sense, craftiness, cunning, knavery: Lk 20:23, I Co 3:19 (LXX, φρόνησις, for עׇרְמָה) II Co 4:2 11:3, Eph 4:14.†
ready to do anything; in cl., chiefly in bad sense, knavish, crafty: II Co 12:16; in good sense, skilful, clever (Pr 13:1 28:2).†
= cl. παμπληθές, with the whole multitude, all together: Lk 23:18.†
everywhere: Ac 21:28.†
from all sides: Mk 1:45, Rec.†
all-complete, entire, perfect; εἰς τ. παντελές, completely, utterly: Lk 13:11, He 7:25 (where perhaps in temp. sense, finally; v. MM, xviii).†
every way, entirely: Ac 24:3.†
from all sides: Mk 1:45, Lk 19:43, He 9:4.†
of time; in late writers (once in Arist.) for διαπαντός, ἑκάστοτε, at all times, always: Mt 26:11, Mk 14:7, Lk 15:31, Jo 6:34, Ro 1:10, and freq. in Paul. Epp

altogether, by all means; without neg. (from Hdt. on) : I Co 16:12; esp. in strong affirmations, surely, at all events: Lk 4:23, Ac 21:22 28:4, I Co 9:10; c. neg. (so always in mom.), in a complete negation: Ro 3:9; in a partial negation (Bl., § 75, 7), I Co 5:10.†

with radical sense, beside. C. gen. pers., from the side of, from beside, from, indicating source or origin, [in LXX for מֵאֵצֶל ,מִיַד ,מִלִּפְנֵי ;] after verbs of motion, Mk 14:43, Lk 8:49, Jo 15:26, al.; after verbs of seeking, receiving, hearing, etc., Mk 8:11 12:2, Jo 4:9, 52 10:18, Phl 4:18, II Ti 1:18, Ja 1:7, al.; after passive verbs, of the agent (like ὑπό), Mt 21:42, Mk 12:11, Lk 1:37; absol., οἱ παρ’ αὐτοῦ, his family, his kinsfolk, Mk 3:21 (cf. M, Pr., 106f.; Field, Notes, 25f.; Swete, in l.); τὰ παρ’ αὐτῆς (αὐτῶν, ὑμῶν, one's means, wealth, Mk 5:26, Lk 10:7, Phl 4:18. C. dat. pers. (exc. Jo 19:25, π. τ. σταυρῷ), by the side of, beside, by, with, [in LXX for בְּעֵינֵי ,בְּיַד ,אֵצֶל ;] Lk 11:37 19:7, Jo 1:40 4:40, Ac 28:14, al.; παρ’ ἑαυτῷ, at home, I Co 16:2; c. dat. pl., among, Mt 22:25, Col 4:16, al.; metaph., Mt 19:26, Mk 10:27, Lk 1:30, Ro 2:13, Ja 1:27, al. C. acc., of motion by or towards, [in LXX for בְּעֵבֶר ,עַל יַד ,אֵצֶל ;] of place, by the side of, beside, by, along: Ac 10:32, He 11:12; after verbs of motion, Mt 4:18, Mk 4:4, Lk 8:5, Ac 4:35, al.; after verbs of rest, Mt 13:1, Mk 5:21, Lk 8:35, al. beside, beyond, metaph.; beyond, against, contrary to: Ac 18:13, Ro 1:26 4:18 11:24, al.; except, II Co 11:24; beyond, above, in comparison with: Lk 3:13, Ro 12:3 14:5, He 1:4, 9 3:3, al.; on account of: I Co 12:15, 16. In composition: beside, to (παραλαμβάνω, παράγω), at hand (πάρειμι), from (παραρρέω), amiss (παρακούω), past (παρέρχομαι), compared with (παρομοιάζω), above measure (παροργίζω).

in Hom. (twice), to go by the side of, stand beside.; In Æsch., Herod., Thuc., al., to go past or pass over, chiefly metaph., to overstep, violate, transgress (Jos 7:11, Ez 16:59, Si 40:14, al.) : τ. παράδοσιν, Mt 15:2; τ. ἐντολήν, Mt 15:3; seq. ἀπό (as מִן סוּר, De 17:20, al.), to turn aside, fall away (cf. π. τῆς ἀληθείας, Arist., Cael., i, 5, 2): Ac 1:25.†

to throw to or beside, as fodder to horses (Hom., al.).; to lay beside, compare (Hdt., Plat., al.): Mk 4:30, Rec.; Reflexive, to betake oneself, come near; of seamen, to cross over: εἰς Σάμον, Ac 20:15.; In mid. = παραβολεύομαι, q.v.†

a going aside, a deviation (Arist.).; In later writers, an overstepping; metaph., transgression (Plut., al.) : Ro 4:15 5:14, He 2:2 9:15; τ. νόμου, Ro 2:23; ἐν π., I Ti 2:14; τ. παραβάσεων χάριν, Ga 3:19
one who stands beside, the warrior who stands by the charioteer (of. παραβαίνω, 1).; a transgressor (Æsch., παρβάτης): Ga 2:18, Ja 2:9; π. νόμου, Ro 2:25, 27, Ja 2:11.†
prop., to force against nature or law.; to compel by force (Polyb.).; to constrain by entreaty (Ge, 1Sam, ll. c.): Lk 24:29, Ac 16:15.†
= cl. παραβάλλομαι (II Mac 14:38),; to expose oneself to danger, hazard one's life: c. dat. ref., τ. ψυχῇ (v. M, Pr., 64), Phl 2:30 (Rec. παραβουλ-). Cited by Deiss., LAE, 84, 120.†

a placing beside, juxtaposition (Polyb., al.).; a comparing, comparison (Plat., Arist., al.).; a comparison, illustration, analogy, figure (Arist., al.) : Mt 24:32, Mk 3:23, He 9:9 11:19; specif. of the pictures and narratives drawn from nature and human life which are characteristic of the synoptic teaching of our Lord, a parable: Mt 13:3, 10 Mk 4:2, 10, Lk 8:4, 9-11, al.; c. gen. ref., Mt 13:18, 36; 4 Like Heb. מָשַׁל (I Ki 10:12, Pr 1:6, Si 3:29, al.), = παροιμία, a proverb or gnomic saying: Lk 4:23 5:36 6:39
to consult amiss, or perh. (v. LS, s.v.), a vulg. form of παρα-βολ- (q.v.) : Phl 2:30, Rec.†
an instruction, charge, com­mand: Ac 5:28 16:24, I Th 4:2, I Ti 1:5 1:18. (In Xen., Polyb., of a military order.)†

to transmit a message (Æsch., Eur.).; to order, command (Hdt., Xen., al.) : c. inf., Ac 15:5; c. acc rei, I Co 11:17, II Th 3:4, I Ti 4:11 5:7; seq. ἵνα (M, Pr., 207; Bl., § 69, 4), Mk 6:8, II Th 3:12; c. dat. pers., Ac 17:30 R, txt., I Th 4:11; seq. λέγων, Mt 10:5; c. inf. aor., Mt 15:35, Mk 8:6, Lk 8:29, Ac 10:42 16:18 (aoristic pres.; v. M, Pr., 119); id. c. neg., μή, Lk 5:14 8:56, Ac 23:22, I Co 7:10; c. inf. pres., Ac 16:23, II Th 3:6; id. c. neg., ιή, Lk 9:21, Ac 1:4 4:18 5:28, 40, I Ti 1:3 6:17; c. acc, τοῦτο, seq. ὅτι (E1., § 70, 3), II Th 3:10; c. acc et inf., Ac 23:30, II Th 3:6, I Ti 6:13 (Bl., § 72, 5).†

to be beside or at hand (Hom., Hdt., al.), hence, to stand by, sup­port (Æsch., Thuc., al.) : c. dat. pers., II Ti 4:16.; to come, come up, arrive (Hdt., Xen., al., and freq. in later writers; v. MM, xviii; Thackeray, Gr., 267.2): absol., Lk 14:21 19:16, Jo 3:23, Ac 5:21-22, 25 9:39 10:32-33 11:23 14:27 17:10 18:27 21:18 23:16, 35 24:17, 24 25:7 28:21, I Co 16:3; seq. εἰς, Jo 8:2, Ac 9:26 15:4; ἐπί, c. acc, Lk 22:52; πρός, c. acc, Lk 7:4, 20 8:19, Ac 20:18; id. seq. ἐκ, Lk 11:6; παρά, c. gen., Mk 14:43; ἀπὸ . . . εἰς, Mt 2:1, Ac 13:14; ἀπὸ . . . ἐπὶ . . . πρός, Mt 3:13; of a teacher coming forward in public: Mt 3:1, Lk 12:51, He 9:11.†

trans., to lead by, lead aside, lead into, lead forward, etc.; Intrans.,; to pass by: Mt 9:9, 27 20:30, Mk 2:14 15:21, Jo 8:59 R, txt., Jo 9:1; seq. παρό, c. acc, Mk 1:16; to go away, depart; metaph., to pass away: I Co 7:31; mid., I Jn 2:8 Jn 2:17.†
to set forth as an example; in bad sense, to put to open shame: He 6:6 (Polyb., Plut., al.).†
a park, pleasure-ground, garden (LXX), an orchard (in π., v. MM, ii, xviii; Deiss., BS, 148).; Paradise, the abode of the blessed dead: Lk 23:43, II Co 12:4, Re 2:7.†
to receive, admit; of things: Mk 4:20, Ac 15:4 16:21 22:18, I Ti 5:19; of persons: He 12:6 (LXX).†
useless wrangling: v.l. in Rec. for διαπαρατριβή (q.v.), I Ti 6:5.†; δια-παρα-τριβή, -ῆς, ἡ; mutual irritation (Field, Notes, 211), wrangling: I Ti 6:5 (Rec. παραδιατριβή).†

to give or hand over to another: c. acc. et dat., Mt 11:27 25:14, Lk 4:6, al.; of being delivered up to a course of teaching, pass. seq. εἰς, Ro 6:17. to commit, commend: Ac 14:26 15:40, I Pe 2:23. to give or deliver up to prison or judgment: c. acc. pers., Mt 4:12, Mk 1:14, Ro 4:25, II Pe 2:4; id. seq. ὑπέρ, Ro 8:32; c. dat., Mt 5:25, Mk 15:1, Lk 12:58, Jo 19:11, al.; id. seq. ἵνα, Jo 19:16; c. inf., Ac 12:4; seq. εἰς, Mt 10:17 17:22 24:9, Lk 21:12, Ac 8:3, II Co 4:11, al.; τ. Σατανᾷ, I Ti 1:20; id. seq. εἰς, I Co 5:5; with the collat. idea of treachery (= προδίδωμι), c. acc. pers., Mt 26:25, Mk 14:11, Jo 6:64, al.; id. c. dat., Mt 26:15, al.; pres. ptcp., ὁ παραδιδοὺς, Mt 26:25, Mk 14:42, Jo 13:11. to hand down, hand on or deliver verbally (traditions, commands, etc.): Mk 7:13, Lk 1:2, Ac 6:14, I Co 11:2 15:2; pass., II Pe 2:21, Ju 3. to permit (for exx. in cl., v. LS, s.v.): Mk 4:29.
contrary to received opinion, incredible, marvellous: pl., Lk 5:26.†

a handing down or over, transfer, transmission (Arist., Polyb., al., LXX).; tradition of doctrine (Plat., Epict., al.); by meton., of the doctrine itself : Mt 15:2-3, 6, Mk 7:3, I Co 11:2, Ga 1:14, Col 2:8, II Th 2:15 3:9.†
to provoke to jealousy: Ro 10:19 (LXX) Ro 11:11, 14, I Co 10:22.†
by the sea: Mt 4:13.†
to examine side by side, compare.; to over­look, neglect: pass., Ac 6:1.†
a deposit or trust: I Ti 6:20, II Ti 1:12 1:14 (for exx. of this form, v. MM, Exp., iii, xviii).†
to exhort, advise: c. acc pers. et inf. (v. Bl., § 72, 5; M, Pr., 205), Ac 27:22; absol., seq. λέγων, Ac 27:9.†

to beg of or from another: Mk 15:6 (Rec. ὅνπερ ᾐτοῦντο, v. Field, Notes, 43).; to deprecate; prop., c. neg., to entreat that not (Thuc., al.): He 12:19; to refuse, decline, avoid: o. acc, I Ti 4:7 5:11, II Ti 2:23, Tit 3:10, He 12:25 (EV; but v. Field, Notes, 234).; to beg off, ask to be excused, excuse (Polyb., al.) : Lk 14:18-19 (He 12:25, Field, l.c.).†
to sit down beside: seq. πρός, Lk 10:39 (Plut.).†
to set beside; act. for mid., to sit down beside: Lk 10:39, Rec. (for -έζομαι, q.v.).†

to call to one, call for, summon: Ac 28:20 (R, mg.; R, txt., entreat); hence (of the gods: Dem., Xen., al.), to invoke, call on, beseech, entreat: τ. πατέρα μου, Mt 26:53; τ. κύριον, II Co 12:8; in late writers (Polyb., Diod., al.; rarely in LXX; in π., v. Deiss., LAE, 17614), also of men: absol., Phm 9; c. acc., Mt 8:5, Mk 1:40, Ac 16:9, al.; c. inf., Mk 5:17, Lk 8:41, Ac 8:31, al.; seq. ἵνα (v. M, Pr., 205, 208), Mt 14"36, Mk 5:18, Lk 8:31, al. to admonish, exhort: absol., Lk 3:18, Ro 12:8, II Ti 4:2, al.; c. acc., Ac 15:32, I Th 2:11, He 3:13, al.; id. seq. inf., Ac 11:23, Ro 12:1, Phl 4:2, I Th 4:10, al.; seq. ἵνα (v. M, Pr., l.c.), I Co 1:10, II Co 8:6, I Th 4:1, al. to cheer, encourage, comfort (Plut., LXX: Jb 43, Is 35:3, Si 43:24, al.): c. acc., II Co 1:6, Eph 6:22, Col 2:2, al.; id. seq. ἐν, I Th 4:18; διά, II Co 1:4; pass., Mt 5:4, Lk 16:25, Ac 20:12.
to cover by hanging something beside, to hide: metaph. (as Plat., al.), Lk 9:45.†
more usual than its variant in Gk. writers for a trust or deposit: I Ti 6:20, II Ti 1:14, Rec.†
to lie beside, be near, be present: Ro 7:18, 21.†

a calling to one's aid, summons (Thus.), hence, appeal, entreaty (Strab., Plut., al., I Mac 10:24; of. Lft., Notes, 20) : II Co 8:4.; exhortation, encouragement: Ac 15:31, Ro 12:8, I Co 14:3, II Co 8:17, Phl 2:1, I Th 2:3, I Ti 4:13, He 12:5; λόγος (τῆς) π., Ac 13:15, He 13:22; υἱὸς π., Ac 4:36.; consolation, comfort (Phalar., LXX) : Lk 6:24, Ac 9:31, II Co 1:4-7 7:4 7:7 7:13, II Th 2:16, Phm 7; τ. γραφῶν, Ro 15:4; θεὸς τῆς π., Ro 15:5, II Co 1:3; π. τοῦ Ἰσραήλ (v. Dalman, Words, 109 f.), Lk

called to one's aid in a judicial cause (Dion. Cass.); hence, most freq. as subst., ὁ π., an advocate, pleader, intercessor (Dem., al.; so in Rabbinic lit., פְּרַקְלִיטָא), "a friend of the accused person, called to speak to his character, or otherwise enlist sympathy in his favour" (Field, Notes, 102). In NT, specif., ὁ π.,; of Christ, I Jn 2:1 (v. ICC, Jo. Epp., 23 ff.); of the Holy Spirit (AV, comforter; but v. opp. c.), Jo 14:16, 26 15:26 16:7 (cf. also Abbott, Essays, 86, 97; Deiss., LAE, 339 f.; MM, xviii; Westc., Jo., ii, 188
a hearing amiss (Flat.); Later, as following inattention, disobedience: Ro 5:19, II Co 10:6, He 2:2 (cf. παρακούω, and v. Tr., Syn., § lxvi).†

c. dat., to follow closely, accompany. Metaph., in various senses,; to result: Mk 16:17; to follow up, trace, investigate: Lk 1:3 (so freq. in cl.); to follow as a standard of conduct: I Ti 4:6, II Ti 3:10. (For exx. from π., v. MM, xviii.)†
to overhear.; to hear amiss or imperfectly.; Later (as in LXX, Polyb., Plut.; also in π., v. MM, xviii), to hear without heeding, take no heed: Mk 5:36; c. gen., Mt 18:17.†
to stoop sideways.; to stoop to look: Lk 24:12 (R, txt.), Jo 20:5, 11, Metaph. (v. Hort, Ja., in l), to look into: seq. εἰς, Ja 1:25, I Pe 1:12.†

c. acc rei, like παραδέχομαι, correl. to παραδίδωμι, to receive from another: Col 4:17, He 12:28; of the mind, I Co 11:23 15:1 15:3, Ga 1:9, Phl 4:9; c. inf., Mk 7:4; seq. παρά, c. gem, Ga 1:12, I Th 2:13 4:1, II Th 3:6; τ. Χριστόν (Lft., in l), Col 2:6.; C. acc pers., to take to or with oneself: Mt 2:13-14, 20-21 17:1 26:37, Mk 4:36 5:40 9:2 10:32, Lk 9:10, 28 11:26 18:31 19:16, Ac 15:39 23:18; γυναῖκα, Mt 1:20, 24; μεθ' ἑαυτοῦ, Mt 12:45 18:16, Mk 14:33; seq. εἰς, Mt 4:5, 8 27:27; κατ' ἰδίαν, Mt 20:17; mid., seq. πρὸς ἐμαυτόν, Jo 14:3; pass., Mt 24:40-41, Lk 17:34-36; ptcp., prefixed to other verbs (Bl, § 74, 2), Ac 16:33 21:24, 26 21:32; metaph., Jo 1:11.†
to lay beside; mid.,; to lie beside (Hom.); later, of sailors, to sail past: c. acc, Ac 27:8, 13.†
by the sea; ἡ π. (sc. χώρα, in LXX ἡ παραλία, De 1:7, Jos 9:1, Jth 1:7, al.), the sea coast: Lk 6:17.†
in various senses (LS, s.v.), change: Ja 1:17.†
to miscalculate.; to reason falsely, hence, to mislead: Col 2:4, Ja 1:22.†
to loose from the side, set free.; to weaken, enfeeble; pass., to be en­feebled, esp. by a paralytic stroke: Lk 5:18, 24, Ac 8:7 9:33, He 12:12 (LXX).†
to remain beside or near: He 7:23, Ja 1:25; of remaining alive, I Co 16:6 (WH, κατα-), Phl 1:25 (cf. συμ-παραμένω).†
to en­courage, exhort.; to comfort, console: c. acc pers., Jo 11:31, I Th 2:11 5:14; id. seq. περί, Jo 11:19.†
encouragement, exhortation.; comfort, consolation: I Co 14:3 .†
an exhortation, persuasion, encouragement: Phl 2:1 (cf. Plat., Legg., vi, 773 E, al.; v. Lft. and ICC, Phi., l.c.).; assuagement, abatement, hence, consolation (Wis, l.c., and freq. in cl.).†
to be a παράνομος, to transgress the law: Ac 23:3.†
law-breaking, transgression: II Pe 2:16.†
to embitter, provoke: absol. (yet sc. τ. θεόν, cf. Ps 106:7, Ez 2:5-8, al., and with τὸν θ. added, Ps 5:4, Ez 20:21, al.), He 3:16 (cf. παραπικρασμός).†
provocation: ἐν τῷ π. (Heb. at Meribah), He 3:8, 15 (LXX).†

most freq. (Hdt., Thuc., al.), to fall in one's way, befall.; to fall into or in (seq. εἰς, Polyb.; c. dat., 2Mac, l.c.).; to fall away (En, Wis, ll. c.; in Polyb., c. gen.) : absol., He 6:6.; to fail (λόγος, Es, l.c.; cf. I Ki 3:19).†
to sail by or past: c. acc, Ac 20:16.†
= ίως, in a way nearly resembling: c. dat., Phl 2:27.†
in like manner: He 2:14.†
to go beside, accom­pany.; to go past, pass by: Mt 27:39, Mk 11:20 15:29; seq. διά, c. gen., Mk 2:23 9:30 (WH, mg.).†
a false step, a blunder (Polyb.).; Ethically, a misdeed, trespass (LXX): Mt 6:14-15, Mk 11:25-26, Ro 4:25 5:15 ff Ro 11:11-12, II Co 5:19, Ga 6:1, Eph 1:7 2:1, 5, Col 2:13.†
to flow by, drift away, slip away: He 2:1.†
in cl., marked amiss, spurious, counterfeit. Later,; marked at the side, annotated (Plut.).; marked with a sign (LXX); as subst., a figure­head : Ac 28:11 (v. MM, xix).†
to prepare, make ready: absol. (sc. τ. δεῖπνον, etc.; of. Hdt., ix, 82, II Mac 2:27), Ac 10:10; mid., to prepare, make preparations: I Co 14:8 (cf. Je, l.c.); pass., II Co 9:2-3.†

preparation.; equipment (Jth, ll c.).; In Jewish usage, the day of preparation for a Sabbath or a feast (= προσάββατον, q.v.) : Mt 27:62, Mk 15:42, Lk 23:54, Jo 19:31; c. gen., τοῦ πάσχα, Jo 19:14; τ. Ἰoυδαίων, Jo 19:42 (it is the name for Friday in MGr.).†
to extend, pro­long: τ. λόγον, Ac 20:7.†

to watch closely, observe narrowly: so mid., τ. πύλας, Ac 9:24; with evil intent, Mk 3:2, Lk 20:20 (absol., v. Field, Notes, 74); so mid., Lk 6:7 14:1.; to observe scrupulously (of days and seasons; cf. Ex 12:42, Sm.): mid., Ga 4:10.†
obser­vation: Lk 17:20 (Polyb., Plut., al.).†

Act., to place beside, set before, c. acc et dat.: of food, Mk 6:41 8:6-7, Lk 9:16 11:6; τράπεζαν, Ac 16:34; pass. ptcp., Lk 10:8, I Co 10:27; metaph., of teaching, παραβολήν, Mt 13:24, 31.; Mid.,; to have set before one (Hom., Thuc., Xen., al.).; to deposit with another, give in charge or commit to (Hdt., Xen., Polyb., al.) : c. acc et dat., Lk 12:48 23:46, Ac 14:23 20:32, I Ti 1:18, II Ti 2:2, I Pe 4:19.; to bring forward, quote as evidence: seq. ὅτι, Ac 17:3 (v. Page, in l).†
to happen to be near or present: Ac 17:17.†
immediately.; C. subst., to express brief duration (cf. ἡ π. λαμπρότης, Thuc., ii, 64), momentary, for a moment: II Co 4:17.†
to bring to, set before, esp. of food (Hdt., al.).; to take or carry away: c. acc rei, seq. ἀπό, Mk 14:36, Lk 22:42; pass., seq. ὑπό, Ju 12; metaph., pass., c. dat., He 13:9.†
to be beside oneself, be deranged: II Co 11:23.†
= cl. παραφροσύνη,; madness: II Pe 2:16.†
to winter at a place: seq. εἰς, Ac 27:12; ἐν, Ac 28:11; πρὸς ὑμᾶς, I Co 16:6; ἐκεῖ, Tit 3:12.†
a wintering: Ac 27:12 (Polyb., al.).†
on the spot, forthwith, instantly: Mt 21:19-20, Lk 1:64 4:39 5:25 8:44, 47 8:55 13:13 18:43 19:11 22:60, Ac 3:7 5:10 12:23 13:11 16:26, 33 (on the usage in Mt, Lk, v. Dalman, Words, 28 f.).†
a panther, leopard: Re 13:2.†

to be by, at hand or present; of persons: Re 17:8; παρών (opp. to ἀπών), I Co 5:3, II Co 10:2 10:11 13:2 13:10; seq. ἐπί c. gen., Ac 24:19; ἐνώπιον, Ac 10:33; ἐνθάδε, Ac 17:6; πρός, c. acc pers., Ac 12:20, II Co 11:8, Ga 4:18, 20; of things : of time, ὁ καιρός, Jo 7:6; τ. παρόν, He 12:11; ἡ ἀλήθεια, II Pe 1:12; ταῦτα, II Pe 1:9; τ. παρόντα, He 13:5.; to have come or arrived (Hdt., Thuc., al.; v. Field, Notes, 65) : Lk 13:1, Jo 11:28, Ac 10:21; seq. εἰς, Col 1:6; seq. ἐπί, c. acc rei, Mt 26:50 (cf. συν-πάρειμι).†
to lead in by one's side, bring forward, introduce.; In late writers, to introduce or bring in secretly: II Pe 2:1.†
brought in secretly (as spies or traitors) : Ga 2:4.†
to slip in secretly, steal in: παρεισεδύησαν (vulgar aor.; pass. for act., El., § 19, 2), Ju 4 (cf. also MM, xix).†
to come in beside or by the way: Ro 5:20.; to come in secretly, steal in: Ga 2:4.†
to bring in or supply besides: σπουδὴν π. (late Gk. for cl. σ. ποιεῖσθαι; cf. Deiss., BS, 361), II Pe 1:5.†
as adv., besides, in addition: τὰ π. (sc. γινόμενα), II Co 11:28.; As prep. c. gen., except: Mt 5:32 19:9 (WH, mg., R, mg.), Ac 26:29.†

an insertion, interpolation (Æschin.); In the Macedonian dialect (Rutherford, NPhr., 473), as a military term; an army in battle array: He 11:34 (cf. Ex 14:19-20, Jg 4:16, al.; freq. in Polyb.); a camp (Ex 29:14, al.) : He 13:11, 13 Re 20:9; barracks, soldiers' quarters: Ac 21:34, 37 22:24 23:10, 16 23:32 28:16 (WH, txt., R, om.).†; παρ-εμ-βάλλω,; to put in beside or between, interpose.; In late writers (Polyb., al., LXX) as technical military term; of soldiers, to draw up in line (freq. in I Mac 2:32, al.); of siege works, to cast up: c. acc et dat., χάρακά σοι, Lk 19:43.†
to annoy concerning a matter (παρά): c. dat. pers., Ac 15:19.†
sojourning in a strange place; as subst., ὁ π., a sojourner: of Christians, I Pe 1:1; ξένοι καὶ π., He 11:13; πάροικοι καὶ π., I Pe 2:11 (v. Deiss., BS, 149).†

to pass, pass by; of persons: absol., Lk 18:37; c. acc pers., Mk 6:48; c. acc lot., Ac 16:8; seq. διά, c. gen., Mt 8:28; of things : τ. ποτήριον, Mt 26:39 (ἀπ' ἐμοῦ), Mt 26:42; of time, Mt 14:15, Mk 14:35, Ac 27:9, I Pe 4:3. Metaph.,; to pass away, perish: Mt 5:18 24:34-35 Mk 13:30-31, Lk 16:17 21:32-33, II Co 5:17, Ja 1:10, II Pe 3:10; to pass by, neglect, disregard: c. acc rei, Lk 11:42 15:29.; to come to, arrive: Lk 12:37 17:7, Ac 24:7, R, mg. (cf. ἀντι-παρέρχομαι).†
a letting go, dismissal.; prætermission, passing by (of debt or sin) : Ro 3:25†

Active voice.,; to furnish, provide, supply; with ref. to incorporeal things, to afford, show, give, cause: c. acc, Ac 22:2, I Ti 1:4; c. acc et dat., Mt 26:10, Mk 14:6, Lk 11:7 18:5, Ac 16:16 17:31 28:2, Ga 6:17, I Ti 6:17.; to present, offer: c. acc et dat., Lk 6:29; c. prop. reflex. et acc pred., to show or present oneself (v. infr., and cf. B1., § 55, 1).; Middle voice.,; to supply, furnish or display of one's own part: c. acc et dat., Lk 7:4, Ac 19:24, Col 4:1.; In late writers, c. prop. reflex. et acc pred. (= act. ut supr.), to show or present oneself (Xen., FlJ, al.; cf. M, Pr., 248; Deiss., BS, 254) : Tit 2:7.†
an address, exhortation (LXX, ll. c.).; comfort, consolation: Col 4:11.†
virginity: Lk 2:36.†
a maiden, virgin: Mt 1:23 (LXX) Mt 25:1, 7 25:11 Lk 1:27, Ac 21:9, I Co 7:25 ff, II Co 11:2; masc., of chaste persons (CIG, 8784 b) : Re 14:4.†
a Parthian: Ac 2:9.†
to pass by or over, let alone, disregard: Lk 11:42.; to relax, loosen; pass., to be relaxed, weakened, exhausted: παρειμένας χεῖρας, He 12:12 (LXX ἀνειμ-).†

Transitive verb. in present tense., imperfect., future tense., 1 aorist.; to place beside, present, provide: c. acc, Ac 9:41 23:24, II Co 4:14, Col 1:28; c. acc et dat., Mt 26:53, Lk 2:22, Ac 1:3 23:33, I Co 8:8; seq. acc pred., Ro 6:13, 16 (late pres., παριστάνετε), Ro 6:19 12:1, II Co 11:2, Eph 5:27, Col 1:22, II Ti 2:15.; to present to the mind (cl.) : by argument, to prove (Xen., FlJ, al.), c. acc, Ac 24:13.; Intransitive. in perfect., pluperfect., 2 aorist.; to stand by or beside one : c. dat. pers., Ac 1:10 9:39 23:2 27:23; ptcp., Mk 14:47, 69-70 15:35, 39 Jo 18:22 19:26.; to appear: c. nom. pred., seq. ἐνώπιον, Ac 4:10; c. dat. pers., Ac 27:24; so fut. mid. (of. LS, s.v., B, ii, 2), Ro 14:10.; to be at hand, be present, have come: Ac 4:26 (LXX); of servants in attendance, ἐνώπιον τ. θεοῦ, Lk 1:19; absol., οἱ παρεστῶτες, Lk 19:24; seq. αὐτῷ, Ac 23:2, 4; of time, Mk 4:29; to stand by for help or defence (Hom., Dem., Xen., al.): c. dat. pers., Ro 16:2, II Ti 4:17.†
Parmenas: Ac 6:5.†
a passing or passage: ἐν π., in passing, I Co 16:7.†
in cl., to dwell beside (c. acc), among (c. dat.) or near by (absol.). In late writers, to dwell in a place as a πάροικος (q.v.) or stranger: Lk 24:18, He 11:9.†
a sojourning: Ac 13:17, I Pe 1:17.†

in cl. Attic, dwelling near, neighbouring; as subst., a neighbour.; In late writers (LXX, Philo) and in Iuser. (Deiss., BS, 227 f.; Kennedy, Sources, 102), foreign, alien; as subst., an alien, a sojourner: Ac 7:6 (LXX), Ac 7:29; metapb., ξένοι καὶ π. (opp. to συμπολίτης), Eph 2:19; π. καὶ παρεπιδήμους (q.v.), I Pe 2:11 (v. Lft. on Clem. Rom., 1 Co., § 1).†

a wayside saying (Hesych.; v. LS, s.v.), a byword, maxim, proverb: II Pe 2:22.; In NT, of figurative discourse (as מָשַׁל, Is 14:4, al.), a parable, allegory: Jo 10:6 16:25, 29 (v. Abbott, Essays, 82 ff.).†
= cl., παροινικός (παρά, οἶνος),; given to wine, drunken: I Ti 3:3, Tit 1:7.†
to have passed by; of time, to be gone by: ἐν τ. παρῳχημέναις γενεαῖς, Ac 14:16.†
to be like: c. dat., Mt 23:27.†
much like, like: Mk 7:13.†

primarily, but never so in cl., to sharpen (μάχαιραν, De 32:41, שָׁנַן).; Metaph., as always in cl.,; to spur on, stimulate (Arist., Xen., al.); to provoke, rouse to anger (De 9:7, 18, Ps 106:29, al.) : pass., Ac 17:16, I Co 13:5.†
stimulation, provocation: π. ἀγάπης, He 10:14.; irritation: Ac 15:39.†
(in cl., passive only), to provoke to anger: Ro 10:19 (LXX), Eph 6:4.†
irritation ("distinguished from ὀργή as implying a less permanent state"; ICC, Eph., 140; and v. Tr., Syn., § xxxvii) : Eph 4:26.†
to urge on, stir up: c. acc pers., Ac 13:50 (find., Hipp., and late writers).†

usually in cl., a being present, presence: I Co 16:17, II Co 10:10; opp. to ἀπουσία, Phl 2:12 (cf. II Mac 15:21).; a coming, arrival, advent (Soph., Eur., Thuc., al., v. LS, s.v.; so Jth, l.c., II Mac 8:12) : II Co 7:6-7, Phl 1:26, II Th 2:9; in late writers (v. M, Th., 145 ff.; MM, xix; LAE, 372 ff.) as technical term for the visit of a king; hence, in NT, specif. of the Advent or Parousia of Christ : Mt 24:3, 27 24:37, 39, I Co 15:23, I Th 2:19 3:13 4:15 5:23, II Th 2:1 2:8, Ja 5:7-8, II Pe 1:16 3:4 3:12, I Jn 2:28.†

a side-dish of dainties (Xen., al.).; In Comic poets and late prose, the dish itself on which the dainties are served: Mt 23:25-26 (In this sense it is condemned by the Atticists; v. Rutherford, NPhr., 265 f.)†

freedom of speech, plainness, openness, freedom in speaking (Eur., Plat., al.) : Ac 4:13, II Co 3:12; παρρησίᾳ, adverbially, freely, openly, plainly, Mk 8:32, Jo 7:13, 26 10:24 11:14 16:29 18:20; opp. to ἐν παροιμίαις, Jo 16:25; ἐν π., Eph 6:19; μετὰ π., Ac 2:29 4:29, 31 28:31; In LXX (I Mac 4:18, Wi 5:1, al.), FlJ, and NT, also (from the absence of fear which accompanies freedom of speech), confidence, boldness: II Co 7:4, Phl 1:20, I Ti 3:13; ἔχειν π., Eph 3:12, Phm 8, He 3:6 10:19, 35, I Jn 2:28 Jn 3:21 Jn 4:17 Jn 5:14; μετὰ π., He 416; ἐν π., Col 2:15; id. (as בפרהסיא in Rabbinic lit.; v. Westc., Jo., i, 262), in public, Jo 7:4 and (without ἐν) Jo 11:54.†
to speak freely or boldly, be bold in speech: Ac 9:27-28 13:46 14:3 18:26 19:8 26:26, Eph 6:20, I Th 2:2.†

all, every. As adj., c. subst. anarth., all, every, of every kind: Mt 3:10 4:23, Mk 9:49, Lk 4:37, Jo 2:1o, Ac 27:20, Ro 7:8, Re 18:17, al. mult.; pl., all, Ac 22:15, Ro 5:12, He 1:6, al.; of the highest degree, π. ἐξουσία (προθυμία, χαρά), Mt 28:18, Ac 17:11, Phi 2:29, al.; also the whole (though in this sense more freq. c. art.), Mt 2:3, Ac 2:36, Ro 11:26. C. art. (before the art., after the noun, or, denoting totality, between the art. and noun), all, whole: Mt 8:32 13:2, Mk 5:33, Lk 1:10, Ac 7:14, Ro 3:19, Ga 5:14, Eph 4:16, al.; pl., Mt 2:4, Mk 4:13, Ro 1:5, al. As pron., masc. and fem., every one: Mk 9:49, Lk 16:16, He 2:9; seq. rel. pron., Mt 7:24, Ac 2:21, Ga 3:10, al.; c. ptcp. (anarth.), Mt 13:19, Lk 11:4; c. ptcp. (c. art.), Mt 5:22, Mk 7:8, Lk 6:47, Jo 3:8, Ro 1:16, al.; pl., πάντες, absol., all, all men, Mt 10:22, Mk 13:13, Lk 20:38, Jo 1:7 3:26, I Co 8:1, al.; οἱ π. (collectively, as a definite whole), Ro 11:32, I Co 1:17, Eph 4:13, al.; π. οἱ (ὅσοι), Mt 4:24, Mk 1:32, Lk 4:40, al. Neut., sing., πᾶν, everything, all: πᾶν τό, c. ptcp., I Co 10:25, 27, Eph 5:13, I Jo 2:16 5:4 (sc. ὄν); πᾶν ὅ, Jo 17:2, Ro 14:23; collectively, of persons (Westc., in l.), Jo 6:37, 39; c. prep., in adverbial phrases, διὰ παντός, always, Mt 18:10, al.; ἐν παντί, in everything, in every way, II Co 4:8, Phi 4:6, al.; pl., πάτνα, all things: absol., Jo 1:3, I Co 2:10, He 2:8, al.; of certain specified things, Mk 4:34, Lk 1:3, Ro 8:28, I Th 5:21, al.; acc., πάντα, adverbially, wholly, in all things, in all respects, Ac 20:35, I Co 9:25, al.; c. art., τὰ π., all things (a totality, as distinct from anarth. πάντα, all things severally; cf. Westc, Eph., 186f.), absol.: Ro 11:36, I Co 8:6, Eph 3:9, He 1:3, al.; relatively, Mk 4:11, Ac 17:25, Ro 8:32, al.; πάντα, c. ptcp., Mt 18:31, al.; πάντα ταῦτα (ταῦτα π.), Mt 6:32, 33, al.; πάντα, c. prep, in adverbial phrases, πρὸ πάντων, above all things, Ja 5:12, I Pe 4:8; ἐν π́, in all things, in all ways, I Ti 3:11, I Pe 4:11, al.; κατὰ πάντα, in all respects, Ac 17:22, al. C. neg., πᾶς οὐ (μή) = οὐδείς, v.s. οὐ and μή, and cf. M, Pr., 245f.

the festival of the Passover: Mt 26:2, Mk 14:1, Lk 22:1, Jo 2:13, 23 6:4 11:55 12:1 18:39 19:14, Ac 12:4, He 11:28; .ἡ ἐορτὴ τοῦ π., Lk 2:41, Jo 13:1.; By meton.,; the paschal supper: ἑτοιμάζειν τὸ π., Mt 26:19, Mk 14:16, Lk 22:8, 13; ποιεῖν τό π., Mt 26:18; the pasohal lamb: θύειν τό π. (Ex 12:21), Mk 14:12, Lk 22:7; of Christ, I Co 5:7; φαγεῖν τὸ π. (lamb or supper), Mt 26:17, Mk 14:12, 14, Lk 22:11, 15, Jo 18:28 (cf. II Ch 30:17).†

to suffer, be acted on, as opp. to acting, often limited by a word expressive of good or evil; of misfortunes (most freq. without any limiting word) : absol., Lk 22:15 24:46, Ac 1:3 3:18 17:3, I Co 12:26, He 2:18 9:26 13:12, I Pe 2:19-20 2:23 3:17 4:15 4:19; seq. ὑπό, c. gen., Mt 17:12; ὑπέρ, Ac 9:16, Phl 1:20, II Th 1:5, I Pe 2:21; c. dat. ref., I Pe 4:1; περί, c. gen. (seq. ὑπέρ), I Pe 3:18; διά, c. acc, I Pe 3:14; ὀλίγον (a little while), I Pe 5:10; c. acc, Mt 27:19, Mk 9:12, Lk 13:2 24:26, Ac 28:5, II Ti 1:12, He 5:8, Re 2:10; παθήματα, II Co 1:6; ταῦτα, Ga 3:4 (EV; cf. Lft., in l, but v. infr.); acc seq. ἀπό, Mt 16:21, Lk 9:22 17:25; ὑπό, Mk 5:26, I Th 2:14; of pleasant experiences (but always with qualifying word, εὖ or acc rei) : Ga 3:4 (cf. Grimm-Thayer, s.v.; Interp. Corn., in l, but v. supr.) (cf. προ-, συν-πάσχω).†
Patara, a maritime city of Lycia: Ac 21:1.†

in Hom., intrans., to beat (of the heart).; Trans. = πλήσσω, to strike, smite: absol., ἐν μαχαίρᾳ, Lk 22:49; c. acc pers., Mt 26:51, Lk 22:50; c. acc rei, Ac 12:7; of a deadly blow, Mt 26:31, Mk 14:27, Ac 7:24. Metaph., of disease: Ac 12:23, Re 11:6 19:15.†

intrans., to tread, walk: seq. ἐπάνω ὄφεων κ.τ.λ. (fig.), Lk 10:19 (cf. Ps 91:13).; Trans., to tread on, trample: τ. ληνόν, Re 14:20 19:15 (cf. Jg 9:27, La 1:15, al.); of the desecration of Jerusalem by its enemies, Lk 21:24, Re 11:2 (cf. κατα-, περι-, ἐν-περι-πατέω).†

a father; prop., of the male parent: Mt 2:22, Lk 1:17, Jo 4:53; anarth., He 12:7 (M, Pr., 82 f.); pl., of both parents (cl.), He 11:23; οἱ π. τ. σαρκός, He 12:9; of a forefather or ancestor (in cl. usually in pl.; Hom., al.): Mt 3:9, Lk 1:73, Jo 8:39, al.; pl., Mt 23:30, 32 Lk 6:23, 26 Jo 4:20, I Co 10:1, al. Metaph., of an author, originator, or archetype (= αἴτιος, ἀρχηγός, etc.; Pind., Plat., al.): Jo 8:41-44, Ro 4:11, 12 16. as a title of respect or honour, used of seniors, teachers and others in a position of responsible authority (Jg 17:10, II Ki 2:12, Pr 1:8, al.): Mt 23:9 Ac 7:2 22:1, I Jo 2:13. Of God (as in cl. of Zeus) as Father; of created things: τ. φώτων, Ja 1:17; of all sentient beings: Eph 3:14, 15 He 12:9; of men, esp. those in covenant relation with Him (freq in OT and later Jewish lit.; v. Dalman, Words, 184ff.): Mt 6:4, Lk 6:36, Jo 4:21, Ja 3:9, al.; ὁ π. ὁ ἐν (τ.) οὐρανοῖς, Mt 5:16, Mk 11:25; ὁ π. ὁ οὐράνιος, Mt 6:14 15:13; esp. in the Epp., of Christians: Ro 8:15, II Co 6:18, Ga 4:6, Eph 2:18 4:6, I Jo 2:1; c. gen. qual., τ. οἰκτιρμῶν, II Co 1:3; τ. δοξῆς, Eph 1:17; of Christ (Dalman, Words, 190 ff.); by our Lord himself: ὁ π., Mt 11:25-27, Lk 10:2, 22 Jo 5:20-23, al.; ὁ π. μου, Mt 11:27, al.; ὁ ἐν τ. οὐρανοῖς, Mt 7:11, al.; ὁ οὐράνιος, Mt 15:13; vocat., Jo 11:41 12:27, 28 17:1, 5, 11, 20, 25 (cf. Abbott, JG., 96 f.); by Apostles: Jo 1:14 (anarth.; v. M, Pr., l.c.), Ro 15:6, II Co 1:3 11:31, Eph 1:3, Col 1:3, He 1:5, I Pe 1:3, Re 1:6 (cf. Westc., Epp. Jo., 27-34).
Patmos, an island in the Ægean Sea: Re 1:9.†

lineage, ancestry (Hdt.).; = πάτρα (more common in cl.), a family or tribe (so sometimes in Hdt., in LXX of related people, in a sense narrower than φυλή and wider than οἶκος; v. Ex 12:3, Nu 32:28): Lk 2:4; in a wider sense (I Ch 16:28, Ps 22:27), Ac 3:25 (LXX) Eph 3:15.†
a patriarch: Ac 2:29 7:8-9, He 7:4.†
paternal, ancestral: Ga 1:14.†

prop. poët. fern. of πάτριος, of one's fathers; as subst., ἡ π. = πάτρα, fatherland, country, home, native place: Ac 18:27, WH, mg., He 11:14; of one's own town, Mt 13:54, 57, Mk 6:1, 4, Lk 4:23-24, Jo 4:44.†
Patrobas: Ro 16:14.†
a parricide: I Ti 1:9 (Av, R, txt.); a smiter of his father : ib. (R, mg.).†
handed down from one's fathers, inherited: I Pe 1:18 (Diod., al.).†
of one's fathers, received from one's fathers: Ac 22:3 24:14 28:17.†
Sergius Paulus: Ac 13:7. the Apostle Paul (cf. Σαῦλος): Ac 13:9, and freq. throughout Ac., Ro 1:1, I Co 1:1, al., II Pe 3:15.

to make to cease, restrain, hinder: c. acc rei, seq. ἀπό I Pe 3:10 (LXX). Mid., to cease, leave off: Lk 8:24 11:1, Ac 20:1, I Co 13:8; c. ptcp., Lk 5:4, Ac 5:42 6:13 13:10 20:31 21:32, Eph 1:16, Col 1:9, He 10:2; c. gen., ἀμαρτίας, I Pe 4:1 (WH, mg., R, txt.); c. dat., ib. (WH, txt., R, mg.).†
Paphos, a city in Cyprus: Ac 13:6, 13 †
to thicken, fatten; pass., to grow fat. Metaph., to make dull or stupid (τ. ψυχάς, Rut.); pass., to wax gross: ἡ καρδία„ Mt 13:15, Ac 28:27 (LXX).†
a fetter: Mk 5:4, Lk 8:29.†
level, plain: Lk 6:17.†
to travel on foot or by land: Ac 20:13.†
on foot: Mt 14:13 (WH, mg., R, txt.).; Opp. to going by sea, by land: Mt 14:13 (WH, mg., R, mg.).; As adv., πεζῇ (sc. ὁδῷ), on foot or by land: Mt 1413 (WH, txt.), Mk 6:33.†
to obey one in authority, be obedient: Tit 3:1; c. dat., Ac 27:21; θεῷ, Ac 5:29, 32.†
persuasive: I Co 2:4 (not found elsewhere).†
Peitho, Persuasion (as a goddess).; per­suasion: ἐν πειθοῖ (so Orig., Eus. and some cursives in I Co 2:4 for πειθός, q.v.).†

Active; trans., to apply persuasion ("conative" in pres.; v. M, Pr., 147), to prevail upon or win over, persuade: absol., Mt 28:14, Ac 19:26; seq. περί, c. gen. rei, Ac 19:8; c. acc pers., Ac 12:20 14:19 18:4, II Co 5:11, Ga 1:10; τ. καρδίας ἡμῶν, I Jn 3:19; c. acc seq. περί, Ac 28:23; c. acc et inf., Ac 13:43 26:28 (v. Field, Notes, 141 ff.); c. acc seq. ἵνα (Plut.), Mt 27:20.; Intrans., 2 pf. πέποιθα with Pres. sense (v. M, Pr., 147, 154; Bl., § 59, 2): to trust, be confident, have confidence: c. acc et inf., Ro 2:19; c. acc ref. (v. Ellic., in l) : Phl 1:6, 25; c. dat., Phl 1:14, Phm 21; ἑαυτῷ, c. inf., II Co 10:7; seq. ἐν, Phl 3:3-4; ἐν κυρίῳ ὅτι, Phl 2:24; ἐπί, c. dat., Mt 27:43 (WH, mg.), Mk 10:24 (T, WH, R, mg., om.), Lk 11:22 18:9, II Co 1:9, He 2:13; ἐπί, c. acc, Mt 27:43 (c. dat., WH, mg.); id. seq. ὅτι, II Co 2:3, II Th 3:4 (v. Lft., Notes, 127); εἰς, c. acc pers. seq. ὅτι, Ga 5:10.; to be persuaded, believe (v. M, Pr., 158) : absol., Lk 16:31, Ac 17:4 21:14, He 13:18; c. dat., Ac 28:24; c. acc et inf., Ac 26:26; so also pf., πέπεισμαι, πεπεισμένος εἰμί: c. acc ref. seq. περί, He 6:9; c. acc et inf., Lk 20:6; ὅτι, Ro 8:38, II Ti 1:5 1:12; id. c. ἐν κυρίῳ, Ro 14:14; περί, c. gen. seq. ὅτι, Ro 15:14.; to listen to, obey: c. dat. pers., Ac 5:36-37, 40 23:21 27:11, Ro 2:8, Ga 5:7, He 13:17, Ja 3:3 (cf. ἀνα-πείθω).†
Pontius Pilate: Mt 27:2, Mk 15:1, Lk 3:1, Jo 18:29, Ac 3:13, I Ti 6:13, al
trial, experiment; π. λαμβάνειν, to make trial, have experience of: He 11:29, 36 (for exx., v. Field, Notes, 232 f.).†

to make proof of (Hom.).; to try, attempt (Luc., Polyb., c. inf. (v. M, Pr., 205; B1., § 69, 4), Ac 9:26 16:7 24:6.; In LXX and NT, like Heb. נָסָה, c. acc pers., to test, try, prove; in a good sense : Jo 6:6, II Co 13:5, He 11:17, Re 2:2; esp. of trials and af6ictions sent or permitted by God (Ge 22:1, Ex 20:20, Wi 3:5, al.), I Co 10:13, He 2:18 4:15 11:17, 37, Re 3:10; in a bad sense (Apoll. Rhod., 3, 10): of the attempts made to ensnare Jesus in his speech, Mt 16:1 19:3 22:18, 35 Mk 8:11 10:2 12:15, Lk 11:16, Jo 8:6; of temptation to sin, to tempt, Ja 1:13-14 (v. Hort, in l), Ga 6:1, Re 2:10; esp. of temptations of the devil, Mt 4:1, 3 Mk 1:13, Lk 4:2, I Co 7:5, I Th 3:5; ὁ πειράζων, the tempter, Mt 4:3, I Th 3:5; in bad sense also (Ex 17:2, 7, Nu 14:22, al.), of distrustful testing, trying or challenging of God: Ac 15:10, I Co 10:9 (WH, mg., ἐξεπείρασαν), He 3:9; τ. πνεῦμα Κυρίου, Ac 5:9 (of. ἐκ-πειράζω).†

= πεῖρα, an experiment Diosc.).; a trial, of ethical purpose and effect, whether good or evil (v. Hort on Ja 1:13); in good or neutral sense: Ga 4:14, Ja 1:12, I Pe 4:12; esp. of afflictions sent by God (De 7:19, Si 21:1-28, al.): II Pe 2:9, Re 3:10; pl., Lk 22:28, Ac 20:19, Ja 1:2, I Pe 1:6; of trial regarded as leading to sin, temptation: Lk 8:13, I Co 10:13, I Ti 6:9; of the temptation of Jesus by the devil, Lk 4:13; εἰσφέρειν (ἔρχεσθαι, εἰσέρχ-) εἰς π., Mt 6:13 26:41, Mk 14:38, Lk 11:4 22:40, 46; of the testing or challenge of God by man (v.s. πειράζω, 3, c.) : He 3:8 (LXX: Ps 95:9, where κατα τ. ἡμέραν πειρασμοῦ = מַסָּה the day of Massah).†
to try, attempt: Ac 26:21.†
persuasion: Ga 5:8.†
the deep sea, the deep, the sea: Ac 27:5; τὸ π. τῆς θαλάσσης, Mt 18:6
to out off with an axe, esp. to behead: c. acc, Re 20:4 (Polyb., al.).†

to send; of persons: c. acc, absol., Mt 22:7, Lk 7:19, Jo 1:22, II Co 9:3, al.; ptcp. seq. verb., Mt 14:10, Ac 19:31, al.; ptcp. seq. διά (= Heb. יָד;, I Ki 16:20, al.), Mt 11:2 (cf. Re 1:1); of teachers sent by God, Jo 1:33 4:34, Ro 8:3, al.; c. acc et dat., I Co 4:17, Phl 2:19; seq. πρός, c. acc, Lk 4:26, Jo 16:7, al.; seq. λέγων (cf. Heb. אָמַר שָׁלַח Ge 38:25, al.), Lk 7:6, 19; seq. εἰς, c. acc loc., Mt 2:8, Lk 15:15, al.; seq. εἰς (of purpose), Eph 6:22, Col 4:8, I Pe 2:14; c. inf., Jo 1:33, I Co 16:3, Re 22:16; of things : Re 11:10; seq. εἰς, Re 1:11; id., of purpose, Ac 11:29, Phl 4:16; c. dat. pers., II Th 2:11; π. τ. δρέπανον σου (cf. εξαποστείλατε δρέπανα = מַגָּל שָׁלַח, Jl 3:13), Re 14:15, 18 (cf. ἀνα-, ἐκ-, μετα-, προ-, συν-πέμπω)
one who works for his living, a labourer, a poor man: II Co 9:9.†
a father-in-law: Jo 18:13.†
to mourn (for), lament; intrans. : Mt 5:4 (5) Mt 9:15, I Co 5:2; π. καὶ κλαίειν, Mt 16:10, Lk 6:25, Ja 4:9, Re 18:15, 19; seq. ἐπί, c. acc, Re 18:11; trans., c. acc, II Co 12:21.†
mourning: Ja 4:9, Re 18:7-8 21:4.†
chiefly in Comic poets and late prose (but Plato, Rep., 578 A), = πένης,; needy, poor: Lk 21:2 (for ex. in π., v. MM, xix).†
five times: II Co 11:24.†
five hundred: Lk 7:41, I Co 15:6.†
indecl., οἱ, αἱ, τά,; five: Mt 14:17, al
the fifteenth: Lk 3:1.†
indecl., οἱ, αἱ, τά,; fifty: Lk 7:41 16:6, Jo 8:57 21:11, Ac 13:20; ἀνὰ π., Lk 9:14; κατὰ π., Mk 6:40.†

fiftieth. As subst., ἡ π.; (sc. μερίς), at Athens, a tax of two per cent.; (sc. ἡμέρα, i.e. the fiftieth day after the Passover), Pentecost, the second of the three great Jewish feasts (To, 2Mac, ll. c.; ἑορτὴ ἑβδομάδων, De 16:10, al.) : Ac 2:1 20:16, I Co 16:8.†
confidence: II Co 1:15 3:4 10:2, Eph 3:12; seq. εἰς, II Co 8:22; ἐν, Phl 3:4 (the word is condemned by the Atticists, v. Rutherford, NPhr., 355).†

enclitic particle, adding force or positiveness to the word which precedes it: indeed, by far, etc. In the NT, it is always affixed to the word to which it relates, v.s. διόπερ, άἐνπερ, εἴπερ, ἐπείπερ, ἐπειδήπερ, ἤπερ, καθάπερ, καίπερ, ἅσπερ, ὥσπερ
compar. adv.,; beyond: Ac 19:39, L, Tr., WH (T, Rec., R, περὶ ἑτέρων).†

on the other side, across (usually with the idea of water lying between); as in the older poets, as prep. c. gen.: τ. θαλάσσης, Jo 6:1, 17 6:22, 25; τ. Ἰορδάνου, Mt 4:15 (LXX), Mt 4:25 19:1, Mk 3:8 10:1, Jo 1:28 3:26 10:40; τ. χειμάρρου τ. Κέδρων, Jo 18:1; τὸ π., the region beyond, the other side: Mt 8:18, 28 14:22 16:5, Mk 4:35 5:21 6:45 8:13; τ. θαλάσσης, Mk 5:1; τ. λίμνης, Lk 8:22.†
an end, limit, boundary; of space: chiefly in pl., τὰ π. τ. γῆς, Mt 12:42, Lk 11:31; τ. οἰκουμένης, Ro 10:18 (LXX); (opp. to ἀρχή) the end: c. gen., ἀντιλογίας, He 6:10.†
Pergamum, a city of Mysia: Re 1:11 2:12.†
Perga, a city of Pamphylia: Ac 13:13-14 14:25.†

with radical sense round about (as distinct from ἀμφί, on both sides). C. gen., of place, about (poët.). Causal, about, on account of, concerning, in reference to: Mt 2:8, Mk 1:44, Lk 4:38, Jo 16:26, Ac 28:21, al. mult.; τὰ περί, c. gen., the things concerning one, one's state or case: Mk 5:27, Ac 1:3 28:15, Eph 6:22, al.; at the beginning of a sentence, περί, regarding, as to, I Co 7:1, al.; in the sense on account of (Mt 26:28, I Co 1:13, al.), often with ὑπέρ as variant (cf. M, Pr., 105). C. acc., of place, about, around: Mt 3:4, Mk 1:6, Lk 13:8, Ac 22:6, al.; οἱ περί, c. acc. pers., of one's associates, friends, etc., Mk 4:10, Lk 22:49, Jo 11:19, Ac 13:13; οἱ περὶ τ. τοιαῦτα ἐργάται, Ac 19:25; metaph., about, as to, concerning: I Ti 1:19 6:4 II Ti 2:18 3:8, Tit 2:7; τὰ περὶ ἐμέ, Phl 2:23; αἱ περὶ τ. λοιπὰ ἐπιθυμίαι, Mk 4:19. Of time, in a loose reckoning, about, near: Mt 20:3, 5 6, 9 27:46, Mk 6:48, Ac 10:3, 9 22:6. In composition: round about (περιβάλλω, περίκειμαι), beyond, over and above (περιποιέω, περιλείπω), to excess (περιεργάζομαι, περισσεύω).

to lead about or around: c. acc pers., I Co 9:5.; Intrans., to go about: Ac 13:11; seq. ἐν, Mt 4:23; c. acc loc. (governed by the περι-, not so in cl., v. Bl., § 34, 1; 53, 1), Mt 9:35 23:15, Mk 6:6.†

to take away that which surrounds, take away, take off (τείχη, Hdt., Thuc.; χιτῶνα, Plat.; δακτύλιον, Ge 41:42, cf. σφρηγῖδα, Hdt., ii, 151) : τ. κάλυΜΜα, pass., II Co 3:16; as nautical term (RV, cast off), ἀγκύρας, Ac 27:40; absol., to cast loose: Ac 28:13. Metaph., to take away entirely: ἐλπίς, pass., Ac 27:20; ἁμαρτίας, He 10:11.†
to tie about, attach.; In late writers, to light a fire around, kindle: πῦρ, Lk 22:55.†
to flash around: c. acc, Ac 9:3; seq. περί Ac 22:6 (Eccl, and Byzant.).†

to throw around or over, put on or over; of siege or defen­sive works: χάρακά σοι, Lk 19:43 (WH, mg.; παρεμβ-, WH, txt.); of clothing, to put on, wrap about, clothe with: c. acc rei, Lk 23:11; c. acc pers., Mt 25:36, 38 25:43; c. dupl. acc (not cl.; Bl., § 34, 4), Jo 19:2; pf. pass., to have wrapped round one: c. acc rei (cl.), Mk 14:51 16:5, Re 7:9, 13 10:1 11:3 12:1 17:4 18:16 19:13; c. dat. rei, Re 4:4 (WH, txt.; seq. ἐν, WH, mg.); fut., seq. ἐν (of. De 22:12, Ps 45:9, 13), Re 3:5. Mid., to clothe oneself, wrap round or put on oneself: absol., Mt 6:29, Lk 12:27, Re 3:18; c. acc rei, Mt 6:31, Ac 12:8, Re 19:8.†
to look around (at). Mid., to look about one (at) : absol., Mk 9:8 10:23; c. inf., Mk 5:32; c. acc pers., Mk 3:5, 34, Lk 6:10; πάντα, Mk 11:11.†
that which is thrown around, a covering, in NT,; a mantle (Ps 102:27, Is 59:17, al.) : He 1:12 (LXX); a veil: I Co 11:15 (but v. ICC, in l).†
to tie round, bind round: c. acc et dat., pass., Jo 11:44.†
to waste one's labour about a thing.; to be a busybody: II Th 3:11 (cf. Plat., Apol., 19 B).†
of persons; over careful.; curious, meddling, a busybody: I Ti 5:13.; Of things; over-wrought.; super­fluous.; curious, uncanny; τὰ π., curious arts, magic: Ac 19:19 (v. Deiss., BS, 3235.).†
to go about (as an itinerant): Ac 19:13 28:13 (περιελόντες, WH, R, mg.), He 11:37; τ. οἰκίας, from house to house: I Ti 5:13.†

to surround, encompass: Lk 5:9 (cf. MM, xix).; to comprehend, include, contain, esp. of books: c. acc, Ac 23:25, Rec.; acc to a late usage, intrans. (BL, § 53, 1.3; MM, xix; Hort, in l), it stands written, I Pe 2:6.†

to gird (c. dupl, acc, as ὁ περιζωννύων με δύναμιν, Ps 18:32): pass., αἱ ὀσφύες περιεζωσμέναι, Lk 12:35; π. ζώνην χρυσῆν, Re 1:13 15:6 (but v. infr.). Mid., to gird oneself: Lk 12:37 17:8 (and so perh. Re, ll. c. supr., cf. I Ki 2:4); c. acc rei (fig.), τ. ὀσφύν, Eph 6:14 (seq. ἐν, cf. I Ch 15:27).†
a putting around, putting on: I Pe 3:3.†
to place around.; to stand around: Jo 11:42; c. acc pers., Ac 25:7. Mid. (in late writers), to turn oneself about to avoid, to shun: c. acc rei, II Ti 2:16, Tit 3:9.†
a victim, expiation (Pr, l.c).; refuse, rubbish: pl., I Co 4:13 (v. ICC, in l).†
to invest, besiege (Diod., IV Ki 6:24, I Mac 11:61, al.). to sit around: Lk 22:55, L, txt. †
to cover around, cover up or over. c. acc, Mk 14:65, Lk 22:64; pass., seq. χρυσίῳ, He 9:4.†
to lie round about: μύλος, λίθος (RV, were hanged about), Mk 9:42, Lk 17:2; νεφος μαρτύρων, He 12:1.; to have around one, be clothed with: Ac 28:20; fig., ἀσθένειαν, He 5:2.†
a helmet: fig., I Th 5:8; c. gen. explic., π. τ. σωτηρίου, Eph 6:17 (cf. Is 59:17).†
having full command of: Ac 27:16.†
to conceal entirely, keep hidden: late 2 aor., περιέκρυβσν (but v. BL, § 17; Soph., Lex., s.v. περικρύβω), Lk 1:24.†
to encircle, encompass: of a besieged city, Lk 19:43.†
to shine around: c. acc, Lk 2:9, Ac 26:13.†
to be left remaining, remain over, survive: I Th 4:15 4:17†
very sad, deeply grieved: Mt 26:38, Mk 6:26 14:34, Lk 18:23.†
to wait for: c. acce., Ac 1:4.†
round about: αἱ π. πολεῖς, Ac 5:16.†
to dwell round about: c. acc, Lk 1:65.†
dwelling around; as subst., ὁ π., a neighbour: Lk 1:58 (cf. πλησίον).†
one's own, of one's own possession: λαὸς π. (cf. LXX, ll. c.), Tit 2:14.†
compass, circumference.; a portion circumscribed, a section: Ac 8:32.†

to walk: absol., Mt 9:5, Mk 5:42, Lk 5:23, Jo 1:36; c. pred., γυμνός, Re 16:15; ἐπάνω Lk 11:44; διά, c. gen., Re 21:24; ἐν, Mk 11:27 12:38, Jo 7:1 11:54, Re 2:1, al.; ἐν τ. σκοτίᾳ, fig., Jo 8:12 12:35, I Jn 1:6-7 Jn 2:11; ἐπί, c. gen., Mt 14:26; id. c. dat., Mt 14:25, 29; μετά, Jo 6:66, Re 3:4; παρά, c. acc, Mt 4:18. Metaph., of living, passing one's life, conducting oneself (like ἀναστρέφομαι in Xen., Plut., LXX, π.; M, Pr 11:1-31; Deiss., BS, 194) : ἀκριβῶς, Eph 5:15; ἀτάκτως, II Th 3:6 3:11; εὐσχημόνως, Re 13:13, I Th 4:12; ἀξίως, c. gen., Eph 4:1, Col 1:10, I Th 2:12; καθώς (ὥς), Eph 4:17 5:8, 15, Phl 3:17, I Th 4:1; οὕτως ὥς, I Co 7:17; seq. nom. qual., Phl 3:18; c. dat., Ac 21:21, Ro 13:13, II Co 12:18, Ga 5:16; seq. ἐν, Ro 6:4, II Co 4:2 5:7 10:3, Eph 2:2, 10 4:17 5:2, Col 3:7 4:5, He 13:9, II Jn 4 Jn 6, al.; ἐν Χριστῷ, Col 2:6; κατά, c. acc, Mk 7:5, Ro 8:4 14:15, I Co 3:3, II Co 10:2, II Jn 6 (cf. ἐν-περιπατέω).
to put on a spit, hence, to pierce: metaph., ἑαυτὸν . . . ὀδύναις, I Ti 6:10.†
to fall around.; to fall in with, light upon, come across: c. dat., λῃσταῖς, Lk 10:30; πειρασμοῖς, Ja 1:2; seq. εἰς, Ac 27:41.†

to make to remain over, preserve.; Mid.; to keep or save for oneself: τ. ψυχήν (cf. Xen., Cyr., iv, 4, 10; Arist., Pol., v, 11, 30), Lk 17:33; to get or gain for oneself, get possession of (Thuc., Xen., al.) : Ac 20:28, I Ti 3:13.†
preservation: He 10:39 (2 Ch, l.c.).; acquisition, obtaining: I Th 5:9, II Th 2:14 (and so perh. Eph 1:14, v. infr.).; a possession: Eph 1:14 (but v. supr., and cf. ICC, in l), I Pe 2:9 (LXX).†
to break or tear off all around: freq. of garments, τ. ἰμάτια, Ac 16:22.†
to draw around, draw off or away. Metaph., to distract: pass., Lk 10:40.†
abundance, superfluity: Ro 5:17, II Co 8:2 10:15, Ja 1:21 (so also Inscr., v. LAE, 80).; (a) superiority (Ec, v. supr.); profit (ib.).†
that which is over and above, superfluity, abundance: opp. to ὑστέρημα (q.v.), II Co 8:13-14; pl., Mk 8:8; metaph., π. τ. καρδίας, Mt 12:34, Lk 6:45 (cf. Ec, l.c.; Plut., al.).†

Prop., intrans.,; of things, to be over and above the number (Hes.), hence,; to be or remain over: Mt 14:20 15:37, Lk 9:17, Jo 6:12-13; to abound, be in abundance: Mk 12:44, Lk 12:15 21:4, Ac 16:5, Ro 3:7 5:15, II Co 1:5 8:2 9:12, Phl 1:26.; Of persons,; to abound in, have in abundance: I Co 14:12 15:58, Phl 4:12, 18; c. gen., Lk 15:17 T; to be superior or better, to excel: absol., I Co 3:9 8:8; c. dat. ref., II Co 3:9; seq. ἐν, Ro 15:13, I Co 15:58, II Co 3:9 8:7, Col 2:7; μᾶλλον, I Th 4:1 4:10; μ καὶ μ., Phl 1:9; πλεῖον, Mt 5:20.; In late writers (Lft., Notes, 48 f.), trans.,; to make to abound: c. acc seq. εἰς, II Co 4:15 9:8, Eph 1:8; pass., Mt 13:12 25:29; c. gen. rei, Lk 15:17, WH; to make to excel: c. acc pers., dat. rei, I Th 3:12 (cf. ὑπερ-περισσεύω).†

more than sufficient, over and above, abundant: Jo 10:10, II Co 9:1; c. gen. (a popular substitute for πλειών, Bl., § 11, 3.4), Mt 5:37; id. c. ellips. gen., Mt 5:47 (EV, more than others; but v. infr.); εκ περισσοῦ, Mk 6:51, Rec., T. (on ὑπὲρ ὲκ π., v.s. ὑπερεκπερισσοῦ). Compar. neut., -ότερον: Lk 12:4, 48; c. gen., Mk 12:33; adverbially (cf. περισσῶς), more abund­antly, II Co 10:8, He 6:17 7:15; c. gen., π. πάντων, I Co 15:10; pleonast., μᾶλλον π., Mk 7:36.; out of the common, pre-eminent, superior: Mt 5:47 (Thayer, s.v., but v. supr.); τὸ π., as subst., Ro 3:1; compar., -ότερος, c. gen., Mt 11:9, Lk 7:26; c. subst., Mk 12:40, Lk 20:47, I Co 12:23-24, II Co 2:7.†

beyond measure, exceedingly, abundantly: Mt 27:23, Mk 10:26 15:14, Ac 26:11. Compar.; περισσότερον (v.s. περισσός); περισσοτέρως: II Co 1:12 2:4 7:15 11:23, Ga 1:14, Phl 1:14, I Th 2:17, He 2:1 13:19; π. μᾶλλον, II Co 7:13; opp. to ἧττον, II Co 12:15.†

to cut around (Hdt.), hence, to circumcise (π. τὰ αἰδοῖα, Hdt.) : Lk 1:59 2:21, Jo 7:22, Ac 7:8 15:5 16:3 21:21. Pass. and mid., to be circumcised, receive circumcision: Ac 15:1, I Co 7:18, Ga 2:3 5:2-3 6:12-13 Metaph. (cf. De 10:16, Je 4:4, al.), Col 2:11 (v. Deiss., BS, 151 f.; MM, xix).†

to place or put around: c. acc et dat., Mt 21:33 27:48, Mk 12:1 15:36, Jo 19:29; of garments, etc., to put on: Mt 27:28 Mk 15:17 (Si 6:31). Metaph., like περιβάλλω, to bestow, confer (Thuc., al., Es 1:20): I Co 12:23.†

circumcision; of the rite itself : Jo 7:22-23 Ac 7:8, Ro 4:11, Ga 5:11, Phl 3:5; of the state of circumcision: Ro 2:25-28 3:1, I Co 7:19, Ga 5:6 6:15, Col 3:11; ἐν π. ὤν, Ro 4:10; by meton., π. = οἱ περιτμηθέντες, the circumcised: Ro 3:30 4:9, 12 15:8, Ga 2:7-9, Eph 2:11; οἱ ἐκ τῆς π., of Jews, Ro 4:12; of Jewish Christians, Ac 11:2, Ga 2:12, Tit 1:10; οἱ ἐκ π. πιστοί, Ac 10:45; οἱ ὄντες ἐκ π., Col 4:11 Metaph., Ro 2:29, Col 2:11, Phl 3:3.†
to turn about, turn: c. acc et, dat., Ac 26:24 (cf. FlJ, Ant., ix, 4, 4).†
to run about: c. acc loc., Mk 6:55.†
to carry about: Mk 6:55, II Co 4:10. Pass., metaph.: Eph 4:14.†
to examine on all sides, consider carefully (Aristoph.).; = ὑπερφρονέω, to have thouphts beyond, to despise (Thuc., Plut., al.; 4Mac, ll. c.) : Tit 2:15.†

round about, neighbouring (Dem., Plut., al.). In LXX and NT, as subst., ἡ π. (sc. γῆ), the region round about: Mt 14:35, Mk 1:28, Lk 4:14, 37 7:17 8:37, Ac 14:6; ἡ π. τοῦ Ἰορδάνου, Lk 3:3; by meton. for the people of the same region, Mt 3:5.†

that which is wiped off, offscouring: metaph. (assoc. with περικάθαρμα, q.v.), I Co 4:13 (and so prob., To, l.c., as EV; but v. Thayer, s.v., for the meaning expiation, ransom, in To; and cf. LS, s.v. κάθαρμα; Lft., Notes, 200 f., and on Ign., Eph., 8).†
to boast or vaunt oneself: I Co 13:4 (elsewhere. only in Antonin.; v. Abbott, Essays, 87).†
Persis: Ro 16:12.†
last year, a year ago: ἀπὸ π. (as in π. v. Deiss., BS, 221; LAE, 70), II Co 8:10 9:2.†
in trag., Ion. and late writers, winged, flying; as subst., τὸ π., a winged fowl, a bird: pl., Mt 6:26 8:20 13:4, 32, Mk 4:4, 32, Lk 8:5 9:58 12:24 13:19, Ac 10:12 11:6, Ro 1:23, Ja 3:7.†
to fly: Re 4:7 8:13 12:14 14:6 19:17 (Rec. πετάομαι, q.v.).†; πετάομαι,; false form of ποτάομαι, poët., frequentat. of πέτομαι (Aristoph., al.), Rec. for πέτομαι (q.v., cf. Veitch, s.v.)

a rock, i.e. a mass of live rock as distinct from πέτρος, a detached stone or boulder : Mt 7:24-25 27:51, 60 Mk 15:46, Lk 6:48 8:6, 13; of a hollow rock, a cave, Re 6:15-16 (of. Is 2:10, al.). Metaph., Mt 16:18 (on the meaning, v. Hort, Eccl., 16 ff., but cf. also ICC, in l), I Co 10:4; = πέτρος, Ro 9:33, I Pe 2:8 (LXX).†
Simon Peter, the Apostle: Mt 4:18 10:2, Mk 3:16, Lk 5:8, Jo 1:41, 43, al.
rock-like, rocky, stony: τὸ, τὰ π., of shallow soil with underlying rock, Mt 13:5, 20, Mk 4:5, 16.†
περισσότερον, -ως, v.s. περισσῶς
a spring, fountain : Ja 3:11, II Pe 2:17; τ. δάτων, Re 8:10 14:7 16:4; of a well fed by a spring, Jo 4:6; π. τοῦ αἵματος, of a flow of blood, Mk 5:29; metaph., Jo 4:14, Re 7:17 21:6.†
to make fast, to fix; of tents, to pitch: He 8:2 (cf. προσ-πήγνυμι).†
a rudder: Ja 3:4; pl., Ac 27:40.†
interrog., how large, how great ? (prop., of magnitude, as πόσος of quantity): in exclamations, = ἡλίκος (v. Bl., § 51, 4), Ga 6:11; of personal greatness, He 7:4.†
clay, as used by a potter: Ro 9:21 (cf. Is 29:16, al.).; - βόρβορος, wet clay, mud: Jo 9:6, 11 9:14-15 †
a leathern pouch for victuals, etc., a wallet (Deiss. thinks an alms-bag, v. LAE, 108 ff.): Mt 10:10, Mk 6:8, Lk 9:3 10:4 22:35-36.†
the forearm (Hom.).; As a measure of length, a cubit: Mt 6:27, Lk 12:25, Jo 21:8, Re 21:17.†
to lay hold of: Ac 3:7 (Theocr.).; to take, capture, apprehend: Jo 7:30, 32 7:44 8:20 10:39 11:57 21:3, 10 Ac 12:4, II Co 11:32, Re 19:20 (v. MM, xx).†
to press, press down or to­gether: Lk 6:38 (cl).; Later, to seize (v.s. πιάζω).†
in cl. (Plat),; the use of probable arguments, as opp. to demonstration (ἀπόδειξις); hence, persuasive speech: Col 2:4 (v. ICC, in l).†
to make bitter: Re 10:9; pass., Re 8:11 10:10; metaph., to embitter (LXX) : pass., seq. πρός, Col 3:19.†
bitterness; of taste (Arist., Je 15:17, al.); metaph., of temper, character, etc.: Ro 3:14 (LXX), Eph 4:31; ῥίζα πικρίας, He 12:15; χολὴ π., a malignant disposition, Ac 8:23.†
sharp, pointed.; sharp to the senses; of taste, bitter: opp. to γλυκύ, Ja 3:11; metaph., harsh, bitter: Ja 3:14
bitterly: metaph., (cf. πικρὸν δάκρυον, Hom.), ἔκλαυσε π., Mt 26:75, Lk 22:62 (v. MM, xviii, s.v. παρακολουθέω).†

trans. form in pres. and impf. of πλήθω (intrans. in these tenses), which supplies the other tense forms; to fill: c. acc, Lk 5:7; c. acc et gen., Mt 27:48; pass., Mt 22:10, Ac 19:29; of that which fills or takes possession of the mind : pass., c. gen., Lk 1:15, 41 1:67 4:28 5:26 6:11, Ac 2:4 3:10 4:8, 31 5:17 9:17 13:9, 45. Metaph. (as in LXX for מָלֵא: Ge 29:27, Jb 15:32), to complete, fulfil: pass., of prophecy, Lk 21:22; of time, Lk 1:23, 57 2:6, 21-22 (cf. ἐμ-πίμπλημι).†; πλήθω, v.s. πίμπλημι
to blow, burn.; Later, to cause to swell; mid., of parts of the body, to become swollen (LXX) : Ac 28:6 (cf. ἐμπίπρημι).†
a writing tablet: Lk 1:63.†
= πινάκιον,; a tablet: Lk 1:63, Tr., mg. (v.s. πινακίδιον).†
prop., a board, plank; hence, of various at wooden articles; a tablet; a disc, a dish: Mt 14:8, 11, Mk 6:25, 28 Lk 11:39.†

to drink: absol., Lk 2:19, Jo 4:7, al.; c. acc rei, Mt 6:26, 31 Mk 14:25, al.; of habitual use, Lk 1:15, Ro 14:21, al.; by meton., τὸ ποτήριον, I Co 10:21, al.; of the earth absorbing rain (Hdt., al.), He 6:7; spiritually, of the blood of Christ, Jo 6:53-54, 56; seq. ἐκ (of the vessel), Mt 26:27, al.; id. (of the drink; Bl., § 36, 1), Mt 26:29, Jo 4:13-14 Re 14:10, al.; ἀπό, Lk 22:18 (cf. ἀπο-, συν-πίνω; on the form πίεσαι, Lk 17:8, v. Bl., § 21, 8, and on the contr. aor. πεῖν, M, Pr., 44 f., Thackeray, Gr., 63 f.)
fatness: Ro 11:17.†

to sell: c. acc rei, Mt 13:46 (on this pf., v. Bl., § 59, 5), Ac 2:45 4:34 5:4; c. gen. (of price), Mt 26:9, Mk 14:5, Jo 12:5; c. acc pers. (of slavery), Mt 18:25; hence metaph., Ro 7:14 (cf. IV Ki 17:17, I Mac 1:15, al.).†

to fall; of descent, to fall, fall down or from: seq. ἐπί, c. acc loc., Mt 10:29, al.; εἰς, Mt 15:14, al.; ἐς μέσῳ, c. gen., Lk 8:7; παρὰ τ. ὁδόν, Mt 13:4, Mk 4:4, Lk 8:5; seq. ἀπό, Mt 15:27, al.; ἐκ, Mk 13:25, Lk 10:18, Re 8:10 9:1. Metaph.: ὁ ἥλιος, seq. ἐπί, Re 7:16; ἀχλὺς κ. σκότος, Ac 13:11; ὁ κλῆρος, Ac 1:26; ὑπὸ κρίσιν, Ja 5:12.; Of prostration,; of persons, to fall prostrate, prostrate oneself: χαμαί Jo 18:6; seq. ἐπί, c. acc, Mt 17:6, Ac 9:4; id. c. gen., Mk 9:20; πρὸς τ. πόδας, Ac 5:10, Re 1:17; πεσὼν ἐξέψυξε, Ac 5:5; of supplication, homage or worship: πρὸς (παρὰ, ἐπὶ) τ. πὸδας, Mk 5:22, Lk 8:41, Ac 10:25, al.; π. καὶ προσκυνεῖν, Re 5:14 19:4; ptcp. c. προσκυνεῖν, Mt 2:11, al.; ἐνώπιον, Re 4:10 5:8; ἐπὶ πρόσωπον, Mt 26:39, al.; of things, to fall, fall down: Mt 21:44, Lk 23:30; of falling to ruin and destruction, Mt 7:25, Ac 15:16, He 11:30; ἔπεσε (timeless aorist; M, Pr.,134), Re 18:2. Metaph.: Ro 11:11; πόθεν πέπτωκας, Re 2:5; opp. to ἑστόναι, I Co 10:12; to στήκειν, Ro 14:4; of virtues, I Co 13:8; of precepts, Lk 16:17.; συν-πίπτω (Rec. συμπ-),; to fall together, fall in, etc.: of a house (cf. MM, xxiv), Lk 6:49.†
Pisidia, a region of Asia Minor: Ac 14:24
of Pisidia: Ac 13:14.†

intrans., to have faith (in), to believe; in cl., c. acc., dat., in NT also c. prep, (on the significance of the various constructions, v. M, Pr., 67f.; Vau. on Ro 4:5; Ellic. on I Ti 1:16; Abbott, JV, 19-80): absol., Mt 24:23, 26 Mk 13:21, I Co 11:18; c. acc. rei, Ac 13:41, I Co 13:7; c. dat. pers. (to believe what one says), Mk 16:[13, 14], I Jo 4:1; τ. ψεύδει, II Th 2:11; περί . . . ὅτι, Jo 9:18; esp. and most freq. with reference to religious belief: absol., Mt 8:13, Mk 5:36, Lk 8:50, Jo 11:40, al.; seq. ὅτι, Mt 9:28, al.; c. dat. (v. supr., and cf. DB, i, 829a), Jo 3:12 5:24 6:30 8:31, Ac 16:34, Ga 3:6 (LXX), II Ti 1:12, I Jo 5:10, al.; c. prep., (expressing personal trust and reliance as distinct from mere credence or belief; v. M, Pr., l.c.; DB, i, 829b), to believe in or on: ἐν (Ps 77 (78):22, al.), Mk 1:15 (v. Swete, in l.); εἰς, Mt 18:6, Jo 2:11 (v. Westc., in l.), and freq., Ac 10:43 19:4, Ro 10:14, Ga 2:16, Phl 1:29, I Jo 5:10, I Pe 1:8; εἰς τ. ὄνομα, Jo 1:12 2:23 3:18, I Jo 5:13; ἐπί, c. acc., Mt 27:42, Ac 9:42 11:17 16:31 22:19, Ro 4:5; ἐπί, c. dat., Ro 9:33 (LXX) 10:11 (ib.), I Ti 1:16, I Pe 2:6 (LXX); ptcp. pres., οἱ π., as subst., Ac 2:44, Ro 3:22, I Co 1:21, al.; aor., Mk 16:[16], Ac 4:32; pf., Ac 19:18 21:20 (on Johannine use of the tenses of π., v. Westc, Epp. Jo., 120). Trans., to entrust: c. acc. et dat., Lk 16:11, Jo 2:24; pass., to be entrusted with: c. acc., Ro 3:2, I Co 9:17, Ga 2:7, I Th 2:4 (v. Lft., Notes, 21f.), I Ti 1:11, Tit 1:3.
having the gift of persuasion (Plat., Gorg., 455A). of persons, faithful, trusty (Plut.); of things, trustworthy, genuine: νάρδος π., Mk 14:3, Jo 12:3. †

in active sense, faith, belief, trust, confidence, in NT always of religious faith in God or Christ or spiritual things: Mt 8:10, Lk 5:20, Ac 14:9, Ro 1:8, I Co 2:5, II Co 1:24, I Ti 1:5, al.; c. gen. obj., Mk 11:22, Ac 3:16, Ro 3:22, Ga 2:16, Eph 3:12, Ja 2:1, al.; c. prep., ἐν, Ro 3:25, Ga 3:26, Eph 1:15, Col 1:24, I Ti 1:14 3:13, II Ti 1:13 3:15, II Pe 1:1; εἰς, Ac 20:21 24:24 26:18, Col 2:5, I Pe 1:21; πρός, I Th 1:8, Phm 5; ἐπί, c. acc. He 6:1; ἐν τῇ π. στήκειν (εἶναι, μένειν), I Co 16:13, I Co 13:5, I Ti 2:15; ὑπακοὴ τῆς π., Ro 1:5 16:26; ὁ ἐκ π., Ro 3:26 4:16, Ga 3:12; διὰ (τῆς) π., Ro 3:30, Ga 2:16, Phl 3:9. By meton., objectively, that which is the object or content of belief, the faith: Ac 6:7 14:22, Ga 1:23 3:23 6:10, Phl 1:26, 27 Ju 3, 20, and perh. also Ac 13:8 16:5, Ro 1:5 and 16:26 (v. supr.), I Co 16:13, Col 1:23, II Th 3:2 (Lft., Notes, 125), I Ti 1:19 3:9 4:1, 6 5:8 6:10, 12, II Ti 3:8 4:7 Tit 1:4, 13 3:15, I Pe 5:9. In passive sense, fidelity, faithfulness: Mt 23:23, Ga 5:22; ἡ π. τοῦ θεοῦ, Ro 3:3; objectively, plighted faith, a pledge of fidelity: I Ti 5:12. (On the various shades of meaning in which the word is used in NT, v. esp. ICC on Ro 1:17, pp. 31ff.; Lft., Ga., 154ff.; Stevens, Th. NT, 422, 515ff.; DB, i, 830ff.; Cremer, s.v.)

Pass., to be trusted or believed; of persons, trusty, faithful : Mt 24:45 25:21, 23 Lk 12:42, Ac 16:15, I Co 4:2 4:17 7:25, Eph 1:1 6:21, Col 1:2, 7 4:7, 9, I Ti 1:12, II Ti 2:2, He 2:17 3:2, 5, I Pe 5:12, Re 2:13 19:11; of God, I Co 1:9 10:13, II Co 1:18, I Th 5:24, II Th 3:3, He 10:23 11:11, II Ti 2:13, I Jn 1:9, I Pe 4:19; seq. ἐν, Lk 16:10-12 19:17, I Ti 3:11; ἐπί, c. acc, Mt 25:23; ἄχρι θανάτου, Re 2:10; ὁ μάρτυς ὁ π., Re 1:5; id. καὶ ἀληθινός, Re 3:14.; Of things, trustworthy, reliable, sure: Ac 13:34, I Ti 1:15 3:1 4:9, II Ti 2:11, Tit 1:9 3:8, Re 21:5 22:6.; Act., believing, trusting, relying: Ac 16:1, II Co 6:15, Ga 3:9, I Ti 4:10 5:16 6:2, Tit 1:6, Re 17:14; pl., Ac 10:45, I Ti 4:3 4:12; opp. to ἄπιστος, Jo 20:27; π. εἰς θεόν, I Pe 1:21; π. ποιεῖν, III Jn 5.; (On the difficulty of choosing in some cases between the active and the passive meaning, v. Lft., Gal., 157.) †
to make trustworthy (Thuc., III Ki 1:36), hence, to establish (I Ch 17:14). Pass. and mid., to be assured of: c. acc rei, II Ti 3:14.†

to cause to wander, lead astray. Pass., to go astray, wander: Mt 18:12-13 He 11:38, I Pe 2:25 (cf. Is 53:6). Metaph., to lead astray, deceive: c. acc pers., Mt 24:4-5, 11 24:24, Mk 13:5-6, Jo 7:12, II Ti 3:13; I Jn 1:8 Jn 2:26 Jn 3:7, Re 2:20 12:9 13:14 19:20 20:3, 8 20:10; pass., to be led astray, to err: Mt 22:29, Mk 12:24, 27, Lk 21:8, Jo 7:47, II Ti 3:13, Tit 3:3, He 5:2, II Pe 2:15, Re 18:23; τ. καρδίᾳ, He 3:10; ἀπὸ τ. ἀληθείας, Ja 5:19;μὴ πλανᾶσθε, I Co 6:9 15:33, Ga 6:7. Ja 1:16 (cf. ἀπο-πλανάω).†
a wandering. Metaph., a going astray, an error (in NT always with respect to morals or religion): Mt 27:64, Ro 1:27, Eph 4:14, I Th 2:3, II Th 2:11, Ja 5:20, II Pe 2:18 3:17 3:1-18; I Jn 4:6, Ju 11.†
= πλάνης, a wanderer: ἀστέρες π. (cl. planets), wandering stars, Ju 13 (WH, mg., -τες).†
wandering.; leading astray, deceiving: πνεύματα π., I Ti 4:1. As subst., ὁ π., a deceiver, impostor: Mt 27:63, II Co 6:8 6:1-18 II Jo 1:7.†
anything flat and broad.; a plain (poët.).; In late writers (Luc., al.), a flat stone, a tablet: II Co 3:3, He 9:4.†
that which is moulded or formed : Ro 9:20 (LXX).†
to form, mould: Ro 9:26 (LXX), I Ti 2:13.†
formed, moulded (Hes., Plat., al.).; Metaph., made up, fabricated, feigned (Hdt., Xen., al.): II Pe 2:3.†
breadth: Eph 3:18, Re 21:16; τ. π. τῆς γῆς (Hb 1:6, מֶרְחָב), Re 20:9.†
to make broad, enlarge, extend: c. acc rei, Mt 23:5. Metaph. (cf. Ps 119:32, al.), pass., ἡ καρδία, II Co 6:11; ὑμεῖς, II Co 6:13.†
what is woven or twisted (as basket-work, nets, etc.); a braiding (sc. τριχῶν, cf. I Pe 3:3) : pl., I Ti 2:9.†
to plait, twist, weave: Mt 27:29, Mk 15:17, Jo 19:2.†

Intrans.; Of persons; to abound in (Arist.); to superabound: II Co 8:15 (LXX).; Of things, to abound, superabound: Ro 5:20 6:1, II Co 4:15, Phl 4:17, II Th 1:3, II Pe 1:8.; Trans. (Nu 26:54, Ps 71:21; not cl, v. Lft., Notes, 48 f.), to make to abound: I Th 3:12 (cf. ὑπερ-πλεονάζω).†

intrans., to have more, to have an advantage (cl., c. gen. pers.).; Trans., in late writers (v. M, Pr., 65), to over­reach, defraud: c. acc pers., II Co 7:2 12:17-18; ἐν τ. πράγματιι, I Th 4:6 (v. M, Th., in l); pass., II Co 2:11 (as also in cl.; v. LS, s.v.).†
= ὁ θέλων πλέον ἔχειν (v. MM, xx),; one desirous of having more, covetous: I Co 5:10-11 6:10 Eph 5:5.†

the character and conduct of a πλεονέκτης.; advantage.; desire for advantage, grasping, aggression, cupidity, covetousness: Lk 12:15, Ro 1:29, II Co 9:5, Eph 4:19 (v. ICC, in l) Eph 5:3, Col 3:5, I Th 2:5, II Pe 2:3 2:14; pl. (v. Bl., § 32, 6), Mk 7:22.†
to sail: Lk 8:23, Ac 27:24; seq. εἰς, Ac 21:3 27:2, 6; ἐπί, Re 18:17; (cf. ἀπό-, δια-, ἐκ-, κατα-, παρα-, ὑπο-πλέω).†

a blow, stripe, wound: pl., Lk 10:30 12:48, Ac 16:23, 33, II Co 6:5 11:23; ἡ π. τ. θανάτου (RV, death-stroke), Re 13:3, 12; τ. μαχαίρας, Re 13:14.; Metaph., a calamity, plague: Re 9:18, 20 11:6 15:1, 6 15:8 16:9, 21 18:4, 8 21:9 22:18.†

a great number, a multitude; of things : ἰχθύων, Lk 5:6, Jo 21:6; φρυγάνων, Ac 28:3; ἁμαρτιίῶν, Ja 5:20, I Pe 4:8; τ. πλήθει, in multitude, He 11:12; of persons: Ac 21:22 (WH, R, om.); c. gen., Lk 2:13, Jo 5:3, Ac 5:14; π. πολύ (πολὺ π.), Mk 3:7-8; id. c. gen., Lk 6:17 23:27, Ac 14:1 17:4; Of persons, c. art., the whole number, the multitude (in Plat., Thuc., Xen., al., = δῆμος, the commons, or-opp. to δῆμος-the populace) : Ac 2:6 15:30 19:9 23:7; τ. λαοῦ, Ac 21:36; τ. πόλεως, Ac 14:4; πᾶν τὸ π., Ac 15:12; c. gen., Lk 1:10 8:37 19:37 23:1, Ac 4:32 5:16 6:2, 5 25:24.†

trans., to increase, multiply: II Co 9:10 6:14 (LXX); pass., to be increased, to multiply: Mt 24:12, Ac 6:7 7:17 9:31 12:24; c. dat. pers. (Da LXX TH 3:31(98) al.), I Pe 1:2, II Pe 1:2, Ju 2.; Intrans., to be increased, to multiply: Ac 6:1.†
a striker, brawler: I Ti 3:3, Tit 1:7 (Arist., Plut., al.).†
a flood (of sea or river) : Lk 6:48.†

introducing a clause (= ἀλλά, δέ; "it is obvious that πλήν was the regular word in the vulgar language": Bl., § 77, 13), yet, howbeit, only: Mt 11:22, 24 18:7 26:39, 64 (M, Pr., 86), Lk 6:24, 35 10:11, 14 10:20 11:41 12:31 13:33 17:1 18:8 19:27 22:21-22, 42 (WH, mg. om.) Lk 23:28, I Co 11:11, Eph 5:33, Phl 3:16 4:14, Re 2:25; π. ὅτι (Hdt., Plat., al.), except that, save that, Ac 20:23, Phl 1:18.; As prep., c. gen., except, save (cl.) : Mk 12:32, Jo 8:10, Ac 8:1 15:28 27:22.†

full, filled: Mt 14:20 15:37; c. gen. rei, Mk 8:19; λέπρας, Lk 5:12; metaph., of the soul: πνεύματος ἀγίου, Lk 4:1, Ac 6:3 7:55 11:24; πίστεως, Ac 6:5; χάριτος, ib. Ac 6:8; χ. καὶ ἀληθείας (where π. is indecl.; v. M, Pr., 50; Milligan, NTD, 65, with reff. in each), Jo 1:14; δόλου, Ac 13:10; θυμοῦ, Ac 19:28; ἔργων ἀγαθῶν, Ac 9:36.; full, complete: μισθός, II Jn 8; σῖτος (π. prob. in­decl. here; v. on Jo 1:14, supr.), Mk 4:28.†

to bring in full measure, hence, to fulfil, accomplish: Lk 1:1, II Ti 4:5 4:17.; to persuade, assure or satisfy fully (so in π.; v. Deiss., LAE, 82 f.; M, Th., 9): pass., Ro 4:21 14:5, Col 4:12 (v. Lft., in l).; to fill: Ro 15:13, L, mg. (Cl. Ro., I Co 5:4); metaph., pass., to be filled with, hence, fully bent on (Ec, l.c.).†
full assurance, confidence: I Th 1:5; τ. συνέσεως, Col 2:2; τ. ἐλπίδος, He 6:11; πίστεως, He 10:22 (cf. Lft. on Col., l.c.; M, Th., 9).†

to fill, make full, fill to the full, c. acc; of things : pass. (σαψήνη, φάραγξ), Mt 13:48, Lk 3:5 (LXX); fig., Mt 23:32; but chiefly of immaterial things: πᾶσαν χρείαν, Phl 4:19; ἦχος ἐλήρωσε τ. οἶκον, Ac 2:2; c. gen. rei (cl.), Ac 5:28; pass., seq. ἐκ, Jo 12:3 (cf. B1., § 36, 4); π. τ. καρδίαν, Jo 16:6, Ac 5:3; metaph., of the all-pervading activity of Christ, Eph 4:10; mid., Eph 1:23; of persons: to fill with, cause to abound in : c. gen. rei (cl.), Ac 2:28 (LXX), Ro 15:13; pass., to be filled with, abound in: Eph 3:19, Phl 4:18; c. gen. rei (cl.), Ac 13:52, Ro 15:14, II Ti 1:4; c. dat. (Æsch., al.), Lk 2:40 (c. gen., T), Ro 1:29, II Co 7:4; c. acc (so in π., v. MM, xx), Phl 1:11, Col 1:9; seq. ἐν, Eph 5:18, Col 2:10.; to complete; to complete, fulfil: of number, Re 6:11, WH, tat.; of time (MM, xx), Mk 1:15, Lk 21:24, Jo 7:8, Ac 7:23, 30 9:23 24:27; ἐυδοκίαν, II Th 1:11; τ. χαράν, Phl 2:2; pass., Jo 3:29 15:11 16:24 17:13, I Jn 1:4, II Jn 12; τ. ἔργα, Re 3:2; ἡ ὑπακυή, II Co 10:6; τ. πάσχα, Lk 22:16; to execute, accomplish, carry out to the full: Mt 3:15, Lk 7:1 9:31, Ac 12:25 13:25 14:26 19:21, Ro 8:4 13:8 15:19, Ga 5:14, Col 1:25 4:17, Re 6:11, T, WH, R, mg.; of sayings, prophecies, etc., to bring to pass, fulfil: Mt 1:22 2:15, 17 2:23 4:14 5:17 8:17 12:17 13:35 21:4 26:54, 56 27:9, Mk 14:49 15:28 (WH, R, txt. om.), Lk 1:20 4:21 24:44, Jo 12:38 13:18 15:25 17:12 18:9, 32 19:24, 36, Ac 1:16 3:18 13:27, Ja 2:23 (cf. Lft., Col., 255 ff.).†

the result of the action involved in πληρόω (Lft., Col., 255 if.; AR, Eph., 255 ff.), hence,; in passive sense, that which has been completed, complement, plenitude, fullness (in Xen., Luc., Polyb., al., of a ship's crew or cargo, and by meton. of the ship itself) : Jo 1:16, Ro 11:12, 25 15:29, I Co 10:26 (LXX) Eph 1:23 (AR, 42 ff.) Eph 3:19 (AR. 87 ff.) Eph 4:13, Col 1:19 2:9; of time, Ga 4:4, Eph 1:10; κοφίνων (σφυρίδων) πληρώματα, basketfuls, Mk 6:43 8:20.; In active sense (= πλήρωσις, as freq. in words of these formations, cf. κτίσις, and v. MM, xx); that which fills up (but v. Lft., l.c.) : Mt 9:16, Mk 2:21; a filling up, completing, fulfilment: Ro 13:10.†

near, close by, neighbouring. As adv., πλησίον = πέλας, near: c. gen., Jo 4:5; c. art., ὁ π., one's neigh­bour; Lk 10:29, 36, Ac 7:27, Ro 13:10 15:2, Eph 4:25, Ja 4:12; ἀγαπήσεις τὸν π. σου ὡς σεαυτόν (Le 19:18, LXX), Mt 5:43 19:19 22:39, Mk 12:31, 33, Lk 10:27, Ro 13:9, Ga 5:14, Ja 2:8 (on the various senses of ὁ π. in OT, NT, v. DB, iii, 511; DCC, ii, 240 f.).†
a filling up, satiety: πρὸς π. σαρκός (RV, against the indulgence of the flesh; but ICC, in l, for the full satisfaction of the flesh, op. cit., 276 ff.), Col 2:23.†
to strike, smite: pass., Re 8:12 (cf. ἐπι, πλήσσω).†
a boat: Mk 3:9, Lk 5:2 (πλοῖα, WH, txt., R), Jo 6:22-23 (πλοῖα, WH) Jo 6:24 21:8.†
a boat, also (= obsol. ναῦς) a ship: Mt 4:21-22, and freq. in Gosp. and Ac, Ja 3:4, Re 8:9 18:19.

rich, wealthy: Mt 27:57, Lk 12:16 14:12 16:1, 19 18:23 19:2. Substantively, ὁ π., Lk 16:21-22, Ja 1:10-11; oἱ π., Lk 6:24 21:1, I Ti 6:17, Ja 2:6 5:1, Re 6:15 13:16; anarth., a rich man, Mt 19:23-24, Mk 10:25 12:41, Lk 18:25. Metaph., of God, ἐν ἐλέει (= cl., c. gen., dat.), Eph 2:4; of Christ, II Co 8:9; of Christians, Re 2:9 3:17; ἐν πίστει, Ja 2:5.†
richly, abundantly: Col 3:16, I Ti 6:17. Tit 3:6, II Pe 1:11.†

to be rich, aor., to become rich: Lk 1:53, I Ti 6:9; seq. ἀπό (Si 11:18), Re 18:15; ἐκ, Re 18:3, 19; ἐν (= cl., c. gen., dat., acc, cf. πλούσιος), I Ti 6:18. Metaph., π. εἰς θεόν, Lk 12:21; of God, εἰς πάντας, Ro 10:12; aor., I became rich, I Co 4:8, II Co 8:9, Re 3:18; pf., I have become rich, Re 3:17.†
to make rich, enrich: c. acc pers., pass., II Co 9:11. Metaph., of spiritual riches, c. acc: pers., II Co 6:10; seq. ἐν, pass., I Co 1:5.†

riches, wealth: of external possessions, Mt 13:22, Mk 4:19, Lk 8:14, I Ti 6:17, Ja 5:2, Re 18:16; of moral and spiritual conceptions, Ro 2:4 9:23 11:12, 33, II Co 8:2, Eph 1:7, 18 2:7 3:8, 16 Phl 4:19, Col 1:27 2:2, He 11:26, Re 5:12.†
to wash (inanimate objects, esp. clothing): τ. δίκτυα, Lk 5:2. Fig., τ. στολάς, Re 7:14 22:14 (cf. Ps 51:4, 9 and v.s. ἀπο-πλύνω).†

of air in motion; wind: Jo 3:8; pl., He 1:7 (LXX); breath: π. ζωῆς, Re 11:11; π. τοῦ στόματος, fig., II Th 2:8 (cf. Ps 32 (33)6). Of the vital principle, the spirit (Arist., Polyb., al.): Lk 8:55, Jo 19:30, Ac 7:59, al.; opp. to σάρξ, Mt 26:41, Mk 14:38, I Co 5:5, al.; to σῶμα, Ro 8:10, I Co 6:17 7:34, I Pe 4:6; to ψυχή, Phl 1:27, He 4:12; τὸ π. καὶ ἡ ψ. καὶ τ. σῶμα, I Th 5:23 (M, Th., in l.); dat., τῷ π., in spirit, Mk 2:8 8:12, Jo 11:33 13:21, Ac 18:25, Ro 12:11, I Co 7:34, I Pe 3:18, al.; of the human spirit of Christ, Ro 1:4, I Ti 3:16. spirit, i.e. frame of mind, disposition, influence: Lk 1:17, Ro 8:15, I Co 4:21, Gal 6:1, Eph 2:2, II Ti 1:7, I Jo 4:6, al. An incorporeal being, a spirit: Lk 24:37, 39 Ac 23:8; π. ὁ θεός, God is spirit, Jo 4:24; πατὴρ τῶν π., He 12:9; of disembodied human beings, He 12:23, I Pe 3:19 (ICC, in l.; DB, iii, 795); of angels. He 1:14; of demons or evil spirits, Mt 8:16, Mk 9:20, Lk 9:39, al.; π. πύθυωνα, Ac 16:16; πνεύματα δαιμονίων, Re 16:14; π. δαιμονίου ἀκαθάρτου, Lk 4:33; π. ἀσθενείας (Bl., §35, 5), Lk 13:11; π. ἀκάθαρτον, Mt 10:1, Mk 1:23, Lk 4:36, Ac 5:16; π. ἄλαλον (καὶ κωφόν), Mk 9:17, 25; πονηρόν, Lk 7:21, Ac 19:12, al. Of the Holy Spirit, π. ἅγιον, τὸ ἅ. π., τὸ π. τὸ ἅ. τὸ π., π. (the article as a rule being used when the Spirit is regarded as a Person or a Divine Power, and omitted when the reference is to an operation, influence or gift of the Spirit; v. WM, 151:5; Bl., §46, 7): anarth., Mt 1:18 3:11, 16 4:1, Mk 1:8 (Swete, in l.), ib.10, Lk 1:15, Jo 7:39, Ac 19:2, Ro 5:5, I Co 2:4, al.; c. art., Mt 4:1 12:31, 32 Mk 1:10 3:29, Lk 2:26, Jo 7:36 14:26, Ac 4:31 5:3, Ro 8:16, al.; (τὸ) π. (τοῦ) θεοῦ, Mt 3:16, Ro 8:9, Eph 3:16, I Jo 4:2, al.; τὸ π. τ. πατρός, Mt 10:20; π. θεοῦ ζῶντος, II Co 3:3; (τὸ) π. τοῦ κυρίου, Lk 4:18, Ac 5:9 8:39; τὸ π. Ἰησοῦ, Ac 16:7; Χριστοῦ, Ro 8:9; Ἰησοῦ Χριστοῦ, Phl 1:19; τὸ π. τ. ἀληθείας, Jo 15:26 16:13, I Jo 4:6; λείγει (μαρτυρεῖ) τὸ π. (τὸ ἅγιον), Ac 21:11 28:25, I Ti 4:1, He 3:7 10:15, Re 14:13; seq. τ. ἐκκλησίαις, Re 2:7, 11 17, 29, 3:6, 12, 22; ἐν τ. π., Lk 2:27; κατὰ πνεῦμα, Ro 8:4, 5; ἐξ ὕδατος καὶ π., Jo 3:5, διὰ πνεύματος αἰωνίου, He 9:14; ἐν ἁγιασμῷ πνεύματος, II Th 2:13, I Pe 1:2; ἓν π., I Co 12:13, Eph 2:18 4:4; ὁ δὲ κύριος τὸ π. ἐστιν, II Co 3:17; of that which is effected or governed by the Spirit, opp. to γράμμα, Ro 2:29 7:6, II Co 3:6.

of or caused by the wind, air or breath (Arist., al.).; spiritual (opp. to σωματικός, Plut.); of created beings : τὰ π. (RV, the spiritual hosts), Eph 6:12; of that which is related to the human spirit, opp. to ψυχικός, I Co 15:44 15:46; of that which belongs to or is actuated by the Divine Spirit; of persons : I Co 2:15 3:1 14:37, Ga 6:1; οἶκος π., fig., I Pe 2:5; of things : Ro 1:11 7:14, I Co 2:13 10:3-4 12:1 14:1, Eph 1:3 5:19, Col 1:9 3:16, I Pe 2:5; opp. to τ. σαρκικά, Ro 15:27, I Co 9:11.†
spiritually; by the aid of the Holy Spirit: I Co 2:13 (WH, mg.), I Co 2:14; in a spiritual sense : Re 11:8.†
to breathe, blow: of the wind, Mt 7:25, 27, Lk 12:55, Jo 3:8 6:18, Re 7:1; ηῇ πνεούσῃ (sc. αὔρᾳ), Ac 27:40 (cf. ἐκ-, ἐν-, ὑπο-πνέω).†; αὔρα, a breeze : τ. πνεούσῇ (sc. αὔρᾳ), Ac 27:40.†
to choke: c. acc, Mt 13:7 (WH, mg.); impf. (coniative), Mt 18:28; of drowning, pass., Mk 5:13 (cf. ἀπο-, ἐπι-, συν-πνίγω).†
a blowing, blast, wind: Ac 2:2.; a breathing, breath: Ac 17:25 (Ge 2:7, al.).†
reaching to the feet. of a garment (sc. χιτών, cf. Ex, Ez, ll. c.; Xen., al.), Re 1:13 (for -η, LT7 read -ην; v. M, Pr., 49).†

whence; of place: Mt 15:33, Lk 13:25, 27, Jo 3:8 6:5 8:14 9:29-30 19:9, Re 7:13; metaph., of condition, Re 2:5; of origin: Mt 13:27, 54 13:56 21:25, Mk 6:2, Lk 20:7, Jo 2:9, Ja 4:1; of parentage, Jo 7:27-28; of cause: Mk 8:4 12:37, Lk 1:43, Jo 1:49 4:11.†

to make, produce, create, cause: c. acc. rei, Mt 17:4, Mk 9:5, Jo 9:11, Ac 9:39, Ro 9:20, al.; of God as Creator (c. acc. pers. also), Mt 19:4, Mk 10:6, Lk 11:40, Ac 4:24, He 1:2, al.; like Heb. עשׂה, absol. = ἐργάζομαι, to work, Mt 20:12 (cf. Ru 2:19; so AV, but v. infr.), Re 13:5, R, mg. (but v. infr.); σκάνδαλα, Ro 16:17; εἰρεήνην, Eph 2:15, Ja 3:18; ἐπίστασιν, Ac 24:12; συστροφήν, Ac 23:12; c. acc. rei et dat. pers., Lk 1:68, Ac 15:3; with nouns expressing action or its accomplishment, forming a periphr. for the cogn. verb: ὁδόν π. (cl. ὁ ποιεῖσθαι), to go on, advance, Mk 2:23; πόλεμον, Re 11:7, al.; ἐκδίκησιν, Lk 18:7, 8; ἐνέδραν, Ac 25:3; κρίσιν, Jo 5:27, Ju 15; ἔργα, Jo 5:36, al.; (σημεῖα), Jo 2:23 and freq., Ac 2:22, al.; so also mid. ποιεῖσθαι: μονήν, Jo 14:23; πορείαν, Lk 13:22; κοινωνίαν, Ro 15:26; of food, to make ready, prepare: δεῖπνον, Mk 6:21, al.; δοχήν, Lk 5:29 14:13; γάμους, Mt 22:2; of time, to spend (cl.): ὥραν, Mt 20:12, RV (but v. supr. and cf. McN, in l.); μῆνας, Re 13:5, R, txt. (cf. Swete, in l.; but v. supr.); ἐνιαυτόν, Ja 4:13; c. acc. seq. ἐκ, Jo 2:15, al.; c. acc. et acc. pred., Mt 3:3 12:16, Mk 1:3 3:12, Jo 5:11, al.; c. adv., καλῶς, Mk 7:37; ἑορτὴν π. (Dem., Ex 23:16, al.), Ac 18:21, Rec.; πάσχα, Mt 26:18; to make or offer a sacrifice (Plat., Xen., al.; Jb 42:8, III Ki 11:33; so some understand τοῦτο ποιεῖτε, Lk 22:19, but v. Abbott, Essays, 110ff.); seq. ἵνα (WM, 422f.; M, Pr., 228), Jo 11:37, Col 4:16, Re 3:9. to do, perform, carry out, execute: absol., c. adv., καλῶς π., Mt 12:12, I Co 7:37, 38 Ja 2:19; id. seq. ptcp. (cl.; v. M, Pr., 228), Ac 10:33, Phl 4:14, II Pe 1:19, III Jo 6; οὕτως, Mt 24:46, Lk 9:15, al.; ὡς (καθώς), Mt 1:24 2:16, al.; ὁμοίως, Lk 3:11; ὡσαύτως, Mt 20:5; c. ptcp., ἀγνοῶν ἐποίησα, I Ti 1:13; c. acc. rei: τί interrog., Mt 12:3, Mk 2:25, Lk 6:2, al.; τοῦτο, Mt 13:28, Mk 5:32, Lk 22:19 (WH om.; v. supr., ref. to Abbott, Essays), Ro 7:20, al.; with nouns expressing command or regulation: τ. νόμον (not as in cl., to make a law), Jo 7:19, Ga 5:3 (cf. in LXX, Jos 22:5, I Ch 22:12, al.); τ. ἐντολάς, Mt 5:19; similarly with other nouns expressing conduct: τ. δικαιοσύνην, Mt 6:1, al.; τ. ἀλήθειαν, Jo 3:21, al., etc.; c. dupl. acc., Mt 27:22, Mk 15:12; c. acc. rei et dat. pers. (commod., incomm.; rare in cl.), Mt 7:12, Mk 5:19, 20 Lk 1:49, Jo 9:26, al.
that which is made or done, a work: Ro 1:20, Eph 2:10.†
a making (Hdt., Thuc., al.).; a doing (Si 19:18 51:19): Ja 1:25.†
in cl.,; a maker, author.; Esp., a poet: Ac 17:28. Later,; a doer: τ. νόμου, Ro 2:13, Ja 4:11 (1Mac, l.c.); ἔργου, Ja 1:25; λόγου, ib. Ja 1:22-23.†
many-coloured, variegated. Metaph., various, manifold: Mt 4:24, Mk 1:34, Lk 4:40, II Ti 3:6, Tit 3:3, He 2:4 13:9, Ja 1:2, I Pe 1:6 4:10.†
to act as shepherd, tend flocks: Lk 17:7; c. acc, ποιμνην, I Co 9:7. Metaph., to tend, shepherd, govern: c. acc, Mt 2:6 (LXX), Jo 21:16, Ac 20:28, I Pe 5:2, Ju 12, Re 2:27 7:17 12:5 19:15.†

a shepherd: Mt 9:36 25:32 26:31 (LXX), Mk 6:34 14:27, Lk 2:8, 15 2:18, 20 Jo 10:2, 12 Metaph., of Christ; Jo 10:11, 14 10:16 He 13:20, I Pe 2:25; of Christian pastors, Eph 4:11 (cf. Hom., Il, i, 263, ποιμένα λαῶν).†
a flock, prop., of sheep: Mt 26:31, Lk 2:8, I Co 9:7. Metaph., of Christ's followers, Jo 10:16.†
a flock, prop., of sheep. Metaph., of Christians: Lk 12:32, Ac 20:23, 28, I Pe 5:3; τ. θεοῦ, ib. I Pe 5:2.†

of what quality or sort: absol., n. pl., Lk 24:19; c. subst.; prop., in direct questions: Mt 19:18 21:23 22:36 24:42, Mk 11:28 12:28, Lk 6:32-34, Jo 10:32, Ac 4:7 7:49, Ro 3:27, I Co 15:35, Ja 4:14 (but v.s. ποία), I Pe 2:20; in indirect questions = ὁποῖος : Mt 21:24, 27 24:43, Mk 11:29, 33, Lk 12:39 20:2, 8, Jo 12:33 18:32 21:19 Ac 23:34, I Pe 1:11, Re 3:3; ποῖας (sc. ὁδοῦ), Lk 5:19.†
to make war, fight: Re 12:7 b Re 19:11; seq. μετά (II Ki 21:15 and v. M, Pr., 106, 247), Re 2:16 12:7 a Re 13:4 17:14; hyperb., of private quarrels, Ja 4:2.†
