war: Mt 24:6, Mk 13:7, Lk 14:31 21:9, He 11:34; π. ποιεῖν, seq. μετά, c. gen. (cf. πολεμέω), Re 11:7 12:17 13:7 19:19.; = μάχη, a fight, battle: I Co 14:8, Re 9:7, 9 12:7 16:14 20:8; hyperb., of private quarrels (cf. πολεμέω), Ja 4:1.†

a city: Mt 2:23, Mk 1:45, Lk 4:29, Jo 4:8, al. mult.; opp. to κῶμαι (κ. καὶ ἀγροί), Mt 9:35 10:11, Mk 6:56, Lk 8:1 13:22; c. nom. propr. in appos. (cl.), Ac 11:5 16:14; c. id. in gen. appos. (BL, §35, 5), Ac 8:5, II Pe 2:6; gen., of the region, Lk 1:26 4:31, Jo 4:5; of the inhabitants, Mt 10:5, 23 Lk 23:51, Ac 19:35, II Co 11:32; c. gen. pers., of one's residence or native place, Mt 22:7, Lk 2:4, 11 4:29 10:11, Jo 1:45, Ac 16:20, Re 16:9; of Jerusalem: ἡ ἁγία π., Mt 4:5 27:53, Re 11:2; ἡ ἠγαπημένη, Re 20:19; π. τοῦ μεγάλου, Mt 5 ̈35 (cf. Ps 47 (48):2); of the heavenly city in the Apocalyptic visions, Re 3:12 21:2, 10 14ff. 22:14, 19. By meton., of the inhabitants of a city: Mt 8:34 12:25 21:10, Mk 1:33, Ac 14:21 21:30.
= πολίαρχος (Pind., Eur.),; the ruler of a city, a politarch: Ac 17:6, 8 (v. MM, xx).†
citizenship: Ac 22:28 (3 Mac, ll. c., Hdt., Xen., a1.).; government, administration (Aristoph., Dem., al.).; a commonwealth: Eph 2:12.†
an act of administration.; a form of government.; = πολιτεία,; citizenship : Phl 3:20 (R, txt.); community, commonwealth : Phi, l.c. (R, mg.; for exx, v. MM, xx).†
to be a citizen, live as a citizen: metaph., of conduct as based on heavenly citizenship, Ac 23:1, Phl 1:27.†
a citizen: c. gen. loc., Lk 15:15, Ac 21:39.; a fellow-citizen: c. gen. pers., Lk 19:14, He 8:11 (LXX).†
often: Mt 17:15, al
= πολλαπλάσιος,; many times more: Mt 19:29, Lk 18:30.†; ἑπταπλασίων, -ον,; gen., -ονος,; sevenfold: Lk 18:30 (WH, mg., for πολλαπλ- WH, txt., RV; v. WH, Notes, 62).†
much speaking, loquacity: Mt 6:7.†
in many parts or portions: He 1:1 (Plut., al.).†
much variegated, of greatly differing colours (Eur.).; manifold: Eph 3:10.†

as adj., much, many, great, of number, space, degree, value, time, etc.: ἀριθμός, Ac 11:21; ὄχλος, Mk 5:24; θερισμός, Mt 9:37; χόρτος, Jo 6:10; χρόνος, Mt 25:19; γογγυσμός, Jo 7:12; πόνος, Col 4:13; δόξα, Mt 24:30; σιγή, Ac 21:40; pl., προφῆται, Mt 13:17; ὄχλοι, Mt 4:25; δαιμόνια, Mk 1:34; δυνάμεις, Mt 7:22, As subst., pl. masc, πολλοί, many (persons): Mt 7:22, Mk 2:2, al.; c. gen. partit., Mt 3:7, Lk 1:16, al.; seq. ἐκ, Jo 7:31, Ac 17:12; c. art., οἱ π., the many, Mt 24:12, Ro 12:5, I Co 10:17, 33 II Co 2:17; opp. to ὁ εἶς (Lft., Notes, 291), Ro 5:15, 19; neut. pl., πολλά: Mt 13:3, Mk 5:26, al.; acc. with adverbial force, Mk 1:45, Ro 16:6 (Deiss., LAE, 317), I Co 16:12, Ja 3:2, al.; neut. sing., πολύ: Lk 12:48; adverbially, Mk 12:27, al.; πολλοῦ (gen. pret.), Mt 26:9; c. compar. (Bl., §44, 5), π. σπουδαιότερον, II Co 8:22; πολλῷ πλείους, Jo 4:41. Compar., πλείων, neut., πλεῖον and πλέον (v. WH, App., 151), pl., πλείονες, -ας, -α, contr., πλείους, -ω (cf. Mayser, 69), more, greater; as adj.: Jo 15:2, Ac 18:2o, He 3:3; seq. παρά, He 11:4 (cf. Westc, in l. Was ΠΛΙΟΝΑ here a primitive error for ΗΔΙΟΝΑ ?); pi., Ac 13:31, al.; c. gen. compar., Mt 21:36; c. num. (ἤ of comp. omitted), Ac 4:22 24:11, al. As subst., οἱ π., the greater number: Ac 10:32 27:12, I Co 10:5 15:6; also (Bl., §44, 3) others, more, the more: II Co 2:6 4:15, Phl 1:14; πλείονα, Lk 11:53; πλειον, πλέον, Mt 20:10, II Ti 3:9; c. gen. comp., Mk 12:43, Lk 21:3; π. Ἰωνᾶ ὧδε, Mt 12:41; adverbially, Ac 4:17 20:9 24:4. As adv., πλεῖον: seq. ἤ, Lk 9:13; c. gen. comp., Mt 5:20; πλείω: c. num., Mt 26:53. Superl., πλεῖστος, -η, -ον, prop., most: Mt 11:20 21:8; adverbially, τὸ π., I Co 14:27; elative (M, Pr., 79), very great: ὄχλος π., Mk 4:1.
very pitiful: Ja 5:11.†
very costly, very precious, of great value: Mk 14:3, I Ti 2:9; metaph., I Pe 3:4.†
much revered (Menand.).; very costly, very precious: Mt 13:46 26:7 (βαρύτιμος, WH), Jo 12:3; comparat., I Pe 1:7.†
in many ways or manners: He 1:1 (Philo).†
late form of Att.. πῶμα,; drink: I Co 10:4, He 9:10.†
iniquity, wickedness: Mt 22:18, Lk 11:39, Ro 1:29, Eph 6:12; pl. (v. Bl., § 32, 6; WM, 220; Swete, Mk., 153), Mk 7:22, Ac 3:26; κακία καὶ π., I Co 5:8.†

of persons, oppressed by toils (Hes.); of things, toilsome, painful (καιρός, Si 51:12): Eph 5:16 6:13 Re 16:2. bad, worthless; in physical sense: καρπός, Mt 7:17-18; in ethical sense, bad, evil, wicked; of persons: Mt 7:11 12:34-35 18:32 25:26, Lk 6:45 11:13 19:22, Ac 17:5, II Th 3:2, II Ti 3:13; γενεά, Mt 12:39, 45 16:4, Lk 11:29; πνεῦμια, Mt 12:45, Lk 7:21 8:2 11:26, Ac 19:12-13, 15-16; as subst., οἱ π., opp. to δίκαιοι, Mt 13:49; to ἀγαθοί, Mt 5:45 22:10; οἱ ἀχάριστοι καὶ π., Lk 6:35; sing., ὁ π., Mt 5:39, I Co 5:13; id. esp. of Satan, the evil one, Mt 5:37 6:13 (v. Lft., Notes, 125 ff.; but cf. McN, in l) Mt 13:19, 38, Lk 11:4 (WH, R, om.), Jo 17:15, Eph 6:16, II Th 3:3 (Lft., Notes, l.c.), I Jn 2:13-14 Jn 3:12 Jn 5:18-19; of things: Mt 5:11 12:35 15:19, Lk 6:22, 45, Jo 3:19 7:7, Ac 18:14 25:18, Ga 1:4, Col 1:21, I Ti 6:4, II Ti 4:18, He 3:12 10:22, Ja 2:4 4:16, I Jn 3:12, II Jn 11, III Jn 10; ὀφθαλμός (q.v.), Mt 6:23 20:15, Mk 7:22, Lk 11:34; as subst., neut., τὸ π., Ac 28:21, I Th 5:22; opp. to ἀγαθόν, Lk 6:45, Ro 12:9; pl., Mt 9:4, Mk 7:23, Lk 3:19. †
labour, toil: Col 4:13; The consequence of toil, distress, suffering, pain (Xen., al., LXX): Re 16:10-11 21:4.†
Pontic, of Pontus: Ac 18:2
Pontius, the prænomen of Pilate (v.s. Πειλᾶτος), Mt 27:2 (Rec., WH, mg.), Lk 3:1, Ac 4:27, I Ti 6:13.†
Pontus, a region of Asia Minor, bordering on the πόντος Εὔξεινος: Ac 2:9, I Pe 1:1.†
(Latin), Publius: Ac 28:7-8.†
a journey: Lk 13:22.; a going: metaph. ("the rich man perishes while he is still on the move," Hort., in l), Ja 1:11.†

in cl. (the act. becomes obsolete in late Gk.; v. M, Pr., 162), to cause to go over, carry, convey. Mid. (always in LXX and NT), ־ομαι, to go, proceed, go on one's way: c. acc., ὁδόν, Ac 8:39; seq. ἐκεῖθεν, Mt 19:15; ἐντεῦθεν, Lk 13:31; ἀπό, Mt 25:41, Lk 4:42; εἰς, Mt 2:20, Mk 16:12, Lk 1:39, Jo 7:35, al; εἰς εἰρήνην (cf. I Ki 1:17). Lk 7:50; ἐν εἰρήνῃ, Ac 16:36; ἐπί, c. acc., Mt 22:9, Ac 25:12, al; ἕως, Ac 23:23; οὗ, Lk 24:28, I Co 16:6; πρός, c. acc. pers., Mt 25:9, Lk 11:5, al.; κατὰ τ. ὁδόν, Ac 8:36; διά, c. gen., Mt 12:1, Mk 9:30; c. inf., Lk 2:3, Jo 14:2; σύν, Lk 7:6, al.; ἵνα, Jo 11:11; absol., Mt 2:9, Lk 7:8, Jo 4:50, Ac 5:20, al.; ptcp., πορευθείς (on the pass. form of the aor., v. M, Pr., 161f.), redundant (as in Heb. and Aram.; V. M, Pr., 231; Dalman, Words, 21), Mt 2:8, Lk 7:22, al. Metaph. (cf. Soph., O.T., 884; Xen., Cyr., 2, 2, 24, al), like οἴχομαι in cl., as euphemism for θνήσκω (so הלךְ in Ge 15:2); Lk 22:22 and perh. also 13:33 (v. Field, Notes, 66); in ethical sense (De 19:9, Ps 14:2, al; cf. M, Pr., 112; Kennedy, Sources, 107): seq. ἐν, Lk 1:6, I Pe 4:3, II Pe 2:19; κατά, c. acc., II Pe 3:3, Ju 16, 18; c. dat. (Bl, §38, 3), Ac 9:31 14:16, Ju 11; of disciples or partisans ( Jg 2:12, III Ki 11:10, Si 46:10): seq. ὀπίσω, c. gen. pers., Lk 21:8 (cf. δια-, εἰς-, (-μαι), ἐκ- (-μαι), ἐν- (-μαι), ἐπι- (-μαι), παρα- (-μαι), προ-, προσ- (-μαι), συν- (-μαι)).
to destroy, ravage: Ac 9:21, Ga 1:13, 23.†
a providing.; a means of gain: I Ti 6:5-6 (Polyb., al.).†
Porcius, prænomen of Porcius Festus (v.s. Φῆστος): Ac 24:27.†

fornication: Ac 15:20, 29 21:25, I Co 5:1 6:13 6:18, II Co 12:21, Ga 5:19, Eph 5:3, Col 3:5, I Th 4:3 (Lft., Notes, 53), Re 9:21; pl. (v. WM, 220; Bl., § 32, 6), I Co 7:2; disting. from μοιχεία, Mt 15:19, Mk 7:21; = μοιχεία (Amos 8:17 Si 23:23, al.), Mt 5:32 19:9. Metaph. (of idolatry: De 23:2, Ho 1:2): Jo 8:41 (Westc., in l), and so perh. (Thayer-Grimm, s.v.; but v. Swete, in 11.), Re 2:21 14:18 17:2, 4 18:3 19:2.†

to prostitute the body for hire.; to commit fornication: Mk 10:19 (WH, mg), I Co 6:18 10:8, Re 2:14, 20. Metaph. (as in LXX: I Ch 5:25, Je 3:6, Ho 9:1, al.), of idolatry (but v. Swete, Ap., 180 f.), Re 17:2 18:3, 9 (cf. ἐκ- πορνεύω).†
a prostitute, harlot: Mt 21:31-32, Lk 15:30, I Co 6:15-16 He 11:31, Ja 2:25. Metaph. (v. Swete, Ap., 180 f.), of Babylon (i.e. Rome): Re 17:1, 5 17:15-16 19:2.†
a male prostitute (Xen., al.).; a fornicator: I Co 5:9-11 6:9, Eph 5:5, I Ti 1:10, He 12:15 13:4, Re 21:8 22:15.†
far off: Mt 15:8, Mk 7:6 (LXX), Lk 14:32; comparat., πορρώτερον (-ρω, T), Lk 24:28.†
from afar: Lk 17:12, He 11:13.†
the purple fish (cf. I Mac 4:23).; purple dye.; Later, = πορφυρίς, a purple gar­ment: Mk 15:17, 20, Lk 16:19, Re 18:12.†
purple: Jo 19:2, 5; as subst., πορφυροῦν (sc. ἱμάτιον), Re 17:4 18:6.†
a seller of purple fabrics: Ac 16:14.†
interrog. num. adv.,; how often: Mt 18:21 23:37, Lk 13:34.†
prop., drinking: Ro 14:17, Col 2:16 (v. Lft.; ICC, in l).; = πόμα, drink: Jo 6:55 (cf. βρῶσις).†

adj. of number, magnitude, degree, etc.,; how much, how great, how many: Mt 6:23, II Co 7:11; of time, Mk 9:21; neut., absol., Lk 16:5, 7; dat., πόσῳ, adverbially, how much, Mt 12:12; id. seq. μᾶλλον, Mt 7:11 10:25, Lk 11:13 12:24, 28, Ro 11:12, 24, Phm 16, He 9:14; π. χείρονος τιμωρίας, He 10:29; pl., Mt 15:34 16:9-10 27:13, Mk 6:38 8:5, 19-20 15:4, Lk 15:17, Ac 21:20.†
carried away by a stream:; Re 12:15 (for two exx. in π., v. MM, xxi).†
(= ποδαπός) from what country?; In late writers, = ποῖος, of what sort?: Mt 8:27, Mk 13:1, Lk 1:29 7:39, II Pe 3:11, I Jn 3:1.†

enclitic particle,; once, formerly, sometime: of the past, Jo 9:13 Ro 7:9 11:30, Ga 1:13, 23 2:6 (Lft., in l), Eph 2:2-3, 11 2:13 5:8, Col 1:21 3:7, I Th 2:5, Tit 3:3, Phm 11, I Pe 2:10 3:5 3:20; ἤδη ποτέ, now at length, Phl 4:10; of the fut., Lk 22:32; εἴ πως ἤδη ποτέ, if sometime soon at length, Ro 1:10.; ever: after a neg., Eph 5:29, II Pe 1:10 1:21; in a question, τίς π., I Co 9:7, He 1:5, 13.†

interrog. adv. of time,; when?: Mt 25:37-39, 44 Lk 21:7, Jo 6:25; ἕως π., how long: Mt 17:17, Mk 9:19, Lk 9:41, Jo 10:24, Re 6:10. In indir. questions, = ὁπότε, Mt 24:3, Mk 13:4, 33 13:35, Lk 12:36 17:20 (v. Bl., § 25, 4).†
which of two. Neut., adverbially, πότερον, whether: Jo 7:17.†

a wine cup: Mt 23:25-26 26:27, Mk 7:4 14:23, Lk 11:39 22:17, 20 a (WH, R, mg., cm.), I Co 11:25, Re 17:4; πίνειν ἐκ τοῦ π., I Co 11:28; c. gen. rei, Mt 10:42, Mk 9:41; τ. εὐλογίας, I Co 10:16; by meton., of the contents of the cup, Lk 22:20 b (WH, R, mg., cm.), I Co 11:25-26; c. gen. pers., I Co 10:21 11:27. Metaph., of experience of divine providence; of prosperity (Ps 16:5, al.); of adversity (Ps 11:6, Is 51:17, al.): of the sufferings of Christ, Mt 20:22-23 26:39 10:38-39 14:36, Lk 22:42, Jo 18:11; of divine punishment, Re 14:10 16:19 18:6.†

to give to drink: c. acc pers., Mt 25:35, 37 25:42 27:48, Mk 15:36, Lk 13:15, Ro 12:20; c. dupl. acc, Mt 10:42, Mk 9:41; fig., γάλα, I Co 3:2; ἐκ τ. οἴνου Re 14:8; of plants, to water (Xen., Strab., al.; Ge 13:10), fig., I Co 3:6-8 Metaph. (cf. Is 29:10 Si 15:3), of the Spirit, I Co 12:13.†
Puteoli (mod. Pozzuoli), a city on the Bay of Naples: Ac 28:13.†
a drinking bout, carousal: I Pe 4:3.†
enclitic particle,; anywhere, somewhere: He 2:6 4:4.; in some degree, perhaps, about: Ac 27:29 (T, μήπου), Ro 4:19; δή που (T, δήπου), surely: He 2:16.†

prop., where?: Mt 2:2 26:17, Mk 14:12, 14, Lk 17:17, 37 22:9, 11, Jo 1:39 7:11 8:10, 19 9:12 11:34; ποῦ (ἐστιν), indicating that the subject in question is not to be found, Lk 8:25, Ro 3:27, I Co 1:20 12:17 12:19 15:55, Ga 4:15, II Pe 3:4; ποῦ φανεῖται, I Pe 4:18.; = ὅπου (WM, 640; B1., § 50, 5): c. indic., Mt 2:4, Mk 15:47, Jo 1:40 11:57 20:2, 13 20:15 Re 2:13; c. subjc., Mt 8:20, Lk 9:58 12:17.; In colloq. (as in Eng.) = ποῖ, whither: in direct questions, Jo 7:35 9:12 13:36 16:5; in indir. quest., Jo 3:8 8:14 12:35 14:5, He 11:8, I Jn 2:11.†
Pudens: II Ti 4:21.†

a foot, both of men and beasts: Mt 4:6 (LXX), Mk 9:45, Lk 1:79, Jo 11:44, Ac 7:5, al.; ὑπο τοὺς π., Ro 16:20, I Co 15:25 15:27 Eph 1:22, He 2:8; ὑποκάτω τῶν π., Mt 22:44 (LXX); πρὸς (παρὰ) τοὺς π., Mk 5:22, Lk 8:41, al.; fig., Mt 15:30, Lk 10:39, Ac 5:2, al.; ἔμπροσθεν τῶν π., Re 3:9 19:10, al.; ἐπὶ τοὺς π., Ac 10:25. By meton., of a person in motion (Ps 119:101): Lk 1:79, Ac 5:9, Ro 3:15 10:15, He 12:13

that which has been done, a deed, act: Lk 1:1, Ac 5:4, II Co 7:11, He 6:18.; That which is being done (like Lat. res), hence, a thing, matter, affair: Mt 18:19, Ro 16:2, I Th 4:6 (v. M, Th., in l), He 10:1 11:1, Ja 3:16; in forensic sense (as freq. in π., v. Deiss., BS, 233), a law-suit: I Co 6:1.†
to busy oneself.; to be engaged in business, esp. to trade: Lk 19:13 (cf. δια-πραγματεύομαι).†
careful application, hard work.; business, occupation: pl., II Ti 2:4.†

headquarters in a Roman camp,; The palace or official residence of the Governor of a province: Mt 27:27, Mk 15:16 (v. Swete, in l), Jo 18:28, 33 19:9; τ. π. τ. Ἡρώδου, Ac 23:35.; the Prætorian Guard: Phl 1:13 (v. Lft., in l; ICC, 51 f.).†
(poët.) one who does or accomplishes.; In Athens, one who exacts payment, a collector; hence, generally (freq. in π., v. Deiss., BS, 154), a court officer: Lk 12:58.†

a doing, deed, act: Mt 16:27; pl., π. ἀποσπτόλων, Ac, title,; in late writers especially of wicked deeds or practices (freq. in Polyb.): Lk 23:51; p1., Ro 8:13, Col 3:9; with ref. to magic (v. BS, 3235), Ac 19:18.; an acting, action, business, function: Ro 12:4.†
a garden-bed; metaph., of ranks or orderly groups of persons: Mk 6:40.†

= Lat agere, as ποιέω (q.v.) = facere,; to do, practise, be engaged in: Ac 19:19, 36, I Co 9:17; τ. ἴδια π., to mind one's own business (τὰ ἑαυτοῦ, Soph., Plat.), I Th 4:11; intrans., to act, Ac 17:7.; to achieve, effect, accomplish, perform: Ac 26:20, 26 Ro 7:15 9:11, II Co 5:10, Phl 4:9; νόμον (ICC, in l), Ro 2:25; of unworthy acts (for WH. usually ποιέω in cl.), to commit, do: Lk 22:23 23:41, Jo 3:20 5:29, Ac 3:17 5:35 16:28 25:11, 25 26:9, 31, Ro 1:32 (ICC, in l), Ro 2:1-3 7:19 13:4, I Co 5:2, II Co 12:21, Ga 5:21.; to transact, manage, hence, of payment, to exact (cl.): Lk 3:13 19:23.; Reflexively, of state or condition, to do or fare Æsch., Hdt., al.): Eph 6:21; εὖ π. (v. M, Pr., 228 f.), Ac 15:29.†
gentle, meek: Mt 5:5 11:29 21:5 (LXX) I Pe 3:4.†
gentleness, meekness: I Co 4:21, II Co 10:1, Ga 5:23 6:1, Eph 4:2, Col 3:12 (v. Lft., in l), 2Ti_2:25, Tit 3:2, Ja 1:21 3:13, I Pe 3:15.†; SIN.: ἐπιεικία, q.v

to be clearly seen.; to resemble.; to be fitting or becoming, to suit: c. dat., He 7:26, I Ti 2:10, Tit 2:1; impers., c. dat., Eph 5:3; id. seq. inf., He 2:10; πρέπον ἐστίν, c. dat. pers. et inf., Mt 3:15; c. acc et inf., I Co 11:13 (v. Bl., § 72, 5).†
age, seniority.; rank, dignity.; an embassy; by meton., of the am­bassadors, embassy: Lk 14:32 19:14.†
to be the elder, to take precedence.; to be an ambassador (v.s. πρεσβύτης): II Co 5:20, Eph 6:20.†

an old man.; Compar.,; πρεσβύτερος, -α, -ον,; of age, elder: ὁ νἱὸς ὁ π., Lk 15:25; as subst., opp. to νεανίσκοι, Ac 2:17; to νεώτερος, I Ti 5:1-2; of the religious leaders of the past, Mt 15:2, Mk 7:3, 5, He 11:2 (= οἱ πατέρες, He 1:1).; Of dignity, rank or office (as found in π. and Inscr. of civil and religious offices, including priesthood, in Asia Minor and in Egypt; v. Deiss., BS, 154 ff., 233 If.; LAE, 373); among Jews: Mt 16:21 26:47, 57 27:3, 12 27:20, 41 28:12, Mk 8:31 11:27 14:43, 53 15:1, Lk 7:3 9:22 20:1 22:52, Jo 8:9, Ac 4:5, 8 4:23 6:12 23:14 24:1; τ. Ἰουνδαίων, Ac 25:15; τ. λαοῦ, Mt 21:23 26:3 27:1; among Christians: Ac 11:30 14:23 15:2, 4 15:6, 22-23 16:4 21:18, I Ti 5:17 5:19, Tit 1:5, II Jn 1, III Jn 1, I Pe 5:1 5:5; τ. ἐκκλησίας, Ac 20:17, Ja 5:14; in the visions of the Apocalypse: Re 4:4, 10 5:5-6, 8 5:11, 14 7:11, 13 11:16 14:3 19:4.
a body of elders, presbytery: of the Sanhedrin (cf. συνέδριον), Lk 22:66, Ac 22:5; of Christian presbyters, I Ti 4:14.†
an old man: Lk 1:18, Tit 2:2, Phm 9 (R, txt., but v. infr.).; As in LXX, also = πρεσβευτής, an am­bassador: Phm 9 (R, mg., v. Lft. and ICC, in l).†
an aged woman: Tit 2:3.†
headlong, prone: Ac 1:18.†
to saw, saw asunder (= π. δίχα, Thuc., iv, 100): pass, He 11:37 (cf. δια-πρίω).†

as adv. of time, before, formerly (cl.; III Mac 5:28 Mac 6:4 Mac 6:31); As conic. (cl.), before; after a positive sentence, c. acc et inf.: Mt 26:34, 75, Mk 14:72, Lk 22:61, Jo 4:49 8:58 (where D. om. γενέσθαι and π. becomes prep. c. gen.; v. Bl., § 69, 7) Jo 14:29, Ac 2:20 (LXX), WH, txt.; πρὶν ἤ (not such good Attic in this construction; v. Bl., l.c.), Mt 1:18 Mk 14:30, Ac 2:20, WH, mg., Ac 7:2; after a negative sentence, πρὶν ἤ: a. subjc. (seq. ἄν, M, Pr., 169), Lk 2:26; c. optat., Ac 25:16.†

before; of place: Ac 12:6, 14 14:13, Ja 5:9; π. προσώπου (= Heb. פָּנִים, De 3:18, Ma 3:1, al.; Bl., § 40, 9), Mt 11:10, Mk 1:2, Lk 1:76 7:27 9:52 10:1, Ac 14:13; of time: Mt 8:29 24:38, Lk 11:38 21:12, Jo 11:55 13:1 17:24, Ac 5:36 21:38, I Co 2:7 4:5, Eph 1:4, Col 1:17, II Ti 1:9 4:21, Tit 1:2, He 11:5, I Pe 1:20, Ju 25; π. ἐτῶν δεκατεσσάρων, fourteen years ago, II Co 12:2; π. προσώπου (v. supr.), Ac 13:24; c. gen. pers., Mt 5:12, Jo 5:7 10:8, Ro 16:7, Ga 1:17; c. gen. art. inf. (= πρίν; M, Pr., 100; Bl., § 69, 7), Mt 6:8 Lk 2:21 22:15, Jo 1:49 13:19 17:5, Ac 23:15, Ga 2:12 3:23; as in late writers (resembling a Latin idiom but indepen­dent of it; B1., § 40, 5; M, Pr., 100 f.; of. Am II Mac 15:36, and for other exx., Soph., Lex., s.v.), πρὸ ἓξ ἡμέρας τοῦ πάσχα, on the sixth day before the Passover, Jo 12:1; of preference: π. πάντων, Ja 5:12, I Pe 4:8; in compos.,; c. subst., of position before: προαύλιον, πρόδρομος; priority of rank or order, προπάτωρ; anticipation, πρό γνωσις, πρό νοια; c. adj., intensity, πρόδηλος; c. verb., of place, προάγω, προβαίνω; of preference, προαιρέομαι.†

prop. trans., to lead on, lead forth or forward: c. acc pers., Ac 16:30 17:5; of bringing forth to trial, Ac 12:6 (WH, txt., προσάγ-); seq. ἐπί, c. gen. pers., Ac 25:26.; Intrans. (Plat., Polyb., and later writers; v. Bl., § 53, 1; MM, xxi); to lead the way, I Ti 1:18 (R, mg.), hence, to go before, precede: Lk 18:39; opp. to ἀκολουθέω, Mk 11:9; seq. εἰς, Mt 14:22, Mk 6:45, I Ti 5:24, He 7:18; c. acc pers., Mt 2:9 21:9, Mk 10:32; seq. εἰς, Mt 21:31 26:32 28:7, Mk 14:28 16:7; to go on, advance (Si 20:27): II Jn 9.†
to bring forth or forward. Most freq. in mid., to take by choice, prefer, propose: II Co 9:7.†
to accuse or charge beforehand: Ro 3:9 (not elsewhere) .†
to hear beforehand: Col 1:5 (v. Lft., in l).†
to sin before: II Co 12:21 13:2.†
a porch, vestibule: Mk 14:68.†
to go forwards, go on, advance: Mt 4:21, Mk 1:19. Metaph., of age (Ge 18:11, al., Lys., Diod., al.), ἐν τ. ἡμέραις, Lk 1:7, 18 2:36.†
to throw before.; to put forward: c. acc, Ac 19:33; of trees, to put forth, produce (sc. φύλλα), Lk 21:30.†
of sheep: ἡ π. (sc. πύλη, v. supr.), the sheep-gate, Jo 5:2.†
dimin. of πρόβατον (used as a term of endearment, v. El., § 27, 4), a little sheep: Jo 21:16-17 (πρόβατα, WH, mg.).†

in Hom., Hdt., cattle, esp. of small cattle, sheep and goats.; In NT, as in Attic writers generally (cf. MM, xxi), a sheep: Mt 7:15, Mk 6:34, al.; πρόβατα σφαγῆς, Ro 8:36 (LXX). Metaph. (in cl. of timidity, stupidity or idleness), of the followers of a leader or master, esp. of those who are subject to the care of the Good Shepherd: Mt 10:6 15:24 26:31 (LXX) Mk 14:27 (LXX), Jo 10:7-8, 15-16 10:26-27 21:16-17 (WH txt., προβάτια), He 13:20; opp. to ἐρίφια, Mt 25:33.
to lead forward, lead on; metaph., to induce, incite, urge: Mt 14:8.†
to foresee: mid., He 11:40 (v. Bl., § 24, 55, 1).†
to happen before: pf. pass. ptcp., Ro 3:25.†
to know beforehand, foreknow: II Pe 3:17; c. acc pers., Ac 26:5; of the Divine foreknowledge, Ro 8:29 11:2, I Pe 1:20.†
fore­knowledge: Ac 2:23, I Pe 1:2.†
born before.; As subst., in pl., οἱ π., ancestors, forefathers: II Ti 1:3; of living parents (so Plat.), I Ti 5:4.†

to write before: Ro 15:4, Eph 3:3, Ju 4.; to write in public, placard, proclaim (Dem., Plut., al.): Ga 3:1 (Lft., in l).; = ζωγραφέω, to pourtray, depict: Ga, l.c. (Syr. Pesh., Chrys.; Field, Notes, 189; CGT, in l).†
evident beforehand.; clearly evident: I Ti 5:24-25 He 7:14.†
to give before, give first: Ro 11:35 (Jb 41:2 (11) LXX, al.).; to betray (4Mac, l.c.).†
a betrayer, traitor: Lk 6:16, Ac 7:52, II Ti 3:4.†
running forward, going in advance. As subst., ὁ π., an advance guard, forerunner: He 6:20.†
to foresee: Ac 2:31 (προϊδών; WH, προιδών), Ga 3:8.†

to say before: Ga 1:9, I Th 4:6 (on the form -αμεν, v. WH, App., 164), He 4:7; seq. ὅτι, II Co 7:3 13:2, Ga 5:21; of prophecy, Mt 24:25, Mk 13:23, Ac 1:16, Ro 9:29, II Pe 3:2, Ju 17.; to proclaim publicly, declare openly or plainly (cl.): so R, mg., in II Co 13:2, Ga 5:21, I Th 4:6 (cf. προλέγω; but v. supr., and cf. M, Th., 38).†
to hope before: seq. ἐν, Eph 1:12.†
to begin before: II Co 8:6; c. acc, τὸ θέλειν, II Co 8:10 (not elsewhere).†
to announce before. Mid., to promise before: c. acc rei, Ro 1:2, II Co 9:5 (Dio. Cass.).†

to go forward, go on, advance: seq. μικρόν, Mt 26:39 and Mk 14:35 (WH, mg., προσελθών): ῥύμην μίαν (cf. Plat., Rep., i, 328e), Ac 12:10.; Of relative position, to go before, precede: c. gen. (cl.; Jth, l.c.); c. acc pers. (not cl.), Lk 22:47 (c. gen., Rec.); seq. ἐνώπιον, Lk 1:17 (cf. Ge 33:3).; Of time, to go before or in advance: Ac 20:5, 13 (WH, mg., R, mg.), II Co 9:5; c. acc pers. (= cl. φθάνω), Mk 6:33.†
to prepare before: c. acc rei, Ro 9:23 (οἱς for ἅ by attraction), Eph 2:10.†
to announce glad tidings beforehand: Ga 3:8.†

Trans., to hold before; mid., to hold something before oneself (Hdt.), hence, metaph., to excuse oneself: Ro 3:9, R, mg. (but v. Field, Notes, 152 f.; Lft., Notes, 266 f.; ICC and Vau., in l).; Intrans.; to project; in running, to have the start, hence, metaph., to excel: pass., Ro, l.c., R, txt. (v. reff. supr.).†

to go before as leader (in cl., c. gen., dat.): Ro 12:10 (Chrys., Vg., al.; v. ICC, in l).; In a sense not elsewhere found, ἀλλήλους προηγούμενοι = ἀ. ἡγούμενοι ὑπερέχοντας: Ro, l.c. (ICC, cf. I Th 5:13, Phl 2:3 and EV "preferring").†

a setting forth (Plat., Plut., al.): οἱ ἄρτοι τῆς π. (cf. LXX, ll. c., elsewhere ἄρτοι ἐνώπιοι, Ex 25:29; οἱ ἄ. τοῦ προσώπου, Ne 10:33), Mt 12:4, Mk 2:26, Lk 6:4; ἡ π. τῶν ἄρτων, He 9:2.; a purpose (Mist., Polyb., al.; 2Mac, l.c.): Ac 11:23 27:13, Ro 8:28 9:11, Eph 1:11 3:11, II Ti 1:9 3:10.†
appointed before­hand. In Attic law, as subst. (so always in cl.), ἡ π. (sc. ἡμέρα), a day appointed beforehand, a previously appointed time: Ga 4:2.†
eagerness, willingness, readiness: Ac 17:11, II Co 8:11-12 8:19 9:2.†
willing, ready: Mt 26:41, Mk 14:38; neut., τὸ π. = ἡ προθυμία (Thuc., al., III Mac 5:26), οὕτως τὸ κατ' ἐμὲ (= cl. τὸ ἐμὸν) π., Ro 1:15 (but v. ICC, in l).†
eagerly, readily, with a ready mind: I Pe 5:2.†
= the more common πρώιος (q.v.),; early: of rain (as most freq. in LXX), Ja 5:7.†

trans. in fut., 1 aor., and mid. 1 aor., to put before, set over (Plat., al.).; Intrans., in pf., plpf., 2 aor. and mid. Pres. and impf.; to preside, rule, govern: Ro 12:8, I Ti 5:17; c. gen., I Th 5:12, I Ti 3:4-5 3:12; to direct, maintain: c. gen. rei, καλῶν ἔργων, Tit 3:8, 14 (on R, mg., profess honest occupations, v. CGT, in l; Field, Notes, 223 f.).†
to call forth.; Most freq. in mid.,; to challenge; hence, to provoke: Ga 5:26; to invite (2Mac, l.c.).†
to announce beforehand: c. acc et inf., Ac 3:18; seq. περί, Ac 7:52.†
to make ready beforehand: II Co 9:5.†
used as pass. of προτίθημι; to be set before one, to be set forth: He 6:18 12:1-2, Ju 7.; to present oneself, be present: II Co 8:12 (v. Mey., in l).†
to proclaim by herald.; Of one who acts as a herald, to proclaim: Ac 13:24.†
progress (prop., on a journey, then generally): Phl 1:12, 25, I Ti 4:15 (condemned by Atticists, v. Rutherford, NPhr., 158).†

to cut forward a way, for­ward, advance, in cl. trans. with neut. adj., as οὐδὲν π., τὰ πολλὰ π. In late writers (Polyb., al.), wholly intrans., to advance, progress: of time, Ro 13:12. Metaph., Lk 2:52, Ga 1:14, II Ti 2:16 3:9 3:13.†
pre-judging, prejudice: I Ti 5:21 (v. Cremer, 378).†
to establish or confirm beforehand: Ga 3:17.†

to take beforehand: c. acc, I Co 11:21 (but v. infr.).; to be beforehand, anticipate (in cl., c. acc, gen. or dat.): c. inf. (= cl. φθάνω, v. Bl., § 69, 4; Swete, in l), Mk 14:8.; to overtake, surprise: pass., Ga 6:1 (on the virtual disappearance of the temporal force of the preposi­tion in this compound here and perhaps also in 1Co, l.c., v. MM, xxi).†
to tell or say before­hand: II Co 13:2, Ga 5:21, I Th 3:4 (R, txt.; cf. προεῖπον, but v. infr.).; to declare, tell plainly: 2Co, Ga, 1Th, ll. c. (R, mg.; v. MM, xxi, and cf. Isa, l.c.).†
to protest beforehand (cf. μαρτύρομαι, and V. Hort, in l): I Pe 1:11 (elsewhere only in Theod. Met., xiv/AD.).†
to premeditate: Lk 21:14.†
to be anxious beforehand: Mk 13:11.†
to foresee.; to provide (RV, take thought for): c. acc rei, καλά, Ro 12:17 (-ούμενοι), II Co 8:21 (-οῦμεν).; to provide for (seq. περί, Wis, l.c.): c. gen. pers., I Ti 5:8 (-εῖ, WH, mg., -εῖται).†
foresight, forethought: Ac 24:3; π. ποιεῖσθαι, c. gen. (Dem., 546, 6), make provision for, show care for: Ro 13:14.†
to see before (as to place or time): c. acc, Ac 21:29. Mid., c. acc, seq. ἐνώπιόν μου, Ac 2:25 (LXX).†
to predetermine, foreordain: c. acc, Ro 8:30; id. et inf., Ac 4:28; id. seq. εἰς, I Co 2:7, Eph 1:5; c. dupl. acc, Ro 8:26; pass., Eph 1:11.†
to suffer before: I Th 2:2.†
to send before, send forth.; to set forward on a journey, escort: c. acc pers., I Co 16:11, Tit 3:13, III Jn 6; seq. εἰς, Ac 20:38; οὗ, I Co 16:6; ἕως, Ac 21:5; pass., Ac 15:3, Ro 15:24, II Co 1:16.†
falling forwards, headlong. Metaph., precipitate, rash, reck­less: of persons, II Ti 3:4; of things, Ac 19:36.†
to make to go before. Pass. and mid., to go before: Lk 1:76, Ac 7:40 (LXX),†

I. C. gen., of motion from a place, from the side of, hence metaph., in the interests of, Ac 27:34 (cf. Page, in l.). II. C. dat., of local proximity, hard by, near, at: Mk 5:11, Lk 19:37, Jo 18:16 20:11, 12 Re 1:13. C. acc., of motion or direction towards a place or object, to, towards. Of place, after verbs of motion or of speaking and other words with the idea of direction: ἔρχομαι, ἀναβαίνω, πορεύομαι, λέγω, ἐπιστολή, etc., Mt 3:14, Mk 6:51, Lk 11:5, Jo 2:3, Ac 9:2, al. mult.; metaph., of mental direction, hostile or otherwise, Lk 23:12, Jo 6:52, II Co 7:4, Eph 6:12, Col 3:13, al.; of the issue or end, Lk 14:32, Jo 11:4, al.; of purpose, Mt 26:12, Ro 3:26, I Co 6:5, al.; πρὸς τό, c. inf., denoting purpose (cf. M, Pr., 218, 220; Lft., Notes, 131), Mt 5:28, Mk 13:22, Eph 6:11, I Th 2:9, al.; of close proximity, at, by, with: Mt 3:10, Mk 11:4, Lk 4:11, Ac 3:2, al.; after εἶναι, Mt 13:56, Mk 6:3, Jo 1:1, al. 2. Of time, towards (Plat., Xen., LXX: Ge 8:11, al.): Lk 24:29; for: πρὸς καιρόν, Lk 8:13, I Co 7:5; πρὸς ὥραν, Jo 5:35, al.; πρὸς ὀλίγον, Ja 4:14. Of relation toward, with: Ro 5:1, II Co 1:12, Col 4:5, I Th 4:12, al.; with regard to: Mt 19:8, Mk 12:12, Ro 8:31, al.; pertaining to, to: Mt 27:4, Jo 21:22, Ro 15:17, He 2:17 5:1; according to: Lk 12:47, II Co 5:10, Ga 2:14, Eph 3:4 4:14; in comparison with: Ro 8:18. In composition: towards (προσέρχομαι), to (προσάγω), against (προσκόπτω), besides (προσδαπανάω) .
the day before the Sabbath: Mk 15:42 (L, Tr., txt., πρὸς σ.).†
to address, greet, salute; hence, to call by name, address, style: c. dupl. acc, pass., He 5:10.†

trans., to bring or lead: c. acc et dat., Ac 16:20; metaph., τ. θεῷ, I Pe 3:18; seq. ὧδε, Lk 9:41; pass., c. dat., Mt 18:24 (προσηνέχθη, T); in forensic sense, to summon: Ac 12:6 (προαγαγεῖν, T, WH, mg., R).; Intrans., to draw near, approach (Jos 3:9, Je 26:3 (Je 46:3), al.): c. dat., Ac 27:27 (WH, προσαχεῖν).†
to approach: v.l. for προσαχέω, Ac 27:27 L.†
a bringing to.; approach, access (v. Lft., Notes, 284; MM, xxi): Ro 5:2, Eph 2:18 3:12 (but v. Ellic., Eph., 59 f., where the transitive sense "introduction " is advocated).†
to ask besides.; to continue asking; hence, to importune, beg, ask alms: Jo 9:8.†
a beggar: Mk 10:46, Jo 9:8.†
to go up besides.; to go up higher: Lk 14:10.†
to spend besides: Lk 8:43 (WH, R, mg., om.).†
to fill up by adding to, to supply fully: II Co 9:12 11:9.†

to lay on or offer besides; mid.,; to lay on oneself in addition, undertake besides; c. gen. pers., of giving or obtaining information, to consult, communicate: Ga 1:16 2:6 (Lft., in l; cf. ἀνα-τίθημι)
to threaten further: Ac 4:21.†
Doric for προσηχέω; to resound: of land perceived by the roar of the surf, Ac 27:27 (WH, mg., cf. προσάγω).†
to spend besides: c. acc, Lk 10:35.†
to want further, need in addition: Ac 17:25.†

to receive to oneself, receive favourably, admit, accept: c. acc pers., Lk 15:2, Ro 16:2, Phl 2:29; c. acc rei, Ac 24:15 (R, mg.), He 10:34 11:35.; to expect, look for, wait for: c. acc pers., Lk 12:36; c. acc rei, Mk 15:43, Lk 2:25, 38 23:51, Ac 23:21, Tit 2:13, Ju 21 (cf. δέχομαι).†
to await, expect: Mt 24:50, Lk 3:15 12:46, Ac 27:33 28:6; c. acc pers., Mt 11:3, Lk 1:21 7:19-20 8:40 Ac 10:24; c. acc rei, II Pe 3:12-14; c. acc et inf., Ac 28:6; c. inf., Ac 3:5.†
expectation: c. gen. obj., Lk 21:26; c. gen. subjc., Ac 12:11.†
to permit further: Ac 27:7.†
trans., to bring near (Luc.).; Intrans., to approach: c. dat., Mk 2:4 (WH, προσενέγκαι).†
to sit near.; to attend regularly: c. dat., I Co 9:13, Rec. (v.s. παρεδρεύω).†; παρ-εδρεύω; to sit constantly beside, attend constantly (cf. MM, xix): τ. θυσιαστηρίω, I Co 9:13.†
to work or do service besides (Hdt., Plut.).; to gain besides, by working or trading: Lk 19:16 (Xen.).†

to approach, draw near: absol., Mt 4:11, Lk 9:42, al.; c. infin., Mt 24:1, al.; c. dat. loc., He 12:18, 22; dat. pers., Mt 5:1, and freq., Jo 12:21, al.; ptcp., προσελθών, c. indic., Mt 8:2, and freq., Mk 1:31, Lk 7:14, al.; π. αὐτῷ, c. indic., Mt 4:3, Mk 6:35,; Metaph.,; of approaching God: absol. (Le 21:17, De 21:5, al.), He 10:1, 22; τ. θεῷ, He 7:25 11:6; τ. θρόνῳ τ. χάριτος, He 4:16; πρὸς Χριστόν, I Pe 2:4; in sense not found elsewhere (Field, Notes, 211), to consent to: ὑγιαίνουσι λόγοις, I Ti 6:3

prayer to God: Mt 17:21 (WH, R, txt., om.) Mt 21:22, Mk 9:29, Lk 22:45, Ac 3:1 6:4 10:31, Ro 12:12, I Co 7:5, Col 4:2; pl., Ac 2:42 10:4, Ro 1:10, Eph 1:16 Col 4:12, I Th 1:2, Phm 4 22, I Pe 3:7 4:7, Re 5:8 8:3-4; οἶκος προσευχῆς, Mt 21:13, Mk 11:17, Lk 19:46 (LXX); π. καὶ δέησις, Eph 6:18, Phl 4:6; pl., I Ti 2:1 5:5; ἡ π. τοῦ θεοῦ, prayer to God (ef. Wi 16:28), Lk 6:12; πρὸς τ. θεόν, seq. ὑπέρ, Ac 12:5; pl., Ro 15:30; Hebraistically (B1., § 38, 3), προσευχῇ προσεύχεσθαι, Ja 5:17 (EV, prayed fervently).; a place of prayer: of a synagogue (III Mac 7:20, v.l.; v. Charles, APOT, i, 173; for other exx., v. Kennedy, Sources, 114); of a place in the open (FlJ, Ant., xiv, 10, 23), Ac 16:13, 16.†

to turn to, bring to (freq. ναῦν, expressed or understood, to bring to port, land; Hdt., al.).; τ. νοῦν, seq. dat., to turn one's mind to, attend to; in Xen. and later writers with νοῦν omitted (El., § 53, 1; 81, 1): Ac 8:6 16:14, He 2:1, II Pe 1:19; in sense of caring or providing for, Ac 20:28; π. ἑαυτῷ, to give heed to oneself (M, Pr., 157; cf. Ge 24:6, Ex 10:28, al.): Lk 17:3 21:34, Ac 5:35; id. seq. ἀπό (M, Pr., 102; B1., § 34, 11; 40, 3; v.s. βλέπω), Lk 12:1; (without dat.) Mt 7:15 10:17 16:6, 11-12, Lk 20:46 (cf. Si 6:13, al.); seq. μή, c. inf. (M, Pr., 193; Bl., § 69, 4), Mt 6:1.; to attach or devote oneself to: c. dat. pers., Ac 8:10-11, I Ti 4:1; c. dat. rei, I Ti 1:4 3:8 4:13 6:3 T (-ερχ-, WH, R), Tit 1:14, He 7:13.†
to nail to: c. acc et dat., fig., Col 2:14.†
one who has arrived, a stranger.; Of converts to Judaism, a proselyte (v. DB, s.v.): Mt 23:15, Ac 2:10 6:5 13:43.†
in season.; for a season, temporary, transient: II Co 4:18, He 11:25; of plants, short-lived: Mt 13:21, Mk 4:17.†

to call to. Mid., to call to oneself (v. M, Pr., 157): c. acc pers., Mt 10:1, Mk 3:13 6:7, Lk 7:19, Ac 5:40, Ja 5:14, al. Metaph., of the Divine call: Ac 2:39; c. inf., Ac 16:10 (v. Bl., § 69, 4); seq. εἰς, Ac 13:2.†
to attend constantly, continue stedfastly, adhere to, wait on: c. dat. pers., Mk 3:9, Ac 8:13 10:7; c. dat. rei, Ac 1:14 2:42 6:4, Ro 12:12, Col 4:2; seq. ἐν, Ac 2:46; εἰς, Ro 13:6.†
stedfastness, persever­ance: Eph 6:18.†
a pillow, cushion: Mk 4:38.†
to allot to, assign to by lot; pass. (but perh. as nid., EV, consorted with, so Syr.): Ac 17:4 (for exx., v, Cremer, 749).†
LTr., mg., for πρόσκλισις, q.v
to make to lean against.; to make the scale incline one way or another; hence, metaph., of persons, to incline (sc. ἑαυτόν) towards: pass., Ac 5:36.†
inclination partiality: I Ti 5:21.†
to glue to; pass., reflexive, to stick to, cleave to (Plat.): metaph. (c. dat., Jos 23:8, Si 6:34 al.), seq. πρός, Mk 10:7 (R, txt.), Eph 5:31 (LXX).†

a stumble, stumbling: λίθος προσκόμματος (= נֶגֶף אֶבֶן, Isa, l.c.), fig., Ro 9:32-33, I Pe 2:8 (LXX); = προσκοπή, an occasion of stumbling, a stumbling-block: metaph., Ro 14:13, 20, I Co 8:9 (Plut.).†
an occasion of stumbling, offence: II Co 6:3.†

trans., to strike (e.g. hand or foot) against: c. acc seq. πρός, fig., Mt 4:6, Lk 4:11, (LXX); Intrans., to stumble: absol. (To 11:9, Pr 3:23), Jo 11:9-10; of wind, to rush against, beat upon: c. dat, Mt 7:27. Metaph., in late writers,; to offend (Polyb.); to take offence at, stumble at: seq. ἐν, Ro 14:21; c. dat., τ. λόγῳ, I Pe 2:8; τ. λίθῳ τ. προσκόμματος, Ro 9:32.†
to roll up, roll to: c. acc et dat., Mt 27:60; acc seq. ἐπί, Mk 15:46.†

to make obeisance, do reverence to, worship; prop. (as in cl., of the gods: Hdt., Æsch., Plat., al.), of God, Christ and supra-mundane beings: absol., Jo 4:20 12:20, Ac 8:27 24:11, He 11:21 (Westc., in l), Re 11:1; πίπτειν καὶ π., Re 5:14; c. dat. (of the significance of this constr. as com­pared with the usual cl., c. acc, v. Abbott, JG, 78 f.; JV, 133 ff.), Jo 4:21, 23, Ac 7:43, I Co 14:25, He 1:6, Re 4:10 7:11 11:16 13:4, 15 14:7 16:2 19:4, 10 19:20 22:8-9; c. acc (v. supr.), Mt 4:10, Lk 4:8 24:52 (WH, R, mg., om.), Jo 4:22, 24, Re 9:20 13:4, 8 13:12 14:9, 11 20:4; Seq. ἐπώπιον, Lk 4:7, Re 15:4; as in cl., of homage to human superiors (cf. MM, xxi): absol., Mt 20:20, Ac 10:25; c. dat. (v. supr.), Mt 2:2, 8 8:2 9:18 14:33 15:25 18:26 28:9, Mk 15:19, Jo 9:38; πεσὼν., Mt 2:11 4:9; ἐνώπιον τ. ποδῶν, Re 3:9; c. acc, Mk 5:6 (dat. T).†
a worshipper: Jo 4:23.†
to speak to: Ac 28:20; c. dat. pers., Ac 13:43.†

to take in addition.; to take to oneself, take, receive; in NT always mid., -ομαι; of things: of food, c. acc, Ac 27:33; c. gen. part., Ac 27:36; of persons: c. acc, Mt 16:22, Mk 8:32 (v. Swete, in l), Ac 17:5 18:26 28:2, Ro 14:1, 3 15:7, Phm 17.†
an assumption (Plat.).; a receiving (cf. προσλαμβάνω): Ro 11:15,†

to wait longer, continue, remain still: Ac 18:18; seq. ἐν, I Ti 1:3.; C. dat., to remain with: Mt 15:32, Mk 8:32. Metaph., to remain attached to, cleave unto, abide in: τ. κυρίῳ, Ac 11:23 (R, txt.; ἐν τ. κ., R, mg., v. supr.); τ. χάριτι τ. θεοῦ, Ac 13:43; τ. δεήσεσιν, I Ti 5:5.†
to bring a ship to anchor at; usually in mid., to come to anchor near, and so pass. in late writers (Ael., Dio Cass.): Mk 6:53.†
to owe besides: Phm 19 (v. Field, Notes, 225).†
to be angry with: c. dat., He 3:10 (LXX), He 3:17.†
Mt 7:25 L (v.s. προσπίπτω).†
hungry: Ac 10:10.†
to fasten to: absol., to crucify, Ac 2:23.†

to fall upon, strike against: c. dat., of wind, Mt 7:25.; to fall down at one's feet, fall prostrate before: absol., seq. πρός, Mk 7:25; c. dat. pers., Mk 3:11 5:33, Lk 8:28, Ac 16:29; τ. γόνασιν, Lk 5:8.†
to make over to, add or attach to. Mid., to take to oneself, claim; hence, to pretend; c. inf. (cf. Xen., Anab., iv, 3, 20), to make as if: Lk 24:28.†
to come near, approach: c. dat. pers., Mk 10:35.†
to break against, dash against; trans. (παιδία πέτραις, FlJ, Ant., ix, 4, 6); intrans., c. dat.: Lk 6:48-49 (cf. προσπίπτω).†
c. acc pers., to place at, to attach to.; to give a command, enjoin, appoint: Lk 5:14; c. dat. pers., Mt 1:24; c. acc rei, Mt 8:4, Mk 1:44; c. acc et inf., Ac 10:48; pass., Ac 10:33 17:26.†
a patroness, protectress: Ro 16:2.†

to put to.; to add, join to, give in addition: c. acc seq. ἐπί, Mt 6:27, Lk 3:20 12:25; ἐπὶ τὸ αὐτό, Ac 2:47; c. acc et dat., Lk 17:5, He 12:19 (v. MM, xxi); pass., absol., Ac 2:41, Ga 3:19; c. dat., Mt 6:33, Mk 4:24, Lk 12:31, Ac 5:14 11:24; προσιτέθη πρὸς τ. πατέρας (cf. Ge 26:8, Jg 2:10, al.), Ac 13:36; c. inf., of repeating or continuing the action signified by the following verb, as in Heb. idiom (Ge 4:2 8:12, al.; cf. WM, § 54, 5; Lft. on Clem., 1Co., xii; but v. also M, Pr., 67, 233; Deiss., BS, 67.1; MM, xxi), Lk 20:11, Ac 12:3; similarly ptcp., προσ-θείς, c. indic. (Ge 38:5, al.), Lk 19:11.†

Hellenistic for ὄψον ὀψάριον); a relish or dainty (esp, cooked fish), to be eaten with bread: Jo 21:5 (have ye taken any fish, Field, Notes, 109; Abbott, Essays, 105; cf. M, Pr., 170n; MM, Exp., xxi).†
originally, freshly slain.; Generally (from Æsch. on), new, fresh, recent: ὁδός, He 10:20 (v. MM, Exp., xxi; Rutherford, NPhr., 471 f.).†
recently: Ac 18:2 (v. MM, Exp., xxi).†

to bring to, lead to: c. acc et dat. pers., Mt 4:24 8:16 9:2, 32 14:35 17:16, Mk 2:4 (WH, R, txt.; sc. αὐτόν) Mk 10:13, Lk 18:15 23:14; pass., Mt 12:22 (act., WH, txt.) Mt 18:24 (προσήχθη, WH) Mt 19:13; c. acc rei, Mt 25:20; id. c. dat. pers., Mt 22:19, Lk 23:36; τ. στόματι, Jo 19:29; metaph., c. dat pers., to deal with, He 12:7 (cl.).; to offer: Mt 2:11, Ac 8:18; esp. (as freq. in LXX; cf. FlJ, Ant., iii, 9, 3) sacrifices, gifts and prayers to God: absol., seq. περί (ὑπέρ), Mk 1:44, Lk 5:14, He 5:1, 3 9:7 10:12; pass., Ac 21:26; c. acc rei (δῶρον, θυσίαν, λυτρείαν, προσφοράν), Mt 5:23-24 (aoristic pres.; M, Pr., 247) Mt 8:4, Jo 16:2, Ac 7:42 21:26, He 5:1 8:3-4 9:7, 9 10:1-2, 8 10:11-12; δεήσεις τε κ. ἱκετηρίας, He 5:7; c. acc pers., He 11:17 (conative impf.; M, Pr., 129); of Christ, He 7:27 (ἀνενέγκας, WH, txt.) He 9:14, 25 9:28.†
of persons, in both act, and pass. sense (LXX, ll. c.); of things, pleas­ing, agreeable (EV, lovely): Phl 4:8.†

a bringing to, offering (Plat., al.).; (Less freq. in cl.), a present, an offering; in NT, of sacrificial offerings: Ac 21:26 24:17, Eph 5:2, He 10:5, 8 10:14; περί ἀμαρτίας, He 10:18; c. gen. obj., Ro 15:16, He 10:10.†

to address, call to; in cl., c. acc pers., c. dupl. acc (cf. 2Mac, l.c.); absol. (Hom., Od., v, 159, al.): Ac 21:40 In late writers, c. dat. pers.: Mt 11:16, Lk 7:32 13:12 23:20, Ac 22:2.; to call by name, summon: c. acc (as in cl.), Lk 6:13.†
a pouring or sprinkling upon: He 11:28.†
in poët. and late writers,; to touch: c. dat., Lk 11:46.†
to have respect of persons: Ja 2:9.†
a respecter of persons: Ac 10:34 (on this group of cognate forms, v. Mayor, da., 78 f.; and cf. Thackeray, Gr., 44).†
respect of persons: Ro 2:11, Eph 6:9, Col 3:25, Ja 2:1 (v. Mayor, in l).†

prop., of persons (so always in cl.); the face, countenance: Mt 6:16-17, Mk 14:65, Lk 9:29, II Co 3:7, Re 4:7, al.; τὸ π. τῆς γενέτεως (EV, natural face), Ja 1:23; πίπτειν ἐπὶ (τὰ) π., Mt 17:6, Lk 5:12, Re 7:11, al.; ἀγνοούμενος τῷ π., Ga 1:22; π., οὐ καρδίᾳ, I Th 2:17; κατὰ πρόσωπον (in front, facing: Thuc., Xen., al.), when present, face to face, Ac 25:16, II Co 10:1 10:7, Ga 2:11; id. c. gen., as compound prep., in the presence of (not cl.; v. Bl., § 40, 9; M, Pr., 99 f.; Thackeray, Gr., 43 f.), Lk 2:31, Ac 3:13; similarly ἀπὸ π. (Heb. (פָּנִים מִלִּפְּנֵי); v. Dalman, Words, 29), from the presence of, Ac 3:19 5:41 7:45, II Th 1:9, Re 12:14 20:11; πρὸ π. (Heb. (פָּנִים לִפְנֵי), before, Mt 11:10, Mk 1:2, Lk 7:27 (LXX), al.; in other phrases resembling Heb. idiom (Thackeray, Gr., 42), βλέπειν (ὁρᾶν, θεωρεῖν, ἰδεῖν) τὸ π., to see one's face, i.e. see him in person, Mt 18:10, Ac 20:25, 38, I Th 3:10, Re 22:4; ἐμφανισθῆναι τῷ π. τοῦ θεοῦ, He 9:24; ἐν π. Χριστοῦ, II Co 2:10 4:6; μετὰ τοῦ π. σου with thy presence, Ac 2:28 (LXX); εἰς π. τῶν ἐκκλησιῶν, II Co 8:24; στηρίζειν τὸ π. (Heb. פָּנִים שׂוּם: Je 21:10, al.; v. Dalman, Words, 30), c. inf., to set one's face towards, Lk 9:51; similarly, τὸ π. αὐτοῦ ἦν πορευόμενον (op. cit., 31), Lk 9:53; τὸ π. τοῦ κυρίου ἐπί, I Pe 3:12 (LXX); form, person: καυχᾶσθαι. ἐν π. καὶ μὴ ἐν καρδίᾳ, II Co 5:12 (cf. I Ki 16:7); metaph., as in Heb. idiom, of judgment according to appearance, external condition or circumstances (פָּנִים H5387; v. Dalman, Words, 30; Thackeray, Gr., 43 f.): λαμβάνειν π., Lk 20:21, Ga 2:6; βλέπειν εἰς π., Mt 22:16, Mk 12:14; θαυμάζειν πρόσωπα, Ju 16.; Of things (cf. Dalman, l.c.); face, appearance (Ps 104:30): Mt 16:3 (WH, R, mg., om.), Lk 12:56, Ja 1:11; surface (Ge 2:6): Lk 21:35, Ac 17:26
to place in front.; to arrange beforehand: Ac 17:26, Rec. (for προστ., Edd.).†
to stretch out, stretch forth: of preparations for scourging (v. Field, Notes, 136 f.), Ac 22:25.†

before, of time, place, rank, etc.; in NT always of Time, before, former: Eph 4:22. Adverbially, πρότερον, before, aforetime, formerly: Jo 7:50, II Co 1:15, He 4:6; opp. to ἔπειτα, He 7:27; τὸ π., Jo 6:62 9:8, Ga 4:13, I Ti 1:13; αἱ π. ἡμέραι, He 10:32; αἱ π. ἐπιθυμίαι, I Pe 1:14.†

first, of Time or Place; absol., as subst., ὁ π.., Lk 14:18, Jo 19:32, I Co 14:30; ὁ π. καὶ ὁ ἔσχατος, Re 1:17 2:8 22:13; neut., τὸ π., opp. to τ. δεύτερον, He 10:9; τὰ π., opp. to τ. ἔσχατα, Mt 12:45, Lk 11:26, II Pe 2:20; anarth., Mt 10:2; pl., Mt 19:30, Mk 10:31, Lk 13:30; ἐν πρώτοις (EV, first of all), I Co 15:3; as adj.: πρώτῃ; (sc. ἡμέρᾳ) σαββάτου, Mk 16:[9]; φυλακή, opp. to δευτέρα, Ac 12:10; equiv. to adv. in English, Jo 8:[7] 20:4, 8 Ac 27:43, Ro 10:19, I Ti 1:16, I Jo 4:19; = πρότερος (v. infr.; cf. M, Pr., 79; Bl, §11, 5; Thackeray, Gr., 183f.): c. gen., π. μου ἦν (my chief: Abbott, Jg., 509ff.; but cf. M, Pr., 245), Jo 1:15, 30; c. art., Mk 14:12, Ac 1:1, al.; seq. ὁ δεύτερος, etc., Mt 22:25, Mk 12:20, al. Of Rank or Dignity, chief, principal: Mt 20:27 22:38, Mk 9:35, Eph 6:2, al.; c. gen., Mk 12:28, 29 al.; πόλις (Field, Notes, 124), Ac 16:12; c. art., Lk 15:22 19:47, Ac 13:50, al. Neut., πρῶτον, as adv., first, at the first; of Time: Mt 8:21, Mk 4:28, al.; τὸ π., Jo 10:40, al.; of Order: Ro 3:2, I Co 11:18, al.

to set before, set forth publicly; so also in mid.: c. acc pers., Ro 3:25 (for a suggested alt, rend., v. MM, xxii).; Mid., to set before oneself, propose, purpose: c. inf., Ro 1:13; c. acc rei, Eph 1:9.†
to urge forwards, exhort, persuade. Mid., in same sense (as also in cl.): Ac 18:27.†
to run forward.; to run on, run in advance: Jo 20:4; seq. εἰς τὸ ἔμπροσθεν, Lk 19:4.†
to be beforehand in.; to be before or previously: c. ptcp., Lk 23:12, Ac 8:9.†
a pretence, pretext: Mt 23:1 (WM, R, txt., om.), Mk 12:40, Lk 20:47 Jo 15:22, Ac 27:30, Phl 1:18, I Th 2:5.†
to bring forth: c. acc rei, seq. ἐκ, Lk 6:45.†

the gift (and its exercise) of interpreting the Divine will and purpose, prophecy, prophesying: of OT prophecy, Mt 13:14, II Pe 1:20-21; of NT prophecy, Ro 12:6, I Co 12:10 13:2 14:6 14:22, I Ti 4:14, Re 11:6 22:19; pl., I Co 13:8, I Th 5:20, I Ti 1:18; οἱ λόγοι τῆς π., Re 1:3 22:7, 10 22:18; τ. πνεῦμα τῆς π., Re 19:10 (Luc., FlJ, LXX, π.; v. Deiss., BS, 235 f.; MM, xxii).†

to be a προφήτης (q.v.), to prophesy: in the primary sense of telling forth the Divine counsels, Mt 7:22 26:68, Mk 14:65, Lk 1:67 22:64, Ac 19:6, I Co 11:4-5 13:9 14:1 14:3-5 14:24 14:31 14:39, He 11:3; with the idea of foretelling future events (an idea merely incidental, not essential; v. Lft., Notes, 83 f.), Mt 11:13, Ac 2:17-18 (LXX) Ac 21:9; seq. περί, Mt 15:7, Mk 7:6, I Pe 1:10; ἐπί, c. dat., Re 10:11; λέγων, Ju 14; ὅτι, Jo 11:51.†

one who acts as an interpreter or forth-teller of the Divine will (v. Lft., Notes, 83f.; Tr., Syn., §vi), a prophet; in cl. (Æsch., Hdt., Plat., al.), of the interpreters of oracles. In NT, of the OT prophets: Mt 5:12, Mk 6:15, Lk 4:27, Jo 8:52, Ro 11:3, al.; of prophets in general: Mt 10:41 13:57 21:46, Mk 6:4, Lk 13:33, al.; of John the Baptist: Mt 21:26, Mk 6:15, Lk 1:76; of Christ: Mt 21:11, Jo 6:14, Ac 3:22, 23 7:37 (LXX); of Christian prophets in the apostolic age: Ac 15:32, I Co 12:28, Eph 2:20, al.; by meton., of the writings of prophets: Lk 24:27, Ac 8:28, al.; of a poet: Tit 1:12 (on the use of the term in π. and Inscr., v. Deiss., BS, 235f.; MM, xxii).
of prophecy, prophetic: Ro 16:26, II Pe 1:19.†
a prophetess: Lk 2:36, Re 2:20.†
c. ptcp. (as in cl., but more freq. the simple φθάνω, q.v.),; to anticipate: Mt 17:25.†
to put into the hand, deliver up: pass., Ac 3:20.; More freq. as depon., -ομαι, to take into one's hand; hence, metaph., to propose, determine, choose: c. inf., Ac 22:14; c. acc pers., Ac 26:16.†
to choose or appoint beforehand: Ac 10:41 (Plat., al.).†
Prochorus: Ac 6:5
prop. fem. of adj. πρύμνο, -η, -ον, (sc. ναῦς), the hindmost part of a ship, the stern: Mk 4:38, Ac 27:29; opp. to πρῷρα, Ac 27:41.†
in the morning, early: Mt 16:3 (R, txt.) Mt 21:18, Mk 1:35 11:20 13:35 15:1, Jo 18:28 20:1; λίαν π., Mk 16:2; ἅμα π., Mt 20:1; ἀπὸ π. (cf. ἀπὸ πρωΐθεν, Ex 18:13), Ac 28:23.†
= cl. πρώιος,; at early morn, early: ἀστήρ, Re 2:28 22:16.†
at early morn, early; as subst., ἡ π. (sc. ὥρα, cf. ἡ ὥ. ἡ π., III Mac 5:24), early morning: Mt 27:1, Jo 21:4.†
the forward part of a ship, the prow: Ac 27:30; opp. to πρύμνα, ib. Ac 27:41.†
to be first, pre-eminent, have the first place: Col 1:18.†
the chief seat: Mt 23:6, Mk 12:39 (v. Swete, in l), Lk 11:43 20:46.†
the chief place at table (v. Swete, Mk., l.c.): Mt 23:6, Mk 12:39, Lk 14:7-8 20:46.†
prop., of soldiers, one who stands first, one in the front rank (Thuc., Xen.); hence, metaph., a leader: Ac 24:5.†
the rights of the first-born, birthright (= cl. ἡ πρεσβεία): He 12:16.†

first-born: Lk 2:7; pl., He 11:28. Metaph., of the priority of Christ (originally perh. a Messianic title, cf. Ps 89:28, He 1:6; v. ICC on Col 1:15): He 1:6; π. πάσης κτίσεως, Col 1:15; ἐν πολλοῖς ἀδελφοῖς, Ro 8:29; π. (ἐκ) τ. νεκρῶν, Col 1:18, Re 1:5; pl., of the elect, ἐκκλησία πρωτοτόκων, He 12:23.†
trans., to cause to stumble (I Ki 4:3, cf. Deiss., BS, 681).; Intrans., to stumble. Metaph., in moral sense, Ro 11:11, Ja 2:10 3:2, II Pe 1:10.†
the heel: fig., ἐπαίρειν τὴν π. ἐπί, Jo 13:18 (LXX).†
a little wing.; Anything like a wing, as a turret, battlement: τ. ἱεροῦ, Mt 4:5, Lk 4:9.†
a wing: of birds, Mt 23:37, Lk 13:34, Re 12:14; of creatures seen in a vision, Re 4:8 9:9.†
winged; as subst., π., birds: I Co 15:39.†
to terrify. Pass., to be terrified: Lk 21:9 24:37 (WH, mg., θροηθέντες).†
a fluttering, excitement, caused by any emotion, but esp. by fear, hence, terror: φοβεῖσθαι πτόησιν, to be afraid with (cogn. acc) or of any terror (v. ICC, in l): I Pe 3:6.†
Ptolemais, a maritime city of Phœnicea: Ac 21:7.†
a winnowing shovel or fan: Mt 3:12, Lk 3:17.†
to be startled, frightened: Phl 1:28. (The active πτύρω is also found in some late writers.) †
spittle: Jo 9:6 (Hipp., Polyb., al.).†
to fold; of a scroll, to roll up: βιβλίον, Lk 4:20 (cf. ἀνα-πτύσσω).†
to spit: Mk 7:33 8:23, Jo 9:6 (cf. ἐκ-, ἐμ-πτύω).†

a fall, metaph., a misfortune, calamity (Trag., Plat., Polyb., al.; LXX).; That which has fallen; of buildings, a ruin (Polyb.); of living creatures, in cl. (poët. only) usually c. gen., νεκρῶν, etc., but also absol., as in late writers and NT, a fallen body, a carcase, corpse: Mt 14:12 24:28, Mk 15:45; π. αὐτοῦ, Mk 6:29; αὐτῶν, Re 11:8-9 (cf. Rutherford, NPhr., 472 f.).†
a falling, fall (Plat., Plut., al.): Mt 7:27; metaph., Lk 2:34.†
beggary, destitution: II Co 8:2 8:9, Re 2:9.†
to be a beggar, to beg (so chiefly in cl.).; to be poor as a beggar, to be destitute, poor: opp. to πλούσιος ὤν, II Co 8:9.†

of one who crouches and cowers, hence,; as subst., a beggar: Lk 14:13, 21 16:20, 22.; As adj.,; prop., beggarly: metaph., στοιχεῖα, Ga 4:9 (v. Lft., in l); in broader sense (opp. to πλούσιος), poor: Mt 11:5 19:21 26:9, 11, Mk 10:21 12:42-43 14:5, 7, Lk 4:18 7:22 18:22 19:8 21:3, Jo 12:5-6, 8 13:29, Ro 15:26, II Co 6:10, Ga 2:10, Ja 2:2-3, 6, Re 13:16; π. τ. κόσμῳ, Ja 2:5; metaph., Lk 6:20, Re 3:17; π. τ. πνεύματι, Mt 5:3.†

the fist: πυγμῇ νίψασθαι τ. χῖρας (Τ, πυκνά; Vg., Goth., Copt., crebro), to wash the hands with the fist (diligently, R, txt.; up to the elbow, R, mg.; the exact meaning is doubtful; v. Swete, in l): Mk 7:3.†

in cl., Python, a serpent slain by Apollo, who is hence surnamed the Pythian.; In Plut. (ii, 414 E), a name given to ventriloquist soothsayers (ἐγγαστρίμυθοι; cf. Le 19:31 20:6, 27, I Ki 28:7), and perhaps in this sense πνεῦμα πύθωνα, a python-spirit: Ac 16:16.†

close, compact, solid.; frequent: I Ti 5:23. Neut. pl., πυκνά, as adv., much, often: Mk 7:3 Τ (v.s. πυγμή), Lk 5:33. Comparat., πυκνότερον, very often or so much the oftener (v.Bl., § 44, 3,): Ac 24:26.†
to box: I Co 9:26.†
a gate: Lk 7:12, Ac 9:24 12:10 16:13, He 13:12; ἡ Ὡραία Π. τ. ἱεροῦ, Ac 3:10. Metaph., Mt 7:13-14; πύλαι ᾅδου (Wi 16:13, III Mac 5:51, and cf. κλαῖς ᾅδου Re 1:18): Mt 16:18.†
the porch or vestibule of a house or palace: Mt 26:71, Lk 16:20, Ac 10:17 12:13-14; The gate-way or gate-tower of a walled town: Ac 14:13, Re 21:12-13, 15 21:21, 25 22:14.†

to inquire: c. acc rei, Jo 4:42, Ac 23:20; seq. quæst. indir., Mt 2:4, Lk 15:25 18:36, Ac 10:18 21:33; quæst. dir., Ac 4:7 10:20 23:10; seq. παρά, c. gen. pers., Mt 2:4, Jo 4:52.; to learn by inquiry: seq. ὅτι, Ac 23:34.†

fire: Mk 9:22, Lk 3:9, Jo 15:6, Ac 2:10, I Co 3:13, Ja 3:5, Re 8:5, al; π. καὶ θεῖον, Lk 17:29; κατακαίειν (ἐν) π., Mt 13:40, Re 17:16 18:8; καίεσθαι πυρί, He 12:18, Re 8:8 21:8; φλὸξ πυρός, Ac 7:30, II Th 1:8, He 1:7, Re 1:14 2:18 19:12; λαμπάδες πυρός, Re 4:5; στῦλοι πυρός, Re 10:1; ἄνθρακες πυρός, Ro 12:20 (LXX); γλῶσσαι ὡσεὶ πυρός, Ac 2:3; δοκιμάζειν (πυροῦσθαι) διὰ πυρός, I Pe 1:7, Re 3:18; ὡς διὰ. π. (Lft., Notes, 193), I Co 3:15. Of the fire of hell (cf. Dalman, Words,161): Mk 9:48 (LXX); τὸ π. τὸ αἰώνιον, Mt 18:8 25:41 (cf. IV Mac 12:12); ἄσβεστον, Mk 9:43; πυρὸς αἰωνίου δίκην ὑπέχειν, Ju 7; γέεννα τοῦ π., Mt 5:22 18:9; κάμινος τοῦ π., Mt 13:42, 50; ἡ λίμνη τοῦ π., Re 19:20 20:10, 14-15; πυρὶ τηρεῖσθαι, II Pe 3:7; βασανισθῆναι ἐν π., Re 14:10. Metaph.: βαπτίζειν πυρί, Lk 3:16; of the tongue, Ja 3:5; of strife and discord, Lk 12:49; ἐκ π. ἁρπάζειν, Ju 23; πυρὶ αλίζεσθαι, Mk 9:49; ζῆλος πυρός, He 10:27; of God, π, καταναλίσκον, He 12:29 (LXX)
a fire: Ac 28:2-3.†
a tower: Lk 13:4; of a watch-tower in a vineyard (Is 5:2): Mt 21:33, Mk 12:1, and prob., Lk 14:28.†
to be ill of a fever: Mt 8:14, Mk 1:3.†
a fever: Mt 8:15, Mk 1:31, Lk 4:39, Jo 4:52, Ac 28:8; π. μέγας, a high fever: Lk 4:38 (on the technical phrase here, v. MM, xxii).†
fiery: Re 9:17.†

to set on fire, burn up. In NT always pass.,; to be set on fire, to burn: Eph 6:16, II Pe 3:12; ptcp., glowing, Re 1:15. Metaph., of grief or indignation, II Co 11:29; of lust, I Co 7:9.; Of metals (cf. Jb 22:25, Ps 12:7, Za 13:9), to be refined or purified by fire: Re 3:18 (and so in RV, Re 1:15, but v. supr.).†
to be fiery red: Mt 16:2-3.†
fiery red: Re 6:4 12:3.†; Πύρρος, -ου, ὁ,; Pyrrhus: Ac 20:4.†
a burning: Re 18:9, 18.; a refining or trial by fire: metaph., I Pe 4:12.†
enclit. part.,; yet, v.s. μή-πω, μηδέ-πω, οὔ-πω, οὐδέ-πω, πώ-ποτε

to exchange or barter.; to sell: Lk 17:28, Re 13:17; οἱ πωλοῦντες, Mt 21:12 25:9, Mk 11:15, Lk 19:45; c. acc rei, Mt 13:44 19:21 21:12, Mk 10:21 11:15, Lk 12:33 18:22 22:36, Jo 2:14, 16 Ac 5:1 (sc. αὐτά, αὐτόν), Ac 4:34, 37. Pass., I Co 10:25; c. gen. pretii, Mt 10:29, Lk 12:6.†
a foal, colt, prop., of a horse, then the young of other animals; in NT of the colt of an ass: Mt 21:2, 5 (LXX), Mt 21:7, Mk 11:2, 4-5 11:7, Lk 19:30, 33 19:35, Jo 12:15 (LXX).†
to petrify, harden, form a callus. Metaph., π. τ. καρδίαν, Jo 12:40. Pass., Ro 11:7; τ. νοήματα, II Co 3:14; ἡ καρδία, Mk 6:52 8:17 †
a covering with a callus, a hardening: metaph., Mk 3:6, Ro 11:2, Eph 4:18.†
at all; v.s. εἴπως, μήπως.

prop., in direct questions, how?: c. indic., Mt 12:29, Mk 3:23, Lk 11:18, Jo 3:4, al.; καὶ π., Mk 4:13, Lk 20:44; π. οὖν, Mt 12:26; π. οὐ, Mt 16:11, Lk 12:56; in deliberative questions (cf. Bl., §64, 6), c. subjc., Mt 23:33 26:54; π. οὖν, Ro 10:14; π. δέ, Ro 10:14, 15; seq. ἄν, c. optat., Ac 8:31. As sometimes in cl. but more freq. and increasingly so in late writers (v. WM, §57, 2; Bl., §70, 2; Thumb, MGr., 192; Jannaris, Gr., App., vi, 13f.), = ὅπως, ὥς; in indirect discourse: c. indic., Mt 6:28, Mk 12:41, Lk 8:36, Jo 9:15, Ac 9:27, al.; c. subjc., Mk 11:18, Lk 12:11; in exclamations: Mt 21:20, Mk 10:23, 24 Lk 12:50 18:24, Jo 11:36.
Rahab (LXX, Jos 2:1, al.): He 11:31, Ja 2:25.†

a title of respectful address to Jewish teachers, Rabbi: Mt 23:7-8; of John, Jo 3:26; of Christ, Mt 26:25, 49, Mk 9:5 11:21 14:45, Jo 1:30, 50 3:2 4:31 6:25 9:2 11:8; κύριε ῥ Mk 10:51 (WH, mg., v.s. ῥαββουνεί).†
Rabboni: Mk 10:51 (WH, mg., κύριε ῥαββεί), Jo 20:16.†
to beat with a rod: Ac 16:22, II Co 11:25.†

a staff, rod: He 9:4, Re 11:1; in particular,; a staff, such as is used on a journey: Mt 10:10, Mk 6:8, Lk 9:3, He 11:21 (LXX); a ruler's staff, a sceptre: He 1:8 (LXX) Re 2:27 12:5 19:15; a rod for chastisement (cf. ῥαβδίζω): ἐν ῥ. (v.s. ἐν): I Co 4:21.†
one who carries a rod or staff of office; an umpire or judge (Plat.); in late writers, a Roman lictor: Ac 16:38.†
Reu: Lk 3:35.†
a reckless act.; crime, villany: Ac 18:14.†
ease in doing, facility (Xen.).; easiness, laziness (Xen.).; recklessness, wickedness (of lewdness, Xen.; fraud, Plut.; in π., of theft, MM, xxii): Ac 13:10.†

usually taken to represent the Aram. רֵיקָא, a shortened form of H7386, " empty," as vocalized in the Galilæan dialect; an expression of contempt, raca: Mt 5:22 (cf. DB, iv, 191 f.; and for other explanations, v. Zorell, s.v.).†
a ragged garment (Hom.).; a rag, remnant, piece of cloth: Mt 9:16, Mk 2:21.†
Ramah: Mt 2:18 (LXX).†

= cl., ῥαίνω,; to sprinkle, besprinkle: c. acc, He 9:13, 19; id. et dat., He 9:21; pass., Re 19:13, WH; of cleansing by sprinkling, He 10:22 (v. M, Gr., ii, 100); mid., Mk 7:4 (WH, txt., R, mg.).†; περι-ραίνω; to sprinkle around: Re 19:13 T (ῤεραντισμένον, WH; ῤε-, R, txt.; βεβαμμένον, Rec., R, mg.).†
sprinkling: of the ceremonial sprinkling of blood for purification, He 12:24, I Pe 1:2 (v. Hort, Pe., 23 ff.).†
prop., to strike with a rod.; In late writers, to strike (the face) with the palm of the hand: Mt 26:67; c. acc pers., seq. εἰς τ. σιαγόνα, Mt 5:39 (cf. Field, Notes, 40, 105).†
a needle: Mt 19:24, Mk 10:25 (cf. βελόνη).†
Rachel: Mt 2:18 (LXX).†
Rebecca: Ro 9:10.†
a chariot: Re 18:13.†
Rompha, Rephan (RV), one of the names of Seb, the Egyptian Saturn: Ac 7:43 (LXX).†
to flow: Jo 7:38 (cf. παραρρέω).†
Rhegium, a town in Sicily: Ac 28:13.†
cl. (and so in LXX), a fracture; then by meton., that which is torn.; In NT, ruin: Lk 6:49.†

to rend, break asunder: Mt 7:6, Mk 2:22, Lk 5:37; pass., Mt 9:17.; Of the voice, c. acc, φωνήν, etc. (Hdt., al.), to break forth into speech: absol., Ga 4:27 (LXX).; = ῥήσσω (Dem., al.), to throw or dash down: Mk 9:18, Lk 9:42; (cf. δια-, περι-, προσ-ρήγνυμι).†

prop., of that which is said or spoken,; a word: Mt 27:14, II Co 12:4; pl., τὰ ῥ., of speech, discourse, Lk 7:1, Jo 8:20, Ac 2:14, Ro 10:18, II Pe 3:2, al.; opp. to ὄνομα (a single word), a saying, statement, word of prophecy, instruction or command (in cl., phrase): Mt 26:75, Mk 9:32, Lk 1:38 2:50, Ac 11:16, Ro 10:8, He 11:3; ῥ. θεοῦ (κυρίου), Lk 3:2, Ac 11:16, Eph 6:17, He 6:5 11:3, I Pe 1:25 (LXX); τὰ ῥ. τ. θεοῦ, Jo 3:34 8:47; ῥ. ἀργόν, Mt 12:36;ῥ. ἄρρητα, II Co 12:4.; Like Heb. דָּבָר (but perh. also a Gk. colloquialism, v. Kennedy, Sources, 124; Thackeray, Gr., 41), of that which is the subject of speech, a thing, matter (Ge 15:1, De 17:8, al.): Lk 1:37 2:15, Ac 10:37; pl., Lk 1:65 2:19, 51, Ac 5:32 13:42
indecl.,; Rhesa: Lk 3:27.†
a public speaker, an orator: Ac 24:1.†
in stated terms, expressly: I Ti 4:1.†

a root: Mt 3:10, Lk 3:9; ἐκ ῥιζῶν, Mk 11:20; ῥ. ἔχειν, Mt 13:6, Mk 4:6; id. seq. ἐν ἑαυτῷ, fig., Mt 13:21, Mk 4:17, Lk 8:13. Metaph. (as in various senses in cl.), of cause, origin, source, etc.; of things, ῥ. πάντων τ. κακῶν (Eur.), I Ti 6:10; of persons: of ancestors, Ro 11:16-18; ῥ. πικρίας, He 12:15. Of that which springs from a root, a shoot; metaph., of offspring, Ro 15:12 (LXX) Re 5:5 22:16.†
to cause to take root. Metaph., to plant, fix firmly, establish: pass. (EV, rooted), ἐν ἀγάπῃ, Eph 3:18(17); ἐν Χριστῷ, Col 2:7 (cf. ἐκ ριζόω).†

poët. in cl., any rapid movement such as the throw or flight of a javelin, the rush of wind or flame, the flapping of wings, the twinkling of lights; ῥ. ὀφθαλμοῦ, the twinkling of an eye: I Co 15:52 (L, mg., ῥοπή, q.v.).†
inclination downwards, as the turn of the scale: L, mg., for ῥιπή, q.v., I Co 15:52 (v. Tdf., in l).†

primarily, to fan a fire, hence generally, to make a breeze (Plut., al.). In pass. (cf. Philo, de inter. round., 24), to be tossed or blown by the wind: of waves, ἀνεμιζομένῳ καὶ ῥιπιζομένῳ, blown and raised with the wind (Hort, in l), Ja 1:6.†

to throw, cast, hurl: c. acc rei, Mt 27:5, Ac 27:19, 29; c. acc pers., Mt 15:30, Lk 4:35; pass., Lk 17:2; ptcp., ἐριμμένοι, cast down, prostrate (Polyb., al.): Mt 9:36; of garments, to throw off (for flight, Eur., Xen., al.; ὅπλα, I Mac 5:43; so EV in Ac 22:23, but v. infr.).; = ῥιπτάζω, to shake, toss, throw about: τ. ἱμάτια, Ac 22:23 (EGT, Page, Rackham, in l; Field, Notes, 136; but v. supr.).†
Rehoboam: Mt 1:7.†
Rhoda: Ac 12:13.†
the island of Rhodes: Ac 21:1.†
with rushing sound (as of roaring flames): II Pe 3:10.†
a large broad sword, used by the Thracians (v. DB, iv, 634); then generally (in LXX used interchangeably with μάχαιρα, q.v.), a sword: Re 1:16 2:12, 16 6:8 19:15, 21; metaph., Lk 2:35.†
Reuben: Re 7:5.†
(Lat.), Rufus: Mk 15:21, Ro 16:13.†

in cl., the force, rush, swing, of a moving body; esp. of a charge of soldiers.; In late Greek (as in Macedonian, v. Kennedy, Sources, 15), a narrow road, lane, street: in Polyb., of a road in camp; in LXX and NT (π. also) of streets in a town, Mt 6:2, Lk 14:21 Ac 9:11 12:10 (cf. Rutherford, NPhr., 488).†

to draw to oneself, hence, to rescue, deliver: c. acc pers., Mt 27:43, II Pe 2:7; id. seq. ἀπό, Mt 6:13, Lk 11:4 (Rec., R, mg.), II Ti 4:18; seq. ἐκ, Ro 7:24, II Co 1:10, Col 1:13, I Th 1:10, II Ti 3:11, II Pe 2:9; absol., ὁ ῥυύμενος, the deliverer, Ro 11:26. Passive: seq. ἀπό, Ro 15:31, II Th 3:2; seq. ἐκ, Lk 1:74, II Ti 4:17.†
in Arist., Xen., and later writers, to make filthy, defile: pass., in ethical sense (on the tense, v. Swete, in l), Re 22:11 LT, Tr., WH, txt
= ῥυπαίνομαι, q.v.: Re 22:11, WH, mg. (nowhere else).†
filthiness: metaph., of moral defile­ment, Ja 1:21.†
filthy, dirty: of old, shabby clothing (Za, l.c.), Ja 2:2; metaph., of moral defilement, Re 22:11.†
dirt, filth: I Pe 3:21.†
to make filthy: Re 22:11 Rec. (AV, tr. as = ῥυπάω, to be filthy).†
a flowing, issue: τ. αἵματος, Mk 5:25, Lk 8:43-44.†
a wrinkle: Eph 5:27.†
Roman, Latin: Lk 23:38 Rec.†
in Latin: Jo 19:20.†
to strengthen; most freq. in pf., ἔρρωμαι, to put forth strength, be strong, hence, often in imperat., ἔρρωσο, ἔρρωσθε, farewell (Lat. vale): Ac 15:29 23:30 Rec., R, mg.†
sabachthani, i.e. thou host forsaken me: Mt 27:46, Mk 15:34 (Ps 22:2, Heb. עָזַב).†
zaphthanei: Mt 27:46 (WH, mg., for Rec. σεβαχθανεί, q.v.; "probably an attempt to reproduce the Heb. as disting from Aram. forms," WE, Notes, 21; cf. also Dalman, Words, 53 f.).†
Sabaoth, i.e. hosts or armies (v. DB, l.c.): Ro 9:29 (LXX), Ja 54.†
a keeping sabbath, a sabbath rest: metaph., as in Mishna (Zorell, s.v.), He 4:9.†

the seventh day of the week, the sabbath; the sing. form -ον, τὸ σ.: Mt 12:8, Mk 2:27, Lk 6:5, al.; ἡ ἡμέρα τοῦ σ. (in LXX, Ex 20:8, al., usually τῶν σ., v. infr.), Lk 13:16 14:5; ὁδὸς σαββάτου, Ac 1:12 (cf. Mt 24:29); dat., of time (τῷ) σ., Lk 6:9 14:1; ἐν (τῷ) σ., Mt 12:2, Lk 6:7, Jo 5:16, al.; acc, of duration, τὸ σ., Lk 23:56; κατὰ πᾶν σ., Ac 13:27 15:21 18:4; pl., σ. τρία, Ac 17:2 R, txt. (but v. infr.); as most freq. in LXX (v. Swete, Mk., 17; Thackeray, Gr., 35) the pl. form, τὰ σ. (v. supr. on the Aram. form. There is also an analogy in the names of other festivals, τ. ἐγκαίνια, ἄζυμα, etc.): Mt 28:1, Col 2:16; ἡ ἡμέρα τῶν σ. (Ex 20:8, al.), Lk 4:16, Ac 13:14 16:13; dat. pl. (in LXX -τοις, but I Mac 2:38 as in NT) by metaplasmus (El., § 9, 3), σάββασι, Mt 12:1, 5 12:10-12 Mk 1:21 2:23 3:2, 4, Lk 4:31 6:2.; seven days, a week; the sing. form: πρώτη σαββάτσυ, Mk 16:9; δὶς τοῦ σ. (Bl., § 35, 4; 36, 13), Lk 18:12; κατὰ μίαν σαββάτου, I Co 16:2; pl., σ. τρία, Ac 17:2 R, mg. (but v. supr.); the pl. form: ἡ μία τῶν σ. (where the gen. = μετὰ τά; Soph., Lex., 43a), Mt 28:1, Mk 16:2, Lk 24:1, Jo 20:1, 19, Ac 20:7
a drag-net, seine: Mt 13:47.†
Sadoc, Zadok: Mt 1:14.†
prop. (Hom., al.), of dogs, to wag the tail, fawn.; Metaph., of persons, c. acc, to fawn upon, flatter, beguile: pass., I Th 3:3 (for conjectural emendations of the text, v. ICC, and M, Th., in l).†

a coarse cloth, sackcloth, usually made of hair: Re 6:12.; Anything made of sackcloth; a sack (Ge 42:25, al.); a garment of sackcloth, expressive of mourning or penitence: Mt 11:21, Lk 10:13, Re 11:3.†
Sala, Shalah: Lk 3:32 (R, txt., Σαλμών, q.v.), Lk 3:35.†
indecl. (Heb. שְׁאַלְתִּיאֵל),; Salathiel: Mt 1:12, Lk 3:27.†
Salamis, the chief city of Cyprus: Ac 13:5.†
Salim: Jo 3:23 (v. Westc., in l; DB, iii, 354).†

prop., of the action of wind, storm, etc., to agitate, shake: of a reed, Mt 11:7, Lk 7:24; a house, Lk 6:48, Ac 4:31 16:26; the earth, He 12:26; the heavenly bodies, Mt 24:29, Mk 13:25, Lk 21:26; of a vessel shaken in filling, Lk 6:38. Metaph.,; to shake, i.e. to render insecure: τὰ σαλευόμενα, τὰ μὴ., He 12:27; c. acc pers., to cast down from a sense of security and happiness: Ac 2:25 (LXX); to unsettle or drive away: pass., seq. ἀπὸ τ. νοός, II Th 2:2; to stir up: τ. ὄχλους, Ac 17:13.†
Salem: He 7:1-2 (LXX).†
Salmon: Mt 1:4-5, Lk 3:32 (Σαλά, WH, R, mg.).†
Salmone, a promontory of Crete: Ac 27:7.†
in poets and late prose, a tossing, as of an earthquake; esp. the tossing, the rolling swell of the sea: Lk 21:25.†

a trumpet, used in war and in religious ceremonies: I Co 14:8, He 12:19, Re 1:10 4:1 8:2, 6 8:11 9:14 By meton., a trumpet blast: μετὰ σ. μεγάλης, Mt 24:31; ἐν σ. θεοῦ, I Th 4:16; ἐν τ. ἐσχάτῃ σ., I Co 15:52.†
to sound a trumpet: Re 8:6 ff. Re 9:1, 13 10:7 11:15; metaph., Mt 6:2. Impers., the trumpet sounds: I Co 15:52.†
a trumpeter: Re 18:22.†
Salome: Mk 15:40 16:1.†

a Samaritan, i.e. an inhabitant of the city or the region of Samaria, in NT always the latter (v.s. Σαμαρία): Mt 10:5, Lk 9:52 10:33 17:16, Jo 4:9, 39-40, Ac 8:25; as an opprobrious epithet, Jo 8:48.†
in FlJ (B.J., i, 21, 2, al.), the region of Samaria.; a Samaritan woman: Jo 4:9.†
Samaria; the city: Ac 8:5 (and perhaps also Ac 8:9, 14); the region: Lk 17:11, Jo 4:4-5, 7, Ac 1:8 8:1 (and perhaps also Ac 8:9, 14) Ac 9:31 15:3.†
Samothrace, an island in the Ægean: Ac 16:11.†
Samos, an island in the Ægean: Ac 20:15.†
Samson (Jg 13:1-25 ff.): He 11:32.†
a sandal: Mk 6:9, Ac 12:8.†
a board, plank: Ac 27:44
Saul; the King of Israel: Ac 13:21; the Jewish name of the Apostle Paul, used in the indecl. form only in address (cf. Σαῦλος): Ac 9:4, 17 22:7, 13 26:14.†

rotten, corrupt, bad, worth­less: of trees and fruit (opp. to ἀγαθός, καλός), Mt 7:17-18 12:33 Lk 6:43; of fish, Mt 13:48.; Metaph., in moral sense: λόγος σ., Eph 4:29. "In Hellenistic . . . it became a synonym for αἰσχρός or κακός," MM, xxii.†
Sapphia: Ac 5:1.†
sapphire (perh. = lapis lazuli): Re 21:19.†
a plaited rope (Æsch.).; a hamper, a basket made of ropes: II Co 11:33.†
Sardis, the chief city of Lydia: Re 1:11 3:1, 4
= σάρδιον (q.v.), Re 4:3, Rec.†
the sardian stone, sard (of which carnelian is one variety): Re 4:3 21:20.†
sardonyx, a stone marked by the red of the sard and the white of the onyx: Re 21:20.†
Sarepta, a city of Sidon: Lk 4:26.†

= Lat. carnalis, i.e.; associated with or pertaining to the flesh, fleshly, carnal: Ro 15:27, I Co 9:11; in a more ethical sense, of the nature of the flesh, under the control of its appetites, fleshly, carnal, sensual (but including more than mere sensuality; cf. Hort, 1Pe., 133): I Co 3:3, II Co 1:12 10:4, I Pe 2:11.†

= Lat. carneus (the termination -ινος denoting the substance or material of a thing; v. Tr., Syn., § LXXii; Lft., Notes, 184; and for illustrations from π., v. MM, xxii), of the flesh, of flesh, fleshy (Plat., Arist., Plut., al.): Ro 7:14, I Co 3:1, II Co 3:3, He 7:16. (Rec. has -ικός in all these passages except II Co 3:3, but the evidence is decisive against it.)†

flesh; as in cl. generally, prop., of the soft substance of the animal body: I Co 15:39, II Co 12:7, Ga 6:13, al.; σ. καὶ αἷμα, I Co 5:50; σ. καὶ ὀστέα, Lk 24:39; pl., of the flesh of many or parts of the flesh of one (cl.), Re 17:16 19:18; φαγεῖν, Re, ll. c. (cf. κατεσθίειν, IV Ki 9:36, al., and βιβρώσκειν, freq. in l.); metaph., Ja 5:3; mystically, φ. (τρώγειν) τὴν σ. τοῦ υἱοῦ τ. ἀνθρώπου, Jo 6:52-56; Of the whole substance of the body, = σῶμα: Ac 2:26 (LXX), 31, II Co 12:7, Ga 4:14, Eph 5:29; μία σ., Mk 10:8; εἰς σ. μίαν (Ge 2:24), Mt 19:5, Mk 10:8, I Co 6:16, Eph 5:31; hence, of the material as opp. to the immaterial part of man (cf. Lft., Notes, 88): opp. to πνεῦμα, I Co 5:5, II Co 7:1, Col 2:5, I Pe 3:18, 4:6; to ψύχη, Ac 2:31, Rec.; of the present life, ἐν (τῇ) σ., Ro 7:5, Ga 2:20, Phl 1:22, 24 I Pe 4:2; of Christ's life on earth, αἱ ἡμέραι τ. σαρκὸς αὐτοῦ, He 5:7; of things pertaining to the body, ἐν (τῇ) σ., Ga 6:12, 13 Phl 3:3, 4. As in Heb. idiom, of a living creature: πᾶσα σ. (Heb. כָּל־בָּשָׂר; cf. Bl., §47, 9), Mt 24:22, Mk 13:20, I Pe 1:24; esp. of man and his mortality (Ps 55 (56):5, Si 28:5, al.), Jo 1:14; πᾶσα σ. (v. supr.), Lk 3:6, Jo 17:2, Ac 2:17, ἐν σ., I Jo 4:2, I Ti 3:16; of natural origin and relationship (Ge 2:24, Is 58:7, al.): τέκνα τῆς σ., Ro 9:8; κατὰ σάρκα, ib. 3, 5, I Co 10:18, Ga 4:23, 29; ἡ σ. μου, Ro 11:14 (cf. Jg 9:2, II Ki 5:1, al.). Of the physical nature as subject to sensation and desire (Plut.), without any ethical disparagement: Ro 7:18 13:14; opp. to πνεῦμα, Mt 26:41, Mk 14:38; τ. θέλημα τῆς σ., Jo 1:13; ἡ ἐπιθυμία τῆς σ., I Jo 2:16; pl., II Pe 2:18; παθεῖν σαρκί, I Pe 4:1; in ethical sense, esp. in Pauline Epp., of the flesh as the seat and vehicle of sinful desires: opp. to νοῦς, Ro 7:25; to πνεῦμα, Ro 8:4-9, 12, 13, Ga 5:16, 17 19 6:8 (cf. DB, ii, 14f.; iv, 165f.; Cremer, 844ff.).
late form of σαίρω,; to sweep: c. acc, Lk 15:8; pass., Mt 12:44, Lk 11:25.†
the plain of Sharon: Ac 9:35.†

Satan (i.e. the adversary, as in LXX, ll. c.): Mt 4:10 12:26, Mk 1:13 3:23, 26 4:15 Lk 10:18 11:18 13:16 22:3, 31, Jo 13:27, Ac 5:3 26:18, Ro 16:20, I Co 5:5 7:5, II Co 2:11 11:14, I Th 2:18, II Th 2:9, I Ti 1:20 5:15, Re 2:9, 13 2:24 3:9 12:9 20:2, 7; addressed in person of Peter, Mt 16:23 Mk 8:33; ἄγγελος Σατανᾶ, II Co 12:7.†
a Hebrew measure (= about a peck and a half): Mt 13:33, Lk 13:21.†

of fire or things on fire, to quench: c. acc, Mt 12:20, Eph 6:16, He 11:34; pass., Mt 25:8, Mk 9:48, [44, 46]. Metaph. (cf. Ca 8:7, IV Mac 16:4): τὸ πνεῦμα, I Th 5:19.†; ζβέννυμι, for σβ-, I Th 5:19 T (v. WH, Notes, 148).†
(of, to) thyself: Mt 4:6, Jo 8:13, I Ti 4:16, al. (In Hellenistic, the pl. is ἑαυτῶν (q.v.), not ὑμῶν αὐτῶν as in Attic, v. Bl., § 13, 1.) †
to fear (Hom).; In later writers, = σέβομαι, to worship: Ro 1:25
an object of worship: Ac 17:23, II Th 2:4.†
reverend, august.; In late writers, with reference to the Roman Imperial name; ὁ Σ., Augustus, i.e. the Roman Emperor: Ac 25:21, 25; Augustan: σπείρα σ., Ac 27:1 (See further, Deiss., BS, 218.) †
to worship: c. acc pers., Mt 15:9, Mk 7:7, Ac 18:13 19:27; σεβόμενος τ. θεόν, Ac 16:14 18:7; σεβόμενοι (σ. προσήλυτοι, σ. Ἕλληνες), devout, Ac 13:43, 50 17:4, 17 (cf. προσήλυτος).†
(a) a cord; a chain (cf. Pr., l.c.): σειραὶ ζόφου, II Pe 2:4, Rec., R, mg. (v.s. σειρός).; a lock of hair (Jg, ll. c.).†
a pit for the storage of grain: σειροὶ ζόφου, II Pe 2:4, WH, R., txt. (but v. Mayor, in l; Field, Notes, 241).†
a shaking, commotion, as a tempest at sea: Mt 8:24; esp. an earthquake: Mt 24:7 27:54 28:2, Mk 13:8, Lk 21:11, Ac 16:26, Re 6:12 8:5 11:13, 19 16:18.†

to shake, move to and fro: τ. γῆν, He 12:26 (LXX); pass., ἡ γῆ, Mt 27:51 (LXX); συκῆ, Re 6:13. Metaph., to agitate, stir up, with fear or some other emotion: Mt 21:10 28:4 (cf. ἀνα-, δια-, κατα-σείω).†
(Lat.), Secundus: Ac 20:4.†
Seleucia, a city of Syria: Ac 13:4.†
to be moonstruck, i.e. epileptic (epilepsy being supposed to be influenced by the moon): Mt 4:24 17:15.†
Semein: Lk 3:26.†
fine wheaten flour: Re 18:13.†
reverend, august, venerable, in cl. of the gods and also of human beings.; grave, serious; of persons: I Ti 3:8 3:11, Tit 2:2; of things: Phl 4:8 (v. Tr., Syn., § xcii; Cremer, 37; MM, xxii).†
gravity: I Ti 2:2 3:4 (Vg. eastitas, cf. Soph., Lex., and Zorell, s.v.), Tit 2:7.†
Sergius, surnamed Paulus: Ac 13:7.†
Serug: Lk 3:35.†
indecl.,; Seth (Ge 4:25): Lk 3:38.†
Shem: Lk 3:36.†
to give a sign, signify, indicate: c. acc rei, Ac 25:27, Re 1:1 (cf. MM, xxii); c. acc et inf., Ac 11:28; seq. quæst. indir., Jo 12:33 18:32 21:19.†

a sign, mark, token; of that which distinguishes a person or thing from others: Mt 26:48 Lk 2:12, II Th 3:17 (cf. Deiss., LAE, 153.2); seq. gen. epexeg., Ro 4:11; c. gen. obj., Mt 24:8, 30, II Co 12:12; c. gen. subj., Mt 16:3; a sign of warning or admonition: Mt 12:39 16:4, Lk 2:34 11:29-30, I Co 14:22; a sign portending future events (Soph., Plat. al.): Mk 13:4, Lk 21:7, 11 21:25, Ac 2:19, Re 12:1, 3 15:1; of miracles and wonders (MM, xxii), regarded as signs of a divine authority: Mt 12:38-39 16:1, 4 Mk 8:11-12 Lk 11:16, 29 23:8, Jo 2:11, 18 2:23 4:54 6:30 10:41 12:18, Ac 4:16, 22; pl., Mk 16:17, 20, Jo 2:11, 23 3:2 6:2, 14 6:26 7:31 9:16 11:47 12:37 20:30, Ac 8:6, I Co 1:22 (Lft., Notes, 162); the same ascribed to false teachers and demons: Mt 24:24, Mk 13:22, II Th 2:9, Re 13:13-14 16:14 19:20; σ. καὶ τέρατα (τ. καὶ σ.; cf. Tr., Syn., § xci), Mt 24:24, Mk 13:22, Jo 4:48, Ac 2:19, 43 4:30 5:12 6:8 7:36 14:3 15:12, Ro 15:19, II Th 2:9; id. seq. καὶ δυνάμεις, II Co 12:12, He 2:4; σ. καὶ δυνάμεις, Ac 8:13; δ. καὶ τ. καὶ σ., Ac 2:22; σ. διδόναι, Mt 24:24, Mk 13:22.†
to mark, note. Mid., to note for oneself: II Th 3:14 (freq. in π.; v. ICC, M, Th., in l).†

to-day: Mt 6:11, Lk 4:21, Ac 4:9, al.; opp. to αὔριον, Mt 6:30, Lk 12:28, Ja 4:13; χθὲς καὶ σ. καὶ εἰς τοὺς αἰῶνας, He 13:8; ἡ σ. ἡμέρα, Ac 20:20; ἕως (ἄχρι) τῆς σ. ἡμέρας, Ro 11:8, II Co 3:14; μέχρι (ἕως) τῆς σ. (sc. ἡμέρας), Mt 11:23 27:8; as subst., τὸ σ., He 3:13; id. in appos., ὁρίζει ἡμὶραν, σ., He 4:7 R, mg., (v. Westc., in l)
to make corrupt: 2 pf. act, with mid, sense (v. M, Pr., 154), σέσηπεν, has perished, become corrupted, Ja 5:2.†
a moth, clothes moth: Mt 6:19-20, Lk 12:33.†
moth-eaten: Ja 5:2.†
to strengthen: c. acc., I Pe 5:10 (Hesych.).†
the jawbone, jaw, cheek: Mt 5:39, Lk 6:29 (cf. MM, xxii).†
intrans., to be silent, keep silence: Lk 9:36 18:39 20:26, Ac 12:17 15:12-13, I Co 14:28 14:30 14:34.; Trans., to keep secret; pass., to be kept secret: Ro 16:25.†
silence: Ac 21:40, Re 8:1.†
iron: Re 18:12.†
Sidon, a maritime city of Phœnicia: Mt 11:21-22 15:21, Mk 3:8 7:24, 31, Lk 6:17 10:13-14, Ac 27:3.†
of Sidon, Sidonian; the region: sc. χώρα, Lk 4:26; the people: Ac 12:20.†
a bandit, assassin, one of the Sicarii (FlJ, B.J., ii, 17, 6, al.): Ac 21:38.†
fermented liquor, strong drink: Lk 1:15.†
Silvanus, latinized name of Silas: II Co 1:19, I Th 1:1, II Th 1:1, I Pe 5:12.†
Siloam (v. DB, iii, 515 f.): Lk 13:4, Jo 9:7, 11.†
a work­man's apron: Ac 19:12.†

a Greek name (transliterated סִימוֺן in Heb.) used as a substitute for Συμεών (q.v.), Simon; Simon Peter: Mt 17:25, Mk 1:29, al.; Simon the Zealot (v.s. ζηλωτής, Καναναῖος): Mt 10:4, Mk 3:18, Lk 6:15, Ac 1:13.; One of the Brethren of our Lord (v.s. ἀδελψός): Mt 13:55, Mk 6:3.; The father of Judas Iscariot, himself surnamed Ἰσκαριώτης (q.v.): Jo 6:71 12:4 (Rec.) 13:2,26; Simon the Cyrenian: Mt 27:32, Mk 15:21, Lk 23:26.; Simon the Pharisee: Lk 7:40, 43-44.; Simon of Bethany, surnamed ὁ λεπρός: Mt 26:6, Mk 14:3.; Simon Magus, a Samaritan sorcerer: Ac 8:9, 13 8:18, 24.; Simon the tanner, of Joppa: Ac 9:43 10:6, 17 10:32
indecl. (but τὸ Σιναῖον, FlJ, Ant., iii, 5, 1; τὸ Σιναῖον ὄρος, ib. ii, 12, 1), τό; Sinai (Ex 19:11, al.): Ac 7:30, 38, Ga 4:24-25†
fine linen cloth; as used for swathing dead bodies (cf. Hdt., ii, 86): Mt 27:59, Mk 15:46, Lk 23:53; a garment or wrap of this material (cf. ICC, Jg, l.c.): Mk 14:51-52.†
to sift, winnow: fig., Lk 22:31.†
silk, silken; as subst., τὸ σ., silken fabric, silk: Re 18:12 (cf. FlJ, B.J., vii, 5, 4).†
= σιτευτός, fattened; as subst., pl., τὰ σ., fatlings: Mt 22:4.†
a measured portion of food: Lk 12:42 (for exx. in π., v. Deiss., BS, 158; LAE, 103.1).†

wheat, corn: Mt 3:12 13:25, 29-30 Mk 4:28, Lk 3:17 12:18 16:7 22:32, Jo 12:24, Ac 27:38, I Co 15:37, Re 6:6 18:13.†; σιτίοι, -ου, τό; corn, grain: Ac 7:12 (but v. 131., § 9, 1).; Mostly in pl., σιτία, bread, food, provisions (LXX, l.c., Hdt., al.).†

indecl.,; in NT anarth., but in LXX when used of the city of Jerusalem, ἡ Σ.; Zion; the mountain: in typical sense, of the Church, He 12:22; of heaven, Re 14:1.; The city, i.e. Jerusalem; in poetical sense; of the inhabitants: θυγάτηρ Σ, Mt 21:5, Jo 12:15 (LXX); in wider sense, of Israel: Ro 11:26; fig.: τίθήμι ἐν Σ λίθον, Ro 9:33, I Pe 2:6 (LXX).†
to be silent or still, keep silence: Mt 20:31 26:63, Mk 3:4 9:34 10:48 14:61, Lk 19:4 , Ac 18:9; of one dumb, Lk 1:20 (cf. IV Mac 10:18); addressed rhetorically to the sea, σιώπα, Mk 4:39.†

prop., to put a snare or stumbling-block in the way; in NT always metaph. of that which hinders right conduct or thought, to cause to stumble: c. acc pers., Mt 5:29-30 17:27 18:6, 8-9 Mk 9:42-43, 45 9:47 Lk 17:2, Jo 6:61, I Co 8:13. Pass., to be made to stumble, to stumble: Mt 11:6 13:21, 57 15:12 24:10 26:31, 33, Mk 4:17 6:3 14:27, 29, Lk 7:23, Jo 16:1, Ro 14:21 (WH, R, txt., om.), II Co 11:29,†

prop., the bait-stick of a trap, a snare, stumbling-block (Le 19:14, Jth 5:1): fig., Ro 9:33, I Pe 2:8 (Is 8:14; aliter in LXX; στερεὸν σκανδάλου in Aq.). Metaph., of that which causes error or sin; of persons: Mt 13:41 16:23; Χριστὸς ἐσταυρωμένος, I Co 1:23; of things: Mt 18:7, Ro 11:9 (LXX) Ro 14:13, I Jn 2:10 Re 2:14; τὸ σ. τοῦ σταυροῦ, Ga 5:11; pl., Mt 18:7, Lk 17:1, Ro 16:17.†
anything scooped out, esp. a light boat, skiff: Ac 27:16, 30 27:32.†
the leg from the hip downwards: ?Jo 19:3-33 †
a covering, esp. clothing: I Ti 6:8.†
Sceva: Ac 19:14.†
equipment, tackle: Ac 27:19.†

a vessel, implement (for exx. in various senses, v. MM, xxii): Mk 11:16, Lk 8:16, Jo 19:29, Ac 10:11, 16 11:5, Ro 9:21, Re 18:12; pl., II Ti 2:20, Re 2:27; τὰ σ. τῆς λειτουργίας, He 9:21; pl., τὰ σ., utensils, goods, Mt 12:29, Mk 3:27, Lk 17:31; id. of the tackle or gear of a ship (Xen., Polyb., al.); so in sing., τὸ σ., Ac 27:17. Metaph., of persons: σ. ἐκλογῆς, Ac 9:15; ὀργῆς, Ro 9:22; ἐλέους, Ro 9:23; σ. εἰς τιμήν (cf. Ro 9:21), II Ti 2:21; of woman, ἀσθενέστερον σ., I Pe 3:7; so perh. τ. ἑαυτοῦ σ., I Th 4:4 (but v. infr.); of the body, II Co 4:7; so perh. I Th 4:4 (but v. supr., and v.s. κτάομαι).†

a tent, booth, tabernacle: Mt 17:4, Mk 9:5, Lk 9:33, He 11:9; αἱ αἰώνιοι σ., Lk 16:9; of the Mosaic tabernacle, He 8:5 9:2-3, 6 9:8, 21; σ. τ. μαρτυρίου, Ac 7:44; of its heavenly prototype, He 8:2 9:11, Re 13:6 15:5 21:3; of the temple, He 13:10; ἡ σ. τοῦ Μολόχ, Ac 7:43 (LXX); metaph., ἡ σ. Δαυείδ Ac 15:16 (LXX).†
prop., the setting up of tents or dwellings (Arist.); in LXX and NT, ἡ σ., ἡ ἑορτή τῆς σ. (called also ἑορτὴ σκηνῶν, Le 23:34, al.; v. Deiss., LAE, 116 f.), the feast of Tabernacles: Jo 7:2.†
making tents; as subst., ὁ σ., a tent-maker: Ac 18:3.†
= σκηνή,; a tent, tabernacle (C.1., 3071). Metaph., of the body as the tabernacle of the soul: II Co 5:1 5:4.†

to have one's tabernacle, to dwell (in π. of temporary dwelling, v. MM, Exp., xxii): seq. ἐπί, c. acc pers., Re 7:15; seq. ἐν, c. dat. pers., Jo 1:14; id. c. dat. loc., Re 12:12 13:6; seq. μετά, c. gen. pers., Re 21:3 (cf. ἐπι-, κατα-σκηνόω).†
a tent, tabernacle (cf. σκηνή, σκῆνος): of the temple as God's dwelling (Ps 132:5, al.), Ac 7:46. Metaph., of the body: II Pe 1:13-14.†

shadow, shade, caused by interception of light: Mk 4:32, Ac 5:15; metaph., σ. θανάτου, of ignorance and error, Mt 4:16, Lk 1:79 (LXX).; a shadow, the image or outline cast by an object: fig., ὑπόδειγμα καὶ σ., He 8:5; opp. to σῶμα, Col 2:17; opp. to εἰκών, He 10:1.†
hardness of heart: Mt 19:8, Mk 10:5 16:14.†

hard to the touch, rough, harsh, (opp. to μαλακός); metaph., in various uses; of men, hard, stern, severe: Mt 25:24; of things, hard, rough, violent: σκληρόν σοι (ἐστι), Ac 26:14; λόγος, Jo 6:60; ἄνεμος, Ja 3:4; σκληρὰ λαλεῖν, Ju 15.†
hardness; metaph., of stubbornness: Ro 2:5.†
stiff-necked: metaph., Ac 7:51.†
to harden. Metaph., to harden, make stubborn: c. acc pers., Ro 9:18; T. καρδίας (Ps 95:8), He 3:8, 15 4:7. Pass., to become hardened: Ac 19:9, He 3:13.†
curved, bent, winding (opp. to ὀρθός, εὐθύς): Lk 3:5 (LXX). Metaph., crooked, perverse, unjust: Ac 2:40, Phl 2:15, I Pe 2:18.†

anything pointed, esp.; in cl., a stake; In Hellenistic vernacular, a thorn (cf. LXX, ll. c.): σ. τῇ σαρκί, II Co 12:7 (cf. MM, i., xxiii; DB, iii, 700 f.; Deiss., St. Paul, 62 f.; Field, Notes, 187).†

to look at, behold, watch, contemplate. Metaph., to look to, consider: c. acc rei, II Co 4:13, Phl 2:4; c. acc pers., Ro 16:17, Phl 3:17; seq. μή, Lk 11:35; σεαυτόν, seq. μή (v. M, Pr., 192), Ga 6:1 (cf. ἐπι-, κατα-σκοπέω).†
a watcher, watchman (Ez 3:17, al.).; a mark on which to fix the eye (Wi 5:12, 21, al.). Metaph., of an aim or object: Phl 3:14.†

in vernac. and in Ion, and late writers for σκεδάννυμι (v. MM, xxiii; Rutherford, NPhr., 295), to scatter: ὁ λύκος, Jo 10:12; ὁ μὴ συνάγων μετ' ἐμοῦ σκορπίζει, Mt 12:30, Lk 11:23; pass., seq. εἰς, c. acc loc., Jo 16:32; of one who dispenses blessings, II Co 9:9 (LXX) (of. δια-σκορπίζομαι).†
dark: opp. to φωτεινός, Mt 6:23, Lk 11:34, 36.†
in late writers = σκότος,; darkness: Jo 6:17 20:1. Metaph.,; of secrecy (opp. to ἐν τ. φωτί): Mt 10:27, Lk 12:3; of spiritual darkness: Mt 4:16, Jo 1:5 8:12 12:35, 40, I Jn 1:5 Jn 2:8-9 Jn 2:11.†
to darken; in NT always pass., -ομαι, to be darkened: of the heavenly bodies, Mt 24:29, Mk 13:24, Lk 23:45 (Rec., WH, mg.), Re 8:12. Metaph., of the mind, Ro 1:21 11:10 (LXX) (cf. σκοτόω).†
darkness: He 12:18, Rec.†

darkness: Mt 27:45, Mk 15:33, Lk 22:53 23:44, Ac 2:20, II Co 4:6; τὰ κρυπτὰ τοῦ σ., I Co 4:5; of blindness, Mt 6:23, Ac 13:11; by meton., of a dark place, Mt 8:12 22:13 25:30, II Pe 2:17, Ju 13. Metaph., of moral and spiritual darkness: Lk 11:35, Jo 3:19, Ac 26:18, II Co 6:14, Eph 6:12, Col 1:13, I Pe 2:9; by meton., of those who are in spiritual darkness, Eph 5:8; τ. ἔργα τοῦ σ., Ro 13:12, Eph 5:11; οκότους εἶναι, I Th 5:5; ἐν σ. εἶναι, I Th 5:4; οἱ ἐν σ., Lk 1:79, Ro 2:19; ὁ λαὸς ὁ καθήμενος ἐν σ., Mt 4:16 (LXX) (WH. οκοτίᾳ); ἐν σ. περιπατεῖν, I Jn 1:6.†
to darken: Re 9:2 16:10. Metaph., of the mind! pass., Eph 4:18 (cf. σκοτίζω).†
refuse, esp. dung (v. MM, ii, iii, xxiii): Phl 3:8.†
Scythian, an inhabitant of Scythia, i.e. Russia and Siberia, a synonym with the Greeks for the wildest of barbarians: Col 3:11.†
of a gloomy countenance: Mt 6:16, Lk 24:17.†

in cl., to skin, flay, rend (Æsch., Anthol.).; In Hellenistic writers, to vex, trouble, annoy: c. acc pers., Mk 5:35, Lk 8:49; pass., ἐσκυλμένοι, distressed, Mt 9:36; mid., to trouble oneself, μὴ σκύλλου, Lk 7:6 (freq. in π.; v. MM, i, ii, and cf. M, Pr., 89; Abbott, Essays, 87; Kennedy, Sources, 82).†
mostly in pl., σκίλα, arms stripped from a foe, spoils: Lk 11:22.†
eaten of worms: Ac 12:23 (cf. II Mac 9:9, and v. MM, xxiii) †
a worm: of the kind which preys upon dead bodies, metaph., of fut. punishment, Mk 9:48 (LXX, Is 66:24; cf. Si 7:17, Jth 16:17).†
of emerald (Luc., V.H., ii, 11).; As in π. (Deiss., BS, 267), emerald-green: Re 4:3 (for the construction, v. Swete, in l; Zorell, s.v.).†
emerald or other trans parent green stone (LS, s.v.; DB, iv, 620; Swete, Ap., 67, 288): Re 21:19.†
myrrh, a resinous gum used as an unguent and for em­balming: Mt 2:11, Jo 19:39.†
Smyrna, an Ionian city on the Ægean: Re 1:11 2:8.†; Ζμύρνα, -ης, ἡ,; Re 1:11 2:8 T, for Σμ-, q.v. (cf. B1., § 3, 9; Mayser, 204).†
of Smyrna: Re 2:8, Rec.†
intrans., to be like myrrh (Diosc., i, 79).; Trans., to mingle or drug with myrrh: pass., Mk 15:23.†
