a cinerary urn (Hom.); a coffin (Hdt., i, 68, 3, a1.): Lk 7:14.†
possess. prop. of second pers.,; thy, thine: Mt 7:3, al.; as subst., οἱ σοί, thy kinsfolk, friends, Mk 5:19; τὸ σόν, what is thine, Mt 20:14 25:25; τὰ σά, thy goods, Lk 6:30
handkerchief, kerchief: Lk 19:20, Ac 19:12; used as a head covering for the dead, Jo 11:44 20:7 (cf. Deiss., BS, 223).†
Susanna: Lk 8:3.†

skill, intelligence, wisdom, ranging from knowledge of the arts and matters of daily life to mental excellence in its highest and fullest sense; of human wisdom: I Co 2:1 2:4-5, Ja 3:15, Re 13:18 17:9; σ. Σολομῶνος, Mt 12:42, Lk 11:31; Αἰγυπτίων, Ac 7:22; Ἕλληνες σ. ζητοῦσιν, I Co 1:22; σ. λόγου, I Co 1:17; τ. σοφῶν, I Co 1:19 (LXX); τ. κόσμου, I Co 1:20-21 3:19; ἀνθρωπίνη, I Co 2:13; σαρκική, II Co 1:12; of wisdom in spiritual things: Lk 21:15, Ac 6:3, 10 7:10, I Co 2:6, Col 1:28 2:23 3:16 4:5, Ja 1:5 3:13, 17, II Pe 3:15; λόγος σοφίας, I Co 12:8; πνεῦμα σοφίας, Eph 1:17; σ. καὶ φρόνησις, Eph 1:8; σ. καὶ σύνεσις, Col 1:9; of divine wisdom: of God, Ro 11:33, I Co 1:21 1:24 2:7, Re 7:12; πολυποίκιλος, Eph 3:10; of Christ, Mt 13:54, Mk 6:2, Lk 2:40, 52, I Co 1:30 Col 2:3, Re 5:12; of wisdom personified, Mt 11:19, Lk 7:35 11:49.†

to make wise, instruct: c. acc pers., II Ti 3:15 (cf. Ps 19:8 (Ps 119:98). As depon., -ομαι; intrans., to become wise (III Ki 4:27 (III Ki 5:11), Ec 2:15, and freq. in Si 7:5, al.); trans., to invent, devise cleverly: pass., II Pe 1:16; (cf. κατα-σοφίζομαι).†

skilled, clever, wise, whether in handicraft, the affairs of life, the sciences or learning: Ro 16:19, I Co 3:10; of the learned, Ro 1:14, 22, I Co 1:19-20 1:26-27 3:18-20; of Jewish teachers, Mt 11:25, Lk 10:21; Christian, Mt 23:34; of those en­dowed with practical wisdom, I Co 6:5, Eph 5:15, Ja 3:13; of God, Ro 16:27; compar., τ. μωρὸν τ. θεοῦ σοφώτερον, I Co 1:25.†
to tear, rend, mangle.; to convulse: Mk 1:26 (v. Swete, in l) Mk 9:26, Lk 9:39; (cf. συν-σπαράσσω).†
to swathe, wrap in swaddling-clothes: Lk 2:7, 12 (Hipp., Arist., Plut.).†
to live riotously: I Ti 5:6, Ja 5:5 (Polyb.).†
in cl. poët. for ἕλκω; mostly used in mid. (cf. M, Pr., 157),; to draw: μάχαιραν, Mk 14:47, Ac 16:27,†

(= Lat. spira) anything wound or rolled up, a coil.; As a military term used (by Polyb. and later writers) of a body of soldiers, a maniple (third part of a cohort) or cohort (v. Swete, Mk., 375; Westc., Jo., 251 f.): Mt 27:27, Mk 15:16, Jo 18:3, 12, Ac 10:1 21:31 27:1.†

to sow (seed): absol., Mt 6:26 13:3-4, 18 25:24, 26, Mk 4:3-4, Lk 8:5 12:24, Jo 4:36, II Co 9:10; c. acc rei, Mt 13:24, 27 13:37, 39, Mk 4:32, Lk 8:5, I Co 15:36-37; seq. εἰς, Mt 13:22, Mk 4:18; ἐν, Mt 13:24, 31; ἐπί, c. gen., Mk 4:31; ἐπί, c. acc, Mt 13:20, 23, Mk 4:16, 20; παρά, c. acc, Mt 13:19. Metaph.: I Co 9:11 15:42-44, Ga 6:7-8, Ja 3:18; in proverbial sayings, Mt 25:24, 26, Lk 19:21-22, Jo 4:37, II Co 9:6, Ga 6:7; in interpretation of parables, Mt 13:19-23 Mk 4:14-20 †
prop., a spy or scout.; An executioner: Mk 6:27 (v. Swete, in l).†

to pour out as a drink-offering, make a libation; pass., fig., σπένδομαι, I am poured out or offered as a libation (in the shedding of my life-blood): Phl 2:17 (v. Lft., in l), II Ti 4:6 (for exx. from π., v. Milligan, Selections, 114 f.; MM, xxiii).†

seed; of plants: Mt 13:24, 27 13:37-38, II Co 9:10; pl., Mt 13:32, Mk 4:31, I Co 15:33; metaph., of an escaping remnant (שָׂרִיד, Is 1:9; cf. Wi 14:6; Plat., Tim., 23c; FlJ, Ant., xi, 5, 3), Ro 9:29; of men (as γονή; Lat. semen genitale; so in cl.; cf. in LXX, Le 15:16, al.): He 11:11; metaph., of the divine influence, I Jn 3:9; by meton. (as freq. in poets), seed, offspring, posterity: Mt 22:24-25, Mk 12:19-22, Lk 1:55 20:28 (LXX) Jo 7:42 8:33, 37 Ac 3:25 7:5-6 13:23, Ro 1:3 4:13, 18 9:7-8 11:1, II Co 11:22, Ga 3:16, 19, II Ti 2:8, He 2:16 11:18; pl. (FlJ, Ant., viii, 7, 6; Flat., Leg., ix, 853 c; IV Mac 18:1; in Ga, l.c., contrasted with sing., v. Lft., in l; Milligan, NTD, 105 f.), Ga 3:16; of spiritual offspring, Ro 4:16, 18 9:8, Ga 3:29, Re 12:17.†
a seed picker; prop., of birds (Arist., Aristoph, al.); in Attic slang, of an idler who lives on scraps picked up in the agora; hence, as subst., ὁ σ., an idle babbler: Ac 17:18.†

most freq. intrans., to hasten: c. inf. (as freq. in cl.), Ac 20:16; ptcp. c. indic., Lk 2:16; c. imperat., Lk 19:5-6; σπεῦσον κ. ἔξελθε, Ac 22:18; Trans., c. acc; to hasten, urge on, accelerate (as Hom., Od., xix, 137; Eur., Med., 152; Si 33:8 (Si 36:8): II Pe 3:12, R, mg. (cf. Mayor and ICC, in l, but v. infr.); to desire eagerly (find., Pyth., iii, 110; Eur., Suppl., 161; Isa 165): 2Pe, l.c., R, txt. (but v. supr.).†
a cave, cavern: Jo 11:38, He 11:38, He 6:15; σ. (EV, den) λῃστῶν (Jo 7:11), Mt 21:13, Mk 11:17, Lk 19:46.†

poët. in cl., a rock or reef over which the sea dashes (Polyb., FlJ, al.). Metaph., of men whose conduct causes danger to others, Ju 12, R, txt. (but v. infr.).; In late writers = σπίλος (q.v.), a spot, stain; metaph., Ju, l.c., R, mg. (cf. Mayor, 41, but v. supr.).†

a rock, cliff (Arist., al.).; In late writers = Att.. κηλίς (v. Rutherford, NPhr., 87 f.), a spot, stain; metaph.,; of moral blemish: Eph 5:27; of riotous and lascivious persons (cf. Dion. Hal., quoted by Mayor, in l): II Pe 2:13.†
to stain, spot, defile: c. acc, Ja 3:6, Ju 23.†

to be moved as to the σπλάγχνα (q.v.), hence, to feel pity or compassion: absol., Lk 10:33 15:20; ptcp., σπλαγχνισθείς, c. indic., Mt 18:27 20:34, Mk 1:41; seq. ἐπί, c. dat. pers., Mt 14:14, Lk 7:13; ἐπί, c. acc, Mt 15:32, Mk 6:34 8:2 9:22; ωερί, Mt 9:36. (The word is elsewhere found only in Sm: I Ki 23:21, Ez 24:21, Test. Zeb., 4:6-7; v. Thayer, s.v.; MM, xxiii quote Thumb, Hellen., 123 as practically confirming Lft. on Phl 1:8, in the suggestion that the verb was a coinage of the Jewish dispersion.) †

the inward parts (heart, liver, lungs, etc.; Lat. viscera): Ac 1:18. Metaph., of the seat of the feelings and of the feelings themselves (in Gk. poets, of anger, anxiety, etc.), the heart, affections (the characteristic LXX and NT reference of the word to feelings of kindness, benevolence and pity, is found in π.; v. MM, xxiii; cf. Lft. on Phl 1:8): II Co 6:12 7:15, Phm 7 12 20, I Jn 3:17; σ. οἰκτιρμοῦ, Col 3:12; σ. καὶ οἰκτιρμοὶ, Phl 2:1; σ. ἐλέους θεοῦ; ἡμῶν, Lk 1:78; σ. Χριστοῦ Ἰησοῦ, Phl 1:8.†
ashes: He 9:13; ἐν σάκκῳ καὶ σ. (Is 58:5, Jo 3:6, Da LXX 9:3, al.), Mt 11:21, Lk 10:13.†
a sowing.; seedtime.; seed sown (of human offspring, Soph., Tr., 316, 420): I Pe 1:23; (cf. σπέρμα, and v. Milligan, NTD, 105 f.).†
fit for sowing, sown; as subst., τὰ σ., corn-fields: Mt 12:1, Mk 2:23, Lk 6:1.†
= σπορά,; sowing or seedtime.; seed sown (so usually in late Gk.): Mk 4:26-27, Lk 8:5, 11, II Co 9:10 a (LTr.); metaph., of almsgiving, II Co 9:10 b.†

to make haste; hence, to be zealous or eager, to give diligence: c. inf. (v. M, Pr., 205 f.), Ga 2:10, Eph 4:3, I Th 2:17, II Ti 2:15 4:9 4:21, Tit 3:12, He 4:11, II Pe 1:10 3:14; c. acc et inf. (on this construction v. Mayor in l; MM, xxiii), II Pe 1:15 (for other constructions v. LS, s.v.).†
in haste; hence, zealous, eager, diligent, earnest: seq. ἐν, II Co 8:22; compar., -οτεροσς II Co 8:17 (here in superl. sense, v. Bl., § 44, 3) II Co 8:22.†

with haste or zeal, i.e. earnestly, zealously, diligently: Lk 7:4, II Ti 1:17, Tit 3:13; compar., -οτέρως, Phl 2:28 (RV, Lft., Weymouth, al., but v. infr.); hastily, speedily: compar., -οτέρως, Phl 2:28 (Thayer, Zorell, s.v.; ICC, in l, al., but v. supr.).†

haste, speed: μετὰ σ. (Wi 19:2), Mk 6:25, Lk 1:39.; zeal, diligence, earnestness: Ro 12:11, II Co 7:11-12 8:7-8; ἐν σ., Ro 12:8 (v. M, Pr, 104); seq. ὑπέρ, II Co 8:16; σπουδὴν ἐνδείκνυσθαι, He 6:11; σ. παρεισφέρειν, II Pe 1:5; πᾶσαν σ. ποιεῖσθαι, Ju 3 (v. MM, xxiii; M, Pr., 214; Deiss., BS, 361, 364).†

a stadium, i.e.; a measure of length = 600 Greek feet or 1⁄8 of a Roman mile Mt 14:24 (Rec., WH, txt., R, mg.), Lk 24:13, Jo 6:19 11:18, Re 14:20 21:16, and, this being the length of the Olympic course,; a race-course: I Co 9:24.†
prop., an earthen jar for racking off wine, hence, generally, a jar: He 9:4.†
= Att.. στασιώτης,; a rebel, revolutionist, one who stirs up sedition: Mk 15:7 (FlJ, al.).†

a standing, place, status: σ. ἔχειν (Polyb., v, 5, 3; and cf. Lat. locum habere), He 9:8.; insurrection, sedition: Mk 15:7, Lk 23:19, 25, Ac 19:40 24:5.; In poets and late prose, strife, dissension (cf. MM, xxiii) Ac 15:2 23:7, 10.†
a stater; a weight; a coin (used by late writers of the Greek τετράδραχμον): Mt 17:27 26:16, WH, mg.†

an upright pale or stake (Hom., Hdt., Thuc., al.); In late writers (Diod., Plut., al.) of the Roman instrument of crucifixion, the Cross: of the Cross on which Christ suffered, Mt 27:32, 40 27:42, Mk 15:21, 30 15:32, Lk 23:26, Jo 19:17, 19 19:25, 31, Col 2:14, He 12:2; θάνατος σταυροῦ, Phl 2:8; τ. αἷμα τοῦ σ., Col 1:20. Metaph., in proverbial sayings: αἴρειν (λαμβάνειν, βαστάζειν) τὸν σ., Mt 10:38 16:24, Mk 8:34 10:21, 15:21, Lk 9:23 14:27 (for an interesting ex. of metaph. use in π., v. MM, xxiii) By meton., for Christ's death on the Cross: I Co 1:17, Ga 5:11 6:12, 14, Eph 2:16, Phl 3:18; ὁ λόγος ὁ τοῦ σ., I Co 1:18.†

to fence with pales, impalisade (Thuc.).; In late writers (Polyb., FlJ; but ἀνασταυρόω is more common) to crucify: c. acc pers., Mt 20:19 23:34 26:2 27:22 ff. Mt 28:5, Mk 15:16 ff. Mk 16:6, Lk 23:21, 23 23:33 24:7, 20, Jo 19:6 ff., Ac 2:36 4:10, I Co 1:13 1:23 2:2 2:8, II Co 13:4, Ga 3:1, Re 11:8; metaph., Ga 5:24 6:14.†

a bunch of grapes: Mt 7:16, Lk 6:44, Re 14:18. "σ. is properly the ripe grape-cluster as opp. to ὄμφαξ, cf. Ge 40:10, Jb 15:33; as contrasted with βότρυς, it describes the grapes rather than the cluster on which they grow" (Swete, Apoc., 187 f.).†
an ear of corn: Mt 12:1, Mk 2:23 4:28, Lk 6:1.†
Stachys: Ro 16:9 (v. Lft., Phi., 174; MM, xxiii).†
a roof: Mk 2:4; of entering a house, εἰσέρχεσθαι ὑπὸ τὴν σ., Mt 8:8, Lk 7:6 (cf. MM, xxiii).†

prop., to cover closely, to protect by covering, esp. to keep water in or out (Soph., Plat., al.).; to cover, keep secret, conceal (Sir, l.c., Polyb., al.): I Co 13:7, R, mg.; By covering to ward of, bear up under, endure (for exx., v., Lft., Notes, 40; M, Th., 36): I Co 9:12 13:7, I Th 3:1 3:5.†
barren: of a woman, Lk 1:7, 36 23:29, Ga 4:27 (LXX).†

prop., to set, place, arrange, fit out; hence, mid., to set oneself for, prepare (Wis, xi Mac, ll. c.).; to bring together, gather up (in Hom. of furling sails), hence to restrain, check; mid., to restrain or withdraw oneself, hold aloof, avoid: II Co 8:20; seq. ἀπό, II Th 3:6; (cf. ἀπο-, ἐξ-απο-, συν-απο-, δια-, ἐπι-, κατα-, συ(ν)-, ὑπο-στέλλω).†
a wreath, garland: as used in sacrifices, Ac 14:13.†
a groaning: Ac 7:34 (LXX κραυγή), Ro 8:26.†
to groan ("the word denotes feeling which is internal and unexpressed," Mayor, Ja., 162): Mk 7:34, II Co 5:2 5:4, He 13:17, Ja 5:9 (EV, murmur); ἐν ἑαυτοῖς, Ro 8:23 (cf. ἀνα-, συ(ν)-στενάζω).†
narrow: fig (v MM, xxiii), Mt 7:13-14, Lk 13:24.†
to be straitened (cf. Is 49:19); metaph., to be anxious (Hipp., al.).; In late writers, trans., to straiten, compress (LXX, Diod., al.; π. ap. MM, xxiii): pass., trop., II Co 4:8 6:12.†

narrowness of space, want of room (Thuc., al.). Metaph. (Ken., Polyb., De 28:53, Wi 5:3, al.), difficulty, distress: θλίψις καὶ (ἢ) σ., Ro 2:9 8:35 (EV, anguish); pl. (cf. Bl., § 32, 6; WM, 220), II Co 6:4 12:10.†
hard, firm, solid: τροψή, He 5:12, 14; θεμέλιος, fig., II Ti 2:19. Metaph.,; in bad sense, hard, cruel (Hom., al.); in good sense, steadfast, firm: τ. πίστει, I Pe 5:9.†
to make firm or solid; to strengthen, make strong; c. acc pers., Ac 3:16; τ. βάσεις, pass., Ac 3:7. Metaph. (cf. Je, l.c.): τ. πίστει, pass., Ac 16:5.†

a solid body; a support, foundation (Arist., al.); metaph., strength (Ps 17:1-15 70:1-5, 1Mac, ll. c.); steadfastness, firmness: τ. πίστεως, Col 2:5; the dome of heaven (believed to be a solid canopy), the firmament (LXX).†
Stephanas: I Co 1:16 16:15 16:17.†

that which surrounds or encompasses (as a wall, a crowd: Hom., al.).; a crown, i.e. the wreath, garland or chaplet given as a prize for victory, as a festal ornament, or as a public honour for disting­uished service or personal worth (so to sovereigns, especially on the occasion of a παρουσία, q.v.; cf. Deiss., LAE, 372 ff.; on its use in LXX for the golden crown of royalty (prop., διάδημα, q.v., cf. Hort and Mayor on Ja 1:12): Mt 27:29, Mk 15:17, Jo 19:2, 5, I Co 9:25, Re 4:4, 10 6:2 9:7 12:1 14:14. Metaph.: Phl 4:1, Re 3:11; τ. δικαιοσύνης (cf. Deiss., LAE, 312), II Ti 4:8; τ. δόξης, I Pe 5:4; καυχήσεως, I Th 2:19 (v. M, Th., in l); τ. ζωῆς (gen. appos.), Ja 1:12, Re 2:10.†
c. acc pers.,; to crown: of a victor, II Ti 2:5. Metaph., δόξῃ κ. τιμῇ, He 2:7, 9 (LXX).†
the breast: Jo 13:25 21:10, Re 15:6; as a sign of penitence, τύπτειν (εἰς) τὸ σ., Lk 18:13 23:48,†

= ἵστημι, to stand: Mk 3:31 11:25, Jo 1:26, Re 12:4 (ἕστηκεν T). Metaph., to stand firm, stand fast: absol., Ga 5:1 (but v. Field, Notes, 189 f.), II Th 2:15; seq. ἐν, Jo 8:44 (ἕστηκεν, T, R, mg.), I Co 16:13, Phl 1:27 4:1; c. dat., Ro 14:4.†
a setting firmly, supporting.; fixedness, firmness, steadfastness: II Pe 3:17.†

to fix, set fast, make fast: Lk 16:26; τ. πρόσωτον (Ez 6:2 13:17, al.; v. Dalman, Words, 30 f.), Lk 9:51. Metaph., to confirm, establish: c., acc, Lk 22:32, Ac 18:23, Ro 1:11 16:25, I Th 3:2 3:13, II Th 3:3, Ja 5:8, I Pe 5:10, Re 3:2; id. seq. ἐν, II Th 2:17, II Pe 1:12.†
a litter of leaves or rushes: pl., Mk 11:8 (Rec. στοιβ-).†
a tattoed mark or brand: τὰ σ. τοῦ Ἰησοῦ, Ga 6:17 (v. Lft., in l; Deiss., BS, 349; LAE, 303; MM, xxiii).†
a prick, a point; metaph., σ. χρόνου, a moment: Lk 4:5.†
to shine, glisten: Mk 9:3.†
a portico: Jo 5:2; used of the covered colonnade in the Temple (EV, porch), Jo 10:23 Ac 3:11 5:12 †

prop., one of a row (στοῖχος) or series, hence,; the shadow-line of a dial (Aristoph.).; an elementary sound or letter of the alphabet (Anth., Plut., π.).; the elements or rudiments of knowledge (Arist., al.) He 5:12; πτωχὰ σ., Ga 4:9; σ. τοῦ κόσμου, Ga 4:3, Col 2:8, 20 (but v. infr.).; The material elements of the universe (Plat.; LXX, ll. c.): II Pe 3:10 3:12.; The heavenly bodies (Ding. Laert.).; The demons or tutelary spirits of nature (Enoch., Test., Sol., al.; for this sense in Ga, Col, ll. c., v. ICC on Col 2:8; Enc. Bibl., s.v. " Elements ").†

to be in rows (of waves, plants, etc., as well as of men), to walk in line (esp. of marching in file to battle; Xen., Cyr., vi, 3, 34, al.). Metaph., in late writers, to walk by rule: Ac 21:24; c. dat., to walk by or in (as a rule of life), Ro 4:12 (cf. MM, xxiii), Ga 5:25 6:16, Phl 3:16 (cf. συν-στοιχέω).†
1, an equipment, an armament (Æsch.).; Equipment in clothes, apparel, esp. flowing raiment, a festal robe: (cf. Jh 3:6, Es 8:15, I Mac 6:15): Mk 12:38 16:5, Lk 15:22 20:46, Re 6:11 7:9, 13-14 22:14.†

the mouth: of man, Mt 15:11, Jo 19:29, Ac 11:8, al.; of animals, Mt 17:27, II Ti 4:17 (fig.), He 11:33, Ja 3:3, al.; fig., of inanimate things (ποταμοῦ, Hom.), ἤνοιξεν ἡ γῆ τὸ σ., Re 12:16; σ. μαχαίρας (Heb. חֶרֶב ־פֶּה, Ge 34:26 al.), the edge of the sword, Lk 21:24, He 11:34; esp. of the mouth as the organ of speech: opp. to καρδία, Mt 12:34, Ro 10:8, 10; in various phrases (some cl., some resembling Hebrew; cf. Bl., § 40, 9): ἀνοίγειν τ. σ. (v.s. ἀνοίγω); σ. πρὸς σ. (פֶּה ־אֵל פֶּה Nu 12:8; = cl., κατὰ σ., Hdt., al.), face to face, II Jn 12, III Jn 14; διὰ τοῦ σ. (of the Holy Spirit), Lk 1:70, Ac 1:16, al.; ἀπὸ (ἐκ) τοῦ σ. (cf. ἀπὸ σ. εἰπεῖν, Plat., al.), of speaking by word of mouth, Lk 22:71, Ac 22:14; δόλος (ψεῦδος) ἐν τ. σ., I Pe 2:22, Re 14:5 (LXX); metaph., ἡ ῥομφαία τοῦ σ., Re 2:16. By meton., for speech (Soph.): Mt 18:16 (LXX), Lk 19:22 21:15, II Co 13:1
prop., a mouth, an opening; in early Gk. writers, the throat; of the opening of the stomach (Arist.); in later writers (Plut., al.), the stomach: I Ti 5:23.†
an expedition, a campaign, warfare: metaph., II Co 10:4 (-τιά, T), I Ti 1:18.†
= στρατεία (Hdt., al.).; an army, a host: pl., Mt 22:7, Re 9:16 19:14, 19; = soldiers, company of soldiers, Ac 23:10, 27; pl., Lk 23:11.†

used of the general, to make war, do battle, and (chiefly) of the soldiers serving under him, to serve as a soldier: Lk 3:14, I Co 9:7, II Ti 2:4. Metaph. (cf. MM, ii, xxiii), of spiritual conflict, to war, make war: II Co 10:3, I Ti 1:18, Ja 4:1, I Pe 2:11.†

a military commander, a general (Hdt., al.).; A civic commander, a governor, magistrate (Hdt., Xen., al.): Ac 16:20, 22 16:35-36, 38.; The commander of the Levitical guard of the Temple, ὁ σ. τ. ἱεροῦ (EV, captain of the Temple): Ac 4:1 5:24, 26; pl., Lk 22:4, 52.†
= στρατός, an army, a host: of angels (III Ki 22:19, al.), Lk 2:13; of the stars of heaven (Je 8:2, II Ch 33:3), Ac 7:42.; As sometimes in cl. (poët.), = στρατεία: II Co 10:4, T (WH, RV, στρατεία).†
a soldier: Mt 8:9, Mk 15:16, Jo 19:2, Ac 10:7, al.; metaph., σ. Χριστοῦ Ἰησ., II Ti 2:3.†
to levy a troop, enlist soldiers: II Ti 2:4 (Diod., Plut., al.).†
στρατοπεδάρχης, v.s. στρατοπέδαρχος
a military camp; an army: Lk 21:20.†
to twist, torture. Metaph. (cf. 2Ki, l.c.), to twist or pervert language: II Pe 3:16.†

to turn: c. acc rei dat. pers., Mt 5:39; = ἀποσ-, to bring back, Mt 27:3 (cf. Is 38:8); reflexively (WM, § 38, 1), to turn oneself, Ac 7:42; c. acc seq. εἰς, = μετασ-, to change, Re 11:6. Pass., reflexive, to turn oneself: seq. εἰς, Jo 20:14, Ac 7:39 13:46; ptcp., στραφείς, c. indic., Mt 7:6 9:22 16:23, Lk 7:9 9:55 14:25 22:61, Jo 1:38 20:16; id. seq. πρός, Lk 7:44 10:22 (WH, R, om.), Lk 7:23 23:28; metaph., to change: absol., Mt 18:3, Jo 12:40 (cf. ἀνα-, ἀπο-, δια-, ἐκ, ἐπι-, κατα-, μετα-, συ(ν)-, ὑπο-στρέφω).†
a word which first appears in the middle comedy (Rutherford, NPhr., 475 f.), to run riot, wax wanton: Re 18:7-9 (cf. κατα-στρηνιάω).†
insolent luxury, wantonness: Re 18:3 (a late word, first found in a Comic poet, B.C. 300, v. Kennedy, Sources, 41, cf. στρηνιάω).†
dimin. of στρουθός; a sparrow: Mt 10:29, 31, Lk 12:6-7.†

to spread: ἱμάτια ἐν τ. ὁδῷ (εἰς τ. ὁδόν), Mt 21:8, Mk 11:8; of making a bed, στρῶσον (sc. τ. κλίνην) σεαυτῷ, Ac 9:34; of furnishing a room, ἐστρωμένον, spread with carpets or carpeted couches (cf. Ez 23:41), Mk 14:15, Lk 22:12.†
hated, hateful: Tit 3:3.†
to have a sombre, gloomy appearance: of the human countenance (RV, his countenance fell), Mk 10:22; of the sky (so στυγνότης, Polyb., iv, 21, 1), Mt 16:3 ([WH], R, mg., om.).†
a pillar, regarded especially as a support: σ. πυρός, Re 10:1; σ. ἐν τ. ναῷ, fig., Re 3:12, Metaph., Ga 2:9; τ. ἀληθείας, I Ti 3:15.†
Stoic: Ac 17:18.†

thou, you, gen., σοῦ, dat., σοί, acc., σέ, pl., ὑμεῖς, -ῶν, -ῖν, -ᾶς (enclitic in oblique cases sing., except after prep. (BL, §48, 3), though πρὸς σέ occurs in Mt 25:39). Nom. for emphasis or contrast: Jo 1:30, 4:10, 5:33, 39, 44, Ac 4:7, Eph 5:32; so also perhaps σὺ εἶπας, Mt 26:64, al. (M, Pr., 86); before voc., Mt 2:6, Lk 1:76, Jo 17:5, al.; sometimes without emphasis (M, Pr., 85f.), as also in cl., but esp. as rendering of Heb. phrase, e.g. υἱός μου εἶ σύ (בְּנִי־אַתָּה, Ps 2:7), Ac 13:33. The gen. (σοῦ, ὑμῶν) is sometimes placed bef. the noun: Lk 7:48, 12:30, al.; so also the enclitic σοῦ, Mt 9:6; on τί ἐμοὶ κ. σοί, v.s. ἐγώ.
kinship.; By meton., kinsfolk, kindred: Lk 1:61, Ac 7:3, 14 †
congenital, natural, innate. akin to; as subst., a kinsman: Mk 6:4, Lk 1:58 2:44 14:12 21:16, Jo 18:26, Ac 10:24; of tribal kinship, Ro 9:3 16:7, 11 16:21.†
late fem. form of σνγγενής, q.v.,; a kinswoman: Lk 1:36.†
chance, coincidence: κατὰ σ. (v. MM, xxiii), Lk 10:31 (Hippocr., Eccl.).†
confusion: of a popular uproar, Ac 19:29.†
the mulberry tree; the sycamine: Lk 17:6. (In LXX, σ. appears to represent the συκόμορος (v.s. συκομορέα), but St. Luke distinguishes between the two; v. ICC, in l; DB, iv, 634.) †
a fig-mulberry, a sycamore: Lk 19:4 (cf. συκάμινος).†

to act the συκοφάντης (on conjectures as to the origin of the term, v. LS, s.v.), to accuse falsely (Aristoph., Xen., al.): Lk 3:14 (R, mg.) Lk 19:8 (RV, exact wrongfully; but cf. Hatch, Essays, 89 ff., v. also Field, Notes, 56 f.; MM, xxiv).†
to carry off as spoil, lead captive (θυγατέρα, Heliod., Aeth., 10, 35): metaph., Col 2:8.†
c. acc pers., to strip, plunder, spoil: II Co 11:8.†

c. acc, to bring together, collect.; to seize, take: c. acc pers., as a prisoner, Mt 26:55, Mk 14:48, Lk 22:54, Jo 18:12, Ac 1:16 12:3; pass., Ac 23:27; mid., in sense of act., Ac 26:21; σ. ἄγραν ἰχθύων, Lk 5:9.; C. dat. pers., to take part with, assist, succour; mid., in same sense: Lk 5:7, Phl 4:3.; Of a woman, to conceive: absol., Lk 1:24; seq. ἐν γαστρί, Lk 1:31; c. acc, Lk 1:36; ib. seq. ἐν τ. κοιλίᾳ, Lk 2:21; metaph., of lust producing sin, Ja 1:15.†
to bring together, collect, gather up: c. acc rei, Mt 13:28-30; pass., Mt 13:40; c. acc, seq. ἀπό, Mt 7:16; id. seq. ἐκ, Mt 13:41, Lk 6:44; seq. εἰς, Mt 13:48.†
to compute.; to reason: Lk 20:5.†

to stand with the feet together.; to come together, come to terms.; Of events, to come to pass, happen: c. dat. pers., Mk 10:32, Ac 3:10 20:19, I Co 10:11, I Pe 4:12, II Pe 2:22; absol., τὰ σνμβεβηκότα, Lk 24:14 (cf. I Mac 4:26); c. acc et nf., Ac 21:35.†
to advise, counsel: c. dat. pers., Jo 18:14; id. seq. inf., Re 3:18.; Mid., to take counsel, consult: seq. ἵνα, Mt 26:4 ("reciprocal middle," v. M, Pr., 157); c. inf., Ac 9:23.†

a word of the Græco-Roman period (of. Lat. consilium, and v. Deiss., BS, 238) = cl. συμβουλία (Arist., Xen.),; counsel: σ. λαμβάνειν, Mt 12:14 22:15 27:7 28:12; διδόναι, Mk 3:6 (ποιεῖν, Rec.); ποιεῖν, Mk 15:1 (ἑτοιμάζειν, WH, mg.).; By meton., a council (4Mac, l.c. א; συνέδριον, AR): Ac 25:12 (v. MM, xxiv).†
a counsellor, adviser: Ro 11:34 (LXX).†

Simeon (so always AV; RV in Lk 2:25, 34 only), Symeon, a Heb. name for which the Gk. Σίμων, q.v., was also used; the son of Jacob (Ge 29:33): Re 7:7.; An ancestor of our Lord: Lk 3:30; An aged worshipper in the Temple: Lk 2:25, 34.; One surnamed Niger: Ac 13:1.; The apostle Peter: Ac 15:14, II Pe 1:1 (R, txt., WH, txt., Σίμων).†
to conform to: pass. ptcp., Phl 3:10 (v. Lft., Phi., 128).†
absol., similar (Luc.).; con­formed to: c. dat., Phl 3:21; c. gen., Ro 8:29 (v. B1., § 36, 11; 37, 6).†
Rec. for -ίζω (q.v.), Phl 3:10.†
affected by like feelings, sympathetic: I Pe 3:8.; exciting sympathy (Jb, l.c.; Dion. H.).†
Rec, for παρα-μένω (q.v.), Phl 1:25.†
a drinking party; By meton., of the party itself, the guests (Plut); pl., σ. σ. (colloq.; v. M, Pr., 97), in parties or companies: Mk 6:39.†

trans. to bring together: c. acc rei, Ac 19:19.; Intrans., and mostly impers., συμφέρει, it is expedient, profitable or an advantage: I Co 6:12 10:23, II Co 8:10; c. inf. (M, Pr., 210), Mt 19:10, Jo 18:14; c. dat., seq. ἵνα (Bl., § 69, 5), Mt 5:29-30 18:6, Jo 11:50 16:7. Ptcp., ςυμφέρων, profitable: I Co 12:7; pl., Ac 20:20; (οὐ σ. sc. ἐστιν; = οὐ συμφέρει; cf. Thuc., iii, 44, 2), II Co 12:1; as subst., τὸ σ., profit, He 12:10.†
profitable, useful, expedient. As subst., τὸ σ. (in cl. usually pl., τὰ σ.), advantage, profit: c. gen. pers., I Co 7:35 10:33.†
a fellow-tribesman, fellow-countryman: I Th 2:14 (v. M, Th., in l, and Intr. liii). Not found elsewhere.†
congenital, innate (Plat., al.; 3Mac, l.c.).; grown along with, united with: τ. ὁμοιώματι τ. θανάτου αὐτσῦ (v. Field, Notes, 155 f.), Ro 6:5.†

prop., to agree in sound, be in harmony (Plat., Arist.). Metaph.,; to agree with, agree together: Lk 5:36; c. dat. rei, Ac 15:15; seq. περί, Mt 18:19; pass., c. dat. pers., συνεφωνήθη ὑμῖν, Ac 5:9; to agree as to a price (Polyb., Diod.): c. dat. pers., gen. pret., Mt 20:13; seq. μετά . . . ἐκ, Mt 20:2.†
concord, agreement: seq. πρός, c. acc pers., II Co 6:15.†
symphony, music: Lk 15:25; a musical instrument (Polyb., al.; Da, ll. c.; v MM, xxiv).†
agreeing in sound. Metaph., harmonious, agreeing: ἐκ συμφώνου (for exx. from π., v. Deiss., BS, 255), by agreement, I Co 7:5.†
to reckon together, count up: Ac 19:19.†

expressing association, fellowship and inclusion. It gradually gave way to μετά, c. gen. (cf. LS, s.v.; Bl., §41, 3), and is therefore comparatively infrequent in NT, being rare in Mt 4, Mk 6, Jo 3, and elsewhere (exx. Ja 1:11, II Pe 1:18) only in Lk (Gosp. and Ac) and Paul. With, together with: of companionship and association, Lk 2:13, Jo 21:3, Ac 10:23, al.; εἶναι σύν τινι, Lk 7:12, Ac 4:13, Phl 1:23, al.; of partisanship, Ac 4:13; οἱ σύν τινι, of attendants, companions or colleagues, Mk 2:26, Lk 5:9, Ac 5:17, al.; of assistance, ἡ χάρις τ. θεοῦ σὺν ἐμοί, I Co 15:10; of two or more things together, almost = καί, Lk 23:11, Ac 3:4 10:2 14:5 23:25, Eph 3:18; σὺν Χριστῷ ζῆν, II Co 13:4; besides (FlJ, LXX), σὺν πᾶσι τούτοις, Lk 24:21. In composition: with (συνχαίρω), together (συνωδίνω), altogether (συντελέω)

to gather or bring together: of things, Jo 6:12-13; seq. εἰς, Mt 3:12, al.; ἐκεῖ, Lk 12:18; ποῦ, Lk 12:17; συναγαγὼν πάντα (sc. εἰς ἀργύριον; v. Field, Notes, 68, MM, xxiv), having sold off all: Lk 15:13; of persons, Jo 11:52; esp. of assemblies, Mt 2:4, Jo 11:47, Ac 14:27, al. Pass., to be gathered or come together: Mt 22:41, Mk 2:2, Lk 22:66, al.; seq. ἐπί Mk 5:21, Ac 4:27; πρός, Mt 13:2, Mk 4:1, al.; εἰς, Re 19:17; ἐν, Ac 11:26; μετά, Mt 28:12; οὗ, Mt 18:20; ὅπου, Mt 26:57; ἐκεῖ, Jo 18:2, al.; In late writers (v. Kennedy, Sources, 128; cf. De 22:2, al.), to receive hospitably, entertain: Mt 25:35, 38 25:43 (cf. ἐπι-συνάγω)

prop., a bringing together; of things,; a gathering in of harvest; a collection of money.; Of persons,; a collecting, assembling (Polyb.); an assembly (MM, xxiv; Deiss., LAE, 101 ff.): Re 2:9 3:9; esp. of a Jewish religious assembly, a synagogue: Lk 12:11, Ac 9:2, al.; of a Christian assembly, Ja 2:2. By meton., of the building in which the assembly is held, a synagogue: Mt 10:17, Mk 1:21, al. (cf. Cremer, s.v. ἐκκλησία)
to strive together with, to help (prop., of sharing in a contest): c. dat. pers. et rei, Ro 15:30.†
= συναγωνίζομαι: c. dat. commod., Phl 1:27; c. dat. pers., seq. ἐν, Phl 4:3.†
to gather together, assemble: c. acc pers., Ac 19:25; pass., Ac 12:12.†; ἀθροίζω; to Gather, assemble: Lk 24:33.†
to take up together: σ. λόγον (of which there are several exx. in π.; v. Deiss., LAE, 118 f.; MM, i, xxiv; M, Pr., 160), to settle accounts, Mt 18:23-24; seq. μετά, C. gen. pers., Mt 25:19.†
a fellow prisoner (prop., of a captive in war, v. Lft., Col., 234): Ro 16:7, Col 4:10, Phm 23.†
to follow along with, accompany: c. dat. pers., Mk 14:51, Lk 23:49; seq. μετά, c. gen. pers., Mk 5:37.†
to assemble with: Ac 1:4 (EV, mg., eating with, but on this rendering and on the force of the Pres. ptcp. here, v. Field, Notes, 110).†
to reconcile: impf. (conative, v. M, Pr., 129), Ac 7:26.†
to go up with: c. dat. pers., seq. εἰς, c. acc loc., Mk 15:41, Ac 13:31.†
to recline with or together at table: Mt 14:9, Mk 6:22, Lk 7:49 14:15; c. dat. pers., Mt 9:10, Mk 2:15, Lk 14:10.†
to mix up together; pass., reflex, and metaph., to associate with (Plut., Ath., al.): I Co 5:9 5:11, II Th 3:14 (v. M, Th., 117).†
c. dat. pers., to lie down to rest with, sleep with. Metaph., to be refreshed in spirit with: Ro 15:32 (L, om.).†
to meet with: c. dat. pers., Lk 9:18, 37 22:10, Ac 10:25, He 7:1, 10. Metaph., of events, to happen, befall (Ding. L., Plut., al.): Ac 20:22.†
Rec. for ὑπάντησις (q.v.), Mt 8:34.†

to take hold with at the side for assistance; hence, to take a share in, help in bearing, and generally, help (with various constructions, v. LXX, ll. c., Deiss., LAE, 83 f.): c. dat., Lk 10:40, Ro 8:26.†

to lead away with or together (Ex, l.c.). Pass., metaph. (as συμπεριφέρομαι, v. LS, s.v.), to be carried away with: c. dat., Ga 2:13, II Pe 3:17; of accommodating one­self to (EV, condescend to) things or persons (on the meaning, v. ICC, in I.; Field, Notes, 163), Ro 12:16.†
to die with or together: Mk 14:31, II Co 7:3 (v. Meyer, in l), II Ti 2:11.†
to destroy with or together. Pass., to perish together (with): c. dat. pers., He 11:31.†
to send along with: c. acc, II Co 12:18 (cf. MM, xxiv).†
to fit or frame together: of the parts of a building, Eph 2:21; of the members of the body, Eph 4:16 (Eccl.).†
"perfective " of ἁοπάζω (v. M, Pr., 113),; to seize and carry away (so most commonly) : Ac 27:15; to seize and hold: Lk 8:29, Ac 6:12 19:29.†
to cause to increase or grow together. Pass., to grow together: Mt 13:30 (Xen., al.).†

to throw together, hence,; of speech (seq. λόγους, Eur., al.), to discuss, confer (sc. λόγους): c. dat. pers., Lk 11:53, WH, mg., Ac 17:18; seq. πρὸς ἀλλήλους, Ac 4:15; to reflect, consider, ponder: ἐν τ. καρδίᾳ, Lk 2:19; to meet with, fall in with: Ac 20:14; in hostile sense, εἰς πόλεμον, c. dat. (εἰς μάχην, Polyb.), Lk 14:31; mid., to contribute (Polyb., al.; cf. MM, xxiv): Ac 18:27.†
to reign together or with: metaph., of sharing the glories of the Kingdom of God, I Co 4:8, II Ti 2:12.†

to join or knit together, unite: Eph 4:16, Col 2:2 (but v. infr.), Col 2:19.; to compare, consider, conclude (Plat.): Ac 16:10.; to deduce, prove, demonstrate (Arist.): Ac 9:22.; As in LXX ("translation Greek," = ἐμβιβάζω, metaph.), to teach, instruct: I Co 2:16 Ac 19:33, R, mg. (also in Vg., Col 2:2, instructi, but v. supr.).†
confession.; fellow feeling; hence, concession, allowance: I Co 7:6 (v. ICC, in l).; pardon.†
that which binds together, a bond: of the ligaments of the body, Col 2:19. Metaph., σ. ἀδικίας, Ac 8:23; τ. τελειότητος, Col 3:14; τ. εἰρήνης, Eph 4:3 (v. Lft., Col., ll. c.).†
to bind together; to bind together with: pass., He 13:3.†
to join in approving (Arist.).; In NT only, to glorify together: pass., Ro 8:17.†
a fellow-servant: Mt 18:28-33 24:49; of servants of the same divine Lord, Col 1:7 4:7, Re 6:11; so of angels, Re 19:10 22:9.†
concourse, esp. of a riotous gathering: Ac 21:30 (Arist., Polyb., al.).†
to raise together: metaph., of the Christian's mystical resur­rection with Christ, Eph 2:6; pass., Col 2:12 3:1.†

a council (Plat., Xen., al.; LXX; in π., σ. τ. πρεσβυτέρων, Deiss., BS, 156): of a local Jewish tribunal, Mt 10:17, Mk 13:9.; The supreme ecclesiastical court of the Jews, the Sanhedrin (i.e. Talmudic סַנְהֵדְרִין = συνέδριον): Mt 5:22 26:59, Mk 14:55 15:1, Lk 22:66, Ac 5:21, 27 5:34, 41 6:12, 15 22:30 23:1, 6 23:15, 20 23:28 (WH, R, mg., om.) Ac 24:20 of a meeting of the Sanhedrin, Jo 11:47; of the place of meeting, Ac 4:15.†

consciousness: c. gen. obj., He 10:2, I Pe 2:19.; In ethical sense, innate discernment, self-judging consciousness, conscience (Stoics and late writers): Ro 2:15 9:1, I Co 10:29, II Co 1:12 4:2 5:11, I Ti 4:2, He 9:14; σ. ἀγαθή, Ac 23:1, I Ti 1:5 1:19, I Pe 3:16 3:21; ἀσθενής, I Co 8:7 8:10; ἀσθενοῦσα, I Co 8:12; ἀπρόσκοπος, Ac 24:16; καθαρά, I Ti 3:9, II Ti 1:3; καλή, He 13:18; πονηρά, He 10:22; ὁ νοῦς καὶ ἡ σ., Tit 1:15; διὰ τὴν σ., Ro 13:5, I Co 10:25 10:27-28; κατὰ σ., He 9:9; ὑπὸ (τῆς) σ., Jo 8:1-59 [9] (Rec.), I Co 10:29 (cf. Cremer, 233 ff.; ICC on Ro 2:15; DB, i, 468 ff.).†

to see together or at the same time (Arist., Xen.).; to see in one view, hence, of mental vision, to comprehend, understand (LXX, Polyb., Plut., al.) : Ac 12:12 14:6 (on the related σύνοιδα, v. s.v.).†
to come together: Lk 8:4.†
to be with: Lk 9:18 (WH, mg., συνήντησαν), Ac 22:11.†
to enter together: c. dat. pers., seq. εἰς, c. acc loc., Jo 6:22 18:15.†
a fellow-traveller: Ac 19:29, II Co 8:1.†
chosen together with, co-elect: ἡ ἐν Βαβυλῶνι συνεκλεκτή (on the meaning, v. ICC, in l), I Pe 5:13.†
to drive together, force together: εἰς εἰρήνην, Ac 7:26, Rec. (WH, RV, συνήλλασσεν).†
to join in attesting, bear witness together with: He 2:4 (Arist., Polyb., a1.).†
to follow with, accompany: c. dat. pers., Ac 20:4.†

prop., to work together (with): absol., Mk 16:20, I Co 16:16, II Co 6:1; c. dat., Ja 2:22; dat. commod., Ro 8:28, T, R, txt. (but v. infr.).; In Hellenistic writers (M, Pr., 65), trans., to cause to work together (cf. ICC, in l): c. acc rei, Ro 8:28 [WH] R, mg. (but v. supr.).†

a fellow-worker: c. gen. pers., Ro 16:3, 9 16:21, Phl 2:25 4:3, I Th 3:2, Rec., Phm 1 24; θεοῦ (cf. Lft., Notes, 41, 188), I Co 3:9 (pl.), I Th 3:2 [WH] R, mg. (R, txt., διάκονον τοῦ θ.; on the original reading, v. ICC, in l); τ. χαρᾶς ὑηῶν, II Co 1:24; τ. ἀληθείᾳ, III Jn 8; seq. εἰς, II Co 8:23, Col 4:11.†

(cl.) to come together, assemble: Mk 3:20 14:53, T, WH, txt., Ac 1:6 2:6 10:27 16:13 19:32 21:22 22:30 28:17, I Co 14:26; seq. εἰς, c. acc loc., Ac 5:16; ἐπὶ τ. αὐτό, I Co 11:20 14:23; c. dat. pers., Mk 14:53, WH, mg., R (πρὸς αὐτόν, v. Field, Notes, 40), Jo 11:33; ἐν ἐκκλησίᾳ, I Co 11:18; ἐνθάδε, Ac 25:17; Mk 6:33, WH, mg. (cf. WH, Intr., 95 ff.); ὅπου, Jo 18:20; c. inf., Lk 5:15; εἰς τ. φαγεῖν, I Co 11:33; εἰς τ. ἧσσον, I Co 11:17 11:34; of sexual intercourse (Xen., al.; γυναικί or absol.), Mt 1:18.; In later sense (v. exx. in Milligan, Selections, 64, 105), to accompany: c. dat. pers., Lk 23:55, Ac 1:21 9:39 10:23, 45 11:12; seq. σύν, Ac 21:16; εἰς, Ac 15:38.†
to eat with one: c. dat. pers., Lk 15:2, Ac 10:41 11:3, I Co 5:11; seq. μετά, c. gen. pers., Ga 2:12.†
a running or flowing together (Hom.).; (a) understanding: Lk 2:47, I Co 1:19 (LXX), Eph 3:4, Col 1:9 2:2, II Ti 2:7; the understanding, the mind or intelligence: Mk 12:33.†
intelligent, sagacious, understanding: Mt 11:25, Lk 10:21, Ac 13:7, I Co 1:19 (LXX).†
to join in approving, consent, agree to or with: absol., Ac 22:20; c. dat. pers., Ro 1:32; c. dat. rei, Lk 11:48, Ac 8:1; c. inf., I Co 7:12-13 (chiefly in late writers).†
to entertain together. Pass., to fare sumptuously or feast together or with: Ju 12; c. dat. pers., II Pe 2:13 (Arist., Luc., al.).†
to place over. Pass.,; to stand over (Thuc.).; to rise together: seq. κατά, c. gen. pers. (against), Ac 16:22.†

to hold together (τ. συνέχον τ. πάντα, Wi 1:7): of closing the ears, Ac 7:57 (τ. στόμα, Is 52:15); to hem in, press on every side: Lk 8:45 19:43.; to hold fast; of a prisoner, to hold in charge (Luc.; cf. exx. in Deiss., BS, 160; MM, xxiv): Lk 22:63; to constrain: II Co 5:14; pass., Lk 12:50, Ac 18:5 (τ. λόγῳ; cf. Field, Notes, 128), Phl 1:23; in pass., of ills, to be seized or afflicted by, suffering from: Mt 4:24, Lk 4:38 8:37, Ac 28:8.†
to live with: opp. to συναποθανεῖν, II Co 7:3; of life in union with Christ, here and hereafter, Ro 6:8, II Ti 2:11.†
to yoke to­gether: metaph., of union in wedlock, Mt 19:6, Mk 10:9.†

to search or examine together (Plat.).; In NT (and π., v. MM, xxiii; also in MGr., v. Kennedy, Sources, 155), to discuss, dispute: Mk 1:27 12:28, Lk 24:15; seq. quæst. indir., Mk 9:10; c. dat. pers., Mk 8:11 Ac 6:9; seq. πρός, c. acc pers., Mk 9:14, 16, Ac 9:29; id. seq. quæst. indir., Lk 22:23.†
disputation: Ac 28:29 (WH, R, txt., om.).†
a disputer, disputant: I Co 1:20.†
a yoke fellow. Prob., as proper name, Σ. γνήσιε, genuinely Synzygus, S. properly so-called, Phl 4:3 (v. ICC, Lft., in l; MM, xxiii).†
to make alive or quicken together with; metaph., of the spiritual life: τ. Χριστῷ, Eph 2:5; σὺν τ. Χ., Col 2:13.†
to rejoice together; c. dat., to rejoice with or in: τ. νόμῳ τ. θεοῦ, Ro 7:22 (v. Lft., Notes, 304).†
1 intimacy.; habit, custom: Jo 18:39, I Co 11:16; c. gen. obj. (cf. Æschin., 23, 37, and v. MM, xxiv), habitual use, force of habit with respect to, I Co 8:7.†
one of the same age, an equal in age: Ga 1:14.†
to bury together with: in symbolical sense, of baptism, σὐτῷ (with Christ), Ro 6:4, Col 2:12.†
to crush together, crush: Mt 21:44 ([WH], R, mg., om.), Lk 20:18.†
to press together, press on all sides: Mk 5:24, 31.†
to break in pieces, crush: metaph., τ. καρδίαν, Ac 21:13.†

to bring or set together.; Metaph., to perceive, understand: Mt 13:13-15 (LXX), Mt 13:19 15:10, Mk 4:9 (WH, mg.), Mk 4:12 7:14 8:17, 21 Lk 8:10, Ac 7:25 28:26-27, Ro 15:21 (LXX), II Co 10:12; c. acc rei, Mt 13:23, 51, Lk 2:50 18:34 24:45; seq. ὅτι, Mt 16:12 17:13; seq. quæst. indir., Eph 5:17; ἐπὶ τ. ἄρτοις, Mk 6:52; as subst., συνίων (ὁ σ., WH, mg.), a man of understanding, i.e. in moral and religious sense, Ro 3:11 (LXX).†

trans.,; to commend, recommend: c. acc pers., II Co 3:1 6:4 10:12 10:18; id. c. dat., Ro 16:1 (as freq. at the beginning of a letter; Deiss., LAE, 226), II Co 5:12; seq. πρός, II Co 4:2; pass., seq. ὑπό, II Co 12:11; to show, prove, establish: c. acc, Ro 3:5 5:8, II Co 6:4; dupl. acc, Ga 2:13; acc et inf., II Co 7:11; Intrans., pf., συνέστηκα (as also 2 aor. and plpf.); to stand with or near: Lk 9:32; to be composed of, consist, cohere: Col 1:17 (v. Lft., in l), II Pe 3:5.†
to sit together or with: c. dat., Ac 26:30; seq. μετά, c. gen., Mk 14:54.†
trans., to make to sit together: c. acc pers., seq. ἐν, Eph 2:6. Intrans. = mid., to sit together: Lk 22:55. †
to bear evil treatment along with, take one's share of ill-treatment: II Ti 2:3; c. dat. commod., τ. εὐαγγελίῳ, II Ti 2:18.†
to endure adversity with: c. dat. pers., He 11:25. Not elsewhere.†
to call together: c. acc, Mk 15:16, Lk 15:6, 9 (v.l. -εῖται, v. B1., § 55, 1), Ac 5:21. Mid., to call together to oneself: Lk 9:1 (and v.l. in Lk 15:6, 9 v. supr.) Lk 23:13, Ac 10:24 28:17.†
to veil or cover completely: c. acc, pass., Lk 12:2.†
to bend completely, bend together: τ. νῶτον, fig., Ro 11:10 (LXX).†
to go down with: Ac 25:5. In late writers also metaph. (Wis, l.c.), to condescend, on WH. v. Rutherford, NPhr., 485 f.†
concord, agreement: II Co 6:16 (Polyb., Plut., al.).†
to deposit together. Mid., to deposit one's vote with, hence, to agree with, assent to: c. dat., Lk 23:51.†
to condemn with or together (Plut., Themist., 21).; to vote one a place among: pass., Ac 1:26. Not elsewhere .†

to mix or blend together, compound: c. acc, I Co 12:24; ptcp. pf. pass., He 4:2, T, WH, mg., R, mg.; id., of persons, c. dat. instr., to be united with, agree with, ib., WH, txt., R, txt. (v. Westc., in l).†
to move together. Metaph., to excite, stir up: τ. λαόν, Ac 6:12 (Arist., Polyb., al.).†
to shut together, enclose, shut in on all sides: of a catch of fish, Lk 5:6; metaph. (Ps 31:9, al.), Ro 11:32, Ga 3:22-23.†
a co-inheritor, fellow-heir: Ro 8:17, Eph 3:6; c. gen. rei, He 11:9, I Pe 3:7 (for exx., v. Deiss., LAE, 88 f.).†
to have fellowship with or in (in cl., c. gen. rei, dat. pers.): c. dat. rei, Eph 5:11, Re 18:4; id. c. gen. pers., Phl 4:14.†
partaking jointly of: c. gen. rei, Ro 11:17, I Co 9:23; id. c. gen. pers., Phl 1:7; seq. ἐν, Re 1:9.†
to bring together, collect (Hdt., Xen., al.).; to take up a body for burial (Soph., Aj., 1048): Ac 8:2 (v. Field, Notes, 116).†

to compound, combine: I Co 2:13, R, mg.1 (Lft., Notes, 180 f.).; In Arist. and later writers (Wi 7:29, a1.) = παραβάλλω, to compare: 1Co, l.c., R, txt. (Field, Notes, 168), II Co 10:12; In LXX, of dreams, to interpret (Ge 40:8, 1Co, l.c., R, mg. 2 (but v. reff. supr.).†
to bend forwards (Arist., al.).; to be bowed down: Lk 13:11.†
to make to grieve with (Arist.). Pass., to be moved to grief by sympathy: seq. ἐπί, c. dat., Mk 3:5.†
a fellow-disciple: Jo 11:16 (on the use of συν- in such compounds as this, v. Rutherford, NPhr., 255 f.).†
to bear witness with: Ro 2:15; c. dat., Ro 8:16; seq. ὅτι, Ro 9:1.†
to distri­bute in shares. Mid., to have a share in: I Co 9:13 (Diod., al.).†
partaking together with; as subst., ὁ σ., a joint partaker (c. dat. pers. et gen. rei, FlJ, BJ, i, 24, 6): c. gen. rei, Eph 3:6; c. gen. pers., Eph 5:7 (Arist.).†
a fellow-imitator: c. gen. obj., Phl 3:17 (v. ICC, in l). Not elsewhere.†
to journey with: c. dat. pers., Ac 9:7 (Plut., al.).†
a journey in company (Plut., al.).; By meton., κ company of travellers, a caravan: Lk 2:44.†

to share the knowledge of, be privy to (Hdt., Thuc., al.): ptcp., Ac 5:2.; C. prop. reflex., to be conscious of (Eur., Plat., al.), esp. of guilty consciousness: οὐδὲν γὰρ ἐμαυτῷ σ., for I know nothing against myself, I Co 4:4.†
to dwell together: of man and wife (Hdt., al.), c. dat. pers., I Pe 3:7,†
to build together or with (c. dat. pers., 1Esdras, l.c.).; Of various materials, to build up together (Thuc., al.): metaph., of Christians, Eph 2:22.†
to converse with (absol., FlJ, Bl, v, 13, 1; seq. μετά, Cebes, 13): c. dat. pers., Ac 10:27.†
to border on: c. dat., Ac 18:7 (Byz.).†
a holding or being held together.; a narrow place (Hom., al.). Metaph., straits, distress: Lk 21:25; καρδίας, II Co 2:4.†
to have a fellow feeling for or with, sympathize with or in: c. dat. rei, He 4:15; dat. pers., He 10:34 (Arist., Plut., al.).†
to come up or be present together: seq. ἐπί, Lk 23:48.; to come up to assist (Thuc., al.; II Ti 4:16, Rec.).†
to call upon or exhort together (Plat.). Pass., to be strengthened or comforted with and among: Ro 1:12.†
to take along with: as a companion, c. acc, Ac 12:25 15:37-38 (on the tenses, v. M, Pr., 130), Ga 2:1.†
to be present together or with: c. dat. pers., Ac 25:24.†
to suffer together or with: Ro 8:17, I Co 12:28.; to sympathize with (Plat., Arist.).†
to send together with: c. acc et dat., II Co 8:22; id. seq. μετά, c. gen., II Co 8:18.†
to enclose (Ez 5:3 (צוּר) *).; to embrace: c. acc pers., Ac 20:10.†
to drink with c. dat. pers., Ac 10:41.†

to fill up completely (Thuc., of manning ships): of a ship filling with water, and by meton., of those on board, Lk 8:23.; to complete, fulfil: of time (Je, l.c., and v. MM, xxiv), Lk 9:51, Ac 2:1 (on the "durative inf.," v. M, Pr., 233).†
to choke: of thronging by a crowd, Lk 8:42. Fig., of seed, τ. λόγον, Mt 13:22, Mk 4:7, 19, Lk 8:14.†
a fellow-citizen: pl., σ. τ. ἁγίων, opp. to ξένοι κ. πάροικοι, Eph 2:19 (Eur.; C.I., 6446; condemned by Atticists; v. Rutherford, NPhr., 255 f.).†
to journey together (Plat., al.): c. dat. pers., Lk 7:11 14:25 24:15.; to come together: Mk 10:1 (Plut., al.).†
a fellow-elder: I Pe 5:1 (Eccl.).†
of the same body: Eph 3:6 (Eccl.).†
to crucify together with: pass., c. dat., Jo 19:32; id. seq. σύν, Mt 27:44, Mk 15:32. Metaph., of the mystical death of the Christian with Christ: Ro 6:6, Ga 2:20 (Eccl.).†
to draw together, contract, shorten: of time, I Co 7:29.; to wrap up: of enshrouding a body for burial (Eur.), c. acc, Ac 5:6.†
to groan together or with: Ro 8:22 (c. dat. pers., Eur., Ion., 935).†
to stand in the same rank or line (Polyb). Metaph., to correspond to: Ga 4:25 (v. Lft., in l).†
a fellow-soldier (Plat., Xen., al.). Metaph., of fellowship in Christian service: Phl 2:25, Phm 2 .†
to conform to (Arist.). Pass., to be conformed to, conform oneself to: Ro 12:2, I Pe 1:14.†
to prescribe, ordain, arrange: c. dat. pers, Mt 21:6 26:19 27:10 (LXX).†

in cl., a joint payment or contribution for public service; hence, generally, joint action (Plat.).; In late writers (Polyb., al.), consummation, completion: σ. τ. αἰῶνος, -ων (cf. Da LXX TH Da 12:13, al.), Mt 13:39-40, 49 24:3 28:20, He 9:26.†

"perfective" of τελέω (cf. M, Pr., 118),; to complete, finish, bring to an end: Lk 4:13; pass., Lk 4:2, Jo 2:3, WH, mg., Ac 21:27.; to effect, accomplish, bring to fulfilment (cf. MM, xxiv): Mk 13:4, Ro 9:28, He 8:8.†
to cut in pieces.; to cut down, cut short: metapb., λόγον, Ro 9:28 (LXX) (Hdt., Plat., Fur., al.).†
"perfective" of τηρέω (v. M, Pr., 113, 116),; to preserve, keep safe, keep close: c. acc pers., Mk 6:20; c. acc rei, Mt 9:17; ἐν τ. καρδίᾳ, Lk 2:19 (Arist. and later writers; cf. MM, xxiv).†

to place or put together, in various senses. Mid.,; to observe, perceive; to determine, agree, covenant: c. inf., Lk 22:5; seq. τοῦ, c. inf., Ac 23:20; seq. ἵνα, Jo 9:22.†; συν-επι-τίθημι,; to help in putting on. Mid., to join in attacking (Thuc.): Ac 24:9 (RV, joined in the charge).†
concisely, briefly: Ac 24:4 (for a similar ex., v. MM, xxiv).†
to run together or with: seq. ἐκεῖ, Mk 6:33; πρόσ, c. acc, Ac 3:11; metaph., I Pe 4:4.†
to shatter, break in pieces: Mt 12:20 (LXX), Mk 5:4 14:3, Jo 19:36 (LXX), Re 2:27; of persons and parts of the body, to break, crush, bruise: Lk 9:39; fig., Ro 16:20.†
a fracture (Arist.; Le, l.c., al.). Metaph., calamity, destruction (Isa, l.c., Wi 3:3, al.): Ro 3:16 (LXX).†
prop., one nourished or brought up with, a foster-brother: Ac 13:1 EV.; In Hellenistic usage, as a court term, an intimate friend of a king (v. Deiss., BS, 305, 310 f.): Ac 13:1 (cf. also MM, xxiv).†
to meet with, fall in with: c. dat. pers., Lk 8:19.†
Syntyche: Phl 4:2.†
to play a part with, dissemble with: c. dat., Ga 2:13 (Polyb.).†
to help together, join in serving: c. dat. instr., II Co 1:11.†
to consent, confess: c. dat., seq. ὅτι, Ro 7:16.†
to cause to grow together. Pass., to grow together or with (Plat. al.): Lk 8:7.†
to rejoice with: c. dat pers., Lk 1:58 15:6, 9, Phl 2:17-18, EV; c. dat. rei, I Co 12:26 13:6.; to congratulate (Æschin., Polyb., al.): Phi, l.c. (Lft., in I.; cf. MM, xxiv).†
to pour together, commingle, confuse; metaph., confound, throw into confusion, stir up trouble: Ac 21:27 (cf. συν-χύννω).†
to use together with. Metaph., c. dat. pers., to associate with: Jo 4:9 (Polyb., a1.).†
Hellenistic form of -χέω (q.v.): Ac 2:6 9:22 19:32 21:31.†
of one mind: Phl 2:2.†
to be in travail together (Arist.): metapb. (Eur.), Ro 8:22.†
a conspiracy: Ac 23:13.†
Syracuse: Ac 28:12.†
a Syrian: Lk 4:27, Mk 7:26, WH, mg.†
a Syropænician woman: Mk 7:26, WH, txt., RV (cf. ἡ Φοινίκη Συρία, Diod., 19, 93).†
a Phænician woman: Σύρα Φ. Mk 7:26, WH, mg., for Συροφοινίκισσα, q.v.†
Syrtis, the name of two large sand-banks on the Libyan coast: Ac 27:17.†
to draw, drag: c. acc rei, Jo 21:8, Re 12:4; c. acc pers., of taking to trial or punish­ment, Ac 8:3; ἔξω τ. πόλεως, Ac 14:19; ἐπὶ τ. πολιτάρχας (cf. 4Mac, l.c.), Ac 17:6 (cf. κατα-ούρω).†
to convulse completely: c. acc pers., Mk 9:20, Lk 9:42 (cf. σπαράσσω).†
a fixed sign or signal: Mk 14:44. (Strab., Plut., al.; condemned by Atticists, v. Rutherford, NPhr., 492 f.) †
a fellow-rioter: Mk 15:7, Rec.†
for putting together, constructive.; for bringing together, introductory, commendatory: ἐπιστολή (Arist., Diog. L., al.; and v. MM, xxiv), II Co 3:1.†
to twist together: c. acc rei, Ac 28:3.; Pass., of persons, to gather themselves together: Mt 17:22 (WH, R, mg.).†
a twisting together (Plat.).; a concourse, a riotous gathering (Polyb.): Ac 19:40; σ. ποιεῖσθαι (Am, l.c.), to make a compact (RV, banded themselves together): Ac 23:12.†
Sychar, a town of Samaria: Jo 4:5.†
Shechem; the son of Hamor (Ge 33:19): Ac 7:16 b, Rec.; A city of Samaria (AV, Sychem; in LXX also sometimes Σίκιμα, -ων, as in FlJ): Ac 7:16 a,b.†
slaughter: Ac 8:32 (LXX); πρόβατα σφαγῆς, Ro 8:36 (LXX); ἡμέρα σφαγῆς, Ja 5:5.†
a victim for slaughter: Ac 7:42 (LXX).†
to slay, slaughter (esp. of victims for sacrifice): ἀρνίον, Re 5:6, 12 13:8; of persons, I Jn 3:12, Re 5:9 6:4, 9 18:24; ἐσφαγμένη εἰς θάνατον (RV, smitten unto death), Re 13:3 (cf. κατα-σφάζω).†
very, very much, exceedingly: with verbs, Mt 17:6, 23 18:31 19:25 26:22 27:54, Ac 6:7; with adjectives, Mt 2:10, Mk 16:4, Lk 18:23, Re 16:21.†
exceedingly: Ac 27:18.†

to seal,; for security: Mt 27:66, Re 20:3; τ. καρπὸν τοῦτον, fig. (cf. Deiss., BS, 238 f.; MM, xxiv; DB, iv, 427a), Ro 15:28; for concealment, hence, metaph., to hide (Da TH Da 9:24, Jo 14:17): Re 10:4 22:10; for distinction, Re 7:3-8; metaph., Eph 4:30; mid., II Co 1:22; for authentication (Es 8:8): Jo 3:33 6:27 (cf. κατα-σφραγίζω).†

a seal, signet: Re 7:2.; The impression of a seal or signet, a seal (on its various purposes, v.s. σφραγίζω): on a book or roll, Re 5:1-2, 5 5:9 6:1, 3 6:5, 7 6:9, 12 8:1; metaph., Ro 4:11, I Co 9:2, II Ti 2:19, Re 9:4.†
= σφυρόν,; the ankle: Ac 3:7 (v. BL, § 6, 8).†
a flexible mat-basket for carrying provisions: Mt 15:37 16:10, Mk 8:8, 20 Ac 9:25 (v.s. κόφινος).†
the ankle: Ac 3:7, Rec. (T, WH, σφυδρόν; v. Bl., § 6, 8).†
of place, near.; Of degree, almost, nearly: Ac 13:44 19:26, He 9:22.†
figure, fashion: I Co 7:31, Phl 2:8.†
to cleave, rend: Mt 27:51, Mk 1:10 15:38, Lk 5:36 23:45, Jo 19:24 21:11; metaph., in pass., to be divided into factions, Ac 14:4 23:7.†
a rent (Arist., al.): Mt 9:16, Mk 2:21. Metaph., a dissension, division: Jo 7:43 9:16 10:19, I Co 1:10 11:18 12:25.†
[in LXX chiefly for a rope (prop., one made of rushes): Jo 2:15, Ac 27:32.†

to be at leisure, hence, to have time or opportunity for, to devote oneself to, be occupied in: I Co 7:5; of things, to be unoccupied, empty (Plut., Eur., al.): οἶκος, Mt 12:44, Lk 11:25 (T [WH], R, om.).†

leisure.; Later (from Plato on),; that for which leisure is employed, a disputation, lecture; the place where lectures are delivered, a school: Ac 19:9 (for the later sense of employment, v. MM, xxiv).†

to save from peril, injury or suffering: Mt 8:25, Mk 13:20, Lk 23:35, al.; τ. ψυχήν, Mt 16:25, al.; seq. ἐκ, Jo 12:27, He 5:7, Ju 5; of healing, restoring to health: Mt 9:22, Mk 5:34, al. In NT, esp. of salvation from spiritual disease and death, in which sense it is "spoken of in Scripture as either (1) past, (2) present, or (3) future, according as redemption, grace, or glory is the point in view. Thus (1) Ro 8:24, Eph 2:5, 8 II Ti 1:9, Tit 3:5; (2) Ac 2:47, I Co 1:18, 15:2, II Co 2:15; (3) Mt 10:22, Ro 13:11, Phl 2:12, He 9:28" (Vau. on Ro 5:9). Seq. ἀπό, Mt 1:21, Ac 2:40, Ro 5:9; ἐκ, Ja 5:20, Ju 23 (cf. Cremer, 532ff.).

a body. Prop., of the human body, as always in Hom. (opp. to δέμας), of the dead body: Mt 27:58, 59 Mk 15:43, al.; of the living body: Lk 11:34, I Co 6:13, al.; ἐν σ. εἶναι, He 13:3; as the instrument of the soul, τὰ διὰ τοῦ σ., II Co 5:10; opp. to πνεῦμα, Ro 8:10, I Co 5:3 7:4, Ja 2:26; to ψυχή, Mt 6:25 10:28, Lk 12:22 (cf. Wi 1:1, al.); to τὸ π. καὶ ἡ ψ., I Th 5:23; σ. ψυχικόν, opp. to σ. πνευματικόν, I Co 15:44; ὁ ναὸς τοῦ σ. αὐτοῦ (gen. epexeg.), Jo 2:21; τὸ σ. τ. ταπεινώσεως (Hebraistic "gen. of definition"; M, Pr., 73f.; Bl., §35, 5), opp. to τὸ σ. τ. δοξῆς αὐτοῦ, Phl 3:21; similarly, τὸ σ. τ. σαρκός, Col 1:22; σ. τοῦ θανάτου (subject to death), Ro 7:24; σ. τ. ἁμαρτίας, Ro 6:6; periphr., ἀνθρώπου, then absol., σῶμα (Soph., Xen., al.), a person, and in later writers (Polyb., al.), a slave: Re 18:13 (cf. MM, i, ii, xxiv; Deiss., BS, 160). Of the bodies of animals: living, Ja 3:3; dead, He 13:11 ( Ex 29:14, al.). Of inanimate objects (cf. Eng. "heavenly bodies"): I Co 15:37, 38 40 (Diod., al.). Of any corporeal substance (Plat., al.): opp. to σκιά, Col 2:17. Metaph., of a number of persons united by a common bond; in NT, of the Church as the spiritual body of Christ: Ro 12:5, I Co 10:16, 17 12:13, 27, Eph 1:23 2:16 4:4, 12, 16 5:23, 30, Col 1:18, 24 2:19 3:15; ἓν σ. κ. ἓν πνεῦμα, Eph 4:4.
of or for the body, bodily: γυμνασία, I Ti 4:8; (opp. to ἀσώματος) bodily, corporeal: εἶδος, Lk 3:22.†
bodily, corporeally: Col 2:9 (v. ICC, Lft., in l).†
Sopater: Ac 20:4.†
to heap on: c. acc seq. ἐπί c. acc, Ro 12:20 (LXX) (Arist., al.); to heap with: c. acc et dat., metaph., ἁμαρτίαις, II Ti 3:6 (overwhelmed with, Field, Notes, 217) (Polyb.).†
Sosthenes; a Jewish ruler: Ac 18:7; a Christian: I Co 1:1.†
Sosipater: Ro 16:21.†

saviour, deliverer, preserver, a freq. epithet of kings in the Ptolemaic and Rom. periods (Deiss., BS, 83; LAE, 368 f.; MM, xxiv), in NT,; of God (as LXX: Ps 24:5, Is 12:2, al.): Lk 1:47, I Ti 1:1 2:3 4:10, Tit 1:3 2:10 3:4, Ju 25; of Christ: Lk 2:11, Ac 5:31 13:23, Phl 3:20; τ. κόσμου, Jo 4:42, I Jn 4:14 (for the general use of the word, v. Westc., in l); ἡμῶν, II Ti 1:10, Tit 1:4 3:6; θεὸς (κύριος) καὶ σ. (v. Deiss., LAE, 348.4; M, Pr., 84), Tit 2:13, II Pe 1:1 1:11 2:20 3:2 3:18; σ. τοῦ σώματος (i.e. of the Church; v.s. σῶμα, 5), Eph 5:23.†

deliverance, preservation, salvation, safety (Lat. salus): Ac 7:25 27:34, He 11:7; ἐξ ἐχθρῶν, Lk 1:71. In NT esp. of Messianic and spiritual salvation (v.s. σώζω): Lk 19:9, Jo 4:22, Ac 4:12 13:47, Ro 11:11, II Th 2:13, II Ti 3:15, He 2:3 6:9, II Pe 3:15, Ju 3; opp. to ἀπηώλεια, Phl 1:28; αἰώνιος-., He 5:9; ὁ λόγος (τὸ εὐαγγέλιον) τῆς σ., Ac 13:26, Eph 1:13; ὁδὸς σωτηρίας, Ac 16:17; κέρας σωτηρίας, Lk 1:69; ἡμέρα σωτηρίας, II Co 6:2 (LXX); κατεργάζεσθαι τὴν ἑαυτοῦ σ., Phl 2:12; κληρονομεῖν σ., He 1:14; ὁ ἀρχηγὸς τῆς σ., He 2:10; εἰς σ., Ro 1:16 10:1, 10, I Pe 2:2; σ. as a present possession (v.s. σώζω), Lk 1:77, II Co 1:6 7:10, Phl 1:19, II Ti 2:10; as more fully realized in the future: Ro 13:11, I Th 5:8-9, He 9:28, I Pe 1:5 1:9-10, Re 7:10 12:10 19:1.†

saving, bringing salvation, in NT always in spiritual sense (v.s. σώζω, σωτηρία): ἡ χάρις ἡ σ., Tit 2:1. Neut., -τὸ σ., as subst. (cl.), salvation: Lk 2:30; τ. σ. τ. θεοῦ, Lk 3:6, Ac 28:28; περικεφαλαίαν τοῦ σ., Eph 6:17.†

to be of sound mind or in one's right mind: Mk 5:15, Lk 8:35; opp. to ἐκστῆναι, II Co 5:13 (Hdt.); to be temperate, discreet, self-controlled (opp. to μαίνεσθαι, ὑβρίζειν, etc.; sch., Thuc., al.): Tit 2:6; opp. to ὑπερφρονεῖν, Ro 12:3; σ. καὶ νήφειν, I Pe 4:7.†
to make σώφρων, recall one to his senses, control (RV, train): c. acc pers., Tit 2:4.†
an admonishing (F1J, Plut., al.); self-control, self-discipline: II Ti 1:7 (on the reflexive meaning here, v. Ellic., in l).†
with sound mind, prudently, soberly: Tit 2:12.†
soundness of mind, good sense, sanity (opp. to μανία, Xen.): Ac 26:25; self-control, sobriety: I Ti 2:9 (v. Tr., Syn., § xx), I Ti 2:15.†
of sound mind, sane, sensible; self-controlled, sober-minded: I Ti 3:2, Tit 1:8 2:2, 5 (Arist.).†
tau, t, the nineteenth letter. As a numeral, τ' = 300, τ, = 300,000.
Tabitha: Ac 9:36, 40 (cf. Δορκάς).†
(Lat. taberna), v.s. Τρεῖς Ταβέρναι.
that which has been arranged or placed in order; esp. as military term, a company, troop, division, rank: metaph., I Co 15:23 (v. ICC, in l).†
ordered, fixed, stated: ἡμέρα, Ac 12:21,†
to do hard labour, suffer hardship or distress: Ja 4:9.; In cl. occasionally trans., to weary, distress (so Ps 17:9, Is 33:1).†
hard work (Hippocr.).; hardship, suffering, distress: Ro 3:16 (LXX) pl., Ja 5:1 (v. B1., § 32, 6; WM, 220; Swete, Mk., 153).; (Hdt., Thuc., al.; and cf. MM, xxiv.)†
distressed, miserable, wretched: Ro 7:24, Re 3:17.†
worth a talent; of a talent's weight: Re 16:21.†

a balance (Hom.).; that which is weighed, a talent; a talent in weight (in Horn. always of gold); a sum of money, whether gold or silver, equivalent to a talent in weight (v. DB, iii, 418 ff.): Mt 18:24 25:15 ff.†
talitha, i.e. maiden: Mk 5:41.†
a treasury (Thuc., al).; a store-chamber (Arist., Xen.; De 28:8): Lk 12:24.; an inner chamber (Xen., Hell., v, 4, 5 Is 26:20, al.): Mt 6:6 24:26, Lk 12:3.†

an arranging, hence, in military sense, disposition of an army, battle array (Thuc., al.).; arrangement, order (Plat., al): Lk 1:8.; due order: Col 2:5 (ICC, in l); κατὰ τάξιν, I Co 14:40.; office, order (for exx., v. MM, xxiv): He 5:6 (LXX), He 5:6 6:20 7:11, 17 (LXX).†

low-lying; metaph.,; lowly, of low degree, brought low: Ja 1:9, II Co 7:6 (cf. Si 25:23); οἱ τ., opp. to δυνάσται, Lk 1:52; τ. ταπεινοῖς (neut., R, txt.; masc., R, mg.; v. ICC, in l), Ro 12:16; lowly in spirit, humble, in cl. usually in a slighting sense (v. Tr., Syn., § xlii; but v. also Abbott, Essays, 81), in NT in an honourable sense: II Co 10:1; seq. τ. καρδίᾳ, Mt 11:29 (cf. Ps 34:19); opp. to ὑπερήφανος, Ja 4:6, I Pe 5:5 (LXX).†

lowliness of mind, humility: Ac 20:19, Eph 4:2, Phl 2:3, Col 3:12, I Pe 5:5; of a false humility, Col 2:18, 23 (rare outside of NT, but found in bad sense in FlJ, BJ, iv, 9, 2; also in Epictet., v. Tr., Syn., § xlii).†
humble-minded: I Pe 3:8 (in bad sense, Plut., 2, 336 E, cf. Deiss., LAE, 72.3).†

to make low: ὄρος (βουνόν), Lk 3:5 (LXX). Metaph., to humble, abase: Mt 18:4 23:12, Lk 14:11 18:14, II Co 11:7 12:21, Phl 2:8; pass., Mt 23:12, Lk 14:11 18:14, Phl 4:12; id. with mid. sense, Ja 4:10, I Pe 5:6.†
abasement, humiliation, low estate: Lk 1:48, Ac 8:33 (LXX), Phl 3:21, Ja 1:10 (Plat., Arist., and later writers).†

to disturb, trouble, stir up: primarily in physical sense (Hom., Eur.): τ. ὕδωρ, Jo 1:5 [4], Jo 1:7. Metaph., of the mind (Æsch., Plat., al.), to trouble, disquiet, perplex: Ac 15:24, Ga 1:7 5:10; ἑαυτόν (troubled himself; Westc., in l), Jo 11:33; of a crowd, to stir up, Ac 17:8, 13; pass., Mt 2:3 14:26, Mk 6:50, Lk 1:12 24:38, Jo 12:27 (Ps 6:4) Ps 14:1, 7, I Pe 3:14 (LXX); τ. πνεύματι, Jo 13:21 (cf. δια-, ἐκ-ταράσσω)
trouble, disturbance: τ. ὕδατος, Jo 1:5 [4]. In pl. (as in cl.), tumults: Mk 13:8, Rec.†
later form of ταραχή (Xen., al.; v. Thackeray, Gr., 159): Ac 12:18 19:23.†
of Tarsus: Ac 9:11 21:39.†
Tarsus, a city of Cilicia: Ac 9:30 11:25 22:3.†
to cast into hell: II Pe 2:4 (v. Mayor, in l).†

primarily, in military sense, then generally, to draw up in order, arrange in place, assign, appoint, order: c. dat. (acc) et inf. (Bl., § 72, 5), Ac 15:2 18:2 (διατ-, WH) Ac 22:10; ἑαυτούς, I Co 16:15; pass., Mt 8:9 (T [WH], R, txt., om.), Lk 7:8, Ro 13:1; ὅσοι ἦσαν τεταγμένοι εἰς ζωὴν αἰώνιον (perh. in mid. sense; v. EGT and Page, in l), Ac 13:48; mid., to appoint for oneself or by one's own authority, Mt 28:16, Ac 28:23.†
burial: Mt 27:7 (Hdt., al.; for other meanings, v. LS, s.v., Deiss., BS, 355 f., MM xxiv).†
a burial (Hom., al.).; a grave, tomb (Res., Hdt., al.): Mt 23:27, 29 27:61, 64 27:66 28:1, Ro 3:13 (LXX).†
(chiefly poët.), quickly, presently; perhaps: Ro 5:7, Phm 15.†
quickly, hastily: Lk 14:21 16:6, Jo 11:31, I Co 4:19, Phl 2:19, 24, II Ti 4:9; with suggestion of rashness, Ga 1:6, II Th 2:2, I Ti 5:22.†
poët. and late for ταχύς, swift: of swift approach, II Pe 1:14 2:1.†
swiftness, speed. Adverbially, ἐν τ. (< ταχέως), quickly, speedily, soon: Lk 18:8, Ac 12:7 22:18 25:4, Ro 16:20, I Ti 3:14, Re 1:1 22:6.†

quickly, speedily, forthwith: Mt 5:25 28:7-8, Mk 9:39, Lk 15:22, Jo 11:29, Re 2:16 3:11 11:14 22:7, 12 22:2 o. Compar., τάχειον (T, Rec. τάχιον), = cl. θᾶσσον, θᾶττον (Att..), (v. Bl., § 44, 3): Jo 13:27 20:4, I Ti 3:14 (T, Rec.), He 13:19, 23 Superl., τάχιστα: ὡς τ., as quickly as possible (BL, § 11, 3), Ac 17:15.†
quick, swift, speedy: opp. to βραδύς, Ja 119.†

τέ solitarium, and, denoting a closer affinity than καί between words and sentences which it connects (BL, §77, 8): Mt 28:12, Jo 4:42, Ac 2:33, 37 40 10:22 11:21, al. Denoting a closer connection than simple καί, τὲ . . . καί, τὲ καί, τὲ . . . τέ (Ac 26:16 Ro 14:8), as well . . . as also, both . . . and: Lk 12:45, Ac 1:1 15:9, 21:30, al.; τὲ . . . δέ, and . . . and, Ac 19:2; τὲ γάρ . . . ὁμοίως δὲ καί, Ro 1:26, 27.
a wall, esp. that about a town: Ac 9:25, II Co 11:33, He 11:30, Re 21:12-19 †
a sure sign, a positive proof: Ac 1:1-26 (for exx., v. MM, xxiv).†
a little child: as a term of endearment, in voc. pl., Jo 13:33, Ga 4:19, I Jn 2:1 Jn 2:12 Jn 2:28 Jn 3:7 Jn 3:13 Jn 4:4 Jn 5:21.†
to beget or bear children: I Ti 5:14 (Anthol.).†
child-bearing: I Ti 2:15 (Arist.).†

that which is begotten, born (cf. Scottish bairn), a child of either sex: Mk 13:12, Lk 1:7, Ac 7:5; pl., Mt 7:11, Mk 7:27, Lk 1:17, Eph 6:1, al.; τέκνα ἐπαγγελίας, Ro 9:8; τ. τῆς σαρκός, ib.; in a wider sense (as Heb. בָּנִים), of posterity, Mt 2:18, Lk 3:8, al.; specif., of a male child, Mt 21:28, Ac 21:21, a,l.; in voc. as a form of kindly address from an elder to a junior or from a teacher to a disciple, Mt 9:2 21:28, Mk 2:5, Lk 2:48; τ. μου (= cl. τ. μοι; v. Bl., §37, 5), Ga 4:19 (τεκνία, WH, txt.), II Ti 2:1. Metaph., of disciples (apart from direct address, v. supr.): Phm 10, I Ti 1:2, Tit 1:4, III Jo 4; with reference to the Fatherhood of God (v.s. πατήρ, γεννάω), τέκνα τ. θεοῦ (cf. Is 30:1, Wi 16:21): Ro 8:16, Eph 5:1, Phl 2:15; and esp. in Johannine bks. (cf. Westc, Epp. Jo., 94, 120), Jo 1:12, I Jo 3:1 al.; of those who imitate others and are therefore regarded as the spiritual offspring of their exemplars: Mt 3:9, Lk 3:8, Jo 8:39, Ro 9:7, I Pe 3:6; τ. διαβόλου, I Jo 3:10; as in Heb. (LXX, Jl 2:23, Ps 149:2, I Mac 1:38), of the inhabitants of a city: Mt 23:37, Lk 13:34 19:44, Ga 4:25; with an adjectival gen., freq. rendering a Heb. expression, adopted from LXX or formed on the analogy of its language, but sometimes with parallels in Gk. writers (v. Deiss., BS, 161ff.): τέκνα φωτός, Eph 5:8; τ. ὑπακοῆς, I Pe 1:14; κατάρας, II Pe 2:14; ὀργῆς, Eph 2:3.
to rear young (of bees, Arist.),; to bring up children: I Ti 5:10.†
an artificer in wood, stone or metal, but esp. a carpenter (v. MM, xxiv): Mt 13:55, Mk 6:3.†

having reached its end, finished, mature, complete, perfect; of persons, primarily of physical development,; full-grown, mature: He 5:14; ethically: Phl 3:15; opp. to νήπιος (-άζειν), I Co 2:6 14:20, Eph 4:13; τ. καὶ πεπληροφορημένοι, Col 4:12; τ. ἐν Χριστῷ, Col 1:28; complete, perfect (expressing the simple idea of complete goodness, without reference either to maturity or to the philosophical idea of a τέλος; v. Hort on Ja 1:4): Mt 5:48 19:21, Ja 1:4 3:2; of God, Mt 5:48.; Of things, complete, perfect: Ro 12:2; ἔργον, Ja 1:4; νόμος, Ja 1:25; δώρημα, Ja 1:17; ἀγάπη, I Jn 4:18; τὸ τ., I Co 13:10; compar., τελειοτέρα (σκηνή), He 9:11.
perfection, completeness: Col 3:14, He 6:1

bring to an end, finish, accomplish, fulfil: Jo 4:34, Ac 20:24; of time, Lk 2:43, Jo 5:36 17:4; pass., ἡ γραφή, Jo 19:28.; to bring to maturity or completeness, to complete, perfect; of things: He 7:19, Ja 2:22, I Jn 2:5 Jn 4:12 Jn 4:17 :; of persons, in ethical and spiritual sense: He 2:10 9:9 10:1, 14; pass., Lk 13:32, Jo 17:23, Phl 3:12, He 5:9 7:28 11:40 12:23, I Jn 4:18 (for a different view of the meaning in He 2:10, al., v. Rendall, in l).†
completely, perfectly: I Pe 1:13.†
fulfilment, completion, perfection: Lk 1:45, He 7:11.†
a consummator, finisher: He 12:2 (nowhere else).†
of plants, to bring fruit to perfection (Theophr.): Lk 8:14; of females, to bear perfect offspring (Artemid.; 4Mac, l.c.).†

trans., to complete, finish; esp. τ. τ. αἰῶνα, τ. βίον, to complete life, to die (Æsch., Hdt., al.).; Intrans., to come to an end, hence, to die (Hdt., al.): Mt 2:19 9:18 22:25, Mk 9:48, Lk 7:2, Jo 11:39, Ac 2:29 7:15, He 11:22; Hebraistically, θανάτῳ τελευτάτω (מוּת, Ex 21:17), Mt 15:4, Mk 7:10 (LXX).†
a finishing.; an end: τ. βίου (Hdt., al.): also without βίου, the end of life, death (Hdt., Plat., al.): Mt 2:15.†

to bring to an end, complete, finish: τ. δρόμον, II Ti 4:7; τ. λόγους, Mt 7:28 19:1 26:1; τ. παραβολάς, Mt 13:53; τ. πόλεις, Mt 10:23; pass., Re 15:8 20:3, 5 20:7; c. ptcp., Mt 11:1.; to execute, perform, complete, fulfil: Lk 2:39, Ac 13:29, Ro 2:27, II Co 12:9, Ga 5:16, Ja 2:8, Re 11:7; pass., Lk 12:50 18:31 22:37, Jo 19:28, 30, Re 10:7 15:1 17:17.; to pay (freq. in cl.): Mt 17:24, Ro 13:6; (cf. ἀπο-, δια-, ἐκ-, ἐπι-, συν-τελέω).†

end: most freq. of the termination or limit of an act or state (in NT also of the end of a period of time, cl. τελευτή), Lk 1:33, I Co 10:11, II Co 3:13, I Pe 4:7; by meton., of one who makes an end, Ro 10:4; ἕως (ἄχρι, μέκρι) τέλους, I Co 1:8, II Co 1:13, He 3:14 6:11, Re 2:26; εἰς τ., to or at the end, Mt 10:22, Mk 13:13, Lk 18:5, Jo 13:1 (or here, to the uttermost, v. Westc., in l); τ. ἔχειν, Lk 22:37; adverbially, τὸ δὲ τέλος, finally, I Pe 3:8; of the last in a series, Re 21:6 22:13; of the issue, fate or destiny, Mt 26:58; c. gen. rei, Ro 6:21, al.; c. gen. pers., II Co 11:13, al.; of the aim or purpose, I Ti 1:5.; toll, custom, revenue: Ro 13:7; pl., as most usually, Mt 17:25

a farmer of taxes (Let. publicanus).; A subordinate of the former, who collected taxes or tolls in a particular district, a tax-gatherer (EV, publican): Mt 5:46 10:3, Lk 3:12 5:27, 29 7:29 18:10-11, 13; pl., τ. κ. ἁμαρτωλοί, Mt 9:10-11 11:19, Mk 2:15-16, Lk 5:30 7:34 15:1; τ. κ. πόρναι, Mt 21:31-32; ὁ ἐθνικὸς κ. ὁ τ., Mt 18:17 (cf. DB, iv, 172; ext., 394 f.; MM, xxiv).†
a custom house (so in MGr.), tollhouse, place of toll: Mt 9:9, Mk 2:14, Lk 5:27.†
a wonder, marvel: in NT always pl., τ. κ. σημεῖα, Mt 24:24, al. (v.s. σημεῖον)
Tertius: Ro 16:22.†
Tertullus: Ac 2:1-2.†
fourteenth: Ac 27:27, 33.†
forty: Mt 4:2, Mk 1:13, Lk 4:2, Jo 2:20, Ac 1:3, al
of forty years, forty years old: Ac 7:23 13:18.†
of or on the fourth day: τ. εἶναι (Hdt., τ. γενέσθαι), to be four days dead, Jo 11:39.†
to be tetrarch: c. gen., Lk 3:1 (FlJ, BJ, iii, 10, 7).†
a tetrarch, i.e.; prop., the governor of a fourth part of a region (Strab.); any petty ruler (Plut.); in NT, of Herod Antipas: Mt 14:1, Lk 3:19 9:7, Ac 13:1.†
square: Re 21:16 (Hdt., Plat., al.).†
a quarternion, a group of four: στρατιωτῶν, Ac 12:4 (Philo).
four thousand: Mt 15:38 16:10, Mk 8:9, 20, Ac 21:38.†
four hundred: Ac 5:36 7:6 (LXX) 13:20, Ga 3:17.†
of four months, four months; as subst., τ. (sc. ὥρα, but neut. in Rec.), Jo 4:35 (Thuc., al.).†
fourfold: Lk 19:8.†
four-footed: of beasts, neut. pl., Ac 10:12 11:6, Ro 1:23.†
to burn to ashes: II Pe 2:6.†
art, craft, trade: Ac 17:29 18:3, Re 18:22 (WH, R, mg., om.).†
a craftsman, artificer: Ac 19:24, 38, Re 18:22; of God (Wi 13:1), He 11:10.†
trans.,; to melt, melt down; pass., to melt, melt away: II Pe 3:12.†
at a distance clearly: Mk 8:25 (W, mg., δηλαυγῶς).†
of persons,; of such an age, so old; so young.; Of things, so great: II Co 1:10, He 2:3, Ja 3:4, Re 16:18.†

to watch over, guard, keep, preserve: Mt 27:36, Ac 16:23, al.; ἑαυτόν, II Co 11:9, I Ti 5:22, Ja 1:27, Ju 21; seq. εἰς, Jo 12:7, Ac 25:21, I Pe 1:4, II Pe 2:4 2:9 3:7, Ju 6; ἐν, Jo 17:11-12, Ju 21; ἐκ, Jo 17:15, Re 3:10; τ. πίστιν, II Ti 4:7, Re 14:12; τ. ἑνότητα τ. πνεύματος, Eph 4:3.; to watch, give heed to, observe: τ. σάββατον, Jo 9:16; τ. ἐντολήν (-άς), Mt 19:17, Jo 14:15 15:10, I Ti 6:14, I Jn 2:3-4 Jn 3:22 Jn 3:24 Jn 5:3, Re 12:17 14:12; τ. λόγον (-ους), Jo 8:51-52, 55 14:23-24 15:20 17:6, I Jn 2:5, Re 3:8, 10 22:7, 9; τ. νόμον, Ac 15:5, Ja 2:10; τ. παράδοσιν, Mk 7:9; τ. ἔργα, Re 2:26; τ. γεγραμμένα, Re 1:3 (cf. δια-, παρα-, συν-τηρέω)
a watching, hence, imprisonment, ward (v. Deiss., BS, 267): Ac 4:3 5:18.; a keeping: τ. ἐντολῶν (cf. Sir, Wis, ll. c., and v. Westc. on I Jn 2:3.), I Co 7:19.†
Tiberias, a city of Galilee: Jo 6:23, Jo 6:1 21:1 (cf Γεννησσαρέτ, Γαλιλαία).†
the Emperor Tiberius: Lk 3:1.†

causative of κεῖμαι, to place, lay, set: Lk 6:48, Ro 9:33, al.; of laying the dead to rest, Mk 15:47, Lk 23:55, Jo 11:34, Ac 7:16, al.; seq. ἐπί, c. gen., Lk 8:16, Jo 19:19, al.; id. c. acc., Mk 4:21, II Co 3:13, al.; ὑπό, Mt 5:15, al.; παρά, Ac 4:35, 37. Mid., to have put or placed, to place for oneself: of putting in prison, Ac 4:3, 5:18, 25, al.; of giving counsel, βουλήν, Ac 27:12; of laying up in one's heart, Lk 1:66 21:14 ( I Ki 21:12); to put down, lay down: of bending the knees, τ. γόνατα, to kneel, Mk 15:19, Ac 7:60, al.; of putting off garments, Jo 13:4; of laying down life, τ. ψυχήν, Jo 10:11, 15 17, 18 13:37, 38 15:13, I Jo 3:16; of laying by money, παρ ̓ ἑαυτῷ, I Co 16:2; of setting on food, Jo 2:10; metaph., of setting forth an idea in symbolism, Mk 4:30. to set, fix, establish: ὑπόδειγμα, II Pe 2:6. to make, appoint: Mt 22:44, Mk 12:36, Lk 20:43, Ac 2:35, Ro 4:17, al. Mid., to make, set or appoint for oneself: Ac 20:28, I Co 12:28, I Th 5:9, I Ti 1:12, al.; seq. ἵνα, Jo 15:16 (cf . ἀνα-, προσ-ανα-, ἀπο-, δια-, ἀντι-δια-, ἐκ-, ἐπι-, συν-επι-, κατα-, συν-κατα-, μετα-, παρα-, περι-, προ-, προσ-, συν-, ὑπο-τίθημι).

prop., of parents,; to beget, bring forth, but esp. the latter, and so always in NT: absol., Lk 1:57 2:6, Jo 16:21, Ga 4:27 (LXX) (v. M, Pr., 127), Re 12:2, 4; υἱόν, Mt 1:21, 23 1:25 Lk 1:31 2:7, Re 12:5, 13; pass., Mt 2:2, Lk 2:11. Metaph., of the earth, βοτάνην, He 6:7 (Æsch., al.); of lust, ἁμαρτίαν, Ja 1:15.†
to pluck, pluck off: στάχυας, Mt 12:1, Mk 2:23, Lk 6:1.†
Timæus: Mk 10:46.†

to fix the value, price: c. acc pers., of Christ, Mt 27:9 (LXX).; to honour: c. acc pers., Mt 15:4 (LXX), Mt 15:5, 8 (LXX) Mt 19:19 (LXX), Mk 7:6, 10 10:19, Lk 18:28 (LXX), Jo 5:23 8:49 12:26, Eph 6:2 (LXX), I Ti 5:3, I Pe 2:17; πολλαῖς τιμαῖς, Ac 28:10.†

a valuing, hence, objectively; a price paid or received: c. gen. pers., Mt 27:9; c. gen. rei, Ac 5:2-3; pl., Ac 4:34 19:19; τ. αἵματος, Mt 27:6; ἠγοράσθητε τιμῆς, I Co 6:20 7:23; ὠνεῖσθαι τιμῆς ἀργυρίου, Ac 7:16.; esteem, honour: Ro 12:10 13:7, I Co 12:23, I Ti 5:17 6:1, He 5:4, I Pe 2:7 (R, txt., preciousness, cf. Hort, in l), I Pe 3:7; τ. διδόναι, I Co 12:24; ἔχειν, Jo 4:44, He 3:3; τ. καὶ δόξα (δ. κ. τ.), Ro 2:7, 10, I Ti 1:17, He 2:7 (LXX), He 2:9, I Pe 1:7, II Pe 1:17, Re 4:9, 11 5:12-13 7:12 21:26; τ. καὶ κράτος, I Ti 6:16; εἰς τ., Ro 9:21, II Ti 2:20-21; ἐν τ., Col 2:23; I Th 4:4; by meton., of marks of honour, Ac 28:10.†

valued, hence,; precious, costly, highly valued: primarily, of money value, λίθος, Re 17:4 18:12, 16 21:19; pl., I Co 3:12; compar., -ώτεφος, I Pe 1:7, Rec.; superl., -ώτατος, Re 18:12 21:11; in extended sense, καρπός, Ja 5:7; αἷμα, I Pe 1:19; ἐπαγγέλματα, II Pe 1:4; held in honour, honoured, esteemed worthy: c. dat., Ac 5:34; ὁ γάμος, He 13:4; ψυχή, Ac 20:24 (where τ. is pleonastic, v. Page, in l).†
preciousness, worth: Re 18:19 (cf. Hort on τιμή, I Pe 2:7).†
Timon: Ac 6:5.†
to help.; to avenge; mid., to avenge oneself on, punish (Hdt., Eur., al): act, in this sense, Ac 22:5 26:11 (v. MM, xxiv).†
help, assistance.; vengeance, punishment: He 10:29.†
to pay: t. δίκην (cf. Pr, l.c.), to pay penalty, II Th 1:9 (v. M, Th., in l).†

As subst., one, a certain one: Lk 9:49, Jo 11:1, Ac 5:25, al.; pl., τίνες, certain, some: Lk 13:1, Ac 15:1, Ro 3:8, al. someone, anyone, something, anything: Mt 12:29, Mk 9:30, Lk 8:46, Jo 2:25, Ac 17:25, Ro 5:7, al.; = indef., one (French on), Mk 8:4, Jo 2:25, Ro 8:24, al.; pl., τινες, some, Mk 14:4, al. II. As adj., a certain: Mt 18:12, Lk 1:5 8:27, Ac 3:2, al.; with proper names, Mk 15:21, Lk 23:26, al.; c. gen. partit., Lk 7:19, al. some: Mk 16:[8], Jo 5:14, Ac 17:21 24:24, He 11:40, al.

who, which, what?; in neut., which, what?, used both in direct and in indirect questions. I. As subst., 1. masc., fem.: τίς; who, what?, Mt 3:7 26:68; Mk 11:28, Lk 9:9, al. mult.; c. gen. partit., Ac 7:52, He 1:5, al; seq. ἐκ (= gen. partit.), Mt 6:27, Lk 14:28, Jo 8:46; = ποῖος, Mk 4:41 6:2, Lk 19:3, Ac 17:19, al.; = πότερος (M, Pr., 77), Mt 21:31 27:17, Lk 22:27, al.; = ὅς or ὅστις (rare in cl.; cf. Bl., §50, 5; M, Pr., 93), Ac 13:25. Neut.: τί; what?, Mt 5:47 11:7, Mk 10:3, al.; χάριν τίνος, I Jo 3:12; διὰ τί, Mt 9:11, al.; εἰς τί, Mt 14:31, al.; elliptically, ἵνα τί (sc. γένηται), why, Mt 9:5, al.; τί οὖν, Ro 3:9 6:1, 15 I Co 14:15, al.; τί γάρ, Ro 3:3, Phi 1:18; τί ἐμοὶ (ὑμῖν) καὶ σοί, v.s. ἔγω. As adj.: who? what? which?, Mt 5:46, Lk 14:31, Jo 2:18, al. As adv.: = διὰ τι (τί ὅτι), why, Mt 6:28, Mk 4:40, Lk 6:46, Jo 18:23, al.; in rhet. questions, = a negation, Mt 27:4, Jo 21:22, 23 I Co 5:12 7:16, al. in exclamations (like Heb. מָה), how (II Ki 6:20, Ps 3:2, al.), Lk 12:49.
a title, inscription: Jo 19:19-20 (in Christian Inscr., epitaph, v. MM. xxiv).†
Titus; St. Paul's disciple and companion: II Co 2:13 7:6 7:13-14 8:6 8:16 8:23 12:18, Ga 2:1, 3, II Ti 4:10, Tit 1:4, subscr., Rec. (Τῖτος).; One surnamed Justus: Ac 18:7, RV (T, WH, Τίτιος).†
Titius, surnamed Justus: Ac 18:7, T, WH (RV., Τίτος).†
wherefore then, so therefore: I Th 4:8, He 12:1 (Hat., Plat., al.).†
accordingly, therefore: as in cl., after the first word in a sentence, I Co 9:26; acc to later usage, at the beginning, Lk 20:25, He 13:13.†
such: II Pe 1:17.†

correlat. of οἷος, ὁποῖος, ὥς, etc.,; such as this, of such a kind, such: Mt 9:8 18:5, Mk 4:33 6:2 7:13 9:37 (T, τούτων), Jo 9:16, Ac 16:24, I Co 5:1 11:16, II Co 3:4 3:12 12:3, He 7:26 8:1 12:3 13:16, Ja 4:16; οἷος . . . τ., I Co 15:48, II Co 10:11; id. pleonast. (v. Bl., § 50, 4), Mk 13:19; seq. ὁποῖος, Ac 26:29; ὥς, Phm 9. As subst., anarth: pl., Lk 9:9; c. art., ὁ τ., such a one (Bl., § 47, 9; Ellic. on Ga 5:21): Ac 22:22, I Co 5:5, al.; pl., Mt 19:14, Mk 10:14, al.; neut. pl., Ac 19:25, Ro 1:32, al
a wall, esp. of a house: fig., Ac 23:3 (cf. τεῖχος).†
a bringing forth, birth; offspring. Metaph., of the produce of money lent out, interest, usury (cf. Merch. of Venice, I, iii, "a breed of barren metal "): Mt 25:27, Lk 19:23 (Soph., Plat., al.).†

to have courage, to venture, dare, be bold: absol, II Co 11:21; seq. ἐπί, II Co 10:2; c. inf. (Bl., § 69, 4), Mt 22:46, Mk 12:34, Lk 20:40, Jo 21:12, Ac 5:13 7:32, Ro 15:18, I Co 6:1, II Co 10:12, Phl 1:14, Ju 9; to submit to (in cl. usually absol. in this sense), Ro 5:7 (v. Field, Notes, 155); τολμήσας εἰσῆλθεν, took courage and went in (v. Field, op. cit., 44), Mk 15:43 (cf. ἀπο-τολμάω).†
boldly: compar., -ότερως (T, Rec. -ότερον), Ro 15:15.†
a bold, daring man: II Pe 2:10 (Thuc.).†
sharp: compar., -ώτερος, metaph., He 4:12.†
a bow: Re 6:2.†
topaz: Re 21:20 (v. Swete, in l).†

place: Lk 4:37 10:1, 32 Jo 5:13 6:10, Ac 12:17, I Co 1:2, al.; τ. ἅγιος (cf. Is 60:13), Mt 24:15; ἔρημος, Mt 14:13, al.; πεδινός, Lk 6:17; ἄνυδρος (pl.), Mt 12:43, Lk 11:24; κατὰ τόπος (BV, in divers places), Mt 24:7, Mk 13:8; τραχεῖς τ., Ac 27:29; τ. διθάλασσος (q.v.), ib. 41; ἑτοιμάζειν τ., Jo 14:2, 3; ἔχειν, Re 12:6; διδόναι, Lk 14:9; c. gen. defin., τ. βασάνου, Lk 16:28; τ. καταπαύσεως, Ac 7:49; κρανίου, Mt 27:33, Mk 15:22, Jo 19:17; seq. οὗ, Ro 9:26; ὅπου, Mt 28:6, Mk 16:6, Jo 4:20 6:23 10:40 11:30 19:41; ἐν ᾧ, Jo 11:6; ἐφ ̓ ᾧ, Ac 7:33; of a place which a person or thing occupies, Re 2:5 6:14 12:8; τ. μαχαίρας, Mt 26:52; ὁ ἴδιος τ., Ac 1:25; of a place in a book, Lk 4:17 (cf. Clem. Rom., I Co., 8, 4). Metaph., of condition, station, occasion, opportunity or power: Ac 25:16, Ro 12:19 15:23, Eph 4:27 (cf. Si 38:12).

(He 7:22) and (elsewhere, as usually in Attic) -οῦτον, correlat. of ὅσος, of quantity, size, number, so great, so much, pl., so many: Mt 8:10 Lk 7:9, He 12:1, Re 18:7, 16; of time, so long, χρόνος, Jo 14:9, He 4:7; pl., Lk 15:29 (ἔτη), Jo 12:37 21:11, I Co 14:10; seq. ὥστε, Mt 15:33; absol.: pl., Jo 6:9, Ga 3:4; of price, τοσούτου, Ac 5:8; dat., τοσούτῳ κρείττων, He 1:4; τ. μᾶλλον ὅσῳ, He 10:25; καθ' ὅσον . . . κατὰ τ., He 7:22.†

then, at that time; of concurrent events: Mt 2:17 3:5 and freq., Ro 6:21; seq. ptcp., Mt 2:16, Ga 4:8; opp. to νῦν, Ga 4:29, He 12:26; ὁ τ. κόσμος, II Pe 3:6; of consequent events, then, thereupon: Mt 2:7 3:5 4:1 and freq., Lk 11:26; τ. οὖν, Jo 11:14 19:1, 16 20:8; εὐθέως τ., Ac 17:14; ὅτε . . . τ., Mt 13:26 21:1, Jo 12:16; ἀπὸ τ., Mt 4:17 16:21 26:16, Lk 16:16; of things future: Mt 24:28, 40 25:1, 31ff.; opp. to ἄρτι, I Co 13:12; καὶ τ., Mt 7:23, Mk 13:21, Lk 21:27, I Co 4:5, al.; ὅταν . . . τ., Mt 9:15, Mk 2:20, Lk 5:35, I Th 5:3, al. (more freq. in Mt than in the rest of the NT).
by crasis for τὸ ἐνανίον, neut. acc, used adverbially, on the contrary, contrariwise: II Co 2:7, Ga 2:7, I Pe 3:9.†
by crasis for τὸ ὄνομα, acc absol.,; by name: Mt 27:57.†

a table, dining-table: Mt 15:27, Mk 7:28, Lk 16:21 19:23 22:21, 30; of the table of shewbread, He 9:2. By meton., of food provided (v. DB, iv, 670 a): Ac 16:34, Ro 11:9 (LXX) I Co 10:21; διακονεῖν ταῖς τ., Ac 6:2 (cf. Page, in l, but v. infr.).; A money-changer's table, a bank (Dem., Arist., al.): Mt 21:12, Mk 11:15, Lk 19:23, Jo 2:15; so also acc to Dr. Field (Notes, 113), Ac 6:2 (but v. supr.).†
a money­changer, banker: Mt 25:27 (Dem., Plut., al.).†
a wowed: Lk 10:34.†
to wound: Lk 20:12, Ac 19:16.†

prop., of wrestlers,; to take by the throat, hence (Philo), to prostrate, overthrow. Metaph., but in what sense and from what age it is doubtful (v. Westc., Rendall, on He, l.c.; DB, iii, 625n), τραχηλισμένα, laid open (RV, Westc.; downcast, Rendall): He 4:13.†

the neck: Mt 18:6, Mk 9:42, Lk 17:2; ἐπιπεσεῖν ἐπὶ τὸν τ., to embrace (Ge 46:29), Lk 15:20, Ac 20:37. Metaph., ὑποθεῖναι τὸν ἑαυτοῦ τ. (for similar phrase in π., v. Zorell, s.v.), Ro 16:4; ἐπιθεῖναι ζυγὸν ἐπὶ τὸν τ., Ac 15:10.†
rough: ὁδοί (Is, l.c.), Lk 3:5 (LXX); τοποί (i.e. rocky), Ac 27:29.†
Trachonitis, a rough region S. of Damascus (in FlJ, sometimes ἡ Τ., sometimes ό Τράχων): ἡ Τ. χώρα, Lk 3:1.†

three: Mt 12:40, al.; μετὰ τ. ἡμέρας = τῇ τρίτῃ ἡ., Mk 10:34, al. (cf. Field, Notes, 11 ff.); Τρεῖς Ταβέρναι; Three Taverns (Lit. Tres Tabernae) a halting place on the Appian Way: Ac 28:15 (v. DB, iv, 690).†
to tremble, esp. with fear: Mk 5:33, Lk 8:47; c. ptcp. (in cl more freq. c. inf.), II Pe 2:10.†

to make to grow, bring up, rear (cl.; I Mac 3:33 Mac 11:39): Lk 4:16 (T, WH, mg., ἀνατ-); to nourish, feed: Mt 6:26 25:37, Lk 12:24, Ac 12:20, Re 12:6, 14; of a mother, to give suck, Lk 23:29; of animals, to fatten (Je 26:21 (Je 46:21), fig., Ja 5:5 (cf. ἀνα-, ἐκ-, ἐν-τρέφω).†

to run: Mk 5:6, Jo 20:2, 4, I Co 9:24 9:26; c. inf., Mt 28:8; seq. ἐπί, Lk 24:12 [T [WH] R, mg., om.]; εἰς, Re 9:9; ptcp., δραμών, c. indic., Mt 27:48, Mk 15:36, Lk 15:20. Metaph., from runners in a race, of swiftness or of effort to attain an end: Ro 9:16, Ga 2:2 5:7, Phl 2:16; τ. ἀγῶνα (Hdt., Eur., al.), He 12:1; ὁ λόγος τ. κυρίου (cf. Ps 147:4), ἕως τάχους δραμεῖται ὁ λ. αὐτοῦ), II Th 3:1 (cf. εἰς-, κατα-, περι-, προ-, προσ-, συν-, ἐπι-συν-, ὑπο-τρέχω); δράμω, obsol., to run, v.s. τρέχω
a perforation, hole: ῥαφίδος, Mt 19:24, WH, txt. βελόνης, Lk 18:25 (Aristoph., Plat., al.).†
thirty: Mt 13:8, al.
three hundred: Mk 14:5, Jo 12:5.†
a thistle: Mt 7:16, He 6:8.†
a beaten track, a path: Mt 3:3, Mk 1:3, Lk 3:4 (LXX).†
a period of three years: Ac 20:31.†
prop., of sounds by animals, to cry, chirp, etc.; Of other sounds, e.g., trans., τ. ὀδόντας, to gnash or grind the teeth: Mk 9:18.†
of three months; as subst., τὸ τ. (= cl. ἡ τ.), a space of three months (Polyb., al.; LXX): He 11:23.†
of three stories: τὸ τ. (sc. ὄκημα),; the third story, Ac 20:9 (Dion., FlJ, al.).†
three thousand: Ac 2:41.†

the third: Mt 22:26, Mk 12:21 15:25, Lk 24:21, Ac 2:15, al.; τῇ τ. ἡμέρᾳ (i.e. the next day but one: Xen., al.; v. Field, Notes, 11 ff.), Mt 16:21, Lk 24:46, al.; substantively, acc masc., τρίτον, a third (servant), Lk 20:12; neut., τὸ τ., c. gen., the third part of: Re 8:7-12 9:15, 18 12:4. As adv., τὸ τ., the third time: Mk 14:41, Jo 21:17; anarth., τρίτον, a third time, Lk 23:22, Jo 21:14, II Co 12:14 13:1; in enumerations, thirdly, I Co 12:28; ἐκ τ., a third time, Mt 26:44
of hair: στόκος, Re 6:12 (Xen., Plat., al.).†
trembling, quaking, esp. from fear: Mk 16:8; φόβος κ. τ. (as in Ge 9:2, Ex 15:16, De 2:25, Is 19:16, al.), I Co 2:3, II Co 7:15, Eph 6:5, Phl 2:12.†
a turning: esp. of the revolution of heavenly bodies, fig., Ja 1:17 (v.s. ἀποσκίασμα).†

a way, manner, fashion: Mt 23:37, Lk 13:34, Ac 1:11 7:28, II Ti 3:8, Ju 7; καθ' ὃν τ., Ac 15:11 27:25 (ef. MM, xxv); κατὰ πάντα τ., Ro 3:2; κατὰ μηδένα τ. (IV Mac 4:24, al.), II Th 2:3; (ἐν) παντὶ τ., Phl 1:18, II Th 3:16; Of persons, manner of life, character (Hdt., Æsch., al.): He 13:5.†
to bear another's manners (R, txt., suffered he their manners): c. acc pers., Ac 13:18 (Rec., WH, R, txt.; ἐτροφο-, T, R, mg.).; = τροφοφορέω (q.v.), (v. Kühner3, I, 276): Ac, l.c.†
Trophimus: Ac 20:4 21:29, II Ti 4:20.†
a nurse: I Th 2:7.†
to nourish (Hesych.), bear like a nurse (R, mg., bare he them as a nursing-father): c. acc pers., Ac 13:18, T, Tr., R, mg. (WH, R, txt., τροποφορέω, q.v.).†
the track of a wheel, hence, a track, path: fig., He 12:13 (LXX) †
a wheel: Ja 3:6 (v. Mayor, Hort, in l).†
a bowl, dish: Mt 26:23, Mk 14:20 (Hippocr., Aristoph., Pint., al.).†
to gather in: c. acc,; of the fruit, Lk 6:44, Re 14:18; of that from which it is gathered, Re 14:19.†
a turtle-dove: Lk 2:24.†
= τρύμη, a hole: τ. ῥαφίδος, eye of a needle, Mk 10:25.†
a hole: τ. ῥαφιδος, eye of a needle, Mt 19:24 (WH, txt., τρῆμα).†
Tryphæna: Ro 16:12 (v. Lft., Phi., 175 f.; MM, xxv).†
to live daintily, luxuriously, to fare sumptuously: Ja 5:5 (cf. ἐν-τρυφάω).†
softness, daintiness, luxuriousness: Lk 7:25, II Pe 2:13.†
Tryphosa: Ro 16:12 (v. Lft., Phi., 175 f.).†
Troas, a city near the Hellespont: Ac 16:8, 11 20:5-6, II Co 2:12, II Ti 4:13.†
Trogyllium, a city of Ionia: Ac 20:15 (WH, txt., R, txt., om.).†

prop., of animals, to gnaw, munch, crunch (Hom., al.).; Of men, to eat raw food, as vegetables, nuts, etc. (Hdt., al.).; In late vernacular, simply to eat (= ἐσθίω): Mt 24:38, Jo 6:54, 56-58 13:18 (LXX ἐσθίων) (v. Kennedy, Sources, 82, 155; MM, xxv).†

Trans.; to hit (opp. to ἁμαρτάνω, to miss the mark: Hom., Xen., al.).; to hit upon, light upon; of persons, to meet with, fall in with: absol., ptcp., ὁ τυχών, a chance person, anyone (Lat. quivis), οὐ τυχών, not common or ordinary, Ac 19:11 28:2; of things, to reach, get, obtain: c. gen. rei.
