Lk 20:35, Ac 24:3 26:22 27:3, II Ti 2:10 He 8:6 11:35.; Intrans., to happen; of things, to happen, chance, befall: impers., εἰ τύχοι, it may be, perhaps, I Co 14:10 15:37; so ptcp., τυχόν (old acc absol.; v. M, Pr., 74), I Co 16:6; τυχόν, adv., v.s. τυγχάνω
to beat a drum.; to torture by beating, beat to death (cf. Westc. on He, l.c.): pass., He 11:35.†

the mark of a blow: τῶν ἥλων, Jo 20:25.; An impression, impress, the stamp made by a die; hence, a figure, image: Ac 7:43 (LXX).; form (Plat.): Ro 6:17; the sense or substance of a letter (3Mac, l.c.), Ac 23:25.; an example, pattern: Ac 7:44, He 8:6 (LXX); in ethical sense, Phl 3:17, I Th 1:7, II Th 3:9, I Ti 4:12, Tit 2:7, I Pe 5:3; in doctrinal sense, type (v. ICC, in l), Ro 5:14.†; τυπικῶς, adv.; typically (Greg. Naz.); by way of example: I Co 10:11.†

to strike, smite, beat: c. acc, Mt 24:49, Mk 15:19, Lk 12:45, Ac 18:17 21:32 23:2-3; of mourners, τὰ στήθη, Lk 18:13 23:48; ἐπὶ τ. σιαγόνα, Lk 6:29; εἰς τ. κεφαλήν, Mt 27:30. Metaph., of God inflicting evil: Ac 23:3 (cf. Ex 8:2, Ez 7:9, al.); of disquieting conscience, I Co 8:12.†
Tyrannus: Ac 19:9.†
to disturb, trouble: pass., Lk 10:41, Rec. (WH, R, θορυβάζω).†
a Tyrian: Ac 12:20.†
Tyre, a maritime city of Phænicia: Mk 7:31, Ac 21:3, 7; Τ. κ, Σιδών, Mt 11:21-22 15:21, Mk 3:8 7:24, Lk 6:17 10:13-14.†
blind: as subst., ὁ τ., Mt 9:27, Mk 8:22, Lk 4:18 (LXX), Jo 5:3, al. Metaph.: Mt 15:14 23:16-26, Jo 9:39-41, Ro 2:19, II Pe 1:9, Re 3:17.
to blind, make blind: metaph., Jo 12:40 (LXX, καμμύω), II Co 4:4, I Jn 2:11.†
prop., to wrap in smoke; used only metaph., to puff up, becloud with pride: pass., I Ti 3:6 6:4, II Ti 3:4 (Dem., Arist., al.).†
to raise a smoke; pass., to smoke: Mt 12:20 (LXX, καπνιζόμενον).†
tempestuous: Ac 27:14.†
Tychicus: Ac 20:4, Eph 6:21, Col 4:7, II Ti 4:12, Tit 3:12.†
of hyacinth, hyacinthine (v.s. ὑάκινθος), "doubtless meant to describe the blue smoke of a sulphurous flame" (Swete): Re 9:17 (Hom., Eur., al.).†
hyacinth; in cl., a flower, prob. the dark blue iris; in late writers, a precious stone of the same colour, perhaps the sapphire: Re 21:20 (Phil., FlJ, al.).†
of glass, glassy Re 4:6 15:2.†
(Hdt.) a clear transparent stone.; (from Plat. on) glass: Re 21:18, 21.†
intrans., to wax wanton, run riot.; Trans., to outrage, insult, treat insolently: c. acc pers., Mt 22:6, Lk 11:45 18:32, Ac 14:5, I Th 2:2.†
wantonness, insolence.; = ὕβρισμα, an act of wanton violence, an outrage, injury: II Co 12:10; metaph., of a loss by sea (find.), Ac 27:10, 21 (v. MM, xxv).†
a violent, insolent man: Ro 1:20, I Ti 1:13 (EV, injurious).†

to be sound, healthy, in good health: Lk 5:31 7:10 15:27, III Jo 2. In Past. Epp. (as also in cl.) metaph., ὑ. ἐν τ. πίστει, Tit 1:13 ; τ. πίστει, τ. ἀγάπῃ, τ. ὑπομονῇ, Tit 2:2; ἡ ὑγιαίνουσα διδασκαλία, I Ti 1:10, II Ti 4:3, Tit 1:9 2:1 ; λόγοι ὑγιαίνοντες, I Ti 6:3 , II Ti 1:13.†
sound, whole, healthy: Mt 12:13 15:31, Jo 5:[4], 6, 9, 11, 14, 15 7:23, Ac 4:10; seq. ἀπό, Mk 5:34; of words, opinions, etc. (as in cl.), metaph., λόγος, Tit 2:8.†
wet, moist, opp. to ξηρός: of wood, sappy, green: Lk 23:31.†
prop., a water-pot or jar: Jo 2:6, 7 John 4:28. More freq. in Attic = ἄγγυς, a pot, urn or jar of any kind, as for holding wine, coins, etc. (v. Rutherford, NPhr., 23; MM, xxv).†
to drink water, opp. to οἴνῳ χρῆσθαι: I Ti 5:23 (Hdt., i, 71; Plat., Rep., 561 c, al.).†
dropsical, suffering from dropsy: Lk 14:2.†

gen.,; ὕδατος, τό,; water: Mt 3:16, Mk 1:10, Lk 7:44, Jo 4:7, Ja 3:12, Re 8:10, al.; pl., Mt 14:28-29, Jo 3:23, Re 1:15, al.; βαπτίζειν (ἐν) ὕδατι, Mt 3:11, Mk 1:8, Jo 1:26, al.; τ. λυυτρὸν τοῦ ὕ., Eph 5:26; opp. to οἴνος, Jo 2:9 4:46; αἷμα, Jo 19:34, He 9:19, I Jn 5:6 Jn 5:8 Mt 17:15 Mk 9:22; πνεῦμα, Jo 1:26, 31 1:33; πνεῦμα καὶ πῦρ, Mt 3:11, Lk 3:16;ἐξ ὕ. κ. πνεύματος γεννηθῆναι, Jo 3:5; metaph., of divine truth and grace (τ.) ὕ. (τ.) ζῶν, Jo 4:10-11 (cf. Jo 4:13-15); τ. ὕ. τ. ζωῆς, of spiritual refresh­ment, Re 21:6 22:1, 17
with Israel: Ro 9:4; with Christ­ians: Ro 8:15, Ga 4:5, Eph 1:5; of its consummation, Ro 8:23.†

a son; in the ordinary sense: Mt 10:37, Mk 9:17, Lk 1:13, al. mult.; omitted with the art. of origin (WM, §30, 3; Bl., §35, 2), τὸν τοῦ Ἰεσσαί, Ac 13:22 (LXX); also c. gen. anarth. (cl.), Σώπατρος Πύρρου Βεροιαῖος, Ac 20:4; c. adj., προτότοκος, Lk 2:7; μονογένης, Lk 7:12; opp. to νόθος, He 12:8; in a wider sense, of posterity: ὁ υἱ. Δαυΐδ, of the Messiah (cf. Dalman, Words, 316ff.; DCG, ii, 653f.), Mt 22:42, 45 Mk 12:35, 37 Lk 20:41, 44 al.; υἱοὶ Ἰσραήλ, (cf. υἷες Ἀχαιῶν, Hom., Il., i, 162, al.), Mt 27:9, Ac 9:15, al. Metaph.; as belonging to, being connected with or having the quality of that which follows (a usage mainly due to translation from a Semitic original; cf. Deiss., BS, 161ff.; Dalman, Words, 115f.; DCG, ii, 652f.): τ. πονεροῦ (διαβόλου), Mt 13:38, Ac 13:10; τ. νυμφῶνος (v.s. νυμφών), Mt 9:15, Mk 2:19, al.; τ. φωτός (Lft., Notes, 74), Lk 16:8, Jo 12:36, I Th 5:5; τ. εἰρεήμης, Lk 10:6; γεέννης, Mt 23:15; τ. ἀπωλείας, Jo 17:12, II Th 2:3; τ. αἰῶνος τούτου, Lk 16:8 20:34; τ. ἀπειθειάς, Eph 2:2 5:6; βροντῆς, Mk 3:17; τ. ἀναστάσεως, Lk 20:36; παρακλήσεως, Ac 4:36; τ. προφητῶν κ. τ. διαθήκης, Ac 3:25; υἱὸς τ. θεοῦ (cf. Dalman, Words, 268ff.; Deiss., BS, 166f.; DB, iv, 570 ff.; DCG, ii, 654ff.), of men, as partakers of the Divine nature and of the life to come: Mt 5:9, Lk 20:36, Ro 8:14 9:26, al.; υἱοὶ (κ. θυγατέρες) τ. ὑψίστου, Lk 6:35, II Co 6:18; in an unique sense of Jesus, Mt 4:3 8:29 28:19, Mk 3:4, Lk 4:41, Jo 9:35 11:27, al.; ὁ Χριστὸς ὁ υἱ. τ. θεοῦ ζῶντος (τ. εὐλογητοῦ), Mt 16:16, Mk 14:61; (ὁ) υἱὸς τοῦ ἀνθρώπου (in LXX for Heb. בּן אדם, Aram, בּר אנשׁ; cf. Dalman, Words, 234ff.; DB, iv, 579ff.; DCG, ii, 659ff.; Westc., St. John, i, 74ff.; other reff. in Swete, Mk, 2:10), based on the Aram. of Da 7:13, where the phrase, like the corresponding Heb. (as in Ps 8:5), means a man, one of the species, and indicates the human appearance of the person in question. It is used of the Messiah in Enoch, c. 46, §1-4, also in II Es 13:3, 12, al. Our Lord first makes the phrase a title, using the def. art. It seems to combine the ideas of his true humanity and representative character. Exc. in Ac 7:56 and (anarth.) Re 1:13 14:14, it is used of Jesus only by himself: Mt 8:20, Mk 2:10, Lk 5:24, Jo 1:52, al.

wood, forest, woodland (Thus., Xen., al.).; wood, timber, fuel (Hom., Hdt., Thuc., al.): Ja 3:5 (v. Hort, Ja., 70, 104 f.).; = Lat. materia, esp. in Philosophy, matter (Arist. and later writers; Wis, ll. c.).†
Hymenæus: I Ti 1:20, II Ti 2:17.†

poss. pron. of second pers. pl. (= emphasized gen., ὑμῶν),; your, yours: Jo 7:6 8:17 15:20, Ac 27:34, Ro 11:31, I Co 16:17, II Co 8:8, Ga 6:13; as pred., Lk 6:20; τὸ ὑ., as subst., opp. to τ. ἀλλότριον, Lk 16:12 (WH, txt., R, mg., ἡμέτερον); objectively, ὑ. καύχησις, my glorying in you, I Co 15:31.†

trans., c. acc pers. (in cl. also c. acc rei), to sing to, laud, sing to the praise of: Ac 16:25, He 2:12.; Intrans., to sing: in LXX and NT, of singing hymns and praises to God (Ps 65:13, al.), Mt 26:30, Mk 14:26 (v. Swete, in l).†
a hymn; in cl. a festal song in praise of gods or heroes; in LXX and NT a song of praise addressed to God: Eph 5:19, Col 3:16.†

a word of the vulgar language, in Pres. and impf. only (Bl., § 53, 1).; Trans.; to lead or bring under, subdue (Hom., Hdt., al.; Ex, l.c.).; to lead on slowly (Hdt., Xen., al.).; Intrans., to go slowly away, withdraw oneself, depart (so less freq. in cl.; Thuc., Eur., al.): absol., Mt 8:32 13:44, Mk 6:33, Lk 8:42 17:14, Jo 6:67 8:2 11:44 14:5, 28 18:8; οἱ ἐρχόμενοι κ. οἱ ὑπάγοντες, Mk 6:31; ὑπῆγον κ. ἐπίστευον, Jo 12:11; ἵνα ὑπαγῆτε κ. καρπὸν ψέρητε, Jo 15:16; opp. to ἔρχεσθαι, Jo 3:8 8:14; imperat., ὕπαγε, Mt 4:10 8:13 20:14, Mk 2:9 T, Mk 7:29 10:52; εἰς εἰρήνην (ἐν εἰ.), Mk 5:34, Ja 2:16; id. prefixed to another imperat. (Bl., § 79, 4), Mt 5:34 8:4 18:15 19:21 21:28 27:65 28:10, Mk 1:44 10:21 16:7, Jo 4:16 9:7, Re 10:8; with καί inserted, Re 16:1; euphemistically, of death, Mt 26:24, Mk 14:21; c. adv.: ποῦ (q.v.), Jo 12:35 14:5 16:5, I Jn 2:11; ὅπου (q.v.), Jo 8:21-22 13:33, 36 14:4 Re 14:4; ἐκεῖ, Jo 11:8; c. prep.: πρός, Jo 7:33 13:3 16:5, 10 16:17; εἰς, Mt 9:6 20:4, 7, Mk 2:11 11:2 14:13, Lk 19:30, Jo 6:21 7:3 9:11 11:31, Re 13:10 17:8, 11; εἰς . . . πρός, Mt 26:18, Mk 5:19; ἐπί, Lk 12:58; μετά, Mt 5:41; ὀπίσω, Mt 16:23, Mk 8:33; c. inf., Jo 21:3.†

obedience (opp. to παρακοή); in general, absol., εἰς ὑ., Ro 6:16; c. gen. subjc., II Co 7:15 10:6, Phm 21; c. gen. obj., Ro 1:5 (Lft, Notes, 246) Ro 16:26, I Pe 1:22; τ. Χριστοῦ, II Co 10:5.; Of obedience to God's commands: absol., I Pe 1:2; opp. to ἁμαρτία, Ro 6:16; τέκνα ὑπακοῆς, I Pe 1:14; c. gen. subj., Ro 15:18 16:19.; Of Christ's obedience: absol., He 5:8; c. gen. subj., Ro 5:19.; (The word is not found except in LXX, NT and eccl.).†

to listen, attend, hence,; to answer a knock at a door (Plat., Xen., al.): Ac 12:13; to attend to, submit to, obey (Hdt., Thuc., al.): absol., Phl 2:12; c. inf., He 11:8; c. dat. pers. (Plat., al.; but more freq. c. gen.), Mt 8:27, Mk 1:27 4:41, Lk 8:25 17:6, Ro 6:16, Eph 6:1, 5, Col 3:20, 22, He 5:9, I Pe 3:6; c. dat. rei, Ac 6:7, Ro 6:12 10:16, II Th 1:8 3:14; seq. εἰς (by attraction, for dat.; v. ICC, in l), Ro 6:17.†
under or subject to a man, married: γυνή, Ro 7:2 (Polyb., Diod., al.).†
to go to meet, meet: c. dat. pers. (v. M, Pr., 64), Mt 8:28 28:9, Mk 5:2, Lk 8:27 17:12 (ἀπ-, WH, txt.), Jo 4:51 11:20, 30 12:18, Ac 16:16; of meeting in battle, Lk 14:31.†
a going to meet: εἰς ὑ. (v. M, Pr 14:1-35 n), Mt 8:34 25:1, Jo 12:13.†
subsistence, existence (Arist., al.).; In late writers, = τὰ ὑπάρχοντα, substance, property: He 10:34; pl., Ac 2:45.†

to begin, make a beginning (Hom., Hdt., al.).; to be in existence, be ready, be at hand (Hdt., Thuc., al.): Ac 19:40 27:12, 21; seq. ἐν, Ac 28:18.; to be, prop, expressing continuance of an antecedent state or condition (cf. Gifford, Incarnation, 11 ff.; MM, xxv): c, nom, pred., Lk 8:41 9:48, Ac 4:34 7:55 8:16 16:3 19:36 21:20, I Co 7:26 12:22, Ja 2:15, II Pe 3:11; ptcp. c. pred., Lk 16:14 23:50, Ac 2:30, 32 17:24 22:3, Ro 4:19, I Co 2:15, II Co 8:17 12:16, Ga 1:14 2:14; pl., Lk 11:13, Ac 16:20, 37 17:29, II Pe 2:19; seq. ἐν, c. dat. rei, Lk 7:25 16:23, Ac 5:4 10:12, I Co 11:18, Phl 3:20; ἐν μορφῇ θεοῦ ὑπάρχων (R, mg., being originally), Phl 2:6; ἐν, c. dat. pers., (among), I Co 11:18; μακρὰν ἀπό, Ac 17:27; πρὸς τ. σωτηρίας, Ac 27:34.; to belong to (Thuc., Xen., al.): c. dat. pers., Ac 3:6 4:37 28:7, II Pe 1:8; τὰ ὑπάρχοντα, one's belongings, possessions: c. dat. pers., Lk 8:3 12:15, Ac 4:32; c. gen. pers., Mt 19:21 24:47 25:14, Lk 11:21 12:33, 44 14:33 16:1 19:8, I Co 13:3, He 10:34 (cf. προ-υπάρχω).†
to retire, withdraw.; to yield, submit: metaph., He 13:17.†
set over against, opposite. Metaph. (Plat., Arist., al.), opposed to, contrary to: c. dat. pers., Col 2:14; absol., as subst., ὁ ὑ., He 10:27 (cf. Is 26:11).†

C. gen., primarily of place (rest or motion), over, above, across, beyond, hence, metaph., for, on behalf of: of prayer, Mt 5:44, Ac 8:24, Ro 10:1, Ja 5:16, al.; of laying down life, Jo 10:11, Ro 9:3, al.; esp. of Christ giving his life for man's redemption, Mk 14:24, Jo 10:15, Ac 21:13, Ro 5:6-8, al.; opp. to κατά, Mk 9:40, Lk 9:50, Ro 8:31. Causal, for, because of, for the sake of: c. gen. pers., Ac 5:41, Ro 1:5, Phl 1:29, II Co 12:10, al.; c. gen. rei, Jo 11:4, Ro 15:8, II Co 1:6, al. = ἀντί (v. M, Pr., 105), for, instead of, in the name of: I Co 15:29, II Co 5:15, 21 Ga 3:13, Col 1:7, Phm 13 (cf. Field, Notes, 225). In more colourless sense, = περί (M, Pr., l.c.), for, concerning, with regard to: Ro 9:27, II Co 1:6 8:23 12:8, Phl 1:7, II Th 2:1, al. C. acc., primarily of place, over, beyond, across, hence, metaph., of measure or degree in excess, above, beyond, over, more than: Mt 10:24, 37 Lk 6:40, Ac 26:13, I Co 10:13, II Co 1:8, Eph 1:22 3:20, Phm 16, al.; after comparatives = than (Jg 11:25, al.), Lk 16:8, He 4:12. As adv. (v. supr. ad init.), more: ὕπερ ἐγώ, I more, II Co 11:23; in compounds, v.s. ὑπεράνω, ὑπερλίαν, ὑπερπερισσῶς. In composition: over (ὑπεραίρω), beyond (ὑπερβάλλω), more (ὐπερνικάω), on behalf of (ὐπερεντυγχάνω).
to lift or raise over. Mid., to uplift oneself: II Co 12:7; seq. ἐπί, c. acc, pers., II Th 2:4 (cf. II Mac 5:23).†
past the bloom of youth: I Co 7:36 (Eustath.).†
above: as prep. c. gen., Eph 1:21 4:10, He 9:5.†
to increase beyond measure: II Th 1:3 (v. Lft., Notes, 98).†
trans., to step over, trans­gress (R, overreach: I Th 4:6).; Intrans., to transgress: metaph., I Th 4:6 (R, txt.; v. M, Th., in l).†
above measure: II Co 11:23.†
trans., to throw over or beyond.; Intrans., to run beyond. In both senses, metaph., to exceed, surpass, transcend: II Co 3:10 9:14, Eph 1:19 2:7; c. gen. obj., Eph 3:19.†

a throwing beyond. Metaph., excess, superiority, excellence: II Co 4:7 12:7; καθ' ὑπερβολήν, beyond measure, exceedingly, Ro 7:13, I Co 12:31, II Co 1:8, Ga 1:13; κ. ὑ. εἰς ὑ., beyond all measure, II Co 4:17.†
to overlook: c. acc rei, Ac 17:30
comp. adv. (v. Bl., 28, 2; M, Pr., 99),; beyond: as prep. c. gen., τὰ ὑ. ὑμῶν, II Co 10:16 (Byz. and Ec 1:1-18.).†
to stretch out overmuch: metaph., ἑαυτούς, II Co 10:14.†
to pour out over. Pass., to overflow, run over: Lk 6:38 (not elsewhere).†
to intercede or make petition for (v. Deiss., BS, 121 f.): seq. ὑπέρ, Ro 8:26.†

trans., to hold over or above.; Intrans. (when a noun follows, the case is governed by the prep.; v. Bl., § 34, 1; 36, 8), to rise above, overtop; metaph.,; to be superior in rank, etc.: Ro 13:1, I Pe 2:13 (cf. Wi 6:6); to be superior, excel, surpass: c. gen. (cl.; v. supr.), Phl 2:3; c. acc (cl.; v. supr.), Phl 4:7; as subst., τ. ὑπερέχον, the excel­lency, the surpassing worth, Phl 3:8.†
haughtiness, arrogance, disdain: Mk 7:22 (Plat., Xen.).†

showing oneself above others; in good sense (Plat., al.), pre-eminent, splendid; more freq. in had sense, and so always in Scr., arrogant, haughty, disdainful (v. Westc. Epp. Jo., 65b): Ro 1:30, II Ti 3:2; διανοίᾳ καρδίας, Lk 1:51; opp. to ταπεινός (as in Pr 3:34), Ja 4:6, I Pe 5:5 (LXX).†
exceedingly, pre-eminently: II Co 11:5 12:11.†
to be more than conqueror: Ro 8:37 (eccl.).†
of excessive weight or size; metaph., excessive, immoderate, in late writers, of arrogant speech (v. Mayor on Ju, l.c.): n. pl., II Pe 2:18, Ju 16.†

a projection, eminence, as the peak of a mountain. Metaph. (Arist.), excellence, pre-eminence: λόγου ἢ σοφίας, I Co 2:1; οἱ ἐν ὑ (for a parallel to this phrase, v. Deiss., BS, 255, and cf. 2Mac, l.c.), I Ti 2:2.†
to abound more exceedingly: Ro 5:21. Mid., in same sense (RV, overflow): c. dat. rei, II Co 7:4.†
beyond measure, exceedingly: Mk 7:37.†
to abound exceedingly: I Ti 1:14 (Ps Sol 5:19; Herm., Mand., v, 2, 5).†
to exalt beyond measure, exalt to the highest place: Phl 2:9.; to extol (Da, ll. c.).†
to be overproud, high-minded (Æsch.): μὴ ὑ. παρ' ὃ δεῖ φρονεῖν (on the paranom., v. Vau., in l), Ro 12:3.; to overlook, think slightly of (Thuc., Plat.).†

in cl., the upper story or upper rooms where the women resided (Hom., a1.).; In LXX and NT, an upper chamber, roof-chamber, built on the flat roof of the house (v. DB, iii, 674a): Ac 1:13 9:37, 39 20:8 (cf. IV Ki 23:22).†
to hold or put under. Metaph., to undergo, suffer: δίκην, Ju 7 (Soph., Eur., al.).†
giving ear, obedient, subject: Phl 2:8; c. dat. pers., Ac 7:39; εἰς πάντα, II Co 2:9.†
prop., to serve as rower on a ship (Diod., al.). In cl. always metaph., to minister to, serve: c. dat. pers., Ac 13:36 20:34 24:23.†

prop., an under rower; hence, generally, a servant, attendant, minister: of a magistrate's attendant, Mt 5:25; of officers of the Synagogue or Sanhedrin, Mt 26:58, Mk 14:54, 65, Lk 4:20, Jo 7:32, 45-46 18:3, 12 18:22 19:6, Ac 5:22, 26; of the attendants of kings, οἱ ὑ. οἱ ἑμοί Jo 18:36; of Christian ministers, Ac 13:5 26:16; ὑπηρέται λόγου, Lk 1:2; Χριστοῦ, I Co 4:1; δοῦλοι κ. ὑ., Jo 18:18.†
sleep: Mt 1:24, Lk 9:32, Jo 11:13, Ac 20:9; metaph., Ro 13:11.†

C. gen., primarily of place, under, hence, metaph., of the efficient cause, by: after passive verbs, c. gen. pers., Mt 1:22, Mk 1:5, Lk 2:18, Jo 14:21, Ac 4:11, I Co 1:11, He 3:4, al.; c. gen. rei, Mt 8:24, Lk 7:24, Ro 3:21, al.; with neut. verbs and verbs with pass, meaning, Mt 17:12, Mk 5:26, I Co 10:9, 10 I Th 2:14, al. C. acc., under; of motion: Mt 5:15 8:8, Mk 4:21, Lk 13:34; hence, metaph., of subjection, Ro 7:14, I Co 15:27, Ga 3:22, I Pe 5:6, al. Of position: Jo 1:49, Ac 4:12, Ro 3:13, I Co 10:1, al.; hence, metaph., under, subject to, Mt 8:9, Ro 3:9, I Co 9:20, Ga 4:5, al. Of time, about: Ac 5:21. In composition: under (ὑποδέω), hence, of subjection (ὑποτάσσω), compliance (ὑπακούω), secrecy (ὑποβάλλω), diminution (ὑποπνέω).
to throw or put under. Metaph.,; to subject, submit; to suggest, whisper, prompt; to suborn (v. Field, Notes, 113), instigate: c. acc pers., Ac 6:11.†
a writing-copy, hence,; an example: I Pe 2:11 (Philo).†
used by later writers (Xen. onwards) for παράδειγμα (v. Rutherford, NPhr., 62),; a figure, copy: He 8:5 9:23; an example: for imitation, Jo 13:15, Ja 5:10; for warning, He 4:11, II Pe 2:6.†
to show secretly.; to show by tracing out; hence, generally, to teach, make known: c. dat. pers., Lk 6:47 12:5, Ac 9:16; id. c. inf., Mt 3:7, Lk 3:7; seq., ὅτι, Ac 20:35.†
to receive under one's roof, receive as a guest, entertain hospitably: c. acc pers., Lk 19:6, Ac 17:7, Ja 2:25; εἰς τ. οἶκον, Lk 10:38 (v. MM, xxv).†
to blind under, esp. of foot gear. Most freq. in mid, and pass. c. acc; of the foot, ὑποδησάμενοι τ. πόδας, your feet shod: Eph 6:15; of that which is put on, σανδάλια: Mk 6:9, Ac 12:8.†
a sole bound under the foot, a sandal: Mt 3:11 10:10, Mk 1:7, Lk 3:16 10:4 15:22 22:35, Jo 1:27; τ. ποδῶν, Ac 7:33 (LXX) Ac 13:25.†
brought to trial, answerable to: c. dat. pers., τ. θεῷ, Ro 3:19 (v. MM, xxv).†
under the yoke; as subst., τ . (Hdt., al.), a beast of burden; colloq., an ass (v. Deiss., BS, 160 f.), and so always in LXX and NT: Mt 21:5 (LXX), II Pe 2:16.†
to undergird (Hdt., al.; ὑπὸ τ. μάστους, 2Mac, l.c.); of a ship, to undergird or frap: Ac 27:17 (v. DB, ext. 367a).†
below, under: as prep. c. gen., Mt 22:44, Mk 6:11 7:28 12:36 (Rec., R, txt., ὑποπόδιον, as in LXX), Lk 8:16, Jo 1:51, He 2:8 (LXX), Re 5:3, 13 6:9 12:1.†

= Att.. ἀποκρίνομαι (q.v.), to answer, reply (Hom., Hdt., al.).; to answer on the stage, play apart (Arist., al.). Metaph., to feign, pretend (Demos., Polyb.): c. acc et inf., Lk 20:20 (cf. Ps sol 4:22).†
a reply, answer (Hdt.).; play-acting (Arist., Polyb., al.). Metaph., pretence, hypocrisy: Mt 23:28, Mk 12:15, Lk 12:1, Ga 2:13, I Ti 4:2, I Pe 2:1 (Polyb., Pss Ca 4:7).†

one who answers, an interpreter (Plat.).; a stage player, actor (Plut., Xen., al.). Metaph. (in LXX and NT), a pretender, dissembler, hypocrite: Mt 6:2, 5 6:16 7:5 15:7 22:18 23:13-15 24:51, Mk 7:6 Lk 6:42 12:56 13:15.†

to take or bear up (by supporting from beneath): c. acc pers., Ac 1:9.; to receive, welcome, entertain (Xen.): III Jn 8.; to catch up in speech (Hdt., al.; Jb, ll. c.): Lk 10:30.; Of mental action, to assume, suppose (Xen., al.; To, Wis, 3Mac, ll. c.): Ac 2:15; seq. ὅτι (v. Bl., § 70, 2), Lk 7:43.†
a window: Ac 20:8 D (for λαμπάς; v. MM, xxv).†
a remnant: Ro 9:27 (Arist., al.; cf. κατάλειμμα).†
to leave remaining (Hom., Thuc., al.): pass., of survivors, Ro 11:3.†
a vessel or trough beneath a winepress to receive the juice (RV, a pit for the winepress): Mk 12:1 (v. Swete, in l, and cf. ληνός).†
collat. form of ὑπολείπω,; to leave behind: I Pe 2:21.†

in-trans., to stay behind: seq. ἐν, Lk 2:43; ἐκεῖ, Ac 17:14.; Trans.,; c. acc, to await, wait for: Ro 8:24 (Hom., Hdt., Xen., al.); of things, to bear patiently, endure: absol., Mt 10:22 24:13, Mk 13:13, II Ti 2:12, Ja 5:11, I Pe 2:20; τ. θλίψει (dat. of circumstance), Ro 12:12; seq. εἰς, He 12:7; c. acc rei, I Co 13:7, II Ti 2:10, He 10:32 12:2-3, Ja 1:12.†

to cause one to remember, put one in mind or remind one of: c. acc rei, II Ti 2:14, III Jn 10; c. dupl. acc (Thus., al.), Jo 14:26; c. acc pers., seq. περί, II Pe 1:12; id., seq. ὅτι, Ju 5; c. inf., Tit 3:1; pass., c. gen. rei, Lk 22:61.†
a reminding, reminder: ἐν ὑ., II Pe 1:13 3:1; c. gen., II Ti 1:5.†

a remaining behind (Arist.).; patient enduring, endurance: Lk 8:15 21:19, Ro 5:3-4 15:4-5, II Co 6:4 12:12, Col 1:11, II Th 1:4, I Ti 6:11, II Ti 3:10, Tit 2:2, He 10:36, Ja 1:3-4 5:11, II Pe 1:6, Re 2:2-3, 19 13:10 14:12; δι' ὑπομονῆς, Ro 8:25, He 12:1; c. gen. pers., II Th 3:5 (ICC, in l), Re 3:10; c. gen. rei, Ro 2:7, II Co 1:6, I Th 1:3; seq. ἐν, Re 1:9.†
to suspect, conjecture: Ac 25:18; c. acc et inf., Ac 13:25 27:27.†
a suspicion: I Ti 6:4.†
to sail under, i.e. under the lee of: c. acc, Ac 27:4, 7.†
to blow underneath (Arist.).; to blow gently: Ac 27:13.†

a footstool (= cl. θρᾶνος): Ja 2:3; metaph., Mt 5:35, Mk 12:36 (ὑποκάτω, WH, R, mg.), Lk 20:43, Ac 2:35 7:49, He 1:13 10:13 (all, except Mt, l.c., from LXX, Ps 110:1, Is 66:1) (for exx., v. Deiss., BS, 223).†

a support, base or foundation (in various senses).; substance (Arist., al.; opp. to φαντασία, ἔμφασις): He 1:3; steadiness, firmness (Polyb., al.), hence, assurance, confidence: II Co 9:4 11:17, He 3:14 11:1 (here perhaps title-deed, as that which gives reality or guarantee; v. MM, xxv).†

to draw in, let down (ἱστίον, οὐράν, etc.).; to draw back, withdraw: ἑαυτόν, Ga 2:12 (Polyb., al.; v. Lft., in l). Mid., to shrink or draw back: He 10:38 (LXX); seq. τοῦ, c. inf., Ac 20:27; οὐδέν, Ac 20:20.†
a letting down, lowering (Plut.).; a shrinking back (Hesych.): οὐκ ἐσμὲν ὑποστολῆς (on the gen., v. Bl., § 35, 2), He 10:39.†
late form of ὑπο-στορέννυμι, to spread or strew under: c. acc rei, Lk 19:36.†
subjection: II Co 9:13, Ga 2:5. I Ti 2:11 3:4.†

as a military term, to place or rank under (Polyb.).; to subject, put in subjection: I Co 15:27, Phl 3:21, He 2:5, 8; pass., Ro 8:20, I Co 15:27-28, I Pe 3:22, Eph 1:22. Mid., to subject oneself, obey: absol., Ro 13:5, I Co 14:34; c. dat. pers., Lk 2:51 10:17, 20, Ro 8:7 10:3 13:1, I Co 14:32 15:28 (ὑποταγήσεται; cf. M, Pr., 163), I Co 16:16, Eph 5:21-22 (T, WH, txt., R, om.), Eph 5:24, Col 3:18, Tit 2:5, 9 3:1, He 12:9, I Pe 2:18 3:1 3:5 5:5; imperat., Ja 4:7, I Pe 2:13 5:5.†
to place under, lay down. Metaph., τ. τράχηλον ὑποθεῖναι, to risk one's life (v. Deiss., LAE, 119 f.): Ro 16:4; mid., to suggest: I Ti 4:6.†
to run in under; of navigators, to run in the lee of: c. acc (v. M, Pr., 65), Ac 27:16.†
an outline, sketch. Metaph., a pattern, example: I Ti 1:16, II Ti 1:13.†
to bear by being under. Metaph., to endure: c. acc rei, I Co 10:13, II Ti 3:11, I Pe 2:19.†
to go back, retire: seq. ἐν, Lk 5:16; seq. εἰς, Lk 9:10.†

to strike under the eye, give a black eye:; metaph.,; of persistent annoyance (RV, wear out), Lk 18:6; of severe self-discipline (R, txt. buffet, mg. bruise), I Co 9:27 (v. Field, Notes, 71, 174).†; ὑπο-πιάζω,; later form of ὑποπιέζω, to press slightly; metaph.,; to repress: I Co 9:27 T.7 for ὑπωπιάζω, q.v.†
swine: fem. (sow), II Pe 2:22,†
hyssop, of which a bunch was used in ritual sprinklings: He 9:19; of a branch or rod (?) of hyssop, Jo 19:29 (but v. Field, Notes, 106 ff., for suggestion to substitute ὑσσῷ here).†

to come late, be behind (opp. to προτερέω, φθάνω; c. gen. rei, for; c. gen. pers., later than).; Metaph.,; of persons,; absol., to come short, fail: He 4:1; seq. ἀπό, He 12:15.; c. gen. pers., to come short of, be inferior to: II Co 11:5; οὐδέν (in nothing, in no respect), II Co 12:11; with reference to things, to come short (of ), be in want (of ): c. acc rei, Mt 19:20 (Si 51:24); c. gen. rei, Lk 22:35; so mid. (Diod., FlJ), Ro 3:23; absol., to be in want, suffer want, Lk 15:14, I Co 8:8, II Co 11:8, He 11:37 (Si 11:11); opp. to περισσεύειν, Phl 4:12; seq. ἐν, I Co 1:7.; Of things,; to fail, be lacking: Jo 2:3; c. acc pers. (v. Swete, in l; Mozley, Ps 42:1-11), Mk 10:21; to be inferior: mid., I Co 12:24 (cf. ἀφ-υστερέω).†

that which is lacking, deficiency, shortcoming: c. gen. puss. (prop. pose.), I Co 16:17, Phl 2:30; c. gen. rei, Col 1:24, I Th 3:10; need, want, poverty (Ps 34:10, Jg 18:10, al.): Lk 21:4, II Co 9:12 11:9; opp. to περίσσευμα, II Co 8:13-14 (eccl.).†
need, want: opp. to τὸ περισσεῦον, Mk 12:44; καθ' ὑ., Phl 4:11 (eccl.).†

latter, later: ἐν ὑ. καιροῖς, I Ti 4:1 (on the reading ὁ ὕ., WH, for ὁ πρῶτος, v. WH, App., in l). Neut., τὸ ὕ., used adverbially instead of ὑστέρως, afterwards, later: Mt 4:2 21:29, 32 21:37 25:11 26:60, Mk 16:14, Lk 20:32, Jo 13:36, He 12:11; c. gen., Mt 22:27.†
woven: Jo 19:23.†; ὑφαίνω,; to weave: Lk 12:27, T, WH, mg.†

high, lofty: ὄρος, Mt 4:8 17:1, Mk 9:2, Re 21:10; τεῖχος, Re 21:12; μετὰ βραχίονος., fig., Ac 13:17 (cf. Ex 6:6, al); pl., ὑψηλά, of heaven (Ps 93:4, Is 33:5, al.), He 1:3; compar., ὑψηλότερος τ. οὐρανῶν, He 7:26. Metaph: Lk 16:15; ὑψηλὰ ψρσνεῖν, Ro 11:20 12:16, I Ti 6:17 (WH, txt., ὑψηλοφρονείν).†
to be high-minded: I Ti 6:17 (WH, mg., ὑψηλὰ, φρονεῖν).†

highest, most high: of place, τὰ ὕ. (of the heavens), Mt 21:9, Mk 11:10, Lk 2:14 19:38 (cf. Joshua 16:19, Is 57:15); of God (in cl., of Zeus; Pind., Æsch., al.), ὕ., Lk 1:32, 35 1:76 6:35 (as freq. in Si 4:10, al.); ὁ ὕ., Ac 7:48; ὁ θεὸς ὁ ὕ., Mk 5:7, Lk 8:28, Ac 16:17, He 7:1 (cf. Ge 14:18).†
height: Eph 3:18 Ja 1:9, Re 21:16; of heaven (EV, on high), ἐξ ὕ., Lk 1:78 24:49; εἰς ὕ., Eph 4:8 (LXX)†

to lift or raise up: c. acc, Jo 3:14 8:28 12:32, 34; ἕως τ. οὐρανοῦ, fig., pass., Mt 11:23, Lk 10:15. Metaph., to exalt, uplift: Ac 2:33 5:31, II Co 11:7, Ja 4:10, I Pe 5:6; opp. to ταπεινῶ, Lk 1:52; ἑαυτόν, Mt 23:12, Lk 4:11 18:14 (cf. ὑπερ-υψόω).†
height: Ro 8:39; that which is lifted up, a barrier: II Co 10:5.†
a glutton: Mt 11:19, Lk 7:34.†

Act.,; to bring to light, cause to appear (so most freq. in cl.).; Absol., to give light, shine (Hom., Plat., al.): Jo 1:5 5:35, II Pe 1:19, I Jn 2:8, Re 1:16 8:12 18:23 21:23.; Pass., to come to light, appear, be manifest: Mt 2:7 13:26 24:27, 30, Lk 9:8, Phl 2:15, He 11:3, I Pe 4:18 (LXX); opp. to ἀφανίζεσθαι, Jo 4:14; c. dat. pers. (Bl. § 54, 4), Mt 1:20 2:13, 19 Mk 16:9; c. nom. pred., Mt 23:27-28, Ro 7:13, II Co 13:7; id. c. dat. pers., Mt 6:5, 16 6:18 (seq. nom. ptcp., but not as in cl.; v. Bl., § 73, 4); impers., Mt 9:33; of the mind and judgment (= δοκεῖ, q.v.), Mk 14:64 (cf. I Es 2:21), Lk 24:11.†
Peleg: Lk 3:35.†

open to sight, visible, manifest: Ga 5:19; seq. ἐν, Ro 1:19, I Jn 3:10; c. dat. pers., Ac 4:16 7:13, I Ti 4:15; φ. γίνεσθαι (in LXX for בָּחַן ni., Ge 42:16), Mk 6:14, Lk 8:17, I Co 3:13 14:25; id. seq. ἐν, I Co 11:19, Phl 1:13; φ. ποιεῖν, Mt 12:16, Mk 3:12; εἰς φ. ἐλθεῖν (cf. Bl., § 47, 2), Mk 4:22, Lk 8:17; ἐν τῷ φ. (opp. to ἐν τ. κρυπτῷ), Ro 2:28.†

to make visible, clear, manifest or known: c. acc rei, Jo 2:11 17:6, Ro 1:19, I Co 4:5, II Co 2:14 11:6, Col 4:4, Tit 1:3; pass., Mk 4:22, Jo 3:21 9:3, Ro 3:21 16:26, II Co 4:10-11, Eph 5:13, Col 1:26, II Ti 1:10, He 9:8, I Jn 3:2 Jn 4:9, Re 3:18 15:4; c. acc pers., of Christ, Jo 7:4 21:1; pass., II Co 3:3 5:10-11, I Jn 2:19; of Christ, Mk 16:12, 14, Jo 1:31 21:14, Col 3:4, I Ti 3:16, He 9:26, I Pe 1:20 5:4, I Jn 1:2 (ἡ ζωή; v. Westc., in l) I Jn 2:28 Jn 3:2 Jn 3:5 Jn 3:8.†
manifestly, openly: Mk 1:45; opp. to ἐν κρυπτῷ„ Jo 7:10; clearly: Ac 10:3 (II Mac 3:28).†
manifestation: I Co 12:7, II Co 4:2.†
a torch or lantern (v. Rutherford, NPhr., 131 f.): Jo 18:3.†
Phanuel: Lk 2:36.†
to make visible. In cl. used in pass. only, = φαίνομαι, to become visible, appear: ptcp., He 12:21.†
as philos. term,; imagination; = φάντασμα (Plat., Arist.).; In later writers (Polyb., al.), show, display: Ac 25:23.†
= φάσμα, an appearance, apparition (Æsch., al.): Mt 14:26, Mk 6:49 (v. DCG, i, 111b).†
a chasm, ravine: Lk 3:5 (LXX) (v. DB, iv, 845 f.).†
Pharaoh, the general title of the kings of Egypt: Ac 7:13, 21, Ro 9:17, He 11:24; Φ. βασιλεὺς Αἰγύπτου, Ac 7:10.†
Peres: Mt 1:3, Lk 3:33.†

a Pharisee: Mt 23:26, Phl 3:5; usually in pl., Mt 9:11, Mk 2:18, al.; Φ. κ. γραμματεῖς, Mt 5:20, Mk 2:16, Lk 5:21, al.; Φ. κ. Σαδδυκαῖοι, Mt 16:1, Ac 23:6, 7 al.; ἀρχιερεῖς, Mt 21:45, Jo 7:32, al. (v. DB, iii, 826b).
a sorcerer: Re 21:8, Rec.†

poët. and late prose form of φαρμακεία,; generally, the use of medicine, drugs or spells (Xen.).; (a) poisoning (Plut., Polyb.); sorcery, witchcraft: Ga 5:20 (v. Lft., in l), Re 9:21 (WH, txt., φαρμάκων) Re 18:23 (cf. LXX, ll. c.).†
a drug; an in­cantation, enchantment: Re 9:21, Tr., mg., WH, txt. (RV, sorceries).†
devoted to magical arts. As subst., ὁ φ. = φαρμακεύς, a magician, sorcerer: Re 21:8 22:15.†
information, esp. against fraud or other crime: Ac 21:31.†
to affirm, assert: c. acc et inf., Ac 24:9 25:19; c. inf. et nom., Ro 1:22.†
a manger: Lk 2:7, 12 2:16 13:15 (v. DB, iii, 234a, DCG, ii, 111a),†

slight, worthless, of no account, both of persons and things in various shades of meaning (v. LS, s.v.), in NT, as freq. in cl., always with distinct moral reference (v. Ellic., Past. Epp., 203; Hort, Ja., 85; Tr., Syn., LXXxiv), worthless, bad: Jo 3:20, Tit 2:8, Ja 3:16; opp. to ἀγαθός (q.v.), Jo 5:29, Ro 9:11, II Co 5:10.†
light, brightness, usually c. gen. of something that shines or reflects: of the moon, Mt 24:29, Mk 13:24; of a lamp, Lk 11:33 (WH, RV, φῶς).†
to spare: II Co 13:2; c. gen. pers., Ac 20:29, Ro 8:32 11:21, I Co 7:28, II Co 1:23, II Pe 2:4-5; c. inf., to forbear, II Co 12:6.†
adv. from ptcp. (v. 131., § 25, 1),; sparingly: II Co 9:6 (Plut.).†

by metath. for παινόλης (also φενόλης, φαινόλιον; Lat. pænula); a cloak (v. DCG, i, 338; on the idea that the meaning here is book-cover, v. CGT, in l; Milligan, NTD, 20; Field, Notes, 217 f., where the view that the φ. here is an eccl. vestment is discussed): II Ti 4:13.†

to bear; to bear, carry: c. acc, Lk 23:26 24:1, Jo 19:39, He 1:3 (v. Westc., in l); pass., Ac 2:2 27:15, 17 He 6:1, II Pe 1:17-18; of the mind, II Pe 1:21.; to bear, endure: c. acc rei, He 12:20 13:13; c. acc pers., Ro 9:22.; to bring, bring forward: c. acc pers., Ac 5:16; id. seq. πρός, Mk 1:32 2:3 9:17, 19-20; ἐπί, Lk 5:18; c. dat., Mk 7:32 8:22; c. acc rei, Mk 6:27 11:2 12:15, Lk 15:23, Ac 4:34, 37 5:2, II Ti 4:13; id. seq. πρός, Mk 11:7; εἰς, Re 21:24, 26; ἐπί, Mt 14:11, Mk 6:28; ἀπό, Jo 21:10; c. dat., Mk 12:15, Jo 2:8; id. seq. ὧδε, Mt 14:18 17:17; seq. φαγεῖν (sc. τι), Jo 4:33; τ. δάκτυλον (χεῖρα), Jo 20:27; pass., ἡ χάρις, I Pe 1:13; διδαχήν, II Jn 10; θάνατον (cf. Field, Notes, 230), He 9:16; κρίσιν, II Pe 2:11; κατηγορίαν, Jo 18:29; αἰτίαν, Ac 25:18; αἰτιώματα, Ac 25:7, Rec.; to bear, produce, bring forth: καρπόν, Mt 7:18, Mk 4:8, Jo 12:24 15:2, 4-5 15:8, 16.; to bring, lead: Mk 15:22, Jo 21:18, Ac 14:13; metaph., of a gate (ὁδός, cl.), Seq. εἰς, Ac 12:10; SYN: φορέω, which expresses habitual and continuous bearing as distinct from (φέρω) that which is accidental and temporary (cf. Mt 11:8, al., s.v. φορέω, and v. Tr., Syn., § lviii)

to flee from or away, take flight: absol., Mt 8:33 26:56, Mk 5:14 14:50, Lk 8:34, Jo 10:12, Ac 7:29; seq. εἰς, Mt 2:13 10:23 24:16 (WH, txt.), Mk 13:14, Lk 21:21, Re 12:6; ἐπί, c. acc loc., Mt 24:16 (WH, mg.); ἐκ, Ac 27:30; ἀπό, c. gen. loc. (cl.), Mk 16:8; id. c. gen. pers. (as in Heb.), Jo 10:5, Ja 4:7. Metaph.: absol., Re 16:20; c. acc rei, I Co 6:18, He 11:34 (v. M, Fr., 116); opp. to διώκειν, I Ti 6:11, II Ti 2:22; seq. άπό, c. gen. pers., Re 9:6; άπὸ τ. προσώπου, Re 20:11; c. gen. rei, Mt 3:7 (M, Pr., l.c.) Mt 23:33, Lk 3:7, I Co 10:14 (cf. ἀπο-, δια-, ἐκ-, κατα-φεύγω).†
Felix, procurator of Judæa: Ac 23:24, 26 24:3, 22 24:24-25, 27 25:14.†
a saying or report: Mt 9:26, Lk 4:14.†

to declare, say: freq. in quoting the words of another, Mt 13:29 26:61, Lk 7:40 22:58, Jo 1:23, al.; interjected into the recorded words (cl.), Mt 14:8, Ac 23:35, al.; φησί, impersonal (Bl., § 30, 4), I Co 6:16 (Lft., Notes, 217; but cf. Bl., l.c.), II Co 10:10 (WH, mg., φασίν), He 8:5; joined with syn. verb (cf. LS, s.v., II, 2), ἀποκριθεὶς αὐτῷ ἔφη, Lk 23:3; seq. -πρός, Lk 22:70, al.; c. acc rei, I Co 10:15 10:19; acc et inf., Ro 3:8; seq. ὅτι (Bl., § 70, 3), I Co 10:19 15:50 (cf. σύν-φημι)
to spread a report: Mt 28:15, T, WH, mg. (v. δια-φ.).†
(Porcius), Festus, procurator of Judæa: Ac 24:27 25:1 ff. Ac 26:24-25, 32.†

to come before another, anticipate (cl.): c. acc pers., I Th 4:15.; In late writers and MGr. (v. Kennedy, Sources, 156; Lft., Notes, 35), to come, arrive: Ro 9:31; seq. εἰς, Phl 3:16; ἄχρι, II Co 10:14; ἐπί (cf. Da TH Da 4:21, and v. Dalman, Words, 107), Mt 12:28, Lk 11:20, I Th 2:16 (cf. προ-φθάνω).†
perishable, corruptible: ἄνθρωπος, Ro 1:23 (opp. to ἄφθαρτος θεός); στέφανος, I Co 9:25 (opp. to αρτος); σπσρά, I Pe 1:23 (opp. to ἄφθ.); neut., τὸ φ. τοῦτο, I Co 15:53-54; pl., I Pe 1:18.†
of men or animals, to utter a sound or voice: absol., Ac 4:18; seq. ἐν φωνῇ, II Pe 2:16; c. acc, ὑπέρογκα, II Pe 2:18.†

to destroy, corrupt, spoil (on the varied usage and distinctive meaning of the word, v. Mayor on 2Pe, App., 175 ff.): c. acc, I Co 3:17 15:23, II Co 7:2; seq. ἀπό, II Co 11:3; ἐν, II Pe 2:12, Ju 10, Re 19:2; κατά, Eph 4:22 (cf. δια-, κατα-φθείρω).†
autumnal: δένδρα φ., autumn trees (said to be without fruit therefore at a time when fruit might be expected; v. Mayor's elaborate note, Ep. Ju., 55-59, and reff. there): Ju 12.†
a sound: Ro 10:18 (LXX) I Co 14:7.†
to envy: c. dat. (L, txt., Tr., mg., WH, mg., acc), as in cl., Ga 5:26.†
envy: Ro 1:29, Ga 5:21, I Ti 6:4, Tit 3:3, I Pe 2:1; διὰ φθόνον, Mt 27:18, Mk 15:10, Phl 1:15; πρὸς φθόνον ἐπιποθεῖ τ. πνεῦμα (on the meaning, v. R, txt., mg. 1, 2; Hort, Ja., 93 f.), Ja 4:5.†

destruction, corruption, decay (v. Mayor on 2Pe, App.,175 ff.): Ro 8:21, I Co 15:42, Col 2:22, II Pe 2:12; opp. to ζωὴ αἰώνιος, Ga 6:8; by meton., of that which is subject to corruption, I Co 15:50; of moral decay, II Pe 1:4 2:12 2:19 (cf. Wi 14:12).†
a shallow bowl (= Lat. patera), used for pouring libations, etc.: Re 5:8 15:7 16:1-17 17:1 21:9.†
loving that which is good, loving goodness: Tit 1:8 (Arist., Polyb., a l.).†
Philadelphia, a city of Lydia: Re 1:11 3:7.†
the love of brothers, brotherly love: of Christians' mutual love as brethren (v.s. ἀδελφός), Ro 12:10, I Th 4:9, He 13:1, I Pe 1:22, II Pe 1:7.†
loving one's brother, loving like a brother (Soph., Xen., al.): of Christians' love for one another (EV, loving as brethren), I Pe 3:8.†
loving men (Æsch.).; Of a wife, loving her husband (freq. in epitaphs, v. LS, s.v., Deiss., BS, 255): Tit 2:4.†
humanity, kindness (v. Field, Notes, 147 f.): Ac 28:2, Tit 3:4 (cf. also DCG, ii, 356 ff.).†
humanely, kindly: Ac 27:3.†
love of money, avarice: I Ti 6:1.†
loving money, avaricious: Lk 16:14, II Ti 3:2.†
loving oneself (Arist.); in bad sense (ib.), selfish: II Ti 3:2.†

to love (with the love of emotion and friendship, Lat, amare; v, SYN.): c. acc pers., Mt 10:37, Jo 5:20; Jo 11:3, 36 15:19 16:27 20:2 21:15-17, I Co 16:22, Re 3:19; ἐν πίστει, Tit 3:15; c. acc rei, Mt 23:6, Lk 20:46, Jo 12:25, Re 22:15; c. inf. (Is 56:10; cf. Bl., § 69, 4), Mt 6:5.; to kiss: c. acc pers., Mt 26:48, Mk 14:44, Lk 22:47 (cf. κατα-φιλέω).†
loving pleasure: II Ti 3:4 (Polyb., Plut. al.).†
a kiss: Lk 7:45 22:48; as a token of Christian brotherhood, φ. ἅγιον, Ro 16:16, I Co 16:20, II Co 13:12, I Th 5:26; φ. ἀγάπης, I Pe 5:14 (v. Lft., Notes, 90; DB, DCA, s.v. "Kiss").†
Philemon: Phm 1.†
Philetus: II Ti 2:17.†
friendship: c. gen. obj., Ja 4:4.†
a Philippian: Phl 4:15.†
Philippi: Ac 16:12 20:6, Phl 1:1, I Th 2:2.†

Philip; the husband of Herodias: Mt 14:3, Mk 6:17.; The tetrarch: Mt 16:13, Mk 8:27, Lk 3:1.; The apostle: Mt 10:3, Mk 3:18, Lk 6:14, Jo 1:44-49 6:5, 7 12:21-22 14:8-9, Ac 1:13.; The deacon and evangelist: Ac 6:5 8:5-40 21:8.†
loving God (Arist.): II Ti 3:4.†
Philologus: Ro 16:15.†
love of strife, rivalry, emulation (Plat., al.), but mostly in bad sense (Thuc., al.), contentiousness, contention: Lk 22:24 (but v. Field, Notes, 75 f.).†
fond of strife, contentious: I Co 11:16.†
love of strangers, hospitality: Ro 12:13, He 13:2.†
loving strangers, hospitable: I Ti 3:2, Tit 1:8, I Pe 4:9.†
to strive to be first: III Jn 9 (eccl.).†

pass., beloved, dear (Hom., Eur., al.).; Act., loving, friendly (in cl. less freq. and only in poets): Ac 19:31. As subst., a friend; masc., ὁ φ.: Lk 7:6 11:5 14:10 15:6 16:9 21:16 23:12, Ac 27:3, III Jn 14; opp. to δοῦλος, Jo 15:15; φ. ἀναγκαῖοι, Ac 10:24; c. gen. subj., Mt 11:19, Lk 7:34 11:6, 8 12:4 14:12 15:29, Jo 11:11 15:13-14; ὁ φ. τοῦ νυμφίου, Jo 3:29; τ. Καίσαρος (v. Deiss., BS 167; LAE, 382 f.), Jo 19:12; θεοῦ (v. Hort, in l), Ja 2:23; c. gen. rei, τ, κόσμου, Ja 4:4; fem., ἡ φ., Lk 15:9,†
the love and pursuit of wisdom; hence, philosophy, investi­gation of truth and nature: of the so-called philosophy of false teachers, Col 2:8 (v. Lft., ICC, in l).†
a philosopher: Ac 17:18.†
tenderly loving, affectionate (Xen., Plut., al.): of Christians, Ro 12:10.†
loving one's children (Hdt., Arist., Plut., al.): of women, joined with φίλανδρος, q.v., Tit 2:4.†
to love or seek after honour, hence, to be ambitious, emulous (Plat., Plut., al.): c. inf., Ro 15:20, II Co 5:9, I Th 4:11.†
kindly, with friendliness: Ac 28:7.†
friendly, kind. I Pe 3:8, Rec.†
to muzzle: I Co 9:9, I Ti 5:18 (LXX); metaph., to put to silence: c. acc pers., Mt 22:34, I Pe 2:15; pass., to be silenced, silent: Mt 22:12, Mk 1:25 4:39, Lk 4:35.†
Phlegon: Ro 16:14.†
to set on fire, burn, burn up: fig., Ja 3:6 (on the meaning of the sentence, v. Hort, in l).†
a flame: Lk 16:24; φ, πυρός, Ac 7:30, II Th 1:8, He 1:7 (LXX), Re 1:14 2:18 19:12.†
to talk nonsense: c. acc pers., ἡμᾶς (EV, prating against us), III Jn 10.†
babbling, garrulous: I Ti 5:13 (EV, tattlers; of things, φιλοσοφία, 4Mac, l.c.).†
fearful, whether act, or pass.; act., = δεινός, causing fear, terrible (LXX): He 10:27, 31 12:21; Pass., = δειλός, feeling fear, timid (cl. in both senses).†

in Hem., to put to flight. Pass., to be put to flight, to flee affrighted; to terrify, frighten (Wis 179; Hdt. and Att..). Pass. (so always in NT; cf. M, Pr., 162), to be seized with fear, be affrighted, fear: Mt 10:31 14:27, Mk 5:33 6:50, Lk 1:13 8:50, Jo 6:19 12:15, Ac 16:38, al.; opp. to ὑψηλοφρονεῖν, Ro 11:20; σφόδρα, Mt 17:6 27:54; c. cogn. acc, φόβον μέγαν, Mk 4:41, Lk 2:9 (I Mac 10:8); φόβον αὐτῶν (obj, gen., but cf. ICC, in l), I Pe 3:14; πτόησιν, I Pe 3:6; c. acc pers., Mt 10:26, Mk 11:18, Lk 19:21, Jo 9:22, Ac 9:26,; Ro 13:3, al.; seq. ἀπό (like Heb. יָרֵא, Je 1:8, al.; cf. M, Pr., 102, 104n„), Mt 10:28, Lk 12:4; seq. μή (cl.; Bl., § 65, 3; M, Pr., 184 f.), Ac 23:10 27:17; μήπως, Ac 27:29, II Co 11:3 12:20, Ga 4:11; μήποτε, He 4:1; c. inf. (Bl., § 69, 4; M, Pr., 205), Mt 1:20, Mk 9:32, al.; of reverential fear: Mk 6:20, Eph 5:33; τ. θεόν, Lk 1:50, Ac 10:2, I Pe 2:17, Re 14:7, al.; τ. κύριον, Col 3:22, Re 15:4; τ. ὄνομα τ. θεοῦ (v.s. ὄνομα), Re 11:18; οἱ φοβούμενοι τ. θεόν, of proselytes, Ac 13:16, 26 (cf. ἐκ-φοβέω)
that which causes fright, a terror: pl. (as always, exc.Isa, l.c.), Lk 21:11 (Hipp., Plat.).†

in Hom., flight.; That which causes flight, fear, dread, terror: Lk 1:12, Ac 5:5, I Ti 5:20. I Jn 4:18, al.; cogn. acc, φοβεῖσθαι φ., Mk 4:41, Lk 2:9; c. gen. obj., Jo 7:13 19:33 20:19, He 2:5, I Pe 3:14 (but cf. ICC, in l);ἀπὸ (τοῦ) φ., Mt 14:26, Lk 21:26; εἰς φ., Ro 8:15; μετὰ φόβου, Mt 28:8; φ. καὶ τρόμος (Lft., Notes, 172), I Co 2:3, II Co 7:15, Eph 6:5, Phl 2:12; by meton., of that which causes fear, Ro 13:3; of reverential fear, Ro 13:7, I Pe 1:17 2:18 3:2 3:15; τ. κυρίου, Ac 9:31, II Co 5:11 (v. Field, Notes, 183); Χριστοῦ, Eph 5:21; θεοῦ, Ro 3:18, II Co 7:1
Phæbe, a deaconess of Cenchræa: Ro 16:1.†
the date palm, palm: τὰ βαΐα τῶν φ., Jo 12:13; of palm branches, φοίνικες (as Arist., II Mac 10:7, al.), Re 7:9.†
a Phænician (also with fem., Φοίνισσα, Hom., al.); Phænix, a city of Crete: Ac 27:12.†
a murderer: Mt 22:7 Ac 7:52 28:4, I Pe 4:15, Re 21:8 22:15; ἀνὴρ φ., Ac 3:14.†
to kill, murder. absol., Mt 5:21, Ja 4:2; μὴ (οὐ) φονεύσῃς (-εις), Mt 5:21 19:18, Mk 10:19, Lk 18:20, Ro 13:9, Ja 2:11 (all from Ex 20:13-14); c. acc, Mt 23:31, 35, Ja 5:6.†
murder, slaughter: Mk 15:7, Lk 23:19, 25, Ac 9:1, Ro 1:29; φ. μαχαίρης (cf. Ex 17:13, al.), He 11:37; pl., Mt 15:19, Mk 7:21, Re 9:21.†

frequent. of φέρω, denoting repeated or habitual action (cf. Tr., Syn., § lviii), most commonly used of clothing, weapons, etc., to bear constantly, wear: Mt 11:8, Jo 19:5, Ro 13:4, I Co 15:49, Ja 2:3.†
(Lat. forum): Ἀππίου Φ., v.s. Ἄππιος
tribute paid by a subject nation (cf. I Mac 10:33): φ. δοῦναι (I Mac 8:4 Mac 8:7), Lk 20:22 23:2; ἀποδοῦναι, Ro 13:7; τελεῖν, Ro 13:6 (Hdt., al.).†
to load: c. dupl. acc, Lk 11:46; pass., to be laden: metaph. (EV, heavy laden), Mt 11:28.†
a burden, load: of the cargo of a ship (Hdt., al.), Ac 27:10; metaph., Mt 11:30 23:4, Lk 11:46, Ga 6:5.†
a load: esp. of a ship's cargo (Hom., Hdt., and late prose writers), Ac 27:10, Rec.†
(Lat.) Fortunatus: I Co 16:17 (v. Lft., Cl. Ro., 1Co., 59).†
(Lat. flagellum), a scourge: Jo 2:15.†
to scourge: c. acc, Mt 27:26, Mk 15:15 (eccl.).†
prop., a fencing in (Soph., OT, 1387).; = φράγμα, a fence: Mt 21:33, Mk 12:1, Lk 14:23. Metaph., μεσότοιχον (q.v.) τοῦ φ., gen. epexeg., Eph 2:14 (v. Ellic., in l).†
to show forth, tell, declare, explain: Mt 13:36 (WH, RV, διασάφησον) Mt 15:15.†
to fence in, stop, close: στόματα λεόντων, He 11:33; στόμα, metaph., Ro 3:19; pass., καύχησις, II Co 11:10.†
a well: Lk 14:5, Ca 4:11-12; φ. τῆς ἀβύσσου, Re 9:1-2.†
to deceive one's mind (Lft., deceive by fancies, v. Ga., l.c.): c. acc pers., Ga 6:3.†
a deceiver (B1., deceiver of his own mind, § 28, 5.2, where v. ref. to π.): Tit 1:10 (eccl.).†

chiefly in Hom. and Trag., but also in Plat., al., both sing. and pl.; in physical sense, the parts about the heart, midriff.; heart, mind, thought: pl., I Co 14:20 (v. Edwards, Eng.-Gr. Lex., App., 1).†
to be rough, bristle.; to shiver, shudder, tremble, from fear: Ja 2:19 (v. Hort, in l).†

to have understanding (Hon., al.).; to think, to be minded in a certain way: ὡς νήπιος, I Co 13:11; c. acc (usually neut., adj., or pron., as freq. in cl.), ὃ δεῖ, Ro 12:3; ἃ, Ac 28:22; τοῦτο, Phl 3:15; τι ἑτέρως, ib.; οὐδὲν ἄλλο, Ga 5:10; τ. αὐτὸ φ. (Deiss., BS, 256), to be of the same mind, II Co 13:11, Phl 2:2 4:2; id. seq. εἰς (ἐν) ἀλλήλους(οις), Ro 12:16 15:5; τ. ἓν φ., Phl 2:2 (Lft., in l); seq. ὑπέρ, Phl 1:7.; to have in mind, be mindful of, think of (Hdt., Xen., al.; Es, 1Mac, ll. c.): τὰ τ. θεοῦ, opp. to τ. τ. ἀνθρώπων, Mt 16:23, Mk 8:33; τὰ τ. σαρκός, opp. to τ. τ. πνεύρατος, Ro 8:5; τ. ἐπίγεια, Phl 3:19; τὰ ἄνω, opp. to τ. ἐπὶ τ. γῆς, Col 3:2; τοῦτο φρονεῖτε (RV, have this mind in you), Phl 2:5; ὑψηλά, Ro 12:16; φ. ἡμέραν (to observe a day), Ro 14:6; seq. ὑπέρ, Phl 4:10 (cf. κατα-, παρα-, περι-, ὑπερ-φρσνέω).†
that which is in the mind (the content of φρονεῖν, ICC, Ro., 88), the thought: Ro 8:6-7, 27.†
understanding, practical wisdom, prudence: Lk 1:17, Eph 1:8.†

practically wise, sensible, prudent: Mt 10:16 24:45, Lk 12:42, I Co 10:15; opp. to μωρός, Mt 7:24 25:2, 4 25:8-9, I Co 4:10; to ἄφρων, II Co 11:19; φ. παρ' ἑαυτῷ (EV, wise in one's own conceit), Ro 11:25 12:16 (cf. Pr 3:7); compar., -ώτερος, Lk 16:8.†
sensibly, prudently: Lk 16:8.†
to give heed, take thought (in cl. usually absol., c acc, c. gen.), c. inf., Tit 3:8 (v. Bl., § 69, 4; M, Pr., 206 f.).†
to guard, keep under guard, protect or keep by guarding: II Co 11:32; metaph., Ga 3:23, Phl 4:7, I Pe 1:5.†
prop., of horses, to neigh, whinny and prance (Plut., al.). Metaph., to be wanton, insolent: Ac 4:25 (LXX).†
a dry stick: pl., brushwood: Ac 28:3.†
Phrygia, a region of Asia Minor: Ac 2:10; Φ. καὶ Γαλατικὴ χώρα (Γ. χ. κ. Φ.), Ac 16:6 18:23 (on these phrases v. DB, i, 89 f.; CGT, Gal., xxii f.).†
Phygelus: II Ti 1:15.†
flight: Mt 24:20.†

actively, a guarding, guard, watch (Hom., Plat., Xen., al.): cogn. acc, φυλάσσειν φυλακάς, to keep watch, Lk 2:8; of those who keep watch (as also Lat. custodia), a guard; pl., sentinels, a guard (Hom., al.): Ac 12:10; of the place where persons are kept under guard, a prison (Hdt., Thuc., al.): Mt 14:10, Mk 6:17, Lk 3:20, Ac 5:19, II Co 6:5, I Pe 3:19, Re 18:2, al.; of the time during which guard was kept by night (Lest. vigilia; Anthol.), a watch: Mt 14:25 24:43, Mk 6:48, Lk 12:38
to imprison: Ac 22:19.†

an outpost, fortification (Thuc., al.).; a safeguard (Plat.).; an amulet (Plut., al.); in NT for the Talmudic תְּפִלִּין, a prayer fillet, a phylactery, a small strip of parchment on which portions of the law were written and worn on the forehead and next the heart (cf. Ex 13:16): Mt 23:5.†
a guard, keeper: Ac 5:23 12:6, 19.†

to guard, watch; to guard or watch: c. cogn. acc, φυλακάς, Lk 2:8; c. acc pers., Ac 12:4 28:16; pass., Lk 8:29, Ac 23:35; c. acc rei, Ac 22:20; to guard or protect: c. acc, Lk 11:21, Jo 12:25 17:12, II Th 3:3, I Ti 6:20, II Ti 1:12 1:14, II Pe 2:5; ἑαυτὸν ἀπό, I Jn 5:21 (Westc., in l); metaph. of law, precept, etc., to keep, preserve, observe: Mt 19:20, Lk 11:28 18:21, Jo 12:47, Ac 7:53 16:4 21:24, Ro 2:26, Ga 6:13, I Ti 5:21. Mid., to be on one's guard (against), keep oneself from, beware of: c. acc, Ac 21:25, II Ti 4:15; seq. ἀπό., Lk 12:15; ἵνα μή, II Pe 3:17; as in LXX (Ex 12:17, Le 18:4, al.), of laws, etc., to keep, observe: ταῦτα πάντα, Mk 10:20 (cf. δια-φυάσσω).†

a body of men united by kinship or habitation, a clan or tribe: of the tribes of Israel, Mt 19:28, Lk 2:36 22:30, Ac 13:21, Ro 11:1, Phl 3:5, He 7:13-14, Ja 1:1, Re 5:5 7:4-8 21:12; of the tribes of the earth, the peoples and nations, Mt 24:30, Re 1:7 5:9 7:9 11:9 13:7 14:6.†
that which is mixed or kneaded, a lump: of dough, Ro 11:16, I Co 5:6-7, Ga 5:9; of clay, Ro 9:21.†

natural; produced by nature, innate (Xen., Arist., al.); according to nature (Arist., Diod., al.): opp. to παρὰ φύσιν, Ro 1:26-27; governed by mere natural instinct (of. Plut., Mor., 706 A): ζῷα γεγεννημένα φ. (RV, born mere animals; Mayor, born creatures of instinct; ICC, animals born of mere nature), II Pe 2:12,†
naturally, by nature: Ju 10.†

to puff or blow up, inflate. Metaph., to puff up, make proud: I Co 8:1. Pass., to be puffed up with pride: I Co 4:18-19 5:2 13:4; seq. ὑπό, Col 2:18; seq. ὑπὲρ . . . κατά, I Co 4:6 (on the form of the subjc., v. M, Pr., 54; Bl., § 22, 3).†

nature, i.e.,; the nature (natural powers or constitution) of a person or thing: Ja 3:7, II Pe 1:4; τέκνα φυσει ὀργῆς, Eph 2:3; origin, birth (Soph., Xen., al.): Ro 2:27, Ga 2:15; nature, i.e. the regular order or law of nature: I Co 11:14; dat., φύσει adverbially, by nature, Ro 2:14, Ga 4:8; παρὰ φύσιν, against nature, Ro 1:26 11:24; καρὰ φ., according to nature, naturally, Ro 11:21, 24.†
a puffing up, swelling with pride: pl., II Co 12:20.†
a planting (Xen., al.; LXX).; = φύτευμα, that which is planted, a plant (Inscr.): Mt 15:13.†
to plant: Lk 17:28, I Co 3:6-8; c. acc, φυτείαν, Mt 15:13; ἀμπελῶνα, Mt 21:33, Mk 12:1, Lk 20:9, I Co 9:7; pass., seq. ἐν, Lk 13:6 17:6.†
trans., to bring forth, produce (of men, to beget); pass., to spring up, grow: Lk 8:6, 8.; Intrans., in 2 aor., pf., plpf., and rarely in pres. (v. LS, s.v., A, II.), to spring up: He 12:15.†
a hole, den, lair: Mt 8:20, Lk 9:58.†

Intrans.; Of persons, to call out, cry out, speak aloud: Lk 8:8; φωνῇ μεγάλῃ, Mk 1:26, Ac 16:28; ἐφώνησε (φωνῇ μεγάλῇ) λέγων, Lk 8:54, Re 14:18; φωνήσαντες ἐπύθοντο, Ac 10:18.; Of the cries of animals (rarely in cl.; Is 38:14, Je, l.c.): of a cock, to crow, Mt 26:34, Mk 14:30, Lk 22:3, Jo 13:38 18:27.; Trans. (in cl. chiefly poët.), c. acc pers., to call, summon, invite: Mt 20:32 27:47, Mk 9:35 10:49 15:35, Lk 14:12 16:2 19:15, Jo 1:49 2:9 4:16 10:3 11:28 12:17 18:33, Ac 9:41 10:7; to address, call by name (Soph.), Jo 13:13 (cf. ἀνα-, ἐπι-, προσ-, συν-φωνέω).†

a voice; prop., of persons, Mt 2:18 (LXX), al.; φ. αἴρειν (ἐπαίρειν), Lk 17:13, Ac 2:14, al.; φ. μεγάλῃ εἰπεῖν (λέγειν, φωνεῖν, etc.), Lk 8:28, Ac 7:57, Re 5:12, al.; γίνεται (ἔρχεται) φ. ἐκ τ. οὐρανῶν (ἐξ οὐρανοῦ), Mk 1:11, Lk 3:22, Jo 12:28, al. (cf. DCG, ii, 810a; Dalman, Words, 204f.); ἀκούειν φωνήν (-ῆς; v.s. ἀκούω), Ac 9:4, 7 al.; φ. βοῶντος, Mt 3:3, Mk 1:3, Lk 3:4, Jo 1:23 (LXX); τ. θεοῦ, Jo 5:37, He 3:7, al. By meton., of the speaker, βλέπειν τὴν φ., Re 1:12; speech, language ( Ge 11:1, IV Mac 12:7, al.): I Co 14:10; of inanimate things: Mt 24:31, Jo 3:8, Ac 2:6, Re 1:15b 9:9 14:2, al. (cf. Tr., Syn., §lxxxix).

light (opp. to τὸ σκότος, ἡ σκοτία): Mt 17:2, 5, Jo 11:9-10, II Co 4:6; ἡλίου, Re 22:5; of a lamp, Lk 8:16 11:33, Jo 5:35, Re 18:23; of a supernatural heavenly light, Ac 9:3 12:7 22:6, 9 22:11 26:13; hence, ἄγγελος φωτός, II Co 11:14; ὁ κλήρος τ. ἁγίων ἐν τ. φ., Col 1:12; of the divine glory, Re 21:24; by meton., of that which gives light: of fire, Mk 14:54, Lk 22:56 (cl.; I Mac 12:29; cf. DCG, i, 595; pl., of a lamp or torch, Ac 16:29; of heavenly bodies, Ja 1:17.; Metaph.,; of God: I Jn 1:5 Jn 1:7; φῶς οἰκῶν ἀπρόσιτον, I Ti 6:16; of spiritual truth and its effects on the lives of men: Mt 4:16 5:16, Jo 1:4-5 3:19-21, Ac 26:18, 23, II Co 6:14, Eph 5:13, I Pe 2:9, I Jn 2:8; τ. φ. τ. ζωῆς, Jo 8:12; τ. ὅπλα τοῦ φ., Ro 13:12; καρπὸς τοῦ φ., Eph 5:9; έν τ. φ. περιπατεῖν (εἶναι, μένειν), I Jn 1:7 Jn 2:9-10; υἱοὶ (τέκνα) τοῦ φ., Lk 16:8, Jo 12:36, Eph 5:8, I Th 5:5; by meton., of one from whom truth shines forth: Ac 13:47 (LXX), Ro 2:19; esp. of Christ, Lk 2:32, Jo 1:7-8 12:35-36, 46; τ. φ. τ. κόσμου, Jo 8:12 9:5;τ. φ. τ. ἀληθινόν, Jo 1:9; of Christians, Mt 5:14, Eph 5:8; of the spiritual under­standing: τ. φ. τὸ ἐν σοί, Mt 6:23, Lk 11:35; adverbially, of that which is open to view (opp. to ἐν τ. σκοτίᾳ): ἐν τ. φ., Mt 10:27, Lk 12:3.†
a luminary, light: Phl 2:15, Re 21:11.†
light-bringing; as subst., ὁ φ., the morning star (Plat., al.; cf. ἐωσφόρος, Is 14:12, Jb 3:9, Ps 110:3): metaph., II Pe 1:19 (v. Mayor, in l).†
bright, light: νεφέλη, Mt 17:5; opp. to σκοτεινός, Mt 6:22, Lk 11:34, 36.†

intrans., to shine, give light (Arist., Plut., a1.): seq. ἐπί, Re 22:5.; Trans.; to illumine, enlighten (Diod., Plut., al.): c. acc, Lk 11:36, Re 21:23; pass., Re 18:1. Metaph., of spiritual enlightenment (Ps 119:130, Si 45:17, al.): Jo 1:9, Eph 1:18 3:9, R, txt., He 6:4 10:32; to bring to light, make known (Polyb.): I Co 4:5, Eph 3:9, R, mg., II Ti 1:10 (cf. Kennedy, Sources, 107 f.).†
illumination, light: metaph., I Co 4:4 4:6.†

to rejoice, be glad: Mk 14:11, Lk 15:5, 32 19:6, 37 22:5 23:8, Jo 8:56 20:20, Ac 5:41 8:39 11:23 13:48, II Co 6:10 7:7 13:9, Phl 2:17, 28, Col 2:5, I Th 5:16, I Pe 4:13, III Jn 3; χ. καὶ ἀγαλλιᾶσθαι, Mt 5:12; κ. σκιρτᾶν, Lk 6:23; opp. to κλαίειν, Ro 12:15, I Co 7:30; to κλαίειν κ. θρηνεῖν Jo 16:20; to λύπην ἔχειν, Jo 16:22; c. cogn. acc, χ. χαρὰν μεγάλην, Mt 2:10; χαρᾷ χ. (B1., § 38, 3; Dalman, Words, 34 f.), Jo 3:29; ἡ χαρὰ ᾗ χαίρομεν, I Th 3:9; c. prep. (Bl., 38, 2), ἐπί, c. dat. (simple dat. in cl.), Mt 18:13, Lk 1:14 13:17, Ac 15:31, Ro 16:19, I Co 13:6 16:17, II Co 7:13, Re 11:10; διά, Jo 3:29 11:15, I Th 3:9; ἐν, Phl 1:18; ἀπό, II Co 2:3; c. acc (Dem.), Phl 2:18; seq. ὅτι, Jo 14:28, II Co 7:9 7:16, II Jn 4; ἐν τούτῳ ὅτι, Lk 10:20; c. dat., Ro 12:1; ἐν κυρίῳ, Phl 4:10; In salutations, imperat., χαῖρε, χαίρετε,; at meeting, hail: Mt 26:49 27:29, Mk 15:18, Lk 1:28, Jo 19:3; pl., Mt 28:9; so χχαίρειν λέγω, to give greeting, II Jn 11; in letters, χαίρειν (sc. λέγει; 81, 1), greeting: Ac 15:23 23:26 Ja 1:1; at parting, farewell: II Co 13:11; on other occasions, be of good cheer: ἐν κυρίῳ, Phl 3:1 4:4 (cf. συν-χαίρω).†
to slacken, loosen; to let loose, let go; to lower, let down: c. acc rei, Mk 2:4, Lk 5:4-5, Ac 9:25 27:17, 30; c. acc pers. (cf. Je, l.c.), pass., II Co 11:33.†
a Chaldæan: γῆ Χαλδαίων, Ac 7:4.†
hard; hard to do or deal with, difficult; hard to bear, painful, grievous: καιροί, II Ti 3:1; of persons, hard to deal with, harsh, fierce, savage: Mt 8:28.†
to lead with a bridle; metaph., to bridle, restrain: c. acc, γλῶσσαν, Ja 1:26; σῶμα, Ja 3:2.†
a bridle: Ja 3:3, Re 14:20.†
brazen (i.e. of copper): Re 9:20.†
a worker, in metal, esp. a copper-smith: II Ti 4:14.†
chalcedony, "supposed to denote a green silicate of copper found in the mines near Chalcedon " (Swete): Re 21:19.†
a brazen (copper) vessel: Mk 7:4.†
chalcolibanus, probably "a mixed metal of great brilliance" (Swete): Re 1:15 2:18 (RV, burnished brass).†
copper: I Co 13:1, Re 18:12; by meton., of copper coin, Mt 10:9, Mk 6:8 12:41.†
on or to the ground: Jo 9:6 18:6.†
Canaan: Ac 7:11; γῆ Χ., Ac 13:19.†
Canaanite: γυνή, Mt 15:22.†

joy, delight: Lk 1:14 15:7, 10, Jo 15:11 16:22, 24 17:13, Ac 8:8, II Co 1:24 7:13 8:2, Ga 5:22, Col 1:11, Phl 2:2, I Jn 1:4, II Jn 12; opp. to κατήφεια, Ja 4:9; to λύπη, Jo 16:20; χ. τῆς πίστεως, Phl 1:25; ἀγαλλιᾶσθαι (χαίρειν, q.v.), χαρᾷ, Jo 3:29, I Pe 1:8; χ. ἔχειν, Phm 7; πληροῦν (-οῦσθαι) χαρᾶς, Ac 13:52, Ro 15:13, II Ti 1:4; ποιεῖν χ. μεγάλην, Ac 15:3; ἀπὸ τῆς χ., Mt 13:44, Lk 24:41, Ac 12:14; ἐν χ., Ro 15:32; μετὰ χαρᾶς, Mt 13:20 28:8, Mk 4:16, Lk 8:13 10:17 24:52, Phl 1:4 2:29, He 10:34 13:17; id. seq.πνεύματος ἁγίου, I Th 1:6; χ. ἐν π. ἁ, Ro 14:17; χ. ἐπί, II Co 7:4; διά, I Th 3:9; ὅτι, Jo 16:21; ἵνα, III Jn 4 By meton., of the cause or occasion of joy: Lk 2:10, II Co 1:15, WH, txt., R, mg., Phl 4:1, I Th 2:19-20, He 12:2, Ja 1:2; ἡ χ. τ. κυρίου, Mt 25:21, 23.†
a stamp, impress, mark: Re 13:16-17 14:9, 11 16:2 19:20 20:4 (v. Deiss., BS, 240 ff.); a thing graven: Ac 17:29.†
a tool for graving.; a stamp or impress: as on a coin or seal; metaph., χ. τ. ὑποστάσεως, He 1:3.†
a pointed stake; a palisade or rampart: Lk 19:43.†

to show favour or kindness: c. dat. pers., Ga 3:18.; to give freely, bestow: c. acc et dat., Lk 7:21, Ac 3:14 25:11, 16 27:24, Ro 8:32, I Co 2:12, Phl 1:29 2:9, Phm 22.; In late Gk. (= Lat. condonare), to grant forgiveness, forgive freely: of debt, Lk 7:42-43 (EGT, in l); of sin, II Co 2:7 2:10 12:13, Eph 4:32, Col 2:13 3:13 (cf. DB, ii, 57a).†

objectively, that which causes favourable regard, gracefulness, grace, loveliness of form, graciousness of speech (cl.; Ec 10:12, Si 21:16, al.): Col 4:6; λόγοι τ. χάριτος (gen. qual.), Lk 4:22. Subjectively, on the part of the giver, grace, graciousness, kindness, goodwill, favour: Lk 2:52, Ac 7:10, al.; esp. in NT of the divine favour, grace, with emphasis on its freeness and universality: Lk 1:30, Ac 14:26, Ro 1:7, I Co 1:3, al.; opp. to ὀφείλημα, Ro 4:4, 16; to ἔργα, Ro 11:6; on the part of the receiver, a sense of favour received, thanks, gratitude: Ro 6:17 7:25, al.; χ. ἔχειν, to be thankful, Lk 17:9, I Ti 1:12, al. Objectively, of the effect of grace, a state of grace: Ro 5:2, II Ti 2:1, I Pe 5:12, II Pe 3:18; a proof or gift of grace (cl., a favour): Jo 1:16, Ac 6:8, Ro 1:5, I Co 3:10, II Co 9:8, Ga 2:9, Eph 3:2, I Pe 5:5, 10 al. (For fuller treatment of the NT usage, v. AR, Eph., 221ff.; DB, ii, 254ff.; DCG, i, 686ff.; Cremer, s.v.).

a gift of grace, a free gift, esp. of extra­ordinary operations of the Spirit in the Apostolic Church, but including all spiritual graces and endowments (Lft., Notes, 148 f.): Ro 1:11 5:15-16 6:23 11:29 12:6, I Co 1:7 7:7 12:4 12:9 12:28 12:30-31, II Co 1:11, I Ti 4:14, II Ti 1:6, I Pe 4:10.†

to endow with χάρις (q.v.), i.e.; (a) to make graceful; to make gracious (Sir, l.c.).; In Hellenistic writings (for exx., v. AR, Eph., 227; Lft., Notes, 315),; to cause to find favour; to endue with grace (i.e. divine favour): Lk 1:28, Eph 1:6.†
indecl. (in FlJ., Ant., i, 16, 1, Κάρρα, -ας, ib. 6, 5, Χαρρά, -ᾶς; so LXX: Ge 29:4 E, Ez 27:28 B, elsewhere -άν­Heb. חָרָן), Haran, a town in N.W. Mesopotamia: Ac 7:2, 4.†
a sheet of paper, made of papyrus strips (v. Kennedy, Sources, 42; Milligan, NTD, 10-12; DB, iv, 945 f.): II Jn 12 (Plat., Inscr.).†
a chasm, wide space: Lk 16:26.†

a lip (as in Heb., of the lip as the organ of speech): Mt 15:8, Mk 7:6, Ro 3:13, I Co 14:21, He 13:15, I Pe 3:10 (LXX). Metaph., of things, an edge, brink, etc. (Hom., Hdt., al.): of the sea­shore, He 11:12.†
to expose to winter cold, go into winter quarters.; to drive with storm; pass., to be driven with storm, tempest-tossed: Ac 27:18.†
winter-flowing; as subst., ὁ χ. (sc. ποταμός), a torrent: Jo 18:1.†
winter: Jo 10:22, II Ti 4:21; gen., χειμῶνος, in winter, Mt 24:20, Mk 13:18.; Prop., a winter storm, hence, generally, a storm, tempest: Mt 16:3 (T, WH, R, mg., om.), Ac 27:20.†

the hand: Mt 3:12, Mk 3:1, Lk 6:6, al. mult.; ἡ χ., acting subject, Lk 22:21; pl., Ac 17:25 20:34, I Jo 1:1; τ. ἔργα τῶν χ., Ac 7:41, Re 9:20; ὁ ἀσπασμὸς τ. ἐμῇ χ., I Co 16:21, Col 4:18, II Th 3:17; prepositional phrases, esp. those without art., similar to Heb. constructions (Bl., §32, 4; 40, 9; 46, 9), ἐν χ.; c gen. (Lft., in l.), Ga 3:19; σὺν χ. ἀγγέλου, Ac 7:35; διὰ (τῶν) χειρῶν (διὰ χειρός), Mk 6:2, Ac 5:12 7:25, al.; ἐπὶ χειρῶν, Mt 4:6, Lk 4:11; ellipse of χ. (ἡ δεξία, ἀριστερα; Bl., §44, 1), Mt 6:3, al. By meton., for the power or activity of an individual, Mt 17:22, Mk 9:31, Lk 9:31, Jo 10:39, Ac 12:11, al.; metaph., of the activity or power of God: Lk 1:66 23:46, Jo 10:29, Ac 11:21 13:11, al.
to lead by the hand: Ac 9:8 22:11.†
leading by the hand. As subst., ὁ χ., one to lead by the head, a guide: Ac 13:11.†
written with the hand. As subst., τὸ χ., a handwriting (Inscr., Polyb., al.): metaph., Col 2:14.†
made by hand (i.e. of human handiwork): of temples, Mk 14:58, Ac 7:48 17:24, He 9:11, 24; of circumcision, Eph 2:11.†
to vote by stretching out the hand in the Athenian ἐκκλησία (Luc., Plut.).; to appoint:; by vote, II Co 8:19; without vote, Ac 14:23 (v. Rackham, in l) (cf. προχειροτονέω).†
worse: Mt 9:16 12:45 27:64, Mk 2:21, Lk 11:26, Jo 5:14, I Ti 5:8, He 10:29, II Pe 2:20; εἰς (ἐπὶ) τὸ χεῖρον, Mk 5:26, II Ti 3:13.†
Cherubim: He 9:6 (cf. Ex 25:17 (18), al.; v. DB, i, 377 ff.).†

a widow: Mt 23:13 (Rec., R, mg.), Mk 12:40-43, Lk 2:37 4:25 7:12 18:3, 5 20:47 21:2-3, Ac 6:1 9:39, 41, I Co 7:8, I Ti 5:3-5 5:11 5:16, Ja 1:27; γυνὴ χ., Lk 4:26; of one of an ordo viduarum (v. CGT, in l), I Ti 5:9; metaph., of a city forsaken, Re 18:7.†

a chiliarch, the commander of a thousand, esp. a Roman military tribune, the commander of a cohort: Jo 18:12, Ac 21:31-33, 37 22:24-29 23:10, 15 23:17-19, 22 24:7, 22 25:23; more generally, of officers of similar rank, Mk 6:21, Re 6:15 19:18 (v., DB, i, 352b; DCG, i, 271a, 307a).†
the number one thousand, a thousand: Lk 14:31, Ac 4:4, I Co 10:8, Re 5:11 7:4-8 11:13 14:1, 3 21:16.†
Chios, an island in Ægean Sea: Ac 20:15.†

the garment worn next the skin (though two tunics were sometimes worn, v. Swete, Mk., 117), a tunic: Mt 10:10, Mk 6:9 14:63, Lk 3:11 9:3, Ju 23; dieting. from ἱμάτιον (q.v.), Mt 5:40, Lk 6:29, Jo 19:23, Ac 9:39 (v. DCG, i, 338, 340, 499)
snow: Mt 28:3, Re 1:14.†
a chlamys, or short cloak worn over the χιτών (q.v.): Mt 27:28, 31 (v. Tr., Syn., § 1).†
to jest, mock, jeer: Ac 17:32.†
warm, tepid; metaph., of persons, luke-warm: Re 3:16.†
Chloe: I Co 1:11.†
pale green: χόρτος, Mk 6:39, Re 8:7; πᾶν χ., Re 9:4; pale: ἵππος, Re 6:8.†
six hundred and sixty-six (L, mg., R, mg., six hundred and sixteen), the mystical number of the Beast: Re 13:18 (on the interpretation, v. Swete, Ap., 172 f.).†
earthy, made of dust: I Co 15:47-49 (v. Field, Notes, 179 f.).†
a chænix, a dry measure of rather less than a quart: Re 6:6 (EV, measure).†
to be melancholy mad (Aristoph.).; = χολοῦμαι, to be angry: c. dat. pers., Jo 7:23.†
gall: Mt 27:34 (here prob. = myrrh, cf. Mk 15:23, v. Swete, in l; DCG, i, 634); metaph., Ac 8:23.†
Chorazin, a town of Galilee: Mt 11:21, Lk 10:13.†
to lead a χορός (v. LS, s.v.).; to defray the cost of a χορός.; In late writers, metaph., c. acc (v. M, Pr., 65), to supply, furnish abundantly: II Co 9:10, I Pe 4:11 (Polyb., al.).†
a dance: pl., Lk 15:26.†

prop., of animals (v. Lft. on Phl 4:12), to feed, fatten: Re 19:21; in late Gk. (Kennedy, Sources, 82, 156), of persons, to fill or satisfy with food: c. acc pers., Mt 15:33; pass., Mt 14:20 15:37, Mk 6:42 7:27 8:8, Lk 9:17, Jo 6:26, Ja 2:16; opp. to πεινᾶν, Phl 4:12; c. gen. rei, Mk 8:4; ἀπό, Lk 16:21; ἐκ, Lk 15:16, WH, txt.,; metaph., Mt 5:6, Lk 6:21.†
fodder (Polyb., Plut., al.): pl., Ac 7:11 (RV, sustenance).†
an enclosure, a feeding place (Hom.).; food, esp. for cattle, grass: Mt 13:26 14:19, Mk 4:28 6:39, Lk 12:28, Jo 6:10, I Co 3:12, Ja 1:10-11, I Pe 1:24 (LXX), Re 9:4; χ. χλωρός, Mk 6:39, Re 8:7.†
Chuzas (EV, Chuza): Lk 8:3.†
earth, soil.; In later writers (Pint., LXX), = κονιορτός, dust: Mk 6:11, Re 18:19.†

to use, make use of: c. dat. (cf. M, Pr., 64, 158), Ac 27:17, I Co 9:12 9:15, I Ti 1:8 5:23; μᾶλλον χρῆσαι (i.e. the opportunity; v. M, Pr., 247), I Co 7:21; as some­times in late writers (cf. M, Pr., 64; Lft., Notes, 233), c. acc, I Co 7:31; of feelings, etc., to exercise, shew: II Co 1:17 3:12; c. adv., ἀποτόμως, to deal sharply, II Co 13:10; c. dat. pers. (cl.), to treat, deal with, Ac 27:3.†
to lend: Lk 11:5.†

need, necessity: Ac 28:10, Tit 3:14; πρὸς οἰκοδομὴν τῆς χ. (RV, txt., for edifying as the need may be; but v. Field, Notes, 192), Eph 4:29; ἕστι χ., Lk 10:42, He 7:11; χ. ἔχειν, c. gen., Mt 6:8 21:3, Mk 11:3, Lk 9:11 15:7 19:31, 34 22:71, Jo 13:29, I Co 12:21 12:24, I Th 4:12, He 10:36, Re 21:23 22:5; seq. τοῦ, c. inf. (Bl., § 71, 3), He 5:12; absol. (sc. gen.), Ac 2:45 4:35; c. gen. pers., Mt 9:12 26:65, Mk 2:17 14:63, Lk 5:31; c. inf. (Bl., § 69, 5), Mt 3:14 14:16, Jo 13:10, I Th 1:8 4:9; seq. ἵνα, Jo 16:30, I Jn 2:27; absol., Mk 2:25, Eph 4:28, I Jn 3:17; οὐδὲν χ. ἔχειν, Re 3:17; ἡ χ., c. gen. subjc., Phl 2:25 4:16, 19; pl., Ac 20:34, Ro 12:13.; matter, business (so esp. in late writers, Polyb., al.; I Mac 12:45, al.): Ac 6:3.†
a debtor: Lk 7:41 16:5.†
it is necessary: Ja 3:10 (cf. δεῖ.).†
to need, have need of: c. gen. rei, Mt 6:32, Lk 11:8 12:30, II Co 3:1; c. gen. pers. seq. ἐν, Ro 16:2.†

a thing that one uses or needs (and generally, a matter, event, business); hence in pl.,; wealth, riches: οἱ τά χ. ἔχοντες, Mk 10:23-24, Lk 18:24; money: Ac 8:18, 20 24:26; sing. (rare in cl.) of a special sum of money, Ac 4:37.†

to transact business, hence, to consult, deliberate (Thuc., Dem., al.); hence in later writers,; to make answer (esp. of offcial pronounce­ments by magistrates, etc.; in π. of the royal reply to an ἔντευξις, q.v.; cf. Deiss., BS, 122); of an answer by an oracle (Died., Plut., al.); in FlJ, LXX and NT, of divine communications, to instruct, admonish, warn: pass. (Bl., § 54, 3), Mt 2:22, He 8:5 11:7 12:25; c. inf. (Bl., § 69,4; 70, 3; 72, 5), Mt 2:12, Lk 2:26, Ac 10:22; to assume a name (as in business), be called (Polyb., al.): Ac 11:26, Ro 7:3 (gnomic fut.; cf. Burton, § 69).†
a divine response, an oracle: Ro 11:4 (Xen., Plat., al.).†
useful: II Ti 2:14.†
use: in a sexual sense, Ro 1:26; c. gen. obj., θηλείας, Ro 1:27 (for exx., v. Thayer, s.v.).†
to be kind: I Co 13:4 (eccl.).†
fair speaking: in bad sense, Ro 16:18 (in good sense also, eccl.).†

serviceable, good; of things, good, pleasant: of food (as often in cl.), οἶνος, Lk 5:39; ζυγός, Mt 11:30 (EV, easy); in ethical sense, ἤθη, I Co 15:33; of persons, good, kind, gracious: Eph 4:32; of God, Lk 6:35, I Pe 2:3; τ. χρηστὸν (= ἡ χρηστότης) τοῦ θεοῦ, Ro 2:4. †
goodness, excellence, uprightness: Ro 3:12 (LXX). goodness of heart, kindness: Ro 2:4, II Co 6:6, Ga 5:22, Col 3:12, Tit 3:4; seq. ἐπί, c. acc pers., Eph 2:7; id., opp. to ἀποτομία, Ro 11:22.
later form of χρῖμα (Æsch., al.),; an anointing, unction (the result of the action χρίειν; ICC, in l; but cf. Westc., in l, for the view that the oil, not the act, is meant): I Jn 2:20 Jn 2:27.†
a Christian, the name first given to the disciples by pagan gentiles at Antioch: Ac 11:26 26:28, I Pe 4:16 (v. reff. in Thayer, s.v.; also DB, i, 384).†

1. as adj., of things, anointing, to be used as ointment (Æsch., Eur., al.; τ. ἔλαιον τὸ χ., Le 21:10); of persons, anointed (ὁ ἰερεὺς ὁ χ., Le 4:5; οἱ χ. ἰευρεῖς, II Mac 1:10): ὁ χ. τοῦ κυρίου or Θεοῦ (I Ki 2:10, Ps 2:2, al.), of the Messiah (Aram., מְשִׁיחָא; cf. Dalman, Words, 289 ff.), Lk 2:11, 26 Jo 1:41, Ac 2:36 4:26, al. As subst., ὁ Χριστός, the Messiah, the Christ: Mt 2:4, Mk 8:29, Lk 2:11, Jo 1:20, Ac 2:31, Ro 7:4, al.; Ἰησοῦς, Mk 1:1, Jo 1:17, Ac 2:38, al.; Χ. Ἰησοῦς, Mt 1:18, WH, mg. Ac 5:42, Ro 6:3, al.; Χ. κύριος, Lk 2:11; Ἰησοῦς Χ. ὁ κύριος, Ac 15:26, Ro 1:7, al.

to anoint (Hom., al.); In NT, metaph., of God's anointing,; Christ: Ac 4:27; c. inf., Lk 4:18 (LXX); c. dupl. acc (v. B1., § 34, 4), He 1:9 (LXX); πνεύματι ἁγίῳ, Ac 10:38; Christians: II Co 1:21 (cf. Westc., Epp. Jo., 73) (cf. ἐν-, ἐπι-Χριω).†; SYN: v.s. ἀλείφω
to spend or take time, to tarry, linger, delay: Mt 24:48 25:5, He 10:37; seq. ἐν, c. dat. loc., Lk 1:21; c. inf., Lk 12:45.†

time (a space of time, whether long or short; cf. Lft., Notes, 70): Mt 2:7, Mk 9:21, Lk 1:57, Ac 3:21 7:17, 23 13:18 17:30 27:9, He 11:32, I Pe 1:17 4:3, Re 10:6; στιγμὴ χρόνου, Lk 4:5; πλήρωμα τοῦ χ., Ga 4:4; ποιεῖν χ., Ac 15:33 18:23; βιῶσαι, I Pe 4:2; διδόναι, Re 2:21; pl., χ. καὶ (ἢ) καιροί (Lft., l.c.), Ac 1:7, I Th 5:1; ἐπ' ἐσχάτου τῶν χ. (χρόνου), I Pe 1:20, Ju 18; c. prep., ἄχρι, Ac 3:21; διὰ τὸν χ., He 5:12; ἐν χ., Ac 1:6, 21; ἐπὶ (πλείονα) χ., Lk 18:4, Ac 18:20; ἐφ' ὅσον χ., Ro 7:1, I Co 7:39, Ga 4:1; κατὰ τὸν χ., Mt 2:16; μετὰ τολὺν (τοσοῦτον) χ., Mt 25:19, He 4:7; πρὸ χ. αἰωςίων, II Ti 1:9, Tit 1:2, instr. dat. of extension of time (v. M, Pr., 75, 148; Deiss., LAE, 206), Lk 8:27, 29 Jo 14:9, Ac 8:11, Ro 16:25; acc, of duration of time, Mk 2:19, Lk 20:9, Jo 5:6 7:33 12:35 14:9, Ac 14:3, 28 19:22 20:18, I Co 16:7, Re 6:11.†
to spend time: Ac 20:16.†

a piece of gold, gold: I Co 3:12, He 9:4, I Pe 1:7, Re 3:18 21:18, 21; of golden ornaments, I Ti 2:9 (WH, txt., RV), I Pe 3:3, Re 17:4 18:16 (WH, txt., R); of gold coin, money, Ac 3:6 20:33, I Pe 1:18.†
with a gold ring: Ja 2:2.†
a chrysolite (on its identification, v. Swete, Ap., 288 f.; DB, iv, 620): Re 21:20.†
a chrysoprase (v. Swete, Ap., 289): Re 21:20.†
gold: Mt 2:11, Re 9:7; of golden ornaments, Mt 23:16-17, I Ti 2:9 (Rec., WH, mg.), Ja 5:3, Re 17:4 (Rec., WH, mg.) Re 18:12, 16 (Rec., WH, mg.); of images, Ac 17:29; of gold coin, Mt 10:9.†
to gild, cover with gold: pass., c. dat., χρυσίῳ (pleonast., cf. Ex 26:37), Re 17:4 18:16.†
in cl. rare in prose, the surface of the body, skin: Ac 19:12.†

most freq. in cl., a space, place.; land, i.e.; a land, country, region: Mt 12:2, Mk 5:10 6:55, Lk 2:8 15:13-15 19:12, Jo 11:54, Ac 13:49 27:27; χ. Γαλατική, Ac 16:6 18:23; Τραχωνίτιδος, Lk 3:1; τ. Ἰουδαίας, Ac 26:20; τ. Ἰουδαίων, Ac 10:39; pl., τῆς Ἰουδαίας κ. Σαμαρείας, Ac 8:1; Γεργεσηνῶν (Γερασηνῶν, Γαδαρηνῶν) Mt 8:28, Mk 5:1, Lk 8:26; ἐν χ. καὶ σκιᾷ θανάτου, Mt 4:16; land, property: Lk 12:16; the country, opp. to the town; so in pl., Lk 21:21, Jo 4:35, Ja 5:4.†

Intrans.,; to make room, give way, retire, pass: seq. εἰς, Mt 15:17; metaph. (EV, come), εἰς μετάνοιαν, II Pe 3:9.; to go forward, advance, progress (Plat., Polyb., al.) ὁ λόγος ὁ ἐμὸς οὐ χωρεῖ. ἐν ὑμῖν, Jo 8:37 (R, txt., hath not free course; R, mg., hath no place, for WH. cf. Field, Notes, 94 f.).; Trans., to have space for holding, to hold: Mk 2:2 (cf. Ge, l.c.), Jo 21:25; of measures (1Ki, 2Ch, ll. c.), Jo 2:6. Metaph., of having or making room in mind or heart: Mt 19:11-12 (EV, receive), II Co 7:2 (R, txt., open your hearts; mg., make room) (cf. ἀνα-, ἀπο-, ἐκ-, ὑπο-χωρέω).†

to separate, divide, put asunder: c. acc rei, opp. to συζεύγνυμι Mt 19:6, Mk 10:9; c. acc pers., seq. ἀπό (Wi 1:3), Ro 8:35, 39; pf. pass ptcp., He 7:26.; In late writers, mid. and 1 aor pass., to separate oneself, depart: Phm 15; seq. ἀπό Ac 1:4, ἐκ, Ac 18:1-2; of divorce (polyb., al.), I Co 7:10-11 7:15 (cf. ἀπο-, δια-χωρίζω).†
a place, region.; an estate, property, piece of land: Mt 26:36, Mk 14:32, Jo 4:5, Ac 1:18-19 4:34 5:3, 8 28:7.†

separately, apart: Jo 20:7.; As prep., c. gen.,; separate from, apart from, without (practically equiv. to ἄνευ; v. Field, Notes, 103): Mt 13:34, Mk 4:34, Lk 6:49, Jo 1:3 15:5, Ro 3:21, 28 4:6 7:8-9 10:14, I Co 4:8 11:11, II Co 12:3, Eph 2:12, Phl 2:14, I Ti 2:8 5:21, Phm 14, He 4:15 7:7, 20 9:7, 18 9:22, 28 10:25 11:6, 40 12:8, 14 (οὗ χωρίς; v. Bl., § 82, 3), Ja 2:18, 20 2:26; besides: Mt 14:21 15:38, II Co 11:28.†
(Lat. corus), the N.W. wind: Ac 27:12.†

to pull, twitch, twang (as a bowstring, etc.; Æsch., Eur., al.), hence,; absol.,; to play a stringed instrument with the fingers (Hdt., Plat., al.); later, to sing to a harp, sing psalms (LXX); in NT, to sing a hymn, sing praise: Ja 5:13; c. dat. pers., Ro 15:9 (LXX), Eph 5:19; dat. instr., I Co 14:15.†

a striking, twitching with the fingers (Eur., al.), hence, a striking of musical strings (Æsch., a1.), and hence in later writers,; a sacred song sung to musical accompaniment, a psalm (LXX): I Co 14:26, Eph 5:19, Col 3:16; of OT psalms, Lk 24:44, Ac 13:33; βίβλος ψαλμῶν, Lk 20:42, Ac 1:20.†
a false brother: of professing Christians, II Co 11:26, Ga 2:4.†
a false apostle: II Co 11:13.†
lying, false, untrue (of persons and things): Re 2:2; μάρτυρες, Ac 6:13; as subst., ὁ ψ., a liar: Re 21:8.†
a false teacher: II Pe 2:1.†
speaking falsely, lying: I Ti 4:2 (Aristoph., Polyb., al.).†
to bear false witness: Mt 19:18, Mk 10:19, Lk 18:20 (LXX); seq. κατά, c. gen. pers., Mk 14:56-57 (Xen., Plat., al.).†
false witness: Mt 15:19 26:59.†
a false witness: Mt 26:60; c. gen. obj. (v. WM, § 30, 1a), I Co 15:15.†
a false prophet (= cl. ψευδόμαντις): Mt 7:15 24:11, 24, Mk 13:22 (v. Swete, in l), Lk 6:26, Ac 13:6, II Pe 2:1, I Jn 4:1, Re 16:13 19:20 20:10 †

a falsehood, untruth, lie: Re 14:15; opp. to ἡ ἀλήθεια, Jo 8:44, Ro 1:25, Eph 4:25, II Th 2:11, I Jn 2:21; to τὸ ἀληθές, I Jn 2:27; ποιεῖν ψ., Re 21:27 22:15; ἐν πάσῃ δυνάμει κ. σημείοις κ. τέρασιν ψεύδους (gen. qual., v. M, Th., 104; and on the meaning and construction, v. also ICC, in l), II Th 2:9.†
a false Christ or Messiah, "a pretender to the Messianic office" (Swete, Mk., 309; cf. also Tr., Syn., § xxx): Mt 24:24, Mk 13:22 (cf. ἀντίχριστος).†

absol., to lie: He 6:18, I Jn 1:6, Re 3:9; οὐ ψεύδομαι, Ro 9:1, II Co 11:31, Ga 1:20, I Ti 2:7 c. dat. pers. (Ps 18:45, Jo 5:12, al.), Ac 5:4; seq. εἰς, Col 3:9; κατά, Ja 3:14 (Hort, in l).; Like act., c. acc, to deceive by lies (Æsch., al.): Ac 5:3.†
under a false name, falsely called: I Ti 6:20 (Æsch., Plut., a1.).†
a lie, falsehood: Ro 3:7 (Plat., Plut. al.).†

to feel or grope about; c. acc, to feel about for, search after: metaph., of seeking God, Ac 17:27.; to feel, touch, handle: c. acc pers., Lk 24:39, I Jn 1:1; προσεληλύθατε ψηλαφωμένῳ (ὄρει ?), He 12:18 (R, txt., a mount that might be touched; mg., a palpable and kindled fire; v. Westc., in l).†

to count (prop., with pebbles), reckon, calculate: τ. δαπάνην, Lk 14:28; τ. ἀριθμόν (i.e. calculate the number's meaning), Re 13:18 (in cl. chiefly mid., to vote by casting a pebble; cf. συγ-κατα-, συμ-φηφίζω).†
a small smooth stone, a pebble: ψ. λευκή (for suggestions as to the meaning, v. Swete, in l), Re 2:17.; From the use of pebbles in voting, a vote: Ac 26:10.†
a whispering; of secret slander, II Co 12:20 (Plut.); of a murmured enchantment, Ec, l.c.†
a whisperer (as epithet of Hermes, Dem., 1358, 6): in bad sense, Ro 1:30.†; Syn.: καταλάλος, q.v
dimin. of ψίξ,; a crumb: Mt 15:27, Mk 7:28.†

breath (Lat. anima), breath of life, life (Hom., al.; in Arist., of the vital principle): Mt 6:25, Mk 3:4 10:45, Lk 12:22, Jo 10:11, Ac 20:10, 24 II Co 1:23, Phl 2:30, I Th 2:8, al. the soul, as the seat of the will, desires and affections: Mt 26:38, Mk 12:30 (LXX) 14:34, Lk 1:46, Jo 10:24, Ac 14:2, Phl 1:27, al.; ἐκ ψυχῆς, from the heart, heartily: Eph 6:6, Col 3:23; as a periphrasis for person or self (freq. in translation from Semitic originals, v. M, Pr., 87; Robinson, Gospels, 113ff.; but also freq. in cl., v. LS, s.v. II, 2; Edwards, Lex., App. A.): Mt 11:29, Mk 8:36, Ac 2:41, Ro 2:9, I Pe 3:20, al.; πᾶσα ψ., Ac 2:43 3:23 (LXX), Ro 13:1; ψ. ζῶσα (ζωῆς), I Co 15:45, Re 16:3; as the object of divine grace and eternal salvation: He 13:17, Ja 1:21 5:20, I Pe 1:9, 22 2:11 4:19, III Jo 2.

of the ψυχή (as the lower part of the immaterial in man), EV, natural: opp. to πνευματικός, I Co 2:14 15:44 15:46; πνεῦμα μὴ ἔχοντες (EV, sensual; R, mg., natural or animal; better perhaps, of the mind; v. infr.), Ju 19; with ἐπίγειος, δαιμονιώδης, opp. to ἄνωθεν κατερχομένη (σοψία), of the mind (Hort, in l), Ja 3:15†
cold: sc. ὕδωρ (cf. Theogn., 263; Hdt., ii, 37), Mt 10:42; metaph., of indifferent persons, Re 3:15-16 †
to breathe, blow; hence, to make cool. Pass., to grow cool: metaph., Mt 24:12.†

to feed with morsels (as children or the sick; Hippocr.), hence, generally, in late writers, to feed, nourish: c. acc pers., Ro 12:20 (LXX); c. acc rei, to give out for food, I Co 13:3 (cf. WM, § 32, 4an; for dupl. acc, cf. Nu 11:4, Si 15:3, al.).†
dimin. of ψωμός, a fragment, morsel: Jo 13:26-27, 30.†
to rub: Lk 6:1.†
omega, ô, the twenty-fourth and last letter. As a numeral, ω' = 800, ω, = 800,000. As a symbol of the last (= τὸ τέλος), τὸ Ὦ (Rec. Ω, L, ὦ, T, ω), the Omega: Re 1:8 21:6 22:13 (cf. Ἄλφα).†

interj., c. vocat.,; O; in simple address (less freq. than in cl.; M, Pr., 71); Ac 1:1 18:14 27:21, Ro 2:1, 3 9:20, I Ti 6:20; expressing reproof, Ja 2:20; in exclamations of surprise, etc.: Mt 15:28, Lk 24:25, Ac 13:10, Ro 11:33, Ga 3:1; c. nom. (Bl., § 33, 4), Mt 17:17, Mk 9:19, Lk 9:41.†

prop., of manner, so (Hom., al.). In poets (rarely) and late writers, of place, hither (BL, §25, 2): Mt 8:29, Mk 11:3, Lk 9:41, Jo 6:25, al.; ἕως ὧδε, Lk 23:5; here: Mt 12:6, Mk 9:1, Lk 9:33, Jo 6:9, al.; τὰ ὧδε, Col 4:9; opp. to ἐκεῖ, He 7:8; ὧδε . . . ἢ ὧδε (ἐκεῖ), Mt 24:23, Mk 13:21; metaph., here (i.e. in this circumstance or connection), I Co 4:2, Re 13:10, 18 14:12 17:9.
a song, ode, whether sad or joyful; in LXX and NT always in praise of God or Christ: Re 5:9 14:3 15:3; ᾠ πνευματικαί Eph 5:19, Col 3:16.†
a birth pang, travail pain: I Th 5:3; metaph., of extreme suffering, Mt 24:8, Mk 13:8; ὠδῖνες θανάτου (Ps 18:4 מָוֶת חֶבֶל), Ac 2:24.†
to have birthpangs, to travail: Ga 4:27 (LXX), Re 12:2; metaph., Ga 4:19 (cf. συν-ωδίνω).†
the shoulder: Mt 23:4, Lk 15:5.†
to buy: ὠνήσατο (= cl. ἐπρίατο; v. Rutherford, NPhr., 210 ff.; Veitch, s.v.), c. gen. pret., Ac 7:16.†
an egg: Lk 11:12.†

any time or period fixed by nature, esp. a season (Hom., Hdt., Plat., al.). A part of the day, and esp. a twelfth part of day or night, an hour: Mt 24:36, Mk 13:32, Ac 10:3, al.; accus. in ans. to "when"? (M, Pr., 63, 215; Bl., §34, 8), Jo 4:52, Ac 10:3, 30 I Co 15:30, Re 3:3; acc. of duration, Mt 20:12 26, Mk 14:37; inexactly, πρὸς ὥραν, for a season, for a time, Jo 5:35, II Co 7:8, Ga 2:5; πρὸς καιρὸν ὥρας, for a short season (ICC, in l.), I Th 2:17. A definite point of time, time, hour: Mt 26:45; c. gen. rei, Lk 1:10 14:17, Re 3:10, al.; c. gen. pers., Lk 22:53, Jo 2:4 7:30, al.; ἡ ἄρτι ὥρα, I Co 4:11; ἐσχάτη ὥ., I Jo 2:18; seq. ὅτε, Jo 4:21, 23 5:25 16:25; ἵνα, Jo 12:23, al.; c. acc. et inf., Ro 13:11 (cf. DB, ext., 475b 476b).
seasonable, timely, esp. of ripe fruits; hence, blooming, beautiful (both of things and persons): Mt 23:27, Ac 3:2, 10, Ro 10:15 (LXX, ὥρα).†
of animals (also of men, Hdt., al.), to roar, howl: λέων, I Pe 5:8.†

As relat. adv. of manner, as, like as, just as, even as; with a demonstrative, like οὕτως, expressed or understood: οὕτως . . . ὡς, Mk 4:26, I Co 3:15, Eph 5:28, Ja 2:12, al.; ὡς . . . οὕτως, Ac 8:32, I Co 7:17, al.; elliptically (sc. οὕτως, οὕτω), c. nom., Mt 6:29, al.; c. acc., Mt 19:19, Mk 12:31, al.; c. prep., Mt 26:55, Mk 14:48, Lk 22:52, Jo 7:10, al.; c. verb., Jo 15:6, II Co 3:1, Eph 2:3, I Th 5:6, al.; c. ptcp. (the ptcp. however not having the special force wh. it has in cl.; v. Bl., §73, 5; 74, 6), Mt 7:29, Mk 1:22, He 13:17, al.; freq implying opinion or belief, Ro 9:32; so esp, c. gen. absol., I Co 4:18, II Co 5:20, I Pe 4:12, II Pe 1:3. Before numerals, about, nearly: Mk 5:13, Jo 1:40, Ac 5:7, al. Before adjectives and adverbs, how: Ro 10:15 11:33, I Th 2:10; c. superl., ὡς τάχιστα, as quickly as possible, Ac 17:15. As conjunction; temporal, as, when, since: Mk 9:21 14:72, Lk 1:23, Jo 2:9, al.; while, when, as long as: Lk 12:58, Jo 12:36, Ga 6:10 (Field, Notes, 191); ὡς ἄν (M, Pr., 167, and v.s. ἄν), Ro 15:24, I Co 11:34, Phl 2:23. Final, in order that; c. inf., in order to (M, Pr., 204n), Lk 9:52, Ac 20:24, He 7:9.
hosanna: Mt 21:9, Mk 11:9-10, Jo 12:13; τ. υἱῷ Δανείδ, Mt 21:9, 15.†

strengthened for ὡς (in Hom, at the beginning of a clause, in the form ὣς δ' αὔτως, later in one word), in like manner, just so, likewise: Mt 20:5 21:30, 36 25:17, Mk 14:31, Lk 13:5 20:31, Ro 8:26, I Ti 5:25, Tit 2:6; with verb to be supplied from context, Mk 12:21, Lk 22:20, I Co 11:25, I Ti 2:9 3:8 3:11, Tit 2:3.†

as if, .as it were, like as, like: Mt 3:16 9:36, Ac 2:3 6:15, Ro 6:13, He 1:12; γίνεσθαι (φαίνεσθαι) ὡσεί, Mk 9:26, Lk 22:44 ([WH] R, mg., om.), Lk 24:11; in calculation, and with numbers, about: Mt 14:21, Lk 3:23 9:14, 28 22:41, 59 23:44, Ac 2:41 10:3 19:7; ὡσεὶ λίθου βολήν, Lk 22:41.†
Hosea: Ro 9:25.†
just as, even as: Mt 6:2 20:28, Ac 3:17, I Co 8:5, I Th 5:3 al.; in protasis, with οὕτως (καί) in apodosis: Mt 12:40, Lk 17:24, Jo 5:21, Ro 5:19, Ga 4:29, Ja 2:26, al
as, as it were: I Co 15:8.†

consecutive particle,; c. infin., expressing result, so as to: Mt 8:24 12:22, Mk 1:27, Lk 5:7, Ac 1:19, Ro 7:6, I Co 1:7, He 13:6, al.; of a designed result, Mt 10:1, Lk 4:29, al.; preceded by οὕτως, Ac 14:1; by τοσοῦτος, Mt 15:33.; C. indic.,; so that: Ga 2:13, preceded by οὕτως, Jo 3:16; so then, therefore: Mt 12:12, Mk 2:28, Ro 7:4, I Co 3:7, Ga 3:9, al.; so then, therefore: c. subjc., I Co 5:8; c. imperat., I Co 3:21 4:5, Phl 2:12 I Th 4:18, I Pe 4:19, al
= ὠτίον (q.v.),; the ear: Mk 14:47, Jo 18:10.†
assistance, help (Thuc., Plat., al.).; profit, advantage, benefit (Hdt., Plat., al.): Ro 3:1, Ju 16.†

to help, benefit, do good, profit: absol., Ro 2:25; οὐδέν (do no good; v. Field, Notes, 21), Mt 27:24, Jo 6:63 12:19; c. acc pers., He 4:2; c. dupl. acc, Mk 8:36, I Co 14:6, Ga 5:2; pass., He 13:9; c. acc, Mt 15:5 16:26, Mk 5:26 7:11, Lk 9:25, I Co 13:3.†
useful, serviceable, profitable: c. dat. commod., Tit 3:8; seq. πρός, c. acc, I Ti 4:8, II Ti 3:16.†
